text: CONCLUSIONS: Anti-PD-1 antibody produced objective responses in approximately one in four to one in five patients with non-small-cell lung cancer, melanoma, or renal-cell cancer; the adverse-event profile does not appear to preclude its use.
title: Safety, activity, and immune correlates of anti-PD-1 antibody in cancer.

text: Preliminary data suggest a relationship between PD-L1 expression on tumor cells and objective response.
title: Safety, activity, and immune correlates of anti-PD-1 antibody in cancer.

text: (Funded by Bristol-Myers Squibb and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00730639.
title: Safety, activity, and immune correlates of anti-PD-1 antibody in cancer.
Safety, activity, and immune correlates of anti-PD-1 antibody in cancer.

text: PURPOSE: G proteins mediate signaling from cell surface receptors to specific intracellular proteins.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: In vitro cancer cell line studies revealed a link between the Galphas protein and proapoptotic processes.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: We have recently shown that TT genotypes of the GNAS1 T393C polymorphism display increased transcription of Galphas and a more favorable clinical course in bladder and colorectal cancer patients compared both with TC or CC genotypes.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: In the present study, 150 patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma surgically treated by nephrectomy with curative intent were retrospectively genotyped to elucidate a potential association between T393C genotypes and clinical outcome.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: The C-allele frequency in the renal cell carcinoma patient group was 0.51, which is not significantly different from that of a healthy blood donor group.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Kaplan-Meier curves for tumor progression, development of metastasis, and tumor-related death showed a significant association of the T393C polymorphism with outcome (5-year cancer-specific survival rates: TT, 91%; TC, 81%; CC, 69%; P = 0.015).
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Multivariate Cox proportional analysis of a 10-year follow-up confirmed the T393C polymorphism as an independent prognostic factor in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Homozygous CC patients were at highest risk for progression (hazard ratio, 2.48; P = 0.009) or tumor-related death (hazard ratio, 3.15; P = 0.018) compared with T-allele carriers.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: Our results show that besides tumor stage, lymph node status, and tumor grade, the GNAS1 T393C status is a novel independent host factor for disease progression in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma and provides further evidence for the T393C polymorphism as a general prognostic tumor marker.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism predicts survival in patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: High FLT3-ITD/wildtype (wt) load in FLT3-ITD-mutated AML has been associated with adverse impact on outcome in several studies.
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: To clarify whether FLT3-ITD load as expressed as FLT3-ITD/wt ratio is also relevant in patients with NPM1 mutated AML, we assessed the FLT3-ITD mutation status and FLT3-ITD/wt ratio by fragment analysis in 638 NPM1mut AML (339 females; 299 males; 17.8-88.0 years), and analyzed its prognostic relevance in 355 patients.
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: FLT3-ITD of various length and load were detected in 243/638 cases (38.1%).
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Median EFS (19.3 vs 9.7 months, P<0.001) and median 2-year survival rate (72.0 vs 52.7%, P=0.006) was better in FLT3wt (n=212 with available follow-up data) than FLT3-ITD (n=143).
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: A higher FLT3-ITD/wt ratio as continuous variable was correlated with a shorter EFS (P=0.028).
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: When patients were separated into subgroups according to the FLT3-ITD mutation load, only a FLT3-ITD/wt ratio >/=0.5 conferred an independent adverse impact on EFS and OS, and retained its prognostic significance also in multivariate analysis (P=0.009 for EFS, P=0.008 for OS).
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In conclusion, for risk estimation in NPM1 mutated AML not only the FLT3-ITD status, but also the FLT3-ITD load has to be taken into account.
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: These data might contribute to clinical decision making in AML.
title: Prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD load in NPM1 mutated acute myeloid leukemia.

text: PURPOSE: The tet oncogene family member 2 (TET2) gene was recently identified to be mutated in myeloid disorders including acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: To date, there is increasing evidence for a functional role of TET2 mutations (TET2(mut)) in AML.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: Thus, we explored the frequency, gene-expression pattern, and clinical impact of TET2(mut) in a large cohort of patients with AML in the context of other AML-associated aberrations.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Samples from 783 younger adult patients with AML were analyzed for the presence of TET2(mut) (coding exons 3 to 11), and results were correlated with data from molecular genetic analyses, gene-expression profiling, and clinical outcome.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: RESULTS: In total, 66 TET2(mut) were found in 60 patients (60 of 783 patients; 7.6%), including missense (n = 37), frameshift (n = 16), and nonsense (n = 13) mutations, which, with one exception, were all heterozygous.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: TET2(mut) were not correlated with distinct clinical features or genetic alterations, except for isocitrate dehydrogenase mutations (IDH(mut)) that were almost mutually exclusive with TET2(mut) (P < .001).
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: TET2(mut) were characterized by only a weak gene-expression pattern, which, nevertheless, reflected TET2(mut)-associated biology.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: TET2(mut) did not impact the response to induction therapy and clinical outcome; the combination of patients who exhibited TET2(mut) and/or IDH(mut) revealed shorter overall survival (P = .03), although this association was not independent from known risk factors.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: CONCLUSION: TET2(mut) were identified in 7.6% of younger adult patients with AML and did not impact the response to therapy and survival.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: Mutations were mutually exclusive with IDH(mut), which supported recent data on a common mechanism of action that might obscure the impact of TET2(mut) if compared against all other patients with AML.
title: TET2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML): results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis of the AML study group.

text: AIM: To investigate the impact of KRAS mutation variants on the activity of regorafenib in SW48 colorectal cancer cells.
title: KRAS exon 2 mutations influence activity of regorafenib in an SW48-based disease model of colorectal cancer.

text: MATERIALS & METHODS: Activity of regorafenib was evaluated in isogenic SW48 KRAS wild-type (WT) and mutant cells.
title: KRAS exon 2 mutations influence activity of regorafenib in an SW48-based disease model of colorectal cancer.

text: Subcutaneous xenografts (KRAS WT and G12C mutant variants) in NOD/SCID mice were analyzed to elucidate the effect of regorafenib treatment in vivo.
title: KRAS exon 2 mutations influence activity of regorafenib in an SW48-based disease model of colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Compared with KRAS WT cells, all mutant variants seemed associated with some degree of resistance to regorafenib-treatment in vitro.
title: KRAS exon 2 mutations influence activity of regorafenib in an SW48-based disease model of colorectal cancer.

text: In vivo, activation of apoptosis (TUNEL) and reduction of proliferation (Ki67) after treatment with regorafenib were more pronounced in KRAS WT tumors as compared with G12C variants.
title: KRAS exon 2 mutations influence activity of regorafenib in an SW48-based disease model of colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: In SW48 cells, exon 2 mutations of the KRAS gene may influence antitumor effects of regorafenib.
title: KRAS exon 2 mutations influence activity of regorafenib in an SW48-based disease model of colorectal cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2; also known as ERBB2), was investigated in combination with chemotherapy for first-line treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: METHODS: ToGA (Trastuzumab for Gastric Cancer) was an open-label, international, phase 3, randomised controlled trial undertaken in 122 centres in 24 countries.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: Patients with gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer were eligible for inclusion if their tumours showed overexpression of HER2 protein by immunohistochemistry or gene amplification by fluorescence in-situ hybridisation.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive a chemotherapy regimen consisting of capecitabine plus cisplatin or fluorouracil plus cisplatin given every 3 weeks for six cycles or chemotherapy in combination with intravenous trastuzumab.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: Allocation was by block randomisation stratified by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, chemotherapy regimen, extent of disease, primary cancer site, and measurability of disease, implemented with a central interactive voice recognition system.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: The primary endpoint was overall survival in all randomised patients who received study medication at least once.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01041404.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: FINDINGS: 594 patients were randomly assigned to study treatment (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, n=298; chemotherapy alone, n=296), of whom 584 were included in the primary analysis (n=294; n=290).
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: Median follow-up was 18.6 months (IQR 11-25) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 17.1 months (9-25) in the chemotherapy alone group.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: Median overall survival was 13.8 months (95% CI 12-16) in those assigned to trastuzumab plus chemotherapy compared with 11.1 months (10-13) in those assigned to chemotherapy alone (hazard ratio 0.74; 95% CI 0.60-0.91; p=0.0046).
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: The most common adverse events in both groups were nausea (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, 197 [67%] vs chemotherapy alone, 184 [63%]), vomiting (147 [50%] vs 134 [46%]), and neutropenia (157 [53%] vs 165 [57%]).
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: Rates of overall grade 3 or 4 adverse events (201 [68%] vs 198 [68%]) and cardiac adverse events (17 [6%] vs 18 [6%]) did not differ between groups.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy can be considered as a new standard option for patients with HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: FUNDING: F Hoffmann-La Roche.
title: Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastro-oesophageal junction cancer (ToGA): a phase 3, open-label, randomised controlled trial.

text: On May 14, 2013, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved erlotinib (Tarceva, Astellas Pharma Inc., Northbrook, IL, http://www.us.astellas.com/) for the first-line treatment of patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) whose tumors have epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: This indication for erlotinib was approved concurrently with the cobas EGFR Mutation Test (Roche Molecular Systems, Inc., Basel, Switzerland, http://www.molecular.roche.com), a companion diagnostic test for patient selection.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: The approval was based on clinically important improvements in progression-free survival (PFS) and objective response rate (ORR) and an acceptable toxicity profile demonstrated in a multicenter, open label trial enrolling 174 patients with metastatic NSCLC whose tumors had EGFR mutations as determined by a laboratory-developed test.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: Patients were randomized (1:1) to receive erlotinib (150 mg/day) or platinum-based doublet chemotherapy.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: The primary endpoint was investigator-assessed PFS.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: Secondary endpoints included overall survival (OS) and ORR.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: Superior PFS (hazard ratio [HR] 0.34; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.23, 0.49; p < .001) and ORR (65% vs. 16%) were observed in the erlotinib arm.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: Median PFS was 10.4 months and 5.2 months in the erlotinib and chemotherapy arms, respectively.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: There was no difference in OS (HR 0.93; 95% CI: 0.64, 1.35) with median OS of 22.9 months and 19.5 months in the erlotinib and chemotherapy arms, respectively.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: The most frequent (>/=30%) adverse reactions in the erlotinib-treated patients were rash, diarrhea, asthenia, cough, dyspnea, and decreased appetite.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: The most frequent (>/=5%) grade 3 and 4 adverse reactions were rash and diarrhea.
title: U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval summary: Erlotinib for the first-line treatment of metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with epidermal growth factor receptor exon 19 deletions or exon 21 (L858R) substitution mutations.

text: PURPOSE: Neratinib is an oral, irreversible pan-ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: The efficacy and safety of neratinib were evaluated in two cohorts of patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer-those with and those without prior trastuzumab treatment-in an open-label, multicenter, phase II trial.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients in the two cohorts (prior trastuzumab, n = 66; no prior trastuzumab, n = 70) received oral neratinib 240 mg once daily.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: The primary end point was the 16-week progression-free survival (PFS) rate for the evaluable population (prior trastuzumab, n = 63; no prior trastuzumab, n = 64), as assessed by independent review.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: The 16-week PFS rates were 59% for patients with prior trastuzumab treatment and 78% for patients with no prior trastuzumab treatment.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: Median PFS was 22.3 and 39.6 weeks, respectively.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: Objective response rates were 24% among patients with prior trastuzumab treatment and 56% in the trastuzumab-naive cohort.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: The most common adverse events were diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and fatigue.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: Diarrhea was the most frequent grades 3 to 4 adverse event, occurring in 30% of patients with prior trastuzumab treatment and in 13% of patients with no prior trastuzumab treatment, which prompted dose reductions in 29% and 4% of patients, respectively, but treatment discontinuation in only one patient.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: No neratinib-related, grades 3 or 4 cardiotoxicity was reported.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Oral neratinib showed substantial clinical activity and was reasonably well tolerated among both heavily pretreated and trastuzumab-naive patients who had advanced, ErbB2-positive breast cancer.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: Diarrhea was the most common adverse effect but was manageable with antidiarrheal agents and dose modification.
title: Neratinib, an irreversible ErbB receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with advanced ErbB2-positive breast cancer.

text: PURPOSE: We examined the prognostic and predictive value of serum human epidermal growth factor 2 (HER2) extracellular domain (sHER2) in patients with advanced breast cancer treated with lapatinib using data from three randomized trials.
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We analyzed sHER2 and tissue HER2 (tHER2) data from 1,902 patients (84%) who were randomly assigned to receive lapatinib or control in the trials EGF30001, EGF30008, and EGF100151.
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: Cox regression analyses were performed to correlate both biomarkers with progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS).
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Median sHER2 levels were 25.1 and 10.1 ng/mL in tHER2-amplified (tHER-positive) and nonamplified (tHER-negative) populations, respectively (r = 0.42 for sHER2-tHER2 correlation).
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: Lapatinib had significant PFS benefit over control (hazard ratio [HR], 0.855; P = .004), but not OS (HR, 0.941; P = .33).
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: Lapatinib PFS benefit is independently predicted by higher sHER2 values (HR per 10-ng/mL increase in sHER2: lapatinib-containing therapies, 1.009 v nonlapatinib-containing therapies, 1.044; P(interaction) < .001) and by positive tHER2 (HR [lapatinib v nonlapatinib]: tHER2 positive, 0.638 v tHER2 negative, 0.940; P(interaction) = .001).
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: Within the tHER2-positive subpopulation (n = 515), higher sHER2 values still independently predicted lapatinib PFS benefit (HR per 10-ng/mL increase in sHER2: lapatinib-containing therapies, 1.017 v nonlapatinib-containing therapies, 1.041; P(interaction) = .008).
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: In control arms (n = 936), higher sHER2 was associated with worse prognosis in multivariable analyses (PFS HR per 10 ng/mL: PFS, 1.024; P < .001; and OS, 1.018; P < .001).
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Higher sHER2 predicts greater PFS benefit with lapatinib independent of tHER2 status.
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: High sHER2 is also independently prognostic for worse survival in patients who received nonlapatinib-containing therapies.
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: The predictive role of sHER2 for other anti-HER2 agents requires further research.
title: Serum Human Epidermal Growth Factor 2 Extracellular Domain as a Predictive Biomarker for Lapatinib Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer.

text: Inhibition of the BRAF(V600E) oncoprotein by the small-molecule drug PLX4032 (vemurafenib) is highly effective in the treatment of melanoma.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: However, colon cancer patients harbouring the same BRAF(V600E) oncogenic lesion have poor prognosis and show only a very limited response to this drug.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: To investigate the cause of the limited therapeutic effect of PLX4032 in BRAF(V600E) mutant colon tumours, here we performed an RNA-interference-based genetic screen in human cells to search for kinases whose knockdown synergizes with BRAF(V600E) inhibition.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: We report that blockade of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) shows strong synergy with BRAF(V600E) inhibition.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: We find in multiple BRAF(V600E) mutant colon cancers that inhibition of EGFR by the antibody drug cetuximab or the small-molecule drugs gefitinib or erlotinib is strongly synergistic with BRAF(V600E) inhibition, both in vitro and in vivo.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: Mechanistically, we find that BRAF(V600E) inhibition causes a rapid feedback activation of EGFR, which supports continued proliferation in the presence of BRAF(V600E) inhibition.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: Melanoma cells express low levels of EGFR and are therefore not subject to this feedback activation.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: Consistent with this, we find that ectopic expression of EGFR in melanoma cells is sufficient to cause resistance to PLX4032.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: Our data suggest that BRAF(V600E) mutant colon cancers (approximately 8-10% of all colon cancers), for which there are currently no targeted treatment options available, might benefit from combination therapy consisting of BRAF and EGFR inhibitors.
title: Unresponsiveness of colon cancer to BRAF(V600E) inhibition through feedback activation of EGFR.

text: The identification of molecular markers, useful for therapeutic decisions in pancreatic cancer patients, is crucial for advances in disease management.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: Gemcitabine, although a cornerstone of current therapy, has limited efficacy.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: RRM1 is a key molecule for gemcitabine efficacy and is also involved in tumor progression.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: We determined in situ RRM1 and excision repair cross complementation group 1 (ERCC1) protein levels in 68 pancreatic cancer patients.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: All had R0 resections without preoperative therapy.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: Protein levels were determined by automated quantitative analysis (AQUA), a fluorescence-based immunohistochemical method.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: The relationship between protein expressions and clinical outcomes, including response to gemcitabine at the time of disease recurrence, was determined.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: Patients with high RRM1 showed significantly better overall survival than patients with low expression (P=0.0196).
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: There was a trend toward better overall survival for patient with high ERCC1 (P=0.0552).
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: When both markers were considered together, patients with both high RRM1 and ERCC1 faired the best in terms of overall and disease-free survival (P=0.0066, P=0.0127).
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: In addition, treatment benefit from gemcitabine in patients with disease recurrence was observed only in patients with low RRM1.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: The combination of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression is prognostic in pancreatic cancer patients after a complete resection.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: On disease recurrence, only patients with low RRM1 derive benefit from gemcitabine.
title: Significance of RRM1 and ERCC1 expression in resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: To investigate whether EGF receptor (EGFR) pathway mutations predicted response to monotherapy with panitumumab, an anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody, in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Using massively parallel multigene sequencing, we analyzed 320 samples for 9 genes, with multigene sequence data from 288 (90%) samples.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Mutation rates were: KRAS (45%), NRAS (5%), BRAF (7%), PIK3CA (9%), PTEN (6%), TP53 (60%), EGFR (1%), AKT1 (<1%), and CTNNB1 (2%).
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: In the randomized study and open-label extension, 22 of 138 (16%) wild-type KRAS (codons 12/13/61) patients versus 0 of 103 mutant KRAS (codons 12/13) patients had objective responses.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Of 6 mutant KRAS (codon 61) patients, 1 with a Q61H mutation achieved partial response during the extension.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Among wild-type KRAS (codons 12/13/61) patients, 0 of 9 patients with NRAS mutations, 0 of 13 with BRAF mutations, 2 of 10 with PIK3CA mutations, 1 of 9 with PTEN mutations, and 1 of 2 with CTNNB1 mutations responded to panitumumab.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: No patients responded to best supportive care alone.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Panitumumab treatment was associated with longer progression-free survival (PFS) among wild-type KRAS (codons 12/13/61) patients [HR, 0.39; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.28-0.56].
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Among wild-type KRAS patients, a treatment effect for PFS favoring panitumumab occurred in patients with wild-type NRAS (HR, 0.39; 95% CI, 0.27-0.56) and wild-type BRAF (HR, 0.37; 95% CI, 0.24-0.55) but not mutant NRAS (HR, 1.94; 95% CI, 0.44-8.44).
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These results show the feasibility and potential clinical use of next-generation sequencing for evaluating predictive biomarkers.
title: Massively parallel tumor multigene sequencing to evaluate response to panitumumab in a randomized phase III study of metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Activating mutations of FGFR3 are frequently identified in superficial urothelial carcinoma (UC) and increased expression of FGFR1 and FGFR3 are common in both superficial and invasive UC.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: METHODS: The effects of inhibition of receptor activity by three small molecule inhibitors (PD173074, TKI-258 and SU5402) were investigated in a panel of bladder tumour cell lines with known FGFR expression levels and FGFR3 mutation status.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: RESULTS: All inhibitors prevented activation of FGFR3, and inhibited downstream MAPK pathway signalling.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: Response was related to FGFR3 and/or FGFR1 expression levels.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: Cell lines with the highest levels of FGFR expression showed the greatest response and little or no effect was measured in normal human urothelial cells or in UC cell lines with activating RAS gene mutations.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: In sensitive cell lines, the drugs induced cell cycle arrest and/or apoptosis.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: IC(50) values for PD173074 and TKI-258 were in the nanomolar concentration range compared with micromolar concentrations for SU5402.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: PD173074 showed the greatest effects in vitro and in vivo significantly delayed the growth of subcutaneous bladder tumour xenografts.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: CONCLUSION: These results indicate that inhibition of FGFR1 and wild-type or mutant FGFR3 may represent a useful therapeutic approach in patients with both non-muscle invasive and muscle invasive UC.
title: Small molecule FGF receptor inhibitors block FGFR-dependent urothelial carcinoma growth in vitro and in vivo.

text: Childhood BCR-ABL1-positive B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia (BCP-ALL) has an unfavorable outcome and shows high frequency of IKZF1 deletions.
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: The prognostic value of IKZF1 deletions was evaluated in 2 cohorts of BCR-ABL1-positive BCP-ALL patients, before tyrosine kinase inhibitors (pre-TKI) and after introduction of imatinib (in the European Study for Philadelphia-Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia [EsPhALL]).
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: In 126/191 (66%) cases an IKZF1 deletion was detected.
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: In the pre-TKI cohort, IKZF1-deleted patients had an unfavorable outcome compared with wild-type patients (4-year disease-free survival [DFS] of 30.0 +/- 6.8% vs 57.5 +/- 9.4%; P = .01).
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: In the EsPhALL cohort, the IKZF1 deletions were associated with an unfavorable prognosis in patients stratified in the good-risk arm based on early clinical response (4-year DFS of 51.9 +/- 8.8% for IKZF1-deleted vs 78.6 +/- 13.9% for IKZF1 wild-type; P = .03), even when treated with imatinib (4-year DFS of 55.5 +/- 9.5% for IKZF1-deleted vs 75.0 +/- 21.7% for IKZF1 wild-type; P = .05).
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: In conclusion, the highly unfavorable outcome for childhood BCR-ABL1-positive BCP-ALL with IKZF1 deletions, irrespective of imatinib exposure, underscores the need for alternative therapies.
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: In contrast, good-risk patients with IKZF1 wild-type responded remarkably well to imatinib-containing regimens, providing a rationale to potentially avoid hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation in this subset of patients.
title: IKZF1 status as a prognostic feature in BCR-ABL1-positive childhood ALL.

text: The genomic events responsible for the pathogenesis of relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) are not yet clear.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: We performed integrative analysis of whole-genome, whole-exome, custom capture, whole-transcriptome (RNA-seq), and locus-specific genomic assays across nine time points from a patient with primary de novo B-ALL.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Comprehensive genome and transcriptome characterization revealed a dramatic tumor evolution during progression, yielding a tumor with complex clonal architecture at second relapse.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: We observed and validated point mutations in EP300 and NF1, a highly expressed EP300-ZNF384 gene fusion, a microdeletion in IKZF1, a focal deletion affecting SETD2, and large deletions affecting RB1, PAX5, NF1, and ETV6.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Although the genome analysis revealed events of potential biological relevance, no clinically actionable treatment options were evident at the time of the second relapse.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: However, transcriptome analysis identified aberrant overexpression of the targetable protein kinase encoded by the FLT3 gene.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Although the patient had refractory disease after salvage therapy for the second relapse, treatment with the FLT3 inhibitor sunitinib rapidly induced a near complete molecular response, permitting the patient to proceed to a matched-unrelated donor stem cell transplantation.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: The patient remains in complete remission more than 4 years later.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Analysis of this patient's relapse genome revealed an unexpected, actionable therapeutic target that led to a specific therapy associated with a rapid clinical response.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: For some patients with relapsed or refractory cancers, this approach may indicate a novel therapeutic intervention that could alter outcome.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis reveals FLT3 activation and a therapeutic strategy for a patient with relapsed adult B-lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: CHEK2 encodes for a G2 checkpoint kinase which plays a critical role in DNA repair.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Its mutation confers an increased risk of breast cancer.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: It has also been suggested to increase risks of prostate cancer, but its involvement with this type of cancer has not been confirmed.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to clarify the association between CHEK2 1100delC, IVS2+1G>A, I157T mutation and risk of Prostate Cancer.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: A comprehensive, computerized literature search of PubMed until December 27, 2014 was carried out.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Eligible studies were included according to specific inclusion criteria.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Pooled hazard ratio was estimated using the fixed effects model or random effects model according to heterogeneity between studies.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Eight eligible studies were included in the analysis, all were retrospective studies.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The overall meta-analysis demonstrated that the CHEK2 1100delC mutation (OR 3.29; 95% confidence interval: 1.85-5.85; P = 0.00) and I157T missense mutation (OR 1.80; 95% confidence interval: 1.51-2.14; P = 0.00) was associated with higher risk of Prostate Cancer, and CHEK2 1100delC mutation is irrelevant to familial aggregation phenomenon of prostate cancer (OR 1.59; 95% confidence interval: 0.79-3.20; P = 0.20).
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The IVS2+1G>A mutation is also irrelevant to Prostate Cancer (OR = 1.59, 95% CI = 0.93-2.71, P = 0.09).
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: None of the single studies materially altered the original results and no evidence of publication bias was found.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSION: CHEK2 1100delC mutation and I157T missense mutation in males indicates higher risk of Prostate Cancer, but there's no evidence to prove the CHEK2 1100delC mutation was associated with Familial prostate cancer.
title: CHEK2 mutation and risk of prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: The efficacy of the ALK inhibitor crizotinib as compared with standard chemotherapy as first-line treatment for advanced ALK-positive non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is unknown.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: METHODS: We conducted an open-label, phase 3 trial comparing crizotinib with chemotherapy in 343 patients with advanced ALK-positive nonsquamous NSCLC who had received no previous systemic treatment for advanced disease.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Patients were randomly assigned to receive oral crizotinib at a dose of 250 mg twice daily or to receive intravenous chemotherapy (pemetrexed, 500 mg per square meter of body-surface area, plus either cisplatin, 75 mg per square meter, or carboplatin, target area under the curve of 5 to 6 mg per milliliter per minute) every 3 weeks for up to six cycles.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Crossover to crizotinib treatment after disease progression was permitted for patients receiving chemotherapy.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: The primary end point was progression-free survival as assessed by independent radiologic review.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Progression-free survival was significantly longer with crizotinib than with chemotherapy (median, 10.9 months vs. 7.0 months; hazard ratio for progression or death with crizotinib, 0.45; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.35 to 0.60; P<0.001).
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Objective response rates were 74% and 45%, respectively (P<0.001).
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Median overall survival was not reached in either group (hazard ratio for death with crizotinib, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.54 to 1.26; P=0.36); the probability of 1-year survival was 84% with crizotinib and 79% with chemotherapy.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: The most common adverse events with crizotinib were vision disorders, diarrhea, nausea, and edema, and the most common events with chemotherapy were nausea, fatigue, vomiting, and decreased appetite.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: As compared with chemotherapy, crizotinib was associated with greater reduction in lung cancer symptoms and greater improvement in quality of life.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Crizotinib was superior to standard first-line pemetrexed-plus-platinum chemotherapy in patients with previously untreated advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: (Funded by Pfizer; PROFILE 1014 ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01154140.
title: First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.
First-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy in ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Pancreatic cancer is the most lethal of all solid tumors partially because of its chemoresistance.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: Although gemcitabine is widely used as a first selected agent for the treatment of this disease despite low response rate, molecular mechanisms of gemcitabine resistance in pancreatic cancer still remain obscure.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: The aim of this study is to elucidate the mechanisms of gemcitabine resistance.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: The 81-fold gemcitabine resistant variant MiaPaCa2-RG was selected from pancreatic cancer cell line MiaPaCa2.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: By microarray analysis between MiaPaCa2 and MiaPaCa2-RG, 43 genes (0.04%) were altered expression of more than 2-fold.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: The most upregulated gene in MiaPaCa2-RG was ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit (RRM1) with 4.5-fold up-regulation.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: Transfection with RRM1-specific RNAi suppressed more than 90% of RRM1 mRNA and protein expression.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: After RRM1-specific RNAi transfection, gemcitabine chemoresistance of MiaPaCa2-RG was reduced to the same level of MiaPaCa2.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: The 18 recurrent pancreatic cancer patients treated by gemcitabine were divided into 2 groups by RRM1 levels.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: There was a significant association between gemcitabine response and RRM1 expression (p = 0.018).
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: Patients with high RRM1 levels had poor survival after gemcitabine treatment than those with low RRM1 levels (p = 0.016).
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: RRM1 should be a key molecule in gemcitabine resistance in human pancreatic cancer through both in vitro and clinical models.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: RRM1 may have the potential as predictor and modulator of gemcitabine treatment.
title: Involvement of ribonucleotide reductase M1 subunit overexpression in gemcitabine resistance of human pancreatic cancer.

text: Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by benign and malignant tumors.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: This study presents the clinical and genetic features of VHL syndrome in a Turkish family.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: For the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma-related diseases, 49 family members from three generations were evaluated between March 2008 and January 2013.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: Family members were examined to identify components of pheochromocytoma-related genetic syndromes through physical examination, laboratory tests, and imaging methods.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: For the causative mutation, sequence analysis of VHL gene was performed.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: Nine patients were diagnosed with pheochromocytoma.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: Lumbal spinal hemangioblastoma and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor without pheochromocytoma were detected in one patient.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: In patients with pheochromocytoma, additional tumors, such as retinal angioma, renal cell carcinoma, pancreatic serous cystadenoma, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors were detected.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: All patients were diagnosed as VHL syndrome type 2B.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: Sequence analysis of VHL gene revealed heterozygous p.A149S mutation in all symptomatic patients and in seven of the asymptomatic family members.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: This is the first study that identified VHL p.A149S mutation in a Turkish family with VHL syndrome.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: However, VHL p.A149S mutation was identified in an American family by Atuk et al.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: (J Clin Endocrinol Metab, 83:117-120, 14) and the family was defined as VHL type 2A.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: In our study, the family was identified as VHL type 2B.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: This variability in the phenotypic features suggests that further studies are required to beter assess the genotype-phenotype correlation in such cases.
title: Clinical presentation of Von Hippel Lindau syndrome type 2B associated with VHL p.A149S mutation in a large Turkish family.

text: Ewing's sarcoma is a rare and aggressive malignancy.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: In the present study, tumor from a patient with a Ewing's sarcoma with cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A/B (CDKN2A/B) loss and FUS-ERG fusion was implanted in the right chest wall of nude mice to establish a patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) model.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: The aim of the present study was to determine efficacy of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 (CDK4/6) and insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) inhibitors on the Ewing's sarcoma PDOX.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: The PDOX models were randomized into the following groups when tumor volume reached 50 mm3: G1, untreated control; G2, doxorubicin (DOX) (intraperitoneal (i.p.)
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: injection, weekly, for 2 weeks); G3, CDK4/6 inhibitor (palbociclib, PD0332991, per oral (p.o.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: ), daily, for 14 days); G4, IGF-1R inhibitor (linsitinib, OSI-906, p.o., daily, for 14 days).
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: Tumor growth was significantly suppressed both in G3 (palbociclib) and in G4 (linsitinib) compared to G1 (untreated control) at all measured time points.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: In contrast, DOX did not inhibit tumor growth at any time point, which is consistent with the failure of DOX to control tumor growth in the patient.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: The results of the present study demonstrate the power of the PDOX model to identify effective targeted molecular therapy of a recalcitrant DOX-resistant Ewing's sarcoma with specific genetic alterations.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: The results of this study suggest the potential of PDOX models for individually-tailored, effective targeted therapy for recalcitrant cancer.
title: Effective molecular targeting of CDK4/6 and IGF-1R in a rare FUS-ERG fusion CDKN2A-deletion doxorubicin-resistant Ewing's sarcoma patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude-mouse model.

text: The recognition of recurrent genetic alterations in specific tumour types has provided the basis for the reclassification of certain soft tissue neoplasms, and molecular analysis of patient material has the potential to provide both diagnostic and prognostic information.
title: Diagnostic gold standard for soft tissue tumours: morphology or molecular genetics?

text: In this review, we evaluate the role of molecular genetic testing as the prospective 'gold standard' for sarcoma diagnosis.
title: Diagnostic gold standard for soft tissue tumours: morphology or molecular genetics?

text: Molecular genetic testing, as with every new method, promises to improve accuracy and to be more sensitive and less subjective, claims that have been made previously by histochemistry, electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry.
title: Diagnostic gold standard for soft tissue tumours: morphology or molecular genetics?

text: Technical limitations in molecular assays, as well as more general specificity issues, decrease the clinical usefulness of molecular pathological testing significantly and suggest that, at present, molecular evaluation is best considered an ancillary technique that neither supersedes other ancillary techniques nor eclipses traditional pathological examination.
title: Diagnostic gold standard for soft tissue tumours: morphology or molecular genetics?

text: Translating whole-exome sequencing (WES) for prospective clinical use may have an impact on the care of patients with cancer; however, multiple innovations are necessary for clinical implementation.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: These include rapid and robust WES of DNA derived from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor tissue, analytical output similar to data from frozen samples and clinical interpretation of WES data for prospective use.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: Here, we describe a prospective clinical WES platform for archival formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: The platform employs computational methods for effective clinical analysis and interpretation of WES data.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: When applied retrospectively to 511 exomes, the interpretative framework revealed a 'long tail' of somatic alterations in clinically important genes.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: Prospective application of this approach identified clinically relevant alterations in 15 out of 16 patients.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: In one patient, previously undetected findings guided clinical trial enrollment, leading to an objective clinical response.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: Overall, this methodology may inform the widespread implementation of precision cancer medicine.
title: Whole-exome sequencing and clinical interpretation of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples to guide precision cancer medicine.

text: Mucinous gastric carcinoma (MGC) is a unique subtype of gastric cancer with a poor survival outcome.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: Comprehensive molecular profiles and putative therapeutic targets of MGC remain undetermined.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: We subjected 16 tumour-normal tissue pairs to whole-exome sequencing (WES) and an expanded set of 52 tumour-normal tissue pairs to subsequent targeted sequencing.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: The latter focused on 114 genes identified by WES.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: Twenty-two histologically differentiated MGCs (D-MGCs) and 46 undifferentiated MGCs (U-MGCs) were analysed.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: Chromatin modifier genes, including ARID1A (21%), MLL2 (19%), MLL3 (15%), and KDM6A (7%), were frequently mutated (47%) in MGC.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: We also identified mutations in potential therapeutic target genes, including MTOR (9%), BRCA2 (9%), BRCA1 (7%), and ERBB3 (6%).
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: RHOA mutation was detected only in 4% of U-MGCs and in no D-MGCs.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: MYH9 was recurrently (13%) mutated in MGC, with all these being of the U-MGC subtype (p = 0.023).
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: Three U-MGCs harboured MYH9 nonsense mutations.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: MYH9 knockdown enhanced cell migration and induced intracytoplasmic mucin and cellular elongation.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: BCOR mutation was associated with improved survival.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: In U-MGCs, the MLH1 expression status and combined mutation status (TP53/BCL11B or TP53/MLL2) were prognostic factors.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: A comparative analysis of driver genes revealed that the mutation profile of D-MGC was similar to that of intestinal-type gastric cancer, whereas U-MGC was a distinct entity, harbouring a different mutational profile to intestinal- and diffuse-type gastric cancers.
title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

title: Comprehensive mutation profiling of mucinous gastric carcinoma.

text: Persistent RET activation is a frequent event in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC).
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: In these cancers, RET activates the ERK/MAPK, the PI3K/AKT/mTOR and the JAK/STAT3 pathways.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: Here, we tested the efficacy of a JAK1/2- inhibitor, AZD1480, in the in vitro and in vivo growth of thyroid cancer cell lines expressing oncogenic RET.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: Thyroid cancer cell lines harboring RET/PTC1 (TPC-1), RET M918T (MZ-CRC1) and RET C634W (TT) alterations, as well as TPC-1 xenografts, were treated with JAK inhibitor, AZD1480.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: This inhibitor led to growth inhibition and/or apoptosis of the thyroid cancer cell lines in vitro, as well as to tumor regression of TPC-1 xenografts, where it efficiently blocked STAT3 activation in tumor and stromal cells.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: This inhibition was associated with decreased proliferation, decreased blood vessel density, coupled with increased necrosis.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: However, AZD1480 repressed the growth of STAT3- deficient TPC-1 cells in vitro and in vivo, demonstrating that its effects in this cell line were independent of STAT3 in the tumor cells.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: In all cell lines, the JAK inhibitor reduced phospho-Y1062 RET levels, and mTOR effector phospho-S6, while JAK1/2 downregulation by siRNA did not affect cell growth nor RET and S6 activation.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: In conclusion, AZD1480 effectively blocks proliferation and tumor growth of activated RET- thyroid cancer cell lines, likely through direct RET inhibition in cancer cells as well as by modulation of the microenvironment (e g  via JAK/phospho-STAT3 inhibition in endothelial cells).
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: Thus, AZD1480 should be considered as a therapeutic agent for the treatment of RET- activated thyroid cancers.
title: AZD1480 blocks growth and tumorigenesis of RET- activated thyroid cancer cell lines.

text: PURPOSE: PALB2 is a recently identified breast cancer susceptibility gene.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: We have previously identified in the Finnish population a PALB2 c.1592delT founder truncation mutation that is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: In the present study, we wanted to assess in more detail the increased risk (hazard ratio, HR) and the age-specific cumulative risk (penetrance) of c.1592delT with regard to susceptibility to breast and other forms of cancer.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Modified segregation analyses fitted under maximum likelihood theory were used to estimate age-specific cumulative risks and HRs using the families of mutation carriers identified from a consecutive series of breast cancer cases unselected for age at onset or family history.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: RESULTS: We found a substantially increased risk of breast cancer [HR, 6.1; 95% confidence interval (95% CI), 2.2-17.2; P = 0.01] equivalent to a 40% (95% CI, 17-77) breast cancer risk by age 70 years, comparable to that for carriers of mutations in BRCA2.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: We found marginal evidence (P = 0.06) that the HR for breast cancer decreased with age by 4.2% per year (95% CI, 0.2-8.1), from 7.5-fold at age 30 years to 2.0-fold at age 60 years.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our results suggest that it may be appropriate to offer PALB2 c.1592delT mutation testing to Finnish women with breast cancer, especially those with an early age at onset or a family history of breast or related cancers, and to offer carriers the option of participation in extended disease surveillance programs.
title: Penetrance analysis of the PALB2 c.1592delT founder mutation.

text: The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) family of receptor tyrosine kinases has been implicated in a variety of cancers.
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: In particular, activating mutations such as the L858R point mutation in exon 21 and the small in-frame deletions in exon 19 of the EGFR tyrosine kinase domain are correlated with sensitivity to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients.
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: Clinical treatment of patients is limited by the development of drug resistance resulting mainly from a gatekeeper mutation (T790M).
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: In this study, we evaluated the therapeutic potential of a novel, irreversible pan-HER inhibitor, HM781-36B.
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: The results from this study show that HM781-36B is a potent inhibitor of EGFR in vitro, including the EGFR-acquired resistance mutation (T790M), as well as HER-2 and HER-4, compared with other EGFR tyrosine kinases inhibitors (erlotinib, lapatinib and BIBW2992).
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: HM781-36B treatment of EGFR DelE746_A750-harboring erlotinib-sensitive HCC827 and EGFR L858R/T790M-harboring erlotinib-resistant NCI-H1975 NSCLC cells results in the inhibition of EGFR phosphorylation and the subsequent deactivation of downstream signaling proteins.
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: Additionally, HM781-36B shows an excellent efficacy in a variety of EGFR- and HER-2-dependent tumor xenograft models, including erlotinib-sensitive HCC827 NSCLC cells, erlotinib-resistant NCI-H1975 NSCLC cells, HER-2 overexpressing Calu-3 NSCLC cells, NCI-N87 gastric cancer cells, SK-Ov3 ovarian cancer cells and EGFR-overexpressing A431 epidermoid carcinoma cancer cells.
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: On the basis of these preclinical results, HM781-36B is the most potent pan-HER inhibitor, which will be advantageous for the treatment of patients with NSCLC including clinical limitation caused by acquired mutation (EGFR T790M), breast cancer and gastric cancer.
title: Antitumor activity of HM781-36B, a highly effective pan-HER inhibitor in erlotinib-resistant NSCLC and other EGFR-dependent cancer models.

text: BACKGROUND: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma is frequently associated with aberrant epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) signaling, which contributes to tumor growth.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: Here, the functional importance of EGFR ligands in relation to proliferation and sensitivity to the EGFR-targeted therapy cetuximab was investigated in three tongue cancer cell lines.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: METHODS: The influence of epidermal growth factor (EGF), amphiregulin (AR), and epiregulin (EPR) on tumor cell proliferation and cetuximab response was evaluated by the addition of recombinant human (rh) proteins or by siRNA-mediated downregulation of the endogenous ligand production.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: The expression, activation and cellular distribution of EGFR were assessed by Western blot analysis and immunocytochemistry.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: RESULTS: EGF downregulation suppressed the proliferation of all investigated tumor cell lines, whereas the response to an increased level of EGF differed between EGFR-overexpressing and EGFR-non-overexpressing cell lines.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: Furthermore, tumor cells consistently displayed increased cetuximab resistance upon the addition of rhEGF, whereas EGF silencing was associated with an improved cetuximab response.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: The data regarding AR and EPR were inconclusive.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our data suggest that the amount of EGF is a determinant of the tumor cell proliferation rate and the response to cetuximab treatment in tongue cancer.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: Thus, EGF is a potential predictive biomarker of poor cetuximab response and a possible treatment target.
title: Epidermal growth factor is a potential biomarker for poor cetuximab response in tongue cancer cells.

text: The PTEN gene, located on 10q23, has recently been implicated as a candidate tumor suppressor gene in brain, breast and prostate tumors.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: In the present study, 123 brain tumors, including various grades and histological types of gliomas occurring in children and adults, were analyzed for PTEN mutations by SSCP assay and sequencing.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: Mutations in the PTEN gene were found in 13 of 42 adult glioblastomas and 3 of 13 adult anaplastic astrocytomas, whereas none of the 21 low-grade adult gliomas or the 22 childhood gliomas of all grades showed mutations.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: The single medulloblastoma with a mutation was a recurrent tumor that also possessed a p53 mutation.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: High-grade adult gliomas with PTEN mutations included cases that also contained gene amplification or p53 gene mutations, as well as cases that did not contain either of these abnormalities.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: There was no obvious relationship between presence of PTEN mutation and survival; however, there was a tendency for PTEN mutations to occur in older age group patients.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: This analysis suggest that PTEN gene mutations are restricted to high-grade adult gliomas and that this abnormality is independent of the presence or absence of gene amplification or p53 gene mutation in these tumors.
title: PTEN gene mutations are seen in high-grade but not in low-grade gliomas.

text: BACKGROUND: Merkel-cell carcinoma is an aggressive skin cancer that is linked to exposure to ultraviolet light and the Merkel-cell polyomavirus (MCPyV).
title: PD-1 Blockade with Pembrolizumab in Advanced Merkel-Cell Carcinoma.

text: Advanced Merkel-cell carcinoma often responds to chemotherapy, but responses are transient.
title: PD-1 Blockade with Pembrolizumab in Advanced Merkel-Cell Carcinoma.
