title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Tumors with VHL mutation showed higher CAIX expression than those without (p = 0.02).
title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL mutation were associated with a more advanced tumors e.g., higher T stages and presence of metastases.
title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: VHL mutation and high CAIX expression predicted longer progression-free survival (p = 0.037) and disease-specific survival (p = 0.001), respectively.
title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: In combination, they defined three prognostic groups (p = 0.002): (i) good prognosis, defined as VHL mutation and high CAIX (2-year survival: 86%), (ii) intermediate prognosis with either VHL mutation or high CAIX (69%), and (iii) poor prognosis with no VHL mutation and low CAIX (45%, median survival 18 months).
title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: CAIX expression, but not VHL mutational status, was an independent prognostic factor in multivariate analysis.
title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Taken together, CAIX expression and VHL mutational status are able to stratify patients with clear cell RCC into distinct groups with regards to clinicopathological variables and prognosis, with low CAIX expression and absence of VHL mutation being associated with a poor clinicopathological phenotype and diminished survival.
title: Low CAIX expression and absence of VHL gene mutation are associated with tumor aggressiveness and poor survival of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Desmoid tumors are benign monoclonal fibroblastic or myofibroblastic neoplasms, characterized by local invasiveness and high rates of recurrence.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: Desmoid tumors must be distinguished from benign fibroblastic and myofibroblastic lesions, as well as from low-grade sarcoma, which can appear histologically similar to desmoid tumors.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: This differential diagnosis can be very difficult, especially when diagnosis is based on a core needle biopsy.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: On the molecular level, most sporadic desmoid tumors are associated with mutations of the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1).
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: A minority of desmoid tumors are associated with Gardner syndrome and mutations of the familial adenomatous polyposis gene.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: We identified the common CTNNB1 mutations associated with sporadic desmoid tumors by direct sequencing: in (i) 260 cases of typical desmoid tumors; and (ii) in 191 cases of spindle cell lesions, which can morphologically 'mimic' desmoid tumors.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: Formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues were obtained via core needle biopsy (n=150) or open biopsy/surgical excision (n=301).
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: Only 16 cases (4%) were not analyzable (Bouin's fixed tissue).
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: CTNNB1 mutations were observed in 223 of 254 (88%) of sporadic desmoid tumors.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: No CTNNB1 mutations were detected in all other lesions (n=175) studied.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: CTNNB1 sequencing can be easily and reliably done using tissues obtained via core needle biopsy.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: Detection of CTNNB1 mutations in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues among spindle cell lesions is proposed as a specific diagnostic tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: This result has significant implications for patient care and management.
title: CTNNB1 mutation analysis is a useful tool for the diagnosis of desmoid tumors: a study of 260 desmoid tumors and 191 potential morphologic mimics.

text: BACKGROUND: Phase 1 and 2 clinical trials of the BRAF kinase inhibitor vemurafenib (PLX4032) have shown response rates of more than 50% in patients with metastatic melanoma with the BRAF V600E mutation.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: METHODS: We conducted a phase 3 randomized clinical trial comparing vemurafenib with dacarbazine in 675 patients with previously untreated, metastatic melanoma with the BRAF V600E mutation.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Patients were randomly assigned to receive either vemurafenib (960 mg orally twice daily) or dacarbazine (1000 mg per square meter of body-surface area intravenously every 3 weeks).
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Coprimary end points were rates of overall and progression-free survival.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Secondary end points included the response rate, response duration, and safety.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: A final analysis was planned after 196 deaths and an interim analysis after 98 deaths.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: RESULTS: At 6 months, overall survival was 84% (95% confidence interval [CI], 78 to 89) in the vemurafenib group and 64% (95% CI, 56 to 73) in the dacarbazine group.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: In the interim analysis for overall survival and final analysis for progression-free survival, vemurafenib was associated with a relative reduction of 63% in the risk of death and of 74% in the risk of either death or disease progression, as compared with dacarbazine (P<0.001 for both comparisons).
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: After review of the interim analysis by an independent data and safety monitoring board, crossover from dacarbazine to vemurafenib was recommended.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Response rates were 48% for vemurafenib and 5% for dacarbazine.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Common adverse events associated with vemurafenib were arthralgia, rash, fatigue, alopecia, keratoacanthoma or squamous-cell carcinoma, photosensitivity, nausea, and diarrhea; 38% of patients required dose modification because of toxic effects.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Vemurafenib produced improved rates of overall and progression-free survival in patients with previously untreated melanoma with the BRAF V600E mutation.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: (Funded by Hoffmann-La Roche; BRIM-3 ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01006980.
title: Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.
Improved survival with vemurafenib in melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

text: BACKGROUND: Although recent reports indicate that K-ras mutation status is a biomarker that acts as a prognostic factor, only a few analyses of K-ras mutation subtypes have been published.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: In addition, there are no reports that analyze overall survival and prognostic factors according to K-ras mutation status and subtypes in only unresectable pancreatic cancer (PC) determined from tissues obtained by endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: METHODS: We retrospectively analyzed 242 patients who were diagnosed as having unresectable PC with available histological diagnosis.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: Clinical data collected included sex, age, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, carbohydrate antigen (CA) 19-9, primary tumor location, stage (local or metastatic) according to TNM staging, first-line chemotherapy, K-ras mutation status and subtypes (G12D, G12V, and G12R), and overall survival.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: We analyzed the negative prognostic factors for reduced overall survival in unresectable PC patients using these data.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: RESULTS: From multivariate analysis, CA19-9 >/=1000 U/ml (hazard ratio [HR] 1.78, 95 % confidence interval [CI] 1.28-2.46, P < 0.01), metastatic stage (HR 2.26, 95 % CI 1.58-3.24, P < 0.01), and mutant-K-ras (HR 1.76, 95 % CI 1.03-3.01, P = 0.04) were negative prognostic factors, indicating a reduced survival.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: Among the patients who had K-ras mutation subtypes, CA19-9 >/=1000 U/ml (HR 1.65, 95 % CI 1.12-2.37, P < 0.01), metastatic stage (HR 2.12, 95 % CI 1.44-3.14, P < 0.01), and the presence of the G12D or G12R mutations (HR 1.60, 95 % CI 1.11-2.28) were negative prognostic factors for overall survival.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: K-ras mutation status and subtypes may be associated with survival duration in pancreatic cancer patients.
title: Prognostic value of K-ras mutation status and subtypes in endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration specimens from patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Olaparib (AZD2281) is a small-molecule, potent oral poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitor.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: We aimed to assess the safety and tolerability of this drug in patients without BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations with advanced triple-negative breast cancer or high-grade serous and/or undifferentiated ovarian cancer.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: METHODS: In this phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study, women with advanced high-grade serous and/or undifferentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer were enrolled and received olaparib 400 mg twice a day.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: Patients were stratified according to whether they had a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation or not.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: The primary endpoint was objective response rate by Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors (RECIST).
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: All patients who received treatment were included in the analysis of toxic effects, and patients who had measurable lesions at baseline were included in the primary efficacy analysis.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: This trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00679783.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: FINDINGS: 91 patients were enrolled (65 with ovarian cancer and 26 breast cancer) and 90 were treated between July 8, 2008, and Sept 24, 2009.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: In the ovarian cancer cohorts, 64 patients received treatment.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: 63 patients had target lesions and therefore were evaluable for objective response as per RECIST.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: In these patients, confirmed objective responses were seen in seven (41%; 95% CI 22-64) of 17 patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations and 11 (24%; 14-38) of 46 without mutations.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: No confirmed objective responses were reported in patients with breast cancer.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: The most common adverse events were fatigue (45 [70%] of patients with ovarian cancer, 13 [50%] of patients with breast cancer), nausea (42 [66%] and 16 [62%]), vomiting (25 [39%] and nine [35%]), and decreased appetite (23 [36%] and seven [27%]).
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: INTERPRETATION: Our study suggests that olaparib is a promising treatment for women with ovarian cancer and further assessment of the drug in clinical trials is needed.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: FUNDING: AstraZeneca.
title: Olaparib in patients with recurrent high-grade serous or poorly differentiated ovarian carcinoma or triple-negative breast cancer: a phase 2, multicentre, open-label, non-randomised study.

text: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is an aggressive PDGFB-dependent cutaneous sarcoma characterized by infiltrative growth and frequent local recurrences.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: Some DFSP progress to a higher-grade fibrosarcomatous form, with rapid growth and increased risk of metastasis.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: Imatinib provides clinical benefit in approximately 50% of patients with unresectable or metastatic DFSP.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: However, efficacious medical therapies have not been developed for imatinib-resistant DFSP.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: We established a model of imatinib-resistant DFSP and evaluated CDK4/6 inhibition as a genomically credentialed targeted therapy.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: DFSP105, an imatinib-resistant human cell line, was established from a fibrosarcomatous DFSP (FS-DFSP), and was studied by SNP arrays and sequencing to identify targetable genomic alterations.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: Findings were validated in vitro and in vivo, and confirmed in a series including 12 DFSP and 6 FS-DFSP.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: SNP analysis of DFSP105 revealed a homozygous deletion encompassing CDKN2A and CDKN2B.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: The resultant p16 loss implicated CDK4/6 as a potential therapeutic target in DFSP.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: We further demonstrated CDKN2A homozygous deletion in 1 of 12 conventional DFSP and 2 of 6 FS-DFSP, whereas p16 expression was lost in 4 of 18 DFSP.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: In vitro treatment of DFSP105 with two structurally distinct selective CDK4/6 inhibitors, PD-0332991 and LEE011, led to inhibition of RB1 phosphorylation and inhibition of proliferation (GI50 160 nmol/L and 276 nmol/L, respectively).
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: In vivo treatment of DFSP105 with PD-0332991 (150 mg/kg) inhibited xenograft growth in mice, in comparison with imatinib-treated or -untreated tumors.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: In conclusion, CDKN2A deletion can contribute to DFSP progression.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: CDK4/6 inhibition is a preclinically effective treatment against p16-negative, imatinib-resistant FS-DFSP, and should be evaluated as a therapeutic strategy in patients with unresectable or metastatic imatinib-resistant DFSP.
title: CDKN2A/p16 Loss Implicates CDK4 as a Therapeutic Target in Imatinib-Resistant Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans.

text: According to the prevailing multistep model of melanoma development, oncogenic BRAF or NRAS mutations are crucial initial events in melanoma development.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: It is not known whether melanocytic nevi that are found in association with a melanoma are more likely to carry BRAF or NRAS mutations than uninvolved nevi.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: By laser microdissection we were able to selectively dissect and genotype cells either from the nevus or from the melanoma part of 46 melanomas that developed in association with a nevus.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: In 25 cases we also genotyped a control nevus of the same patients.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: Available tissue was also immunostained using the BRAF(V600E)-mutation specific antibody VE1.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: The BRAF(V600E) mutation was found in 63.0% of melanomas, 65.2% of associated nevi and 50.0% of control nevi.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: No significant differences in the distribution of BRAF or NRAS mutations could be found between melanoma and associated nevi or between melanoma associated nevi and control nevi.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: In concordant cases immunohistochemistry showed a higher expression (intensity of immunohistochemistry) of the mutated BRAF(V600E)-protein in melanomas compared to their associated nevi.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: In this series the presence of a BRAF- or NRAS mutation in a nevus was not associated with the risk of malignant transformation.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: Our findings do not support the current traditional model of stepwise tumor progression.
title: NRAS and BRAF mutations in melanoma-associated nevi and uninvolved nevi.

text: INTRODUCTION: Amrubicin is a promising agent in the treatment of lung cancer, but predictive biomarkers have not yet been described.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: NAD(P)H:quinone oxidoreductase 1 (NQO1) is an enzyme known to metabolize amrubicinol, the active metabolite of amrubicin, to an inactive compound.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: We examined the relationship between NQO1 and amrubicinol cytotoxicity.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: METHODS: Gene and protein expression of NQO1, amrubicinol cytotoxicity, and C609T single-nucleotide polymorphism of NQO1 were evaluated in 29 lung cancer cell lines: 14 small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and 15 non-SCLC (NSCLC).
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: The involvement of NQO1 in amrubicinol cytotoxicity was evaluated by small interfering RNA against NQO1.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: RESULTS: A significant inverse relationship between both gene and protein expression of NQO1 and amrubicinol cytotoxicity was found in all cell lines.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: Treatment with NQO1 small interfering RNA increased amrubicinol cytotoxicity and decreased NQO1 expression in both NSCLC and SCLC cells.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: Furthermore, cell lines genotyped homozygous for the 609T allele showed significantly lower NQO1 protein expression and higher sensitivity for amrubicinol than those with the other genotypes in both NSCLC and SCLC cells.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: CONCLUSIONS: NQO1 expression is one of the major determinants for amrubicinol cytotoxicity, and C609T single-nucleotide polymorphism of NQO1 could be a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin treatment.
title: C609T polymorphism of NAD(P)H quinone oxidoreductase 1 as a predictive biomarker for response to amrubicin.

text: We used the paclitaxel-resistant human small cell lung cancer subline PC-6/TAX1-1, selected from PC-6 cells by paclitaxel, to test whether MRP7/ABCC10 (ABCC10) confers paclitaxel resistance.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: We found that gene expression of both ABCB1/MDR1 (ABCB1) and ABCC10 was higher in PC-6/TAX1-1 cells than in PC-6 cells.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The expression levels of ABCC10 showed a significant inverse correlation with paclitaxel sensitivity (r = 0.574; P < 0.05) in 17 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells unlike the expression levels of ABCB1.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Pretreatment with the ABCC10 inhibitor sulfinpyrazone altered the sensitivity to paclitaxel in ABCC10-expressing NSCLC cells, concomitant with increased intracellular paclitaxel accumulation.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: These findings suggest that expression of the ABCC10 gene is induced by paclitaxel and that ABCC10 confers paclitaxel resistance by enhancing the efflux for paclitaxel.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: To confirm this hypothesis, we tested the effect on paclitaxel cytotoxicity of decreasing the expression of ABCC10 by small interfering RNA and found that this enhanced paclitaxel cytotoxicity in NCI-H23 cells concomitant with increased intracellular paclitaxel accumulation.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: These data indicate that ABCC10 may be one of the biomarkers for paclitaxel resistance in NSCLC.
title: MRP7/ABCC10 expression is a predictive biomarker for the resistance to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Mutations of receptor tyrosine kinases are implicated in the constitutive activation and development of human malignancy.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: An internal tandem duplication (ITD) of the juxtamembrane (JM) domain-coding sequence of the FLT3 gene (FLT3/ITD) is found in 20% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and is strongly associated with leukocytosis and a poor prognosis.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: On the other hand, mutations of the c-KIT gene, which have been found in mast cell leukemia and AML, are clustered in 2 distinct regions, the JM domain and D816 within the activation loop.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: This study was designed to analyze the mutation of D835 of FLT3, which corresponds to D816 of c-KIT, in a large series of human hematologic malignancies.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: Several kinds of missense mutations were found in 30 of the 429 (7.0%) AML cases, 1 of the 29 (3.4%) myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) cases, and 1 of the 36 (2.8%) acute lymphocytic leukemia patients.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: The D835Y mutation was most frequently found (22 of the 32 D835 mutations), followed by the D835V (5), and D835H (1), D835E (1), and D835N (1) mutations.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: Of note is that D835 mutations occurred independently of FLT3/ITD.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: An analysis in the 201 patients newly diagnosed with AML (excluding M3) revealed that, in contrast to the FLT3/ITD mutation (n = 46), D835 mutations (n = 8) were not significantly related to the leukocytosis, but tended to worsen disease-free survival.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: All D835-mutant FLT3 were constitutively tyrosine-phosphorylated and transformed 32D cells, suggesting these mutations were constitutively active.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: These results demonstrate that the FLT3 gene is the target most frequently mutated to become constitutively active in AML.
title: Activating mutation of D835 within the activation loop of FLT3 in human hematologic malignancies.

text: UNLABELLED: We report a case of follicular thyroid carcinoma with concomitant NRAS p.Q61K and GNAS p.R201H mutations, which manifested as a 13.5 cm thyroid mass with lung, humerus and T9 spine metastases, and exhibited good response to radioactive iodine treatment.
title: Follicular thyroid carcinoma with NRAS Q61K and GNAS R201H mutations that had a good (131)I treatment response.

text: LEARNING POINTS: GNAS p.R201H somatic mutation is an activating or gain-of-function mutation resulting in constitutively activated Gs-alpha protein and downstream cAMP cascade, independent of TSH signaling, causing autonomously functioning thyroid nodules.
title: Follicular thyroid carcinoma with NRAS Q61K and GNAS R201H mutations that had a good (131)I treatment response.

text: NRAS p.Q61K mutations with GNAS p.R201H mutations are known for a good radioactive iodine treatment response.Further exploration of the GNAS-activating pathway may provide therapeutic insights into the treatment of metastatic follicular carcinoma.
title: Follicular thyroid carcinoma with NRAS Q61K and GNAS R201H mutations that had a good (131)I treatment response.

text: PURPOSE: All patients with EGF receptor (EGFR)-mutant lung cancers eventually develop acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI).
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: Smaller series have identified various mechanisms of resistance, but systematic evaluation of a large number of patients to definitively establish the frequency of various mechanisms has not been conducted.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Patients with lung adenocarcinomas and acquired resistance to erlotinib or gefitinib enrolled onto a prospective biopsy protocol and underwent a rebiopsy after the development of acquired resistance.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: Histology was reviewed.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: Samples underwent genotyping for mutations in EGFR, AKT1, BRAF, ERBB2, KRAS, MEK1, NRAS and PIK3CA, and FISH for MET and HER2.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: RESULTS: Adequate tumor samples for molecular analysis were obtained in 155 patients.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: Ninety-eight had second-site EGFR T790M mutations [63%; 95% confidence interval (CI), 55%-70%] and four had small cell transformation (3%, 95% CI, 0%-6%).
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: MET amplification was seen in 4 of 75 (5%; 95% CI, 1%-13%).
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: HER2 amplification was seen in 3 of 24 (13%; 95% CI, 3%-32%).
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: We did not detect any acquired mutations in PIK3CA, AKT1, BRAF, ERBB2, KRAS, MEK1, or NRAS (0 of 88, 0%; 95% CI, 0%-4%).
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: Overlap among mechanisms of acquired resistance was seen in 4%.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This is the largest series reporting mechanisms of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: We identified EGFR T790M as the most common mechanism of acquired resistance, whereas MET amplification, HER2 amplification, and small cell histologic transformation occur less frequently.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: More comprehensive methods to characterize molecular alterations in this setting are needed to improve our understanding of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKIs.
title: Analysis of tumor specimens at the time of acquired resistance to EGFR-TKI therapy in 155 patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancers.

text: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is a frequently recurrent deadly cancer for which no efficient targeted drug exists.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: AXL is an adverse prognostic factor in some cancers.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Strong clinical evidence to support the prognostic role of AXL in ESCC is lacking.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: A total of 116 patients diagnosed with operable primary ESCC were enrolled.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Both AXL and HER2 expression were detected by immunohistochemistry (IHC) in esophageal tissue and were correlated with the clinical outcome of patients.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The efficacy of the AXL targeted drug foretinib was also evaluated in ESCC cells.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Expression of AXL was found in about 80 % of ESCC tissue, and was significantly correlated with progression of tumor (P<0.001), increased risk of death (Hazard ratio HR [95 % CI=2.09[1.09-4.04], P=0.028], and distant metastasis (odds ratio OR [95 %CI]=3.96 (1.16-13.60), P=0.029).
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The adverse clinical impact of AXL was more evident when cumulatively expressed with HER2.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: In cell model, ESCC cells were more sensitive to AXL inhibitor foretinib than to the HER2 inhibitor lapatinib.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Meanwhile, the AXL inhibitor foretinib showed a synergistic effect with HER2 inhibitors and the potential to overcome drug resistance to lapatinib.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: We thus concluded that AXL is a strong adverse prognostic factor for ESCC.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Therapeutic agents targeting AXL have great potential to improve prognosis of ESCC patients.
title: The AXL receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with adverse prognosis and distant metastasis in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND & AIMS: Most gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) have gain-of-function mutations of c-kit receptor tyrosine kinase (KIT) gene, but some GISTs do not.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: We investigated the cause of GISTs without KIT mutations.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Because GISTs apparently expressed platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR) alpha, we examined whether GISTs without KIT mutations had a mutation of PDGFR alpha.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: METHODS: Whole coding region of PDGFR alpha complementary DNA (cDNA) was sequenced in GISTs with or without KIT mutations.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Mutant PDGFR alpha cDNA was transfected into 293T human embryonic kidney cells, and autophosphorylation of PDGFR alpha was examined.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Proliferation of Ba/F3 murine lymphoid cells stably transfected with mutant PDGFR alpha cDNA was estimated by tritium thymidine incorporation.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Wild-type KIT cDNA was cotransfected with mutant PDGFR alpha cDNA, and immunoprecipitation by anti-KIT antibody was performed.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Inhibitory effect of Imatinib mesylate on activated PDGFR alpha was examined.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: RESULTS: We found 2 types of constitutively activated mutations of PDGFR alpha, Val-561 to Asp or Asp-842 to Val, in 5 of 8 GISTs without KIT mutations but not in 10 GISTs with KIT mutations.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Stable transfection of each mutation induced autonomous proliferation of Ba/F3 cells.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Constitutively activated mutant PDGFR alpha bound and activated the cotransfected wild-type KIT.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: The constitutive activation of PDGFR alpha with Val-561 to Asp was inhibited effectively by Imatinib mesylate but that of PDGFR alpha with Asp-842 to Val was inhibited only weakly, even at the concentration of 10 micromol/L.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The gain-of-function mutations of PDGFR alpha appear to play an important role in development of GISTs without KIT mutations.
title: Gain-of-function mutations of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha gene in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: Activating mutations in the K-ras oncogene mainly occur in codons 12 and 13 and may be predictive of response to drugs directly linked to the K-ras signaling pathway, such as panitumumab and cetuximab.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: K-ras analysis was carried out on DNA extracted from paraffin-embedded tumor samples after microdissection.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: Exons 1 and 2 were amplified by PCR and then sequenced.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: RESULTS: A never-reported K-ras mutation (CAG>TAG) determining a premature stop signal at codon 22 (Gln22Stop) was found in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: BRAF and p53 were not found to be modified and microsatellite instability was not present.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: The patient, however, was found to be unresponsive to an anti-EGFR MAb treatment.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: CONCLUSION: This study is the first report of a novel K-ras truncating mutation in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer and is also suggestive for the evaluation of alternative pathways to better identify individuals who are likely to benefit from targeted therapies.
title: A novel K-ras mutation in colorectal cancer. A case report and literature review.

text: BRAF mutations play a well-established role in melanomagenesis; however, without additional genetic alterations, tumor development is restricted by oncogene-induced senescence (OIS).
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: Here, we show that mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene cooperate with BRAF mutations in melanomagenesis by preventing OIS.
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: In a genetically engineered mouse model, Nf1 mutations suppress Braf-induced senescence, promote melanocyte hyperproliferation, and enhance melanoma development.
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: Nf1 mutations function by deregulating both phosphoinositide 3-kinase and extracellular signal-regulated kinase pathways.
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: As such, Nf1/Braf-mutant tumors are resistant to BRAF inhibitors but are sensitive to combined inhibition of mitogen-activated protein/extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase and mTOR.
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: Importantly, NF1 is mutated or suppressed in human melanomas that harbor concurrent BRAF mutations, NF1 ablation decreases the sensitivity of melanoma cell lines to BRAF inhibitors, and NF1 is lost in tumors from patients following treatment with these agents.
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: Collectively, these studies provide mechanistic insight into how NF1 cooperates with BRAF mutations in melanoma and show that NF1/neurofibromin inactivation may have an impact on responses to targeted therapies.
title: Elucidating distinct roles for NF1 in melanomagenesis.

text: We evaluated the frequency, genetic architecture, clinico-pathologic features and prognostic impact of RUNX1 mutations in 2439 adult patients with newly-diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: RUNX1 mutations were found in 245 of 2439 (10%) patients; were almost mutually exclusive of AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; and they co-occurred with a complex pattern of gene mutations, frequently involving mutations in epigenetic modifiers (ASXL1, IDH2, KMT2A, EZH2), components of the spliceosome complex (SRSF2, SF3B1) and STAG2, PHF6, BCOR.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: RUNX1 mutations were associated with older age (16-59 years: 8.5%; 60 years: 15.1%), male gender, more immature morphology and secondary AML evolving from myelodysplastic syndrome.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: In univariable analyses, RUNX1 mutations were associated with inferior event-free (EFS, P<0.0001), relapse-free (RFS, P=0.0007) and overall survival (OS, P<0.0001) in all patients, remaining significant when age was considered.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: In multivariable analysis, RUNX1 mutations predicted for inferior EFS (P=0.01).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: The effect of co-mutation varied by partner gene, where patients with the secondary genotypes RUNX1(mut)/ASXL1(mut) (OS, P=0.004), RUNX1(mut)/SRSF2(mut) (OS, P=0.007) and RUNX1(mut)/PHF6(mut) (OS, P=0.03) did significantly worse, whereas patients with the genotype RUNX1(mut)/IDH2(mut) (OS, P=0.04) had a better outcome.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: In conclusion, RUNX1-mutated AML is associated with a complex mutation cluster and is correlated with distinct clinico-pathologic features and inferior prognosis.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia are associated with distinct clinico-pathologic and genetic features.

text: Germline mutations in the human breast cancer genes BRCA1 and BRCA2 account for a substantial proportion of familial, early-onset breast and ovarian cancers.
title: A novel BRCA1 mutation in a patient with breast and ovarian cancer: A case report.

text: The present study reports a novel disease-causing BRCA1 mutation, nucleotide 3020insCT/c.2901insCT, in a 55-year-old Spanish female with breast and ovarian cancer.
title: A novel BRCA1 mutation in a patient with breast and ovarian cancer: A case report.

text: This frameshift mutation creates a premature stop codon at amino acid 1000, leading to a truncated BRCA1 protein.
title: A novel BRCA1 mutation in a patient with breast and ovarian cancer: A case report.

text: To the best of our knowledge, this mutation has not been previously described in the Breast Cancer Information Core (BIC) database or the published literature.
title: A novel BRCA1 mutation in a patient with breast and ovarian cancer: A case report.

text: BACKGROUND: Once metastasized, despite a variety of therapeutic options, the prognosis of patients with malignant melanoma (MM) is still poor.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: Therefore, the search for reliable markers to identify patients with high risk of disease progression is of high clinical importance.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: We have recently shown that TT genotypes of the single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) T393C in the gene GNAS1 are significantly associated with better outcome in a variety of carcinomas.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: - PATIENTS: In the present study we assessed whether the T393C SNP is also related to the clinical course in MM.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: 328 patients with MM were retrospectively genotyped and genotypes were correlated with clinical outcome.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: - RESULTS: While the allele frequency in the MM group (fC 0.52) did not significantly differ from that of healthy blood donors, the T393C SNP was associated with tumor progression of MM.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: Carriers of the C-allele showed a significantly more severe tumor progression as estimated from the time period to develop metastasis (HR 2.2, 95% CI 1.1-3.2, p = 0.017).
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: Proportions of 5-year metastasis-free intervals were 87.1% for TT genotypes and 66.0% for C-allele carriers.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: Moreover, multivariable Cox regression analysis including tumor stage and melanoma subtype proved the T393C polymorphism to be an independent factor for metastasis (p = 0.012).
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: - CONCLUSIONS: In summary, the GNAS1 T393C SNP represents a genetic host factor for predicting tumor progression also in patients with MM; genotyping of this SNP may contribute to better define patients who could benefit from an early individualized therapy.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with malignant melanoma.

text: Cellular senescence is emerging as an important in vivo anticancer response elicited by multiple stresses, including currently used chemotherapeutic drugs.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: Nutlin-3a is a recently discovered small-molecule antagonist of the p53-destabilizing protein murine double minute-2 (MDM2) that induces cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in cancer cells with functional p53.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: Here, we report that nutlin-3a induces cellular senescence in murine primary fibroblasts, oncogenically transformed fibroblasts, and fibrosarcoma cell lines.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: No evidence of drug-induced apoptosis was observed in any case.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: Nutlin-induced senescence was strictly dependent on the presence of functional p53 as revealed by the fact that cells lacking p53 were completely insensitive to the drug, whereas cells lacking the tumor suppressor alternative reading frame product of the CDKN2A locus underwent irreversible cell cycle arrest.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: Interestingly, irreversibility was achieved in neoplastic cells faster than in their corresponding parental primary cells, suggesting that nutlin-3a and oncogenic signaling cooperate in activating p53.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: Our current results suggest that senescence could be a major cellular outcome of cancer therapy by antagonists of the p53-MDM2 interaction, such as nutlin-3a.
title: Induction of p53-dependent senescence by the MDM2 antagonist nutlin-3a in mouse cells of fibroblast origin.

text: PURPOSE: Recent studies have shown activating KIT mutations in melanoma originating from mucosa, acral, or cumulative sun-damaged skin sites.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: We aimed to assess the predictive role of KIT mutation, amplification, or overexpression for response to treatment with the kinase inhibitor sunitinib.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumor tissues from 90 patients with stage III or IV acral, mucosal, or cumulative sun-damaged skin melanoma underwent sequencing of KIT, BRAF, NRAS, and GNAQ genes, FISH analysis for KIT amplification, and immunohistochemistry of KIT protein (CD117).
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: Patients with mutations, amplifications, or overexpression of KIT were treated with sunitinib and responses measured by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST).
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: RESULTS: Eleven percent of the melanomas tested had mutations in KIT, 23% in BRAF, 14% in NRAS, and none in GNAQ.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: Of 12 patients treated with sunitinib, 10 were evaluable.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: Of the 4 evaluable patients with KIT mutations, 1 had a complete remission for 15 months and 2 had partial responses (1- and 7-month duration).
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: In contrast, only 1 of the 6 patients with only KIT amplification or overexpression alone had a partial response.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: In 1 responder with rectal melanoma who later progressed, the recurring tumor had a previously undetected mutation in NRAS, which was found in addition to the persisting mutation in KIT.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: Interestingly, among patients with manifest stage IV disease, KIT mutations were associated with a significantly shortened survival time (P < 0.0001).
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Sunitinib may have activity in patients with melanoma and KIT mutations; more study is needed.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: KIT mutations may represent an adverse prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.
title: Sunitinib therapy for melanoma patients with KIT mutations.

text: High-Grade Serous Ovarian Carcinoma (HGSOC) is the predominant histotype of epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC), characterized by advanced stage at diagnosis, frequent TP53 mutation, rapid progression, and high responsiveness to platinum-based-chemotherapy.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: To date, standard first-line-chemotherapy in advanced EOC includes platinum salts and paclitaxel with or without bevacizumab.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: The major prognostic factor is the response duration from the end of the platinum-based treatment (platinum-free interval) and about 10-0 % of EOC patients bear a platinum-refractory disease or develop early resistance (platinum-free interval shorter than 6 months).
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: On these bases, a careful selection of patients who could benefit from chemotherapy is recommended to avoid unnecessary side effects and for a better disease outcome.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: In this retrospective study, an immunohistochemical evaluation of Aurora Kinase A (AURKA) was performed on 41 cases of HGSOC according to platinum-status.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: Taking into account the number and intensity of AURKA positive cells we built a predictive score able to discriminate with high accuracy platinum-sensitive patients from platinum-resistant patients (p < 0.001).
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: Furthermore, we observed that AURKA overexpression correlates to worse overall survival (p = 0.001; HR 0.14).
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: We here suggest AURKA as new effective tool to predict the biological behavior of HGSOC.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: Particularly, our results indicate that AURKA has a role both as predictor of platinum-resistance and as prognostic factor, that deserves further investigation in prospective clinical trials.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: Indeed, in the era of personalized medicine, AURKA could assist the clinicians in selecting the best treatment and represent, at the same time, a promising new therapeutic target in EOC treatment.
title: Aurora Kinase A expression predicts platinum-resistance and adverse outcome in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma patients.

text: PURPOSE: EML4-ALK fusions define a subset of lung cancers that can be effectively treated with anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) inhibitors.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: Unfortunately, the duration of response is heterogeneous and acquired resistance limits their ultimate efficacy.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: Thus, a better understanding of resistance mechanisms will help to enhance tumor control in EML4-ALK-positive tumors.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: By applying orthogonal functional mutagenesis screening approaches, we screened for mutations inducing resistance to the aminopyridine PF02341066 (crizotinib) and/or the diaminopyrimidine TAE684.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: Here, we show that the resistance mutation, L1196M, as well as other crizotinib resistance mutations (F1174L and G1269S), are highly sensitive to the structurally unrelated ALK inhibitor TAE684.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: In addition, we identified two novel EML4-ALK resistance mutations (L1198P and D1203N), which unlike previously reported mutations, induced resistance to both ALK inhibitors.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: An independent resistance screen in ALK-mutant neuroblastoma cells yielded the same L1198P resistance mutation but defined two additional mutations conferring resistance to TAE684 but not to PF02341066.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our results show that different ALK resistance mutations as well as different ALK inhibitors impact the therapeutic efficacy in the setting of EML4-ALK fusions and ALK mutations.
title: ALK mutations conferring differential resistance to structurally diverse ALK inhibitors.

text: Effective targeted cancer therapeutic development depends upon distinguishing disease-associated 'driver' mutations, which have causative roles in malignancy pathogenesis, from 'passenger' mutations, which are dispensable for cancer initiation and maintenance.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Translational studies of clinically active targeted therapeutics can definitively discriminate driver from passenger lesions and provide valuable insights into human cancer biology.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Activating internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutations in FLT3 (FLT3-ITD) are detected in approximately 20% of acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) patients and are associated with a poor prognosis.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Abundant scientific and clinical evidence, including the lack of convincing clinical activity of early FLT3 inhibitors, suggests that FLT3-ITD probably represents a passenger lesion.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Here we report point mutations at three residues within the kinase domain of FLT3-ITD that confer substantial in vitro resistance to AC220 (quizartinib), an active investigational inhibitor of FLT3, KIT, PDGFRA, PDGFRB and RET; evolution of AC220-resistant substitutions at two of these amino acid positions was observed in eight of eight FLT3-ITD-positive AML patients with acquired resistance to AC220.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Our findings demonstrate that FLT3-ITD can represent a driver lesion and valid therapeutic target in human AML.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: AC220-resistant FLT3 kinase domain mutants represent high-value targets for future FLT3 inhibitor development efforts.
title: Validation of ITD mutations in FLT3 as a therapeutic target in human acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: INTRODUCTION: MET proto-oncogene, receptor tyrosine kinase gene (MET) exon 14 skipping is a targetable alteration in lung cancer.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: Treatment with MET proto-oncogene, receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor can cause dramatic responses in patients whose cancers have MET exon 14 skipping.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: Little is known, however, about acquired resistance in patients with MET exon 14 skipping.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: METHODS: Biopsy specimens obtained at baseline and at the time of progression for a patient being treated with crizotinib were compared using targeted next-generation sequencing to assess for mechanisms of resistance.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: RESULTS: An acquired mutation in the MET kinase domain, D1228N, was found at time of progression on crizotinib in a patient with MET exon 14 skipping.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: CONCLUSIONS: One potential mechanism of acquired resistance to crizotinib in patients with MET exon 14 skipping is through second-site mutations in the MET gene.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: Understanding mechanisms of resistance will be important in optimizing therapy in these patients.
title: Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in NSCLC with MET Exon 14 Skipping.

text: BACKGROUND: Non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) harboring the anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene (ALK) rearrangement is sensitive to the ALK inhibitor crizotinib, but resistance invariably develops.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Ceritinib (LDK378) is a new ALK inhibitor that has shown greater antitumor potency than crizotinib in preclinical studies.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: In this phase 1 study, we administered oral ceritinib in doses of 50 to 750 mg once daily to patients with advanced cancers harboring genetic alterations in ALK.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In an expansion phase of the study, patients received the maximum tolerated dose.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Patients were assessed to determine the safety, pharmacokinetic properties, and antitumor activity of ceritinib.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Tumor biopsies were performed before ceritinib treatment to identify resistance mutations in ALK in a group of patients with NSCLC who had had disease progression during treatment with crizotinib.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: A total of 59 patients were enrolled in the dose-escalation phase.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The maximum tolerated dose of ceritinib was 750 mg once daily; dose-limiting toxic events included diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, elevated aminotransferase levels, and hypophosphatemia.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: This phase was followed by an expansion phase, in which an additional 71 patients were treated, for a total of 130 patients overall.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among 114 patients with NSCLC who received at least 400 mg of ceritinib per day, the overall response rate was 58% (95% confidence interval [CI], 48 to 67).
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among 80 patients who had received crizotinib previously, the response rate was 56% (95% CI, 45 to 67).
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Responses were observed in patients with various resistance mutations in ALK and in patients without detectable mutations.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among patients with NSCLC who received at least 400 mg of ceritinib per day, the median progression-free survival was 7.0 months (95% CI, 5.6 to 9.5).
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Ceritinib was highly active in patients with advanced, ALK-rearranged NSCLC, including those who had had disease progression during crizotinib treatment, regardless of the presence of resistance mutations in ALK.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: (Funded by Novartis Pharmaceuticals and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01283516.
title: Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.
Ceritinib in ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Neomorphic mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1) are driver mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and other cancers.
title: New IDH1 mutant inhibitors for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We report the development of new allosteric inhibitors of mutant IDH1.
title: New IDH1 mutant inhibitors for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Crystallographic and biochemical results demonstrated that compounds of this chemical series bind to an allosteric site and lock the enzyme in a catalytically inactive conformation, thereby enabling inhibition of different clinically relevant IDH1 mutants.
title: New IDH1 mutant inhibitors for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Treatment of IDH1 mutant primary AML cells uniformly led to a decrease in intracellular 2-HG, abrogation of the myeloid differentiation block and induction of granulocytic differentiation at the level of leukemic blasts and more immature stem-like cells, in vitro and in vivo.
title: New IDH1 mutant inhibitors for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Molecularly, treatment with the inhibitors led to a reversal of the DNA cytosine hypermethylation patterns caused by mutant IDH1 in the cells of individuals with AML.
title: New IDH1 mutant inhibitors for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Our study provides proof of concept for the molecular and biological activity of novel allosteric inhibitors for targeting different mutant forms of IDH1 in leukemia.
title: New IDH1 mutant inhibitors for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the most frequent cause of cancer deaths worldwide; nearly half contain mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase/RAS pathway.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Here we show that RAS-pathway mutant NSCLC cells depend on the transcription factor GATA2.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Loss of GATA2 reduced the viability of NSCLC cells with RAS-pathway mutations, whereas wild-type cells were unaffected.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Integrated gene expression and genome occupancy analyses revealed GATA2 regulation of the proteasome, and IL-1-signaling, and Rho-signaling pathways.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: These pathways were functionally significant, as reactivation rescued viability after GATA2 depletion.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In a Kras-driven NSCLC mouse model, Gata2 loss dramatically reduced tumor development.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Furthermore, Gata2 deletion in established Kras mutant tumors induced striking regression.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Although GATA2 itself is likely undruggable, combined suppression of GATA2-regulated pathways with clinically approved inhibitors caused marked tumor clearance.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Discovery of the nononcogene addiction of KRAS mutant lung cancers to GATA2 presents a network of druggable pathways for therapeutic exploitation.
title: The GATA2 transcriptional network is requisite for RAS oncogene-driven non-small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Promoter methylation of O(6)-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) is an important predictive biomarker in glioblastoma.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: The T variant of the MGMT promoter-enhancer single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP; rs16906252) has been associated with the presence of MGMT promoter methylation in other cancers.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: We examined the association of the T allele of rs16906252 with glioblastoma development, tumor MGMT methylation, MGMT protein expression, and survival outcomes.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: METHODS: Two independent temozolomide-treated glioblastoma cohorts-one Australian (Australian Genomics and Clinical Outcomes of Glioma, n = 163) and the other American (University of California Los Angeles/Kaiser Permanente Los Angeles, n = 159)-were studied.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: Allelic bisulphite sequencing was used to determine if methylation was specific to the T allele.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: Additionally, we compared the incidence of the T allele between glioblastoma cases and matched controls to assess whether it was a risk factor for developing MGMT methylated glioblastoma.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: RESULTS: Carriage of the T allele of the rs16906252 SNP was associated with both MGMT methylation and low MGMT protein expression and predicted significantly longer survival in temozolomide-treated patients with both MGMT methylated and nonmethylated glioblastoma.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: Methylation was linked to the T allele, inferring that the T variant plays a key role in the acquisition of MGMT methylation.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: Carriage of the T allele was associated with a significantly elevated risk of developing glioblastoma (adjusted odds ratio, 1.96; P = .013), increasing further when glioblastoma was classified by the presence of MGMT methylation (adjusted odds ratio, 2.86; P = .001).
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The T allele of the rs16906252 SNP is a key determinant in the acquisition of MGMT methylation in glioblastoma.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: Temozolomide-treated patients with the rs16906252 T genotype have better survival, irrespective of tumor methylation status.
title: The MGMT promoter SNP rs16906252 is a risk factor for MGMT methylation in glioblastoma and is predictive of response to temozolomide.

text: EGFR-mutated lung adenocarcinomas routinely develop resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI).
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: To better characterize the relative frequencies of the resistance mechanisms, we analyzed 48 EGFR-mutated TKI-resistant specimens from 41 patients.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Next-generation sequencing of post-treatment specimens detected EGFR p.T790M in 31 (79%) of 39 patients, PIK3CA mutations in 10 (26%), EGFR p.S768_V769delinsIL in one, and KRAS p.G12C in one.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Five PIK3CA mutations were outside of codons 542, 545, and 1047.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Three of four pre-treatment specimens did not carry the PIK3CA mutation found in the post-treatment sample.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Small cell carcinoma transformation was identified in four patients; none had p.T790M, including two where p.T790M was identified in the co-existing adenocarcinoma.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: In p.T790M-mutated specimens, the allele frequency was less than 5% in 24% of cases.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: p.T790M allele frequency was usually lower than that of the sensitizing mutation indicating that the resistance mutation was present either in a subset of cells or, if the sensitizing mutation was amplified, in a subset of the sensitizing alleles of a dominant clone.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Eight patients had multiple resistance mutations, suggesting either multiple separate resistant clones or a single clone harboring multiple resistance mechanisms.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: PIK3CA mutations appear to be a more significant resistance mechanism than previously recognized.
title: Heterogeneity of resistance mutations detectable by nextgeneration sequencing in TKI-treated lung adenocarcinoma.

text: The classification of epithelioid vascular tumors remains challenging, as there is considerable morphological overlap between tumor subtypes, across the spectrum from benign to malignant categories.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: A t(1;3)(p36.3;q25) translocation was reported in two cases of epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (EHE), however, no follow-up studies have been performed to identify the gene fusion or to assess its prevalence in a larger cohort of patients.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: We undertook a systematic molecular analysis of 17 EHE, characterized by classic morphological and immunophenotypic features, from various anatomical locations and with different malignant potential.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: For comparison, we analyzed 13 epithelioid hemangiomas, five epithelioid angiosarcomas, and four epithelioid sarcoma-like EHE.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.
