text: A fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) positional cloning strategy, spanning the cytogenetically defined regions on chromosomes 1p36.3 and 3q25, confirmed rearrangements in two candidate genes from these loci in all EHE cases tested.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: None of the other benign or malignant epithelioid vascular tumors examined demonstrated these abnormalities.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: Subsequent reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) confirmed in three EHE the WWTR1-CAMTA1 fusion product.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: CAMTA1 and WWTR1 have been previously shown to play important roles in oncogenesis.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: Our results demonstrate the presence of a WWTR1-CAMTA1 fusion in all EHE tested from bone, soft tissue, and visceral location (liver, lung) in keeping with a unique and specific pathological entity.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: Thus, FISH or RT-PCR analysis for the presence of WWTR1-CAMTA1 fusion may serve as a useful molecular diagnostic tool in challenging diagnoses.
title: A novel WWTR1-CAMTA1 gene fusion is a consistent abnormality in epithelioid hemangioendothelioma of different anatomic sites.

text: UNLABELLED: Entrectinib is a first-in-class pan-TRK kinase inhibitor currently undergoing clinical testing in colorectal cancer and other tumor types.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: A patient with metastatic colorectal cancer harboring an LMNA-NTRK1 rearrangement displayed a remarkable response to treatment with entrectinib, which was followed by the emergence of resistance.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: To characterize the molecular bases of the patient's relapse, circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) was collected longitudinally during treatment, and a tissue biopsy, obtained before entrectinib treatment, was transplanted in mice (xenopatient), which then received the same entrectinib regimen until resistance developed.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Genetic profiling of ctDNA and xenopatient samples showed acquisition of two point mutations in the catalytic domain of NTRK1, p.G595R and p.G667C.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Biochemical and pharmacologic analysis in multiple preclinical models confirmed that either mutation renders the TRKA kinase insensitive to entrectinib.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: These findings can be immediately exploited to design next-generation TRKA inhibitors.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: We provide proof of principle that analyses of xenopatients (avatar) and liquid biopsies allow the identification of drug resistance mechanisms in parallel with clinical treatment of an individual patient.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: We describe for the first time that p.G595R and p.G667C TRKA mutations drive acquired resistance to entrectinib in colorectal cancers carrying NTRK1 rearrangements.
title: Acquired Resistance to the TRK Inhibitor Entrectinib in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Activating epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations are recognized biomarkers for patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) treated with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EGFR TKIs can also have activity against NSCLC without EGFR mutations, requiring the identification of additional relevant biomarkers.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Previous studies on tumor EGFR protein levels and EGFR gene copy number revealed inconsistent results.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The aim of the study was to identify novel biomarkers of the response to TKIs in NSCLC by investigating whole genome expression at the exon-level.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: We used exon arrays and clinical samples from a previous trial (SAKK19/05) to investigate the expression variations at the exon-level of 3 genes potentially playing a key role in modulating treatment response: EGFR, V-Ki-ras2 Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog (KRAS) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGFA).
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: We identified the expression of EGFR exon 18 as a new predictive marker for patients with untreated metastatic NSCLC treated with bevacizumab and erlotinib in the first line setting.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The overexpression of EGFR exon 18 in tumor was significantly associated with tumor shrinkage, independently of EGFR mutation status.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: A similar significant association could be found in blood samples.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In conclusion, exonic EGFR expression particularly in exon 18 was found to be a relevant predictive biomarker for response to bevacizumab and erlotinib.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Based on these results, we propose a new model of EGFR testing in tumor and blood.
title: EGFR exon-level biomarkers of the response to bevacizumab/erlotinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) has received a great deal of attention in recent years for its role as a prognostic and predictive molecular marker of glioma.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: However, the results of studies examining its mutation frequency and predictive value are inconsistent, and several studies have investigated the association between TERT gene polymorphisms and gliomagenesis.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: We used a meta-analysis approach to examine these unsolved problems.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: A bibliography search using EMBASE and MEDLINE was performed to identify potentially relevant articles and conference abstracts that investigated TERT mutations in glioma.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: The references contained in the identified trials were also examined to identify any other relevant published or unpublished articles.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: Sixteen studies were included.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: Pooled estimates of the relative risks (RR), 95% confidence intervals (95% CI), hazard ratios (HR) and frequency were calculated.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: TERT mutations occurred frequently in glioblastoma (69%) and oligodendrogliomas (72%) but were less frequent in astrocytomas (24%) and oligoastrocytomas (38%).
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: The HR for glioma patients with TERT mutations versus wild type TERT was 1.63 (95% CI 1.35-1.98).
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: TERT polymorphisms were associated with an increased risk of glioma compared to controls (RR=1.28, 95% CI 1.23-1.33).
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: Our study shows that the TERT gene is a valuable prognostic and predictive biomarker of glioma, and TERT gene polymorphisms are significantly associated with an increased risk of glioma.
title: TERT mutation in glioma: Frequency, prognosis and risk.

text: BACKGROUND: Everolimus, an inhibitor of the mammalian target of rapamycin, shows promising antitumor activity when combined with trastuzumab and chemotherapy for human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer or when combined with endocrine agents for hormone receptor (HR)-positive tumors.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: However, data are limited regarding the effect of everolimus in combination with endocrine drugs in HER2-positive advanced breast cancer regardless of the HR status.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: CASE PRESENTATION: A 44-year-old female was diagnosed with recurrent HER2-positive breast cancer.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: The primary tumor was HR positive; however, the metastatic tumor was HR negative.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: The patient was resistant to classical chemotherapeutic agents and anti-HER2 treatment.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: Thus, the combination of everolimus and fulvestrant, a selective estrogen receptor downregulator, was chosen to reverse the resistance to anti-HER2 therapy.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: Indeed, the patient experienced long-term disease stabilization.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: Adverse events associated with the treatment were manageable by dose adjustments.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: We performed genetic testing of the metastatic tumor, which harbored a PIK3CA gene mutation but was positive for phosphatase and tensin homologue expression, which might result in resistance to the mammalian target of rapamycin inhibitor.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: CONCLUSION: This case study indicates that combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant might be a viable option for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer patients who are HER2 positive and carry a PIK3CA gene mutation but are resistant to anti-HER2 therapy and classical chemotherapeutic agents.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: Further prospective randomized trials are needed to confirm this finding.
title: Combined treatment with everolimus and fulvestrant reversed anti-HER2 resistance in a patient with refractory advanced breast cancer: a case report.

text: PURPOSE: We sought to identify predictive biomarkers for a novel nicotinamide phosphoribosyltransferase (NAMPT) inhibitor.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We use a NAMPT inhibitor, GNE-617, to evaluate nicotinic acid rescue status in a panel of more than 400 cancer cell lines.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: Using correlative analysis and RNA interference (RNAi), we identify a specific biomarker for nicotinic acid rescue status.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: We next determine the mechanism of regulation of expression of the biomarker.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: Finally, we develop immunohistochemical (IHC) and DNA methylation assays and evaluate cancer tissue for prevalence of the biomarker across indications.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: Nicotinate phosphoribosyltransferase (NAPRT1) is necessary for nicotinic acid rescue and its expression is the major determinant of rescue status.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: We demonstrate that NAPRT1 promoter methylation accounts for NAPRT1 deficiency in cancer cells, and NAPRT1 methylation is predictive of rescue status in cancer cell lines.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: Bisulfite next-generation sequencing mapping of the NAPRT1 promoter identified tumor-specific sites of NAPRT1 DNA methylation and enabled the development of a quantitative methylation-specific PCR (QMSP) assay suitable for use on archival formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor tissue.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Tumor-specific promoter hypermethylation of NAPRT1 inactivates one of two NAD salvage pathways, resulting in synthetic lethality with the coadministration of a NAMPT inhibitor.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: NAPRT1 expression is lost due to promoter hypermethylation in most cancer types evaluated at frequencies ranging from 5% to 65%.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: NAPRT1-specific immunohistochemical or DNA methylation assays can be used on archival formalin paraffin-embedded cancer tissue to identify patients likely to benefit from coadministration of a Nampt inhibitor and nicotinic acid.
title: Loss of NAPRT1 expression by tumor-specific promoter methylation provides a novel predictive biomarker for NAMPT inhibitors.

text: Despite compelling antitumour activity of antibodies targeting the programmed death 1 (PD-1): programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) immune checkpoint in lung cancer, resistance to these therapies has increasingly been observed.
title: Adaptive resistance to therapeutic PD-1 blockade is associated with upregulation of alternative immune checkpoints.

text: In this study, to elucidate mechanisms of adaptive resistance, we analyse the tumour immune microenvironment in the context of anti-PD-1 therapy in two fully immunocompetent mouse models of lung adenocarcinoma.
title: Adaptive resistance to therapeutic PD-1 blockade is associated with upregulation of alternative immune checkpoints.

text: In tumours progressing following response to anti-PD-1 therapy, we observe upregulation of alternative immune checkpoints, notably T-cell immunoglobulin mucin-3 (TIM-3), in PD-1 antibody bound T cells and demonstrate a survival advantage with addition of a TIM-3 blocking antibody following failure of PD-1 blockade.
title: Adaptive resistance to therapeutic PD-1 blockade is associated with upregulation of alternative immune checkpoints.

text: Two patients who developed adaptive resistance to anti-PD-1 treatment also show a similar TIM-3 upregulation in blocking antibody-bound T cells at treatment failure.
title: Adaptive resistance to therapeutic PD-1 blockade is associated with upregulation of alternative immune checkpoints.

text: These data suggest that upregulation of TIM-3 and other immune checkpoints may be targetable biomarkers associated with adaptive resistance to PD-1 blockade.
title: Adaptive resistance to therapeutic PD-1 blockade is associated with upregulation of alternative immune checkpoints.

text: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is a dominantly inherited familial cancer syndrome predisposing to a variety of malignant and benign neoplasms, most frequently retinal, cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastoma, renal cell carcinoma, phaeochromocytoma and pancreatic tumours.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: We have previously detected large germline deletions by Southern analysis and pulsed field gel electrophoresis in 19% and 3% of VHL patients respectively.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: We have now investigated 94 VHL patients without large deletions for intragenic mutations using single strand conformation polymorphism and heteroduplex analysis.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: Forty different mutations were identified in 55 unrelated kindreds.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: A wide variety of mutations were detected including missense (n = 19), nonsense (n = 6), frameshift deletions or insertions (n = 12), in frame deletions (n = 2) and a splice donor site mutation (n = 1).
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: The two most frequent mutations, were missense mutations at codon 238 (Arg-->Gln and Arg-->Trp) and were detected in five and four unrelated kindreds, respectively.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: VHL disease shows marked phenotypic variability and although phaeochromocytoma occurs in only about 7% of patients, marked interfamilial differences are observed.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: We examined the relationship between VHL gene mutations and phenotype in 65 kindreds.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: Large deletions or intragenic mutations predicted to cause a truncated protein were found in 36 of 53 families without phaeochromocytoma but only two of 12 families with phaeochromocytoma (chi 2 = 8.58; P < 0.01).
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: Of 12 families with phaeochromocytoma 10 had missense mutations compared with 13 of 53 kindreds without phaeochromocytoma (chi 2 = 12.33; P < 0.001).
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: In particular, substitution of an arginine at codon 238 (Arg-->Trp or Arg-->Gln) was associated with a high risk (62%) of phaeochromocytoma.
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: (ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)
title: Identification of intragenic mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene and correlation with disease phenotype.

text: BACKGROUND: We and other researchers have previously reported that pulmonary adenocarcinomas with epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations are usually sensitive to gefitinib, an EGFR-specific tyrosine kinase inhibitor, although this relationship is not complete.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: In this study, we searched for mutations or changes in the expression of genes downstream to EGFR and evaluated their relationship with the effectiveness of gefitinib.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: METHODS: We studied 78 lung cancer patients who had recurrent disease after surgical resection and were treated with gefitinib.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: We searched for mutations occurring in the KRAS and PIK3CA gene.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: We also evaluated the expression level of EGFR, PIK3CA, and PTEN by real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: Gefitinib effectiveness was evaluated by imaging studies; a survival analysis was also done.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: We found seven (9%) somatic mutations in KRAS and two (2%) in PIK3CA.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: EGFR mutations were present in 44 (56%).
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: KRAS mutations were found only in tumors without EGFR mutations, whereas PIK3CA mutation was found in tumors with EGFR mutation.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: Tumor response was assessable in 52 tumors.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: None of the six tumors with KRAS mutations responded to gefitinib treatment; however, two tumors with PIK3CA mutations showed partial response.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: Survival was significantly longer in patients with EGFR mutations or in those without KRAS mutations.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: In tumors with EGFR mutations, survival was longer in those with high PIK3CA or PTEN expression than in those with low expression of these molecules.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: An evaluation of the KRAS mutation, as well as PIK3CA and PTEN expression, might help identify lung cancer patients who are most suitable for gefitinib treatment.
title: PTEN and PIK3CA expression is associated with prolonged survival after gefitinib treatment in EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients.

text: UNLABELLED: Metastatic solid tumors are almost invariably fatal.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: Patients with disseminated small-cell cancers have a particularly unfavorable prognosis, with most succumbing to their disease within two years.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: Here, we report on the genetic and functional analysis of an outlier curative response of a patient with metastatic small-cell cancer to combined checkpoint kinase 1 (CHK1) inhibition and DNA-damaging chemotherapy.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: Whole-genome sequencing revealed a clonal hemizygous mutation in the Mre11 complex gene RAD50 that attenuated ATM signaling which in the context of CHK1 inhibition contributed, via synthetic lethality, to extreme sensitivity to irinotecan.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: As Mre11 mutations occur in a diversity of human tumors, the results suggest a tumor-specific combination therapy strategy in which checkpoint inhibition in combination with DNA-damaging chemotherapy is synthetically lethal in tumor cells but not normal cells with somatic mutations that impair Mre11 complex function.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: Strategies to effect deep and lasting responses to cancer therapy in patients with metastatic disease have remained difficult to attain, especially in early-phase clinical trials.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: Here, we present an in-depth genomic and functional genetic analysis identifying RAD50 hypomorphism as a contributing factor to a curative response to systemic combination therapy in a patient with recurrent, metastatic small-cell cancer.
title: Synthetic lethality in ATM-deficient RAD50-mutant tumors underlies outlier response to cancer therapy.

text: Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is a well-defined lymphoid malignancy characterized by a rapid clinical evolution and poor response to current therapeutic protocols.
title: Genetic and molecular pathogenesis of mantle cell lymphoma: perspectives for new targeted therapeutics.

text: The genetic and molecular mechanisms involved in its pathogenesis combine the dysregulation of cell proliferation and survival pathways with a high level of chromosome instability that seems related to the disruption of the DNA damage response pathway.
title: Genetic and molecular pathogenesis of mantle cell lymphoma: perspectives for new targeted therapeutics.

text: Understanding these mechanisms and how they affect tumour behaviour is providing the rationale for the identification of reliable predictors of clinical evolution and the design of innovative therapeutic strategies that could open new avenues for the treatment of patients with MCL.
title: Genetic and molecular pathogenesis of mantle cell lymphoma: perspectives for new targeted therapeutics.

text: Germline RUNX1 mutations result in a rare autosomal dominant condition characterized by qualitative and quantitative platelet defects and predisposition to the development of myeloid malignancies (familial platelet disorder with propensity to acute myeloid leukaemia, FPD/AML).
title: Clinical phenotype of germline RUNX1 haploinsufficiency: from point mutations to large genomic deletions.

text: Only 13 pedigrees have previously been described so far.
title: Clinical phenotype of germline RUNX1 haploinsufficiency: from point mutations to large genomic deletions.

text: We report on two novel germline RUNX1 mutations: (1) an out-of-frame 8 bp heterozygous deletion (c.442_449del) in an FPD/AML pedigree and (2) a de novo 3.5 Mb deletion in the 21q22.11.21q22.12 region encompassing the RUNX1 gene in a mentally retarded female patient with short stature and thrombocytopenia.
title: Clinical phenotype of germline RUNX1 haploinsufficiency: from point mutations to large genomic deletions.

text: Interestingly, a similar de novo submicroscopic deletion has been recently reported in the literature in a mentally retarded patient.
title: Clinical phenotype of germline RUNX1 haploinsufficiency: from point mutations to large genomic deletions.

text: Mental retardation is one of the most common disorders and primary causes of thrombocytopenia are rare.
title: Clinical phenotype of germline RUNX1 haploinsufficiency: from point mutations to large genomic deletions.

text: When occurring together, these features should prompt to test for 21q22 deletion for comprehensive genetic counselling and clinical management.
title: Clinical phenotype of germline RUNX1 haploinsufficiency: from point mutations to large genomic deletions.

text: Genetic alterations that activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAP kinase) pathway occur commonly in cancer.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: For example, the majority of melanomas harbor mutations in the BRAF oncogene, which are predicted to confer enhanced sensitivity to pharmacologic MAP kinase inhibition (e.g., RAF or MEK inhibitors).
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: We investigated the clinical relevance of MEK dependency in melanoma by massively parallel sequencing of resistant clones generated from a MEK1 random mutagenesis screen in vitro, as well as tumors obtained from relapsed patients following treatment with AZD6244, an allosteric MEK inhibitor.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: Most mutations conferring resistance to MEK inhibition in vitro populated the allosteric drug binding pocket or alpha-helix C and showed robust ( approximately 100-fold) resistance to allosteric MEK inhibition.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: Other mutations affected MEK1 codons located within or abutting the N-terminal negative regulatory helix (helix A), which also undergo gain-of-function germline mutations in cardio-facio-cutaneous (CFC) syndrome.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: One such mutation, MEK1(P124L), was identified in a resistant metastatic focus that emerged in a melanoma patient treated with AZD6244.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: Both MEK1(P124L) and MEK1(Q56P), which disrupts helix A, conferred cross-resistance to PLX4720, a selective B-RAF inhibitor.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: However, exposing BRAF-mutant melanoma cells to AZD6244 and PLX4720 in combination prevented emergence of resistant clones.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: These results affirm the importance of MEK dependency in BRAF-mutant melanoma and suggest novel mechanisms of resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibitors that may have important clinical implications.
title: MEK1 mutations confer resistance to MEK and B-RAF inhibition.

text: We identified a polyclonal CD8+ T-cell response against mutant KRAS G12D in tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes obtained from a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: T-Cell Transfer Therapy Targeting Mutant KRAS in Cancer.

text: We observed objective regression of all seven lung metastases after the infusion of approximately 1.11x10(11) HLA-C*08:02-restricted tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes that were composed of four different T-cell clonotypes that specifically targeted KRAS G12D.
title: T-Cell Transfer Therapy Targeting Mutant KRAS in Cancer.

text: However, one of these lesions had progressed on evaluation 9 months after therapy.
title: T-Cell Transfer Therapy Targeting Mutant KRAS in Cancer.

text: The lesion was resected and found to have lost the chromosome 6 haplotype encoding the HLA-C*08:02 class I major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule.
title: T-Cell Transfer Therapy Targeting Mutant KRAS in Cancer.

text: The loss of expression of this molecule provided a direct mechanism of tumor immune evasion.
title: T-Cell Transfer Therapy Targeting Mutant KRAS in Cancer.

text: Thus, the infusion of CD8+ cells targeting mutant KRAS mediated effective antitumor immunotherapy against a cancer that expressed mutant KRAS G12D and HLA-C*08:02.
title: T-Cell Transfer Therapy Targeting Mutant KRAS in Cancer.

text: The associations of mutations in the enhancer of trithorax and polycomb family gene ASXL1 with pretreatment patient characteristics, outcomes, and gene-/microRNA-expression profiles in primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML) are unknown.
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: We analyzed 423 adult patients for ASXL1 mutations, other prognostic gene mutations, and gene-/microRNA-expression profiles.
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: ASXL1 mutations were 5 times more common in older (>/= 60 years) patients (16.2%) than those younger than 60 years (3.2%; P < .001).
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: Among older patients, ASXL1 mutations associated with wild-type NPM1 (P < .001), absence of FLT3-internal tandem duplications (P = .002), mutated CEBPA (P = .01), and with inferior complete remission (CR) rate (P = .04), disease-free survival (DFS; P = .03), overall survival (OS; P = .006), and event-free survival (EFS; P = .002).
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: Within the European LeukemiaNet (ELN) genetic categories of older CN-AML, ASXL1 mutations associated with inferior CR rate (P = .02), OS (P < .001), and EFS (P < .001) among ELN Favorable, but not among ELN Intermediate-I patients.
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: Multivariable analyses confirmed associations of ASXL1 mutations with unfavorable CR rate (P = .03), DFS (P < .001), OS (P < .001), and EFS (P < .001) among ELN Favorable patients.
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: We identified an ASXL1 mutation-associated gene-expression signature, but no microRNA-expression signature.
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: This first study of ASXL1 mutations in primary CN-AML demonstrates that ASXL1-mutated older patients, particularly within the ELN Favorable group, have unfavorable outcomes and may be candidates for experimental treatment approaches.
title: ASXL1 mutations identify a high-risk subgroup of older patients with primary cytogenetically normal AML within the ELN Favorable genetic category.

text: OBJECTIVES: Although T790M mutation is considered to be the major mechanism of acquired resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), its clinical implication remains undetermined.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: METHODS: Post-progression tumor specimens were prospectively collected for T790M mutation analysis in NSCLC patients with acquired resistance to initial EGFR TKIs.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Clinical features were compared between patients with and without T790M.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: Out of 70 cases, 36 (51%) were identified to have T790M mutation in the rebiopsy specimen.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: There was no difference in the pattern of disease progression, progression-free survival for initial TKIs (12.8 and 11.3 months), post-progression survival (14.7 and 14.1 months), or overall survival (43.5 and 36.8 months) in patients with and without T790M.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: In total, 34 patients received afatinib after post-progression biopsy as a subsequent treatment, and the response rate was 18%.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: The median progression-free survival for afatinib was 3.7 months for the entire group, and 3.2 and 4.6 months for the groups with and without T790M, respectively (P = 0.33).
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The identification of T790M as acquired resistance mechanism was clinically feasible.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Although T790M had no prognostic or predictive role in the present study, further research is necessary to identify patients with T790M-mutant tumors who might benefit from newly developed T790M-specific TKIs.
title: Clinical implications of T790M mutation in patients with acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Approximately 25% of breast cancers overexpress and depend on the receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB2, one of 4 ERBB family members.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: Targeted therapies directed against ERBB2 have been developed and used clinically, but many patients continue to develop resistance to such therapies.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: Although much effort has been focused on elucidating the mechanisms of acquired resistance to ERBB2-targeted therapies, the involvement of ERBB4 remains elusive and controversial.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: We demonstrate that genetic ablation of ERBB4, but not ERBB1-3, led to apoptosis in lapatinib-resistant cells, suggesting that the efficacy of pan-ERBB inhibitors was, at least in part, mediated by the inhibition of ERBB4.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: Moreover, ERBB4 was upregulated at the protein level in ERBB2+ breast cancer cell lines selected for acquired lapatinib resistance in vitro and in MMTV-Neu mice following prolonged lapatinib treatment.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: Knockdown of ERBB4 caused a decrease in AKT phosphorylation in resistant cells but not in sensitive cells, suggesting that ERBB4 activated the PI3K/AKT pathway in lapatinib-resistant cells.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: Importantly, ERBB4 knockdown triggered apoptosis not only in lapatinib-resistant cells but also in trastuzumab-resistant cells.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: Our results suggest that although ERBB4 is dispensable for naive ERBB2+ breast cancer cells, it may play a key role in the survival of ERBB2+ cancer cells after they develop resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors, lapatinib and trastuzumab.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinase ERBB4 mediates acquired resistance to ERBB2 inhibitors in breast cancer cells.

text: The majority of lung adenocarcinomas express the lineage-specific thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1).
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: We recently reported that in a subset of lung adenocarcinomas the TTF-1 gene is amplified.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Although the prognostic significance of TTF-1 expression has been previously investigated, the significance of TTF-1 amplification has not been established.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: We studied 89 consecutive patients with lung adenocarcinomas treated by surgery at Brigham and Women's Hospital between 1997 and 1999 and performed immunohistochemical analysis for TTF-1 expression and fluorescence in situ hybridization for TTF-1 amplification.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: We investigated associations between clinical-pathological characteristics, TTF-1 expression, TTF-1 amplification and overall survival.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: TTF-1 expression was categorized as high (48%), low (24%) or absent (28%).
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: TTF-1 was amplified in 7% of cases.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Patients with adenocarcinomas with low or high TTF-1 expression had a significantly better outcome than those with absent TTF-1 expression (median overall survival times of 72.4, 77.8 and 30.5 months, respectively, P = 0.002).
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: In contrast, patients with adenocarcinomas with TTF-1 expression had a worse outcome if TTF-1 was amplified (median overall survival time 39.5 versus 87.5 months).
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: In multivariate analysis, improved overall survival was independently predicted by TTF-1 expression in combination with no TTF-1 amplification (P < 0.001).
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: In patients with lung adenocarcinoma, TTF-1 expression is a predictor of good outcome.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Patients with no TTF-1 expression or TTF-1 expression and TTF-1 gene amplification tend to have a significantly worse prognosis than patients with TTF-1 expression and no TTF-1 gene amplification.
title: Clinical significance of TTF-1 protein expression and TTF-1 gene amplification in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: We sought to determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of patients with lung cancer harboring NRAS mutations.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: We used preclinical models to identify targeted therapies likely to be of benefit against NRAS-mutant lung cancer cells.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We reviewed clinical data from patients whose lung cancers were identified at six institutions or reported in the Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer (COSMIC) to harbor NRAS mutations.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: Six NRAS-mutant cell lines were screened for sensitivity against inhibitors of multiple kinases (i.e., EGFR, ALK, MET, IGF-1R, BRAF, PI3K, and MEK).
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: RESULTS: Among 4,562 patients with lung cancers tested, NRAS mutations were present in 30 (0.7%; 95% confidence interval, 0.45%-0.94%); 28 of these had no other driver mutations.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: 83% had adenocarcinoma histology with no significant differences in gender.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: While 95% of patients were former or current smokers, smoking-related G:C>T:A transversions were significantly less frequent in NRAS-mutated lung tumors than KRAS-mutant non-small cell lung cancer [NSCLC; NRAS: 13% (4/30), KRAS: 66% (1772/2733), P < 0.00000001].
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: Five of 6 NRAS-mutant cell lines were sensitive to the MEK inhibitors, selumetinib and trametinib, but not to other inhibitors tested.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: CONCLUSION: NRAS mutations define a distinct subset of lung cancers ( approximately 1%) with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: Although NRAS mutations are more common in current/former smokers, the types of mutations are not those classically associated with smoking.
title: Characteristics of lung cancers harboring NRAS mutations.

text: BACKGROUND: The impact of BRAF tumor mutations on the natural course of disease of melanoma patients is controversial.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We analyzed the mutational status and overall survival of 215 patients receiving treatment with dacarbazine or temozolomide.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: All patients who started first-line treatment at our institution between 2000 and 2010 were included to prevent selection and bias due to thereafter arising therapeutic options.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: RESULTS: No patient received BRAF- or MEK-inhibitors during follow-up.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: Survival was associated with the pattern of visceral involvement, the presence of brain metastases and the serum lactate dehydrogenase level (all p<0.001).
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: The BRAF-V600 mutational status was not associated with survival and no differences in overall survival were detected according to age, gender or to the cytotoxic agent used for therapy.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: In Cox regression analysis the presence of brain metastases (hazard ratio 2.3; p<0.001) and an elevated serum LDH (hazard ratio 2.5; p<0.001) were the only factors, which independently predicted survival.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: No differences in prognosis were observed according to the BRAF mutational status in patients with distant metastasis treated with monochemotherapy.
title: BRAF-V600 mutations have no prognostic impact in stage IV melanoma patients treated with monochemotherapy.

text: IMPORTANCE: The Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitor ibrutinib is effective in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Reasons for discontinuing therapy with this drug and outcomes following discontinuation have not been evaluated outside of clinical trials with relatively short follow-up.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: OBJECTIVE: To determine features associated with discontinuation of ibrutinib therapy and outcomes.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: A total of 308 patients participating in 4 sequential trials of ibrutinib at The Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center were included.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: These clinical trials accrued patients included in this analysis from May 2010 until April 2014, and data were locked in June 2014.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Patients were evaluated for time to therapy discontinuation, reasons for discontinuation, and survival following discontinuation.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: For patients who discontinued therapy because of disease progression, targeted deep sequencing was performed in samples at baseline and time of relapse.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: RESULTS: With a median follow-up of 20 months, 232 patients remained on therapy, 31 had discontinued because of disease progression, and 45 had discontinued for other reasons.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Disease progression includes Richter's transformation (RT) or progressive CLL.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Richter's transformation appeared to occur early and CLL progressions later (cumulative incidence at 12 months, 4.5% [95% CI, 2.0%-7.0%] and 0.3% [95% CI, 0%-1.0%], respectively).
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Median survival following RT was 3.5 months (95% CI, 0.3-6.0 months) and 17.6 months (95% CI, 4.7 months-"not reached") following CLL progression.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Sequencing on peripheral blood from 8 patients with RT revealed 2 with mutations in BTK, and a lymph node sample showed no mutations in BTK or PLCG2.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Deep sequencing on 11 patients with CLL progression revealed BTK or PLCG2 mutations in all.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: These mutations were not identified before treatment in any patient.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: This single-institution experience with ibrutinib confirms it to be an effective therapy and identifies, for the first time, baseline factors associated with ibrutinib therapy discontinuation.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Outcomes data show poor prognosis after discontinuation, especially for those patients with RT.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: Finally, sequencing data confirm initial reports associating mutations in BTK and PLCG2 with progression and clearly show that CLL progressions are associated with these mutations, while RT is likely not.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: TRIAL REGISTRATIONS: clinicaltrials.gov Identifiers:NCT01105247, NCT01217749, NCT01589302, and NCT01578707.
title: Etiology of Ibrutinib Therapy Discontinuation and Outcomes in Patients With Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia.

text: BRAF inhibitor (BRAFi) therapy leads to remarkable anti melanoma responses, but the initial tumor shrinkage is commonly incomplete, providing a nidus for subsequent disease progression.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: Adaptive signaling may underlie early BRAFi resistance and influence the selection pattern for genetic variants, causing late, acquired resistance.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: We show here that BRAFi (or BRAFi + MEKi) therapy in patients frequently led to rebound phosphorylated AKT (p-AKT) levels in their melanomas early on-treatment.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: In cell lines, BRAFi treatment led to rebound levels of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTK; including PDGFRbeta), phosphatidyl (3,4,5)-triphosphate (PIP3), pleckstrin homology domain recruitment, and p-AKT.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: PTEN expression limited this BRAFi-elicited PI3K-AKT signaling, which could be rescued by the introduction of a mutant AKT1 (Q79K) known to confer acquired BRAFi resistance.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: Functionally, AKT1(Q79K) conferred BRAFi resistance via amplification of BRAFi-elicited PI3K-AKT signaling.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: In addition, mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway inhibition enhanced clonogenic growth dependency on PI3K or AKT.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: Thus, adaptive or genetic upregulation of AKT critically participates in melanoma survival during BRAFi therapy.
title: A novel AKT1 mutant amplifies an adaptive melanoma response to BRAF inhibition.

text: Circadian clock systems regulate many biologic functions, including cell division and hormone secretion in mammals.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: In this study, we explored the effects of circadian control on the pivot cell growth regulatory mTOR, the activity of which is deregulated in tumor cells compared with normal cells.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Specifically, we investigated whether the antitumor effect of an mTOR inhibitor could be improved by changing its dosing schedule in RenCa tumor-bearing mice.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Active, phosphorylated mTOR displayed a 24-hour rhythm, and levels of total mTOR protein (but not mRNA) also showed a circadian rhythm in RenCa tumor masses.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Through investigations of the oscillation mechanism for mTOR expression, we identified the ubiquitination factor Fbxw7 as an mTOR regulator that oscillated in its expression in a manner opposite from mTOR.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Fbxw7 transcription was regulated by the circadian regulator D-site-binding protein.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Notably, administration of the mTOR inhibitor everolimus during periods of elevated mTOR improved survival in tumor-bearing mice.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Our findings demonstrate that the circadian oscillation of mTOR activity is regulated by circadian clock systems, which influence the antitumor effect of mTOR inhibitors.
title: Circadian regulation of mTOR by the ubiquitin pathway in renal cell carcinoma.

text: Recent work in human glioblastoma (GBM) has documented recurrent mutations in the histone chaperone protein ATRX.
title: ATRX loss promotes tumor growth and impairs nonhomologous end joining DNA repair in glioma.

text: We developed an animal model of ATRX-deficient GBM and showed that loss of ATRX reduces median survival and increases genetic instability.
title: ATRX loss promotes tumor growth and impairs nonhomologous end joining DNA repair in glioma.

text: Further, analysis of genome-wide data for human gliomas showed that ATRX mutation is associated with increased mutation rate at the single-nucleotide variant (SNV) level.
title: ATRX loss promotes tumor growth and impairs nonhomologous end joining DNA repair in glioma.

text: In mouse tumors, ATRX deficiency impairs nonhomologous end joining and increases sensitivity to DNA-damaging agents that induce double-stranded DNA breaks.
title: ATRX loss promotes tumor growth and impairs nonhomologous end joining DNA repair in glioma.

text: We propose that ATRX loss results in a genetically unstable tumor, which is more aggressive when left untreated but is more responsive to double-stranded DNA-damaging agents, resulting in improved overall survival.
title: ATRX loss promotes tumor growth and impairs nonhomologous end joining DNA repair in glioma.

text: PURPOSE: Efflux transporters of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family are major determinants of chemoresistance in tumor cells.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: This study examined associations between functional variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes in patients with epithelial ovarian/primary peritoneal cancer (EOC/PPC) following platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: METHODS: Sequenom iPLEXTMGOLD Assay and MALDI-TOF platform were used to genotype the non-synonymous G2677T/A (rs2032582; encoding Ala893Ser/Thr) and synonymous C3435T (rs1045642; encoding Ile1145Ile) variants in ABCB1, the non-synonymous G1249A variant in ABCC2 (rs2273697; encoding Val417Ile), and the non-synonymous C421A variant in ABCG2 (rs2231142; encoding Q141K, Gln141Lys) in normal DNA from up to 511 women in Gynecologic Oncology Group (GOG) phase III trials, GOG-172 or GOG-182.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) were analyzed in relation to genetic polymorphisms using Kaplan-Meier and Cox proportional hazards model.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: RESULTS: The C421A variant (CA+AA versus CC) in ABCG2 was associated with a 6-month longer median PFS (22.7 versus 16.8 months, p=0.041).
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: In multivariate analysis, patients with variant genotypes were at a reduced risk of disease progression (hazard ratio [HR]=0.75, 95% confidence interval [CI]=0.59-0.96, p=0.022).
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: The association between C421A and OS was not statistically significant (HR=0.88, 95% CI=0.67-1.15, p=0.356).
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: None of the other variants measured in either ABCB1 or ABCC2 was associated with PFS or OS.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: CONCLUSION: The C421A variant in ABCG2, previously shown to be associated with enhanced protein degradation and drug sensitivity, was associated with longer PFS in advanced stage EOC/PPC patents treated with platinum+taxane-based chemotherapy.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: This finding requires further validation.
title: Common variants in ABCB1, ABCC2 and ABCG2 genes and clinical outcomes among women with advanced stage ovarian cancer treated with platinum and taxane-based chemotherapy: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: PURPOSE: We performed this analysis to improve the understanding of the clinicopathological characteristics and clinical outcome of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients harboring the primary epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) T790M mutation along with activating EGFR mutation.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: METHODS: Resected tumors from 1903 NSCLC patients were analyzed for mutation in EGFR, as well as KRAS (Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog), BRAF (v-raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homolog B), HER2 (human epidermal growth factor 2), PIK3CA (phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate 3-kinase, catalytic subunit alpha), and EML4 (echinoderm microtubule associated protein like 4)-ALK (anaplastic lymphoma receptor tyrosine kinase) fusion.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Fluorescence in situ hybridization was performed to define EGFR and c-MET (met proto-oncogene gene amplification.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Expression of PIK3CA and p-Akt (phosphorylated protein kinase B) were tested using immunohistochemistry.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Clinical and pathological data, including sex, age at diagnosis, stage, tumor differentiation, smoking history, histological subtype, relapse-free and overall survival, were further analyzed.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: In all, 16 NSCLC patients were found to harbor primary EGFR T790M mutation, including 14 adenocarcinomas and two adenosquamous carcinomas, accounting for 2.04% of all the EGFR mutant cases and 0.84% of the total.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: No c-MET amplification was found to coexist with primary EGFR T790M.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Fewer EGFR copy-number variations were found in samples harboring EGFR T790M mutations compared with those in patients with exon 19 deletions and L858R.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Overall survival was significantly shorter for patients harboring EGFR T790M mutation than it was for patients with exon 19 deletions (logrank P=0.008).
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: When taking patients harboring EGFR L858R or exon 19 deletions as one group, the overall survival was also significantly longer than that in patients with T790M mutation (logrank P=0.012).
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: There was no significant difference in relapse-free survival among three subgroups of patients.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSION: Our study described the clinicopathological and molecular characteristics of NSCLC patients harboring primary EGFR T790M mutations.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Its value of being a predictor for worse prognosis was established.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Primary EGFR T790M mutation is a rare event in NSCLC cases, but the therapeutic strategies for this subtype of patients should be precisely considered.
title: Primary concomitant EGFR T790M mutation predicted worse prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: KRAS and BRAF activating mutations drive tumorigenesis through constitutive activation of the MAPK pathway.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: As these tumours represent an area of high unmet medical need, multiple allosteric MEK inhibitors, which inhibit MAPK signalling in both genotypes, are being tested in clinical trials.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: Impressive single-agent activity in BRAF-mutant melanoma has been observed; however, efficacy has been far less robust in KRAS-mutant disease.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: Here we show that, owing to distinct mechanisms regulating MEK activation in KRAS- versus BRAF-driven tumours, different mechanisms of inhibition are required for optimal antitumour activity in each genotype.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: Structural and functional analysis illustrates that MEK inhibitors with superior efficacy in KRAS-driven tumours (GDC-0623 and G-573, the former currently in phase I clinical trials) form a strong hydrogen-bond interaction with S212 in MEK that is critical for blocking MEK feedback phosphorylation by wild-type RAF.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: Conversely, potent inhibition of active, phosphorylated MEK is required for strong inhibition of the MAPK pathway in BRAF-mutant tumours, resulting in superior efficacy in this genotype with GDC-0973 (also known as cobimetinib), a MEK inhibitor currently in phase III clinical trials.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: Our study highlights that differences in the activation state of MEK in KRAS-mutant tumours versus BRAF-mutant tumours can be exploited through the design of inhibitors that uniquely target these distinct activation states of MEK.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: These inhibitors are currently being evaluated in clinical trials to determine whether improvements in therapeutic index within KRAS versus BRAF preclinical models translate to improved clinical responses in patients.
title: Mechanism of MEK inhibition determines efficacy in mutant KRAS- versus BRAF-driven cancers.

text: BACKGROUND: The anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) monoclonal antibodies (moAbs) cetuximab or panitumumab are administered to colorectal cancer (CRC) patients who harbor wild-type RAS proto-oncogenes.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: However, a percentage of patients do not respond to this treatment.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: In addition to mutations in the RAS genes, mutations in other genes, such as BRAF, PI3KCA, or PTEN, could be involved in the resistance to anti-EGFR moAb therapy.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: METHODS: In order to develop a comprehensive approach for the detection of mutations and to eventually identify other genes responsible for resistance to anti-EGFR moAbs, we investigated a panel of 21 genes by parallel sequencing on the Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine platform.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: We sequenced 65 CRCs that were treated with cetuximab or panitumumab.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: Among these, 37 samples were responsive and 28 were resistant.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: We confirmed that mutations in EGFR-pathway genes (KRAS, NRAS, BRAF, PI3KCA) were relevant for conferring resistance to therapy and could predict response (p = 0.001).
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: After exclusion of KRAS, NRAS, BRAF and PI3KCA combined mutations could still significantly associate to resistant phenotype (p = 0.045, by Fisher exact test).
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: In addition, mutations in FBXW7 and SMAD4 were prevalent in cases that were non-responsive to anti-EGFR moAb.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: After we combined the mutations of all genes (excluding KRAS), the ability to predict response to therapy improved significantly (p = 0.002, by Fisher exact test).
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The combination of mutations at KRAS and at the five gene panel demonstrates the usefulness and feasibility of multigene sequencing to assess response to anti-EGFR moAbs.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: The application of parallel sequencing technology in clinical practice, in addition to its innate ability to simultaneously examine the genetic status of several cancer genes, proved to be more accurate and sensitive than the presently in use traditional approaches.
title: Prediction of response to anti-EGFR antibody-based therapies by multigene sequencing in colorectal cancer patients.

text: BACKGROUND: The inhibition of poly(adenosine diphosphate [ADP]-ribose) polymerase (PARP) is a potential synthetic lethal therapeutic strategy for the treatment of cancers with specific DNA-repair defects, including those arising in carriers of a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: We conducted a clinical evaluation in humans of olaparib (AZD2281), a novel, potent, orally active PARP inhibitor.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: METHODS: This was a phase 1 trial that included the analysis of pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic characteristics of olaparib.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: Selection was aimed at having a study population enriched in carriers of a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: RESULTS: We enrolled and treated 60 patients; 22 were carriers of a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation and 1 had a strong family history of BRCA-associated cancer but declined to undergo mutational testing.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: The olaparib dose and schedule were increased from 10 mg daily for 2 of every 3 weeks to 600 mg twice daily continuously.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: Reversible dose-limiting toxicity was seen in one of eight patients receiving 400 mg twice daily (grade 3 mood alteration and fatigue) and two of five patients receiving 600 mg twice daily (grade 4 thrombocytopenia and grade 3 somnolence).
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: This led us to enroll another cohort, consisting only of carriers of a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation, to receive olaparib at a dose of 200 mg twice daily.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: Other adverse effects included mild gastrointestinal symptoms.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: There was no obvious increase in adverse effects seen in the mutation carriers.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: Pharmacokinetic data indicated rapid absorption and elimination; pharmacodynamic studies confirmed PARP inhibition in surrogate samples (of peripheral-blood mononuclear cells and plucked eyebrow-hair follicles) and tumor tissue.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: Objective antitumor activity was reported only in mutation carriers, all of whom had ovarian, breast, or prostate cancer and had received multiple treatment regimens.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Olaparib has few of the adverse effects of conventional chemotherapy, inhibits PARP, and has antitumor activity in cancer associated with the BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00516373.)
title: Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase in tumors from BRCA mutation carriers.

text: PURPOSE: To explore predictive factors for time to treatment failure (TTF) in chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients receiving gefitinib treatment.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We designed a phase II study to test gefitinib antitumor efficacy in advanced-stage, chemotherapy-naive NSCLC patients.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Patients were treated with gefitinib 250 mg/d.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Tumor assessments were performed every 2 months.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Responding or stable patients were treated until progression or unacceptable toxicity.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: All scans were reviewed independently.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: EGFR exons 18-21 sequence, K-ras exon 2 sequence, and MET gene copy numbers were examined in available samples.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Clinical or molecular predictors of TTF were examined by multivariate analysis.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: RESULTS: One hundred six patients were enrolled.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Ninety patients had tumor samples for biomarker tests.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Overall response rate was 50.9% (95% CI, 41.4% to 60.4%).
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: Median TTF was 5.5 months, and median overall survival (OS) was 22.4 months.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: The response rate and median TTF of the patients with exon 19 deletion (n = 20) were 95.0% and 8.9 months, for exon 21 L858R mutation (n = 23) were 73.9% and 9.1 month, and for other types of EGFR mutations (N = 12) were 16.7% and 2.3 months, respectively.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: In multivariate analysis, the presence of EGFR deletion exon 19 or L858R EGFR mutations in adenocarcinoma patients predicted longer TTF.
