title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: High copy number of MET seemed to correlate with shorter TTF in patients with gefitinib-sensitive activating EGFR mutations.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: CONCLUSION: In this prospective study, EGFR exon 19 deletion or L858R mutations in adenocarcinoma were the best predictors for longer TTF in stage IIIB/IV chemotherapy-naive NSCLC patients receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.
title: Specific EGFR mutations predict treatment outcome of stage IIIB/IV patients with chemotherapy-naive non-small-cell lung cancer receiving first-line gefitinib monotherapy.

text: The catalytic activities of covalent and ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling are central to regulating the conformational state of chromatin and the resultant transcriptional output.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: The enzymes that catalyze these activities are often contained within multiprotein complexes in nature.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: Two such multiprotein complexes, the polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) methyltransferase and the SWItch/Sucrose Non-Fermentable (SWI/SNF) chromatin remodeler have been reported to act in opposition to each other during development and homeostasis.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: An imbalance in their activities induced by mutations/deletions in complex members (e.g.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: SMARCB1) has been suggested to be a pathogenic mechanism in certain human cancers.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: Here we show that preclinical models of synovial sarcoma-a cancer characterized by functional SMARCB1 loss via its displacement from the SWI/SNF complex through the pathognomonic SS18-SSX fusion protein-display sensitivity to pharmacologic inhibition of EZH2, the catalytic subunit of PRC2.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: Treatment with tazemetostat, a clinical-stage, selective and orally bioavailable small-molecule inhibitor of EZH2 enzymatic activity reverses a subset of synovial sarcoma gene expression and results in concentration-dependent cell growth inhibition and cell death specifically in SS18-SSX fusion-positive cells in vitro.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: Treatment of mice bearing either a cell line or two patient-derived xenograft models of synovial sarcoma leads to dose-dependent tumor growth inhibition with correlative inhibition of trimethylation levels of the EZH2-specific substrate, lysine 27 on histone H3.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: These data demonstrate a dependency of SS18-SSX-positive, SMARCB1-deficient synovial sarcomas on EZH2 enzymatic activity and suggests the potential utility of EZH2-targeted drugs in these genetically defined cancers.
title: Preclinical Evidence of Anti-Tumor Activity Induced by EZH2 Inhibition in Human Models of Synovial Sarcoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Approximately 50% of melanomas harbor activating (V600) mutations in the serine-threonine protein kinase B-RAF (BRAF).
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: The oral BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib (PLX4032) frequently produced tumor regressions in patients with BRAF V600-mutant metastatic melanoma in a phase 1 trial and improved overall survival in a phase 3 trial.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: METHODS: We designed a multicenter phase 2 trial of vemurafenib in patients with previously treated BRAF V600-mutant metastatic melanoma to investigate the efficacy of vemurafenib with respect to overall response rate (percentage of treated patients with a tumor response), duration of response, and overall survival.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: The primary end point was the overall response rate as ascertained by the independent review committee; overall survival was a secondary end point.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: RESULTS: A total of 132 patients had a median follow-up of 12.9 months (range, 0.6 to 20.1).
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: The confirmed overall response rate was 53% (95% confidence interval [CI], 44 to 62; 6% with a complete response and 47% with a partial response), the median duration of response was 6.7 months (95% CI, 5.6 to 8.6), and the median progression-free survival was 6.8 months (95% CI, 5.6 to 8.1).
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: Primary progression was observed in only 14% of patients.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: Some patients had a response after receiving vemurafenib for more than 6 months.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: The median overall survival was 15.9 months (95% CI, 11.6 to 18.3).
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: The most common adverse events were grade 1 or 2 arthralgia, rash, photosensitivity, fatigue, and alopecia.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: Cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas (the majority, keratoacanthoma type) were diagnosed in 26% of patients.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Vemurafenib induces clinical responses in more than half of patients with previously treated BRAF V600-mutant metastatic melanoma.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: In this study with a long follow-up, the median overall survival was approximately 16 months.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: (Funded by Hoffmann-La Roche; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00949702.
title: Survival in BRAF V600-mutant advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.

text: Germline variants in the 3' untranslated region (3'UTR) of cancer genes disrupting microRNA (miRNA) regulation have recently been associated with cancer risk.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: A variant in the 3'UTR of the KRAS oncogene, referred to as the KRAS variant, is associated with both cancer risk and altered tumor biology.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Here, we test the hypothesis that the KRAS variant can act as a biomarker of outcome in epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC), and investigate the cause of altered outcome in KRAS variant-positive EOC patients.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: As this variant seems to be associated with tumor biology, we additionally test the hypothesis that this variant can be directly targeted to impact cell survival.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: EOC patients with complete clinical data were genotyped for the KRAS variant and analyzed for outcome (n=536), response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (n=125) and platinum resistance (n=306).
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Outcome was separately analyzed for women with known BRCA mutations (n=79).
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Gene expression was analyzed on a subset of tumors with available tissue.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Cell lines were used to confirm altered sensitivity to chemotherapy associated with the KRAS variant.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Finally, the KRAS variant was directly targeted through small-interfering RNA/miRNA oligonucleotides in cell lines and survival was measured.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Postmenopausal EOC patients with the KRAS variant were significantly more likely to die of ovarian cancer by multivariate analysis (hazard ratio=1.67, 95% confidence interval: 1.09-2.57, P=0.019, n=279).
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: Perhaps explaining this finding, EOC patients with the KRAS variant were significantly more likely to be platinum resistant (odds ratio=3.18, confidence interval: 1.31-7.72, P=0.0106, n=291).
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: In addition, direct targeting of the KRAS variant led to a significant reduction in EOC cell growth and survival in vitro.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: These findings confirm the importance of the KRAS variant in EOC, and indicate that the KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome in EOC likely due to platinum resistance.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: In addition, this study supports the hypothesis that these tumors have continued dependence on such 3'UTR lesions, and that direct targeting may be a viable future treatment approach.
title: A KRAS variant is a biomarker of poor outcome, platinum chemotherapy resistance and a potential target for therapy in ovarian cancer.

text: To study clonal evolution in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), we searched for BCR-ABL-independent gene mutations in both Philadelphia chromosome (Ph)-negative and Ph-positive clones in 29 chronic-phase CML patients by targeted deep sequencing of 25 genes frequently mutated in myeloid disorders.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: Ph-negative clones were analyzed in 14 patients who developed clonal cytogenetic abnormalities in Ph-negative cells during treatment with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI).
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: Mutations were detected in 6/14 patients (43%) affecting the genes DNMT3A, EZH2, RUNX1, TET2, TP53, U2AF1 and ZRSR2.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: In two patients, the mutations were also found in corresponding Ph-positive diagnostic samples.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: To further investigate Ph-positive clones, 15 randomly selected CML patients at diagnosis were analyzed.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: Somatic mutations additional to BCR-ABL were found in 5/15 patients (33%) affecting ASXL1, DNMT3A, RUNX1 and TET2.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: Analysis of individual hematopoietic colonies at diagnosis revealed that most mutations were part of the Ph-positive clone.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: In contrast, deep sequencing of subsequent samples during TKI treatment revealed one DNMT3A mutation in Ph-negative cells that was also present in Ph-positive cells at diagnosis, implying that the mutation preceded the BCR-ABL rearrangement.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: In summary, BCR-ABL-independent gene mutations were frequently found in Ph-negative and Ph-positive clones of CML patients and may be considered as important cofactors in the clonal evolution of CML.
title: Molecular-defined clonal evolution in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia independent of the BCR-ABL status.

text: BACKGROUND: Previous trials have shown that anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies can improve clinical outcomes of patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: We assessed the efficacy and safety of panitumumab combined with cisplatin and fluorouracil as first-line treatment for these patients.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: METHODS: This open-label phase 3 randomised trial was done at 126 sites in 26 countries.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Eligible patients were aged at least 18 years; had histologically or cytologically confirmed SCCHN; had distant metastatic or locoregionally recurrent disease, or both, that was deemed to be incurable by surgery or radiotherapy; had an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 1 or less; and had adequate haematological, renal, hepatic, and cardiac function.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Patients were randomly assigned according to a computer-generated randomisation sequence (1:1; stratified by previous treatment, primary tumour site, and performance status) to one of two groups.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Patients in both groups received up to six 3-week cycles of intravenous cisplatin (100 mg/m(2) on day 1 of each cycle) and fluorouracil (1000 mg/m(2) on days 1-4 of each cycle); those in the experimental group also received intravenous panitumumab (9 mg/kg on day 1 of each cycle).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Patients in the experimental group could choose to continue maintenance panitumumab every 3 weeks.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: The primary endpoint was overall survival and was analysed by intention to treat.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: In a prospectively defined retrospective analysis, we assessed tumour human papillomavirus (HPV) status as a potential predictive biomarker of outcomes with a validated p16-INK4A (henceforth, p16) immunohistochemical assay.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Patients and investigators were aware of group assignment; study statisticians were masked until primary analysis; and the central laboratory assessing p16 status was masked to identification of patients and treatment.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00460265.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between May 15, 2007, and March 10, 2009, we randomly assigned 657 patients: 327 to the panitumumab group and 330 to the control group.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Median overall survival was 11.1 months (95% CI 9.8-12.2) in the panitumumab group and 9.0 months (8.1-11.2) in the control group (hazard ratio [HR] 0.873, 95% CI 0.729-1.046; p=0.1403).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Median progression-free survival was 5.8 months (95% CI 5.6-6.6) in the panitumumab group and 4.6 months (4.1-5.4) in the control group (HR 0.780, 95% CI 0.659-0.922; p=0.0036).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Several grade 3 or 4 adverse events were more frequent in the panitumumab group than in the control group: skin or eye toxicity (62 [19%] of 325 included in safety analyses vs six [2%] of 325), diarrhoea (15 [5%] vs four [1%]), hypomagnesaemia (40 [12%] vs 12 [4%]), hypokalaemia (33 [10%] vs 23 [7%]), and dehydration (16 [5%] vs seven [2%]).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Treatment-related deaths occurred in 14 patients (4%) in the panitumumab group and eight (2%) in the control group.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Five (2%) of the fatal adverse events in the panitumumab group were attributed to the experimental agent.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: We had appropriate samples to assess p16 status for 443 (67%) patients, of whom 99 (22%) were p16 positive.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Median overall survival in patients with p16-negative tumours was longer in the panitumumab group than in the control group (11.7 months [95% CI 9.7-13.7] vs 8.6 months [6.9-11.1]; HR 0.73 [95% CI 0.58-0.93]; p=0.0115), but this difference was not shown for p16-positive patients (11.0 months [7.3-12.9] vs 12.6 months [7.7-17.4]; 1.00 [0.62-1.61]; p=0.998).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: In the control group, p16-positive patients had numerically, but not statistically, longer overall survival than did p16-negative patients (HR 0.70 [95% CI 0.47-1.04]).
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Although the addition of panitumumab to chemotherapy did not improve overall survival in an unselected population of patients with recurrent or metastatic SCCHN, it improved progression-free survival and had an acceptable toxicity profile.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: p16 status could be a prognostic and predictive marker in patients treated with panitumumab and chemotherapy.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: Prospective assessment will be necessary to validate our biomarker findings.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: FUNDING: Amgen Inc.
title: Cisplatin and fluorouracil with or without panitumumab in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SPECTRUM): an open-label phase 3 randomised trial.

text: MMNG HOS Transforming gene (MET) is an important driver gene in non-small cell lung cancer.
title: Response to Crizotinib Observed in Lung Adenocarcinoma with MET Copy Number Gain but without a High-Level MET/CEP7 Ratio, MET Overexpression, or Exon 14 Splicing Mutations.

text: Yet, MET-relevant biomarkers predictive of clinical response to MET inhibitors remain elusive.
title: Response to Crizotinib Observed in Lung Adenocarcinoma with MET Copy Number Gain but without a High-Level MET/CEP7 Ratio, MET Overexpression, or Exon 14 Splicing Mutations.

text: Limited studies have indicated some possibly effective biomarkers, including amplification with a high-level MET/centromere probe of chromosome 7 (CEP7) ratio, MET exon 14 (METex14) splicing mutations, and MET overexpression.
title: Response to Crizotinib Observed in Lung Adenocarcinoma with MET Copy Number Gain but without a High-Level MET/CEP7 Ratio, MET Overexpression, or Exon 14 Splicing Mutations.

text: MET copy number gain (MCNG) is an independent negative prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.
title: Response to Crizotinib Observed in Lung Adenocarcinoma with MET Copy Number Gain but without a High-Level MET/CEP7 Ratio, MET Overexpression, or Exon 14 Splicing Mutations.

text: Therefore, there remains a lack of clinical evidence regarding whether MCNG is a biomarker predictive of response to MET inhibitors.
title: Response to Crizotinib Observed in Lung Adenocarcinoma with MET Copy Number Gain but without a High-Level MET/CEP7 Ratio, MET Overexpression, or Exon 14 Splicing Mutations.

text: Here we report a patient with lung adenocarcinoma with MCNG but without a high-level MET/CEP7 ratio or METex14 splicing mutations who achieved a rapid response to crizotinib, indicating that MCNG may be an independent predictive biomarker for response to MET inhibitors.
title: Response to Crizotinib Observed in Lung Adenocarcinoma with MET Copy Number Gain but without a High-Level MET/CEP7 Ratio, MET Overexpression, or Exon 14 Splicing Mutations.

text: OBJECTIVES: There is no molecular biomarker available in the clinical practice to assess the prognosis of advanced pancreatic carcinoma.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: This multicenter prospective study aimed to investigate the role of KRAS mutation subtypes within the primary tumor to determine the prognosis of advanced pancreatic cancer.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: METHODS: The exon-2 KRAS mutation status was tested on endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy material (primary tumor; restriction fragment-length polymorphism plus sequencing and TaqMan allelic discrimination) of patients with proven locally advanced and/or metastatic pancreatic ductal carcinoma.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: We used the Kaplan-Meier method, log-rank test, and Cox's model to evaluate the impact of KRAS status on the overall survival (OS), adjusting for age, stage of disease, clinical performance status, CA 19-9 levels, and treatment.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: A total of 219 patients (men: 116; mean age: 67+/-9.4 years) were included: 147 harbored a codon-12 KRAS mutation (G12D: 73; G12V: 53; G12R: 21) and 72 had a wild-type KRAS.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: There was no difference in the OS between patients with a mutant KRAS (8 months; 95% confidence interval (95% CI): 8.7-12.3) and the wild-type (9 months; 95% CI: 8.7-12.8; hazard ratio (HR): 1.03; P=0.82).
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: However, the patients with a G12D mutation had a significantly shorter OS (6 months; 95% CI: 6.4-9.7) compared with the other patients (OS: 9 months; 95% CI: 10-13; HR: 1.47; P=0.003; i.e., wild type: 9 months, G12V: 9 months, G12R: 14 months).
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: Similar results were observed in the subgroup of 162 patients who received chemotherapy (HR: 1.66; P=0.0013; G12D (n=49): 8 months, wild type (n=56): 10 months, G12V (n=38): 10 months, G12R (n=19): 14 months).
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: Multivariate analyses identified KRAS G12D as an independent predictor for worse prognosis within the entire series (HR: 1.44; P=0.01) and in the subgroup of patients that received chemotherapy (HR: 1.84; P=0.02).
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The KRAS G12D mutation subtype is an independent prognostic marker for advanced pancreatic ductal carcinoma.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: Codon and amino-acid-specific mutations of KRAS should be considered when evaluating the prognoses as well as in trials testing drugs that target RAS and downstream RAS pathways.
title: KRAS G12D Mutation Subtype Is A Prognostic Factor for Advanced Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) is a transcription factor that is overexpressed in most acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs).
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: Recently, 2 groups reported that WT1 mutations occur in approximately 10% of normal karyotype AMLs and are an independent predictor of poor outcome in this subgroup of patients with AML.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: METHODS: The authors studied a cohort of 268 young adults (ages 15-50 years) with AML who were treated on the Acute Leukemia French Association 9802 trial.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: WT1 exon 7 and 9 mutations were screened retrospectively by polymerase chain reaction and direct sequencing.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: The patients also were assessed for the presence of the fms-related tyrosine kinase 3 internal tandem duplication (FLT3-ITD), FLT3-D835/I836, nucleophosmin 1 (NPM1), and CCAAT/enhancer binding protein alpha (CEBPA) mutations.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: RESULTS: WT1 mutations were identified in 14 patients (5%) and were associated with a younger age (P = .02) and an FLT3-ITD (P = .03).
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: No mutation was detected in patients who had favorable cytogenetics.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: Patients who had WT1 mutations had a shorter overall survival at 4 years (22% vs 56%; P = .01) and a higher risk of recurrence at 4 years (82% vs 46%; P = .0008) compared with patients who had wild-type WT1.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: Within the subgroup of patients who had normal karyotype AML (n = 106), WT1 mutation was identified as an independent adverse prognostic factor for the risk of recurrence.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The current results indicted that WT1 mutations represent an adverse prognostic factor in young adults with AML.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: Prospective trials should confirm the clinical relevance of WT1 mutations in relation to other prognostic factors in patients with AML.
title: Wilms tumor 1 gene mutations are associated with a higher risk of recurrence in young adults with acute myeloid leukemia: a study from the Acute Leukemia French Association.

text: BACKGROUND: Crizotinib is approved to treat advanced ALK-positive non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), but most patients ultimately develop progressive disease (PD).
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: We investigated whether continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond PD (CBPD) is clinically beneficial and attempted to identify clinicopathologic characteristics associated with patients who experience clinical benefit.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC enrolled in two ongoing multicenter, single-arm trials who developed RECIST-defined PD were allowed to continue crizotinib if they were deriving ongoing clinical benefit.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: In the present retrospective analysis, continuation of CBPD was defined as >3 weeks of crizotinib treatment after PD documentation.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: Patients who had PD as best response to initial crizotinib treatment were excluded.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: Baseline and post-progression characteristics, sites of PD, and overall survival (OS) were compared in patients who continued CBPD versus those who did not.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: The impact of continuing CBPD on OS after adjusting for potential confounding factors was assessed.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: RESULTS: Among 194 crizotinib-treated patients with RECIST-defined PD, 120 (62%) continued CBPD.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: A significantly higher proportion of patients who continued CBPD than patients who did not had an ECOG performance status (PS) of 0/1 at PD (96% versus 82%; P=0.02).
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: CBPD patients had significantly longer OS from the time of PD [median 16.4 versus 3.9 months; hazards ratio (HR) 0.27, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.17-0.42; P<0.0001] and from the time of initial crizotinib treatment (median 29.6 versus 10.8 months; HR 0.30, 95% CI: 0.19-0.46; P<0.0001).
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: The multiple-covariate Cox regression analysis revealed that CBPD remained significantly associated with improved OS after adjusting for relevant factors.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Patients who continued CBPD were more likely to have good ECOG PS (0/1) at the time of PD.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: Continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib after PD may provide survival benefit to patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.
title: Clinical benefit of continuing ALK inhibition with crizotinib beyond initial disease progression in patients with advanced ALK-positive NSCLC.

text: BACKGROUND: The p53 gene (also known as TP53) may be the most common genetic target involved in the malignant transformation of human cells.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Direct sequence analysis has demonstrated that alteration of this gene occurs in approximately 45% of head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The consequences of p53 mutations in these cancers with respect to tumor behavior and patient survival have not been rigorously determined.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: We evaluated the implications of p53 mutations in relation to the control of locoregional disease and overall survival following radiation therapy.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: METHODS: Data from 110 consecutive patients with invasive disease who were treated with primary radiation therapy (given with curative intent) or with adjuvant radiation therapy (following complete surgical extirpation of gross disease) were included in the analysis.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: A 1.8-kilobase fragment of the p53 gene encompassing exons 5-9 was amplified from the DNA of stored (frozen) tumor specimens; the amplified DNA was cloned and sequenced by use of standard techniques.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Overall survival and locoregional disease-free survival after the completion of radiation therapy were estimated by the Kaplan-Meier method; survival comparisons were made by use of the logrank test or proportional hazards regression models.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Reported P values are two-sided.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Fortyeight (44%) of the 110 tumors had cells bearing p53 mutations.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The risk of locoregional recurrence following either primary or adjuvant radiation therapy was significantly greater (i.e., the time to recurrence was shorter) for patients whose tumors contained mutant p53 genes (univariate model hazard ratio [HR] for p53 mutation versus wild-type = 2.2; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.2-4.1; P = .02).
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The presence of regional lymph node metastases (presence versus absence, HR = 2.0; 95% CI = 1.0-4.2; P = .05) and treatment type (primary radiation therapy versus surgery plus adjuvant radiation therapy, HR = 2.3; 95% CI = 1.2-4.3; P = .01) were also associated with greater risks of locoregional failure.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The presence of p53 mutations and lymph node metastases and treatment with primary, as opposed to adjuvant, radiation therapy remained significant risk factors in multivariate regression analysis.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: No relationship was demonstrated between p53 status and overall survival (mutant versus wild-type, HR = 1.1; 95% CI = 0.6-2.1; P = .66); however, a relationship was shown for tumor stage and overall survival (stages III and IV [more advanced] versus stages I and II [less advanced], HR = 3.3; 95% CI = 1.0-10.8; P = .05).
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Mutation of the p53 gene was not associated with patient age, sex, tumor stage, primary tumor site, regional lymph node status, degree of tumor cell differentiation, or treatment method.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Mutation of the p53 gene is associated with an increased risk of locoregional failure in patients with invasive head and neck squamous cell carcinoma who are treated with radiation therapy.
title: p53 mutation and locoregional treatment failure in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: IMPORTANCE: Uveal melanoma is characterized by mutations in GNAQ and GNA11, resulting in mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway activation.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: OBJECTIVE: To assess the efficacy of selumetinib, a selective, non-adenosine triphosphate competitive inhibitor of MEK1 and MEK2, in uveal melanoma.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized, open-label, phase 2 clinical trial comparing selumetinib vs chemotherapy conducted from August 2010 through December 2013 among 120 patients with metastatic uveal melanoma at 15 academic oncology centers in the United States and Canada.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: INTERVENTIONS: One hundred one patients were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive selumetinib, 75 mg orally twice daily on a continual basis (n = 50), or chemotherapy (temozolomide, 150 mg/m2 orally daily for 5 of every 28 days, or dacarbazine, 1000 mg/m2 intravenously every 21 days [investigator choice]; n = 51) until disease progression, death, intolerable adverse effects, or withdrawal of consent.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: After primary outcome analysis, 19 patients were registered and 18 treated with selumetinib without randomization to complete the planned 120-patient enrollment.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: Patients in the chemotherapy group could receive selumetinib at the time of radiographic progression.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Progression-free survival, the primary end point, was assessed as of April 22, 2013.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: Additional end points, including overall survival, response rate, and safety/toxicity, were assessed as of December 31, 2013.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: RESULTS: Median progression-free survival among patients randomized to chemotherapy was 7 weeks (95% CI, 4.3-8.4 weeks; median treatment duration, 8 weeks; interquartile range [IQR], 4.3-16 weeks) and among those randomized to selumetinib was 15.9 weeks (95% CI, 8.4-21.1 weeks; median treatment duration, 16.1 weeks; IQR, 8.1-25.3 weeks) (hazard ratio, 0.46; 95% CI, 0.30-0.71; P < .001).
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: Median overall survival time was 9.1 months (95% CI, 6.1-11.1 months) with chemotherapy and 11.8 months (95% CI, 9.8-15.7 months) with selumetinib (hazard ratio, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.41-1.06; P = .09).
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: No objective responses were observed with chemotherapy.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: Forty-nine percent of patients treated with selumetinib achieved tumor regression, with 14% achieving an objective radiographic response to therapy.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: Treatment-related adverse events were observed in 97% of patients treated with selumetinib, with 37% requiring at least 1 dose reduction.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: In this hypothesis-generating study of patients with advanced uveal melanoma, selumetinib compared with chemotherapy resulted in a modestly improved progression-free survival and response rate; however, no improvement in overall survival was observed.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: Improvement in clinical outcomes was accompanied by a high rate of adverse events.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: TRIAL REGISTRATION: clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT01143402.
title: Effect of selumetinib vs chemotherapy on progression-free survival in uveal melanoma: a randomized clinical trial.

text: DISEASE OVERVIEW: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) results from accumulation of abnormal immature cells in the marrow.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: These cells interfere with normal hematopoiesis can escape into the blood and infiltrate lung and CNS.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: The most common cause of death is bone marrow failure.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: It is likely that many different mutations and/or epigenetic aberrations can produce the same disease, with these differences responsible for the very variable response to therapy, which is AML's principal clinical feature.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: DIAGNOSIS: This rests on demonstration that the marrow or blood has >20% blasts of myeloid lineage.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: Blast lineage is assessed by multiparameter flow cytometry with CD33 and CD13 being surface markers typically expressed by myeloid blasts.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: It should be realized that clinical/prognostic considerations, not the blast % per se, should be the main factor determining how a patient is treated.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: RISK STRATIFICATION: Two features determine risk: the probability of treatment-related mortality (TRM) and, more important, even in patients aged >75 with Zubrod performance status 1, the probability of resistance to standard therapy despite not incurring TRM.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: The chief predictor of resistance is cytogenetics with a monosomal karyotype (MK) denoting the disease is essentially incurable with standard therapy even if followed by a standard allogeneic transplant (HCT).
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: The most common cytogenetic finding is a normal karyotype (NK) and those of such patients with an NPM1 mutation but no FLT3 internal tandem duplication (ITD), or with a CEBPA mutation, have a prognosis similar to that of patients with the most favorable cytogenetics [inv(16) or t(8;21)] (60-70% cure rate).
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: In contrast, NK patients with a FLT3 ITD have only a 30-40% chance of cure even after HCT.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: Accordingly analyses of NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA should be part of routine evaluation, much as is cytogenetics.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: Risk is best assessed considering several variables simultaneously rather than, for example, only age.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: RISK-ADAPTED THERAPY: Patients with inv(16) or t(8;21) or who are NPM1+/FLT3ITD- can receive standard therapy (daunorubicin + cytarabine) and should not receive HCT in first CR.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: It seems likely that use of a daily daunorubicin dose of 90 mg/m(2) will further improve outcome in these patients.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: There appears no reason to use doses of cytarabine > 1 g/m(2) (for example, bid x 6 days), as opposed to the more commonly used 3 g/m(2) .
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: Patients with an unfavorable karyotype (particularly MK) are unlikely to benefit from standard therapy (even with dose escalation) and are thus prime candidates for clinical trials of new drugs or new approaches to HCT; the latter should be done in first CR.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: Patients with intermediate prognoses (for example, NK and NPM and FLT3ITD negative) should also receive HCT in first CR and can plausibly receive either investigational or standard induction therapy, with the same prognostic information about standard therapy leading one patient to choose the standard and another an investigational option.
title: Acute myeloid leukemia: 2012 update on diagnosis, risk stratification, and management.

text: BACKGROUND: Afatinib-an oral irreversible ErbB family blocker-improves progression-free survival compared with pemetrexed and cisplatin for first-line treatment of patients with EGFR mutation-positive advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: We compared afatinib with gemcitabine and cisplatin-a chemotherapy regimen widely used in Asia-for first-line treatment of Asian patients with EGFR mutation-positive advanced NSCLC.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: METHODS: This open-label, randomised phase 3 trial was done at 36 centres in China, Thailand, and South Korea.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: After central testing for EGFR mutations, treatment-naive patients (stage IIIB or IV cancer [American Joint Committee on Cancer version 6], performance status 0-1) were randomly assigned (2:1) to receive either oral afatinib (40 mg per day) or intravenous gemcitabine 1000 mg/m(2) on day 1 and day 8 plus cisplatin 75 mg/m(2) on day 1 of a 3-week schedule for up to six cycles.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Randomisation was done centrally with a random number-generating system and an interactive internet and voice-response system.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Randomisation was stratified by EGFR mutation (Leu858Arg, exon 19 deletions, or other; block size three).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Clinicians and patients were not masked to treatment assignment, but the independent central imaging review group were.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Treatment continued until disease progression, intolerable toxic effects, or withdrawal of consent.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was progression-free survival assessed by independent central review (intention-to-treat population).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01121393.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: FINDINGS: 910 patients were screened and 364 were randomly assigned (242 to afatinib, 122 to gemcitabine and cisplatin).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Median progression-free survival was significantly longer in the afatinib group (11.0 months, 95% CI 9.7-13.7) than in the gemcitabine and cisplatin group (5.6 months, 5.1-6.7; hazard ratio 0.28, 95% CI 0.20-0.39; p<0.0001).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: The most common treatment-related grade 3 or 4 adverse events in the afatinib group were rash or acne (35 [14.6%] of 239 patients), diarrhoea (13 [5.4%]), and stomatitis or mucositis (13 [5.4%]), compared with neutropenia (30 [26.5%] of 113 patients), vomiting (22 [19.5%]), and leucopenia (17 [15.0%]) in the gemcitabine and cisplatin group.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Treatment-related serious adverse events occurred in 15 (6.3%) patients in the afatinib group and nine (8.0%) patients in the gemcitabine and cisplatin group.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: First-line afatinib significantly improves progression-free survival with a tolerable and manageable safety profile in Asian patients with EGFR mutation-positive advanced lung NSCLC.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Afatinib should be considered as a first-line treatment option for this patient population.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: FUNDING: Boehringer Ingelheim.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin plus gemcitabine for first-line treatment of Asian patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring EGFR mutations (LUX-Lung 6): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Purpose: Cyclin E1 (CCNE1) amplification is associated with primary treatment resistance and poor outcome in high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC).
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: Here, we explore approaches to target CCNE1-amplified cancers and potential strategies to overcome resistance to targeted agents.Experimental Design: To examine dependency on CDK2 in CCNE1-amplified HGSC, we utilized siRNA and conditional shRNA gene suppression, and chemical inhibition using dinaciclib, a small-molecule CDK2 inhibitor.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: High-throughput compound screening was used to identify selective synergistic drug combinations, as well as combinations that may overcome drug resistance.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: An observed relationship between CCNE1 and the AKT pathway was further explored in genomic data from primary tumors, and functional studies in fallopian tube secretory cells.Results: We validate CDK2 as a therapeutic target by demonstrating selective sensitivity to gene suppression.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: However, we found that dinaciclib did not trigger amplicon-dependent sensitivity in a panel of HGSC cell lines.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: A high-throughput compound screen identified synergistic combinations in CCNE1-amplified HGSC, including dinaciclib and AKT inhibitors.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: Analysis of genomic data from TCGA demonstrated coamplification of CCNE1 and AKT2 Overexpression of Cyclin E1 and AKT isoforms, in addition to mutant TP53, imparted malignant characteristics in untransformed fallopian tube secretory cells, the dominant site of origin of HGSC.Conclusions: These findings suggest a specific dependency of CCNE1-amplified tumors for AKT activity, and point to a novel combination of dinaciclib and AKT inhibitors that may selectively target patients with CCNE1-amplified HGSC.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 23(7); 1862-74.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: Selective Targeting of Cyclin E1-Amplified High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer by Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2 and AKT Inhibition.

text: UNLABELLED: The aim of this study was to explore predictive genes involved in docetaxel sensitivity of gastric cancer.
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: Microarray analysis was performed to explore various gene expression levels between parental and docetaxel-resistant cells.
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: A panel of 11 genes selected according to microarray analysis were validated and tested further in 11 cancer cell lines, resulting in 4 genes, CXCR4, CDK6, USP15 and CDH1.
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: Histoculture drug response assay (HDRA) was used to examine docetaxel sensitivity, while qRT-PCR was used to measure the mRNA levels of the genes in 25 surgically dissected gastric cancer specimens.
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: RESULTS: Only CXCR4 mRNA levels in gastric cancer tissues were correlated with docetaxel sensitivity (R(2)=0.23, p=0.019) and significantly higher in resistant specimens (p=0.038).
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: AMD3100, a CXCR4 antagonist, enhanced the docetaxel cytotoxicity in vitro.
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: CXCR4 mRNA expression levels may be a potential predictive biomarker in gastric cancer.
title: CXCR4, a potential predictive marker for docetaxel sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: In this updated analysis of the EXPERT-C trial we show that, in magnetic resonance imaging-defined, high-risk, locally advanced rectal cancer, adding cetuximab to a treatment strategy with neoadjuvant CAPOX followed by chemoradiotherapy, surgery, and adjuvant CAPOX is not associated with a statistically significant improvement in progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) in both KRAS/BRAF wild-type and unselected patients.
title: TP53 mutational status and cetuximab benefit in rectal cancer: 5-year results of the EXPERT-C trial.

text: In a retrospective biomarker analysis, TP53 was not prognostic but emerged as an independent predictive biomarker for cetuximab benefit.
title: TP53 mutational status and cetuximab benefit in rectal cancer: 5-year results of the EXPERT-C trial.

text: After a median follow-up of 65.0 months, TP53 wild-type patients (n = 69) who received cetuximab had a statistically significant better PFS (89.3% vs 65.0% at 5 years; hazard ratio [HR] = 0.23; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.07 to 0.78; two-sided P = .02 by Cox regression) and OS (92.7% vs 67.5% at 5 years; HR = 0.16; 95% CI = 0.04 to 0.70; two-sided P = .02 by Cox regression) than TP53 wild-type patients who were treated in the control arm.
title: TP53 mutational status and cetuximab benefit in rectal cancer: 5-year results of the EXPERT-C trial.

text: An interaction between TP53 status and cetuximab effect was found (P < .05) and remained statistically significant after adjusting for statistically significant prognostic factors and KRAS.
title: TP53 mutational status and cetuximab benefit in rectal cancer: 5-year results of the EXPERT-C trial.

text: PURPOSE: To identify genetic markers in the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic pathways of sunitinib that predispose for development of toxicities: thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, mucosal inflammation, hand-foot syndrome, and any toxicity according to National Cancer Institute Common Toxicity Criteria higher than grade 2.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: A multicenter pharmacogenetic association study was performed in 219 patients treated with single-agent sunitinib.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: A total of 31 single nucleotide polymorphisms in 12 candidate genes, together with several nongenetic variants, were analyzed for a possible association with toxicity.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: In addition, genetic haplotypes were developed and related to toxicity.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: RESULTS: The risk for leukopenia was increased when the G allele in CYP1A1 2455A/G (odds ratio [OR], 6.24; P = .029) or the T allele in FLT3 738T/C (OR, 2.8; P = .008) were present or CAG in the NR1I3 (5719C/T, 7738A/C, 7837T/G) haplotype (OR, 1.74; P = .041) was absent.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: Any toxicity higher than grade 2 prevalence was increased when the T allele of vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 1191C/T (OR, 2.39; P = .046) or a copy of TT in the ABCG2 (-15622C/T, 1143C/T) haplotype (OR, 2.63; P = .016) were present.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: The risk for mucosal inflammation was increased in the presence of the G allele in CYP1A1 2455A/G (OR, 4.03; P = .021) and the prevalence of hand-foot syndrome was increased when a copy of TTT in the ABCB1 (3435C/T, 1236C/T, 2677G/T) haplotype (OR, 2.56; P = .035) was present.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: CONCLUSION: This exploratory study suggests that polymorphisms in specific genes encoding for metabolizing enzymes, efflux transporters, and drug targets are associated with sunitinib-related toxicities.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: A better understanding of genetic and nongenetic determinants of sunitinib toxicity should help to optimize drug treatment in individual patients.
title: Pharmacogenetic pathway analysis for determination of sunitinib-induced toxicity.

text: PURPOSE: Adequate biomarkers are still required to optimize therapy in patients with locally advanced head and neck squamous carcinomas (HNSCC) treated with chemoradiotherapy (CRT).
title: Correlation of TP53 and MDM2 genotypes and clinical outcome in platinum-treated head and neck cancer patients with more than 10 years' follow-up.

text: METHODS: We updated the follow-up of 66 HNSCC patients treated with CRT we described more than 10 years ago, focusing on SNP Arg/Pro (R/P) at codon 72 and somatic mutations in TP53 and on SNP309 in the MDM2 gene.
title: Correlation of TP53 and MDM2 genotypes and clinical outcome in platinum-treated head and neck cancer patients with more than 10 years' follow-up.

text: RESULTS: In wild-type TP53 cases, overall survival (OS) was longer in 72RR and less favorable in 72PP (p = 0.005); when TP53 was mutated, OS was longest in 72PP and less favorable in 72RR and 72RP (p = 0.058).
title: Correlation of TP53 and MDM2 genotypes and clinical outcome in platinum-treated head and neck cancer patients with more than 10 years' follow-up.

text: Median OS was significantly shorter in patients with MDM2 SNP309 GG or GT genotypes compared with the TT genotype (p = 0.002).
title: Correlation of TP53 and MDM2 genotypes and clinical outcome in platinum-treated head and neck cancer patients with more than 10 years' follow-up.

text: CONCLUSIONS: TP53 SNP72 may be useful in selecting patients for CRT, but has to be related to somatic TP53 mutations.
title: Correlation of TP53 and MDM2 genotypes and clinical outcome in platinum-treated head and neck cancer patients with more than 10 years' follow-up.

text: The MDM2 SNP309, easily determined in peripheral blood, might be more convenient as a predictive biomarker.
title: Correlation of TP53 and MDM2 genotypes and clinical outcome in platinum-treated head and neck cancer patients with more than 10 years' follow-up.

text: PURPOSE: CD44, a cell surface glycoprotein, plays important roles in the development, progression, and metastasis of various tumor types.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: The aim of this study was to investigate how the expression of CD44 isoforms influences the interaction with hyaluronic acid (HA) and how differential isoform expression impacts antitumoral responses in vivo to treatment with RG7356, a humanized anti-CD44 antibody inhibiting CD44-HA interaction.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: CD44 isoform expression on various tumor cell lines was analyzed by RNASeq while data on patients with different tumor types were obtained from the publicly available TCGA RNASeq dataset as well as a phase I clinical study (NCT01358903).
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: We analyzed the link between HA production and CD44 isoform expression as well as the consequences of blocking the CD44-mediated cell adhesion to HA using RG7356.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: The correlation between CD44 isoform expression and antitumor response to RG7356 treatment was investigated in the corresponding murine xenograft in vivo models as well as in a subset of patients treated with RG7356 from a recently completed phase I clinical trial.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: RESULTS: CD44 isoform expression, in particular expression of CD44s, is associated with HA production and predicts response to treatment with RG7356 in tumor xenograft models.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: Furthermore, patient data suggest that CD44 isoform status is a potential predictive biomarker for clinical response to treatment with RG7356.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We provide new insights into the close interplay between CD44 and HA and a potential biomarker to enrich patient responses to RG7356 in the clinic.
title: CD44 Isoform Status Predicts Response to Treatment with Anti-CD44 Antibody in Cancer Patients.

text: Human epidermal growth factor 2 (HER2, ERBB2) mutations in lung cancers are oncogenic drivers that respond to HER2 targeted therapies.
title: HER2 insertion YVMA mutant lung cancer: Long natural history and response to afatinib.

text: Little is known about the sensitivity of subtypes of HER2 mutant lung cancers to targeted agents.
title: HER2 insertion YVMA mutant lung cancer: Long natural history and response to afatinib.

text: We present a patient with HER2 mutant lung cancer with a 12 base pair insertion YVMA (p.A775_G776insYVMA), who had a long natural history and durable partial response to afatinib.
title: HER2 insertion YVMA mutant lung cancer: Long natural history and response to afatinib.

text: We demonstrate that afatinib has activity in patients with HER2 mutant lung cancers with exon 20 YVMA insertions, the most common variant.
title: HER2 insertion YVMA mutant lung cancer: Long natural history and response to afatinib.

text: Receptor tyrosine kinase genes were sequenced in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and matched normal tissue.
title: EGFR mutations in lung cancer: correlation with clinical response to gefitinib therapy.

text: Somatic mutations of the epidermal growth factor receptor gene EGFR were found in 15of 58 unselected tumors from Japan and 1 of 61 from the United States.
title: EGFR mutations in lung cancer: correlation with clinical response to gefitinib therapy.

text: Treatment with the EGFR kinase inhibitor gefitinib (Iressa) causes tumor regression in some patients with NSCLC, more frequently in Japan.
title: EGFR mutations in lung cancer: correlation with clinical response to gefitinib therapy.

text: EGFR mutations were found in additional lung cancer samples from U.S. patients who responded to gefitinib therapy and in a lung adenocarcinoma cell line that was hypersensitive to growth inhibition by gefitinib, but not in gefitinib-insensitive tumors or cell lines.
title: EGFR mutations in lung cancer: correlation with clinical response to gefitinib therapy.

text: These results suggest that EGFR mutations may predict sensitivity to gefitinib.
title: EGFR mutations in lung cancer: correlation with clinical response to gefitinib therapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Biallelic von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene defects, a rate-limiting event in the carcinogenesis, occur in approximately 75% of sporadic clear-cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC).
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: We studied the VHL mutation status in a large population-based case group.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: METHODS: Cases were identified within the Netherlands cohort study on diet and cancer, which includes 120,852 men and women.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: After 11.3 years of follow-up, 337 incident cases with histologically confirmed epithelial cancers were identified.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: DNA was isolated from paraffin material collected from 51 pathology laboratories and revised by one pathologist, leaving material from 235 cases.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: VHL mutational status was assessed by SSCP followed by direct sequencing, after testing SSCP as a screening tool in a subsample.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: RESULTS: The number of mutations was significantly higher for clear-cell RCC compared to other histological types.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: We observed 131 mutations in 114 out of 187 patients (61%) with clear-cell RCC.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: The majority of mutations were truncating mutations (47%).
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: The mean tumor size was 72.7 mm for mutated tumors compared to 65.3 mm for wildtype tumors (p = 0.06).
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: No statistically significant differences were observed for nuclear grade, TNM distribution or stage.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: In other histological types, we observed 8 mutations in 7 out of 48 patients (15%), 1 mutation in 1 of 6 oncocytoma, 3 mutations in 2 of 7 chromophobe RCC, 2 mutations in 2 of 30 papillary RCC, no mutations in 1 collecting duct carcinoma and 2 mutations in 2 of 4 unclassified RCC.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: CONCLUSION: VHL mutations were detected in 61% of sporadic clear-cell RCC.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: VHL mutated and wildtype clear-cell RCC did not differ with respect to most parameters.
title: Prevalence of von Hippel-Lindau gene mutations in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: results from The Netherlands cohort study.

text: Anti-PD-1 therapy yields objective clinical responses in 30-40% of advanced melanoma patients.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: Since most patients do not respond, predictive biomarkers to guide treatment selection are needed.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: We hypothesize that MHC-I/II expression is required for tumour antigen presentation and may predict anti-PD-1 therapy response.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: In this study, across 60 melanoma cell lines, we find bimodal expression patterns of MHC-II, while MHC-I expression was ubiquitous.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: A unique subset of melanomas are capable of expressing MHC-II under basal or IFNgamma-stimulated conditions.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: Using pathway analysis, we show that MHC-II(+) cell lines demonstrate signatures of 'PD-1 signalling', 'allograft rejection' and 'T-cell receptor signalling', among others.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: In two independent cohorts of anti-PD-1-treated melanoma patients, MHC-II positivity on tumour cells is associated with therapeutic response, progression-free and overall survival, as well as CD4(+) and CD8(+) tumour infiltrate.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: MHC-II(+) tumours can be identified by melanoma-specific immunohistochemistry using commercially available antibodies for HLA-DR to improve anti-PD-1 patient selection.
title: Melanoma-specific MHC-II expression represents a tumour-autonomous phenotype and predicts response to anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy.

text: Aberrant mutational activation of FGFR2 is associated with endometrial cancers (ECs).
title: Antitumor effects and molecular mechanisms of ponatinib on endometrial cancer cells harboring activating FGFR2 mutations.

text: AP24534 (ponatinib) currently undergoing clinical trials has been known to be an orally available multi-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
title: Antitumor effects and molecular mechanisms of ponatinib on endometrial cancer cells harboring activating FGFR2 mutations.

text: Our biochemical kinase assay showed that AP24534 is potent against wild-type FGFR1-4 and 5 mutant FGFRs (V561M-FGFR1, N549H-FGFR2, K650E-FGFR3, G697C-FGFR3, N535K-FGFR4) and possesses the strongest kinase-inhibitory activity on N549H-FGFR2 (IC50 of 0.5 nM) among all FGFRs tested.
title: Antitumor effects and molecular mechanisms of ponatinib on endometrial cancer cells harboring activating FGFR2 mutations.

text: We therefore investigated the effects of AP24534 on endometrial cancer cells harboring activating FGFR2 mutations and explored the underlying molecular mechanisms.
title: Antitumor effects and molecular mechanisms of ponatinib on endometrial cancer cells harboring activating FGFR2 mutations.

text: AP24534 significantly inhibited the proliferation of endometrial cancer cells bearing activating FGFR2 mutations (N549K, K310R/N549K, S252W) and mainly induced G1/S cell cycle arrest leading to apoptosis.
title: Antitumor effects and molecular mechanisms of ponatinib on endometrial cancer cells harboring activating FGFR2 mutations.
