title: Mutations of the VHL gene in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: definition of a risk factor for VHL patients to develop an RCC.

text: We then analyzed the occurrence of RCC in VHL families, based on the nature of mutations.
title: Mutations of the VHL gene in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: definition of a risk factor for VHL patients to develop an RCC.

text: We observed RCC in at least one member of the VHL families in 77% of cases with mutations leading to truncated proteins versus 55% in cases with missense mutations (P < 0.05).
title: Mutations of the VHL gene in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: definition of a risk factor for VHL patients to develop an RCC.

text: Thus, mutations resulting in truncated proteins may lead to a higher risk of RCC in VHL patients.
title: Mutations of the VHL gene in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: definition of a risk factor for VHL patients to develop an RCC.

text: Platinum agents cause DNA cross-linking.
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: Nucleotide excision repair genes play a key role in DNA damage repair.
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: This study aims to investigate whether polymorphisms in these genes are associated with tumor response and survival in cisplatin-treated osteosarcoma patients.
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: Eight single nucleotide polymorphisms in ERCC2, XPC, XPA, ERCC1, ERCC4 and ERCC5 genes were analyzed in 91 patients diagnosed with osteosarcoma and treated with cisplatin.
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: A significant association with tumor response, after correction for multiple testing, was found for the Lys751Gln polymorphism in the ERCC2 gene.
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: We found that only 45% of patients with at least one polymorphic G allele responded compared with 80% of patients homozygous for the common T allele (odds ratio=4.9, 95% confidence interval=1.64-14.54, adjusted P-value=0.047).
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: In addition, carrying at least one ERCC2 Lys751GlnG allele was significantly associated with shorter event-free survival (median=184 months, compared with 240 months for TT homozygotes; hazard ratio=5.76, 95% confidence interval=1.30-25.55; P-value=0.021).
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: Although ototoxicity was only recorded in 32 patients, we found weak evidence of an association with the CC genotype of XPC Lys939Gln (P-value= 0.042).
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: This is the first pharmacogenetic study focused on osteosarcoma treatment providing evidence that polymorphic variants in DNA repair genes could be useful predictors of response to cisplatin chemotherapy in osteosarcoma patients.
title: Common variations in ERCC2 are associated with response to cisplatin chemotherapy and clinical outcome in osteosarcoma patients.

text: Germline HOXB13 G84E mutation (rs138213197) has been described associated with prostate cancer (PCa) susceptibility but results of different studies are inconsistent.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: We conducted this meta-analysis to evaluate the specific role of this mutation.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Relevant available studies were identified by searching the databases Pubmed, Embase and Web of Science.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated to measure the strength of the association.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Subgroup analysis were performed to evaluate the specific role of rs138213197 in disease aggressiveness, diagnostic age and family history.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Furthermore, trial sequential analysis (TSA) was conducted for the first time to estimate whether the evidence of the results is sufficient.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Our results indicated that significant increased PCa susceptibility was associated with rs138213197 compared with non-carriers (OR = 3.38, 95% CI: 2.45-4.66).
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Besides, in subgroup analysis, HOXB13 G84E variant was obviously associated with early onset (OR = 2.90, 95% CI: 2.24-3.75), affected relatives (OR = 2.60, 95% CI 2.19-3.10) and highly aggressive disease (OR = 2.38, 95% CI 1.84-3.08).
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: By TSA, the findings in the current study were based on sufficient evidence.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Therefore, our results indicated that the G84E mutation in HOXB13 gene might increase susceptibility to PCa.
title: Association between germline homeobox B13 (HOXB13) G84E allele and prostate cancer susceptibility: a meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.

text: Programmed death-ligand 1(PD-L1) expression on tumor cells is emerging as a potential predictive biomarker in anti-PD-L1 directed cancer immunotherapy.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: We analyzed PD-L1 expression in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and its variants and determined its prognostic potential to predict clinical outcome in these patients.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: This study was conducted at an academic oncology hospital which is a prime referral centre for thyroid diseases.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: Immunohistochemical subcellular localization (IHC) analyses of PD-L1 protein was retrospectively performed on 251 archived formalin fixed and paraffin embedded (FFPE) surgical tissues (66 benign thyroid nodules and 185 PTCs) using a rabbit monoclonal anti-PD-L1 antibody (E1L3N, Cell Signaling Technology) and detected using VECTASTAIN rapid protocol with diaminobenzidine (DAB) as the chromogen.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: The clinical-pathological factors and disease outcome over 190 months were assessed; immunohistochemical subcellular localization of PD-L1 was correlated with disease free survival (DFS) using Kaplan Meier survival and Cox multivariate regression analysis.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: Increased PD-L1 immunostaining was predominantly localized in cytoplasm and occasionally in plasma membrane of tumor cells.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: Among all combined stages of PTC, patients with increased PD-L1 membrane or cytoplasmic positivity had significantly shorter median DFS (36 months and 49 months respectively) as compared to those with PD-L1 negative tumors (DFS, both 186 months with p < 0.001 and p < 0.01 respectively).
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: Comparison of PD-L1+ and PD-L1- patients with matched staging showed increased cytoplasmic positivity in all four stages of PTC that correlated with a greater risk of recurrence and a poor prognosis, but increased membrane positivity significantly correlated with a greater risk of metastasis or death only in Stage IV patients.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: In conclusion, PD-L1 positive expression in PTC correlates with a greater risk of recurrence and shortened disease free survival supporting its potential application as a prognostic marker for PTC.
title: Programmed death-ligand 1 overexpression is a prognostic marker for aggressive papillary thyroid cancer and its variants.

text: The protein kinase BRAF is a key component of the RAS-RAF signaling pathway which plays an important role in regulating cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival.
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Mutations in BRAF at codon 600 promote catalytic activity and are associated with 8% of all human (solid) tumors, including 8% to 10% of colorectal cancers (CRC).
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Here, we report the preclinical characterization of vemurafenib (RG7204; PLX4032; RO5185426), a first-in-class, specific small molecule inhibitor of BRAF(V600E) in BRAF-mutated CRC cell lines and tumor xenograft models.
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: As a single agent, vemurafenib shows dose-dependent inhibition of ERK and MEK phosphorylation, thereby arresting cell proliferation in BRAF(V600)-expressing cell lines and inhibiting tumor growth in BRAF(V600E) bearing xenograft models.
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Because vemurafenib has shown limited single-agent clinical activity in BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic CRC, we therefore explored a range of combination therapies, with both standard agents and targeted inhibitors in preclinical xenograft models.
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: In a BRAF-mutant CRC xenograft model with de novo resistance to vemurafenib (RKO), tumor growth inhibition by vemurafenib was enhanced by combining with an AKT inhibitor (MK-2206).
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: The addition of vemurafenib to capecitabine and/or bevacizumab, cetuximab and/or irinotecan, or erlotinib resulted in increased antitumor activity and improved survival in xenograft models.
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Together, our findings suggest that the administration of vemurafenib in combination with standard-of-care or novel targeted therapies may lead to enhanced and sustained clinical antitumor efficacy in CRCs harboring the BRAF(V600E) mutation.
title: Antitumor activity of BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in preclinical models of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Endocrine resistance is a significant problem in breast cancer treatment.
title: AGR2 predicts tamoxifen resistance in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: Thus identification and validation of novel resistance determinants is important to improve treatment efficacy and patient outcome.
title: AGR2 predicts tamoxifen resistance in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: In our work, AGR2 expression was determined by qRT-PCR in Tru-Cut needle biopsies from tamoxifen-treated postmenopausal breast cancer patients.
title: AGR2 predicts tamoxifen resistance in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: Our results showed inversed association of AGR2 mRNA levels with primary treatment response (P = 0.0011) and progression-free survival (P = 0.0366) in 61 ER-positive breast carcinomas.
title: AGR2 predicts tamoxifen resistance in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: As shown by our experimental and clinical evaluations, elevated AGR2 expression predicts decreased efficacy of tamoxifen treatment.
title: AGR2 predicts tamoxifen resistance in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: From this perspective, AGR2 is a potential predictive biomarker enabling selection of an optimal algorithm for adjuvant hormonal therapy in postmenopausal ER-positive breast cancer patients.
title: AGR2 predicts tamoxifen resistance in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: BACKGROUND: Diffuse low-grade and intermediate-grade gliomas (which together make up the lower-grade gliomas, World Health Organization grades II and III) have highly variable clinical behavior that is not adequately predicted on the basis of histologic class.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Some are indolent; others quickly progress to glioblastoma.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: The uncertainty is compounded by interobserver variability in histologic diagnosis.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Mutations in IDH, TP53, and ATRX and codeletion of chromosome arms 1p and 19q (1p/19q codeletion) have been implicated as clinically relevant markers of lower-grade gliomas.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: METHODS: We performed genomewide analyses of 293 lower-grade gliomas from adults, incorporating exome sequence, DNA copy number, DNA methylation, messenger RNA expression, microRNA expression, and targeted protein expression.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: These data were integrated and tested for correlation with clinical outcomes.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: RESULTS: Unsupervised clustering of mutations and data from RNA, DNA-copy-number, and DNA-methylation platforms uncovered concordant classification of three robust, nonoverlapping, prognostically significant subtypes of lower-grade glioma that were captured more accurately by IDH, 1p/19q, and TP53 status than by histologic class.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Patients who had lower-grade gliomas with an IDH mutation and 1p/19q codeletion had the most favorable clinical outcomes.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Their gliomas harbored mutations in CIC, FUBP1, NOTCH1, and the TERT promoter.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Nearly all lower-grade gliomas with IDH mutations and no 1p/19q codeletion had mutations in TP53 (94%) and ATRX inactivation (86%).
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: The large majority of lower-grade gliomas without an IDH mutation had genomic aberrations and clinical behavior strikingly similar to those found in primary glioblastoma.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The integration of genomewide data from multiple platforms delineated three molecular classes of lower-grade gliomas that were more concordant with IDH, 1p/19q, and TP53 status than with histologic class.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Lower-grade gliomas with an IDH mutation either had 1p/19q codeletion or carried a TP53 mutation.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: Most lower-grade gliomas without an IDH mutation were molecularly and clinically similar to glioblastoma.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: (Funded by the National Institutes of Health.
title: Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.
Comprehensive, Integrative Genomic Analysis of Diffuse Lower-Grade Gliomas.

text: von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is a dominantly inherited familial cancer syndrome resulting from mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: VHL disease displays marked variation in expression and the presence of pheochromocytoma has been linked to missense VHL mutations.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: We analyzed genotype-phenotype correlations in 573 individuals with VHL disease.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: Routine clinical and radiological surveillance of VHL patients and at-risk relatives was associated with increased detection of retinal angiomatosis (73 vs. 59% of cases) and a reduction in age at diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (44.0+/-10.9 vs. 39.7+/-10.3 years).
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: We confirmed the association of pheochromocytoma with missense mutations described previously, but stratifying missense mutations into those that resulted in substitution of a surface amino acid and those that disrupted structural integrity demonstrated that surface amino acid substitutions conferred a higher pheochromocytoma risk.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: Age at first manifestation of VHL disease was significantly earlier (P=0.001), and age-related risks of retinal angiomas and RCC were higher (P=0.022 and P=0.0008, respectively) in individuals with a nonsense or frameshift mutation than in those with deletions or missense mutations that disrupted the structural integrity of the VHL gene product (pVHL).
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: These results extend genotype-phenotype-protein structure correlations in VHL disease and provide a baseline for future chemoprevention studies in VHL disease.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlations in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

text: BACKGROUND: Mutations in the v-Ki-ras2 Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog (KRAS) play a critical role in cancer cell growth and resistance to therapy.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: Most mutations occur at codons 12 and 13.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: In colorectal cancer, the presence of any mutant KRas amino acid substitution is a negative predictor of patient response to targeted therapy.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: However, in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), the evidence that KRAS mutation is a predictive factor is conflicting.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: METHODS: We used data from a molecularly targeted clinical trial for 215 patients with tissues available out of 268 evaluable patients with refractory NSCLC to examine associations between specific mutant KRas proteins and progression-free survival and tumor gene expression.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: Transcriptome microarray studies of patient tumor samples and reverse-phase protein array studies of a panel of 67 NSCLC cell lines with known substitutions in KRas and in immortalized human bronchial epithelial cells stably expressing different mutant KRas proteins were used to investigate signaling pathway activation.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: Molecular modeling was used to study the conformations of wild-type and mutant KRas proteins.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: Kaplan-Meier curves and Cox regression were used to analyze survival data.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: All statistical tests were two-sided.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: RESULTS: Patients whose tumors had either mutant KRas-Gly12Cys or mutant KRas-Gly12Val had worse progression-free survival compared with patients whose tumors had other mutant KRas proteins or wild-type KRas (P = .046, median survival = 1.84 months) compared with all other mutant KRas (median survival = 3.35 months) or wild-type KRas (median survival = 1.95 months).
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: NSCLC cell lines with mutant KRas-Gly12Asp had activated phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI-3-K) and mitogen-activated protein/extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase (MEK) signaling, whereas those with mutant KRas-Gly12Cys or mutant KRas-Gly12Val had activated Ral signaling and decreased growth factor-dependent Akt activation.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: Molecular modeling studies showed that different conformations imposed by mutant KRas may lead to altered association with downstream signaling transducers.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Not all mutant KRas proteins affect patient survival or downstream signaling in a similar way.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: The heterogeneous behavior of mutant KRas proteins implies that therapeutic interventions may need to take into account the specific mutant KRas expressed by the tumor.
title: Effect of KRAS oncogene substitutions on protein behavior: implications for signaling and clinical outcome.

text: BACKGROUND: Inhibition of MEK stops cell proliferation and induces apoptosis; therefore, this enzyme is a key anticancer target.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Trametinib is a selective, orally administered MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: We aimed to define the maximum tolerated dose and recommended phase 2 dose of trametinib and to assess its safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and response rate in individuals with advanced solid tumours.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: METHODS: We undertook a multicentre phase 1 study in patients with advanced solid tumours and adequate organ function.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The study was in three parts: dose escalation to define the maximum tolerated dose; identification of the recommended phase 2 dose; and assessment of pharmacodynamic changes.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Intermittent and continuous dosing regimens were analysed.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Blood samples and tumour biopsy specimens were taken to assess pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic changes.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Adverse events were defined with common toxicity criteria, and tumour response was measured by Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00687622.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: FINDINGS: We enrolled 206 patients (median age 58.5 years, range 19-92).
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Dose-limiting toxic effects included rash (n=2), diarrhoea (n=1), and central serous retinopathy (n=2).
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The most common treatment-related adverse events were rash or dermatitis acneiform (n=165; 80%) and diarrhoea (87; 42%), most of which were grade 1 and 2.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The maximum tolerated dose was 3 mg once daily and the recommended phase 2 dose was 2 mg a day.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The effective half-life of trametinib was about 4 days.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: At the recommended phase 2 dose, the exposure profile of the drug showed low interpatient variability and a small peak:trough ratio of 1.81.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Furthermore, mean concentrations in plasma were greater than the preclinical target concentration throughout the dosing interval.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Pathway inhibition and clinical activity were seen, with 21 (10%) objective responses recorded.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: The recommended phase 2 dose of 2 mg trametinib once a day is tolerable, with manageable side-effects.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Trametinib's inhibition of the expected target and clinical activity warrants its further development as a monotherapy and in combination.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: FUNDING: GlaxoSmithKline.
title: Safety, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, and efficacy data for the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: BACKGROUND: The combined inhibition of BRAF and MEK is hypothesized to improve clinical outcomes in patients with melanoma by preventing or delaying the onset of resistance observed with BRAF inhibitors alone.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: This randomized phase 3 study evaluated the combination of the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib and the MEK inhibitor cobimetinib.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: METHODS: We randomly assigned 495 patients with previously untreated unresectable locally advanced or metastatic BRAF V600 mutation-positive melanoma to receive vemurafenib and cobimetinib (combination group) or vemurafenib and placebo (control group).
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: The primary end point was investigator-assessed progression-free survival.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: RESULTS: The median progression-free survival was 9.9 months in the combination group and 6.2 months in the control group (hazard ratio for death or disease progression, 0.51; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.39 to 0.68; P<0.001).
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: The rate of complete or partial response in the combination group was 68%, as compared with 45% in the control group (P<0.001), including rates of complete response of 10% in the combination group and 4% in the control group.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Progression-free survival as assessed by independent review was similar to investigator-assessed progression-free survival.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Interim analyses of overall survival showed 9-month survival rates of 81% (95% CI, 75 to 87) in the combination group and 73% (95% CI, 65 to 80) in the control group.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Vemurafenib and cobimetinib was associated with a nonsignificantly higher incidence of adverse events of grade 3 or higher, as compared with vemurafenib and placebo (65% vs. 59%), and there was no significant difference in the rate of study-drug discontinuation.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: The number of secondary cutaneous cancers decreased with the combination therapy.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The addition of cobimetinib to vemurafenib was associated with a significant improvement in progression-free survival among patients with BRAF V600-mutated metastatic melanoma, at the cost of some increase in toxicity.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: (Funded by F. Hoffmann-La Roche/Genentech; coBRIM ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01689519.
title: Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.
Combined vemurafenib and cobimetinib in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Prostate cancer (PCa) is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in men; however, the molecular mechanisms leading to its development and progression are not yet fully elucidated.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Of note, it has been recently shown that conditional stk11 knockout mice develop atypical hyperplasia and prostate intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: We recently reported an inverse correlation between the activity of the STK11/AMPK pathway and the MAPK/p38 cascade in HIF1A-dependent malignancies.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Furthermore, MAPK/p38 overactivation was detected in benign prostate hyperplasia, PIN and PCa in mice and humans.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Here we report that STK11 expression is significantly decreased in PCa compared to normal tissues.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Moreover, STK11 protein levels decreased throughout prostate carcinogenesis.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: To gain insight into the role of STK11-MAPK/p38 activity balance in PCa, we treated PCa cell lines and primary biopsies with a well-established MAPK14-MAPK11 inhibitor (SB202190), which has been extensively used in vitro and in vivo.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Our results indicate that inhibition of MAPK/p38 significantly affects PCa cell survival in an STK11-dependent manner.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Indeed, we found that pharmacologic inactivation of MAPK/p38 does not affect viability of STK11-proficient PCa cells due to the triggering of the AMPK-dependent autophagic pathway, while it induces apoptosis in STK11-deficient cells irrespective of androgen receptor (AR) status.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Of note, AMPK inactivation or autophagy inhibition in STK11-proficient cells sensitize SB202190-treated PCa cells to apoptosis.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: On the other end, reconstitution of functional STK11 in STK11-deficient PCa cells abrogates apoptosis.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Collectively, our data show that STK11 is a key factor involved in the early phases of prostate carcinogenesis, and suggest that it might be used as a predictive marker of therapeutic response to MAPK/p38 inhibitors in PCa patients.
title: Loss of STK11 expression is an early event in prostate carcinogenesis and predicts therapeutic response to targeted therapy against MAPK/p38.

text: Activating mutations in the neuroblastoma rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog (NRAS) gene are common genetic events in malignant melanoma being found in 15-25% of cases.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: NRAS is thought to activate both mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) and PI3K signaling in melanoma cells.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: We studied the influence of different components on the MAP/extracellular signal-regulated (ERK) kinase (MEK) and PI3K/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR)-signaling cascade in NRAS mutant melanoma cells.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: In general, these cells were more sensitive to MEK inhibition compared with inhibition in the PI3K/mTOR cascade.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K was superior to MEK and mTOR1,2 inhibition in all NRAS mutant melanoma cell lines tested, suggesting that PI3K signaling is more important for cell survival in NRAS mutant melanoma when MEK is inhibited.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: However, targeting of PI3K/mTOR1,2 in combination with MEK inhibitors is necessary to effectively abolish growth of NRAS mutant melanoma cells in vitro and regress xenografted NRAS mutant melanoma.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: Furthermore, we showed that MEK and PI3K/mTOR1,2 inhibition is synergistic.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: Expression analysis confirms that combined MEK and PI3K/mTOR1,2 inhibition predominantly influences genes in the rat sarcoma (RAS) pathway and growth factor receptor pathways, which signal through MEK/ERK and PI3K/mTOR, respectively.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: Our results suggest that combined targeting of the MEK/ERK and PI3K/mTOR pathways has antitumor activity and might serve as a therapeutic option in the treatment of NRAS mutant melanoma, for which there are currently no effective therapies.
title: Combined targeting of MEK and PI3K/mTOR effector pathways is necessary to effectively inhibit NRAS mutant melanoma in vitro and in vivo.

text: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to understand the role of PIK3CA and PTEN on the resistance of human ovarian cancer cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: METHODS: Human ovarian cancer cell OVCAR-3 and cisplatin-resistant subclone OVCAR-3/CDDP cells were used for these studies.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: The expressions of apoptosis regulating proteins and PI3K/Akt signaling proteins were systematically examined.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: RESULTS: OVCAR-3/CDDP cells were 4.8-fold more resistant to cisplatin compared to OVCAR-3 cells following 72 h exposure to this drug.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: This resistance was paralleled with reduced susceptibility to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: Apoptotic proteins were differentially expressed in OVCAR-3/CDDP cells, resulting in the inhibition of Bax translocalization.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: Cisplatin inhibited Akt phosphorylation and activation in OVCAR-3 cells but not in OVCAR-3/CDDP cells.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: The specific PI3K inhibitors LY294002 and wortmannin sensitized OVCAR-3/CDDP cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis and decreased cell viability.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: A low level of PTEN expression was strongly associated with amplified PIK3CA and PI3K/Akt activities in OVCAR-3/CDDP cells.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: Small interfering RNA knockdown of PTEN and the expression of active p110alpha resulted in a blockade of apoptosis by cisplatin in OVCAR-3 cells.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These results collectively indicate that the development of resistance in OVCAR-3 cells was derived by increased PIK3CA transcription and reduction of PTEN expression.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: These alterations conferred cisplatin resistance to cisplatin through the activation of PI3K/Akt and the inhibition of Bax translocation.
title: Activation of PI3K/Akt pathway by PTEN reduction and PIK3CA mRNA amplification contributes to cisplatin resistance in an ovarian cancer cell line.

text: BACKGROUND: Previous, uncontrolled studies have suggested that first-line treatment with gefitinib would be efficacious in selected patients with non-small-cell lung cancer.
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: METHODS: In this phase 3, open-label study, we randomly assigned previously untreated patients in East Asia who had advanced pulmonary adenocarcinoma and who were nonsmokers or former light smokers to receive gefitinib (250 mg per day) (609 patients) or carboplatin (at a dose calculated to produce an area under the curve of 5 or 6 mg per milliliter per minute) plus paclitaxel (200 mg per square meter of body-surface area) (608 patients).
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: The primary end point was progression-free survival.
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: The 12-month rates of progression-free survival were 24.9% with gefitinib and 6.7% with carboplatin-paclitaxel.
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: The study met its primary objective of showing the noninferiority of gefitinib and also showed its superiority, as compared with carboplatin-paclitaxel, with respect to progression-free survival in the intention-to-treat population (hazard ratio for progression or death, 0.74; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.65 to 0.85; P<0.001).
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: In the subgroup of 261 patients who were positive for the epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) mutation, progression-free survival was significantly longer among those who received gefitinib than among those who received carboplatin-paclitaxel (hazard ratio for progression or death, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.36 to 0.64; P<0.001), whereas in the subgroup of 176 patients who were negative for the mutation, progression-free survival was significantly longer among those who received carboplatin-paclitaxel (hazard ratio for progression or death with gefitinib, 2.85; 95% CI, 2.05 to 3.98; P<0.001).
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: The most common adverse events were rash or acne (in 66.2% of patients) and diarrhea (46.6%) in the gefitinib group and neurotoxic effects (69.9%), neutropenia (67.1%), and alopecia (58.4%) in the carboplatin-paclitaxel group.
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Gefitinib is superior to carboplatin-paclitaxel as an initial treatment for pulmonary adenocarcinoma among nonsmokers or former light smokers in East Asia.
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: The presence in the tumor of a mutation of the EGFR gene is a strong predictor of a better outcome with gefitinib.
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00322452.)
title: Gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel in pulmonary adenocarcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND/AIMS: Resembling a potential therapeutic drug target, fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) amplification and expression was assessed in 515 human colorectal cancer (CRC) tissue samples, lymph node metastases and CRC cell lines.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: FGFR1 amplification status was determined using fluorescence in situ hybridization.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: Additionally, we assessed protein levels employing Western blots and immunohistochemistry.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: The FGFR1 mRNA localization was analyzed using mRNA in situ hybridization.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: Functional studies employed the FGFR inhibitor NVP-BGJ398.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Of 454 primary CRCs, 24 displayed FGFR1 amplification.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: 92/94 lymph node metastases presented the same amplification status as the primary tumor.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: Of 99 investigated tumors, 18 revealed membranous activated pFGFR1 protein.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: FGFR1 mRNA levels were independent of the amplification status or pFGFR1 protein occurrence.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: In vitro, a strong antiproliferative effect of NVP-BGJ398 could be detected in cell lines exhibiting high FGFR1 protein.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: FGFR1 is a potential therapeutic target in a subset of CRC.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: FGFR1 protein is likely to represent a central factor limiting the efficacy of FGFR inhibitors.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: The lack of correlation between its evaluation at genetic/mRNA level and its protein occurrence indicates that the assessment of the receptor at an immunohistochemical level most likely represents a suitable way to assess FGFR1 as a predictive biomarker for patient selection in future clinical trials.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 as a putative therapy target in colorectal cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Gene mutations along the Ras pathway (KRAS, NRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA) occur in approximately 50% of colorectal cancers (CRC) and correlate with poor response to anti-EGF receptor (EGFR) therapies.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: We assessed the effects of mitogen-activated protein (MAP)/extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) kinase (MEK) and phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/mTOR inhibitors, which neutralize the major Ras effectors, in patient-derived xenografts from RAS/RAF/PIK3CA-mutant metastatic CRCs (mCRC).
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Forty mCRC specimens harboring KRAS, NRAS, BRAF, and/or PIK3CA mutations were implanted in nonobese diabetic/severe combined immunodeficient (NOD/SCID) mice.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: Each xenograft was expanded into four treatment arms: placebo, the MEK inhibitor AZD6244, the PI3K/mTOR inhibitor, BEZ235, or AZD6244 + BEZ235.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: Cases initially treated with placebo crossed over to AZD6244, BEZ235, and the anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody cetuximab.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: RESULTS: At the 3-week evaluation time point, cotreatment of established tumors with AZD6244 + BEZ235 induced disease stabilization in the majority of cases (70%) but did not lead to overt tumor regression.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: Monotherapy was less effective, with BEZ235 displaying higher activity than AZD6244 (disease control rates, DCRs: AZD6244, 27.5%; BEZ235, 42.5%).
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: Triple therapy with cetuximab provided further advantage (DCR, 88%).
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: The extent of disease control declined at the 6-week evaluation time point (DCRs: AZD6244, 13.9%; BEZ235, 16.2%; AZD6244 + BEZ235, 34%).
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: Cross-analysis of mice harboring xenografts from the same original tumor and treated with each of the different modalities revealed subgroups with preferential sensitivity to AZD6244 (12.5%), BEZ235 (35%), or AZD6244 + BEZ235 (42.5%); another subgroup (10%) showed equivalent response to any treatment.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The prevalent growth-suppressive effects produced by MEK and PI3K/mTOR inhibition suggest that this strategy may retard disease progression in patients.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: However, data offer cautionary evidence against the occurrence of durable responses.
title: Inhibition of MEK and PI3K/mTOR suppresses tumor growth but does not cause tumor regression in patient-derived xenografts of RAS-mutant colorectal carcinomas.

text: Metastatic melanoma is one of the most aggressive forms of cutaneous cancers.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: Although recent therapeutic advances have prolonged patient survival, the prognosis remains dismal.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: C-MER proto-oncogene tyrosine kinase (MERTK) is a receptor tyrosine kinase with oncogenic properties that is often overexpressed or activated in various malignancies.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: Using both protein immunohistochemistry and microarray analyses, we demonstrate that MERTK expression correlates with disease progression.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: MERTK expression was highest in metastatic melanomas, followed by primary melanomas, while the lowest expression was observed in nevi.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: Additionally, over half of melanoma cell lines overexpressed MERTK compared with normal human melanocytes; however, overexpression did not correlate with mutations in BRAF or RAS.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: Stimulation of melanoma cells with the MERTK ligand GAS6 resulted in the activation of several downstream signaling pathways including MAPK/ERK, PI3K/AKT, and JAK/STAT.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: MERTK inhibition via shRNA reduced MERTK-mediated downstream signaling, reduced colony formation by up to 59%, and diminished tumor volume by 60% in a human melanoma murine xenograft model.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: Treatment of melanoma cells with UNC1062, a novel MERTK-selective small-molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor, reduced activation of MERTK-mediated downstream signaling, induced apoptosis in culture, reduced colony formation in soft agar, and inhibited invasion of melanoma cells.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: This work establishes MERTK as a therapeutic target in melanoma and provides a rationale for the continued development of MERTK-targeted therapies.
title: MERTK receptor tyrosine kinase is a therapeutic target in melanoma.

text: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations are predictive markers for response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (EGFR-TKIs) in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: The most common mutations, exon 19 short deletions and exon 20 point mutation (L858R), activate the tyrosine kinase and confer sensitivity to EGFR-TKIs.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: However, the function and sensitivity of rare mutations to EGFR-TKIs are unknown.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: In this study, we found five EGFR mutations out of 16 patients with NSCLC of African-American descent.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: The frequency of such mutations in this patient population appears to be significantly higher than previously reported.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: Two of them (N771GY and A767-V769dup) are rare insertion mutations located in exon 20.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: Using YFP-tagged EGFR mutants, we demonstrated that the mutations confer increased kinase activity, but no sensitivity to erlotinib at clinically available concentrations.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: In addition, we examined efficacy of PF00299804, an irreversible EGFR-TKI.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: Although the drug failed to show efficacy to T790M and S768N mutations, the exon 20 insertion mutations were sensitive to PF00299804.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: These data suggest that rare mutations in exon 20 are resistant to erlotinib but may be sensitive to irreversible inhibitors.
title: Characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer patients of African-American ancestry.

text: Treatment success in patients with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is heterogeneous.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Cytogenetic and molecular alterations are strong prognostic factors, which have been used to individualize treatment.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Here, we studied the impact of TP53 mutations on the outcome of AML patients with adverse cytogenetic risk treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Samples of 97 patients with AML and adverse-risk cytogenetics who had received a HSCT within three randomized trials were analysed.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Complete sequencing of the TP53 coding region was performed using next generation sequencing.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: The median age was 51 years.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Overall, TP53 mutations were found in 40 patients (41%).
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: With a median follow up of 67 months, the three-year probabilities of overall survival (OS) and event-free survival for patients with TP53 wild type were 33% [95% confidence interval (CI), 21% to 45%] and 24% (95% CI, 13% to 35%) compared to 10% (95% CI, 0% to 19%) and 8% (95% CI, 0% to 16%) (P = 0.002 and P = 0.007) for those with mutated TP53, respectively.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: In multivariate analysis, the TP53-mutation status had a negative impact on OS (Hazard Ratio = 1.7; P = 0.066).
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Mutational analysis of TP53 might be an important additional tool to predict outcome after HSCT in patients with adverse karyotype AML.
title: TP53 mutation in patients with high-risk acute myeloid leukaemia treated with allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

text: Previous reports have provided evidence that p53 mutation is a strong negative predictor of response to MDM2 inhibitors.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: However, this correlation is not absolute, as many p53Mutant cell lines have been reported to respond to MDM2 inhibition, while many p53WT cell lines have been shown not to respond.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: To better understand the nature of these exceptions, we screened a panel of 260 cell lines and noted similar discrepancies.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: However, upon extensive curation of this panel, these apparent exceptions could be eliminated, revealing a perfect correlation between p53 mutational status and MDM2 inhibitor responsiveness.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: It has been suggested that the MDM2-amplified subset of p53WT tumors might be particularly sensitive to MDM2 inhibition.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: To facilitate clinical testing of this hypothesis, we identified a rationally derived copy number cutoff for assignment of functionally relevant MDM2 amplification.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: Applying this cutoff resulted in a pan-cancer MDM2 amplification rate far lower than previously published.
title: Identifying the determinants of response to MDM2 inhibition.

text: OBJECTIVE: Bevacizumab is the only anti-angiogenic agent approved in first-line therapy for metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: Although chemotherapy plus bevacizumab has led to improve outcomes for mCRC patients and is a common choice for first-line treatment of mCRC, previous research has established no prominent biomarker that can help to select patients who may benefit from bevacizumab in order to improve cost-effectiveness and therapeutic outcomes.
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: The aim of this study was to compare pre- and post-therapeutic VEGF immunohistochemical (IHC) expression in mCRC patients treated with FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab to identify its potential role as a predictive biomarker.
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: METHODS: A total of 57 mCRC patients who underwent FOLFIRI combined with bevacizumab chemotherapy as a first-line neoadjuvant regimen were enrolled and clinical outcome data analyzed.
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: RESULTS: Low post-therapeutic VEGF expression (P < 0.001) and decreased peri-therapeutic VEGF expression (P < 0.001) were significantly predictive factors of responders.
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: Furthermore, the 6-month progression-free survival (PFS) rate in mCRC patients with decreased peri-therapeutic VEGF expression was significantly better than the rate for those patients with no peri-therapeutic VEGF expression alterations (P = 0.033).
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Decreased peri-therapeutic VEGF expression in mCRC patients could probably be used to predict responsiveness to bevacizumab and subsequent PFS in clinical practice.
title: Decreased peritherapeutic VEGF expression could be a predictor of responsiveness to first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab in mCRC patients.

text: PURPOSE: To assess the tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PKs), and pharmacodynamics (PDs) of the mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase (MEK) 1/2 inhibitor AZD6244 (ARRY-142886) in patients with advanced cancer.
title: Phase I pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study of the oral, small-molecule mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase 1/2 inhibitor AZD6244 (ARRY-142886) in patients with advanced cancers.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: In part A, patients received escalating doses to determine the maximum-tolerated dose (MTD).
title: Phase I pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study of the oral, small-molecule mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase 1/2 inhibitor AZD6244 (ARRY-142886) in patients with advanced cancers.

title: Phase I pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study of the oral, small-molecule mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase 1/2 inhibitor AZD6244 (ARRY-142886) in patients with advanced cancers.

title: Phase I pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study of the oral, small-molecule mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase 1/2 inhibitor AZD6244 (ARRY-142886) in patients with advanced cancers.

title: Phase I pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study of the oral, small-molecule mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase 1/2 inhibitor AZD6244 (ARRY-142886) in patients with advanced cancers.
