text: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a highly heterogeneous disease, for which prognosis has been relegated to clinicopathologic staging for decades.
title: A multigene mutation classification of 468 colorectal cancers reveals a prognostic role for APC.

text: There is a need to stratify subpopulations of CRC on a molecular basis to better predict outcome and assign therapies.
title: A multigene mutation classification of 468 colorectal cancers reveals a prognostic role for APC.

text: Here we report targeted exome-sequencing of 1,321 cancer-related genes on 468 tumour specimens, which identified a subset of 17 genes that best classify CRC, with APC playing a central role in predicting overall survival.
title: A multigene mutation classification of 468 colorectal cancers reveals a prognostic role for APC.

text: APC may assume 0, 1 or 2 truncating mutations, each with a striking differential impact on survival.
title: A multigene mutation classification of 468 colorectal cancers reveals a prognostic role for APC.

text: Tumours lacking any APC mutation carry a worse prognosis than single APC mutation tumours; however, two APC mutation tumours with mutant KRAS and TP53 confer the poorest survival among all the subgroups examined.
title: A multigene mutation classification of 468 colorectal cancers reveals a prognostic role for APC.

text: Our study demonstrates a prognostic role for APC and suggests that sequencing of APC may have clinical utility in the routine staging and potential therapeutic assignment for CRC.
title: A multigene mutation classification of 468 colorectal cancers reveals a prognostic role for APC.

text: INTRODUCTION: We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene copy number as a potential biomarker of survival for patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) receiving single-agent treatment with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: We systematically identified articles investigating EGFR gene copy number by fluorescent or chromogenic in situ hybridization in patients with advanced or recurrent NSCLC treated with the TKIs erlotinib or gefitinib, (last search: 31 June 2009).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Eligible studies had to report on overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS) or time-to-progression (TTP), stratified by EGFR gene copy number.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Summary hazard ratios (HRs) were calculated using random-effects models.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Among 255 identified studies, 20 (1689 patients, 594 with increased gene copy number), 10 (822 patients, 290 with increased gene copy number) and 5 (294 patients, 129 with increased gene copy number) were eligible for the OS, PFS and TTP meta-analyses, respectively.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Increased EGFR gene copy number was associated with increased OS (HR = 0.77; 95% CI 0.66-0.89; P = 0.001), PFS (HR = 0.60; 95% CI 0.46-0.79; P<0.001) and TTP (HR = 0.50; 95% CI 0.28-0.91; P = 0.02).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among predominantly white populations, increased EGFR gene copy number was strongly associated with improved survival (HR = 0.70; 95% CI 0.59-0.82; P<0.001), whereas it did not influence survival in East Asians (HR = 1.11; 95% CI 0.82-1.50; P=0.50).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: This difference was statistically significant (P=0.02).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Among TKI-treated patients, increased EGFR gene copy number appears to be associated with improved survival outcomes.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The effect on OS appears to be limited to patients of non-Asian descent.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for patients receiving tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment: a systematic review and meta-analysis in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Through a prospective clinical sequencing program for advanced cancers, four index cases were identified which harbor gene rearrangements of FGFR2, including patients with cholangiocarcinoma, breast cancer, and prostate cancer.
title: Identification of targetable FGFR gene fusions in diverse cancers.

text: After extending our assessment of FGFR rearrangements across multiple tumor cohorts, we identified additional FGFR fusions with intact kinase domains in lung squamous cell cancer, bladder cancer, thyroid cancer, oral cancer, glioblastoma, and head and neck squamous cell cancer.
title: Identification of targetable FGFR gene fusions in diverse cancers.

text: All FGFR fusion partners tested exhibit oligomerization capability, suggesting a shared mode of kinase activation.
title: Identification of targetable FGFR gene fusions in diverse cancers.

text: Overexpression of FGFR fusion proteins induced cell proliferation.
title: Identification of targetable FGFR gene fusions in diverse cancers.

text: Two bladder cancer cell lines that harbor FGFR3 fusion proteins exhibited enhanced susceptibility to pharmacologic inhibition in vitro and in vivo.
title: Identification of targetable FGFR gene fusions in diverse cancers.

text: Because of the combinatorial possibilities of FGFR family fusion to a variety of oligomerization partners, clinical sequencing efforts, which incorporate transcriptome analysis for gene fusions, are poised to identify rare, targetable FGFR fusions across diverse cancer types.
title: Identification of targetable FGFR gene fusions in diverse cancers.

text: This is the case of a 47-year-old woman diagnosed with chemotherapy and radiation-refractory BRAF V600E mutant, poorly differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC), with multiple metastatic lesions within the liver, lungs, pleura, and bone, stage IV.
title: Dramatic response to dabrafenib and trametinib combination in a BRAF V600E-mutated cholangiocarcinoma: implementation of a molecular tumour board and next-generation sequencing for personalized medicine.

text: Discussion of her malignancy's next-generation sequencing genomic information at a multidisciplinary molecular tumour board took place.
title: Dramatic response to dabrafenib and trametinib combination in a BRAF V600E-mutated cholangiocarcinoma: implementation of a molecular tumour board and next-generation sequencing for personalized medicine.

text: The patient was considered a suitable candidate for dual BRAF and MEK inhibition, with the intent to prolong her survival and optimize the quality of life.
title: Dramatic response to dabrafenib and trametinib combination in a BRAF V600E-mutated cholangiocarcinoma: implementation of a molecular tumour board and next-generation sequencing for personalized medicine.

text: We report her excellent tolerance and exceptional response to dual therapy with dabrafenib and trametinib, including symptomatic and sustained near-complete radiological improvement.
title: Dramatic response to dabrafenib and trametinib combination in a BRAF V600E-mutated cholangiocarcinoma: implementation of a molecular tumour board and next-generation sequencing for personalized medicine.

text: We also briefly review the current knowledge of the genomics of cholangiocarcinoma with a focus on BRAF mutations, and make a point of the importance of the establishment of a molecular tumour board for personalized genomic medicine approaches.
title: Dramatic response to dabrafenib and trametinib combination in a BRAF V600E-mutated cholangiocarcinoma: implementation of a molecular tumour board and next-generation sequencing for personalized medicine.

text: To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of the use of personalized genomic information for the successful management of a patient with ICC, and it is also the first description of dual BRAF and MEK targeted therapy in this malignancy, leading to what is considered an exceptional response.
title: Dramatic response to dabrafenib and trametinib combination in a BRAF V600E-mutated cholangiocarcinoma: implementation of a molecular tumour board and next-generation sequencing for personalized medicine.

text: Studies on the role of TP53 mutation in breast cancer response to chemotherapy are conflicting.
title: p53-mediated senescence impairs the apoptotic response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in breast cancer.

text: Here, we show that, contrary to dogma, MMTV-Wnt1 mammary tumors with mutant p53 exhibited a superior clinical response compared to tumors with wild-type p53.
title: p53-mediated senescence impairs the apoptotic response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in breast cancer.

text: Doxorubicin-treated p53 mutant tumors failed to arrest proliferation, leading to abnormal mitoses and cell death, whereas p53 wild-type tumors arrested, avoiding mitotic catastrophe.
title: p53-mediated senescence impairs the apoptotic response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in breast cancer.

text: Senescent tumor cells persisted, secreting senescence-associated cytokines exhibiting autocrine/paracrine activity and mitogenic potential.
title: p53-mediated senescence impairs the apoptotic response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in breast cancer.

text: Wild-type p53 still mediated arrest and inhibited drug response even in the context of heterozygous p53 point mutations or absence of p21.
title: p53-mediated senescence impairs the apoptotic response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in breast cancer.

text: Thus, we show that wild-type p53 activity hinders chemotherapy response and demonstrate the need to reassess the paradigm for p53 in cancer therapy.
title: p53-mediated senescence impairs the apoptotic response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in breast cancer.

text: All trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is able to induce complete remission (CR) in almost all patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) through in vivo differentiation of APL blasts.
title: All trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: However, it cannot eliminate the leukemic clone and to be effective must be used in combination with anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
title: All trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Experience accumulated over the last 10 years has clearly shown that the combination of ATRA and chemotherapy gives better survival in newly diagnosed APL than chemotherapy alone because of fewer relapses and a higher CR rate experienced by these patients.
title: All trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: It is also strongly suggested that maintenance treatment with ATRA, and possibly in combination with low-dose chemotherapy, can further reduce the incidence of relapse.
title: All trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Overall, more than 90% of patients with newly diagnosed APL can achieve CR and about 75% can be cured by the combination of ATRA and chemotherapy.
title: All trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Regorafenib is an oral multikinase inhibitor that blocks the activity of protein kinases involved in the regulation of tumor angiogenesis (VEGFR1, 2, 3; angiopoietin-1 receptor), oncogenesis (stem cell growth factor receptor; RET; BRAF including BRAFV600E), and tumor microenvironment (PDGFR-beta and FGFR).
title: Regorafenib in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Based on data from the Phase III CORRECT study, regorafenib stands as a further option for patient affected by metastatic colorectal cancer who have exhausted previous available therapies.
title: Regorafenib in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Its multi-targeted effect might explain activity in advanced lines of treatment, when cancer cells have been heavily challenged with previous lines of therapy and potentially developed multiple mechanisms of resistance, but also makes difficult to identify predictive biomarkers.
title: Regorafenib in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: In this article we examine preclinical as well as clinical data of regorafenib in the therapy of metastatic colorectal cancer, challenges for potential markers of efficacy and its role in the treatment algorithm.
title: Regorafenib in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Lung cancer patients carrying sensitive epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations show dramatic responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).
title: EGFR T790M resistance mutation in non small-cell lung carcinoma.

text: However, the majority of patients whose disease responds to drugs eventually develop resistance to these EGFR-TKIs.
title: EGFR T790M resistance mutation in non small-cell lung carcinoma.

text: The T790M gatekeeper mutation in the EGFR tyrosine kinase domain accounts for half of resistance to these drugs.
title: EGFR T790M resistance mutation in non small-cell lung carcinoma.

text: In some patients, this mutation is also detected as a primary event before drug exposure, at a frequency that is highly dependent on the technique used.
title: EGFR T790M resistance mutation in non small-cell lung carcinoma.

text: This review will focus on the methods that have been used to detect the T790M mutation, and its potential clinical applications both in TKI naive patients and in patients with an acquired resistance.
title: EGFR T790M resistance mutation in non small-cell lung carcinoma.

text: Everolimus, an inhibitor of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), is effective in treating tumors harboring alterations in the mTOR pathway.
title: Response and acquired resistance to everolimus in anaplastic thyroid cancer.

text: Mechanisms of resistance to everolimus remain undefined.
title: Response and acquired resistance to everolimus in anaplastic thyroid cancer.

text: Resistance developed in a patient with metastatic anaplastic thyroid carcinoma after an extraordinary 18-month response.
title: Response and acquired resistance to everolimus in anaplastic thyroid cancer.

text: Whole-exome sequencing of pretreatment and drug-resistant tumors revealed a nonsense mutation in TSC2, a negative regulator of mTOR, suggesting a mechanism for exquisite sensitivity to everolimus.
title: Response and acquired resistance to everolimus in anaplastic thyroid cancer.

text: The resistant tumor also harbored a mutation in MTOR that confers resistance to allosteric mTOR inhibition.
title: Response and acquired resistance to everolimus in anaplastic thyroid cancer.

text: The mutation remains sensitive to mTOR kinase inhibitors.
title: Response and acquired resistance to everolimus in anaplastic thyroid cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: We have identified previously undiscovered BRAF in-frame deletions near the alphaC-helix region of the kinase domain in pancreatic, lung, ovarian, and thyroid cancers.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: These deletions are mutually exclusive with KRAS mutations and occur in 4.21% of KRAS wild-type pancreatic cancer.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: siRNA knockdown in cells harboring BRAF deletions showed that the MAPK activity and cell growth are BRAF dependent.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: Structurally, the BRAF deletions are predicted to shorten the beta3/alphaC-helix loop and hinder its flexibility by locking the helix in the active alphaC-helix-in conformation that favors dimer formation.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: Expression of L485-P490-deleted BRAF is able to transform NIH/3T3 cells in a BRAF dimer-dependent manner.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: BRAF homodimer is confirmed to be the dominant RAF dimer by proximity ligation assays in BRAF deletion cells, which are resistant to the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib and sensitive to LY3009120, a RAF dimer inhibitor.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: In tumor models with BRAF deletions, LY3009120 has shown tumor growth regression, whereas vemurafenib is inactive.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: This study discovered oncogenic BRAF deletions with a distinct activation mechanism dependent on the BRAF dimer formation in tumor cells.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: LY3009120 is active against these cells and represents a potential treatment option for patients with cancer with these BRAF deletions, or other atypical BRAF mutations where BRAF functions as a dimer.
title: Oncogenic BRAF Deletions That Function as Homodimers and Are Sensitive to Inhibition by RAF Dimer Inhibitor LY3009120.

text: AIMS: Preclinical data suggest that signalling through the HGF-MET pathway may confer resistance to BRAF inhibition in BRAF(V600E/K) melanoma.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: Therefore, blockade of HGF-MET signalling might be a valid therapeutic strategy, in combination with BRAF inhibition, in BRAF(V600E/K) melanoma.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: The aim of this study was to investigate the clinical relevance of these observations by evaluating the survival impact of MET expression in patients with BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma treated with vemurafenib.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: METHODS AND RESULTS: Formalin-fixed tissue blocks were obtained of tumours from patients enrolled in the BRIM2 (n = 59) and BRIM3 (n = 150) trials of vemurafenib in advanced BRAF(V600E/K) melanoma.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: Immunohistochemistry for MET (SP44 rabbit monoclonal antibody) was performed with a highly validated assay and clinically validated scoring system.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: Pretreatment MET expression was frequent at the >/=1 + cutoff (BRIM3, 31%; BRIM2, 49%), but relatively infrequent at the >/=2 + cutoff (BRIM3, 9%; BRIM2, 19%).
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: Retrospective subset analyses showed that, irrespective of the cutoff used or the treatment arm, MET expression did not show prognostic significance, in terms of objective response rate, progression-free survival, or overall survival.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: MET is expressed in a proportion of BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanomas.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: Further analyses on appropriately powered subsets are needed to determine the prognostic and predictive significance of MET in vemurafenib-treated melanoma.
title: Impact of MET expression on outcome in BRAF(V600E/K) advanced melanoma.

text: INTRODUCTION: Current targeted therapy proves no effective outcomes in lung squamous cell carcinoma (SQCC).
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Recent studies suggested that FGFR1 would be promising.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: This systematic review elaborated FGFR1 amplification in lung SQCC.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: An electronic search was conducted on PubMed, EMBASE, Web of SCI, Google Scholar and Cochrane Library.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Eligible studies regarding incidence of FGFR1 amplification in lung SQCC and correlation between FGFR1 amplification and clinicopathological features or survival were extracted and analyzed.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: We identified 13 eligible studies with a total of 1798 patients.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: The results showed about 19% of FGFR1 amplification (95% CI: 0.15-0.24; I(2)=84.5%; p=0.000).
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Using the same test method: FISH, definition and ethnicity, the rates were 17% (95% CI: 0.14-0.20; I(2)=53.1%; p=0.037), 21% (95% CI: 0.18-0.24; I(2)=0; p=0.615), and 16% (95% CI: 0.13-0.19; I(2)=72.1%; p=0.028), respectively.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Pearson's correlation analysis suggested that smoking status was highly correlated with FGFR1 amplification (coefficient=0.961, p<0.001).
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: FGFR1 amplification was significantly correlated with lymph node metastasis (OR: 2.27; 95% CI: 1.62-3.20; p=0.000), but not correlated with gender (OR: 1.12; 95% CI: 0.90-1.38; p=0.91), differentiation (OR: 1.02; 95% CI: 0.76-1.38; p=0.959) and stage (OR: 0.93; 95% CI: 0.73-1.19; p=0.877) in lung SQCC patients.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: With respect to survival, FGFR1 amplification had no influence on PFS (HR: 1.57; 95% CI: 0.85-2.30; p=0.259) and OS (HR: 1.40; 95% CI: 0.90-1.89; p=0.416) for SQCC patients.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSION: FGFR1 amplification is about 19%.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Gender, stage, differentiation, ethnicities and test methods have no influence on FGFR1 amplification.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: FGFR1 amplification trends to correlate with lymph node metastasis and smoking.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Whether FGFR1 amplification has effect on survival remains controversial.
title: FGFR1 amplification in lung squamous cell carcinoma: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Atypical chronic myeloid leukemia (aCML) shares clinical and laboratory features with CML, but it lacks the BCR-ABL1 fusion.
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: We performed exome sequencing of eight aCMLs and identified somatic alterations of SETBP1 (encoding a p.Gly870Ser alteration) in two cases.
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: Targeted resequencing of 70 aCMLs, 574 diverse hematological malignancies and 344 cancer cell lines identified SETBP1 mutations in 24 cases, including 17 of 70 aCMLs (24.3%; 95% confidence interval (CI) = 16-35%).
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: Most mutations (92%) were located between codons 858 and 871 and were identical to changes seen in individuals with Schinzel-Giedion syndrome.
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: Individuals with mutations had higher white blood cell counts (P = 0.008) and worse prognosis (P = 0.01).
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: The p.Gly870Ser alteration abrogated a site for ubiquitination, and cells exogenously expressing this mutant exhibited higher amounts of SETBP1 and SET protein, lower PP2A activity and higher proliferation rates relative to those expressing the wild-type protein.
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: In summary, mutated SETBP1 represents a newly discovered oncogene present in aCML and closely related diseases.
title: Recurrent SETBP1 mutations in atypical chronic myeloid leukemia.

text: Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) is an emerging target for cancer therapy due to its important role in maintaining the activity and stability of key oncogenic signaling proteins.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: We show here that the echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4)-anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) fusion protein, presumed to be the oncogenic driver in about 5% of patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), is associated with Hsp90 in cells and is rapidly degraded upon exposure of cells to IPI-504.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: We find EML4-ALK to be more sensitive to Hsp90 inhibition than either HER2 or mutant epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) with an inhibitory concentration (IC)(50) for protein degradation in the low nanomolar range.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: This degradation leads to a potent inhibition of downstream signaling pathways and to the induction of growth arrest and apoptosis in cells carrying the EML4-ALK fusion.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: To generate a causative link between the expression of EML4-ALK and sensitivity to IPI-504, we introduced an EML4-ALK cDNA into HEK293 cells and show that the expression of the fusion protein sensitizes cells to IPI-504 both in vitro and in vivo.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: In a xenograft model of a human NSCLC cell line containing the ALK rearrangement, we observe tumor regression at clinically relevant doses of IPI-504.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: Finally, cells that have been selected for resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors retain their sensitivity to IPI-504.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: We have recently observed partial responses to administration of IPI-504 as a single agent in a phase 2 clinical trial in patients with NSCLC, specifically in patients that carry an ALK rearrangement.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: This study provides a molecular explanation for these clinical observations.
title: The Hsp90 inhibitor IPI-504 rapidly lowers EML4-ALK levels and induces tumor regression in ALK-driven NSCLC models.

text: Ewing sarcoma occurs in children, adolescents and young adults.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: High STAT3 levels have been reported in approximately 50% of patients with Ewing sarcoma, and may be important in tumorigenesis.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: Protein tyrosine phosphatase delta (PTPRD) is a tumor suppressor that inhibits STAT3 activation.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: To date, while somatic mutations in PTPRD have been reported in diverse tumors, germline mutations of PTPRD have not been investigated in Ewing sarcoma or other cancers.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: We identified a novel germline mutation in the PTPRD gene in three of eight patients (37.5%) with metastatic Ewing sarcoma.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: Although the functional impact in two of the patients is unclear, in one of them the aberration was annotated as a W775stop germline mutation, and would be expected to lead to gene truncation and, hence, loss of the STAT3 dephosphorylation function of PTPRD.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: Since STAT3 is phosphorylated after being recruited to the insulin growth factor receptor (IGF-1R), suppression of IGF-1R could attenuate the enhanced STAT3 activation expected in the presence of PTPRD mutations.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: Of interest, two of three patients with germline PTPRD mutations achieved durable complete responses following treatment with IGF-1R monoclonal antibody-based therapies.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: Our pilot data suggest that PTPRD germline mutations may play a role in the development of Ewing sarcoma, a disease of young people, and their presence may have implications for therapy.
title: Germline PTPRD mutations in Ewing sarcoma: biologic and clinical implications.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate frequency, biologic features, and clinical relevance of RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Diagnostic samples from 945 patients (age 18 to 60 years) were analyzed for RUNX1 mutations.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: In a subset of cases (n = 269), microarray gene expression analysis was performed.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: RESULTS: Fifty-nine RUNX1 mutations were identified in 53 (5.6%) of 945 cases, predominantly in exons 3 (n = 11), 4 (n = 10), and 8 (n = 23).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: RUNX1 mutations clustered in the intermediate-risk cytogenetic group (46 of 640, 7.2%; cytogenetically normal, 34 of 538, 6.3%), whereas they were less frequent in adverse-risk cytogenetics (five of 109, 4.6%) and absent in core-binding-factor AML (0 of 77) and acute promyelocytic leukemia (0 of 61).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: RUNX1 mutations were associated with MLL-partial tandem duplications (P = .0007) and IDH1/IDH2 mutations (P = .03), inversely correlated with NPM1 (P < .0001), and in trend with CEBPA (P = .10) mutations.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: RUNX1 mutations were characterized by a distinct gene expression pattern; this RUNX1 mutation-derived signature was not exclusive for the mutation, but also included mostly adverse-risk AML [eg, 7q-, -7, inv(3), or t(3;3)].
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: RUNX1 mutations predicted for resistance to chemotherapy (rates of refractory disease 30% and 19%, P = .047, for RUNX1-mutated and wild-type patients, respectively), as well as inferior event-free survival (EFS; P < .0001), relapse-free survival (RFS, P = .022), and overall survival (P = .051).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: In multivariable analysis, RUNX1 mutations were an independent prognostic marker for shorter EFS (P = .007).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: Explorative subgroup analysis revealed that allogeneic hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation had a favorable impact on RFS in RUNX1-mutated patients (P < .0001).
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: CONCLUSION: AML with RUNX1 mutations are characterized by distinct genetic properties and are associated with resistance to therapy and inferior outcome.
title: RUNX1 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia: results from a comprehensive genetic and clinical analysis from the AML study group.

text: One major reason for the failure of advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) treatment is the occurrence of chemoresistance to fluoropyrimidine (FU)-based chemotherapy.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: Various reports showed that ectopic expression and function of microRNAs (miRNAs) played key roles to mediate apoptosis at the post-transcriptional level.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: To further explore the possible mechanisms, we evaluated the prognostic effect of miR-218 in patients with CRC receiving 5-FU-based treatment and investigated the proapoptotic role of miR-218 in vitro.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: Primary tumour specimens and adjacent non-tumour sites were used to determine miR-218 expression distribution and explore its potential prognostic value in response to 5-FU-based treatment in patients with CRC.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: HCT116 and HT29 cells were transfected with precursor miR-218 or negative control, followed by assays to investigate its influence on apoptosis, cell proliferation and pathways involved in molecular mechanisms of chemoresistance to 5-FU.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: Results showed that high miR-218 expression was associated with positive response to firstline 5-FU treatment in CRC patients.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: MiR-218 promoted apoptosis, inhibited cell proliferation and caused cell cycle arrest in CRC cells by suppressing BIRC5 expression.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: Furthermore, miR-218 enhanced 5-FU cytotoxicity in CRC cells by suppressing the 5-FU targeted enzyme, thymidylate synthase (TS).
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: In conclusion, we demonstrated that high miR-218 expression had a positive prognostic value in 5-FU-based treatments for CRC patients and discovered a novel mechanism mediated by miR-218 to promote apoptosis and to function synergistically with 5-FU to promote chemosensitivity by suppressing BIRC5 and TS in CRC.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: These suggest the unique potential of miR-218 as a novel candidate for developing miR-218-based therapeutic strategies in CRC.
title: MicroRNA-218 is a prognostic indicator in colorectal cancer and enhances 5-fluorouracil-induced apoptosis by targeting BIRC5.

text: We investigated the benefit of adding all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) to chemotherapy for younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome, and considered interactions between treatment and molecular markers.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: Overall, 1075 patients less than 60 years of age were randomized to receive or not receive ATRA in addition to daunorubicin/Ara-C/thioguanine chemotherapy with Ara-C at standard or double standard dose.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: There were data on FLT3 internal tandem duplications and NPM1 mutations (n = 592), CEBPA mutations (n = 423), and MN1 expression (n = 195).
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: The complete remission rate was 68% with complete remission with incomplete count recovery in an additional 16%; 8-year overall survival was 32%.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: There was no significant treatment effect for any outcome, with no significant interactions between treatment and demographics, or cytarabine randomization.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: Importantly, there were no interactions by FLT3/internal tandem duplications, NPM1, or CEBPA mutation.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: There was a suggestion that ATRA reduced relapse in patients with lower MN1 levels, but no significant effect on overall survival.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: Results were consistent when restricted to patients with normal karyotype.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: ATRA has no overall effect on treatment outcomes in this group of patients.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: The study did not identify any subgroup of patients likely to derive a significant survival benefit from the addition of ATRA to chemotherapy.
title: The impact on outcome of the addition of all-trans retinoic acid to intensive chemotherapy in younger patients with nonacute promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: overall results and results in genotypic subgroups defined by mutations in NPM1, FLT3, and CEBPA.

text: The recent discovery of mutations in metabolic enzymes has rekindled interest in harnessing the altered metabolism of cancer cells for cancer therapy.
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: One potential drug target is isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1), which is mutated in multiple human cancers.
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: Here, we examine the role of mutant IDH1 in fully transformed cells with endogenous IDH1 mutations.
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: A selective R132H-IDH1 inhibitor (AGI-5198) identified through a high-throughput screen blocked, in a dose-dependent manner, the ability of the mutant enzyme (mIDH1) to produce R-2-hydroxyglutarate (R-2HG).
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: Under conditions of near-complete R-2HG inhibition, the mIDH1 inhibitor induced demethylation of histone H3K9me3 and expression of genes associated with gliogenic differentiation.
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: Blockade of mIDH1 impaired the growth of IDH1-mutant--but not IDH1-wild-type--glioma cells without appreciable changes in genome-wide DNA methylation.
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: These data suggest that mIDH1 may promote glioma growth through mechanisms beyond its well-characterized epigenetic effects.
title: An inhibitor of mutant IDH1 delays growth and promotes differentiation of glioma cells.

text: The pathogenesis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common leukemia in adults, is still largely unknown.
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: The full spectrum of genetic lesions that are present in the CLL genome, and therefore the number and identity of dysregulated cellular pathways, have not been identified.
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: By combining next-generation sequencing and copy number analysis, we show here that the typical CLL coding genome contains <20 clonally represented gene alterations/case, including predominantly nonsilent mutations, and fewer copy number aberrations.
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: These analyses led to the discovery of several genes not previously known to be altered in CLL.
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: Although most of these genes were affected at low frequency in an expanded CLL screening cohort, mutational activation of NOTCH1, observed in 8.3% of CLL at diagnosis, was detected at significantly higher frequency during disease progression toward Richter transformation (31.0%), as well as in chemorefractory CLL (20.8%).
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: Consistent with the association of NOTCH1 mutations with clinically aggressive forms of the disease, NOTCH1 activation at CLL diagnosis emerged as an independent predictor of poor survival.
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: These results provide initial data on the complexity of the CLL coding genome and identify a dysregulated pathway of diagnostic and therapeutic relevance.
title: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia coding genome: role of NOTCH1 mutational activation.

text: BACKGROUND: BRAF is mutated in approximately 42% of human melanomas (COSMIC.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/cosmic/) and pharmacological BRAF inhibitors such as vemurafenib and dabrafenib achieve dramatic responses in patients whose tumours harbour BRAF(V600) mutations.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: Objective responses occur in approximately 50% of patients and disease stabilisation in a further approximately 30%, but approximately 20% of patients present primary or innate resistance and do not respond.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: Here, we investigated the underlying cause of treatment failure in a patient with BRAF mutant melanoma who presented primary resistance.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: METHODS: We carried out whole-genome sequencing and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array analysis of five metastatic tumours from the patient.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: We validated mechanisms of resistance in a cell line derived from the patient's tumour.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: RESULTS: We observed that the majority of the single-nucleotide variants identified were shared across all tumour sites, but also saw site-specific copy-number alterations in discrete cell populations at different sites.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: We found that two ubiquitous mutations mediated resistance to BRAF inhibition in these tumours.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: A mutation in GNAQ sustained mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signalling, whereas a mutation in PTEN activated the PI3 K/AKT pathway.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: Inhibition of both pathways synergised to block the growth of the cells.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our analyses show that the five metastases arose from a common progenitor and acquired additional alterations after disease dissemination.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: We demonstrate that a distinct combination of mutations mediated primary resistance to BRAF inhibition in this patient.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: These mutations were present in all five tumours and in a tumour sample taken before BRAF inhibitor treatment was administered.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: Inhibition of both pathways was required to block tumour cell growth, suggesting that combined targeting of these pathways could have been a valid therapeutic approach for this patient.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals complex mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition.

text: PURPOSE: The purpose of the study was to assess the contribution of age and disease variables to the outcome of untreated patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) receiving varying intensive induction chemotherapy.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients 16 to 85 years of age with primary AML, known karyotype, and uniform postremission chemotherapy enrolled onto two consecutive trials were eligible and were randomly assigned to induction either with a standard-dose (cytarabine, daunorubicin, and 6-thioguanine) and a high-dose (cytarabine and mitoxantrone) combination, or with two courses of the high-dose combination.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: Subgroups were defined by karyotype, nucleophosmin and FLT3 mutation, WBC count, serum lactate dehydrogenase, and residual blasts.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: RESULTS: In 1,284 patients, the overall survival at 4 years in those younger and older than 60 years was 37% versus 16% (P < .001) and the ongoing remission duration was 46% versus 22% (P < .001).
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: Similar age-related differences in outcome were found for all defined subgroups.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: No difference in outcome according to randomly assigned treatment regimen was observed in any age group or prognostic subset.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: Regarding prognostic subgroups, molecular factors were also considered.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: CONCLUSION: Under harmonized conditions, older and younger patients with AML show modest differences in their risk profiles and equally no dose response to intensified chemotherapy.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: Their observed fundamental difference in outcome across all subgroups remains unexplained.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: Further molecular investigation may elucidate the age effect in AML and identify new targets.
title: Age-related risk profile and chemotherapy dose response in acute myeloid leukemia: a study by the German Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cooperative Group.

text: BACKGROUND: BRAF V600E is the genetic lesion underlying hairy-cell leukemia.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: We assessed the safety and activity of the oral BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in patients with hairy-cell leukemia that had relapsed after treatment with a purine analogue or who had disease that was refractory to purine analogues.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: METHODS: We conducted two phase 2, single-group, multicenter studies of vemurafenib (at a dose of 960 mg twice daily)--one in Italy and one in the United States.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: The therapy was administered for a median of 16 weeks in the Italian study and 18 weeks in the U.S. study.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: Primary end points were the complete response rate (in the Italian trial) and the overall response rate (in the U.S. trial).
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: Enrollment was completed (28 patients) in the Italian trial in April 2013 and is still open (26 of 36 planned patients) in the U.S. trial.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: RESULTS: The overall response rates were 96% (25 of 26 patients who could be evaluated) after a median of 8 weeks in the Italian study and 100% (24 of 24) after a median of 12 weeks in the U.S. study.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: The rates of complete response were 35% (9 of 26 patients) and 42% (10 of 24) in the two trials, respectively.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: In the Italian trial, after a median follow-up of 23 months, the median relapse-free survival was 19 months among patients with a complete response and 6 months among those with a partial response; the median treatment-free survival was 25 months and 18 months, respectively.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: In the U.S. trial, at 1 year, the progression-free survival rate was 73% and the overall survival rate was 91%.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: Drug-related adverse events were usually of grade 1 or 2, and the events most frequently leading to dose reductions were rash and arthralgia or arthritis.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: Secondary cutaneous tumors (treated with simple excision) developed in 7 of 50 patients.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: The frequent persistence of phosphorylated ERK-positive leukemic cells in bone marrow at the end of treatment suggests bypass reactivation of MEK and ERK as a resistance mechanism.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: A short oral course of vemurafenib was highly effective in patients with relapsed or refractory hairy-cell leukemia.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: (Funded by the Associazione Italiana per la Ricerca sul Cancro and others; EudraCT number, 2011-005487-13; ClinicalTrials.gov number NCT01711632.
title: Targeting Mutant BRAF in Relapsed or Refractory Hairy-Cell Leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: Most women with oestrogen receptor (ER) positive primary breast cancer receive adjuvant tamoxifen after surgery.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: The measurement of tumour biomarkers should allow better selection of patients for such treatment or for therapies such as aromatase inhibitors.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Histopathological blocks of primary breast cancer patients who had been randomized to receive 2-years tamoxifen or no adjuvant therapy in two mature randomised clinical trials were retrieved.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: Immunohistochemical staining for ER, progesterone receptor (PgR), HER2 and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) was undertaken.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: The primary endpoint was relapse free survival.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: RESULTS: 813 patients were included in the study.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: Benefit from tamoxifen was seen in ER-positive patients [Relative risk (rr) 0.77, ci 0.63-0.93].
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: ER-negative patients also showed a strong trend to benefit from tamoxifen (rr 0.73, ci 0.52-1.02) which was largely confined to the PgR-positive group.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: Amongst the ER-positive group, PgR-positive and PgR-negative patients showed similar benefit (rr 0.81; ci 0.65-1.02 and 0.70; ci 0.49-0.99, respectively).
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: Patients positive for HER2 did not benefit significantly (rr 1.14; ci 0.75-1.73) but this group was small.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Measurement of PgR status in ER-negative patients defines a group of patients that benefit from tamoxifen but would be excluded from tamoxifen therapy on the basis of ER status alone.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: The data are consistent with HER2 positive tumours being resistant to tamoxifen.
title: Benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen therapy in primary breast cancer patients according oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, EGF receptor and HER2 status.

text: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) involves the upper aerodigestive tract and can destroy the structure and function of organs involved in voice, speech, taste, smell and hearing, as well as vital structures necessary for survival.
title: Molecular predictors of clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: HNSCC has long been a treatment challenge because of the high rate of recurrences and of advanced disease at the time of diagnosis.
title: Molecular predictors of clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Molecular identification of tissue biomarkers in diagnostic biopsy specimens may not only identify patients at risk for developing HNSCC but may also select patients that may benefit from more aggressive treatment modalities.
title: Molecular predictors of clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Several biomarkers studied to date such as the proteins p53, cyclin D1, p16, Cox-2 enzyme, epidermal growth factor and vascular endothelial growth factor receptors, matrix metalloproteinases and the Fhit marker for genomic instability could be manipulated for the therapeutic benefit of these patients.
title: Molecular predictors of clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: This review presents the most updated information on molecular biomarkers with the greatest prognostic potential in HNSCC and discusses some factors that contribute to the controversy concerning their prognostic importance.
title: Molecular predictors of clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Follicular lymphoma is a clinically and genetically heterogeneous disease, but the prognostic value of somatic mutations has not been systematically assessed.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: We aimed to improve risk stratification of patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy by integrating gene mutations into a prognostic model.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: METHODS: We did DNA deep sequencing to retrospectively analyse the mutation status of 74 genes in 151 follicular lymphoma biopsy specimens that were obtained from patients within 1 year before beginning immunochemotherapy consisting of rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CHOP).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: These patients were recruited between May 4, 2000, and Oct 20, 2010, as part of a phase 3 trial (GLSG2000).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: Eligible patients had symptomatic, advanced stage follicular lymphoma and were previously untreated.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: The primary endpoints were failure-free survival (defined as less than a partial remission at the end of induction, relapse, progression, or death) and overall survival calculated from date of treatment initiation.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: Median follow-up was 7.7 years (IQR 5.5-9.3).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: Mutations and clinical factors were incorporated into a risk model for failure-free survival using multivariable L1-penalised Cox regression.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: We validated the risk model in an independent population-based cohort of 107 patients with symptomatic follicular lymphoma considered ineligible for curative irradiation.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: Pretreatment biopsies were taken between Feb 24, 2004, and Nov 24, 2009, within 1 year before beginning first-line immunochemotherapy consisting of rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CVP).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: Median follow-up was 6.7 years (IQR 5.7-7.6).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: FINDINGS: We established a clinicogenetic risk model (termed m7-FLIPI) that included the mutation status of seven genes (EZH2, ARID1A, MEF2B, EP300, FOXO1, CREBBP, and CARD11), the Follicular Lymphoma International Prognostic Index (FLIPI), and Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: In the training cohort, m7-FLIPI defined a high-risk group (28%, 43/151) with 5-year failure-free survival of 38.29% (95% CI 25.31-57.95) versus 77.21% (95% CI 69.21-86.14) for the low-risk group (hazard ratio [HR] 4.14, 95% CI 2.47-6.93; p<0.0001; bootstrap-corrected HR 2.02), and outperformed a prognostic model of only gene mutations (HR 3.76, 95% CI 2.10-6.74; p<0.0001; bootstrap-corrected HR 1.57).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: The positive predictive value and negative predictive value for 5-year failure-free survival were 64% and 78%, respectively, with a C-index of 0.80 (95% CI 0.71-0.89).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: In the validation cohort, m7-FLIPI again defined a high-risk group (22%, 24/107) with 5-year failure-free survival of 25.00% (95% CI 12.50-49.99) versus 68.24% (58.84-79.15) in the low-risk group (HR 3.58, 95% CI 2.00-6.42; p<0.0001).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: The positive predictive value for 5-year failure-free survival was 72% and 68% for negative predictive value, with a C-index of 0.79 (95% CI 0.69-0.89).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: In the validation cohort, risk stratification by m7-FLIPI outperformed FLIPI alone (HR 2.18, 95% CI 1.21-3.92), and FLIPI combined with ECOG performance status (HR 2.03, 95% CI 1.12-3.67).
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: INTERPRETATION: Integration of the mutational status of seven genes with clinical risk factors improves prognostication for patients with follicular lymphoma receiving first-line immunochemotherapy and is a promising approach to identify the subset at highest risk of treatment failure.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: FUNDING: Deutsche Krebshilfe, Terry Fox Research Institute.
title: Integration of gene mutations in risk prognostication for patients receiving first-line immunochemotherapy for follicular lymphoma: a retrospective analysis of a prospective clinical trial and validation in a population-based registry.

text: The overall survival rate and prognosis of patients with laryngeal cancer are not optimistic despite advances in therapeutic techniques.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: Gene expression prognostic models enable the development of more appropriate treatment strategies.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: The human gene PTPN11 encoding a non-receptor protein tyrosine phosphatase, Src homology phosphotyrosine phosphatase 2 (SHP2), is a well-documented proto-oncogene in various malignancies.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: This study investigated the role of SHP2 expression and associated clinical manifestations in laryngeal cancer using a tissue microarray of 112 pairs of laryngeal cancer samples and corresponding adjacent normal mucosae.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: SHP2 expression increased in laryngeal cancer, and this result was associated with the poor survival rate of laryngeal cancer patients.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: Moreover, increased SHP2 expression remarkably promoted the growth of laryngeal cancer cells in vitro and tumorigenicity of laryngeal cancer cells in vivo.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: The Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway was also found to be involved in the SHP2-induced growth of laryngeal cancer cells.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: Overall, our findings indicated that SHP2 plays an important role in laryngeal cancer tumorigenesis and that its expression is negatively correlated with the prognosis of patients.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: Thus, SHP2 may be a promising combinational therapeutic target for treatment of laryngeal cancer.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: The interference of SHP2 expression can serve as a novel strategy for laryngeal cancer treatment.
title: SHP2 promotes laryngeal cancer growth through the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway and serves as a prognostic indicator for laryngeal cancer.

text: Understanding the genetic mechanisms of sensitivity to targeted anticancer therapies may improve patient selection, response to therapy, and rational treatment designs.
title: Activating mTOR mutations in a patient with an extraordinary response on a phase I trial of everolimus and pazopanib.

text: One approach to increase this understanding involves detailed studies of exceptional responders: rare patients with unexpected exquisite sensitivity or durable responses to therapy.
title: Activating mTOR mutations in a patient with an extraordinary response on a phase I trial of everolimus and pazopanib.

text: We identified an exceptional responder in a phase I study of pazopanib and everolimus in advanced solid tumors.
title: Activating mTOR mutations in a patient with an extraordinary response on a phase I trial of everolimus and pazopanib.

text: Whole-exome sequencing of a patient with a 14-month complete response on this trial revealed two concurrent mutations in mTOR, the target of everolimus.
title: Activating mTOR mutations in a patient with an extraordinary response on a phase I trial of everolimus and pazopanib.

text: In vitro experiments demonstrate that both mutations are activating, suggesting a biologic mechanism for exquisite sensitivity to everolimus in this patient.
title: Activating mTOR mutations in a patient with an extraordinary response on a phase I trial of everolimus and pazopanib.

text: The use of precision (or "personalized") medicine approaches to screen patients with cancer for alterations in the mTOR pathway may help to identify subsets of patients who may benefit from targeted therapies directed against mTOR.
title: Activating mTOR mutations in a patient with an extraordinary response on a phase I trial of everolimus and pazopanib.

text: Recently our group and others have identified DDX41 mutations both as germ line and acquired somatic mutations in families with multiple cases of late onset myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and/or acute myeloid leukemia (AML), suggesting that DDX41 acts as a tumor suppressor.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: To determine whether novel DDX41 mutations could be identified in families with additional types of hematologic malignancies, our group screened two cohorts of families with a diverse range of hematologic malignancy subtypes.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: Among 289 families, we identified nine (3%) with DDX41 mutations.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: As previously observed, MDS and AML were the most common malignancies, often of the erythroblastic subtype, and 1 family displayed early-onset follicular lymphoma.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: Five novel mutations were identified, including missense mutations within important functional domains and start-loss and splicing mutations predicted to result in truncated proteins.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: We also show that most asymptomatic mutation carriers have normal blood counts until malignancy develops.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: This study expands both the mutation and phenotypic spectra observed in families with germ line DDX41 mutations.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: With an increasing number of both inherited and acquired mutations in this gene being identified, further study of how DDX41 disruption leads to hematologic malignancies is critical.
title: Novel germ line DDX41 mutations define families with a lower age of MDS/AML onset and lymphoid malignancies.

text: BACKGROUND: Overexpression of the ERBB2 kinase is observed in about one-third of breast cancer patients and the dual ERBB1/ERBB2 kinase inhibitor lapatinib was recently approved for the treatment of advanced ERBB2-positive breast cancer.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: Mutations in the ERBB2 receptor have recently been reported in breast cancer at diagnosis and also in gastric, colorectal and lung cancer.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: These mutations may have an impact on the clinical responses achieved with lapatinib in breast cancer and may also have a potential impact on the use of lapatinib in other solid cancers.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: However, the sensitivity of lapatinib towards clinically observed ERBB2 mutations is not known.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We cloned a panel of 8 clinically observed ERBB2 mutations, established stable cell lines and characterized their sensitivity towards lapatinib and alternative ERBB2 inhibitors.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: Both lapatinib-sensitive and lapatinib-resistant ERBB2 mutations were observed.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: Interestingly, we were able to generate lapatinib resistance mutations in wt-ERBB2 cells incubated with lapatinib for prolonged periods of time.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: This indicates that these resistance mutations may also cause secondary resistance in lapatinib-treated patients.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: Lapatinib-resistant ERBB2 mutations were found to be highly resistant towards AEE788 treatment but remained sensitive towards the dual irreversible inhibitors CL-387785 and WZ-4002.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Patients harbouring certain ERBB2 kinase domain mutations at diagnosis may not benefit from lapatinib treatment.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: Moreover, secondary lapatinib resistance may develop due to kinase domain mutations.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: Irreversible ERBB2 inhibitors may offer alternative treatment options for breast cancer and other solid tumor patients harbouring lapatinib resistance mutations.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: In addition, these inhibitors may be of interest in the scenario of secondary lapatinib resistance.
title: Differential sensitivity of ERBB2 kinase domain mutations towards lapatinib.

text: CONTEXT: Some melanomas arising from acral, mucosal, and chronically sun-damaged sites harbor activating mutations and amplification of the type III transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase KIT.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: We explored the effects of KIT inhibition using imatinib mesylate in this molecular subset of disease.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: OBJECTIVE: To assess clinical effects of imatinib mesylate in patients with melanoma harboring KIT alterations.
