title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS: A single-group, open-label, phase 2 trial at 1 community and 5 academic oncology centers in the United States of 295 patients with melanoma screened for the presence of KIT mutations and amplification between April 23, 2007, and April 16, 2010.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: A total of 51 cases with such alterations were identified and 28 of these patients were treated who had advanced unresectable melanoma arising from acral, mucosal, and chronically sun-damaged sites.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: INTERVENTION: Imatinib mesylate, 400 mg orally twice daily.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Radiographic response, with secondary end points including time to progression, overall survival, and correlation of molecular alterations and clinical response.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: RESULTS: Two complete responses lasting 94 (ongoing) and 95 weeks, 2 durable partial responses lasting 53 and 89 (ongoing) weeks, and 2 transient partial responses lasting 12 and 18 weeks among the 25 evaluable patients were observed.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: The overall durable response rate was 16% (95% confidence interval [CI], 2%-30%), with a median time to progression of 12 weeks (interquartile range [IQR], 6-18 weeks; 95% CI, 11-18 weeks), and a median overall survival of 46.3 weeks (IQR, 28 weeks-not achieved; 95% CI, 28 weeks-not achieved).
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: Response rate was better in cases with mutations affecting recurrent hotspots or with a mutant to wild-type allelic ratio of more than 1 (40% vs 0%, P = .05), indicating positive selection for the mutated allele.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Among patients with advanced melanoma harboring KIT alterations, treatment with imatinib mesylate results in significant clinical responses in a subset of patients.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: Responses may be limited to tumors harboring KIT alterations of proven functional relevance.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: Trial Registration clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00470470.
title: KIT as a therapeutic target in metastatic melanoma.

text: Thymidylate synthase (TS) and dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) are target enzymes of inhibition by pemetrexed, an antifolate for treatment of advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: This study is to evaluate the association of TS and DHFR expressions and the treatment efficacy of pemetrexed in NSCLC patients.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: From January 2006 to October 2008, patients with advanced NSCLC treated with pemetrexed after prior chemotherapy were included.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: The TS and DHFR expressions in tumor tissues were examined by immunohistochemistry and evaluated by a semiquantitative histologic score (H-score).
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: The H-score was derived from the degrees of intensity of tumor cells multiplied by the percentage of positive neoplastic cells.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: The medical records were reviewed and analyzed with respect to patients' characteristics, histology types, treatment responses and survivals.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: Among 268 NSCLC patients treated with pemetrexed, 49 had tumor specimens available for TS and DHFR evaluation.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: The TS expression was positively correlated with DHFR expression (r(2)=0.11, p=0.02).
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: Patients with low TS (</=150) expression had a longer median progression-free survival (PFS) than those with high TS (>150) expression (4.8 vs. 3.4 months; p=0.01).
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: Patients with low DHFR expression (</=120) also had a longer median PFS than patients with high DHFR expression (>120), which was not statistically significant (5.8 vs. 3.6 months; p=0.33).
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: In patients with adenocarcinoma, the low TS patient group also had a longer median PFS and a longer median overall survival (OS) as compared with patients with high TS expression (PFS, 4.8 vs. 3.8 months, p=0.03; OS, 21.4 vs. 10.0 months, p=0.03).
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: Nevertheless, the association of DHFR expression level and median PFS as well as OS were not statistically significant.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: TS expression, rather than DHFR, may be an important predictive factor for treatment efficacy of pemetrexed in NSCLC patients.
title: Thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase expression in non-small cell lung carcinoma: the association with treatment efficacy of pemetrexed.

text: The epigenetic modifier EZH2 is part of the polycomb repressive complex that suppresses gene expression via histone methylation.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: Activating mutations in EZH2 are found in a subset of melanoma that contributes to disease progression by inactivating tumor suppressor genes.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: In this study we have targeted EZH2 with a specific inhibitor (GSK126) or depleted EZH2 protein by stable shRNA knockdown.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: We show that inhibition of EZH2 has potent effects on the growth of both wild-type and EZH2 mutant human melanoma in vitro particularly in cell lines harboring the EZH2Y646 activating mutation.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: This was associated with cell cycle arrest, reduced proliferative capacity in both 2D and 3D culture systems, and induction of apoptosis.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: The latter was caspase independent and mediated by the release of apoptosis inducing factor (AIFM1) from mitochondria.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: Gene expression arrays showed that several well characterized tumor suppressor genes were reactivated by EZH2 inhibition.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: This included activating transcription factor 3 (ATF3) that was validated as an EZH2 target gene by ChIP-qPCR.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: These results emphasize a critical role for EZH2 in the proliferation and viability of melanoma and highlight the potential for targeted therapy against EZH2 in treatment of patients with melanoma.
title: Targeting activating mutations of EZH2 leads to potent cell growth inhibition in human melanoma by derepression of tumor suppressor genes.

text: BACKGROUND: This study examined the clinical significance of CCNE1 (Cyclin E1) amplification and assessed whether CCNE1 is a potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: METHODS: CCNE1 expression and amplification in ovarian cancer was assessed by immunohistochemistry, fluorescence in situ hybridization and clinical data collected by retrospective chart review.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: CCNE1 gene knockdown using silencing RNA and a CCNE1 gene transfection system were used to asses CCNE1 function in tissue samples of ovarian cancer.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: RESULTS: Gene amplification was identified in 18 (20.4%) of 88 ovarian carcinomas.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: CCNE1 copy number significantly correlated with CCNE1 protein expression (r = 0.522, P < .0001).
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: CCNE1 amplification significantly correlated with shorter disease-free survival and overall survival (P < .001).
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: There were nonsignificant trends between high protein expression and poor disease-free survival (P = .2865) and overall survival (P = .1248).
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: Multivariate analysis showed gene amplification was an independent prognostic factor for disease-free survival and overall survival after standard platinum-taxane chemotherapy (P = .0274, P = .0023).
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: Profound growth inhibition and apoptosis were observed in silencing RNA-treated cancer cells with gene amplification compared with results in cancer cells with CCNE1 moderate expression without gene amplification or with low CCNE1 expression.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: CCNE1 overexpression stimulated proliferation in ovarian cancer cell lines ES2 and TOV-21G, which have lower endogenous CCNE1 expression.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These findings indicate that CCNE1 overexpression is critical to growth and survival of ovarian cancer tumors with CCNE1 gene amplification.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: Furthermore, they suggest that CCNE1 silencing RNA-induced phenotypes depend on amplification status of ovarian cancers.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: Therefore, CCNE1-targeted therapy may benefit ovarian cancer patients with CCNE1 amplification.
title: Gene amplification CCNE1 is related to poor survival and potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Panitumumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody directed against the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: We compared the activity of panitumumab plus best supportive care (BSC) to that of BSC alone in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer who had progressed after standard chemotherapy.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We randomly assigned 463 patients with 1% or more EGFR tumor cell membrane staining, measurable disease, and radiologic documentation of disease progression during or within 6 months of most recent chemotherapy to panitumumab 6 mg/kg every 2 weeks plus BSC (n = 231) or BSC alone (n = 232).
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Tumor assessments by blinded central review were scheduled from week 8 until disease progression.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: The primary end point was progression-free survival (PFS).
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Secondary end points included objective response, overall survival (OS), and safety.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: BSC patients who progressed could receive panitumumab in a cross-over study.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Panitumumab significantly prolonged PFS (hazard ratio [HR], 0.54; 95% CI, 0.44 to 0.66, [P < .0001]).
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Median PFS time was 8 weeks (95% CI, 7.9 to 8.4) for panitumumab and 7.3 weeks (95% CI, 7.1 to 7.7) for BSC.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Mean (standard error) PFS time was 13.8 (0.8) weeks for panitumumab and 8.5 (0.5) weeks for BSC.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Objective response rates also favored panitumumab over BSC; after a 12-month minimum follow-up, response rates were 10% for panitumumab and 0% for BSC (P < .0001).
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: No difference was observed in OS (HR, 1.00; 95% CI, 0.82 to 1.22), which was confounded by similar activity of panitumumab after 76% of BSC patients entered the cross-over study.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Panitumumab was well tolerated.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Skin toxicities, hypomagnesaemia, and diarrhea were the most common toxicities observed.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: No patients had grade 3/4 infusion reactions.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Panitumumab significantly improved PFS with manageable toxicity in patients with chemorefractory colorectal cancer.
title: Open-label phase III trial of panitumumab plus best supportive care compared with best supportive care alone in patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: PURPOSE: This study investigated the impact of specific mutations in codon 12 of the Kirsten-ras (KRAS) gene on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: PATIENTS: Overall, 119 patients bearing a KRAS mutation in codon 12 were evaluated.
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: All patients received cetuximab-based first-line chemotherapy within the Central European Cooperative Oncology Group (CECOG), AIO KRK-0104 or AIO KRK-0306 trials.
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: RESULTS: Patients with KRAS codon 12 mutant mCRC showed a broad range of outcome when treated with cetuximab-based first-line regimens.
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: Patients with tumors bearing a KRAS p.G12D mutation showed a strong trend to a more favorable outcome compared to other mutations (overall survival 23.3 vs. 14-18 months; hazard ratio 0.66, range 0.43-1.03).
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: An interaction model illustrated that KRAS p.G12C was associated with unfavorable outcome when treated with oxaliplatin plus cetuximab.
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: CONCLUSION: The present analysis suggests that KRAS codon 12 mutation may not represent a homogeneous entity in mCRC when treated with cetuximab-based first-line therapy.
title: Impact of the specific mutation in KRAS codon 12 mutated tumors on treatment efficacy in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab-based first-line therapy: a pooled analysis of three trials.

text: BACKGROUND: Serum levels of IGF-I in patients affected with multiple myeloma (MM) have been scarcely studied.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: The present study is aimed to explore this point comparing 55 healthy subjects, 71 monoclonal gammopaties of uncertain significance (MGUS) and 77 overt MM patients.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: In the same subjects, basic FGF and VEGF, have been detected.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: All three mediators were analyzed in function of K-ras mutation and melphalan response.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: Concerning IGF-I, two representative monitoring examples have also been added.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: METHODS: Cytokine determinations were performed by commercially available ELISA kits, while K12-ras mutation was investigated on genomic DNA isolated from bone marrow cell specimens by RFLP-PCR assay.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: RESULTS: Significant reductions of IGF-I levels were observed in MGUS and MM as compared with healthy controls.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: In addition, MM subjects showed significantly decreased serum IGF-I levels than MGUS.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: Conversely, increasing levels were observed for bFGF and VEGF, molecules significantly correlated.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: A multivariate analysis corrected for age and gender confirmed the significant difference only for IGF-I values (P = 0.01).
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: K12-ras mutation was significantly associated with malignancy, response to therapy and with significantly increased serum bFGF levels.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: CONCLUSION: IGF-I reduction in the transition: Controls-->MGUS-->MM and changes observed over time suggest that IGF-I should be furtherly studied in future clinical trials as a possible monitoring marker for MM.
title: Reduction of serum IGF-I levels in patients affected with Monoclonal Gammopathies of undetermined significance or Multiple Myeloma. Comparison with bFGF, VEGF and K-ras gene mutation.

text: PURPOSE: In this paper, we aimed to collect genetic and medical information on all Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), in order to contribute to the knowledge of phenotype and genotype.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is a hereditary syndrome characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps in the GI tract, mucocutaneous pigmentations, and an increased risk of cancer in the GI tract and at extraintestinal sites.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Over 90 % of patients harbour a pathogenic mutation in STK11.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: METHODS: Based on the Danish Pathology Data Bank, the Danish National Patient Register, as well as information from relevant departments at Danish hospitals, we identified patients and collected clinical and genetic information.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: RESULTS: We identified 43 patients of which 14 were deceased.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: The prevalence was estimated to be approximately 1 in 195,000 individuals.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: The median age at first symptom was 27.5 with invagination of the small bowel as the most frequent presenting symptom.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: We noted 18 occurrences of cancer at various anatomical sites, including a case of thyroid cancer and penile cancer.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Eight of the deceased patients had died of cancer.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Eighteen different mutations in STK11 had been detected in 28 patients.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: CONCLUSION: This is the first comprehensive study of patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome in the Danish population identified from nationwide registers and databases.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: We have demonstrated that the expressivity of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome varies greatly among the patients, even within the same families, underlining the great phenotypic spectrum.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Patients with PJS should be offered surveillance from childhood in order to prevent morbidity and reduce mortality.
title: Disease pattern in Danish patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Acquired resistance to molecular targeted therapy represents a major challenge for the effective treatment of cancer.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Hyperactivation of the PI3K/AKT pathway is frequently observed in virtually all human malignancies, and numerous PI3K and AKT inhibitors are currently under clinical evaluation.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: However, mechanisms of acquired resistance to AKT inhibitors have yet to be described.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Here, we use a breast cancer preclinical model to identify resistance mechanisms to a small molecule allosteric AKT inhibitor, MK2206.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Using a step-wise and chronic high-dose exposure, breast cancer cell lines harboring oncogenic PI3K resistant to MK2206 were established.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Using this model, we reveal that AKT3 expression is markedly upregulated in AKT inhibitor-resistant cells.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Induction of AKT3 is regulated epigenetically by the bromodomain and extra terminal domain proteins.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Importantly, knockdown of AKT3, but not AKT1 or AKT2, in resistant cells restores sensitivity to MK2206.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: AKT inhibitor-resistant cells also display an epithelial to mesenchymal transition phenotype as assessed by alterations in the levels of E-Cadherin, N-Cadherin, and vimentin, as well as enhanced invasiveness of tumor spheroids.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Notably, the invasive morphology of resistant spheroids is diminished upon AKT3 depletion.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: We also show that resistance to MK2206 is reversible because upon drug removal resistant cells regain sensitivity to AKT inhibition, accompanied by reexpression of epithelial markers and reduction of AKT3 expression, implying that epigenetic reprogramming contributes to acquisition of resistance.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: These findings provide a rationale for developing therapeutics targeting AKT3 to circumvent acquired resistance in breast cancer.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: Mol Cancer Ther; 15(8); 1964-74.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: Upregulation of AKT3 Confers Resistance to the AKT Inhibitor MK2206 in Breast Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: A rare nonconservative substitution (G84E) in the HOXB13 gene has been shown to be associated with risk of prostate cancer.
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: DNA samples from male patients included in the Mayo Clinic Biobank (MCB) were genotyped to determine the frequency of the G84E mutation and its association with various cancers.
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: METHODS: Subjects were genotyped using a custom TaqMan (Applied Biosystems) assay for G84E (rs138213197).
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: In addition to donating a blood specimen, all MCB participants completed a baseline questionnaire to collect information on medical history and family history of cancer.
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: RESULTS: Forty-nine of 9,012 male patients were carriers of G84E (0.5%).
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: Thirty-one percent (n = 2,595) of participants had been diagnosed with cancer, including 51.1% of G84E carriers compared with just 30.6% of noncarriers (P = 0.004).
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: G84E was most frequently observed among men with prostate cancer compared with men without cancer (P < 0.0001).
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: However, the mutation was also more commonly observed in men with bladder cancer (P = 0.06) and leukemia (P = 0.01).
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: G84E carriers were more likely to have a positive family history of prostate cancer in a first-degree relative compared to noncarriers (36.2% vs. 16.0%, P = 0.0003).
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our study confirms the association between the HOXB13 G84E variant and prostate cancer and suggests a novel association between G84E and leukemia and a suggestive association with bladder cancer.
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: Future investigation is warranted to confirm these associations in order to improve our understanding of the role of germline HOXB13 mutations in human cancer.
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: IMPACT: The associations between HOXB13 and prostate, leukemia, and bladder suggest that this gene is important in carcinogenesis.
title: The HOXB13 G84E Mutation Is Associated with an Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer and Other Malignancies.

text: Analysis of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) coding genome has recently disclosed that the NOTCH1 proto-oncogene is recurrently mutated at CLL presentation.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Here, we assessed the prognostic role of NOTCH1 mutations in CLL.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Two series of newly diagnosed CLL were used as training (n = 309) and validation (n = 230) cohorts.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: NOTCH1 mutations occurred in 11.0% and 11.3% CLL of the training and validation series, respectively.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In the training series, NOTCH1 mutations led to a 3.77-fold increase in the hazard of death and to shorter overall survival (OS; P < .001).
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Multivariate analysis selected NOTCH1 mutations as an independent predictor of OS after controlling for confounding clinical and biologic variables.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: The independent prognostic value of NOTCH1 mutations was externally confirmed in the validation series.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: The poor prognosis conferred by NOTCH1 mutations was attributable, at least in part, to shorter treatment-free survival and higher risk of Richter transformation.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Although NOTCH1 mutated patients were devoid of TP53 disruption in more than 90% cases in both training and validation series, the OS predicted by NOTCH1 mutations was similar to that of TP53 mutated/deleted CLL.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: NOTCH1 mutations are an independent predictor of CLL OS, tend to be mutually exclusive with TP53 abnormalities, and identify cases with a dismal prognosis.
title: Mutations of NOTCH1 are an independent predictor of survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Uveal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignant tumor in adults and half of the primary tumors will develop fatal metastatic disease to the liver and the lung.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: Crizotinib, an inhibitor of c-Met, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), and ROS1, inhibited the phosphorylation of the c-Met receptor but not of ALK or ROS1 in uveal melanoma cells and tumor tissue.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: Consequently, migration of uveal melanoma cells was suppressed in vitro at a concentration associated with the specific inhibition of c-Met phosphorylation.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: This effect on cell migration could be recapitulated with siRNA specific to c-Met but not to ALK or ROS1.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: Therefore, we developed a uveal melanoma metastatic mouse model with EGFP-luciferase-labeled uveal melanoma cells transplanted by retro-orbital injections to test the effect of crizotinib on metastasis.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: In this model, there was development of melanoma within the eye and also metastases to the liver and lung at 7 weeks after the initial transplantation.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: When mice were treated with crizotinib starting 1 week after the transplantation, we observed a significant reduction in the development of metastases as compared with untreated control sets.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: These results indicate that the inhibition of c-Met activity alone may be sufficient to strongly inhibit metastasis of uveal melanoma from forming, suggesting crizotinib as a potential adjuvant therapy for patients with primary uveal melanoma who are at high risk for the development of metastatic disease.
title: Crizotinib, a c-Met inhibitor, prevents metastasis in a metastatic uveal melanoma model.

text: PURPOSE: Clinical features of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations, L858R, deletions in exon 19, T790M, and insertions in exon 20, in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) are well known.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The clinical significance of other uncommon EGFR mutations, such as their association with the effectiveness of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI), is not well understood.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: This study aimed to improve the understanding of these uncommon EGFR mutations of unknown clinical significance.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Specimens from 1,261 patients were tested for EGFR mutations.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: We surveyed the clinical data and the effectiveness of gefitinib and erlotinib in NSCLC patients with uncommon EGFR mutations.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Of the 1,261 patients, 627 (49.8%) had EGFR mutations.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: This included 258 patients with deletions in exon 19, 260 patients with L858R, 25 patients with insertions or duplications in exon 20, 6 patients with de novo T790M, and 78 (12.4%) patients with uncommon mutations.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Of the 78 patients, 62 received either gefitinib or erlotinib treatment.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The response rate of TKIs treatment was 48.4%, and the median progression-free survival (PFS) was 5.0 months.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Mutations on G719 and L861 composed a major part (28 of 62) of uncommon mutations, and were associated with a favorable effectiveness of EGFR TKIs (response rate, 57.1%; median PFS, 6.0 months).
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Mutations other than G719 and L861 led to a worse response to EGFR TKIs (response rate, 20.0%; median PFS, 1.6 months).
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Uncommon EGFR mutations constituted a distinct part of the whole group of EGFR mutations.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Their composition was heterogeneous, and their associations with EGFR TKIs differed.
title: Effectiveness of tyrosine kinase inhibitors on "uncommon" epidermal growth factor receptor mutations of unknown clinical significance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Precision medicines exert selective pressure on tumour cells that leads to the preferential growth of resistant subpopulations, necessitating the development of next-generation therapies to treat the evolving cancer.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: The PIK3CA-AKT-mTOR pathway is one of the most commonly activated pathways in human cancers, which has led to the development of small-molecule inhibitors that target various nodes in the pathway.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: Among these agents, first-generation mTOR inhibitors (rapalogs) have caused responses in 'N-of-1' cases, and second-generation mTOR kinase inhibitors (TORKi) are currently in clinical trials.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: Here we sought to delineate the likely resistance mechanisms to existing mTOR inhibitors in human cell lines, as a guide for next-generation therapies.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: The mechanism of resistance to the TORKi was unusual in that intrinsic kinase activity of mTOR was increased, rather than a direct active-site mutation interfering with drug binding.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: Indeed, identical drug-resistant mutations have been also identified in drug-naive patients, suggesting that tumours with activating MTOR mutations will be intrinsically resistant to second-generation mTOR inhibitors.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: We report the development of a new class of mTOR inhibitors that overcomes resistance to existing first- and second-generation inhibitors.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: The third-generation mTOR inhibitor exploits the unique juxtaposition of two drug-binding pockets to create a bivalent interaction that allows inhibition of these resistant mutants.
title: Overcoming mTOR resistance mutations with a new-generation mTOR inhibitor.

text: Lung cancer remains one of the leading causes of cancer-related death in developed countries.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Although lung adenocarcinomas with EGFR mutations or EML4-ALK fusions respond to treatment by epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) inhibition, respectively, squamous cell lung cancer currently lacks therapeutically exploitable genetic alterations.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: We conducted a systematic search in a set of 232 lung cancer specimens for genetic alterations that were therapeutically amenable and then performed high-resolution gene copy number analyses.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: We identified frequent and focal fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) amplification in squamous cell lung cancer (n = 155), but not in other lung cancer subtypes, and, by fluorescence in situ hybridization, confirmed the presence of FGFR1 amplifications in an independent cohort of squamous cell lung cancer samples (22% of cases).
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Using cell-based screening with the FGFR inhibitor PD173074 in a large (n = 83) panel of lung cancer cell lines, we demonstrated that this compound inhibited growth and induced apoptosis specifically in those lung cancer cells carrying amplified FGFR1.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: We validated the FGFR1 dependence of FGFR1-amplified cell lines by FGFR1 knockdown and by ectopic expression of an FGFR1-resistant allele (FGFR1(V561M)), which rescued FGFR1-amplified cells from PD173074-mediated cytotoxicity.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Finally, we showed that inhibition of FGFR1 with a small molecule led to significant tumor shrinkage in vivo.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Thus, focal FGFR1 amplification is common in squamous cell lung cancer and associated with tumor growth and survival, suggesting that FGFR inhibitors may be a viable therapeutic option in this cohort of patients.
title: Frequent and focal FGFR1 amplification associates with therapeutically tractable FGFR1 dependency in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: Despite the impressive clinical activity of the second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509 in patients with prostate cancer, acquired resistance invariably emerges.
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: To identify the molecular mechanisms underlying acquired resistance, we developed and characterized cell lines resistant to ARN-509 and enzalutamide.
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: In a subset of cell lines, ARN-509 and enzalutamide exhibit agonist activity due to a missense mutation (F876L) in the ligand-binding domain of the androgen receptor (AR).
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: AR F876L is sufficient to confer resistance to ARN-509 and enzalutamide in in vitro and in vivo models of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC).
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: Importantly, the AR F876L mutant is detected in plasma DNA from ARN-509-treated patients with progressive CRPC.
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: Thus, selective outgrowth of AR F876L is a clinically relevant mechanism of second-generation antiandrogen resistance that can potentially be targeted with next-generation antiandrogens.
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: A missense mutation in the ligand-binding domain of the androgen receptor F876L confers resistance to the second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509 in preclinical models of AR function and prostate cancer and is detected in plasma DNA from ARN-509-treated patients with progressive disease.
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: These results chart a new path for the discovery and development of next-generation antiandrogens that could be coupled with a blood-based companion diagnostic to guide treatment decisions.
title: A clinically relevant androgen receptor mutation confers resistance to second-generation antiandrogens enzalutamide and ARN-509.

text: UNLABELLED: We identified amplification of RICTOR, a key component of the mTOR complex 2 (mTORC2), as the sole actionable genomic alteration in an 18-year-old never-smoker with lung adenocarcinoma.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: Amplification of RICTOR occurs in 13% of lung cancers (1,016 cases) in The Cancer Genome Atlas and at a similar frequency in an independent cohort of 1,070 patients identified by genomic profiling.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: In the latter series, 11% of cases harbored RICTOR amplification as the only relevant genomic alteration.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: Its oncogenic roles were suggested by decreased lung cancer cell growth both in vitro and in vivo with RICTOR ablation, and the transforming capacity of RICTOR in a Ba/F3-cell system.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: The mTORC1/2 inhibitors were significantly more active against RICTOR-amplified lung cancer cells as compared with other agents targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: Moreover, an association between RICTOR amplification and sensitivities to mTORC1/2 inhibitors was observed.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: The index patient has been treated with mTORC1/2 inhibitors that led to tumor stabilization for more than 18 months.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: RICTOR amplification may define a novel and unique molecular subset of patients with lung cancer who may benefit from treatment with mTORC1/2 inhibitors.
title: RICTOR Amplification Defines a Novel Subset of Patients with Lung Cancer Who May Benefit from Treatment with mTORC1/2 Inhibitors.

text: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a tyrosine kinase receptor which has been implicated in numerous solid and hematologic cancers.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: ALK mutations are reported in about 5-7% of neuroblastoma cases but the ALK-positive percentage increases significantly in the relapsed patient population.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: Crizotinib, the first clinically approved ALK inhibitor for the treatment of ALK-positive lung cancer has had less dramatic responses in neuroblastoma.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: Here we investigate the efficacy of a second-generation ALK inhibitor, brigatinib, in a neuroblastoma setting.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: Employing neuroblastoma cell lines, mouse xenograft and Drosophila melanogaster model systems expressing different constitutively active ALK variants, we show clear and efficient inhibition of ALK activity by brigatinib.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: Similar abrogation of ALK activity was observed in vitro employing a set of different constitutively active ALK variants in biochemical assays.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: These results suggest that brigatinib is an effective inhibitor of ALK kinase activity in ALK addicted neuroblastoma that should be considered as a potential future therapeutic option for ALK-positive neuroblastoma patients alone or in combination with other treatments.
title: Brigatinib, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibitor, abrogates activity and growth in ALK-positive neuroblastoma cells, Drosophila and mice.

text: BACKGROUND: Pre-operative chemoradiotherapy (CRT) is the standard treatment in clinical stage T3/4 or node positive rectal cancer.
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: However, there are no established biomarkers that can predict the pathological response and clinical outcome to CRT.
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: METHODS: Immunohistochemical staining was performed in tissue arrays constructed from core tissue specimens taken before treatment and from operative specimens from 112 patients who received 5-FU based pre-operative CRT and surgery.
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: Expression of Ki67, TS, BAX, EpCAM, p53, p21, EGFR, CD44, CD133, CD166, HIF1alpha and ALDH1 were assessed and correlated with tumor regression grades and disease free survival.
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Of the 112 patients (M/F 74/38, median age: 62), 20 (17.9%) patients achieved pathologic complete remission (pCR).
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: In analyzing the associations between marker expressions and tumor regression grades, high p21 expression at the pretreatment biopsy was significantly associated with non-pCR (p = 0.022) and poor disease free survival (median DFS - low vs high p21: 75.8 vs 58.1 months, p = 0.002).
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: In the multivariate analysis, high p21 expression level at the pre-treatment biopsy was significantly associated with poor DFS (p = 0.001, HR 6.14; 95% CI 2.03, 18.55).
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: High CD166 expression level at the pretreatment biopsy was also associated with poor DFS (p = 0.003; HR 5.61; 95% CI 1.81, 17.35).
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: These show high p21 and CD166 expression at the pretreatment biopsy were associated with tumor regression and poor prognosis in patients treated with 5-FU based CRT.
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: Larger, prospective and functional studies are warranted to determine the role of p21 and CD166 as predictive biomarker of response to CRT.
title: P21 and CD166 as predictive markers of poor response and outcome after fluorouracil-based chemoradiotherapy for the patients with rectal cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: A patient with metastatic BRAF-mutated colorectal cancer initially responded to combined EGFR and BRAF inhibition with panitumumab plus vemurafenib.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: Pre-existing cells with increased MET gene copy number in the archival tumor tissue likely underwent clonal expansion during treatment, leading to the emergence of MET amplification in the rebiopsy taken at progression.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: In BRAF-mutated colorectal cancer cells, ectopic expression of MET conferred resistance to panitumumab and vemurafenib, which was overcome by combining BRAF and MET inhibition.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: Based on tumor genotyping and functional in vitro data, the patient was treated with the dual ALK-MET inhibitor crizotinib plus vemurafenib, thus switching to dual MET and BRAF blockade, with rapid and marked effectiveness of such strategy.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: Although acquired resistance is a major limitation to the clinical efficacy of anticancer agents, the identification of molecular targets emerging during the first treatment may afford the opportunity to design the next line of targeted therapies, maximizing patient benefit.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: MET amplification is here identified-clinically and preclinically-as a new mechanism of resistance to EGFR and BRAF dual/triple block combinations in BRAF-mutated colorectal cancer.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: Switching from EGFR to MET inhibition, while maintaining BRAF inhibition, resulted in clinical benefit after the occurrence of MET-driven acquired resistance.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: Cancer Discov; 6(9); 963-71.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.This article is highlighted in the In This Issue feature, p. 932.
title: MET-Driven Resistance to Dual EGFR and BRAF Blockade May Be Overcome by Switching from EGFR to MET Inhibition in BRAF-Mutated Colorectal Cancer.

text: The tumor suppressor gene PTEN is frequently mutated in diverse human cancers and in autosomal dominant cancer predisposition disorders.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: Recent studies have shown that the lipid phosphatase activity of PTEN is critical for its tumor suppressor function and that PTEN negatively regulates the phosphatidylinositol 3'-kinase-protein kinase B pathway.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: Although more than half of PTEN mutations result in protein truncation, a significant fraction of PTEN mutations are missense mutations.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: To examine whether tumor-derived and germ-line-derived missense mutations inactivate PTEN lipid phosphatase function, we constructed 42 distinct types of PTEN missense mutations and expressed them in Escherichia coli.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: The purified (His)6-tagged PTEN proteins were tested for their ability to dephosphorylate inositol 1,3,4,5-tetrakisphosphate and phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-triphosphate.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: In addition, we examined the effect of mutant PTENs on the ability of PTEN to bind to the phospholipid membrane.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: The results revealed that the majority of PTEN missense mutations [38 of 42 (90%)] eliminated or reduced phosphatase activity and that all of the mutations examined had no effect on the membrane binding activity of PTEN.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: Our study indicated that phosphoinositide phosphatase activity is important for the tumor suppressor function of PTEN and that there may be other mechanisms of PTEN inactivation that are not monitored by in vitro phosphatase assay and in vitro membrane binding assay.
title: Functional evaluation of PTEN missense mutations using in vitro phosphoinositide phosphatase assay.

text: Human stem cell leukemia-lymphoma syndrome usually presents itself as a myeloproliferative disorder (MPD) that evolves to acute myeloid leukemia and/or lymphoma.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: The syndrome associated with t(8;13)(p11;q12) results in expression of the ZNF198-fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) 1 fusion tyrosine kinase.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: Current empirically derived cytotoxic chemotherapy is inadequate for treatment of this disease.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: We hypothesized that small-molecule inhibitors of the ZNF198-FGFR1 fusion would have therapeutic efficacy.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: We characterized the transforming activity of ZNF198-FGFR1 in hematopoietic cells in vitro and in vivo.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: Expression of ZNF198-FGFR1 in primary murine hematopoietic cells caused a myeloproliferative syndrome in mice that recapitulated the human MPD phenotype.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: Transformation in these assays, and activation of the downstream effector molecules PLC-gamma, STAT5, and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/AKT, required the proline-rich domains, but not the ZNF domains, of ZNF198.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: A small-molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor, PKC412 (N-benzoyl-staurosporine) effectively inhibited ZNF198-FGFR1 tyrosine kinase activity and activation of downstream effector pathways, and inhibited proliferation of ZNF198-FGFR1 transformed Ba/F3 cells.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: Furthermore, treatment with PKC412 resulted in statistically significant prolongation of survival in the murine model of ZNF198-FGFR1-induced MPD.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: Based in part on these data, PKC412 was administered to a patient with t(8;13)(p11;q12) and was efficacious in treatment of progressive myeloproliferative disorder with organomegaly.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: Therefore, PKC412 may be a useful therapy for treatment of human stem cell leukemia-lymphoma syndrome.
title: PKC412 inhibits the zinc finger 198-fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 fusion tyrosine kinase and is active in treatment of stem cell myeloproliferative disorder.

text: BACKGROUND: There is a paucity of information about the molecular perturbations involved in MPM tumor formation.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: We previously reported that EGFR-TK mutations in MPM were predictive of achieving optimal surgical cytoreduction, but the status of EGFR pathway activation potential of these mutations was not known.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: Here we present the mutant EGFR activating potential and the matured survival data of the EGFR mutant(mut+) relative to wild type EGFR(mut-) mesothelioma.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: METHODS: Twenty-nine patients were evaluated and their tumors were probed for mutations in the catalytic TK-domain.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: Twenty-five patients were treated with cytoreductive surgery and complete clinical data was available for comparison of the mut+ and mut- groups.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: A COS-7 cell expression model was used to determine mutation activating profiles and response to erlotinib.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: RESULTS: Functional mutations were found in 31%(9/29) of patients; 7 of these mutations were novel and another was the L858R mutation.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: All missense mutations were found to be activating mutations and responsive to erlotinib.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: Of the 25 patients managed surgically, there were 7 mut+ and 18 mut-.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: Two of 7 (29%) mut+ developed progressive disease and died with a median follow-up time of 22 months; while 13/18 (72%) mut- developed progressive disease and 10/18 (56%) died with median TTP of 12 months and median survival of 14 months.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The novel EGFR mutations identified are activating mutations responsive to erlotinib.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: The mut+ subset have a 'relative' improved outcome.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: Erlotinib may have a role in MPM and exploration for mutations in a larger patient cohort is warranted.
title: Clinical implications of novel activating EGFR mutations in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

text: PURPOSE: Gastric cancer cell lines, particularly those with low levels of ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM), a key activator of DNA damage response, are sensitive to the poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibitor olaparib.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: We compared the efficacy of olaparib plus paclitaxel (olaparib/paclitaxel) with paclitaxel alone in patients with recurrent or metastatic gastric cancer and assessed whether low ATM expression is predictive of improved clinical outcome for olaparib/paclitaxel.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: In this phase II, double-blind study (Study 39; NCT01063517), patients were randomly assigned to oral olaparib 100 mg twice per day (tablets) plus paclitaxel (80 mg/m(2) per day intravenously on days 1, 8, and 15 of every 28-day cycle) or placebo plus paclitaxel (placebo/paclitaxel), followed by maintenance monotherapy with olaparib (200 mg twice per day) or placebo.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: The study population was enriched to 50% for patients with low or undetectable ATM levels (ATMlow).
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: Primary end point was progression-free survival (PFS).
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: RESULTS: One hundred twenty-three of 124 randomly assigned patients received treatment (olaparib/paclitaxel, n = 61; placebo/paclitaxel, n = 62).
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: The screening prevalence of ATMlow patients was 14%.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: Olaparib/paclitaxel did not lead to a significant improvement in PFS versus placebo/paclitaxel (overall population: hazard ratio [HR], 0.80; median PFS, 3.91 v 3.55 months, respectively; ATMlow population: HR, 0.74; median PFS, 5.29 v 3.68 months, respectively).
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: However, olaparib/paclitaxel significantly improved overall survival (OS) versus placebo/paclitaxel in both the overall population (HR, 0.56; 80% CI, 0.41 to 0.75; P = .005; median OS, 13.1 v 8.3 months, respectively) and the ATMlow population (HR, 0.35; 80% CI, 0.22 to 0.56; P = .002; median OS, not reached v 8.2 months, respectively).
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: Olaparib/paclitaxel was generally well tolerated, with no unexpected safety findings.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Olaparib/paclitaxel is active in the treatment of patients with metastatic gastric cancer, with a greater OS benefit in ATMlow patients.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: A phase III trial in this setting is under way.
title: Randomized, Double-Blind Phase II Trial With Prospective Classification by ATM Protein Level to Evaluate the Efficacy and Tolerability of Olaparib Plus Paclitaxel in Patients With Recurrent or Metastatic Gastric Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: In single-group studies, chromosomal rearrangements of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene (ALK) have been associated with marked clinical responses to crizotinib, an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting ALK.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Whether crizotinib is superior to standard chemotherapy with respect to efficacy is unknown.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: METHODS: We conducted a phase 3, open-label trial comparing crizotinib with chemotherapy in 347 patients with locally advanced or metastatic ALK-positive lung cancer who had received one prior platinum-based regimen.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Patients were randomly assigned to receive oral treatment with crizotinib (250 mg) twice daily or intravenous chemotherapy with either pemetrexed (500 mg per square meter of body-surface area) or docetaxel (75 mg per square meter) every 3 weeks.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Patients in the chemotherapy group who had disease progression were permitted to cross over to crizotinib as part of a separate study.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: The primary end point was progression-free survival.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: The median progression-free survival was 7.7 months in the crizotinib group and 3.0 months in the chemotherapy group (hazard ratio for progression or death with crizotinib, 0.49; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.37 to 0.64; P<0.001).
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: The response rates were 65% (95% CI, 58 to 72) with crizotinib, as compared with 20% (95% CI, 14 to 26) with chemotherapy (P<0.001).
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: An interim analysis of overall survival showed no significant improvement with crizotinib as compared with chemotherapy (hazard ratio for death in the crizotinib group, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.68 to 1.54; P=0.54).
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Common adverse events associated with crizotinib were visual disorder, gastrointestinal side effects, and elevated liver aminotransferase levels, whereas common adverse events with chemotherapy were fatigue, alopecia, and dyspnea.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: Patients reported greater reductions in symptoms of lung cancer and greater improvement in global quality of life with crizotinib than with chemotherapy.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Crizotinib is superior to standard chemotherapy in patients with previously treated, advanced non-small-cell lung cancer with ALK rearrangement.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: (Funded by Pfizer; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00932893.
title: Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.
Crizotinib versus chemotherapy in advanced ALK-positive lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) patients are commonly treated with vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors or mammalian target of rapamycin inhibitors.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: Correlations between somatic mutations and first-line targeted therapy outcomes have not been reported on a randomized trial.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the relationship between tumor mutations and treatment outcomes in RECORD-3, a randomized trial comparing first-line everolimus (mTOR inhibitor) followed by sunitinib (VEGF inhibitor) at progression with the opposite sequence in 471 metastatic RCC patients.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Targeted sequencing of 341 cancer genes at approximately 540x coverage was performed on available tumor samples from 258 patients; 220 with clear cell histology (ccRCC).
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: Associations between somatic mutations and median first-line progression free survival (PFS1L) and overall survival were determined in metastatic ccRCC using Cox proportional hazards models and log-rank tests.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: RESULTS AND LIMITATIONS: Prevalent mutations (>/= 10%) were VHL (75%), PBRM1 (46%), SETD2 (30%), BAP1 (19%), KDM5C (15%), and PTEN (12%).
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.
