text: With first-line everolimus, PBRM1 and BAP1 mutations were associated with longer (median [95% confidence interval {CI}] 12.8 [8.1, 18.4] vs 5.5 [3.1, 8.4] mo) and shorter (median [95% CI] 4.9 [2.9, 8.1] vs 10.5 [7.3, 12.9] mo) PFS1L, respectively.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: With first-line sunitinib, KDM5C mutations were associated with longer PFS1L (median [95% CI] of 20.6 [12.4, 27.3] vs 8.3 [7.8, 11.0] mo).
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: Molecular subgroups of metastatic ccRCC based on PBRM1, BAP1, and KDM5C mutations could have predictive values for patients treated with VEGF or mTOR inhibitors.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: Most tumor DNA was obtained from primary nephrectomy samples (94%), which could impact correlation statistics.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: PBRM1, BAP1, and KDM5C mutations impact outcomes of targeted therapies in metastatic ccRCC patients.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: PATIENT SUMMARY: Large-scale genomic kidney cancer studies reported novel mutations and heterogeneous features among individual tumors, which could contribute to varied clinical outcomes.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: We demonstrated correlations between somatic mutations and treatment outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma, supporting the value of genomic classification in prospective studies.
title: Genomic Biomarkers of a Randomized Trial Comparing First-line Everolimus and Sunitinib in Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Constitutive activation of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) as a result of gene amplification, mutation, or overexpression of its ligands has been associated with response to EGFR targeting strategies.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: The role of these molecular mechanisms for the responsiveness of squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN) to cetuximab-containing regimens remains unknown.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumor biopsies from 47 patients, enrolled in a single-arm phase II multicenter study for second-line treatment of recurrent or metastatic SCCHN with cetuximab and docetaxel, were analyzed by immunohistochemistry for expression of EGFR, its deletion variant III (EGFRvIII) and its ligand amphiregulin (AREG).
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: The relation between expression levels and disease control rate (DCR) was evaluated by logistic regression.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: Association between expression levels, progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS) was determined by Kaplan-Meier analysis, log-rank test, and uni- and multivariate Cox regression analysis.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: RESULTS: High expression of EGFR, EGFRvIII, and AREG was detected in 73%, 17%, and 45% of SCCHN cases, respectively.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: Expression levels of EGFR had no impact on PFS or OS.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: High expression levels of EGFRvIII were significantly associated with reduced DCR and shortened PFS (HR: 3.3, P = 0.005) but not with OS.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: Patients with high AREG expression in tumor cells had significantly shortened OS (HR: 2.2, P = 0.002) and PFS (HR 2.2, P = 0.019) compared with patients with low expression score.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: Multivariate Cox analysis revealed an independent association of AREG and EGFRvIII with PFS but only AREG was an independent prognosticator of OS.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: CONCLUSIONS: High EGFRvIII and AREG expression levels identify SCCHN patients who are less likely to benefit from combination treatment with cetuximab and docetaxel.
title: Expression of amphiregulin and EGFRvIII affect outcome of patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving cetuximab-docetaxel treatment.

text: Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) is a rare cancer.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: Although EMPD is usually noninvasive and treated with local therapy, once metastatic the prognosis of EMPD is poor and treatment options are limited.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: We report a case of a complete response to single agent trastuzumab in a hemodialysis patient with metastatic Her2/neu overexpressed EMPD of the scrotum.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: Molecular profiling of his case as well as 12 other EMPD and 8 mammary Paget disease (MPD) cases was completed and revealed multiple biomarker aberrations.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: Overexpression of Her2 was frequently noted (30%-40%) in both EMPD and MPD patients and when present can be effectively treated with Her2 targeted agents.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: Trastuzumab therapy can be safely utilized in a hemodialysis patient.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: In addition, multiple protein overexpression and loss were seen in EMPD including PD-1, PD-L1, PTEN, and AR as well as PIK3CA mutation.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: These findings may lead to possible therapeutic interventions targeting these pathways in a disease with few effective treatment options.
title: Metastatic Extramammary Paget's Disease of Scrotum Responds Completely to Single Agent Trastuzumab in a Hemodialysis Patient: Case Report, Molecular Profiling and Brief Review of the Literature.

text: The pharmacogenetics of methotrexate (MTX) was investigated in a large cohort of pediatric patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Four hundred ninety-nine children with ALL from the ALL-BFM (Berlin-Frankfurt-Munster) 2000 trial who received 1996 courses of MTX at 5 g/m(2) were genotyped for 8 single nucleotide polymorphisms in 5 candidate genes of the MTX/folate pathway.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Patients' MTX pharmacokinetics, MTX toxicities, and outcomes were correlated with the genotypes.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: The interindividual variability in MTX kinetics had a substantial genetic component between 68% and 75%.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: The SLCO1B1 rs4149056 variant was significantly associated with MTX kinetics.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: In a multiple regression model, MTX area under the concentration time curve (AUC)0-48h increased by 26% (P < .001) per SLCO1B1 rs4149056 C allele.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: MTX AUC0-48h was a significant predictor of overall toxic adverse events during MTX courses (R(2) = 0.043; P < .001), whereas the thymidylate synthase rs34743033 tandem repeat polymorphism was predictive of stomatitis (R(2) = 0.018; P = .009), a frequent side effect of high-dose MTX.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Multiple Cox regression analyses revealed an association of minimal residual disease (hazard ratio 7.3; P < .001) and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase rs1801131 (hazard ratio 3.1; P = .015) with event-free survival in the ALL-BFM 2000 study population.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Genetic variations substantially influence the kinetics and response to high-dose MTX therapy in childhood ALL.
title: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

text: Cancer drugs often induce dramatic responses in a small minority of patients.
title: Genome sequencing identifies a basis for everolimus sensitivity.

text: We used whole-genome sequencing to investigate the genetic basis of a durable remission of metastatic bladder cancer in a patient treated with everolimus, a drug that inhibits the mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) signaling pathway.
title: Genome sequencing identifies a basis for everolimus sensitivity.

text: Among the somatic mutations was a loss-of-function mutation in TSC1 (tuberous sclerosis complex 1), a regulator of mTOR pathway activation.
title: Genome sequencing identifies a basis for everolimus sensitivity.

text: Targeted sequencing revealed TSC1 mutations in about 8% of 109 additional bladder cancers examined, and TSC1 mutation correlated with everolimus sensitivity.
title: Genome sequencing identifies a basis for everolimus sensitivity.

text: These results demonstrate the feasibility of using whole-genome sequencing in the clinical setting to identify previously occult biomarkers of drug sensitivity that can aid in the identification of patients most likely to respond to targeted anticancer drugs.
title: Genome sequencing identifies a basis for everolimus sensitivity.

text: BACKGROUND: BRAF mutations are frequent in melanoma but their prognostic significance remains unclear.
title: Prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.

text: OBJECTIVE: We sought to further evaluate the prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.
title: Prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.

text: METHODS: We undertook an observational retrospective study of 147 patients with localized invasive (stages I and II) cutaneous melanomas to determine the prognostic value of BRAF mutation status.
title: Prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.

text: RESULTS: After a median follow-up of 48 months, patients with localized melanomas with BRAF-mutant melanomas exhibited poorer disease-free survival than those with BRAF-wt genotype (hazard ratio 2.2, 95% confidence interval 1.1-4.3) even after adjustment for Breslow thickness, tumor ulceration, location, age, sex, and tumor mitotic rate.
title: Prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.

text: LIMITATIONS: The retrospective design and the small number of events are limitations.
title: Prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our findings suggest that reappraisal of clinical treatment approaches for patients with localized melanoma harboring tumors with BRAF mutation might be warranted.
title: Prognostic value of BRAF mutations in localized cutaneous melanoma.

text: KRAS is the most frequently mutated oncogene in human cancer, yet no therapies are available to treat KRAS mutant cancers.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: We used two independent reverse genetic approaches to identify components of the RAS-signaling pathways required for growth of KRAS mutant tumors.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: Small interfering RNA (siRNA) screening of 37 KRAS mutant colorectal cancer cell lines showed that RAF1 suppression was synthetic lethal with MEK inhibition.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: An unbiased kinome short hairpin RNA (shRNA)-based screen confirmed this synthetic lethal interaction in colorectal as well as in lung cancer cells bearing KRAS mutations.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: Compounds targeting RAF kinases can reverse resistance to the MEK inhibitor selumetinib.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: MEK inhibition induces RAS activation and BRAF-RAF1 dimerization and sustains MEK-ERK signaling, which is responsible for intrinsic resistance to selumetinib.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: Prolonged dual blockade of RAF and MEK leads to persistent ERK suppression and efficiently induces apoptosis.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: Our data underlie the relevance of developing combinatorial regimens of drugs targeting the RAF-MEK pathway in KRAS mutant tumors.
title: RAF suppression synergizes with MEK inhibition in KRAS mutant cancer cells.

text: BACKGROUND: Olaparib is an oral poly(adenosine diphosphate-ribose) polymerase inhibitor that has promising antitumor activity in patients with metastatic breast cancer and a germline BRCA mutation.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: METHODS: We conducted a randomized, open-label, phase 3 trial in which olaparib monotherapy was compared with standard therapy in patients with a germline BRCA mutation and human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2)-negative metastatic breast cancer who had received no more than two previous chemotherapy regimens for metastatic disease.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: Patients were randomly assigned, in a 2:1 ratio, to receive olaparib tablets (300 mg twice daily) or standard therapy with single-agent chemotherapy of the physician's choice (capecitabine, eribulin, or vinorelbine in 21-day cycles).
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: The primary end point was progression-free survival, which was assessed by blinded independent central review and was analyzed on an intention-to-treat basis.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: RESULTS: Of the 302 patients who underwent randomization, 205 were assigned to receive olaparib and 97 were assigned to receive standard therapy.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: Median progression-free survival was significantly longer in the olaparib group than in the standard-therapy group (7.0 months vs. 4.2 months; hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.58; 95% confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.80; P<0.001).
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: The response rate was 59.9% in the olaparib group and 28.8% in the standard-therapy group.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: The rate of grade 3 or higher adverse events was 36.6% in the olaparib group and 50.5% in the standard-therapy group, and the rate of treatment discontinuation due to toxic effects was 4.9% and 7.7%, respectively.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Among patients with HER2-negative metastatic breast cancer and a germline BRCA mutation, olaparib monotherapy provided a significant benefit over standard therapy; median progression-free survival was 2.8 months longer and the risk of disease progression or death was 42% lower with olaparib monotherapy than with standard therapy.
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: (Funded by AstraZeneca; OlympiAD ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT02000622 .
title: Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.
Olaparib for Metastatic Breast Cancer in Patients with a Germline BRCA Mutation.

text: FGFR1 amplification has been identified recently as an important therapeutic target in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), particularly squamous cell carcinoma (SqCC).
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: However, data from previous studies on the clinical implications of FGFR amplification in NSCLC are inconsistent.
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: We evaluated FGFR1 gene copy number (GCN) in 369 cases of surgically resected NSCLC using five previously reported criteria and investigated associations between clinicopathologic parameters and FGFR1 amplification.
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: FGFR1 amplification was found in 32/369 (8.7 %) of NSCLC and was more frequent in SqCC (18.0 % in SqCC, 3.0 % in adenocarcinoma; p < 0.001) and in smokers (p < 0.001).
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: On univariate analysis, FGFR1 amplification was significantly associated with shorter overall survival (OS, 58.6 vs 80.0 months; p = 0.033) and shorter disease-free survival (DFS, 58.5 vs 80.0 months; p = 0.042) in patients with SqCC, but this was not statistically significant on multivariate analysis (OS: hazard ratio [HR] = 1.79, 95 % confidence interval [CI] = 0.83-3.87, p = 0.139; DFS: HR = 1.73, 95 % CI = 0.93-3.21, p = 0.081).
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The correlation between FGFR1 amplification and protein expression was poor (rho = 0.08; p = 0.123).
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: These results suggest that FGFR1 amplification is associated with smoking history and squamous cell carcinoma histology and might indicate poor prognosis.
title: FGFR1 amplification is associated with poor prognosis and smoking in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: About half of patients with papillary thyroid cancer have tumours with activating BRAF(V600E) mutations.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Vemurafenib, an oncogenic BRAF kinase inhibitor approved for BRAF-positive melanoma, showed clinical benefit in three patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive papillary thyroid cancer in a phase 1 trial.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: We aimed to establish the activity of vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive papillary thyroid cancer.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: METHODS: We did an open-label, non-randomised, phase 2 trial at ten academic centres and hospitals worldwide in patients aged 18 years or older with histologically confirmed recurrent or metastatic papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine and positive for the BRAF(V600E) mutation.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Participants either had never received a multikinase inhibitor targeting VEGFR (cohort 1) or had been treated previously with a VEGFR multikinase inhibitor (cohort 2).
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Patients received vemurafenib 960 mg orally twice daily.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was investigator-assessed best overall response in cohort 1 (confirmed on two assessments 4 weeks or longer apart).
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Analyses were planned to have a minimum median follow-up of 15 months (data cutoff April 18, 2014) and were done in safety, intention-to-treat, and per-protocol populations.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: This trial is closed and is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01286753.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between June 23, 2011, and Jan 15, 2013, 51 patients were enrolled to the study, 26 in cohort 1 and 25 in cohort 2.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Median duration of follow-up was 18.8 months (IQR 14.2-26.0) in cohort 1 and 12.0 months (6.7-20.3) in cohort 2.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Partial responses were recorded in ten of 26 patients in cohort 1 (best overall response 38.5%, 95% CI 20.2-59.4).
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Grade 3 or 4 adverse events were recorded in 17 (65%) of 26 patients in cohort 1 and 17 (68%) of 25 patients in cohort 2; the most common grade 3 and 4 adverse events were squamous cell carcinoma of the skin (seven [27%] in cohort 1, five [20%] in cohort 2), lymphopenia (two [8%] in each cohort), and increased gamma-glutamyltransferase (one [4%] in cohort 1, three [12%] in cohort 2).
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Two individuals in cohort 2 died due to adverse events, one from dyspnoea and one from multiorgan failure, but neither was treatment related.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Serious adverse events were reported for 16 (62%) of 26 patients in cohort 1 and 17 (68%) of 25 patients in cohort 2.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Vemurafenib showed antitumour activity in patients with progressive, BRAF(V600E)-positive papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine who had never been treated with a multikinase inhibitor.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: As such, this agent represents a potential new treatment option for these patients.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: FUNDING: F Hoffmann-La Roche.
title: Vemurafenib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-positive metastatic or unresectable papillary thyroid cancer refractory to radioactive iodine: a non-randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: BACKGROUND: Ribonucleotide reductase subunit M1 (RRM1) has emerged as a promising biomarker to predict the efficacy of gemcitabine.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The purpose of the study was to evaluate whether the tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical (IHC) expression had any benefit for patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: A single-institution study was conducted in patients with advanced NSCLC.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In personalized therapy group, patients received chemotherapy based on RRM-1 IHC expression levels.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Low RRM1 group received gemcitabine or gemcitabine/cisplatin, high RRM1 group received docetaxel or docetaxel/ cisplatin.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In standard therapy group, non-customized chemotherapy was delivered.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In this trial, Patients aged 70 years received single agent chemotherapy, whereas patients below 70 had platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: There were statistically significant improvements between the personalized therapy group versus the standard therapy group in disease control rate (82.9% vs 55.3%, P=0.004), and PFS (median: 5.5 months vs 3.0 months, P=0.005).
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Besides, the OS had a tendency to become more prolonged (median: 16.0 months vs 12.4 months, P=0.286).
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The subgroup analysis suggested the survival benefit in the elderly patients was more obvious.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: RRM1 IHC expression tailored selection of first-line therapy could improve therapeutic outcomes in patients with advanced NSCLC.
title: The tailored chemotherapy based on RRM1 immunohistochemical expression in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In order to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the recently introduced high-throughput method DHPLC (denaturing high performance liquid chromatography) for mutation screening in the VHL tumor suppressor gene, we subjected DNA from 43 unrelated VHL patients with previously sequenced VHL germline mutations to this method.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: In addition, 36 genomic DNAs of unrelated individuals suspected of being VHL carriers but with unknown germline status were analyzed by DHPLC and sequencing.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: The aims of the present study were to compare mutation results obtained by direct sequencing and DHPLC, and a comparison of two different DHPLC systems.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: The sensitivity of DHPLC was tested with two commercial devices and protocols, i.e., the Varian-Helix system and the Wave Nucleic Acid Fragment Analysis system.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: Both resolved all but one mutation in exons 2 and 3 of the VHL gene.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: In contrast, the GC-rich exon 1 showed discrepancies in the rate of mutation detection.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: Whereas the Varian-Helix system detected 10/15 (67%) of the known mutations, the Wave Nucleic Acid Fragment Analysis system detected 13/14 (93%).
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: All three mutations in samples with unknown mutation status were revealed by both systems raising the mutation detection rate to 72% and 94%, respectively.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: Cases with different substitutions at the same nucleotide showed different elution profiles, but similar elution profiles could be obtained from different mutations.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: The Wave Nucleic Acid Fragment Analysis system detected most VHL mutations; however, when a 100% detection rate is needed, sequencing is still required and must therefore be the standard VHL mutation detection procedure.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: Once a family-specific mutation has been established, DHPLC may be suitable for the rapid and cost-effective determination of VHL carrier status in family members.
title: DHPLC-based germline mutation screening in the analysis of the VHL tumor suppressor gene: usefulness and limitations.

text: The monoclonal antibodies (moAb) panitumumab and cetuximab target the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and have proven valuable for the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: EGFR-mediated signaling involves two main intracellular cascades: on one side KRAS activates BRAF, which in turn triggers the mitogen-activated protein kinases.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: On the other, membrane localization of the lipid kinase PIK3CA counteracts PTEN and promotes AKT1 phosphorylation, thereby activating a parallel intracellular axis.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: Constitutive activation of KRAS bypasses the corresponding signaling cascade and, accordingly, patients with mCRC bearing KRAS mutations are clinically resistant to therapy with panitumumab or cetuximab.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: We hypothesized that mutations activating PIK3CA could also preclude responsiveness to EGFR-targeted moAbs through a similar mechanism.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: Here, we present the mutational analysis of PIK3CA and KRAS and evaluation of the PTEN protein status in a cohort of 110 patients with mCRC treated with anti-EGFR moAbs.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: We observed 15 (13.6%) PIK3CA and 32 (29.0%) KRAS mutations.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: PIK3CA mutations were significantly associated with clinical resistance to panitumumab or cetuximab; none of the mutated patients achieved objective response (P = 0.038).
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: When only KRAS wild-type tumors were analyzed, the statistical correlation was stronger (P = 0.016).
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: Patients with PIK3CA mutations displayed a worse clinical outcome also in terms of progression-free survival (P = 0.035).
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: Our data indicate that PIK3CA mutations can independently hamper the therapeutic response to panitumumab or cetuximab in mCRC.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: When the molecular status of the PIK3CA/PTEN and KRAS pathways are concomitantly ascertained, up to 70% of mCRC patients unlikely to respond to EGFR moAbs can be identified.
title: PIK3CA mutations in colorectal cancer are associated with clinical resistance to EGFR-targeted monoclonal antibodies.

text: Ras is a major signaling molecule activated by interleukin-6.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: There have been no published reports, however, that specifically examine the kinetics and percentage of Ras activation in response to IL-6.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: Model cell lines were used to study activation of N- and K-ras induced by IL-6.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: All of the myeloma cell lines we tested express both N-ras and K-ras, but not H-ras.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: GTP-bound Ras was measured and the percentage of the total Ras pool that was activated in response to IL-6 was calculated.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: IL-6 is able to transiently activate both N- and K-ras in the ANBL6 cell line.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: In addition, increasing concentrations of IL-6 are able to activate increasing levels of both N- and K-ras.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: One ng/ml of IL-6 is able to activate approximately 10% of the N-ras pool and 18% of the K-ras pool.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: The amount of Ras-GTP in the cells correlates with the level of proliferation at low levels, but proliferation plateaus when higher levels of Ras-GTP are present.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: Protection from dexamethasone-induced apoptosis correlates with IL-6 concentration and Ras activation.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: However, IL-6 enhances apoptosis induced by doxorubicin.

text: Interestingly, the ANBL6 cell line transfected with an N-ras12 or a K-ras12 gene is protected from doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
title: Activation of N-ras and K-ras induced by interleukin-6 in a myeloma cell line: implications for disease progression and therapeutic response.

text: Nucleophosmin (NPM1)-mutated acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is recognized as a provisional entity in the World Health Organization 2008 classification of myeloid neoplasms, accounts for 30% of AML.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: We analyzed 1227 diagnostic and follow-up samples in 252 NPM1-mutated AML patients with 17 different NPM1 mutation-specific real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RQ-PCR) assays.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: Paired diagnostic/relapse samples of 84 patients revealed stable NPM1 mutations in all cases, suggesting that they are pathogenetically early events and thus applicable for minimal residual disease detection.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: A total of 47 relapses were predictable because of an NPM1 mutation level (%NPM1/ABL1) increase of at least 1 log or in 15 cases because of NPM1 mutation levels not decreasing less than 3 log ranges.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: A high prognostic value of NPM1 levels was shown for 4 different intervals after therapy was initiated.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: Furthermore, thresholds of 0.1 and 0.01%NPM1/ABL1 during/after treatment discriminated between prognostic subgroups.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: Univariate analyses, including age, white blood cell count, blast count, CD34 positivity, FLT3 mutations status, FAB type, karyotype, NPM1 mutation type, and pretreatment NPM1 mutational level, showed that, besides NPM1 mutation level, only age and FLT3-LM mutation status were prognostically significant for EFS.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: Multivariate analysis, including age, FLT3-LM status, and NPM1 mutation level at different time points, demonstrated that NPM1 level was the most relevant prognostic factor during first-line treatment.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: Similar results were obtained in patients undergoing second-line chemotherapy or allogeneic stem cell transplantation.
title: Minimal residual disease levels assessed by NPM1 mutation-specific RQ-PCR provide important prognostic information in AML.

text: The translocation t(12;16)(q13;p11), which cytogenetically characterizes myxoid liposarcomas (MLS), results in a fusion of the CHOP gene in 12q13 and the FUS gene in 16p11, creating a chimeric FUS/CHOP gene.
title: Fusion of the EWS and CHOP genes in myxoid liposarcoma.

text: We have identified two cases of MLS with translocations giving rise to recombination between 12q13 and 22q12.
title: Fusion of the EWS and CHOP genes in myxoid liposarcoma.

text: The result was a fusion of the N-terminal part of the EWS gene in 22q12, involved in a number of mesenchymal tumor types, with the CHOP gene and the creation of an EWS/CHOP chimeric gene.
title: Fusion of the EWS and CHOP genes in myxoid liposarcoma.

text: The presence of the EWS/CHOP chimeric gene in MLS shows that (i) the N-terminal part of FUS may be replaced by the N-terminal part of EWS in a CHOP fusion oncoprotein (ii) the two N-terminal parts, when fused to certain transcription factors, have a common or very similar oncogenic potential and (iii) the tumorigenic process in MLS and the morphogenetically distinctly different EWS-associated tumor types may be related.
title: Fusion of the EWS and CHOP genes in myxoid liposarcoma.

text: Most colorectal cancers (CRC) are initiated by mutations of APC, leading to increased beta-catenin-mediated signaling.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: However, continued requirement of Wnt/beta-catenin signaling for tumor progression in the context of acquired KRAS and other mutations is less well-established.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: To attenuate Wnt/beta-catenin signaling in tumors, we have developed potent and specific small-molecule tankyrase inhibitors, G007-LK and G244-LM, that reduce Wnt/beta-catenin signaling by preventing poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation-dependent AXIN degradation, thereby promoting beta-catenin destabilization.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: We show that novel tankyrase inhibitors completely block ligand-driven Wnt/beta-catenin signaling in cell culture and display approximately 50% inhibition of APC mutation-driven signaling in most CRC cell lines.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: It was previously unknown whether the level of AXIN protein stabilization by tankyrase inhibition is sufficient to impact tumor growth in the absence of normal APC activity.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: Compound G007-LK displays favorable pharmacokinetic properties and inhibits in vivo tumor growth in a subset of APC-mutant CRC xenograft models.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: In the xenograft model most sensitive to tankyrase inhibitor, COLO-320DM, G007-LK inhibits cell-cycle progression, reduces colony formation, and induces differentiation, suggesting that beta-catenin-dependent maintenance of an undifferentiated state may be blocked by tankyrase inhibition.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: The full potential of the antitumor activity of G007-LK may be limited by intestinal toxicity associated with inhibition of Wnt/beta-catenin signaling and cell proliferation in intestinal crypts.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: These results establish proof-of-concept antitumor efficacy for tankyrase inhibitors in APC-mutant CRC models and uncover potential diagnostic and safety concerns to be overcome as tankyrase inhibitors are advanced into the clinic.
title: A novel tankyrase small-molecule inhibitor suppresses APC mutation-driven colorectal tumor growth.

text: PURPOSE: This study was designed to examine the aggressive features of BRAF-positive papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) and association with age.
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: METHODS: We compared the clinicopathologic parameters and BRAF V600E mutation status of 121 elderly (age >/=65 years) PTC patients who underwent thyroidectomy from January 2007 to December 2009 to a consecutive cohort of 98 younger (age <65 years) PTC patients.
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: RESULTS: Younger and elderly PTC patients had similar incidences of BRAF-positive tumors (41% vs. 38%; p = 0.67).
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: The elderly cohort was more likely to have smaller tumors (mean 1.6 vs. 2.1 cm; p = 0.001), present with advanced TNM stage (36% vs. 19%; p = 0.008), and have persistent/recurrent disease (10% vs. 1%; p = 0.006).
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: BRAF-positive status was associated with PTC that were tall cell variant (p < 0.001), had extrathyroidal extension (p < 0.001), lymph node involvement (p = 0.008), advanced (III/IV) TNM stage (p < 0.001), and disease recurrence (p < 0.001).
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: Except for lymph node involvement, the association between aggressive histology characteristics at presentation and BRAF-positive PTC also was observed within the age-defined cohorts.
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: In short-term follow-up (mean, 18 months), persistent/recurrent PTC was much more likely to occur in patients who were both BRAF-positive and elderly (22%).
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: BRAF mutations are equally present in younger and older patients.
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: Aggressive histology characteristics at presentation are associated with BRAF-positive PTC, irrespective of age.
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: However, the well-established association of BRAF with recurrence is limited to older (age >/=65 years) patients.
title: Both BRAF V600E mutation and older age (>/= 65 years) are associated with recurrent papillary thyroid cancer.

text: The Ataxia Telangiectasia Mutated (ATM) gene is frequently inactivated in lymphoid malignancies such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), T-prolymphocytic leukemia (T-PLL), and mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) and is associated with defective apoptosis in response to alkylating agents and purine analogues.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: ATM mutant cells exhibit impaired DNA double strand break repair.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibition that imposes the requirement for DNA double strand break repair should selectively sensitize ATM-deficient tumor cells to killing.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: We investigated in vitro sensitivity to the poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibitor olaparib (AZD2281) of 5 ATM mutant lymphoblastoid cell lines (LCL), an ATM mutant MCL cell line, an ATM knockdown PGA CLL cell line, and 9 ATM-deficient primary CLLs induced to cycle and observed differential killing compared with ATM wildtype counterparts.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: Pharmacologic inhibition of ATM and ATM knockdown confirmed the effect was ATM-dependent and mediated through mitotic catastrophe independently of apoptosis.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: A nonobese diabetic/severe combined immunodeficient (NOD/SCID) murine xenograft model of an ATM mutant MCL cell line demonstrated significantly reduced tumor load and an increased survival of animals after olaparib treatment in vivo.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: Addition of olaparib sensitized ATM null tumor cells to DNA-damaging agents.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: We suggest that olaparib would be an appropriate agent for treating refractory ATM mutant lymphoid tumors.
title: The PARP inhibitor olaparib induces significant killing of ATM-deficient lymphoid tumor cells in vitro and in vivo.

text: Cetuximab, an antibody directed against the epidermal growth factor receptor, is an effective clinical therapy for patients with colorectal, head and neck, and non-small cell lung cancer, particularly for those with KRAS and BRAF wild-type cancers.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: Treatment in all patients is limited eventually by the development of acquired resistance, but little is known about the underlying mechanism.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: Here, we show that activation of ERBB2 signaling in cell lines, either through ERBB2 amplification or through heregulin up-regulation, leads to persistent extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 signaling and consequently to cetuximab resistance.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: Inhibition of ERBB2 or disruption of ERBB2/ERBB3 heterodimerization restores cetuximab sensitivity in vitro and in vivo.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: A subset of colorectal cancer patients who exhibit either de novo or acquired resistance to cetuximab-based therapy has ERBB2 amplification or high levels of circulating heregulin.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: Collectively, these findings identify two distinct resistance mechanisms, both of which promote aberrant ERBB2 signaling, that mediate cetuximab resistance.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: Moreover, these results suggest that ERBB2 inhibitors, in combination with cetuximab, represent a rational therapeutic strategy that should be assessed in patients with cetuximab-resistant cancers.
title: Activation of ERBB2 signaling causes resistance to the EGFR-directed therapeutic antibody cetuximab.

text: PURPOSE: ERBB3 is overexpressed in a broad spectrum of human cancers, and its aberrant activation is associated with tumor pathogenesis and therapeutic resistance to various anticancer agents.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: Neuregulin 1 (NRG1) is the predominant ligand for ERBB3 and can promote the heterodimerization of ERBB3 with other ERBB family members, resulting in activation of multiple intracellular signaling pathways.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: AV-203 is a humanized IgG1/kappa ERBB3 inhibitory antibody that completed a first-in-human phase I clinical trial in patients with advanced solid tumors.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: The purpose of this preclinical study was to identify potential biomarker(s) that may predict response to AV-203 treatment in the clinic.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We conducted in vivo efficacy studies using a broad panel of xenograft models representing a wide variety of human cancers.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: To identify biomarkers that can predict response to AV-203, the relationship between tumor growth inhibition (TGI) by AV-203 and the expression levels of ERBB3 and NRG1 were evaluated in these tumor models.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: RESULTS: A significant correlation was observed between the levels of NRG1 expression and TGI by AV-203.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: In contrast, TGI was not correlated with ERBB3 expression.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: The correlation between the levels of NRG1 expression in tumors and their response to ERBB3 inhibition by AV-203 was further validated using patient-derived tumor explant models.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: CONCLUSIONS: NRG1 is a promising biomarker that can predict response to ERBB3 inhibition by AV-203 in preclinical human cancer models.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: NRG1 warrants further clinical evaluation and validation as a potential predictive biomarker of response to AV-203.
title: Neuregulin 1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to AV-203, an ERBB3 inhibitory antibody, in human tumor models.

text: Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor (EWS/PNET) is a diagnostically challenging malignant round cell tumor with signature translocations involving the EWS gene.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: These translocations are detectable with both reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: However, RT-PCR is less sensitive in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded than frozen tissue.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: Similarly, commercial FISH probes have recently become available, but have yet to be rigorously tested in the clinical setting.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: Therefore, we have compared RT-PCR with FISH using 'home brew' fusion probes for Ewing sarcoma (EWS)-FLI1 and a commercial EWS break apart probe set in 67 archival round cell tumors, including 27 EWS/PNETs.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: Sensitivities and specificities for both FISH assays were 91 and 100%, respectively, whereas RT-PCR had a sensitivity of 54% and a specificity of 85%.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: The break apart strategy was easier to interpret than probe fusion approach.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: We conclude that FISH is a more sensitive and reliable ancillary technique than RT-PCR for the diagnosis of EWS/PNET in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue, although the latter provides additional information regarding fusion transcript subtype and prognosis.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: The commercial break apart probe set is both readily available and easy to interpret, making it particularly attractive.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: Nonetheless, complex round cell tumors often benefit from molecular testing with multiple methods.
title: Molecular diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor in routinely processed tissue: a comparison of two FISH strategies and RT-PCR in malignant round cell tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: Activating mutations of class III receptor tyrosine kinases (RTK) FLT3, PDGFR and KIT are associated with multiple human neoplasms including hematologic malignancies, for example: systemic mast cell disorders (KIT), non-CML myeloproliferative neoplasms (PDGFR) and subsets of acute leukemias (FLT3 and KIT).
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: First generation tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) are rapidly being integrated into routine cancer care.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: However, the expanding spectrum of TK-mutations, bioavailability issues and the emerging problem of primary or secondary TKI-therapy resistance have lead to the search for novel second generation TKIs to improve target potency and to overcome resistant clones.Quizartinib was recently demonstrated to be a selective FLT3 inhibitor with excellent pharmacokinetics and promising in vivo activity in a phase II study for FLT3 ITD + AML patients.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: In vitro kinase assays have suggested that in addition to FLT3, quizartinib also targets related class III RTK isoforms.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: METHODS: Various FLT3 or KIT leukemia cell lines and native blasts were used to determine the antiproliferative and proapoptotic efficacy of quizartinib.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: To better compare differences between the mutant kinase isoforms, we generated an isogenic BaF3 cell line expressing different FLT3, KIT or BCR/ABL isoforms.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: Using immunoblotting, we examined the effects of quizartinib on activation of mutant KIT or FLT3 isoforms.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: RESULTS: Kinase inhibition of (mutant) KIT, PDGFR and FLT3 isoforms by quizartinib leads to potent inhibition of cellular proliferation and induction of apoptosis in in vitro leukemia models as well as in native leukemia blasts treated ex vivo.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: However, the sensitivity patterns vary widely depending on the underlying (mutant)-kinase isoform, with some isoforms being relatively insensitive to this agent (e.g.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: FLT3 D835V and KIT codon D816 mutations).
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: Evaluation of sensitivities in an isogenic cellular background confirms a direct association with the underlying mutant-TK isoform--which is further validated by immunoblotting experiments demonstrating kinase inhibition consistent with the cellular sensitivity/resistance to quizartinib.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: CONCLUSION: Quizartinib is a potent second-generation class III receptor TK-inhibitor--but specific, mutation restricted spectrum of activity may require mutation screening prior to therapy.
title: Quizartinib (AC220) is a potent second generation class III tyrosine kinase inhibitor that displays a distinct inhibition profile against mutant-FLT3, -PDGFRA and -KIT isoforms.

text: BACKGROUND: Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is frequently associated with mutations in the tyrosine kinase Ret and with increased expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and VEGF receptor 2 (VEGFR2).
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: Motesanib is an investigational, orally administered small molecule antagonist of VEGFR1, 2, and 3; platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR); Kit; and possibly Ret.
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: AIM: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of motesanib on wildtype and mutant Ret activity in vitro and on tumor xenograft growth in a mouse model of MTC.
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: METHODS/RESULTS: In cellular phosphorylation assays, motesanib inhibited the activity of wild-type Ret (IC(50)=66 nM), while it had limited activity against mutant Ret C634W (IC(50)=1100 nM) or Ret M918T (IC(50)>2500 nM).
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: In vivo, motesanib significantly inhibited the growth of TT tumor cell xenografts (expressing Ret C634W) and significantly reduced tumor blood vessel area and tumor cell proliferation, compared with control.
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: Treatment with motesanib resulted in substantial inhibition of Ret tyrosine phosphorylation in TT xenografts and, at comparable doses, in equivalent inhibition of VEGFR2 phosphorylation in both TT xenografts and in mouse lung tissue.
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The results of this study demonstrate that motesanib inhibited thyroid tumor xenograft growth predominantly through inhibition of angiogenesis and possibly via a direct inhibition of VEGFR2 and Ret expressed on tumor cells.
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: These data suggest that targeting angiogenesis pathways and specifically the VEGF pathway may represent a novel therapeutic approach in the treatment of MTC.
title: Anti-tumor activity of motesanib in a medullary thyroid cancer model.

text: We show that a common polymorphic variant in the ERCC5 5' untranslated region (UTR) generates an upstream ORF (uORF) that affects both the background expression of this protein and its ability to be synthesized following exposure to agents that cause bulky adduct DNA damage.
title: A common polymorphism in the 5' UTR of ERCC5 creates an upstream ORF that confers resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy.

text: Individuals that harbor uORF1 have a marked resistance to platinum-based agents, illustrated by the significantly reduced progression-free survival of pediatric ependymoma patients treated with such compounds.
title: A common polymorphism in the 5' UTR of ERCC5 creates an upstream ORF that confers resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy.

text: Importantly, inhibition of DNA-PKcs restores sensitivity to platinum-based compounds by preventing uORF1-dependent ERCC5 expression.
title: A common polymorphism in the 5' UTR of ERCC5 creates an upstream ORF that confers resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy.

text: Our data support a model in which a heritable 5' noncoding mRNA element influences individuals' responses to platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: A common polymorphism in the 5' UTR of ERCC5 creates an upstream ORF that confers resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy.

text: PURPOSE: IPI-504 is a novel, water-soluble, potent inhibitor of heat-shock protein 90 (Hsp90).
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Its potential anticancer activity has been validated in preclinical in vitro and in vivo models.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: We studied the activity of IPI-504 after epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapy in patients with advanced, molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients with advanced NSCLC, prior treatment with EGFR TKIs, and tumor tissue available for molecular genotyping were enrolled in this prospective, nonrandomized, multicenter, phase II study of IPI-504 monotherapy.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The primary outcome was objective response rate (ORR).
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Secondary aims included safety, progression-free survival (PFS), and analysis of activity by molecular subtypes.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Seventy-six patients were enrolled between December 2007 and May 2009 from 10 United States cancer centers.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: An ORR of 7% (five of 76) was observed in the overall study population, 10% (four of 40) in patients who were EGFR wild-type, and 4% (one of 28) in those with EGFR mutations.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Although both EGFR groups were below the target ORR of 20%, among the three patients with an ALK gene rearrangement, two had partial responses and the third had prolonged stable disease (7.2 months, 24% reduction in tumor size).
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The most common adverse events included grades 1 and 2 fatigue, nausea, and diarrhea.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Grade 3 or higher liver function abnormalities were observed in nine patients (11.8%).
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: IPI-504 has clinical activity in patients with NSCLC, particularly among patients with ALK rearrangements.
title: Activity of IPI-504, a novel heat-shock protein 90 inhibitor, in patients with molecularly defined non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: The DNA-repair enzyme O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) inhibits the killing of tumor cells by alkylating agents.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: MGMT activity is controlled by a promoter; methylation of the promoter silences the gene in cancer, and the cells no longer produce MGMT.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: We examined gliomas to determine whether methylation of the MGMT promoter is related to the responsiveness of the tumor to alkylating agents.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: METHODS: We analyzed the MGMT promoter in tumor DNA by a methylation-specific polymerase-chain-reaction assay.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: The gliomas were obtained from patients who had been treated with carmustine (1,3-bis(2-chloroethyl)-1-nitrosourea, or BCNU).
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: The molecular data were correlated with the clinical outcome.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: RESULTS: The MGMT promoter was methylated in gliomas from 19 of 47 patients (40 percent).
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: This finding was associated with regression of the tumor and prolonged overall and disease-free survival.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: It was an independent and stronger prognostic factor than age, stage, tumor grade, or performance status.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Methylation of the MGMT promoter in gliomas is a useful predictor of the responsiveness of the tumors to alkylating agents.
title: Inactivation of the DNA-repair gene MGMT and the clinical response of gliomas to alkylating agents.

text: Palbociclib, an oral small-molecule inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6, was recently approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in combination with letrozole for postmenopausal women with advanced hormone receptor-positive, her2-negative breast cancer.
title: Does CDKN2A loss predict palbociclib benefit?

text: Patients with loss of CDKN2A (p16), an inherent negative regulator of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6, were not separately studied because of the significant response of the patients selected based only on receptor status.
title: Does CDKN2A loss predict palbociclib benefit?

text: Here, we report a patient with metastatic estrogen receptor- positive, her2-negative breast cancer with CDKN2A loss who experienced a clinical response to palbociclib.
title: Does CDKN2A loss predict palbociclib benefit?

text: INTRODUCTION: Deletion of the tumor suppressor gene LRP1B has been reported in glioblastoma, the most aggressive primary brain tumor in adults.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: Our objective was to analyze frequency and prognostic impact of LRP1B deletion and expression levels.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: METHODS: We retrospectively included all the primary IDH1/2 wild-type GBM patients with available clinical follow-up, DNA and RNA from our database.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: Deletions were analyzed by SNP-array.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: LRP1B mRNA expression was analyzed by reverse transcription quantitative polymerase chain reaction.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: RESULTS: 178 patients were included with a median age of 62.36 years.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: LRP1B deletions were observed for 10.1% of patients (complete: 2.8%, partial: 7.3%).
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: LRP1B deletions were associated with poor progression-free survival (PFS) (p=0.004) and overall survival (OS) (p=0.001).
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: By multivariate analysis, LRP1B deletions remained significant for both PFS (p=0.003, hazard ratio (HR): 2.261) and OS (p=0.001, HR: 2.609).
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: LRP1B was down expressed with a mean relative expression of 46% comparatively to normal tissue.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: No association between LRP1B mRNA and patient outcome was observed.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: No correlation was found between the deletions and the mRNA down-expression.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: These results were validated using GBM TCGA data.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: CONCLUSION: LRP1B presents with frequent molecular alterations which impact patient outcome, highlighting the potential interest of this gene for glioblastoma patients.
title: LRP1B deletion is associated with poor outcome for glioblastoma patients.

text: BACKGROUND: Trastuzumab resistance is a key therapeutic challenge in metastatic breast cancer.
title: Afatinib plus vinorelbine versus trastuzumab plus vinorelbine in patients with HER2-overexpressing metastatic breast cancer who had progressed on one previous trastuzumab treatment (LUX-Breast 1): an open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: We postulated that broader inhibition of ErbB receptors with afatinib would improve clinical outcomes compared with HER2 inhibition alone in patients who had progressed on previous trastuzumab treatment.
title: Afatinib plus vinorelbine versus trastuzumab plus vinorelbine in patients with HER2-overexpressing metastatic breast cancer who had progressed on one previous trastuzumab treatment (LUX-Breast 1): an open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: LUX-Breast 1 compared afatinib plus vinorelbine with trastuzumab plus vinorelbine for such patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.
