title: FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3-internal tandem duplication tyrosine kinase inhibitors display a nonoverlapping profile of resistance mutations in vitro.

text: Thus, different FLT3 kinase inhibitors generate distinct, nonoverlapping resistance profiles.
title: FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3-internal tandem duplication tyrosine kinase inhibitors display a nonoverlapping profile of resistance mutations in vitro.

text: This is in contrast to Bcr-Abl kinase inhibitors such as imatinib, nilotinib, and dasatinib, which display overlapping resistance profiles.
title: FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3-internal tandem duplication tyrosine kinase inhibitors display a nonoverlapping profile of resistance mutations in vitro.

text: Therefore, combinations of FLT3 inhibitors may be useful to prevent FLT3 resistance mutations in the setting of FLT3-ITD-positive AML.
title: FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3-internal tandem duplication tyrosine kinase inhibitors display a nonoverlapping profile of resistance mutations in vitro.

text: Advanced basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) frequently acquire resistance to Smoothened (SMO) inhibitors through unknown mechanisms.
title: Smoothened variants explain the majority of drug resistance in basal cell carcinoma.

text: Here we identify SMO mutations in 50% (22 of 44) of resistant BCCs and show that these mutations maintain Hedgehog signaling in the presence of SMO inhibitors.
title: Smoothened variants explain the majority of drug resistance in basal cell carcinoma.

text: Alterations include four ligand binding pocket mutations defining sites of inhibitor binding and four variants conferring constitutive activity and inhibitor resistance, illuminating pivotal residues that ensure receptor autoinhibition.
title: Smoothened variants explain the majority of drug resistance in basal cell carcinoma.

text: In the presence of a SMO inhibitor, tumor cells containing either class of SMO mutants effectively outcompete cells containing the wild-type SMO.
title: Smoothened variants explain the majority of drug resistance in basal cell carcinoma.

text: Finally, we show that both classes of SMO variants respond to aPKC-iota/lambda or GLI2 inhibitors that operate downstream of SMO, setting the stage for the clinical use of GLI antagonists.
title: Smoothened variants explain the majority of drug resistance in basal cell carcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: The genetic characterization of chronic lymphocytic leukemia cells correlates with the behavior, progression and response to treatment of the disease.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: DESIGN AND METHODS: Our aim was to investigate the role of ATM gene alterations, their biological consequences and their value in predicting disease progression.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: The ATM gene was analyzed by denaturing high performance liquid chromatography and multiplex ligation probe amplification in a series of patients at diagnosis.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: The results were correlated with immunoglobulin gene mutations, cytogenetic abnormalities, ZAP-70 and CD38 expression, TP53 mutations, gene expression profile and treatment-free interval.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: RESULTS: Mutational screening of the ATM gene identified point mutations in 8/57 cases (14%).
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: Multiplex ligation probe amplification analysis identified six patients with 11q deletion: all of them had at least 20% of deleted cells, analyzed by fluorescent in situ hybridization.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: Overall, ATM point mutations and deletions were detected in 14/57 (24.6%) cases at presentation, representing the most common unfavorable genetic anomalies in chronic lymphocytic leukemia, also in stage A patients.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: Patients with deleted or mutated ATM had a significantly shorter treatment-free interval compared to patients without ATM alterations.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: ATM-mutated cases had a peculiar gene expression profile characterized by the deregulation of genes involved in apoptosis and DNA repair.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: Finally, definition of the structure of the ATM-mutated protein led to a hypothesis that functional abnormalities are responsible for the unfavorable clinical course of patients carrying these point mutations.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: CONCLUSIONS: ATM alterations are present at diagnosis in about 25% of individuals with chronic lymphocytic leukemia; these alterations are associated with a peculiar gene expression pattern and a shorter treatment-free interval.
title: ATM gene alterations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients induce a distinct gene expression profile and predict disease progression.

text: BACKGROUND: The phase III EXTREME study demonstrated that combining cetuximab with platinum/5-fluorouracil (5-FU) significantly improved overall survival in the first-line treatment of patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (R/M SCCHN) compared with platinum/5-FU alone.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: The aim of this investigation was to evaluate elevated tumor EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker in EXTREME study patients.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Dual-color FISH was used to determine absolute and relative EGFR copy number.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: Models of differing stringencies were used to score and investigate whether increased copy number was predictive for the activity of cetuximab plus platinum/5-FU.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: RESULTS: Tumors from 312 of 442 patients (71%) were evaluable by FISH and met the criteria for statistical analysis.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: A moderate increase in EGFR copy number was common, with high-level amplification of the gene occurring in a small fraction of tumors ( approximately 11%).
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: Considering each of the models tested, no association of EGFR copy number with overall survival, progression-free survival or best overall response was found for patients treated with cetuximab plus platinum/5-FU.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: CONCLUSION: Tumor EGFR copy number is not a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab plus platinum/5-FU as first-line therapy for patients with R/M SCCHN.
title: Evaluation of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for the efficacy of cetuximab in combination with chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck: EXTREME study.

text: Gastric adenocarcinoma is a common form of cancer associated with a poor prognosis.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: We analyzed microarray profiling data from 48 patients with gastric adenocarcinoma to characterize gastric cancer subtypes and identify biomarkers associated with prognosis.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: We identified two major subtypes of gastric adenocarcinoma differentially associated with overall survival (P = 0.025).
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: Genes that were differentially expressed were identified using specific criteria (P < 0.001 and >1.5-fold); expression of 294 and 116 genes was enriched in good and poor prognosis subtypes, respectively.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: Genes related to translational elongation and cell cycle were upregulated in the poor prognosis group.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: Of these genes, upregulation of proteasome subunit beta type 8 PSMB8 and PDZ binding kinase PBK was confirmed by real-time reverse transcription-PCR analysis.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: PSMB8 or PBK knockdown had no effect on gastric cancer cell proliferation but suppressed cell migration and invasion, respectively.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: Furthermore, immunohistochemistry analysis of 385 gastric cancer patients revealed that increased nuclear expression of PSMB8 and PBK was correlated with depth of invasion, lymph node metastasis, and lower survival rates.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: Taken together, two gastric adenocarcinoma subtypes were predictive of prognosis.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: PSMB8 and PBK were predictive of gastric cancer prognosis and could be potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers.
title: PSMB8 and PBK as potential gastric cancer subtype-specific biomarkers associated with prognosis.

text: Stathmin is a prognostic marker in many cancers, including endometrial cancer.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Preclinical studies, predominantly in breast cancer, have suggested that stathmin may additionally be a predictive marker for response to paclitaxel.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: We first evaluated the response to paclitaxel in endometrial cancer cell lines before and after stathmin knock-down.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Subsequently we investigated the clinical response to paclitaxel containing chemotherapy in metastatic endometrial cancer in relation to stathmin protein level in tumors.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Stathmin level was also determined in metastatic lesions, analyzing changes in biomarker status on disease progression.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Knock-down of stathmin improved sensitivity to paclitaxel in endometrial carcinoma cell lines with both naturally higher and lower sensitivity to paclitaxel.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: In clinical samples, high stathmin level was demonstrated to be associated with poor response to paclitaxel containing chemotherapy and to reduced disease specific survival only in patients treated with such combination.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Stathmin level increased significantly from primary to metastatic lesions.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: This study suggests, supported by both preclinical and clinical data, that stathmin could be a predictive biomarker for response to paclitaxel treatment in endometrial cancer.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Re-assessment of stathmin level in metastatic lesions prior to treatment start may be relevant.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Also, validation in a randomized clinical trial will be important.
title: Stathmin protein level, a potential predictive marker for taxane treatment response in endometrial cancer.

text: Improvement in the clinical outcome of lung cancer is likely to be achieved by identification of the molecular events that underlie its pathogenesis.
title: Identification of the transforming EML4-ALK fusion gene in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Here we show that a small inversion within chromosome 2p results in the formation of a fusion gene comprising portions of the echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4) gene and the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells.
title: Identification of the transforming EML4-ALK fusion gene in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Mouse 3T3 fibroblasts forced to express this human fusion tyrosine kinase generated transformed foci in culture and subcutaneous tumours in nude mice.
title: Identification of the transforming EML4-ALK fusion gene in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The EML4-ALK fusion transcript was detected in 6.7% (5 out of 75) of NSCLC patients examined; these individuals were distinct from those harbouring mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor gene.
title: Identification of the transforming EML4-ALK fusion gene in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Our data demonstrate that a subset of NSCLC patients may express a transforming fusion kinase that is a promising candidate for a therapeutic target as well as for a diagnostic molecular marker in NSCLC.
title: Identification of the transforming EML4-ALK fusion gene in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: This is the case of an 84-year-old woman diagnosed with Stage IVb colon adenocarcinoma (CRC) metastatic to the liver, retroperitoneum, anastomotic site, and distal rectal sigmoid colon.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: She experienced intolerable side effects to systemic chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil and bevacizumab, as well as disease progression.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Next generation sequencing of her tumor was ordered, and further discussion of her malignancy's genomic information took place at a multidisciplinary molecular tumor board.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: The patient had mutations in KRAS (Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog) which made her ineligible for epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitors; however, a KDR p.R961W c.2881C>T mutation was noted as a variant of unknown significance (VUS).
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: KDR (kinase insert domain receptor) is the human gene encoding for vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR-2).
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: She was then considered a suitable candidate for regorafenib, which she could only tolerate at a low dose of 40 mg daily, with the intent of prolonging her survival and to optimize her quality of life.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: We report her excellent tolerance and exceptional response to low dose regorafenib, including symptomatic, tumor marker, and sustained partial metabolic radiological improvement.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: In the largest Phase III trial of regorafenib in CRC, only five patients (1%) of 760 experienced a partial response (versus one patient, 0.4%, receiving placebo).
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: KDR R961W mutation has been described but no functional data has been reported.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: This mutation occurs in the tyrosine kinase domain of the VEGFR-2.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Regorafenib targets VEGFR-2 (KDR).
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Hereby we hypothesize KDR mutation as a novel predictive biomarker to exceptional response to regorafenib in metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of the potential correlation between KDR mutation and regorafenib use for the successful management of a patient with advanced CRC, leading to what is considered an exceptional response.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Further studies based on this preliminary data are warranted.
title: KDR Mutation as a Novel Predictive Biomarker of Exceptional Response to Regorafenib in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: PURPOSE: FGFR1 copy-number gain (CNG) occurs in head and neck squamous cell cancers (HNSCC) and is used for patient selection in FGFR-specific inhibitor clinical trials.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: This study explores FGFR1 mRNA and protein levels in HNSCC cell lines, primary tumors, and patient-derived xenografts (PDX) as predictors of sensitivity to the FGFR inhibitor, NVP-BGJ398.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: FGFR1 status, expression levels, and BGJ398 sensitive growth were measured in 12 HNSCC cell lines.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: Primary HNSCCs (n = 353) were assessed for FGFR1 CNG and mRNA levels, and HNSCC TCGA data were interrogated as an independent sample set.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: HNSCC PDXs (n = 39) were submitted to FGFR1 copy-number detection and mRNA assays to identify putative FGFR1-dependent tumors.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: RESULTS: Cell line sensitivity to BGJ398 is associated with FGFR1 mRNA and protein levels, not FGFR1 CNG.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: Thirty-one percent of primary HNSCC tumors expressed FGFR1 mRNA, 18% exhibited FGFR1 CNG, 35% of amplified tumors were also positive for FGFR1 mRNA.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: This relationship was confirmed with the TCGA dataset.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: Using high FGFR1 mRNA for selection, 2 HNSCC PDXs were identified, one of which also exhibited FGFR1 CNG.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: The nonamplified tumor with high mRNA levels exhibited in vivo sensitivity to BGJ398.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: CONCLUSIONS: FGFR1 expression associates with BGJ398 sensitivity in HNSCC cell lines and predicts tyrosine kinase inhibitor sensitivity in PDXs.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: Our results support FGFR1 mRNA or protein expression, rather than FGFR1 CNG as a predictive biomarker for the response to FGFR inhibitors in a subset of patients suffering from HNSCC.
title: FGFR1 Expression Levels Predict BGJ398 Sensitivity of FGFR1-Dependent Head and Neck Squamous Cell Cancers.

text: PURPOSE: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) might be predictive for clinical response to EGFR inhibitor treatment.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: However, retrospective analyses of EGFR mutations in clinical trials have shown inconclusive results and the effect of EGFR sequencing in NSCLC is still controversial.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: Because the vast majority of EGFR mutations described have not been functionally characterized, simple correlation of mutational status and treatment response may not provide reliable information about the predictive value of EGFR mutations.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: Thus, we aimed to characterize a comprehensive panel of clinically observed EGFR mutations.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND RESULTS: A panel of 30 EGFR mutations was cloned and characterized for kinase activity and the ability to confer growth factor independence.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: Interestingly, 4 of 30 EGFR mutations showed no kinase activity even after ligand stimulation and were not able to confer growth factor independence.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: Ba/F3 cells expressing activating EGFR mutants were then used to test the efficacy of EGFR inhibitors in a cell proliferation assay.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: IC(50) values were calculated for gefitinib, erlotinib, and AEE788.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: We show that the sensitivity of EGFR mutations toward different inhibitors varies significantly, thus establishing a comprehensive sensitivity profile for each inhibitor.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: EGFR mutations identified in NSCLC patients display distinct biological features.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: The variability in kinase activity, transforming potential, and sensitivity to EGFR inhibitors has to be considered in clinical studies aiming to correlate mutational status and drug response.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: The identification of comprehensive drug resistance profiles opens the opportunity to test alternative EGFR inhibitors in vitro.
title: Functional analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and potential implications for EGFR targeted therapy.

text: PURPOSE: To determine the potential of crenolanib, a potent inhibitor of PDGFRA, to treat malignancies driven by mutant PDGFRA.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: The biochemical activity of crenolanib was compared with imatinib using a panel of PDGFRA-mutant kinases expressed in several different cell line models, including primary gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) cells.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: The antiproliferative activity of crenolanib was also studied in several cell lines with PDGFRA-dependent growth.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: RESULTS: Crenolanib was significantly more potent than imatinib in inhibiting the kinase activity of imatinib-resistant PDGFRA kinases (D842I, D842V, D842Y, DI842-843IM, and deletion I843).
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: For example, crenolanib was 135-fold more potent than imatinib against D842V in our isogenic model system, with an IC(50) of approximately 10 nmol/L.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: The relative potency of crenolanib was further confirmed in BaF3 and primary GIST cells expressing PDGFRA D842V.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: In contrast, imatinib was at least 10-fold more potent than crenolanib in inhibiting the V561D mutation.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: For all other tested PDGFRA mutations, crenolanib and imatinib had comparable potency.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Crenolanib is a potent inhibitor of imatinib-resistant PDGFRA kinases associated with GIST, including the PDGFRA D842V mutation found in approximately 5% of GISTs.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: The spectrum of activity of crenolanib suggests that this drug is a type I inhibitor (inhibitor of activated conformation of kinase).
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Based in part on these results, a phase II clinical study of this agent to treat GIST with the PDGFRA D842V mutation has been initiated.
title: Crenolanib inhibits the drug-resistant PDGFRA D842V mutation associated with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Recently, de4 EGFR, a variant of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) with exon 4 deletion, was identified in glioblastoma and ovarian cancer.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: However, its biological function on ovarian cancer is still not clear.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: In this study, the expression profile of de4 EGFR and its contribution to epithelial ovarian cancer cells proliferation, invasiveness and drug resistance were studied.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Our results showed that 48.6% (35/72) of epithelial ovarian cancer tissues had de4 EGFR expression and the expression ratio positively correlated with clinical stages.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Compared with EGFR transfectants, de4 EGFR transfectants exhibited significantly higher level of invasiveness in vitro.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Mechanistically, de4 EGFR significantly upregulated the extracellular regulated protein kinase, AKT, focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and Src phosphorylation and matrix metalloproteinase-9 expression while downregulated the expression of E-cadherin.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Additionally, knockdown of FAK obviously suppressed de4 EGFR-induced invasiveness.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Interestingly, de4 EGFR transfectants displayed significantly lower sensitivity to cisplatin than EGFR transfectants, which could be ascribed to the upregulation of Bcl-2 and downregulation of BAD in the de4 EGFR transfectants.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Collectively, these results demonstrate that de4 EGFR plays an important role in the invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer cells and may provide a new potential therapeutic target for epithelial ovarian cancer.
title: Exon 4 deletion variant of epidermal growth factor receptor enhances invasiveness and cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Clinical trials of immune checkpoints modulators, including both programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and programmed cell death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitors, have recently shown promising activity and tolerable toxicity in pre-treated NSCLC patients.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: However the predictive role of PD-L1 expression is still controversial.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: This pooled analysis aims to clarify the association of clinical objective responses to anti PD-1/PD-L1 monoclonal antibodies (MoAbs) and tumor PD-L1 expression in pre-treated NSCLC patients.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: METHODS: Data from published studies, that evaluated efficacy and safety of PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors in pre-treated NSCLC patients, stratified by tumor PD-L1 expression status (immunohistochemistry, cut-off point 1%), were collected by searching in PubMed, Cochrane Library, American Society of Clinical Oncology, European Society of Medical Oncology and World Conference of Lung Cancer, meeting proceedings.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: Pooled Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs) were calculated for the Overall Response Rate (ORR) (as evaluated by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors, version 1.1), according to PD-L1 expression status.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: RESULTS: A total of seven studies, with 914 patients, were eligible.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: Pooled analysis showed that patients with PD-L1 positive tumors (PD-L1 tumor cell staining >/=1%), had a significantly higher ORR, compared to patients with PD-L1 negative tumors (OR: 2.44; 95% CIs: 1.61-3.68).
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: PD-L1 tumor over-expression seems to be associated with higher clinical activity of anti PD-1/PD-L1 MoAbs, in pre-treated NSCLC patients, suggesting a potential role of PD-L1 expression, IHC cut-off point 1%, as predictive biomarker for the selection of patients to treat with immune-checkpoint inhibitors.
title: PD-L1 expression as predictive biomarker in patients with NSCLC: a pooled analysis.

text: Activating mutations of FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) are present in approximately 30% of patients with de novo acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and are associated with lower cure rates from standard chemotherapy-based treatment.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Targeting the mutation by inhibiting the tyrosine kinase activity of FLT3 is cytotoxic to cell lines and primary AML cells harboring FLT3 mutations.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Successful FLT3 inhibition can also improve survival in mouse models of FLT3-activated leukemia.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CEP-701 is an orally available, novel, receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor that selectively inhibits FLT3 autophosphorylation.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We undertook a phase 1/2 trial to determine the in vivo hematologic effects of single-agent CEP-701 as salvage treatment for patients with refractory, relapsed, or poor-risk AML expressing FLT3-activating mutations.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Fourteen heavily pretreated AML patients were treated with CEP-701 at an initial dose of 60 mg orally twice daily.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CEP-701-related toxicities were minimal.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Five patients had clinical evidence of biologic activity and measurable clinical response, including significant reductions in bone marrow and peripheral blood blasts.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Laboratory data confirmed that clinical responses correlated with sustained FLT3 inhibition to CEP-701.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Our results show that FLT3 inhibition is associated with clinical activity in AML patients harboring FLT3-activating mutations and indicate that CEP-701 holds promise as a novel, molecularly targeted therapy for this disease.
title: Single-agent CEP-701, a novel FLT3 inhibitor, shows biologic and clinical activity in patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Ewing sarcoma (ES) is an aggressive malignant small round cell tumor that arises in bone or soft tissue of adolescents and young adults.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: A characteristic molecular finding in ES is EWSR1 gene fusion with ETS (erythroblast transformation-specific) family genes including FLI1 (~90%) and ERG (>5%).
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: Here we report our experience using integrated clinicopathologic, cytogenetic, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), and reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analyses of 32 pediatric patients with ES diagnosed in a single institution between 2005 and 2011.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: Diagnostic EWSR1 rearrangements were detected in 30 (93.8%) of 32 patients.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: Cytogenetics detected t(11;22) (n = 14) and t(21;22) (n = 1) in 15 (46.9%) patients.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: FISH detected EWSR1 rearrangements in 27 (96.4%) of 28 patients tested.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: RT-PCR was positive in 27 (84.4%) of 32 patients, including 24 EWSR1-FLI1 and 3 EWSR1-ERG.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: RT-PCR defined breakpoints and fusion partners in 7 cases with EWSR1 rearrangements detected by FISH.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: Sanger sequencing further delineated breakpoints in 21 (77.8%) of 27 RT-PCR positive cases.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: In summary, conventional cytogenetic analysis provided a global view but had a lower detection rate and longer turnaround time than other methods.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: FISH is a rapid method and theoretically can detect all EWSR1 rearrangements, but it cannot identify all partners and is not completely specific for ES.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: RT-PCR and sequencing are more sensitive and useful in identifying fusion partners and refining breakpoints; however, these methods can be compromised by poor RNA preservation and primer design.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: In conclusion, an integrated approach that uses all methods capable of detecting EWSR1 rearrangements has value in the workup of suspected cases of ES.
title: Integrated multimodal genetic testing of Ewing sarcoma--a single-institution experience.

text: Genetic testing of cancer susceptibility genes is now widely applied in clinical practice to predict risk of developing cancer.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: In general, sequence-based testing of germline DNA is used to determine whether an individual carries a change that is clearly likely to disrupt normal gene function.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: Genetic testing may detect changes that are clearly pathogenic, clearly neutral, or variants of unclear clinical significance.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: Such variants present a considerable challenge to the diagnostic laboratory and the receiving clinician in terms of interpretation and clear presentation of the implications of the result to the patient.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: There does not appear to be a consistent approach to interpreting and reporting the clinical significance of variants either among genes or among laboratories.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: The potential for confusion among clinicians and patients is considerable and misinterpretation may lead to inappropriate clinical consequences.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: In this article we review the current state of sequence-based genetic testing, describe other standardized reporting systems used in oncology, and propose a standardized classification system for application to sequence-based results for cancer predisposition genes.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: We suggest a system of five classes of variants based on the degree of likelihood of pathogenicity.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: Each class is associated with specific recommendations for clinical management of at-risk relatives that will depend on the syndrome.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: We propose that panels of experts on each cancer predisposition syndrome facilitate the classification scheme and designate appropriate surveillance and cancer management guidelines.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: The international adoption of a standardized reporting system should improve the clinical utility of sequence-based genetic tests to predict cancer risk.
title: Sequence variant classification and reporting: recommendations for improving the interpretation of cancer susceptibility genetic test results.

text: Current prognostication in primary myelofibrosis (PMF) is based on the dynamic international prognostic scoring system (DIPSS)-plus, which employs clinical and cytogenetic variables.
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: We recently reported DIPSS-plus independent prognostic significance for calreticulin (CALR) (favorable) and ASXL1 (unfavorable) mutations.
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: In the current study, 570 PMF patients were recruited for derivation (n=277) and validation (n=293) of a molecular prognostic model based on these two mutations.
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: Survival was the longest in CALR(+)ASXL1(-) (median 10.4 years) and shortest in CALR(-)ASXL1(+) patients (median, 2.3 years; hazard ratio (HR), 5.9; 95% confidence interval (CI), 3.5-10.0).
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: CALR(+)ASXL1(+) and CALR(-)ASXL1(-) patients had similar survival and were grouped together in an intermediate-risk category (median survival, 5.8 years; HR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.5-4.0).
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: The CALR/ASXL1 mutations-based prognostic model was DIPSS-plus independent (P<0.0001) and effective in identifying low-/intermediate-1-risk patients with shorter (median, 4 years) or longer (median 20 years) survival and high-/intermediate-2-risk patients with shorter (median, 2.3 years) survival.
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: Multivariable analysis distinguished CALR(-)ASXL1(+) mutational status as the most significant risk factor for survival: HR 3.7 vs 2.8 for age >65 years vs 2.7 for unfavorable karyotype.
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: These observations signify immediate clinical relevance and warrant i) CALR and ASXL1 mutation determination in all patients with PMF and ii) molecular revision of DIPSS-plus.
title: CALR and ASXL1 mutations-based molecular prognostication in primary myelofibrosis: an international study of 570 patients.

text: BACKGROUND: Response to chemotherapy and anatomical spread are significant prognostic factors in patients with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) treated by chemotherapy then surgery.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: Predicting the response to chemotherapy would allow significant optimization of cancer treatment.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: METHODS: Genomic mutation and protein expression of p53 were investigated retrospectively by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) and immunohistochemistry (IHC) using biopsy specimens from 77 ESCC patients before chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, adriamycin, and cisplatin.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: p53 status was correlated with various clinicopathological factors.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: Thereafter, we performed a prospective study of 20 consecutive patients to test our prediction model.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: RESULTS: The retrospective study showed mutant p53 genotype and positive p53 IHC staining in 46.8 and 55.8% of patients, respectively, which was not associated with patient's clinicopathological findings including initial tumor stage.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: Objective response to chemotherapy was observed in 65.9% of patients with wild genotype, but in only 16.7% of patients with mutant genotype.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: Patients with mutations in p53 therefore showed significantly poorer prognosis than those without mutant p53.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: In contrast, p53 IHC staining did not correlate with response to chemotherapy, curative resection rate or prognosis.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: In the prospective study, p53 mutation was seen in 50% (10/20) of patients and was again consistently associated with poorer response to chemotherapy and poorer prognosis.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: CONCLUSIONS: p53 genotype of pretreatment biopsy is a potentially useful predictor of response to chemotherapy and prognosis in ESCC patients.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: This information might be valuable to clinicians in deciding on the optimal clinical strategy in patients with ESCC.
title: p53 genotype predicts response to chemotherapy in patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

text: PURPOSE: P-glycoprotein, encoded by the mdr-1 gene, confers multidrug resistance to a variety of antineoplastic agents, e.g., paclitaxel.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: Recently, different polymorphisms in the mdr-1 gene have been identified and their consequences for the function of P-glycoprotein, as well as for the treatment response to P-glycoprotein substrates, are being clarified.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: We analyzed the allelic frequencies at polymorphic sites G2677T/A and C3435T in ovarian cancer patients with good or poor response to treatment with paclitaxel in combination with carboplatin in order to evaluate their predictive values.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Fifty-three patients were included in the study; 28 of them had been relapse-free for at least 1 year and 25 had progressive disease or relapsed within 12 months.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: A reference material consisting of 200 individuals was also analyzed.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: The genotypes of each single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) were determined using Pyrosequencing.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: RESULTS: The G2677T/A SNP was found to significantly correlate with treatment outcome.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: The probability of responding to paclitaxel treatment was higher in homozygously mutated patients (T/T or T/A; Fisher's exact test; P < 0.05).
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: The frequency of the T or A alleles was also higher in the group of patients who had a good response (P < 0.05).
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: There was also a dose-dependent influence of the number of mutated alleles on the response to paclitaxel treatment (chi2 test for linear-by-linear association; P = 0.03).
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: However, the C3435T SNP was not found to correlate to treatment outcome.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The mdr-1 polymorphism G2677T/A in exon 21 correlates with the paclitaxel response in ovarian cancer and may be important for the function of P-glycoprotein and resistance to paclitaxel and provide useful information for individualized therapy.
title: mdr-1 single nucleotide polymorphisms in ovarian cancer tissue: G2677T/A correlates with response to paclitaxel chemotherapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Despite the molecular heterogeneity of standard-risk acute myeloid leukemia (AML), treatment decisions are based on a limited number of molecular genetic markers and morphology-based assessment of remission.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: Sensitive detection of a leukemia-specific marker (e.g., a mutation in the gene encoding nucleophosmin [NPM1]) could improve prognostication by identifying submicroscopic disease during remission.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: METHODS: We used a reverse-transcriptase quantitative polymerase-chain-reaction assay to detect minimal residual disease in 2569 samples obtained from 346 patients with NPM1-mutated AML who had undergone intensive treatment in the National Cancer Research Institute AML17 trial.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: We used a custom 51-gene panel to perform targeted sequencing of 223 samples obtained at the time of diagnosis and 49 samples obtained at the time of relapse.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: Mutations associated with preleukemic clones were tracked by means of digital polymerase chain reaction.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: RESULTS: Molecular profiling highlighted the complexity of NPM1-mutated AML, with segregation of patients into more than 150 subgroups, thus precluding reliable outcome prediction.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: The determination of minimal-residual-disease status was more informative.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: Persistence of NPM1-mutated transcripts in blood was present in 15% of the patients after the second chemotherapy cycle and was associated with a greater risk of relapse after 3 years of follow-up than was an absence of such transcripts (82% vs. 30%; hazard ratio, 4.80; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.95 to 7.80; P<0.001) and a lower rate of survival (24% vs. 75%; hazard ratio for death, 4.38; 95% CI, 2.57 to 7.47; P<0.001).
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: The presence of minimal residual disease was the only independent prognostic factor for death in multivariate analysis (hazard ratio, 4.84; 95% CI, 2.57 to 9.15; P<0.001).
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: These results were validated in an independent cohort.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: On sequential monitoring of minimal residual disease, relapse was reliably predicted by a rising level of NPM1-mutated transcripts.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: Although mutations associated with preleukemic clones remained detectable during ongoing remission after chemotherapy, NPM1 mutations were detected in 69 of 70 patients at the time of relapse and provided a better marker of disease status.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The presence of minimal residual disease, as determined by quantitation of NPM1-mutated transcripts, provided powerful prognostic information independent of other risk factors.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: (Funded by Bloodwise and the National Institute for Health Research; Current Controlled Trials number, ISRCTN55675535.
title: Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.
Assessment of Minimal Residual Disease in Standard-Risk AML.

text: Angiosarcomas (AS) represent a heterogeneous group of malignant vascular tumors occurring not only in different anatomic locations but also in distinct clinical settings, such as radiation or associated chronic lymphedema.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: Although representing only 1% to 2% of soft tissue sarcomas, vascular sarcomas provide unique insight into the general process of tumor angiogenesis.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: However, no molecular candidates have been identified to guide a specific therapeutic intervention.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: By expression profiling, AS show distinct up-regulation of vascular-specific receptor tyrosine kinases, including TIE1, KDR, SNRK, TEK, and FLT1.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: Full sequencing of these five candidate genes identified 10% of patients harboring KDR mutations.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: A KDR-positive genotype was associated with strong KDR protein expression and was restricted to the breast anatomic site with or without prior exposure to radiation.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: Transient transfection of KDR mutants into COS-7 cells showed ligand-independent activation of the kinase, which was inhibited by specific KDR inhibitors.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: These data provide a basis for the activity of vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-directed therapy in the treatment of primary and radiation-induced AS.
title: KDR activating mutations in human angiosarcomas are sensitive to specific kinase inhibitors.

text: KRAS activation and PTEN inactivation are frequent events in endometrial tumorigenesis, occurring in 10% to 30% and 26% to 80% of endometrial cancers, respectively.
title: Inhibition of activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 in endometrial cancer cells induces cell death despite PTEN abrogation.

text: Because we have recently shown activating mutations in fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 (FGFR2) in 16% of endometrioid endometrial cancers, we sought to determine the genetic context in which FGFR2 mutations occur.
title: Inhibition of activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 in endometrial cancer cells induces cell death despite PTEN abrogation.

text: Analysis of 116 primary endometrioid endometrial cancers revealed that FGFR2 and KRAS mutations were mutually exclusive, whereas FGFR2 mutations were seen concomitantly with PTEN mutations.
title: Inhibition of activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 in endometrial cancer cells induces cell death despite PTEN abrogation.

text: Here, we show that shRNA knockdown of FGFR2 or treatment with a pan-FGFR inhibitor, PD173074, resulted in cell cycle arrest and induction of cell death in endometrial cancer cells with activating mutations in FGFR2.
title: Inhibition of activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 in endometrial cancer cells induces cell death despite PTEN abrogation.

text: This cell death in response to FGFR2 inhibition occurred within the context of loss-of-function mutations in PTEN and constitutive AKT phosphorylation, and was associated with a marked reduction in extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 activation.
title: Inhibition of activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 in endometrial cancer cells induces cell death despite PTEN abrogation.

text: Together, these data suggest that inhibition of FGFR2 may be a viable therapeutic option in endometrial tumors possessing activating mutations in FGFR2, despite the frequent abrogation of PTEN in this cancer type.
title: Inhibition of activated fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 in endometrial cancer cells induces cell death despite PTEN abrogation.

text: UNLABELLED: Non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC) harboring anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene rearrangements invariably develop resistance to the ALK tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) crizotinib.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Herein, we report the first preclinical evaluation of the next-generation ALK TKI, ceritinib (LDK378), in the setting of crizotinib resistance.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: An interrogation of in vitro and in vivo models of acquired resistance to crizotinib, including cell lines established from biopsies of patients with crizotinib-resistant NSCLC, revealed that ceritinib potently overcomes crizotinib-resistant mutations.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In particular, ceritinib effectively inhibits ALK harboring L1196M, G1269A, I1171T, and S1206Y mutations, and a cocrystal structure of ceritinib bound to ALK provides structural bases for this increased potency.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: However, we observed that ceritinib did not overcome two crizotinib-resistant ALK mutations, G1202R and F1174C, and one of these mutations was identified in 5 of 11 biopsies from patients with acquired resistance to ceritinib.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Altogether, our results demonstrate that ceritinib can overcome crizotinib resistance, consistent with clinical data showing marked efficacy of ceritinib in patients with crizotinib-resistant disease.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: The second-generation ALK inhibitor ceritinib can overcome several crizotinib-resistant mutations and is potent against several in vitro and in vivo laboratory models of acquired resistance to crizotinib.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: These findings provide the molecular basis for the marked clinical activity of ceritinib in patients with ALK-positive NSCLC with crizotinib-resistant disease.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Cancer Discov; 4(6); 662-73.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: (c)2014 AACR.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: See related commentary by Ramalingam and Khuri, p. 634 This article is highlighted in the In This Issue feature, p. 621.
title: The ALK inhibitor ceritinib overcomes crizotinib resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Ibrutinib (ibr), a first-in-class Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitor, has demonstrated high response rates in both relapsed/refractory and treatment naive chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: However, about 25% of patients discontinue ibrutinib therapy at a median follow-up of 20 months and many patients discontinue the treatment due to leukemia progression or Richter transformation.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Mutations affecting the C481 residue of BTK disrupt ibrutinib binding and have been characterized by us and others as the most common mechanism of ibrutinib resistance.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Thus far, all described BTK mutations are located in its kinase domain and mutations outside this domain have never been described.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Herein, we report a patient whose CLL progressed, was salvaged with ibrutinib and then relapsed.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Serial analysis of samples throughout patient's clinical course identified a structurally novel mutation (BTKT316A) in the SH2 domain, but not kinase domain, of Bruton tyrosine kinase which was associated with disease relapse.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Functionally, cells carrying BTKT316A show resistance to ibrutinib at both cellular and molecular levels to a similar extent as BTKC481S.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Our study lends further insight into the diverse mechanisms of ibrutinib resistance that has important implications for the development of next-generation BTK inhibitors as well as mutation detection in relapsed patients.
title: Identification of a structurally novel BTK mutation that drives ibrutinib resistance in CLL.

text: Recent studies showed KIT gene aberrations in a substantial number of melanomas on acral skin and mucosa, suggesting the therapeutic benefit of tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: We therefore examined the expression and mutations of KIT in 4 primary and 24 metastatic acral and mucosal melanomas.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Immunohistochemistry revealed moderate or strong KIT protein expression in 13 (48%) tumors.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Sequence analysis revealed K642E and D820Y mutations in two metastases.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Amplification of KIT was identified by real-time PCR in 4 tumors, including one that had K642E.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Western blot analysis showed phosphorylation of the KIT receptor in 8 (62%) of 13 cryopreserved samples, indicating the frequent pathological activation of the receptor in vivo.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Phosphorylation of KIT protein was detected in 2 tumors harboring KIT mutations, as well as in one tumor with KIT gene amplification.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Furthermore, 5 tumors without detectable KIT gene aberrations showed phosphorylation of the KIT receptor.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Expression of stem cell factor (SCF) in melanoma cells as well as stromal cells suggests SCF/KIT autocrine and paracrine activation in these tumors.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: Finally, we found significant growth suppressive effects of sunitinib in two acral melanoma cell lines; one harboring the D820Y mutation and one showing SCF-dependent KIT activation.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: These results show pathological activation of KIT in a substantial number of metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas, and suggest a potential therapeutic benefit of sunitinib for these melanomas.
title: Pathological activation of KIT in metastatic tumors of acral and mucosal melanomas.

text: BACKGROUND: Chromosomal rearrangements of the gene encoding ROS1 proto-oncogene receptor tyrosine kinase (ROS1) define a distinct molecular subgroup of non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLCs) that may be susceptible to therapeutic ROS1 kinase inhibition.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Crizotinib is a small-molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), ROS1, and another proto-oncogene receptor tyrosine kinase, MET.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: We enrolled 50 patients with advanced NSCLC who tested positive for ROS1 rearrangement in an expansion cohort of the phase 1 study of crizotinib.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Patients were treated with crizotinib at the standard oral dose of 250 mg twice daily and assessed for safety, pharmacokinetics, and response to therapy.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: ROS1 fusion partners were identified with the use of next-generation sequencing or reverse-transcriptase-polymerase-chain-reaction assays.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: The objective response rate was 72% (95% confidence interval [CI], 58 to 84), with 3 complete responses and 33 partial responses.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The median duration of response was 17.6 months (95% CI, 14.5 to not reached).
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Median progression-free survival was 19.2 months (95% CI, 14.4 to not reached), with 25 patients (50%) still in follow-up for progression.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among 30 tumors that were tested, we identified 7 ROS1 fusion partners: 5 known and 2 novel partner genes.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: No correlation was observed between the type of ROS1 rearrangement and the clinical response to crizotinib.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The safety profile of crizotinib was similar to that seen in patients with ALK-rearranged NSCLC.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In this study, crizotinib showed marked antitumor activity in patients with advanced ROS1-rearranged NSCLC.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: ROS1 rearrangement defines a second molecular subgroup of NSCLC for which crizotinib is highly active.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: (Funded by Pfizer and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00585195.
title: Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.
Crizotinib in ROS1-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Two phase II studies assessed the efficacy of vismodegib, a sonic hedgehog (SHH) pathway inhibitor that binds smoothened (SMO), in pediatric and adult recurrent medulloblastoma (MB).
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Adult patients enrolled onto PBTC-025B and pediatric patients enrolled onto PBTC-032 were treated with vismodegib (150 to 300 mg/d).
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Protocol-defined response, which had to be sustained for 8 weeks, was confirmed by central neuroimaging review.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Molecular tests to identify patterns of response and insensitivity were performed when tissue was available.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: RESULTS: A total of 31 patients were enrolled onto PBTC-025B, and 12 were enrolled onto PBTC-032.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Three patients in PBTC-025B and one in PBTC-032, all with SHH-subgroup MB (SHH-MB), exhibited protocol-defined responses.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Progression-free survival (PFS) was longer in those with SHH-MB than in those with non-SHH-MB, and prolonged disease stabilization occurred in 41% of patient cases of SHH-MB.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Among those with SHH-MB, loss of heterozygosity of PTCH1 was associated with prolonged PFS, and diffuse staining of P53 was associated with reduced PFS.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Whole-exome sequencing identified mutations in SHH genes downstream from SMO in four of four tissue samples from nonresponders and upstream of SMO in two of four patients with favorable responses.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: CONCLUSION: Vismodegib exhibits activity against adult recurrent SHH-MB but not against recurrent non-SHH-MB.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Inadequate accrual of pediatric patients precluded conclusions in this population.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Molecular analyses support the hypothesis that SMO inhibitor activity depends on the genomic aberrations within the tumor.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: Such inhibitors should be advanced in SHH-MB studies; however, molecular and genomic work remains imperative to identify target populations that will truly benefit.
title: Vismodegib Exerts Targeted Efficacy Against Recurrent Sonic Hedgehog-Subgroup Medulloblastoma: Results From Phase II Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium Studies PBTC-025B and PBTC-032.

text: BACKGROUND: Allelic loss of chromosome 18q predicts a poor outcome in patients with stage II colorectal cancer.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: Although the specific gene inactivated by this allelic loss has not been elucidated, the DCC (deleted in colorectal cancer) gene is a candidate.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: We investigated whether the expression of the DCC protein in tumor cells is a prognostic marker in colorectal carcinoma.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: The expression of DCC was evaluated immunohistochemically in 132 paraffin-embedded samples from patients with curatively resected stage II and III colorectal carcinomas.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: The Cox proportional-hazards model was used to adjust for covariates including age, sex, tumor site, degree of tumor differentiation, and use of adjuvant therapy.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: The expression of DCC was a strong positive predictive factor for survival in both stage II and stage III colorectal carcinomas.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: In patients with stage II disease whose tumors expressed DCC, the five-year survival rate was 94.3 percent, whereas in patients with DCC-negative tumors, the survival rate was 61.6 percent (P<0.001).
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: In patients with stage III disease, the respective survival rates were 59.3 percent and 33.2 percent (P=0.03).
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: DCC is a prognostic marker in patients with stage II or stage III colorectal cancer.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: In stage II colorectal carcinomas, the absence of DCC identifies a subgroup of patients with lesions that behave like stage III cancers.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: These findings may thus have therapeutic implications in this group of patients.
title: The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Neratinib, an irreversible tyrosine-kinase inhibitor of HER1, HER2, and HER4, has clinical activity in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: We aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of 12 months of neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with early-stage HER2-positive breast cancer.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: METHODS: We did this multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial at 495 centres in Europe, Asia, Australia, New Zealand, and North and South America.
