title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Eligible women (aged >/=18 years, or >/=20 years in Japan) had stage 1-3 HER2-positive breast cancer and had completed neoadjuvant and adjuvant trastuzumab therapy up to 2 years before randomisation.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Inclusion criteria were amended on Feb 25, 2010, to include patients with stage 2-3 HER2-positive breast cancer who had completed trastuzumab therapy up to 1 year previously.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Patients were randomly assigned (1:1) to receive oral neratinib 240 mg per day or matching placebo.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: The randomisation sequence was generated with permuted blocks stratified by hormone receptor status (hormone receptor-positive [oestrogen or progesterone receptor-positive or both] vs hormone receptor-negative [oestrogen and progesterone receptor-negative]), nodal status (0, 1-3, or >/=4), and trastuzumab adjuvant regimen (sequentially vs concurrently with chemotherapy), then implemented centrally via an interactive voice and web-response system.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Patients, investigators, and trial sponsors were masked to treatment allocation.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: The primary outcome was invasive disease-free survival, as defined in the original protocol, at 2 years after randomisation.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Analysis was by intention to treat.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00878709.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between July 9, 2009, and Oct 24, 2011, we randomly assigned 2840 women to receive neratinib (n=1420) or placebo (n=1420).
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Median follow-up time was 24 months (IQR 20-25) in the neratinib group and 24 months (22-25) in the placebo group.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: At 2 year follow-up, 70 invasive disease-free survival events had occurred in patients in the neratinib group versus 109 events in those in the placebo group (stratified hazard ratio 0.67, 95% CI 0.50-0.91; p=0.0091).
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: The 2-year invasive disease-free survival rate was 93.9% (95% CI 92.4-95.2) in the neratinib group and 91.6% (90.0-93.0) in the placebo group.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: The most common grade 3-4 adverse events in patients in the neratinib group were diarrhoea (grade 3, n=561 [40%] and grade 4, n=1 [<1%] vs grade 3, n=23 [2%] in the placebo group), vomiting (grade 3, n=47 [3%] vs n=5 [<1%]), and nausea (grade 3, n=26 [2%] vs n=2 [<1%]).
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: QT prolongation occurred in 49 (3%) patients given neratinib and 93 (7%) patients given placebo, and decreases in left ventricular ejection fraction (>/=grade 2) in 19 (1%) and 15 (1%) patients, respectively.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: We recorded serious adverse events in 103 (7%) patients in the neratinib group and 85 (6%) patients in the placebo group.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Seven (<1%) deaths (four patients in the neratinib group and three patients in the placebo group) unrelated to disease progression occurred after study drug discontinuation.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: The causes of death in the neratinib group were unknown (n=2), a second primary brain tumour (n=1), and acute myeloid leukaemia (n=1), and in the placebo group were a brain haemorrhage (n=1), myocardial infarction (n=1), and gastric cancer (n=1).
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: None of the deaths were attributed to study treatment in either group.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Neratinib for 12 months significantly improved 2-year invasive disease-free survival when given after chemotherapy and trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy to women with HER2-positive breast cancer.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: Longer follow-up is needed to ensure that the improvement in breast cancer outcome is maintained.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: FUNDING: Wyeth, Pfizer, Puma Biotechnology.
title: Neratinib after trastuzumab-based adjuvant therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer (ExteNET): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.

text: BACKGROUND: Inhibition of the activated epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) with either enzymatic kinase inhibitors or anti-EGFR antibodies such as cetuximab, is an effective modality of treatment for multiple human cancers.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: Enzymatic EGFR inhibitors are effective for lung adenocarcinomas with somatic kinase domain EGFR mutations while, paradoxically, anti-EGFR antibodies are more effective in colon and head and neck cancers where EGFR mutations occur less frequently.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: In colorectal cancer, anti-EGFR antibodies are routinely used as second-line therapy of KRAS wild-type tumors.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: However, detailed mechanisms and genomic predictors for pharmacological response to these antibodies in colon cancer remain unclear.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: FINDINGS: We describe a case of colorectal adenocarcinoma, which was found to harbor a kinase domain mutation, G724S, in EGFR through whole genome sequencing.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: We show that G724S mutant EGFR is oncogenic and that it differs from classic lung cancer derived EGFR mutants in that it is cetuximab responsive in vitro, yet relatively insensitive to small molecule kinase inhibitors.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: Through biochemical and cellular pharmacologic studies, we have determined that cells harboring the colon cancer-derived G719S and G724S mutants are responsive to cetuximab therapy in vitro and found that the requirement for asymmetric dimerization of these mutant EGFR to promote cellular transformation may explain their greater inhibition by cetuximab than small-molecule kinase inhibitors.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: CONCLUSION: The colon-cancer derived G719S and G724S mutants are oncogenic and sensitive in vitro to cetuximab.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: These data suggest that patients with these mutations may benefit from the use of anti-EGFR antibodies as part of the first-line therapy.
title: Colon cancer-derived oncogenic EGFR G724S mutant identified by whole genome sequence analysis is dependent on asymmetric dimerization and sensitive to cetuximab.

text: A recent randomized EORTC phase III trial, comparing two doses of imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs), reported dose dependency for progression-free survival.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: The current analysis of that study aimed to assess if tumour mutational status correlates with clinical response to imatinib.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: Pre-treatment samples of GISTs from 377 patients enrolled in phase III study were analyzed for mutations of KIT or PDGFRA by combination of D-HPLC and direct sequencing of tumour genomic DNA.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: Mutation types were correlated with patients' survival data.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: The presence of exon 9-activating mutations in KIT was the strongest adverse prognostic factor for response to imatinib, increasing the relative risk of progression by 171% (P<0.0001) and the relative risk of death by 190% (P<0.0001) when compared with KIT exon 11 mutants.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: Similarly, the relative risk of progression was increased by 108% (P<0.0001) and the relative risk of death by 76% (P=0.028) in patients without detectable KIT or PDGFRA mutations.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: In patients whose tumours expressed an exon 9 KIT oncoprotein, treatment with the high-dose regimen resulted in a significantly superior progression-free survival (P=0.0013), with a reduction of the relative risk of 61%.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: We conclude that tumour genotype is of major prognostic significance for progression-free survival and overall survival in patients treated with imatinib for advanced GISTs.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: Our findings suggest the need for differential treatment of patients with GISTs, with KIT exon 9 mutant patients benefiting the most from the 800 mg daily dose of the drug.
title: KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

text: Regulators of the cell cycle such as cyclin E play an important part in neoplasia.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: The cyclin E protein forms a partnership with a specific protein kinase.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: This complex phosphorylates key substrates to initiate DNA synthesis.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (CKIs) are able to suppress the activity of cyclin E. Various substances (including proteins produced by oncogenic viruses) affect cyclin E directly or indirectly through an interaction with CKIs.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: These interactions are important in elucidating the mechanisms of neoplasia.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: They may also provide prognostic information in a wide range of common cancers.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: Cyclin E may even be a target for treatment of cancers in the future.
title: Cyclin E in human cancers.

text: Nucleophosmin 1 (NPM1) is an oligomeric, nucleolar phosphoprotein that functions as a molecular chaperone for both proteins and nucleic acids.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: NPM1 is mutated in approximately one-third of patients with AML.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: The mutant NPM1c+ contains a 4-base insert that results in extra C-terminal residues encoding a nuclear export signal, which causes NPM1c+ to be localized in the cytoplasm.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: Here, we determined the effects of targeting NPM1 in cultured and primary AML cells.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: Treatment with siRNA to NPM1 induced p53 and p21, decreased the percentage of cells in S-phase of the cell cycle, as well as induced differentiation of the AML OCI-AML3 cells that express both NPMc+ and unmutated NPM1.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: Notably, knockdown of NPM1 by shRNA abolished lethal AML phenotype induced by OCI-AML3 cells in NOD/SCID mice.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: Knockdown of NPM1 also sensitized OCI-AML3 to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and cytarabine.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: Inhibition of NPM1 oligomerization by NSC348884 induced apoptosis and sensitized OCI-AML3 and primary AML cells expressing NPM1c+ to ATRA.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: This effect was significantly less in AML cells coexpressing FLT3-ITD, or in AML or normal CD34+ progenitor cells expressing wild-type NPM1.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: Thus, attenuating levels or oligomerization of NPM1 selectively induces apoptosis and sensitizes NPM1c+ expressing AML cells to treatment with ATRA and cytarabine.
title: Targeting levels or oligomerization of nucleophosmin 1 induces differentiation and loss of survival of human AML cells with mutant NPM1.

text: BACKGROUND: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) ranks as the third leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: While sorafenib, a multikinase inhibitor targeting the Raf/extracellular signal-regulated protein kinase (ERK) pathway, has been shown recently to provide a survival advantage to patients with advanced HCC, a predictive biomarker has not been developed.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: We studied whether c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), which promotes liver carcinogenesis in mice, affects therapeutic response to sorafenib in HCC patients.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: METHODS: We collected pathological specimens from 39 patients with advanced HCC before starting sorafenib treatment, and measured JNK activity in HCCs.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: In patients treated with sorafenib, the expression of phospho-c-Jun in HCC, as a read out of JNK activity, was significantly higher (P<0.001) in the non-responder group than in the responder group.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: c-Jun N-terminal kinase activation in HCC was associated with a decreased time to progression and a poor overall survival (P=0.0028 and P=0.0008, respectively).
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: In addition, JNK activity was significantly correlated with CD133 expression level.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Correspondingly, high expression level of CD133 was linked to a poor response to sorafenib.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Furthermore, D-JNKi, a specific JNK inhibitor, reduced the growth of xenografted CD133(+) cells in athymic mice.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: In conclusion, JNK activation was positively correlated with CD133 expression level and inversely correlated with the therapeutic response to sorafenib, suggesting that JNK activity may be considered as a new predictive biomarker for response to sorafenib treatment.
title: Activation of JNK and high expression level of CD133 predict a poor response to sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Mutations in PIK3CA [the gene encoding the p110alpha catalytic subunit of phosphatidylinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)] play an important role in colorectal carcinogenesis.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: Experimental evidence suggests that PIK3CA exon 9 and exon 20 mutations trigger different biologic effects, and that concomitant mutations in both exons 9 and 20 synergistically enhance tumorigenic effects.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: Thus, we hypothesized that PIK3CA exon 9 and exon 20 mutations might have differential effects on clinical outcome in colorectal cancer, and that concomitant PIK3CA exon 9 and 20 mutations might confer aggressive tumor behavior.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We sequenced PIK3CA by pyrosequencing in 1,170 rectal and colon cancers in two prospective cohort studies, and found 189 (16%) PIK3CA mutated tumors.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: Mortality HR according to PIK3CA status was computed using Cox proportional hazards model, adjusting for clinical and molecular features, including microsatellite instability, CpG island methylator phenotype, LINE-1 methylation, and BRAF and KRAS mutations.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: RESULTS: Compared with PIK3CA wild-type cases, patients with concomitant PIK3CA mutations in exons 9 and 20 experienced significantly worse cancer-specific survival [log-rank P = 0.031; multivariate HR = 3.51; 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.28-9.62] and overall survival (log-rank P = 0.0008; multivariate HR = 2.68; 95% CI: 1.24-5.77).
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: PIK3CA mutation in either exon 9 or 20 alone was not significantly associated with patient survival.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: No significant interaction of PIK3CA mutation with BRAF or KRAS mutation was observed in survival analysis.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: CONCLUSION: Coexistence of PIK3CA (the PI3K p110alpha subunit) exon 9 and 20 mutations, but not PIK3CA mutation in either exon 9 or 20 alone, is associated with poor prognosis of colorectal cancer patients.
title: Prognostic role of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer: cohort study and literature review.

text: BACKGROUND: To investigate the role of the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway activation in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-targeted therapy.
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: METHODS: We evaluated the predictive roles of PI3K, catalytic alpha (PIK3CA), and phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) in HER2-based therapy (either trastuzumab or lapatinib).
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: PTEN expression and PIK3CA mutation were analyzed using immunohistochemistry and pyrosequencing.
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: RESULTS: Forty-eight patients received trastuzumab (n = 39) or lapatinib (n = 9) combination chemotherapy.
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: PTEN loss was found in 47.9% (n = 23), but no PIK3CA mutations were identified.
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: Twenty-six (54.1%) patients responded to HER2-based therapy, without a significant difference between patients with PTEN loss and those without (52.2 vs. 56.0%).
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: Among the patients with responsive disease, time to best response did not differ by PTEN status, but the duration of response was significantly shorter for patients with PTEN loss (median 4.2 vs. 6.1 months, p = 0.04).
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: In addition, patients with PTEN loss had a significantly shorter progression-free survival time (median 4.9 vs. 7.3 months, p = 0.047).
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: PTEN deficiency is an important predictive marker for early resistance to HER2 inhibitor treatment in gastric cancer patients.
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: This finding may be useful for the development of drug combinations and identification of patients who need a modified treatment strategy.
title: PTEN deficiency as a predictive biomarker of resistance to HER2-targeted therapy in advanced gastric cancer.

text: G-quadruplex DNAs form four-stranded helical structures and are proposed to play key roles in different cellular processes.
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: Targeting G-quadruplex DNAs for cancer treatment is a very promising prospect.
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: Here, we show that CX-5461 is a G-quadruplex stabilizer, with specific toxicity against BRCA deficiencies in cancer cells and polyclonal patient-derived xenograft models, including tumours resistant to PARP inhibition.
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: Exposure to CX-5461, and its related drug CX-3543, blocks replication forks and induces ssDNA gaps or breaks.
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: The BRCA and NHEJ pathways are required for the repair of CX-5461 and CX-3543-induced DNA damage and failure to do so leads to lethality.
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: These data strengthen the concept of G4 targeting as a therapeutic approach, specifically for targeting HR and NHEJ deficient cancers and other tumours deficient for DNA damage repair.
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: CX-5461 is now in advanced phase I clinical trial for patients with BRCA1/2 deficient tumours (Canadian trial, NCT02719977, opened May 2016).
title: CX-5461 is a DNA G-quadruplex stabilizer with selective lethality in BRCA1/2 deficient tumours.

text: BACKGROUND: We analyzed prospectively whether MGMT (O(6)-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase) mRNA expression gains prognostic/predictive impact independent of MGMT promoter methylation in malignant glioma patients undergoing radiotherapy with concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide or temozolomide alone.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: As DNA-methyltransferases (DNMTs) are the enzymes responsible for setting up and maintaining DNA methylation patterns in eukaryotic cells, we analyzed further, whether MGMT promoter methylation is associated with upregulation of DNMT expression.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: ADULT PATIENTS WITH A HISTOLOGICALLY PROVEN MALIGNANT ASTROCYTOMA (GLIOBLASTOMA: N = 53, anaplastic astrocytoma: N = 10) were included.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: MGMT promoter methylation was determined by methylation-specific PCR (MSP) and sequencing analysis.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Expression of MGMT and DNMTs mRNA were analysed by real-time qPCR.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Prognostic factors were obtained from proportional hazards models.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Correlation between MGMT mRNA expression and MGMT methylation status was validated using data from the Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) database (N = 229 glioblastomas).
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Low MGMT mRNA expression was strongly predictive for prolonged time to progression, treatment response, and length of survival in univariate and multivariate models (p<0.0001); the degree of MGMT mRNA expression was highly correlated with the MGMT promoter methylation status (p<0.0001); however, discordant findings were seen in 12 glioblastoma patients: Patients with methylated tumors with high MGMT mRNA expression (N = 6) did significantly worse than those with low transcriptional activity (p<0.01).
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Conversely, unmethylated tumors with low MGMT mRNA expression (N = 6) did better than their counterparts.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: A nearly identical frequency of concordant and discordant findings was obtained by analyzing the TCGA database (p<0.0001).
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Expression of DNMT1 and DNMT3b was strongly upregulated in tumor tissue, but not correlated with MGMT promoter methylation and MGMT mRNA expression.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: MGMT mRNA expression plays a direct role for mediating tumor sensitivity to alkylating agents.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Discordant findings indicate methylation-independent pathways of MGMT expression regulation.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: DNMT1 and DNMT3b are likely to be involved in CGI methylation.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: However, their exact role yet has to be defined.
title: O-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) mRNA expression predicts outcome in malignant glioma independent of MGMT promoter methylation.

text: Germline mutations in the LKB1/STK11 tumour suppressor gene cause Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), a rare dominant disorder.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: In addition to typical hamartomatous gastrointestinal polyps and pigmented perioral lesions, PJS is associated with an increased risk of tumours at multiple sites.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Follow-up information on carriers is limited and genetic heterogeneity makes counselling and management in PJS difficult.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Here we report the analysis of the LKB1/STK11 locus in a series of 33 PJS families, and estimation of cancer risks in carriers and noncarriers.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Germline mutations of LKB1/STK11 were identified in 52% of cases.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: This observation reinforces the hypothesis of a second PJS locus.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: In carriers of LKB1/STK11 mutations, the risk of cancer was markedly elevated.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: The risk of developing any cancer in carriers by age 65 years was 47% (95% CI: 27-73%) with elevated risks of both gastrointestinal and breast cancer.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: PJS with germline mutations in LKB1/STK11 are at a very high relative and absolute risk of multiple gastrointestinal and nongastrointestinal cancers.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: To obtain precise estimates of risk associated with PJS requires further studies of genotype-phenotype especially with respect to LKB1/STK11 negative cases, as this group is likely to be heterogeneous.
title: Further observations on LKB1/STK11 status and cancer risk in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Granulosa cell tumors of the ovary represent approximately 5% of malignant ovarian cancers.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: It has recently been reported that 95-97% of adult granulosa cell tumors carry a unique somatic mutation in the FOXL2 gene.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: We undertook this study to verify the presence of the FOXL2 Cys134Trp mutation in two geographically independent cohorts of granulosa cell tumors and to examine the expression pattern of FOXL2 in these tumors.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: A total of 56 tumors with the histological diagnosis of adult granulosa cell tumor from two centers, Melbourne and Helsinki, were examined for the presence of the mutation using direct sequence analysis.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: Two granulosa cell tumor-derived cell lines, COV434 and KGN, three juvenile granulosa cell tumors and control tissues were also examined.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: The expression of the FOXL2 gene was determined using quantitative RT-PCR and/or immunohistochemistry.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: We found that 52 of the 56 adult granulosa cell tumors harbor the mutation, of which three were hemi/homozygous.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: Of the four cases with wild-type FOXL2 sequence, reappraisal suggests that three may have been misclassified at primary diagnosis.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: The KGN cells were heterozygous for the mutation, whereas the COV434 cells had a wild-type FOXL2 genotype.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: The expression levels of FOXL2 were similar across the adult granulosa cell tumors and the normal ovary controls; one mutation-negative granulosa cell tumor had high FOXL2 mRNA levels, whereas the COV434 cells and two of the three juvenile granulosa cell tumors lacked the expression of FOXL2.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: Our data provide confirmation of the frequent presence of the FOXL2 C134W mutation in adult granulosa cell tumors and demonstrate that the mutation is not associated with altered FOXL2 expression.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: The mutation analysis may be a useful tool to differentiate particularly between cell-rich diffuse granulosa cell tumors and mitotically active sex cord-stromal tumors.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: This unique FOXL2 mutation appears to be characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors.
title: The FOXL2 C134W mutation is characteristic of adult granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

text: PURPOSE: We explored the potential clinical association between programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression and driven gene status in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: We systemically searched through October 2015.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: Odd ratios (ORs) with 95% CIs were calculated to examine the association of PD-L1 expression with driven gene status.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: A random- or fixed-effects model was used.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Nine studies were identified.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: KRAS-mutant tumors were more likely to be PD-L1 positive than KRAS-wild type tumors (51% vs 36%; OR 1.69; 95% CI 1.01-2.84; p = 0.045).
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: In contrast, PD-L1 expression did not differ by EGFR (OR 0.86; 95% CI 0.43-1.73; p = 0.675) or ALK (OR 1.02; 95% CI 0.44-2.37; p = 0.954) status.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: In subgroup analysis, there was also no significant association between PD-L1 expression and EGFR status in term of the cut-offs or ethnicity.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSION: In conclusion, NSCLC with KRAS mutations showed a trend for higher frequency of positive PD-L1 expression.
title: Association between PD-L1 expression and driven gene status in NSCLC: A meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: The epidermal growth factor receptor variant III deletion mutation, EGFRvIII, is expressed in approximately 30% of primary glioblastoma and linked to poor long-term survival.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: Rindopepimut consists of the unique EGFRvIII peptide sequence conjugated to keyhole limpet hemocyanin.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: In previous phase II trials (ACTIVATE/ACT II), rindopepimut was well tolerated with robust EGFRvIII-specific immune responses and promising progression-free and overall survival.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: This multicenter, single-arm phase II clinical trial (ACT III) was performed to confirm these results.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: METHODS: Rindopepimut and standard adjuvant temozolomide chemotherapy were administered to 65 patients with newly diagnosed EGFRvIII-expressing (EGFRvIII+) glioblastoma after gross total resection and chemoradiation.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: RESULTS: Progression-free survival at 5.5 months ( approximately 8.5 mo from diagnosis) was 66%.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: Relative to study entry, median overall survival was 21.8 months, and 36-month overall survival was 26%.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: Extended rindopepimut vaccination (up to 3.5+ years) was well tolerated.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: Grades 1-2 injection site reactions were frequent.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: Anti-EGFRvIII antibody titers increased >/=4-fold in 85% of patients, and increased with duration of treatment.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: EGFRvIII was eliminated in 4/6 (67%) tumor samples obtained after >3 months of therapy.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This study confirms, in a multicenter setting, the preliminary results seen in previous phase II trials of rindopepimut.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: A pivotal, double-blind, randomized, phase III trial ("ACT IV") is under way.
title: A phase II, multicenter trial of rindopepimut (CDX-110) in newly diagnosed glioblastoma: the ACT III study.

text: PURPOSE: The aim of this study was to investigate the association of the thymidylate synthase (TS) and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) polymorphisms with the clinical outcomes of gastric cancer patients treated with 5-FU-based adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: METHODS: One-hundred and sixteen patients with gastric cancer were treated with 5-FU-based adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: The TS (a 28-bp tandem repeat polymorphism in the TS enhancer region (TSER) and a 6 bp deletion/insertion polymorphism in the 3'-untranslated region) and MTHFR C677T polymorphisms were determined in blood samples from those patients using PCR and PCR-LDR (ligation detection reaction) method, respectively.
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: RESULTS: The overall survival (OS) in patients with the TS ins6/ins6 genotype was significantly shorter than those in patients with the del6/del6 (P = 0.017) and ins6/del6 (P = 0.022) genotype.
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: The relapse-free survival (RFS) and OS in patients with the MTHFR C/C genotype were significantly worse than those in patients with the T/T or C/T genotype (P = 0.043 and 0.040, respectively).
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: Cox multivariate analysis also showed that patients with the TS ins6/ins6 genotype have worse OS than patients with the T/T or C/T genotype (HR = 2.437, P = 0.041), and the MTHFR C/C genotype was associated with shorter RFS (HR = 1.723, P = 0.031) and OS (HR = 1.681, P = 0.056).
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: No significant association was found between the TSER polymorphism and the clinical outcomes (P > 0.05).
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: CONCLUSION: The polymorphisms of TS 3'-UTR ins6/del6 and MTHFR C677T appear to be potential prognostic factors in gastric cancer patients treated with 5-FU-based adjuvant chemotherapy, which may allow identification of gastric cancer patients who will benefit from 5-FU chemotherapy.
title: The polymorphisms of TS and MTHFR predict survival of gastric cancer patients treated with fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy in Chinese population.

text: Genetic alterations in the kinase domain of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients are associated with sensitivity to treatment with small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: Although first-generation reversible, ATP-competitive inhibitors showed encouraging clinical responses in lung adenocarcinoma tumors harboring such EGFR mutations, almost all patients developed resistance to these inhibitors over time.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: Such resistance to first-generation EGFR inhibitors was frequently linked to an acquired T790M point mutation in the kinase domain of EGFR, or upregulation of signaling pathways downstream of HER3.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: Overcoming these mechanisms of resistance, as well as primary resistance to reversible EGFR inhibitors driven by a subset of EGFR mutations, will be necessary for development of an effective targeted therapy regimen.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: Here, we show that BIBW2992, an anilino-quinazoline designed to irreversibly bind EGFR and HER2, potently suppresses the kinase activity of wild-type and activated EGFR and HER2 mutants, including erlotinib-resistant isoforms.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: Consistent with this activity, BIBW2992 suppresses transformation in isogenic cell-based assays, inhibits survival of cancer cell lines and induces tumor regression in xenograft and transgenic lung cancer models, with superior activity over erlotinib.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: These findings encourage further testing of BIBW2992 in lung cancer patients harboring EGFR or HER2 oncogenes.
title: BIBW2992, an irreversible EGFR/HER2 inhibitor highly effective in preclinical lung cancer models.

text: PURPOSE: Aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is often a disfiguring and lethal disease.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Very little is currently known about the mutations that drive aggressive cSCC.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Whole-exome sequencing was performed on 39 cases of aggressive cSCC to identify driver genes and novel therapeutic targets.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Significantly, mutated genes were identified with MutSig or complementary methods developed to specifically identify candidate tumor suppressors based upon their inactivating mutation bias.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Despite the very high-mutational background caused by UV exposure, 23 candidate drivers were identified, including the well-known cancer-associated genes TP53, CDKN2A, NOTCH1, AJUBA, HRAS, CASP8, FAT1, and KMT2C (MLL3).
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Three novel candidate tumor suppressors with putative links to cancer or differentiation, NOTCH2, PARD3, and RASA1, were also identified as possible drivers in cSCC.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: KMT2C mutations were associated with poor outcome and increased bone invasion.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The mutational spectrum of cSCC is similar to that of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and dominated by tumor-suppressor genes.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: These results improve the foundation for understanding this disease and should aid in identifying and treating aggressive cSCC.
title: Mutational landscape of aggressive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) overactivation is a common event in many cancers, including head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), where STAT3 represents a promising therapeutic target.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: HNSCC is not characterized by frequent kinase mutations, in contrast to some malignancies where mutational activation of kinases upstream of STAT3 is common.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: Instead, STAT3 may be activated by loss-of-function of negative regulators of STAT3, including by promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: Here we first analyzed The Cancer Genome Atlas data and determined that the PTPRT promoter is frequently hypermethylated in several cancers, including HNSCC (60.1% of tumors analyzed) in association with downregulation of PTPRT mRNA expression and upregulation of pSTAT3 expression.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: These findings were confirmed in an independent cohort of HNSCC tumors by methylation-specific PCR and immunohistochemistry.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: We demonstrate that PTPRT promoter methylation and gene silencing is reversible in HNSCC cells, leading to PTPRT-specific downregulation of pSTAT3 expression.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: We further show that PTPRT promoter methylation is significantly associated with sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in HNSCC cells, suggesting that PTPRT promoter methylation may serve as a predictive biomarker for responsiveness to STAT3 inhibitors in clinical development.
title: Frequent promoter hypermethylation of PTPRT increases STAT3 activation and sensitivity to STAT3 inhibition in head and neck cancer.

text: A series of 88 conventional follicular and Hurthle cell thyroid tumors were analyzed for RAS mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangements using molecular methods and for galectin-3 and HBME-1 expression by immunohistochemistry.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: A novel LightCycler technology-based method was developed to detect point mutations in codons 12/13 and 61 of the H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS genes.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: Forty-nine percent of conventional follicular carcinomas had RAS mutations, 36% had PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement, and only one (3%) had both.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: In follicular adenomas, 48% had RAS mutations, 4% had PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement, and 48% had neither.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: Follicular carcinomas with PAX8-PPAR gamma typically showed immunoreactivity for galectin-3 but not for HBME-1, tended to present at a younger patient age and be smaller size, and were almost always overtly invasive.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: In contrast, follicular carcinomas with RAS mutations most often displayed an HBME-1-positive/galectin-3-negative immunophenotype and were either minimally or overtly invasive.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: Hurthle cell tumors infrequently had PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement or RAS mutations.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: These results suggest that conventional follicular thyroid carcinomas develop through at least two distinct and virtually nonoverlapping molecular pathways initiated by either RAS point mutation or PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement.
title: RAS point mutations and PAX8-PPAR gamma rearrangement in thyroid tumors: evidence for distinct molecular pathways in thyroid follicular carcinoma.

text: We investigated the genotype-dependent therapeutic potential of targeting the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt pathway for thyroid cancer.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Proliferation of TPC1, Hth7, FTC133, OCUT1, K1, and BCPAP cells that harbored PI3K/Akt-activating genetic alterations was potently inhibited by the Akt inhibitor perifosine, whereas SW1736, Hth74, WRO, KAT18, and TAD2 cells that harbored no genetic alterations had no or only modest responses.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Inhibition of Akt phosphorylation by perifosine was seen in these cells.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Genetic-dependent apoptosis was induced by perifosine in cells selectively tested.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Similarly, potent inhibition of cell proliferation by the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor temsirolimus occurred in virtually all the cells harboring genetic alterations, whereas modest inhibition was seen in some of the cells not harboring genetic alterations.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Temsirolimus inhibited the phosphorylation of p70S6K, a substrate of mTOR.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Knockdown of Akt1/2 or mTOR by shRNA approach inhibited the proliferation and colony formation of FTC133 and OCUT1 cells that harbored genetic alterations in the PI3K/Akt pathway but had no effect on SW1736 and KAT18 cells that did not.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Transfection with PIK3CA mutants greatly sensitized SW1736 cells to perifosine and temsirolimus.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Growth of xenograft tumors derived from FTC133 cells but not SW1736 cells in nude mice was dramatically inhibited by perifosine.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: Thus, this work for the first time shows that genetic alterations in the PI3K/Akt pathway confer thyroid cancer cells addiction to this pathway and their sensitivity to inhibition by targeting Akt and mTOR.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: This genotype-based targeting of the PI3K/Akt pathway using Akt and mTOR inhibitors may offer an effective therapeutic strategy for thyroid cancer and warrants further studies.
title: Genetic alterations in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt signaling pathway confer sensitivity of thyroid cancer cells to therapeutic targeting of Akt and mammalian target of rapamycin.

text: BACKGROUND: To report on a prospective, investigator-driven, phase II study on lapatinib in epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-positive advanced chordoma patients.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: From December 2009 to January 2012, 18 advanced progressing chordoma patients entered this study (median age: 61 years; disease extent: metastatic 72% and locally advanced 28%).
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) expression and activation were evaluated by immunohistochemistry and/or phospho-arrays, real-time polimerase chain reaction, fluorescence immunostaining.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis was also carried out.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Patients received lapatinib 1500 mg/day (mean dose intensity = 1282 mg/day), until progression or toxicity.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: The primary study end point was response rate (RR) as per Choi criteria.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Secondary end points were RR by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumor (RECIST), overall survival, progression-free survival (PFS) and clinical benefit rate (CBR; RECIST complete response + partial response (PR) + stable disease (SD) >/= 6 months).
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: RESULTS: All patients were evaluable for response.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Six (33.3%) patients had PR and 7 (38.9%) SD, as their best Choi responses, corresponding to RECIST SD in all cases.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Median PFS by Choi was 6 [interquartile (IQ) range 3-8] months.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Median PFS by RECIST was 8 (IQ range 4-12) months, with a 22% CBR.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This phase II study showed a modest antitumor activity of lapatinib in chordoma.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: The clinical exploitation of EGFR targeting in chordoma needs to be further investigated, both clinically and preclinically.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: Clinical trial Registration No: EU Clinical Trials Register trial no  2009-014456-29.
title: Phase II study on lapatinib in advanced EGFR-positive chordoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Precision cancer medicine depends on defining distinct tumour subgroups using biomarkers that may occur at very modest frequencies.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: One such subgroup comprises patients with exceptionally mutated (ultramutated) cancers caused by mutations that impair DNA polymerase epsilon (POLE) proofreading.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: METHODS: We examined the association of POLE proofreading domain mutation with clinicopathological variables and immune response in colorectal cancers from clinical trials (VICTOR, QUASAR2, and PETACC-3) and colorectal cancer cohorts (Leiden University Medical Centre 1 and 2, Oslo 1 and 2, Bern, AMC-AJCC-II, and Epicolon-1).
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: We subsequently investigated its association with prognosis in stage II/III colorectal cancer by Cox regression of pooled individual patient data from more than 4500 cases from these studies.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: FINDINGS: Pathogenic somatic POLE mutations were detected in 66 (1.0%) of 6517 colorectal cancers, and were mutually exclusive with mismatch repair deficiency (MMR-D) in the 6277 cases for whom both markers were determined (none of 66 vs 833 [13.4%] of 6211; p<0.0001).
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: Compared with cases with wild-type POLE, cases with POLE mutations were younger at diagnosis (median 54.5 years vs 67.2 years; p<0.0001), were more frequently male (50 [75.8%] of 66 vs 3577 [55.5%] of 6445; p=0.0010), more frequently had right-sided tumour location (44 [68.8%] of 64 vs 2463 [39.8%] of 6193; p<0.0001), and were diagnosed at an earlier disease stage (p=0.006, chi(2) test for trend).
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: Compared with mismatch repair proficient (MMR-P) POLE wild-type tumours, POLE-mutant colorectal cancers displayed increased CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration and expression of cytotoxic T-cell markers and effector cytokines, similar in extent to that observed in immunogenic MMR-D cancers.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: Both POLE mutation and MMR-D were associated with significantly reduced risk of recurrence compared with MMR-P colorectal cancers in multivariable analysis (HR 0.34 [95% CI 0.11-0.76]; p=0.0060 and 0.72 [0.60-0.87]; p=0.00035), although the difference between the groups was not significant.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: INTERPRETATION: POLE proofreading domain mutations identify a subset of immunogenic colorectal cancers with excellent prognosis.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: This association underscores the importance of rare biomarkers in precision cancer medicine, but also raises important questions about how to identify and implement them in practice.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: FUNDING: Cancer Research UK, Academy of Medical Sciences, Health Foundation, EU, ERC, NIHR, Wellcome Trust, Dutch Cancer Society, Dutch Digestive Foundation.
title: Somatic POLE proofreading domain mutation, immune response, and prognosis in colorectal cancer: a retrospective, pooled biomarker study.

text: von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is a dominantly inherited familial cancer syndrome predisposing to retinal, cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastoma, renal cell carcinoma (RCC), pheochromocytoma and pancreatic tumors.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: Clinically two types of the disease can be distinguished: VHL type 1 (without pheochromocytoma) and VHL type 2 (with pheochromocytoma).
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: We report VHL germline mutations and trends in phenotypic variation in families from central Europe.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: We identified 28 mutations in 53/65 (81.5%) families with 18 (64%) mutations being unique to this population.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: Whereas types and distribution of mutations as well as a strong correlation of missense mutations with the VHL 2 phenotype were similar to those identified in other populations, these families have provided new insights into the molecular basis for variability in the VHL 2 phenotype.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: Seven different missense mutations in exons 1 and 3 varied in their biological consequences from a minimal VHL 2 phenotype with pheochromocytoma only to a full VHL 2 phenotype with RCC and pancreatic lesion.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: These findings contribute to a better understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of VHL disease and its phenotypic variability.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: Further, we have provided rapid VHL screening for the families in central Europe, which has resulted in improved diagnosis and clinical management.
title: Mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene and associated lesions in families with von Hippel-Lindau disease from central Europe.

text: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) has been suggested to be the candidate gene for 8p11-12 amplification in breast cancer and its therapeutic/ prognostic value is explored.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: Most previous studies focused on FGFR1 gene amplification, which may not necessarily lead to protein expression.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: Therefore, analysis of protein level may have more clinical relevance.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: We evaluated FGFR1 expression in a large cohort of breast cancer by immunohistochemistry, correlated with the tumor clinic-pathologic features, biomarkers expression, and patient's survival.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: FGFR1 expression was associated mainly with luminal cancers, particularly luminal B subtype (23.5%; p < 0.001), and it also showed adverse prognostic impact on luminal A cancers.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: FGFR1 expression was associated with higher pN (p = 0.023), pT (p = 0.003) stages, lymphovascular invasion (p = 0.010), p-cadherin (p = 0.028), synaptophysin (p = 0.009) and SOX2 expression (p = 0.034) in luminal A cancers.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: FGFR1 expressing luminal A cancers showed a similar outcome as luminal B cancers.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: Multivariate Cox regression analysis demonstrated FGFR1 positive luminal A cancers to be an independently poor prognosticator for disease free survival in luminal cancers (hazard ratio = 3.341, p = 0.008).
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: Thus FGFR1 could be useful in identifying the aggressive cases amongst heterogeneous luminal A cancers.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: Given the relevance of FGFR pathway in treatment resistance in luminal cancers, FGFR1 could be an important tumor biomarker and adverse prognostic factor potentially exploitable in the clinical management of luminal cancers.
title: FGFR1 is an adverse outcome indicator for luminal A breast cancers.

text: BACKGROUND: Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) on chromosomes 1p and 19q has been associated with chemosensitivity and improved prognosis in patients with oligodendrogliomas.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: The DNA repair enzyme O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) may induce resistance to DNA-alkylating agents.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: Recent studies demonstrated that temozolomide (TMZ), an oral alkylating agent, has efficacy in the treatment of patients with progressive, low-grade oligodendroglioma (LGO).
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: However, to the authors' knowledge, limited data are available regarding the 1p/19q profile and its correlation with MGMT protein expression and response to treatment with DNA-alkylating drugs.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: METHODS: Adult patients with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings and/or clinical deterioration compatible with progressive LGO were eligible for the study if they were radiotherapy-naive.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: TMZ cycles were repeated every 28 days at a dose of 200 mg/m2 daily for 5 consecutive days.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: Clinical and MRI data were used to evaluate outcomes, and Kaplan-Meier estimates were used to assess the median time to tumor progression (TTP).
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: The 1p/19q status was analyzed from paired tumor-blood DNA samples using polymerase chain reaction-based microsatellite analysis.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: MGMT protein expression was estimated semiquantitatively by immunohistochemistry using paraffin embedded tumor sections.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: RESULTS: There were 28 patients who received treatment, and the median time from diagnosis to tumor progression was 33.5 months.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: The median number of TMZ cycles per patient was 12.5.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: Marked clinical improvements were recorded in 15 patients (54%), and objective responses were recorded in 17 patients (61%).
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: The median TTP was 31 months, and the progression-free survival rate was 70% at 24 months.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: Loss of chromosome 1p and low MGMT protein expression were associated with objective response (P < .003 and P < .04, respectively).
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: CONCLUSIONS: TMZ was active in patients with progressive LGO, and their response to treatment was associated with 1p deletion and low MGMT protein expression.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: The authors suggest the possible use of MGMT immunostaining as a surrogate marker for predicting tumor chemosensitivity.
title: Progressive low-grade oligodendrogliomas: response to temozolomide and correlation between genetic profile and O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase protein expression.

text: Wnt signaling is one of the key oncogenic pathways in multiple cancers, and targeting this pathway is an attractive therapeutic approach.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: However, therapeutic success has been limited because of the lack of therapeutic agents for targets in the Wnt pathway and the lack of a defined patient population that would be sensitive to a Wnt inhibitor.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: We developed a screen for small molecules that block Wnt secretion.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: This effort led to the discovery of LGK974, a potent and specific small-molecule Porcupine (PORCN) inhibitor.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: PORCN is a membrane-bound O-acyltransferase that is required for and dedicated to palmitoylation of Wnt ligands, a necessary step in the processing of Wnt ligand secretion.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: We show that LGK974 potently inhibits Wnt signaling in vitro and in vivo, including reduction of the Wnt-dependent LRP6 phosphorylation and the expression of Wnt target genes, such as AXIN2.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: LGK974 is potent and efficacious in multiple tumor models at well-tolerated doses in vivo, including murine and rat mechanistic breast cancer models driven by MMTV-Wnt1 and a human head and neck squamous cell carcinoma model (HN30).
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: We also show that head and neck cancer cell lines with loss-of-function mutations in the Notch signaling pathway have a high response rate to LGK974.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: Together, these findings provide both a strategy and tools for targeting Wnt-driven cancers through the inhibition of PORCN.
title: Targeting Wnt-driven cancer through the inhibition of Porcupine by LGK974.

text: BACKGROUND: Preclinical studies have shown that PTEN loss enhances sensitivity to mammalian target of Rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors because of facilitated PI3K (phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase)/Akt activation and consecutive stimulation of the mTOR pathway.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: In patients with advanced transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) treated with the mTOR inhibitor everolimus, PTEN loss was, however, associated with resistance to treatment.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: METHODS: Transitional cell carcinoma specimens, human bladder cancer cells and derived mouse xenografts were used to evaluate how the PTEN status influences the activity of mTOR inhibitors.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: RESULTS: Transitional cell carcinoma patients with a shorter progression-free survival under everolimus exhibited PTEN deficiency and increased Akt activation.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: Moreover, PTEN-deficient bladder cancer cells were less sensitive to rapamycin than cells expressing wild-type PTEN, and rapamycin strikingly induced Akt activation in the absence of functional PTEN.
