title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: Inhibition of Akt activation by the PI3K inhibitor wortmannin interrupted this rapamycin-induced feedback loop, thereby enhancing the antiproliferative effects of the mTOR inhibitor both in vitro and in vivo.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: CONCLUSION: Facilitation of Akt activation upon PTEN loss can have a more prominent role in driving the feedback loop in response to mTOR inhibition than in promoting the mTOR pathway.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: These data support the use of both PI3K and mTOR inhibitors to treat urothelial carcinoma, in particular in the absence of functional PTEN.
title: PTEN deficiency is associated with reduced sensitivity to mTOR inhibitor in human bladder cancer through the unhampered feedback loop driving PI3K/Akt activation.

text: PURPOSE: TP53 mutations have been described in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and have been associated with poor prognosis in retrospective studies.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: We aimed to address the frequency and prognostic value of TP53 abnormalities in patients with CLL in the context of a prospective randomized trial.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We analyzed 529 CLL samples from the LRF CLL4 (Leukaemia Research Foundation Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia 4) trial (chlorambucil v fludarabine with or without cyclophosphamide) at the time of random assignment for mutations in the TP53 gene.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: TP53 mutation status was correlated with response and survival data.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: RESULTS: Mutations of TP53 were found in 40 patients (7.6%), including 25 (76%) of 33 with 17p deletion and 13 (3%) of 487 without that deletion.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: There was no significant correlation between TP53 mutations and age, stage, IGHV gene mutations, CD38 and ZAP-70 expression, or any other chromosomal abnormality other than 17p deletion, in which concordance was high (96%).
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: TP53 mutations were significantly associated with poorer overall response rates (27% v 83%; P < .001) and shorter progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS; 5-year PFS: 5% v 17%; 5-year OS: 20% v 59%; P < .001 for both).
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: Multivariate analysis that included baseline clinical variables, treatment, and known adverse genetic factors confirmed that TP53 mutations have added prognostic value.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: CONCLUSION: TP53 mutations are associated with impaired response and shorter survival in patients with CLL.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: Analysis of TP53 mutations should be performed in patients with CLL who have progressive disease before starting first-line treatment, and those with mutations should be selected for novel experimental therapies.
title: Mutational status of the TP53 gene as a predictor of response and survival in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: results from the LRF CLL4 trial.

text: BACKGROUND: BRAF V600 mutations occur in various nonmelanoma cancers.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: We undertook a histology-independent phase 2 "basket" study of vemurafenib in BRAF V600 mutation-positive nonmelanoma cancers.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: METHODS: We enrolled patients in six prespecified cancer cohorts; patients with all other tumor types were enrolled in a seventh cohort.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: A total of 122 patients with BRAF V600 mutation-positive cancer were treated, including 27 patients with colorectal cancer who received vemurafenib and cetuximab.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: The primary end point was the response rate; secondary end points included progression-free and overall survival.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: RESULTS: In the cohort with non-small-cell lung cancer, the response rate was 42% (95% confidence interval [CI], 20 to 67) and median progression-free survival was 7.3 months (95% CI, 3.5 to 10.8).
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: In the cohort with Erdheim-Chester disease or Langerhans'-cell histiocytosis, the response rate was 43% (95% CI, 18 to 71); the median treatment duration was 5.9 months (range, 0.6 to 18.6), and no patients had disease progression during therapy.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: There were anecdotal responses among patients with pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma, anaplastic thyroid cancer, cholangiocarcinoma, salivary-duct cancer, ovarian cancer, and clear-cell sarcoma and among patients with colorectal cancer who received vemurafenib and cetuximab.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: Safety was similar to that in prior studies of vemurafenib for melanoma.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: BRAF V600 appears to be a targetable oncogene in some, but not all, nonmelanoma cancers.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: Preliminary vemurafenib activity was observed in non-small-cell lung cancer and in Erdheim-Chester disease and Langerhans'-cell histiocytosis.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: The histologic context is an important determinant of response in BRAF V600-mutated cancers.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: (Funded by F. Hoffmann-La Roche/Genentech; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01524978.
title: Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.
Vemurafenib in Multiple Nonmelanoma Cancers with BRAF V600 Mutations.

text: Inactivation of the switch/sucrose nonfermentable complex component SMARCB1 is extremely prevalent in pediatric malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRTs) or atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumors.
title: Durable tumor regression in genetically altered malignant rhabdoid tumors by inhibition of methyltransferase EZH2.

text: This alteration is hypothesized to confer oncogenic dependency on EZH2 in these cancers.
title: Durable tumor regression in genetically altered malignant rhabdoid tumors by inhibition of methyltransferase EZH2.

text: We report the discovery of a potent, selective, and orally bioavailable small-molecule inhibitor of EZH2 enzymatic activity, (N-((4,6-dimethyl-2-oxo-1,2-dihydropyridin-3-yl)methyl)-5-(ethyl(tetrahydro-2H-py ran-4-yl)amino)-4-methyl-4'-(morpholinomethyl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3-carboxamide).
title: Durable tumor regression in genetically altered malignant rhabdoid tumors by inhibition of methyltransferase EZH2.

text: The compound induces apoptosis and differentiation specifically in SMARCB1-deleted MRT cells.
title: Durable tumor regression in genetically altered malignant rhabdoid tumors by inhibition of methyltransferase EZH2.

text: Treatment of xenograft-bearing mice with (N-((4,6-dimethyl-2-oxo-1,2-dihydropyridin-3-yl)methyl)-5-(ethyl(tetrahydro-2H-py ran-4-yl)amino)-4-methyl-4'-(morpholinomethyl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-3-carboxamide) leads to dose-dependent regression of MRTs with correlative diminution of intratumoral trimethylation levels of lysine 27 on histone H3, and prevention of tumor regrowth after dosing cessation.
title: Durable tumor regression in genetically altered malignant rhabdoid tumors by inhibition of methyltransferase EZH2.

text: These data demonstrate the dependency of SMARCB1 mutant MRTs on EZH2 enzymatic activity and portend the utility of EZH2-targeted drugs for the treatment of these genetically defined cancers.
title: Durable tumor regression in genetically altered malignant rhabdoid tumors by inhibition of methyltransferase EZH2.

text: Although most patients with myelofibrosis (MF) derive benefit from ruxolitinib, some are refractory, have a suboptimal response, or quickly lose their response.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: To identify genes that may predict response to ruxolitinib, we performed targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) of a panel of 28 genes recurrently mutated in hematologic malignancies in a cohort of patients with MF who were treated with ruxolitinib in a phase 1/2 study.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: We also tested for CALR deletions by standard polymerase chain reaction methods.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: Ninety-eight percent of patients had a mutation in >/=1 gene.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: Seventy-nine (82.1%) patients had the JAK2(V617F) mutation, 9 (9.5%) had CALR mutations (7 type 1, 2 type 2), 3 (3.1%) had MPL mutations, and 4 (4.2%) were negative for all 3.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: ASXL1/JAK2 and TET2/JAK2 were the most frequently comutated genes.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: Mutations in NRAS, KRAS, PTPN11, GATA2, TP53, and RUNX1 were found in <5% of patients.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: Spleen response (>/=50% reduction in palpable spleen size) was inversely correlated with the number of mutations; patients with </=2 mutations had ninefold higher odds of a spleen response than those with >/=3 mutations (odds ratio = 9.37; 95% confidence interval, 1.86-47.2).
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: Patients with >/=3 mutations also had a shorter time to treatment discontinuation and shorter overall survival than those with fewer mutations.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: In multivariable analysis, only number of mutations and spleen response remained associated with time to treatment discontinuation.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: Patients with >/=3 mutations had the worst outcomes, suggesting that multigene profiling may be useful for therapeutic planning for MF.
title: Correlation of mutation profile and response in patients with myelofibrosis treated with ruxolitinib.

text: A hallmark of cancer is the deregulation of cell-cycle machinery, ultimately facilitating aberrant proliferation that fuels tumorigenesis and disease progression.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: Particularly, in breast cancers, cyclin D1 has a crucial role in the development of disease.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: Recently, a highly specific inhibitor of CDK4/6 activity (PD-0332991) has been developed that may have efficacy in the treatment of breast cancer.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: To interrogate the utility of PD-0332991 in treating breast cancers, therapeutic response was evaluated on a panel of breast cancer cell lines.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: These analyses showed that the chronic loss of Rb is specifically associated with evolution to a CDK4/6-independent state and, ultimately, resistance to PD-0332991.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: However, to interrogate the functional consequence of Rb directly, knockdown experiments were performed in models that represent immortalized mammary epithelia and multiple subtypes of breast cancer.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: These studies showed a highly specific role for Rb in mediating the response to CDK4/6 inhibition that was dependent on transcriptional repression manifest through E2F, and the ability to attenuate CDK2 activity.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: Acquired resistance to PD-03322991 was specifically associated with attenuation of CDK2 inhibitors, indicating that redundancy in CDK functions represents a determinant of therapeutic failure.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: Despite these caveats, in specific models, PD-0332991 was a particularly effective therapy, which induced Rb-dependent cytostasis.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: Combined, these findings indicate the critical importance of fully understanding cell-cycle regulatory pathways in directing the utilization of CDK inhibitors in the clinic.
title: Therapeutic CDK4/6 inhibition in breast cancer: key mechanisms of response and failure.

text: BACKGROUND/AIMS: The GNAS1 locus encodes the Galphas protein, which stimulates the formation of cyclo-adenosinemonophosphate (cAMP).
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: The cAMP pathway mediates pleiotropic effects, including the regulation of apoptosis and proliferation.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: We have recently shown that TT genotypes of the single-nucleotide polymorphism T393C in the gene GNAS1 predict the clinical outcome of patients with various carcinomas.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: METHODS: Eighty-seven patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) were retrospectively genotyped to elucidate a potential association between T393C genotypes and clinical outcome.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: ICCs of patients with homozygous TT genotypes revealed a higher proliferation rate and a lower apoptotic rate.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Homozygous TT patients were at highest risk for cancer-related deaths (hazard ratio = 2.74; 95% confidence interval = 1.03-7.28) compared with C-allele carriers.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Kaplan-Meier curves for disease-specific overall and local recurrence-free survival in a subgroup with R(0)-resected ICC showed a significant association of T393 homozygosity with outcome, which was confirmed in multivariate Cox regression analysis.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: GNAS1 T393C is a novel independent host factor for disease progression in patients with ICC.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Our finding that TT homozygosity (and not CC homozygosity) was associated with unfavorable clinical outcome points to the complex and differing functional effects induced by GNAS1 T393C polymorphism in various human carcinomas.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with clinical course in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: The tumour-suppressor gene TP53 is frequently mutated in breast tumours, and the majority of the mutations are clustered within the core domain, the region involved in DNA binding.
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: We searched for alterations in this central domain of the TP53gene in 222 human breast cancer specimens using polymerase chain reaction-single-strand conformation analysis (PCR-SSCA) followed by sequencing.
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: TP53 gene mutations were observed in 66 tumours (31%), including three tumours that contain two mutations.
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: Fifty-four (78%) of these mutations were missense point mutations, one was a nonsense mutation and four were deletions and/or insertions causing disruption of the protein reading frame, whereas four mutations were either silent or a polymorphism (at codon 213; n = 6).
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: Interestingly, the majority of missense mutations were observed at codon 248.
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: The outcome has been related with patient and tumour characteristics, and with prognosis in 177 patients who were eligible for analysis of both relapse-free and overall survival (median survival for patients alive was 115 months).
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: There was no significant association between the frequency of TP53 mutations and menopausal or nodal status, or tumour size.
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: In a Cox univariate analysis, TP53 gene mutation was significantly associated with poor relapse-free survival (RFS: P = 0.02) but not with overall survival (OS: P = 0.07).
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: In a Cox multivariate analysis, including classical prognostic factors, TP53 gene mutation independently predicted poor RFS and OS (RHR = 1.8 and 1.6 respectively).
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: Unexpectedly, the median relapse-free survival of patients with a polymorphism at codon 213 or with a silent mutation was shorter (median 11 months) than the median relapse-free survival of patients with or without a TP53 gene mutation (median 34 or 48 months respectively).
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: In an exploratory subset analysis, mutations in codons that directly contact DNA were related with the poorest relapse-free (P < 0.05) and overall survival (P < 0.02).
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: These data imply that in the analysis of the prognostic value of TP53, the type of mutation and its biological function should be considered.
title: Mutations in residues of TP53 that directly contact DNA predict poor outcome in human primary breast cancer.

text: Although standard chemotherapies are commonly used to treat most types of solid tumors, such treatment often results in inadequate response to, or relapse after, therapy.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: This is particularly relevant for lung cancer because most patients are diagnosed with advanced-stage disease and are treated with frontline chemotherapy.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: By studying the residual tumor cells that remain after chemotherapy in several in vivo non-small cell lung cancer models, we found that these cells have increased levels of human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER) signaling due, in part, to the enrichment of a preexisting NRG1(HI) subpopulation.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Neuregulin 1 (NRG1) signaling in these models can be mediated by either the HER3 or HER4 receptor, resulting in the differential activation of downstream effectors.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Inhibition of NRG1 signaling inhibits primary tumor growth and enhances the magnitude and duration of the response to chemotherapy.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Moreover, we show that inhibition of ligand-mediated Her4 signaling impedes disease relapse in cases where NRG1 inhibition is insufficient.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: These findings demonstrate that ligand-dependent Her4 signaling plays an important role in disease relapse.
title: Blocking NRG1 and other ligand-mediated Her4 signaling enhances the magnitude and duration of the chemotherapeutic response of non-small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-activating mutation predicts excellent response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: However, lung cancer patients are often with unknown EGFR mutation status because there are little tumor specimen to determine.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: TKIs induce tumor cell apoptosis which associates with several apoptosis-related genes.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: To explore the association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of TKI in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NCSLC) with unknown EGFR mutation status.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: METHODS: A total of 116 patients were recruited for the study from Zhejiang Cancer Hospital, all of whom were treated with gefitinib or erlotinib after failure to prior chemotherapy.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: We detected the genotype of peripheral blood lymphocytes of patients with GNAS1 T393C polymorphism through polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: Statistical analysis was performed by SPSS version 18.0.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: RESULTS: The overall response rate was 29.3%.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: No significant associations were found among GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and the objective response rate.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: The disease control rate of patients with GNAS1 T393C CC genotype was lower than that of patients with variant genotype (TT or CT) (46.2% vs 73.8%, P=0.039).
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: Univariate analysis identified gender, smoking history, histology and GNAS1 T393C polymorphism as predictive marker of PFS (P=0.04, P<0.001, P<0.001 and P=0.005).
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: Multivariate analysis of factors, including smoking history, performance status score, histology, GNAS1 T393C polymorphism demonstrated that GNAS1 T393C polymorphism was correlated independently with PFS (P=0.007).
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our data suggest the role of GNAS1 T393C CC genotype as a poor predictive marker both of DCR and PFS in advanced NSCLC patients treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
title: [Association between GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and therapeutic efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitor in pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer with unknown EGFR mutation status].

text: PURPOSE: Trastuzumab shows clinical activity in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER-2)-positive early and advanced breast cancer.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: In the German Breast Group 26/Breast International Group 03-05 trial, we investigated if trastuzumab treatment should be continued beyond progression.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: METHODS: Patients with HER-2-positive breast cancer that progresses during treatment with trastuzumab were randomly assigned to receive capecitabine (2,500 mg/m(2) body-surface area on days 1 through 14 [1,250 mg/m(2) semi-daily]) alone or with continuation of trastuzumab (6 mg/kg body weight) in 3-week cycles.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: The primary end point was time to progression.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: RESULTS: We randomly assigned 78 patients to capecitabine and 78 patients to capecitabine plus trastuzumab.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: Sixty-five events and 38 deaths in the capecitabine group and 62 events and 33 deaths in the capecitabine-plus-trastuzumab group occurred during 15.6 months of follow-up.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: Median times to progression were 5.6 months in the capecitabine group and 8.2 months in the capecitabine-plus-trastuzumab group with an unadjusted hazard ratio of 0.69 (95% CI, 0.48 to 0.97; two-sided log-rank P = .0338).
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: Overall survival rates were 20.4 months (95% CI, 17.8 to 24.7) in the capecitabine group and 25.5 months (95% CI, 19.0 to 30.7) in the capecitabine-plus-trastuzumab group (P = .257).
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: Overall response rates were 27.0% with capecitabine and 48.1% with capecitabine plus trastuzumab (odds ratio, 2.50; P = .0115).
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: Continuation of trastuzumab beyond progression was not associated with increased toxicity.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: CONCLUSION: Continuation of trastuzumab plus capecitabine showed a significant improvement in overall response and time to progression compared with capecitabine alone in women with HER-2-positive breast cancer who experienced progression during trastuzumab treatment.
title: Trastuzumab beyond progression in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer: a german breast group 26/breast international group 03-05 study.

text: BRCA1-associated RING domain protein 1 (BARD1) stabilizes BRCA1 protein by forming a heterodimeric RING-RING complex, and impacts function of BRCA1, including homologous recombination (HR) repair.
title: Expression of an Oncogenic BARD1 Splice Variant Impairs Homologous Recombination and Predicts Response to PARP-1 Inhibitor Therapy in Colon Cancer.

text: Although colon cancer cells usually express wild type BRCA1, presence of an oncogenic BARD1 splice variant (SV) in select cancers may render BRCA1 dysfunctional and allow cells to become sensitive to HR targeting therapies.
title: Expression of an Oncogenic BARD1 Splice Variant Impairs Homologous Recombination and Predicts Response to PARP-1 Inhibitor Therapy in Colon Cancer.

text: We previously reported association of loss of full-length (FL) BARD1 with poor prognosis in colon cancer as well as expression of various BARD1 SVs with unknown function.
title: Expression of an Oncogenic BARD1 Splice Variant Impairs Homologous Recombination and Predicts Response to PARP-1 Inhibitor Therapy in Colon Cancer.

text: Here we show that loss of BARD1 function through the expression of a BARD1 SV, BARD1beta, results in a more malignant phenotype with decreased RAD51 foci formation, reduced BRCA1 E3 ubiquitin ligase activity, and decreased nuclear BRCA1 protein localization.
title: Expression of an Oncogenic BARD1 Splice Variant Impairs Homologous Recombination and Predicts Response to PARP-1 Inhibitor Therapy in Colon Cancer.

text: BARD1beta sensitizes colon cancer cells to poly ADP ribose polymerase 1 (PARP-1) inhibition even in a FL BRCA1 background.
title: Expression of an Oncogenic BARD1 Splice Variant Impairs Homologous Recombination and Predicts Response to PARP-1 Inhibitor Therapy in Colon Cancer.

text: These results suggest that expression of BARD1beta may serve as a future biomarker to assess suitability of colon cancers for HR targeting with PARP-1 inhibitors in treatment of advanced colon cancer.
title: Expression of an Oncogenic BARD1 Splice Variant Impairs Homologous Recombination and Predicts Response to PARP-1 Inhibitor Therapy in Colon Cancer.

text: Mutations 1 295 228 C>T and 1 295 250 C>T (termed C228T and C250T respectively), corresponding to -124 C>T and -146 C>T from the translation start site in the promoter of the telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) gene, have recently been reported in human cancers, but not in thyroid cancers yet.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: We explored these mutations in thyroid cancers by genomic sequencing of a large number of primary tumor samples.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: We found the C228T mutation in 0 of 85 (0.0%) benign thyroid tumors, 30 of 257 (11.7%) papillary thyroid cancers (PTC), 9 of 79 (11.4%) follicular thyroid cancers (FTC), 3 of 8 (37.5%) poorly differentiated thyroid cancers (PDTC), 23 of 54 (42.6%) anaplastic thyroid cancers (ATC), and 8 of 12 (66.7%) thyroid cancer cell lines.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: The C250T mutation was uncommon, but mutually exclusive with the C228T mutation, and the two mutations were collectively found in 11 of 79 (13.9%) FTC, 25 of 54 (46.3%) ATC, and 11 of 12 (91.7%) thyroid cancer cell lines.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: Among PTC variants, the C228T mutation was found in 4 of 13 (30.8%) tall-cell PTC (TCPTC), 23 of 187 (12.3%) conventional PTC, and 2 of 56 (3.6%) follicular variant PTC samples.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: No TERT mutation was found in 16 medullary thyroid cancer samples.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: The C228T mutation was associated with the BRAF V600E mutation in PTC, being present in 19 of 104 (18.3%) BRAF mutation-positive PTC vs 11 of 153 (7.2%) the BRAF mutation-negative PTC samples (P=0.0094).
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: Conversely, BRAF mutation was found in 19 of 30 (63.3%) C228T mutation-positive PTC vs 85 of 227 (37.4%) C228T mutation-negative PTC samples (P=0.0094).
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: We thus for the first time, to our knowledge, demonstrate TERT promoter mutations in thyroid cancers, that are particularly prevalent in the aggressive thyroid cancers TCPTC, PDTC, ATC and BRAF mutation-positive PTC, revealing a novel genetic background for thyroid cancers.
title: Highly prevalent TERT promoter mutations in aggressive thyroid cancers.

text: Ovarian cancer is a leading cause of death from gynecologic malignancies.
title: An activated ErbB3/NRG1 autocrine loop supports in vivo proliferation in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Treatment for advanced-stage disease remains limited and, to date, targeted therapies have been incompletely explored.
title: An activated ErbB3/NRG1 autocrine loop supports in vivo proliferation in ovarian cancer cells.

text: By systematically suppressing each human tyrosine kinase in ovarian cancer cell lines by RNAi, we found that an autocrine signal-transducing loop involving NRG1 and activated ErbB3 operates in a subset of primary ovarian cancers and ovarian cancer cell lines.
title: An activated ErbB3/NRG1 autocrine loop supports in vivo proliferation in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Perturbation of this circuit with ErbB3-directed RNAi decreased cell growth in three-dimensional culture and resulted in decreased disease progression and prolonged survival in a xenograft mouse model of ovarian cancer.
title: An activated ErbB3/NRG1 autocrine loop supports in vivo proliferation in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Furthermore, a monoclonal ErbB3-directed antibody (MM-121) also significantly inhibited tumor growth in vivo.
title: An activated ErbB3/NRG1 autocrine loop supports in vivo proliferation in ovarian cancer cells.

text: These findings identify ErbB3 as a potential therapeutic target in ovarian cancer.
title: An activated ErbB3/NRG1 autocrine loop supports in vivo proliferation in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Two promoter mutations, chr5:1 295 228C>T and chr5:1 295 250C>T, in the gene for telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) have been recently identified in thyroid cancers and shown to be important in thyroid tumor pathogenesis.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: The diagnostic and prognostic potentials of testing for these mutations on thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) have not been investigated.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: Herein, we examined the two TERT promoter mutations along with the BRAF V600E mutation by direct DNA sequencing on 308 FNAB specimens preoperatively obtained from thyroid nodules with postoperatively confirmed pathological diagnoses.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: We found TERT promoter mutations in 0.0% (0/179) of benign thyroid nodules and 7.0% (9/129) of thyroid nodules of differentiated thyroid cancer, representing a 100% diagnostic specificity and 7.0% sensitivity, with the latter rising to 38.0% (49/129) when combined with BRAF V600E testing.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: Several TERT-promoter-mutation-positive thyroid nodules were cytologically indeterminate on FNAB.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: Approximately 80% of the TERT promoter mutation-positive thyroid nodules were thyroid cancers with aggressive clinicopathological behaviors, such as extrathyroidal invasion, lymph node metastases, distant metastases, disease recurrence or patient death.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: Thus, a positive TERT promoter mutation test not only definitively diagnoses a thyroid nodule as cancerous but also preoperatively identifies a cancer with aggressive potential.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: This is the first study, to our knowledge, of TERT promoter mutations on thyroid FNAB, demonstrating the value of this novel molecular testing in the diagnosis of thyroid nodules and preoperative risk stratification of thyroid cancer.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: Thus, testing of TERT promoter mutations on FNAB will enhance and improve the current molecular-based approaches to the management of thyroid nodules and thyroid cancer.
title: Diagnostic and prognostic TERT promoter mutations in thyroid fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

text: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (CCRCC) is the most common renal cell carcinoma.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: It has a relatively unfavorable prognosis compared to other common renal cell carcinomas.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Recently, comprehensive molecular studies in CCRCC revealed important genetic alterations, including changes in the VHL, PBRM1, and ARID1A genes.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The expression of ARID1A protein is associated with tumor progression and prognosis in many cancers.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: This study aimed to evaluate the nuclear expression of ARID1A in CCRCC and to assess its expression with the clinical prognosis.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The nuclear expression of ARID1A was evaluated in 290 cases of CCRCC by immunohistochemistry.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: To determine the clinicopathological association with ARID1A, each of the cases was divided into 2 groups, low- and high-expression groups, according to the average proportion of nuclear staining.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Decreased ARID1A expression was associated with the higher nuclear grade and higher pTNM stage (P < .001 and P = .013, respectively).
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The ARID1A low-expression group revealed significantly shorter cancer-specific and progression-free survival times (P = .001 and P < .001, respectively).
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Furthermore, Cox regression analysis showed that ARID1A expression was an independent prognostic factor for progression-free survival (P = .009).
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: These results suggest that nuclear expression of ARID1A may serve as a new prognostic marker in CCRCC patients.
title: Decreased ARID1A expression correlates with poor prognosis of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Bevacizumab improves survival in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) under chemotherapy, but few predictive markers have been identified.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: To investigate chemosensitive single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of mCRC, we performed exome sequencing and RNA sequencing in 19 patients.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: A clinical association analysis was performed with the other 116 patients who had received chemotherapy to bevacizumab regimens.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: In vivo biodistribution studies and [(18)F]FDG-PET imaging were performed on mice bearing human colorectal cancer (HCT116 and SW480) xenografts after injection of bevacizumab with 5-FU, leucovorin, and irinotecan (FOLFIRI).
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: PPP1R15A rs557806 showed the most significant association with FRB-driven tumor IR in exome sequencing and the highest correlation (r = 0.74) with drug responses in RNA sequencing.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Patients homozygous for the reference alleles (GG) of PPP1R15A rs557806 exhibited greater disease control rate and a tendency toward greater objective response rate (ORR) than those with homozygous or heterozygous substitution alleles (GC and CC; P = 0.027 and 0.073, respectively).
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: In xenografted mice, HCT116 clones transfected with the G allele at PPP1R15A rs557806 were more sensitive to bevacizumab regimens than those with the C allele.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Tumor volume of xenografts with the G allele was significantly lower than that of xenografts with the C allele (P = 0.004, day 13).
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: [(18)F]FDG uptake decreased to 75 % in HCT116 xenograft-bearing mice with the G allele, whereas [(18)F]FDG uptake was 42 % in mice xenografts with the C allele (P = 0.032).
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: ANXA11 rs1049550, a predictive biomarker of SNP described in our previous study, was validated using the xenograft model.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Tumor volume and [(18)F]FDG uptake analyses showed that tumors in the SW480 xenografts expressing the substitution allele (T) at ANXA11 rs1049550 were more susceptible to FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab-induced suppression than those expressing the reference allele (C) (P = 0.001 and 0.026, respectively).
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: ANXA11 rs1049550 and PPP1R15A rs557806 may improve the identification of mCRC patients sensitive to bevacizumab regimens, and further validation is required in large cohorts.
title: Feasibility of novel PPP1R15A and proposed ANXA11 single nucleotide polymorphisms as predictive markers for bevacizumab regimen in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: FLT3 is constitutively activated by internal tandem duplications (ITDs) in the juxtamembrane domain or by activation loop mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: We tested the sensitivity of 8 activation loop mutations to the small molecule FLT3 inhibitor, MLN518.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: Each FLT3 activation loop mutant, including D835Y, D835A, D835E, D835H, D835N, D835V, D835del, and I836del, transformed Ba/F3 cells to factor-independent proliferation and had constitutive tyrosine kinase activation, as assessed by FLT3 autophosphorylation and activation of downstream effectors, including STAT5 and ERK.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: MLN518 inhibited FLT3 autophosphorylation and phosphorylation of STAT5 and ERK in FLT3-ITD-transformed Ba/F3 cells with an IC(50) (50% inhibition of cell viability) of approximately 500 nM.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: However, there was a broad spectrum of sensitivity among the 8 activation loop mutants, with IC(50) ranging from approximately 500 nM to more than 10 microM for the inhibition of phosphorylation of FLT3, STAT5, and ERK.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: The relative sensitivity of the mutants to MLN518 in biochemical assays correlated with the cellular IC(50) for cytokine-independent proliferation of FLT3-transformed Ba/F3 cells in the presence of MLN518.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: Thus, certain activation loop mutations in FLT3 simultaneously confer resistance to small molecule inhibitors.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: These findings have implications for the evaluation of responses in clinical trials with FLT3 inhibitors and provide a strategy to screen for compounds that can overcome resistance.
title: Variable sensitivity of FLT3 activation loop mutations to the small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor MLN518.

text: Current pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy does not produce a satisfactory therapeutic response in advanced lung cancer patients.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The aim of this study was to determine whether the administration of gefitinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI), intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum could improve the efficacy in chemotherapy-naive patients with advanced non-squamous NSCLC without subsequent gefitinib maintenance therapy.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Treatment-naive patients with stage IIIB or IV NSCLC were randomly assigned to receive pemetrexed (500 mg/m (2) d1) and either cisplatin (75 mg/m (2) d1) or carboplatin (AUC = 5 d1) plus gefitinib (250 mg/d on days 3 to 16 of a 3-week cycle) (PC-G) or pemetrexed-platinum (PC) alone.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Randomization was stratified according to the tobacco smoking status and EGFR mutational status of the patients.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The primary endpoint was the non-progression rate (NPR) at 12 weeks.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Secondary endpoints included progression-free survival (PFS), overall response rate (ORR), overall survival (OS), and biosafety.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The NPR at 12 weeks was 84.5% for the PC-G treatment arm and 83.1% for the PC treatment arm (P = 0.87).
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Median PFS was 7.9 months for the PC-G arm and 7.0 months for the PC arm (P = 0.57).
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The ORR was 50.0% for the PC-G arm and 47.4% for the PC arm (P = 0.78).
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Median survival was 25.4 mo for the PC-G arm and 20.8 mo for the PC arm (P = 0.54).
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The incidence of adverse events was similar between the two treatment arms, except for a higher incidence of skin rash with PC-G. Predefined subgroup analyses demonstrated that PC-G significantly increased the PFS compared with the PC regimen in patients with EGFR mutations (P = 0.017).
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Although gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy did not improve the NPR at 12 weeks compared with chemotherapy, an improvement in the PFS for the intercalated treatment arm was seen in the subgroup of patients with EGFR mutations.
title: A phase II randomized trial evaluating gefitinib intercalated with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy or pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone in unselected patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to investigate the patterns of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) overexpression, EGFR gene amplification, and the presence of activating mutations in the tyrosine kinase domain of this gene in squamous cell carcinomas and adenocarcinomas/adenosquamous carcinomas of the uterine cervix.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: METHODS: The EGFR expression, amplification, and mutation in cervical carcinomas were assessed by immunohistochemistry, fluorescence in situ hybridisation, and PCR-SSCP, respectively, and correlated with clinical data collected by a retrospective chart review.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: A functional assessment was performed by inactivating EGFR in cervical cancer cells with the potent inhibitor AG1478.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: RESULTS: Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that 6 out of 59 (10.2%) cervical squamous cell carcinomas showed significant amplification of the EGFR locus, whereas none of the 52 adeno/adenosquamous cell carcinomas had detectable EGFR amplification (P<0.05).
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: The EGFR amplification significantly correlated with shorter overall survival (P=0.001) in cervical squamous cell carcinomas.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: Multivariate analysis showed that EGFR gene amplification was an independent prognostic factor for overall survival (P=0.011).
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: None of the squamous cell carcinomas (0%: 0 out of 32) had detectable oncogenic mutations in EGFR exons 18 through 21.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: The frequencies of KRAS and BRAF mutations were very low in both squamous and adeno/adenosquamous cell carcinomas.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: Sensitivity of cervical cancer cells to AG1478 depended on the presence of EGFR overexpression.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: AG1478-induced EGFR inactivation in cell lines with EGFR overexpression significantly suppressed tumour development and progression in a mouse xenograft model.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: CONCLUSION: Our data suggest that EGFR signalling is important in a subset of cervical squamous cell carcinomas and that anti-EGFR therapy may benefit patients who carry the 7p11.2 amplicon in their tumours.
title: EGFR gene amplification is related to adverse clinical outcomes in cervical squamous cell carcinoma, making the EGFR pathway a novel therapeutic target.

text: Huntingtin-interacting protein 1 (HIP1) has recently been identified as a new fusion partner fused to anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Identification of a novel HIP1-ALK fusion variant in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) and discovery of ALK I1171 (I1171N/S) mutations in two ALK-rearranged NSCLC patients with resistance to Alectinib.

text: To date, two variants of HIP1-ALK (H21; A20) and (H28; A20) have been identified in NSCLC.
title: Identification of a novel HIP1-ALK fusion variant in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) and discovery of ALK I1171 (I1171N/S) mutations in two ALK-rearranged NSCLC patients with resistance to Alectinib.

text: However, the response of patients with NSCLC harboring HIP1-ALK to ALK inhibitors and potential resistance mechanisms to such remain unknown.
title: Identification of a novel HIP1-ALK fusion variant in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) and discovery of ALK I1171 (I1171N/S) mutations in two ALK-rearranged NSCLC patients with resistance to Alectinib.

text: Here, we report a patient with NSCLC harboring a novel HIP1-ALK fusion variant (H30; A20).
title: Identification of a novel HIP1-ALK fusion variant in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) and discovery of ALK I1171 (I1171N/S) mutations in two ALK-rearranged NSCLC patients with resistance to Alectinib.

text: This patient and another patient with EML4-ALK variant 3a/b initially responded sequentially to crizotinib and then alectinib, a next-generation ALK inhibitor, but developed acquired resistance to alectinib with the presence of a mutation in amino acid residue 1171 (I1171N and I1171S respectively) located in the hydrophobic regulatory spine (R-spine) of the ALK kinase in both the cases as identified by a comprehensive next-generation sequencing-based assay performed on biopsies of new liver metastases that developed during alectinib treatment.
title: Identification of a novel HIP1-ALK fusion variant in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) and discovery of ALK I1171 (I1171N/S) mutations in two ALK-rearranged NSCLC patients with resistance to Alectinib.

text: Treatment of BRAF(V600E) mutant melanoma by small molecule drugs that target the BRAF or MEK kinases can be effective, but resistance develops invariably.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: In contrast, colon cancers that harbour the same BRAF(V600E) mutation are intrinsically resistant to BRAF inhibitors, due to feedback activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: Here we show that 6 out of 16 melanoma tumours analysed acquired EGFR expression after the development of resistance to BRAF or MEK inhibitors.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: Using a chromatin-regulator-focused short hairpin RNA (shRNA) library, we find that suppression of sex determining region Y-box 10 (SOX10) in melanoma causes activation of TGF-beta signalling, thus leading to upregulation of EGFR and platelet-derived growth factor receptor-beta (PDGFRB), which confer resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: Expression of EGFR in melanoma or treatment with TGF-beta results in a slow-growth phenotype with cells displaying hallmarks of oncogene-induced senescence.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: However, EGFR expression or exposure to TGF-beta becomes beneficial for proliferation in the presence of BRAF or MEK inhibitors.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: In a heterogeneous population of melanoma cells having varying levels of SOX10 suppression, cells with low SOX10 and consequently high EGFR expression are rapidly enriched in the presence of drug, but this is reversed when the drug treatment is discontinued.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: We find evidence for SOX10 loss and/or activation of TGF-beta signalling in 4 of the 6 EGFR-positive drug-resistant melanoma patient samples.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: Our findings provide a rationale for why some BRAF or MEK inhibitor-resistant melanoma patients may regain sensitivity to these drugs after a 'drug holiday' and identify patients with EGFR-positive melanoma as a group that may benefit from re-treatment after a drug holiday.
title: Reversible and adaptive resistance to BRAF(V600E) inhibition in melanoma.

text: BACKGROUND: The antibody-drug conjugate trastuzumab emtansine is indicated for the treatment of patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer previously treated with trastuzumab and a taxane.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Approval of this drug was based on progression-free survival and interim overall survival data from the phase 3 EMILIA study.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: In this report, we present a descriptive analysis of the final overall survival data from that trial.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: METHODS: EMILIA was a randomised, international, open-label, phase 3 study of men and women aged 18 years or older with HER2-positive unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer previously treated with trastuzumab and a taxane.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Enrolled patients were randomly assigned (1:1) via a hierarchical, dynamic randomisation scheme and an interactive voice response system to trastuzumab emtansine (3.6 mg/kg intravenously every 3 weeks) or control (capecitabine 1000 mg/m(2) self-administered orally twice daily on days 1-14 on each 21-day cycle, plus lapatinib 1250 mg orally once daily on days 1-21).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Randomisation was stratified by world region (USA vs western Europe vs or other), number of previous chemotherapy regimens for unresectable, locally advanced, or metastatic disease (0 or 1 vs >1), and disease involvement (visceral vs non-visceral).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: The coprimary efficacy endpoints were progression-free survival (per independent review committee assessment) and overall survival.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Efficacy was analysed in the intention-to-treat population; safety was analysed in all patients who received at least one dose of study treatment, with patients analysed according to the treatment actually received.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: On May 30, 2012, the study protocol was amended to allow crossover from control to trastuzumab emtansine after the second interim overall survival analysis crossed the prespecified overall survival efficacy boundary.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00829166.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Feb 23, 2009, and Oct 13, 2011, 991 eligible patients were enrolled and randomly assigned to either trastuzumab emtansine (n=495) or capecitabine and lapatinib (control; n=496).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: In this final descriptive analysis, median overall survival was longer with trastuzumab emtansine than with control (29.9 months [95% CI 26.3-34.1] vs 25.9 months [95% CI 22.7-28.3]; hazard ratio 0.75 [95% CI 0.64-0.88]).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: 136 (27%) of 496 patients crossed over from control to trastuzumab emtansine after the second interim overall survival analysis (median follow-up duration 24.1 months [IQR 19.5-26.1]).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Of those patients originally randomly assigned to trastuzumab emtansine, 254 (51%) of 495 received capecitabine and 241 [49%] of 495 received lapatinib (separately or in combination) after study drug discontinuation.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: In the safety population (488 patients treated with capecitabine plus lapatinib, 490 patients treated with trastuzumab emtansine), fewer grade 3 or worse adverse events occurred with trastuzumab emtansine (233 [48%] of 490) than with capecitabine plus lapatinib control treatment (291 [60%] of 488).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: In the control group, the most frequently reported grade 3 or worse adverse events were diarrhoea (103 [21%] of 488 patients) followed by palmar-plantar erythrodysaesthesia syndrome (87 [18%]), and vomiting (24 [5%]).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: The safety profile of trastuzumab emtansine was similar to that reported previously; the most frequently reported grade 3 or worse adverse events in the trastuzumab emtansine group were thrombocytopenia (70 [14%] of 490), increased aspartate aminotransferase levels (22 [5%]), and anaemia (19 [4%]).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Nine patients died from adverse events; five of these deaths were judged to be related to treatment (two in the control group [coronary artery disease and multiorgan failure] and three in the trastuzumab emtansine group [metabolic encephalopathy, neutropenic sepsis, and acute myeloid leukaemia]).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: This descriptive analysis of final overall survival in the EMILIA trial shows that trastuzumab emtansine improved overall survival in patients with previously treated HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer even in the presence of crossover treatment.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: The safety profile was similar to that reported in previous analyses, reaffirming trastuzumab emtansine as an efficacious and tolerable treatment in this patient population.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: FUNDING: F Hoffmann-La Roche/Genentech.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus capecitabine plus lapatinib in patients with previously treated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (EMILIA): a descriptive analysis of final overall survival results from a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: PURPOSE: Copy number alterations have been shown to be involved in melanoma pathogenesis.
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: The randomized phase III clinical trial E2603: carboplatin, paclitaxel, +/- sorafenib (CP vs. CPS) offers a large collection of tumor samples to evaluate association of somatic mutations, genomic alterations, and clinical outcomes, prior to current FDA-approved therapies.
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Copy number and mutational analysis on 119 pretreatment samples was performed.
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: RESULTS: CPS therapy was associated with improved progression-free survival (PFS) compared with CP in patients with tumors with RAF1 (cRAF) gene copy gains (HR, 0.372; P = 0.025) or CCND1 gene copy gains (HR, 0.45; P = 0.035).
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: CPS therapy was associated with improved overall survival (OS) compared with CP in patients with tumors with KRAS gene copy gains (HR, 0.25; P = 0.035).
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: BRAF gene copy gain and MET amplification were more common in samples with V600K versus V600E mutations (P < 0.001), which was validated in The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) dataset.
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We observed improved treatment response with CPS in patients with melanoma whose tumors have RAF1 (cRAF), KRAS, or CCND1 amplification, all of which can be attributed to sorafenib targeting CRAF.
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: These genomic alterations should be incorporated in future studies for evaluation as biomarkers.
title: Copy Number Changes Are Associated with Response to Treatment with Carboplatin, Paclitaxel, and Sorafenib in Melanoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Cetuximab, an IgG1 chimeric monoclonal antibody against epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), has activity against colorectal cancers that express EGFR.
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: From December 2003 to August 2005, 572 patients who had colorectal cancer expressing immunohistochemically detectable EGFR and who had been previously treated with a fluoropyrimidine, irinotecan, and oxaliplatin or had contraindications to treatment with these drugs underwent randomization to an initial dose of 400 mg of cetuximab per square meter of body-surface area followed by a weekly infusion of 250 mg per square meter plus best supportive care (287 patients) or best supportive care alone (285 patients).
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: The primary end point was overall survival.
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: In comparison with best supportive care alone, cetuximab treatment was associated with a significant improvement in overall survival (hazard ratio for death, 0.77; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.64 to 0.92; P=0.005) and in progression-free survival (hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.57 to 0.80; P<0.001).
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: These benefits were robust after adjustment in a multivariable Cox proportional-hazards model.
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: The median overall survival was 6.1 months in the cetuximab group and 4.6 months in the group assigned to supportive care alone.
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: Partial responses occurred in 23 patients (8.0%) in the cetuximab group but in none in the group assigned to supportive care alone (P<0.001); the disease was stable in an additional 31.4% of patients assigned to cetuximab and in 10.9% of patients assigned to supportive care alone (P<0.001).
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: Quality of life was better preserved in the cetuximab group, with less deterioration in physical function and global health status scores (both P<0.05).
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: Cetuximab treatment was associated with a characteristic rash; a rash of grade 2 or higher was strongly associated with improved survival (hazard ratio for death, 0.33; 95% CI, 0.22 to 0.50; P<0.001).
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: The incidence of any adverse event of grade 3 or higher was 78.5% in the cetuximab group and 59.1% in the group assigned to supportive care alone (P<0.001).
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Cetuximab improves overall survival and progression-free survival and preserves quality-of-life measures in patients with colorectal cancer in whom other treatments have failed.
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00079066 [ClinicalTrials.gov].
title: Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.
Cetuximab for the treatment of colorectal cancer.

text: The PI3K-AKT pathway is activated in a variety of human cancers, resulting in disturbance of cell growth, proliferation and survival.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Among the factors affecting the pathway, the K-Ras mutation and PIK3CA mutation are the most common oncogenic alterations in colorectal cancer.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: We hypothesized that these two mutations are important in activation of the PI3K pathway and colorectal carcinogenesis.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: In this study, we aimed to examine the influence of PIK3CA mutation and K-Ras mutation on AKT activation, and to clarify whether PIK3CA mutation, K-Ras mutation and p-AKT expression may be used as parameters for predicting prognosis in colorectal cancer.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.
