text: Tissue samples from 158 colorectal cancer patients who underwent surgical resection were examined.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: The sequences of exon 1 of K-Ras and exons 9 and 20 of PIK3CA were determined by direct sequencing using genomic DNA extracted from paraffin-embedded blocks.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Activation status of AKT was evaluated by immunohistochemical staining using phospho-specific AKT antibody (Ser473).
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Correlation between these factors and clinicopathologic findings/patient survival were examined.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: As a result, PIK3CA mutation was significantly associated with shorter relapse-free survival (RFS) in stage II/III patients (p = 0.0216) and shorter disease-specific survival in all patients (p = 0.0357).
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: In the multivariate analysis, PIK3CA mutation was the only independent and significant prognostic factor for RFS in stage II/III patients (p = 0.0433, HR 2.478).
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: This study revealed the prognostic value of PIK3CA mutation in colorectal cancer patients.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Patients with PIK3CA mutation should be followed up carefully.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Moreover, our result suggests that inhibition of PIK3CA mutant may be a new molecular target therapy.
title: PIK3CA mutation is predictive of poor survival in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Recently, TERT promoter mutations were identified at high frequencies in cutaneous melanoma tumor samples and cell lines.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: The mutations were found to have a UV-signature and to lead to increased TERT gene expression.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: We analyzed a large cohort of melanoma patients for the presence and distribution of TERT promoter mutations and their association with clinico-pathological characteristics.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: METHODS: 410 melanoma tumor samples were analyzed by Sanger sequencing for the presence of TERT promoter mutations.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: An analysis of associations between mutation status and various clinical and pathologic variables was performed.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: RESULTS: TERT promoter mutations were identified in 154 (43%) of 362 successfully sequenced melanomas.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: Mutation frequencies varied between melanoma subtype, being most frequent in melanomas arising in nonacral skin (48%) and melanomas with occult primary (50%), and less frequent in mucosal (23%), and acral (19%) melanomas.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: Mutations carried a UV signature (C>T or CC>TT).
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: The presence of TERT promoter mutations was associated with factors such as BRAF or NRAS mutation (P < .001), histologic type (P = .002), and Breslow thickness (P < .001).
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: TERT promoter mutation was independently associated with poorer overall survival in patients with nonacral cutaneous melanomas (median survival 80 months vs 291 months for wild-type; hazard ratio corrected for other covariates 2.47; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.29 to 4.74; P = .006).
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: UV-induced TERT promoter mutations are one of the most frequent genetic alterations in melanoma, with frequencies varying depending on melanoma subtype.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: In nonacral cutaneous melanomas, presence of TERT promoter mutations is independently associated with poor prognosis.
title: TERT promoter mutation status as an independent prognostic factor in cutaneous melanoma.

text: Ewing's sarcoma is a poorly characterized malignant tumor with a relatively uniform histologic appearance, made up of densely packed small cells with round to oval nuclei, without distinct cell borders and without any structural differentiation.
title: Detection of t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation of Ewing's sarcoma in paraffin embedded tissue by nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

text: Often the diagnosis has to be made by exclusion.
title: Detection of t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation of Ewing's sarcoma in paraffin embedded tissue by nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

text: Recently, it has been made possible to identify characteristic chromosomal rearrangements associated with certain solid tumors.
title: Detection of t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation of Ewing's sarcoma in paraffin embedded tissue by nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

text: More than 85% of Ewing's sarcoma and peripheral neuroectodermal tumor present a specific t(11;22)(q24;q12) balanced translocation, resulting in the production of a novel chimerical EWS/FLI-1 message.
title: Detection of t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation of Ewing's sarcoma in paraffin embedded tissue by nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

text: Using oligonucleotide primers derived from EWS and FLI-1 complementary DNAs, we were able to use reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) as a diagnostic tool.
title: Detection of t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation of Ewing's sarcoma in paraffin embedded tissue by nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

text: The described nested RT-PCR method as another supportive diagnostic method enables pathologists to differentiate small blue cell tumors not only to make correct diagnosis but also to investigate retrospective archival tumor samples, using formalin fixed paraffin embedded tissue as a source of RNA.
title: Detection of t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation of Ewing's sarcoma in paraffin embedded tissue by nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

text: Cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (cn-AML) is a group of heterogeneous diseases.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: Gene mutations are increasingly used to assess the prognosis of cn-AML patients and guide risk-adapted treatment.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: In the present study, we analyzed the molecular genetics characteristics of 373 adult cn-AML patients and explored the relationship between TET2 gene mutations or different genetic mutation patterns and prognosis.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: We found that 16.1 % of patients had TET2 mutations, 31.6 % had FLT3 internal tandem duplications (ITDs), 6.2 % had FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations, 2.4 % had c-KIT mutations, 37.8 % had NPM1 mutations, 11.3 % had WT1 mutations, 5.9 % had RUNX1 mutations, 11.5 % had ASXL1 mutations, 3.8 % had MLL-PTDs, 7.8 % had IDH1 mutations, 7.8 % had NRAS mutations, 12.3 % had IDH2 mutations, 1.6 % had EZH2 mutations, and 14.7 % had DNMT3A mutations, while none had CBL mutations.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: Gene mutations were detected in 76.94 % (287/373) of all patients.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: In the NPM1m(+) patients, those with TET2 mutations were associated with a shorter median overall survival (OS) as compared to TET2 wild-type (wt) patients (9.9 vs. 27.0 months, respectively; P = 0.023); Interestingly, the TET2 mutation was identified as an unfavorable prognostic factor and was closely associated with a shorter median OS as compared to TET2-wt (9.5 vs. 32.2 months, respectively; P = 0.013) in the NPM1m(+)/FLT3-ITDm(-) patient group.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: Thus, identification of TET2 combined with classic NPM1 and FLT3-ITD mutations allowed us to stratify cn-AML into distinct subtypes.
title: TET2 gene mutation is unfavorable prognostic factor in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia patients with NPM1+ and FLT3-ITD - mutations.

text: UNLABELLED: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT) is a neoplasm that typically occurs in children.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: The genetic landscape of this tumor is incompletely understood and therapeutic options are limited.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: Although 50% of IMTs harbor anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangements, no therapeutic targets have been identified in ALK-negative tumors.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: We report for the first time that IMTs harbor other actionable targets, including ROS1 and PDGFRbeta fusions.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: We detail the case of an 8-year-old boy with treatment-refractory ALK-negative IMT.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: Molecular tumor profiling revealed a ROS1 fusion, and he had a dramatic response to the ROS1 inhibitor crizotinib.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: This case prompted assessment of a larger series of IMTs.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: Next-generation sequencing revealed that 85% of cases evaluated harbored kinase fusions involving ALK, ROS1, or PDGFRbeta.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: Our study represents the most comprehensive genetic analysis of IMTs to date and also provides a rationale for routine molecular profiling of these tumors to detect therapeutically actionable kinase fusions.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: Our study describes the most comprehensive genomics-based evaluation of IMT to date.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: Because there is no "standard-of-care" therapy for IMT, the identification of actionable genomic alterations, in addition to ALK, is expected to redefine management strategies for patients with this disease.
title: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harbor multiple potentially actionable kinase fusions.

text: UNLABELLED: While genomically targeted therapies have improved outcomes for patients with lung adenocarcinoma, little is known about the genomic alterations which drive squamous cell lung cancer.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Sanger sequencing of the tyrosine kinome identified mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene in 3.8% of squamous cell lung cancers and cell lines.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Squamous lung cancer cell lines harboring DDR2 mutations were selectively killed by knock-down of DDR2 by RNAi or by treatment with the multi-targeted kinase inhibitor dasatinib.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Tumors established from a DDR2 mutant cell line were sensitive to dasatinib in xenograft models.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Expression of mutated DDR2 led to cellular transformation which was blocked by dasatinib.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: A squamous cell lung cancer patient with a response to dasatinib and erlotinib treatment harbored a DDR2 kinase domain mutation.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: These data suggest that gain-of-function mutations in DDR2 are important oncogenic events and are amenable to therapy with dasatinib.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: As dasatinib is already approved for use, these findings could be rapidly translated into clinical trials.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: DDR2 mutations are present in 4% of lung SCCs, and DDR2 mutations are associated with sensitivity to dasatinib.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: These findings provide a rationale for designing clinical trials with the FDA-approved drug dasatinib in patients with lung SCCs.
title: Mutations in the DDR2 kinase gene identify a novel therapeutic target in squamous cell lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: This study evaluated efficacy of single-agent trastuzumab against advanced or recurrent HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma (EC), and explored predictors for HER2 amplification.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eligible patients had measurable stage III, IV, or recurrent EC.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: There was no limit on prior therapy although total prior doxorubicin dose was limited to 320 mg/m(2).
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Tumors were required to have HER2 overexpression (2+ or 3+ immunohistochemical staining) or HER2 amplification (FISH HER2/CEP 17 ratio >2.0).
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Trastuzumab was administered intravenously at a dose of 4 mg/kg in week 1, then 2 mg/kg weekly until disease progression.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: The primary endpoint was tumor response.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: RESULTS: Of the 286 tumors centrally screened by LabCorp, 33 (11.5%) were HER2-amplified.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Three of 8 clear (38%) cell carcinomas and 7 of 25 serous carcinomas (28%) screened exhibited HER2 amplification compared with 7% (2/29) of endometrioid adenocarcinomas.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: HER2 overexpression was correlated with HER2 amplification (r=0.459; p<0.0001).
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Thirty-four women were enrolled; 1 was excluded (refused treatment); and 18 had tumors with known HER2 amplification.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: No major tumor responses were observed.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Twelve women experienced stable disease, 18 had increasing disease, and 3 were indeterminate for tumor response.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Neither HER2 overexpression nor HER2 amplification appeared to be associated with progression-free survival or overall survival.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: CONCLUSION: Trastuzumab as a single agent did not demonstrate activity against endometrial carcinomas with HER2 overexpression or HER2 amplification, although full planned accrual of women with HER2 amplified tumors was not achieved due to slow recruitment.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: Serous and clear cell endometrial carcinomas appear to be more likely to demonstrate HER2 amplification.
title: Phase II trial of trastuzumab in women with advanced or recurrent, HER2-positive endometrial carcinoma: a Gynecologic Oncology Group study.

text: BACKGROUND: Pemetrexed is a key drug for therapy of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: In a search for biomarkers for study of the efficacy of pemetrexed treatment, we examined the thymidylate synthase (TYMS) copy number in NSCLC cell lines and in clinical NSCLC samples treated with pemetrexed, combined with platinum drugs.
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: TYMS copy numbers in lung adenocarcinoma cell lines were significantly lower than in squamous cell carcinoma (p=0.0105), and a significant correlation was found between the TYMS copy number and the 50% inhibitory concentration value for pemetrexed in all 17 lung cancer cell lines tested (r=0.6814, p=0.0026).
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Moreover, TYMS copy number was significantly lower in clinical NSCLC samples responsive to treatment with pemetrexed combined with platinum drugs (p=0.0067).
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Furthermore, the decrease in the baseline CT size measurement of pemetrexed combined with platinum drug treatment correlated significantly with TYMS copy number (r=0.7967, p=0.0011).
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: To our knowledge, this is the first report of a significant association between TYMS copy number and response to pemetrexed treatment in tumor biopsy specimens.
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Our results suggest that TYMS copy number could be a predictive biomarker for pemetrexed based chemotherapy.
title: Thymidylate synthase gene copy number as a predictive marker for response to pemetrexed treatment of lung adenocarcinoma.

text: INTRODUCTION: Pre-temozolomide studies demonstrated that loss of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN held independent prognostic significance in GBM patients.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: We investigated whether loss of PTEN predicted shorter survival in the temozolomide era.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: The role of PTEN in the PI3K/Akt pathway is also reviewed.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: METHODS: Patients with histologically proven newly diagnosed GBM were identified from a retrospective database between 2007 and 2010.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: Cox proportional hazards analysis was used to calculate the independent effects of PTEN expression, age, extent of resection, Karnofsky performance scale (KPS), and treatment on overall survival.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: RESULTS: Sixty-five percent of patients were men with median age of 63 years, and 70% had KPS>/=80.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: Most patients (81%) received standard treatment (temozolomide with concurrent radiation).
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: A total of 72 (47%) patients had retained PTEN expression.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: Median overall survival (OS) was 19.1 months (95% CI: 15.0-22.5).
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: Median survival of 20.0 months (95% CI: 15.0-25.5) and 18.2 months (95% CI: 13.0-25.7) was observed in PTEN retained and PTEN loss patients, respectively (p = .71).
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: PTEN loss patients were also found to have amplifications of EGFR gene more frequently than patients with retained PTEN (70.8% vs. 47.8%, p = .01).
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: Multivariate analysis showed that older age (HR 1.64, CI: 1.02-2.63, p = .04), low KPS (HR 3.57, CI: 2.20-5.79, p<.0001), and lack of standard treatment (HR 3.98, CI: 2.38-6.65, p<.0001) yielded worse survival.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: PTEN loss was not prognostic of overall survival (HR 1.31, CI: 0.85-2.03, p = .22).
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Loss of expression of PTEN does not confer poor overall survival in the temozolomide era.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: These findings imply a complex and non-linear molecular relationship between PTEN, its regulators and effectors in the tumorigenesis of glioblastoma.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: Additionally, there is evidence that temozolomide may be more effective in eradicating GBM cancer cells with PTEN loss and hence, level the outcomes between the PTEN retained and loss groups.
title: Loss of PTEN is not associated with poor survival in newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients of the temozolomide era.

text: AKT1(E17K) mutations occur at low frequency in a variety of solid tumors, including those of the breast and urinary bladder.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: Although this mutation has been shown to transform rodent cells in culture, it was found to be less oncogenic than PIK3CA mutations in breast epithelial cells.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: Moreover, the therapeutic potential of AKT inhibitors in human tumors with an endogenous AKT1(E17K) mutation is not known.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: Expression of exogenous copies of AKT1(E17K) in MCF10A breast epithelial cells increased phosphorylation of AKT and its substrates, induced colony formation in soft agar, and formation of lesions in the mammary fat pad of immunodeficient mice.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: These effects were inhibited by the allosteric and catalytic AKT inhibitors MK-2206 and AZD5363, respectively.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: Both AKT inhibitors caused highly significant growth inhibition of breast cancer explant models with AKT1(E17K) mutation.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: Furthermore, in a phase I clinical study, the catalytic Akt inhibitor AZD5363 induced partial responses in patients with breast and ovarian cancer with tumors containing AKT1(E17K) mutations.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: In MGH-U3 bladder cancer xenografts, which contain both AKT1(E17K) and FGFR3(Y373C) mutations, AZD5363 monotherapy did not significantly reduce tumor growth, but tumor regression was observed in combination with the FGFR inhibitor AZD4547.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: The data show that tumors with AKT1(E17K) mutations are rational therapeutic targets for AKT inhibitors, although combinations with other targeted agents may be required where activating oncogenic mutations of other proteins are present in the same tumor.
title: Tumors with AKT1E17K Mutations Are Rational Targets for Single Agent or Combination Therapy with AKT Inhibitors.

text: Uveal melanoma (UM) is a genetically and biologically distinct type of melanoma, and once metastatic there is no effective treatment currently available.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: Eighty percent of UMs harbor mutations in the Galphaq family members GNAQ and GNA11.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: Understanding the effector pathways downstream of these oncoproteins is important to identify opportunities for targeted therapy.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: We report consistent activation of the protein kinase C (PKC) and MAPK pathways as a consequence of GNAQ or GNA11 mutation.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: PKC inhibition with AEB071 or AHT956 suppressed PKC and MAPK signalling and induced G1 arrest selectively in melanoma cell lines carrying GNAQ or GNA11 mutations.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: In contrast, treatment with two different MEK inhibitors, PD0325901 and MEK162, inhibited the proliferation of melanoma cell lines irrespective of their mutation status, indicating that in the context of GNAQ or GNA11 mutation MAPK activation can be attributed to activated PKC.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: AEB071 significantly slowed the growth of tumors in an allograft model of GNAQ(Q209L)-transduced melanocytes, but did not induce tumor shrinkage.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: In vivo and in vitro studies showed that PKC inhibitors alone were unable to induce sustained suppression of MAP-kinase signaling.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: However, combinations of PKC and MEK inhibition, using either PD0325901or MEK162, led to sustained MAP-kinase pathway inhibition and showed a strong synergistic effect in halting proliferation and in inducing apoptosis in vitro.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: Furthermore, combining PKC and MEK inhibition was efficacious in vivo, causing marked tumor regression in a UM xenograft model.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: Our data identify PKC as a rational therapeutic target for melanoma patients with GNAQ or GNA11 mutations and demonstrate that combined MEK and PKC inhibition is synergistic, with superior efficacy compared to treatment with either approach alone.
title: Combined PKC and MEK inhibition in uveal melanoma with GNAQ and GNA11 mutations.

text: INTRODUCTION: Tumor protein p53 gene (TP53) mutations are common in stage I through III non-small cell lung cancer, but clinical trials have shown inconsistent results regarding their relationship to the effects of adjuvant therapy.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: The objective is to clarify their putative prognostic and predictive effects.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: METHODS: A pooled analysis of TP53 mutations (exons 5-8) was conducted in four randomized trials (the International Adjuvant Lung Cancer Trial, J BRonchus 10, Cancer and Leukemia Group B-9633, and Adjuvant Navelbine International Trialist Association trial) of platinum-based adjuvant chemotherapy (ACT) versus observation (OBS).
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: Hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of mutant versus wild-type (WT) TP53 for overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS) were estimated using a multivariable Cox model stratified on trial and adjusted on sex, age, and clinicopathological variables.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: Predictive value was evaluated with an interaction between treatment and TP53.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: RESULTS: A total of 1209 patients (median follow-up 5.5 years) were included.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: There were 573 deaths (47%) and 653 DFS events (54%).
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: Mutations (434 [36%]) had no prognostic effect (OBS HROS = 0.99, 95% CI: 0.77-1.28, p = 0.95; HRDFS = 0.99, 95% CI: 0.78-1.25, p = 0.92) but were marginally predictive of benefit from ACT for OS (test for interaction: OS, p = 0.06; DFS, p = 0.11).
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: Patients with WT TP53 had a tendency toward better outcomes with ACT than did those in the OBS group (HROS = 0.77, 95% CI: 0.62-0.95, p = 0.02; HRDFS = 0.75, 95% CI: 0.62-0.92, p = 0.005).
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: In the ACT arm, a deleterious effect of mutant versus WT TP53 was observed (HROS = 1.40, 95% CI: 1.10-1.78, p = 0.006; HRDFS = 1.31, 95% CI: 1.04-1.64, p = 0.02).
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: TP53 mutation had no prognostic effect but was marginally predictive for survival from ACT.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: In patients who received ACT, TP53 mutation tended to be associated with shorter survival than wild-type TP53.
title: Prognostic and Predictive Effect of TP53 Mutations in Patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer from Adjuvant Cisplatin-Based Therapy Randomized Trials: A LACE-Bio Pooled Analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: More than half of patients with KRAS-wild type advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) fail anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: We studied EGFR-axis messenger RNA (mRNA) expression and RAS, RAF, PIK3CA mutations in order to identify additional biomarkers of cetuximab efficacy.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: METHODS: Previously genotyped (KRAS, NRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA mutations) formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumour biopsies of 226 cetuximab-treated CRC patients (1st to 3rd line therapy) were assessed for mRNA expression of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and its ligands EGF, Transofrming Growth Factor-a (TGFA), Amphiregulin (AREG) and Epiregulin (EREG) with real time quantitative PCR.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: Mutations were detected in 72 (31.9%) tumours for KRAS, in 6 (2.65%) for BRAF, in 7 (3.1%) for NRAS and in 37 (16.4%) for PIK3CA.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: RESULTS: Only PIK3CA mutations occasionally coexisted with other gene mutations.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: In univariate analysis, prognostic significance for survival ( from metastases until death) was seen for BRAF mutations (Hazard Ratio HR 8.1, 95% CI 3.4-19), codon 12-only KRAS mutations (HR 1.62, 95% CI 1.1-2.4), high AREG mRNA expression only in KRAS wild type CRC (HR 0.47, 95% CI 0.3-0.7) and high EREG mRNA expression irrespective of KRAS mutation status (HR 0.45, 95% CI 0.28-0.7).
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: EREG tumoural mRNA expression was significantly associated with a 2.26-fold increased likelihood of objective response to cetuximab therapy (RECIST 1.1).
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: In multivariate analysis, favourable predictive factors were high AREG mRNA in KRAS wild type tumours, high EREG mRNA, low Ephrin A2 receptor mRNA.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: Cetuximab-treated patients with AREG-low KRAS wild type CRC fared very poorly, their survival being similar to KRAS mutant CRC.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: Patients with KRAS codon 13 or other non-codon 12 mutations had a median survival (30 months, 95% CI 20-35) similar to that of patients with KRAS wild-type (median survival 29 months, 95% CI 25-35), in contrast to patients with KRAS codon 12 mutations who fared worse (median survival 19 months, 95% CI 15-26).
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: CONCLUSIONS: BRAF and codon 12 KRAS mutations predict for adverse outcome of CRC patients receiving cetuximab.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: AREG mRNA reflects EGFR signalling in KRAS wild type tumours, predicting for cetuximab efficacy when high and failure when low.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: EREG may have a prognostic role independent of KRAS mutation.
title: Biomarkers of benefit from cetuximab-based therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer: interaction of EGFR ligand expression with RAS/RAF, PIK3CA genotypes.

text: The histone deacetylase inhibitor belinostat is eliminated through glucuronidation by UGT1A1.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: Polymorphisms that reduce UGT1A1 function could result in increased belinostat exposure and toxicities.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: We wanted to determine which single-nucleotide polymorphisms alter belinostat exposure and toxicity.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: In a phase 1 trial (belinostat over 48 hours in combination with cisplatin and etoposide), belinostat (400, 500, 600, or 800 mg/m(2) /24 h, 48-hour continuous infusion) was administered to patients with cancer in combination with cisplatin and etoposide (n = 25).
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: Patients were genotyped for UGT1A1 variants associated with reduced function: UGT1A1*6, UGT1A1*28, and UGT1A1*60.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: End points were associations between UGT1A1 genotype and belinostat pharmacokinetics (PK), toxicities, and global protein lysine acetylation (AcK).
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: Belinostat AUC was increased (P = .003), and t1/2 increased (P = .0009) in UGT1A1*28 and UGT1A1*60 carriers who received more than 400 mg/m(2) /24 h. The incidence of grades 3-4 thrombocytopenia (P = .0081) was associated with UGT1A1 polymorphisms.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: The US Food and Drug Administration-approved package insert recommends dose adjustment of belinostat for UGT1A1*28.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: However, our data suggest dose adjustment is also necessary for UGT1A1*60.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: UGT1A1 polymorphisms were associated with increased systemic belinostat exposure, increased AcK, and increased incidence of toxicities, particularly at doses > 400 mg/m(2) /24 h.
title: Effects of UGT1A1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and toxicities of belinostat administered by 48-hour continuous infusion in patients with cancer.

text: PURPOSE: BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) forms an aggressive subset of colorectal cancer with minimal response to selective RAF inhibitors.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Preclinical data show that reactivation of EGFR signaling occurs in colorectal tumor cells treated with RAF inhibitors and that the addition of an EGFR inhibitor enhances antitumor activity.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: These data suggest that combined therapy with RAF and EGFR inhibitors could be an effective strategy for treating BRAF V600E mCRC.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We undertook a pilot trial to assess the response rate and safety of the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib combined with anti-EGFR antibody panitumumab in patients with BRAF-mutant mCRC.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Patients received standard approved doses of panitumumab and vemurafenib.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: Fifteen patients were treated.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Performance status was Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) 0 in 4 patients (27%) and ECOG 1 in 11 patients (73%).
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: All patients had progressed through at least one standard treatment regimen, and 8 (53%) had received previous fluoropyrimidine, oxaliplatin, and irinotecan chemotherapy.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Treatment was well tolerated, with less cutaneous toxicity than would be expected with either agent, and no cases of keratoacanthomas/squamous cell carcinomas.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Tumor regressions were seen in 10 of 12 evaluable patients with partial responses in 2 patients (100% and 64% regression lasting 40 and 24 weeks, respectively), and stable disease lasting over 6 months in 2 patients.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Combined RAF and EGFR inhibition is well tolerated, with less cutaneous toxicity than would be expected with either agent, and results in modest clinical activity in this highly aggressive and chemoresistant subset of CRC.
title: Pilot trial of combined BRAF and EGFR inhibition in BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) is a dominantly inherited familial cancer syndrome predisposing to a variety of malignant and benign tumours, most frequently retinal, cerebellar, and spinal hemangioblastoma, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and pancreatic tumours.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau gene in Italian patients.

text: The current study investigated the occurrence of VHL mutations in Italian patients with classic VHL disease or with atypical VHL-like clinical features referred to the Service of Medical Genetics for VHL molecular diagnosis.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau gene in Italian patients.

text: In addition, an RQ-PCR protocol was validated in order to introduce it in the routine VHL laboratory diagnosis.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau gene in Italian patients.

text: Recurrent mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase 2 (IDH2) occur in approximately 12% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Mutated IDH2 proteins neomorphically synthesize 2-hydroxyglutarate resulting in DNA and histone hypermethylation, which leads to blocked cellular differentiation.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Enasidenib (AG-221/CC-90007) is a first-in-class, oral, selective inhibitor of mutant-IDH2 enzymes.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: This first-in-human phase 1/2 study assessed the maximum tolerated dose (MTD), pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles, safety, and clinical activity of enasidenib in patients with mutant-IDH2 advanced myeloid malignancies.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We assessed safety outcomes for all patients and clinical efficacy in the largest patient subgroup, those with relapsed or refractory AML, from the phase 1 dose-escalation and expansion phases of the study.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In the dose-escalation phase, an MTD was not reached at doses ranging from 50 to 650 mg per day.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Enasidenib 100 mg once daily was selected for the expansion phase on the basis of pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles and demonstrated efficacy.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Grade 3 to 4 enasidenib-related adverse events included indirect hyperbilirubinemia (12%) and IDH-inhibitor-associated differentiation syndrome (7%).
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Among patients with relapsed or refractory AML, overall response rate was 40.3%, with a median response duration of 5.8 months.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Responses were associated with cellular differentiation and maturation, typically without evidence of aplasia.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Median overall survival among relapsed/refractory patients was 9.3 months, and for the 34 patients (19.3%) who attained complete remission, overall survival was 19.7 months.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Continuous daily enasidenib treatment was generally well tolerated and induced hematologic responses in patients for whom prior AML therapy had failed.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Inducing differentiation of myeloblasts, not cytotoxicity, seems to drive the clinical efficacy of enasidenib.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: This trial was registered at www.clinicaltrials.gov as #NCT01915498.
title: Enasidenib in mutant IDH2 relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Genetic instability is a feature of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) with adverse prognosis.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: We hypothesized that chromosomal translocations or complex karyotypes and distinct somatic mutations may impact outcome after first-line chemoimmunotherapy of CLL patients.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: We performed metaphase karyotyping and next-generation sequencing (NGS) of 85 genes in pretreatment blood samples obtained from 161 patients registered for CLL11, a 3-arm phase 3 trial comparing frontline chlorambucil (Clb) vs Clb plus rituximab (Clb-R) or Clb plus obinutuzumab in CLL patients with significant comorbidity.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: Chromosomal aberrations as assessed by karyotyping were observed in 68.8% of 154 patients, 31.2% carried translocations, and 19.5% showed complex karyotypes.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: NGS revealed 198 missense/nonsense mutations and 76 small indels in 76.4% of patients.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: The most frequently mutated genes were NOTCH1, SF3B1, ATM, TP53, BIRC3, POT1, XPO1, and KRAS Sole chemotherapy, treatment with Clb-R, or genetic lesions in TP53 (9.9% of patients) and KRAS (6.2% of patients) were significantly associated with nonresponse to study therapy.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: In multivariate models, complex karyotypes and POT1 mutations (8.1% of patients) represented significant prognostic factors for an unfavorable survival, independently of IGHV mutation status, Binet stage, and serum beta-2-microglobuline.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: Patients with the copresence of complex karyotypes and deletions/mutations involving TP53 demonstrated a particularly short survival.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: In summary, this is the first prospective, controlled study in CLL patients that shows a role of complex karyotype aberrations as an independent prognostic factor for survival after front-line therapy.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: Moreover, the study identifies mutations in KRAS and POT1 as novel determinants of outcome after chemoimmunotherapy using chlorambucil and anti-CD20 treatment.
title: Complex karyotypes and KRAS and POT1 mutations impact outcome in CLL after chlorambucil-based chemotherapy or chemoimmunotherapy.

text: Breast cancer is a heterogeneous disease with distinct molecular subtypes characterized by differential response to targeted and chemotherapeutic agents.
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: Enhanced understanding of the genetic alterations characteristic of different subtypes is needed to pave the way for more personalized administration of therapeutic agents.
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: We have taken a functional genomics approach using a well-characterized panel of breast cancer cell lines to identify putative biomarkers of resistance to antimitotic agents such as paclitaxel and monomethyl-auristatin-E (MMAE).
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: In vitro studies revealed a striking difference in sensitivity to these agents between cell lines from different subtypes, with basal-like cell lines being significantly more sensitive to both agents than luminal or HER2-amplified cell lines.
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: Genome-wide association studies using copy number data from Affymetrix single nucleotide polymorphism arrays identified amplification of the chromosome 17q21 region as being highly associated with resistance to both paclitaxel and MMAE.
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: An unbiased approach consisting of RNA interference and high content analysis was used to show that amplification and concomitant overexpression of the gene encoding the ABCC3 drug transporter is responsible for conferring in vitro resistance to paclitaxel and MMAE.
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: We also show that amplification of ABCC3 is present in primary breast tumors and that it occurs predominantly in HER2-amplified and luminal tumors, and we report on development of a specific fluorescence in situ hybridization assay that may have utility as a predictive biomarker of taxane resistance in breast cancer.
title: Functional genomics identifies ABCC3 as a mediator of taxane resistance in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Lung adenocarcinomas can be distinguished by identifying mutated driver oncogenes, including epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and KRAS.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: Mutations in EGFR are associated with both improved survival as well as response to treatment with erlotinib and gefitinib.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: However, the prognostic significance of KRAS has not been evaluated in large numbers of patients and remains controversial.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: For the current report, the authors examined the association of EGFR and KRAS mutations with survival among patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: METHODS: Data were analyzed from patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas who had known EGFR and KRAS mutation status evaluated between 2002 and 2009.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: The collected clinical variables included age, sex, Karnofsky performance status, smoking history, and treatment history.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: Overall survival from the diagnosis of advanced disease was analyzed using Kaplan-Meier and Cox proportional hazard methods.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: RESULTS: In total, 1036 patients were evaluated, including 610 women (59%) and 344 never-smokers (33%).
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: The median patient age was 65 years (range, 25-92 years), and the majority of patients (81%) had a Karnofsky performance status >/=80%.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: In multivariate analysis, EGFR mutations were associated with longer overall survival (hazard ratio, 0.6; P < .001), and KRAS mutations were associated with shorter survival (hazard ratio, 1.21; P = .048).
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: KRAS mutations predicted shorter survival for patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: The presence of EGFR and KRAS mutations define distinct subsets of patients with lung adenocarcinomas and should be determined in patients when they are diagnosed with advanced disease.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: Clinical trial reports should include EGFR and KRAS mutation status along with other prognostic factors.
title: Association of KRAS and EGFR mutations with survival in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas.

text: OBJECTIVES: Recent studies have shown that IDH1 and IDH2 mutations occur frequently in gliomas, including low-grade gliomas.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: However, their impact on the prognosis and chemosensitivity of low-grade gliomas remains unclear.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: METHODS: Search for IDH1 and IDH2 mutations, loss of heterozygosity on chromosomes 1p and 19q, MGMT promoter methylation, and p53 expression was performed in a series of 271 low-grade gliomas and correlated with overall survival.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: A subgroup of 84 patients treated up-front with temozolomide was individualized.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: Response to temozolomide was evaluated by progression-free survival, as well as by tumor size on successive MRI scans, and then correlated with molecular alterations.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: RESULTS: IDH (IDH1 or IDH2) mutations were found in 132/189 patients (70%).
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: IDH mutation and 1p-19q codeletion were associated with prolonged overall survival in univariate (p = 0.002 and p = 0.0001) and multivariate analysis (p = 0.003 and p = 0.004).
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: 1p-19q codeletion, MGMT promoter methylation, and IDH mutation (p = 0.01) were correlated with a higher rate of response to temozolomide.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: Further analysis of the course of the disease prior to any treatment except for surgery (untreated subgroup) showed that 1p-19q codeletion was associated with prolonged progression-free survival in univariate analysis, whereas IDH mutation was not.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: CONCLUSION: IDH mutation appears to be a significant marker of positive prognosis and chemosensitivity in low-grade gliomas, independently of 1p-19q codeletion, whereas its impact on the course of untreated tumors seems to be limited.
title: IDH1 or IDH2 mutations predict longer survival and response to temozolomide in low-grade gliomas.

text: BACKGROUND: Selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886)+docetaxel increases median overall survival (OS) and significantly improves progression-free survival (PFS) and objective response rate (ORR) compared with docetaxel alone in patients with KRAS mutant, stage IIIB/IV non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC; NCT00890825).
title: Impact of KRAS codon subtypes from a randomised phase II trial of selumetinib plus docetaxel in KRAS mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: Retrospective analysis of OS, PFS, ORR and change in tumour size at week 6 for different sub-populations of KRAS codon mutations.
title: Impact of KRAS codon subtypes from a randomised phase II trial of selumetinib plus docetaxel in KRAS mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: In patients receiving selumetinib+docetaxel and harbouring KRAS G12C or G12V mutations there were trends towards greater improvement in OS, PFS and ORR compared with other KRAS mutations.
title: Impact of KRAS codon subtypes from a randomised phase II trial of selumetinib plus docetaxel in KRAS mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Different KRAS mutations in NSCLC may influence selumetinib/docetaxel sensitivity.
title: Impact of KRAS codon subtypes from a randomised phase II trial of selumetinib plus docetaxel in KRAS mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: GADD45A (growth arrest and DNA damage 45 A) is the first stress-inducible gene identified to be a target of p53.
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: However, no studies to date have assessed variants of the GADD45 gene and their potential relationship to tumor susceptibility.
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: We investigated the association of the GADD45A (1506T>C) polymorphism with ovarian cancer development in 258 ovarian cancer patients and 332 age-matched healthy women as controls using sequence analysis.
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: We found a statistically significant difference in the GADD45A (1506T>C) genotype distributions between the case and control groups (TT vs. TC vs. CC, P = 0.0021) and found that variant 1506T>C was significantly associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer (P<0.001, OR = 1.71, 95% CI [1.28-2.29]).
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: We observed a statistically significant effect between tumor histology (P = 0.032) and CA125 status (P = 0.021).
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: Carrying the C allele (TC+CC) was associated with an increased risk of positive CA125 (OR = 3.20, 95% CI [1.15-8.71).
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: Carrying the T allele (TT+TC) showed a significant correlation with both higher GADD45A mRNA expression and longer ovarian cancer RFS (relapse-free survival) and OS (overall survival).
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: We are the first group to demonstrate that the GADD45A (1506T>C) polymorphism is associated with ovarian cancer susceptibility and prognosis.
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: These data suggest that GADD45A (1506T>C) is a new tumor susceptibility gene and could be a useful molecular marker for assessing ovarian cancer risk and for predicting ovarian cancer patient prognosis.
title: The GADD45A (1506T>C) Polymorphism Is Associated with Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility and Prognosis.

text: PURPOSE: Melanomas harbor aberrations in the c-Kit gene.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: We tested the efficiency of the tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib in selected patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutations or amplifications.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Forty-three patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit aberrations were enrolled on this phase II trial.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Each patient received a continuous dose of imatinib 400 mg/d unless intolerable toxicities or disease progression occurred.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Fifteen patients who experienced progression of disease were allowed to escalate the dose to 800 mg/d.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: RESULTS: Forty-three patients were eligible for evaluation, and the median follow-up time was 12.0 months.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: The median progression-free survival (PFS) was 3.5 months, and the 6-month PFS rate was 36.6%.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Rate of total disease control was 53.5%: 10 patients (23.3%; 95% CI, 10.2% to 36.4%) and 13 patients (30.2%; 95% CI, 16.0% to 44.4%) achieved partial response (PR) and stable disease (SD), respectively.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Eighteen patients (41.9%) demonstrated regression of tumor mass.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Notably, nine of the 10 PRs were observed in patients with mutations in exons 11 or 13.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: The 1-year overall survival (OS) rate was 51.0%.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: The median PFS and OS times for patients who had PR or SD versus disease progression were 9.0 months versus 1.5 months (P < .001) and 15.0 months versus 9.0 months (P = .036), respectively.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Imatinib 400 mg/d was well tolerated, and only one of the 15 patients who received dose escalation to 800 mg/d achieved SD.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: CONCLUSION: Imatinib demonstrated significant activity in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring genetic c-Kit aberrations, with an overall response rate of 23.3%.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Escalation to 800 mg/d could not restore disease control.
title: Phase II, open-label, single-arm trial of imatinib mesylate in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring c-Kit mutation or amplification.

text: Phosphatase and tensin homologue deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) is one of the most frequently disrupted tumor suppressors in cancer.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: The lipid phosphatase activity of PTEN antagonizes the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/AKT/mTOR pathway to repress tumor cell growth and survival.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: In the nucleus, PTEN promotes chromosome stability and DNA repair.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: Consequently, loss of PTEN function increases genomic instability.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: PTEN deficiency is caused by inherited germline mutations, somatic mutations, epigenetic and transcriptional silencing, post-translational modifications, and protein-protein interactions.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: Given the high frequency of PTEN deficiency across cancer subtypes, therapeutic approaches that exploit PTEN loss-of-function could provide effective treatment strategies.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: Herein, we discuss therapeutic strategies aimed at cancers with loss of PTEN function, and the challenges involved in treating patients afflicted with such cancers.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: We review preclinical and clinical findings, and highlight novel strategies under development to target PTENdeficient cancers.
title: Therapeutic targeting of cancers with loss of PTEN function.

text: OBJECTIVE: BRAF D594G mutations in colorectal cancer patients are not clearly understood.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: We retrospectively investigated the clinicopathological features of colorectal cancers with BRAF D594G mutations.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: METHODS: We selected 908 colorectal cancer patients who underwent surgical resection from January 2008 to January 2013, and assessed BRAF, KRAS, microsatellite instability, and CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP).
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: RESULTS: We detected BRAF D594G in 7 patients and BRAF V600E in 45 patients.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: The clinicopathological features of cancers with BRAF D594G mutation were similar to those with BRAF wild-type, but differed from those with BRAF V600E mutations.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: Regarding microsatellite instability status, 44.4% of cases with BRAF V600E mutations exhibited high microsatellite instability, compared to 14.3% of those with BRAF D594G mutations and 4.4% of those with BRAF wild-type.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: There were no CIMP-positive tumors in cancers with BRAF D594G mutations, whereas 67.8% of tumors with BRAF V600E mutations were CIMP-positive.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: In stage IV cancers, the survival rates of patients at 2 years were 8.5, 50.0, and 68.2% in the BRAF V600E mutation, BRAF D594G mutation, and BRAF wild-type groups, respectively.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: CONCLUSION: Colorectal cancers with BRAF D594G mutations exhibit similar clinicopathological features, microsatellite instability status, and prognosis as those with BRAF wild-type.
title: Colorectal Cancer with BRAF D594G Mutation Is Not Associated with Microsatellite Instability or Poor Prognosis.

text: PURPOSE: Cetuximab is efficient in advanced colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: We previously showed that KRAS mutations were associated with resistance to cetuximab in 30 CRC patients.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: The aim of this study was to validate, in an independent larger series of 89 patients, the prognostic value of KRAS mutations on response to cetuximab and survival.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eighty-nine metastatic CRC patients treated with cetuximab after treatment failure with irinotecan-based chemotherapy were analyzed for KRAS mutation by allelic discrimination on tumor DNA.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: The association between KRAS mutations and tumor response, skin toxicity, progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) was analyzed.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: RESULTS: A KRAS mutation was present in 27% of the patients and was associated with resistance to cetuximab (0% v 40% of responders among the 24 mutated and 65 nonmutated patients, respectively; P < .001) and a poorer survival (median PFS: 10.1 v 31.4 weeks in patients without mutation; P = .0001; median OS: 10.1 v 14.3 months in patients without mutation; P = .026).
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: When we pooled these 89 patients with patients from our previous study, the multivariate analysis showed that KRAS status was an independent prognostic factor associated with OS and PFS, whereas skin toxicity was only associated with OS.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: In a combined analysis, median OS times of patients with two, one, or no favorable prognostic factors (severe skin toxicity and no KRAS mutation) was of 15.6, 10.7, and 5.6 months, respectively.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: CONCLUSION: These results confirm the high prognostic value of KRAS mutations on response to cetuximab and survival in metastatic CRC patients treated with cetuximab.
title: KRAS mutations as an independent prognostic factor in patients with advanced colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab.

text: PURPOSE: ALK rearrangement-positive lung cancers can be effectively treated with ALK inhibitors.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: However, the magnitude and duration of response is heterogeneous.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: In addition, acquired resistance limits the efficacy of ALK inhibitors, with most upfront resistance mechanisms being unknown.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: By making use of the Ba/F3 cell line model, we analyzed the cytotoxic efficacy of ALK kinase inhibitors as a function of different EML4-ALK fusion variants v1, v2, v3a, and v3b as well as of three artificially designed EML4-ALK deletion constructs and the ALK fusion genes KIF5b-ALK and NPM1-ALK.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: In addition, the intracellular localization, the sensitivity to HSP90 inhibition and the protein stability of ALK fusion proteins were studied.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: RESULTS: Different ALK fusion genes and EML4-ALK variants exhibited differential sensitivity to the structurally diverse ALK kinase inhibitors crizotinib and TAE684.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: In addition, differential sensitivity correlated with differences in protein stability in EML4-ALK-expressing cells.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: Furthermore, the sensitivity to HSP90 inhibition also varied depending on the ALK fusion partner but differed from ALK inhibitor sensitivity patterns.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: Finally, combining inhibitors of ALK and HSP90 resulted in synergistic cytotoxicity.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our results might explain some of the heterogeneous responses of ALK-positive tumors to ALK kinase inhibition observed in the clinic.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: Thus, targeted therapy of ALK-positive lung cancer should take into account the precise ALK genotype.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: Furthermore, combining ALK and HSP90 inhibitors might enhance tumor shrinkage in EML4-ALK-driven tumors.
title: Differential protein stability and ALK inhibitor sensitivity of EML4-ALK fusion variants.

text: Following mutations in BRAF and NRAS, the RAC1 c.85C>T single-nucleotide variant (SNV) encoding P29S amino acid change represents the next most frequently observed protein-coding hotspot mutation in melanoma.
title: The RAC1 P29S hotspot mutation in melanoma confers resistance to pharmacological inhibition of RAF.

text: However, the biologic and clinical significance of the RAC1 P29S somatic mutation in approximately 4% to 9% of patients remains unclear.
title: The RAC1 P29S hotspot mutation in melanoma confers resistance to pharmacological inhibition of RAF.
