text: Here, we demonstrate that melanoma cell lines possessing the RAC1 hotspot variant are resistant to RAF inhibitors (vemurafenib and dabrafenib).
title: The RAC1 P29S hotspot mutation in melanoma confers resistance to pharmacological inhibition of RAF.

text: Enforced expression of RAC1 P29S in sensitive BRAF-mutant melanoma cell lines confers resistance manifested by increased viability, decreased apoptosis, and enhanced tumor growth in vivo upon treatment with RAF inhibitors.
title: The RAC1 P29S hotspot mutation in melanoma confers resistance to pharmacological inhibition of RAF.

text: Conversely, RNAi-mediated silencing of endogenous RAC1 P29S in a melanoma cell line with a co-occurring BRAF V600 mutation increased sensitivity to vemurafenib and dabrafenib.
title: The RAC1 P29S hotspot mutation in melanoma confers resistance to pharmacological inhibition of RAF.

text: Our results suggest RAC1 P29S status may offer a predictive biomarker for RAF inhibitor resistance in melanoma patients, where it should be evaluated clinically.
title: The RAC1 P29S hotspot mutation in melanoma confers resistance to pharmacological inhibition of RAF.

text: BACKGROUND: Identifying patients who will experience lung cancer recurrence after surgery remains a challenge.
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: We aimed to evaluate whether mutant forms of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog (KRAS) (mEGFR and mKRAS) are useful biomarkers in resected non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed data from 841 patients who underwent surgery and molecular testing for NSCLC between 2007 and 2012.
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: RESULTS: mEGFR was observed in 103 patients (12.2%), and mKRAS in 265 (31.5%).
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: The median overall survival (OS) and time to recurrence (TTR) were significantly lower for mKRAS (OS: 43 months; TTR: 19 months) compared with mEGFR (OS: 67 months; TTR: 24 months) and wild-type patients (OS: 55 months; disease-free survival (DFS): 24 months).
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: Patients with KRAS G12V exhibited worse OS and TTR compared with the entire cohort (OS: KRAS G12V: 26 months vs COHORT: 60 months; DFS: KRAS G12V: 15 months vs COHORT: 24 months).
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: These results were confirmed using multivariate analyses (non-G12V status, hazard ratio (HR): 0.43 (confidence interval: 0.28-0.65), P<0.0001 for OS; HR: 0.67 (0.48-0.92), P=0.01 for TTR).
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: Risk of recurrence was significantly lower for non-KRAS G12V (HR: 0.01, (0.001-0.08), P<0.0001).
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: CONCLUSIONS: mKRAS and mEGFR may predict survival and recurrence in early stages of NSCLC.
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: Patients with KRAS G12V exhibited worse OS and higher recurrence incidences.
title: Prognostic value of the KRAS G12V mutation in 841 surgically resected Caucasian lung adenocarcinoma cases.

text: BACKGROUND: Lapatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor of human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2, also referred to as HER2/neu) and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), is active in combination with capecitabine in women with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer that has progressed after trastuzumab-based therapy.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: In this trial, we compared lapatinib plus capecitabine with capecitabine alone in such patients.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: METHODS: Women with HER2-positive, locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer that had progressed after treatment with regimens that included an anthracycline, a taxane, and trastuzumab were randomly assigned to receive either combination therapy (lapatinib at a dose of 1250 mg per day continuously plus capecitabine at a dose of 2000 mg per square meter of body-surface area on days 1 through 14 of a 21-day cycle) or monotherapy (capecitabine alone at a dose of 2500 mg per square meter on days 1 through 14 of a 21-day cycle).
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: The primary end point was time to progression, based on an evaluation by independent reviewers under blinded conditions.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: The interim analysis of time to progression met specified criteria for early reporting on the basis of superiority in the combination-therapy group.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: The hazard ratio for the independently assessed time to progression was 0.49 (95% confidence interval, 0.34 to 0.71; P<0.001), with 49 events in the combination-therapy group and 72 events in the monotherapy group.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: The median time to progression was 8.4 months in the combination-therapy group as compared with 4.4 months in the monotherapy group.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: This improvement was achieved without an increase in serious toxic effects or symptomatic cardiac events.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Lapatinib plus capecitabine is superior to capecitabine alone in women with HER2-positive advanced breast cancer that has progressed after treatment with regimens that included an anthracycline, a taxane, and trastuzumab.
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00078572 [ClinicalTrials.gov].
title: Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.
Lapatinib plus capecitabine for HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Although ROS1-rearranged non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is sensitive to crizotinib, development of resistance is inevitable.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Here, we identified molecular alterations in crizotinib-resistant tumors from two NSCLC patients with the CD74-ROS1 rearrangement, and in HCC78 cells harboring SLC34A2-ROS1 that showed resistance to crizotinib (HCC78CR cells).
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: ROS1 kinase domain mutations were examined in fresh tumor tissues from two NSCLC patients and HCC78CR1-3 cells by direct sequencing.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Ba/F3 cells expressing ROS1 secondary mutations were constructed to evaluate resistance to crizotinib.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: An upregulated pathway was identified using phospho-receptor tyrosine kinase array, EGFR signaling antibody array, and RNA sequencing (RNA-seq).
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Cell proliferation and ROS1 downstream signaling pathways were compared between HCC78 and HCC78CR1-3 cells.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: The ROS1 G2032R mutation was identified in crizotinib-resistant tumors from one patient.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Furthermore, HCC78CR1 and CR2 cells harbored a novel ROS1 L2155S mutation (73.3% and 76.2%, respectively).
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: ROS1 G2032R and L2155S mutations conferred resistance to crizotinib in Ba/F3 cells.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Evidence of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition with downregulated E-cadherin and upregulated vimentin was observed in HCC78CR1-2 cells and in the other patient.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RNA-seq and EGFR signaling antibody array revealed that the EGFR pathway was significantly upregulated in HCC78CR3 versus HCC78 cells.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Cells with the ROS1 mutation and upregulated EGFR were sensitive to foretinib, an inhibitor of c-MET, VEGFR2, and ROS1 and irreversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors plus crizotinib, respectively.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Molecular changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ROS1-rearranged NSCLC are heterogeneous, including ROS1 tyrosine kinase mutations, EGFR activation, and epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition.
title: Molecular Changes Associated with Acquired Resistance to Crizotinib in ROS1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The clinical and prognostic relevance of many recently identified driver gene mutations in adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is poorly defined.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We sequenced the coding regions or hotspot areas of 68 recurrently mutated genes in a cohort of 664 patients aged 18 to 86 years treated on 2 phase 3 trials of the German AML Cooperative Group (AMLCG).
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The median number of 4 mutations per patient varied according to cytogenetic subgroup, age, and history of previous hematologic disorder or antineoplastic therapy.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We found patterns of significantly comutated driver genes suggesting functional synergism.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Conversely, we identified 8 virtually nonoverlapping patient subgroups, jointly comprising 78% of AML patients, that are defined by mutually exclusive genetic alterations.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: These subgroups, likely representing distinct underlying pathways of leukemogenesis, show widely divergent outcomes.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Furthermore, we provide detailed information on associations between gene mutations, clinical patient characteristics, and therapeutic outcomes in this large cohort of uniformly treated AML patients.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In multivariate analyses including a comprehensive set of molecular and clinical variables, we identified DNMT3A and RUNX1 mutations as important predictors of shorter overall survival (OS) in AML patients <60 years, and particularly in those with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: NPM1 mutations in the absence of FLT3-ITD, mutated TP53, and biallelic CEBPA mutations were identified as important molecular prognosticators of OS irrespective of patient age.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In summary, our study provides a comprehensive overview of the spectrum, clinical associations, and prognostic relevance of recurrent driver gene mutations in a large cohort representing a broad spectrum and age range of intensively treated AML patients.
title: Spectrum and prognostic relevance of driver gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: IMPORTANCE: Randomized clinical trials demonstrate no benefit for epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors in unselected patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: However, a patient with stage IVA HNSCC received 13 days of neoadjuvant erlotinib and experienced a near-complete histologic response.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: OBJECTIVE: To determine a mechanism of exceptional response to erlotinib therapy in HNSCC.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Single patient with locally advanced HNSCC who received erlotinib monotherapy in a window-of-opportunity clinical trial (patients scheduled to undergo primary cancer surgery are treated briefly with an investigational agent).
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: Whole-exome sequencing of pretreatment tumor and germline patient samples was performed at a quaternary care academic medical center, and a candidate somatic variant was experimentally investigated for mediating erlotinib response.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: INTERVENTION: A brief course of erlotinib monotherapy followed by surgical resection.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Identification of pretreatment tumor somatic alterations that may contribute to the exceptional response to erlotinib.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: Hypotheses were formulated regarding enhanced erlotinib response in preclinical models harboring the patient tumor somatic variant MAPK1 E322K following the identification of tumor somatic variants.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: No EGFR alterations were observed in the pretreatment tumor DNA.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: Paradoxically, the tumor harbored an activating MAPK1 E322K mutation (allelic fraction 0.13), which predicts ERK activation and erlotinib resistance in EGFR-mutant lung cancer.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: The HNSCC cells with MAPK1 E322K exhibited enhanced EGFR phosphorylation and erlotinib sensitivity compared with wild-type MAPK1 cells.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Selective erlotinib use in HNSCC may be informed by precision oncology approaches.
title: Genomic Correlate of Exceptional Erlotinib Response in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: When the integrity of the genome is threatened, cells activate a complex, kinase-based signaling network to arrest the cell cycle, initiate DNA repair, or, if the extent of damage is beyond repair capacity, induce apoptotic cell death.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: The ATM protein lies at the heart of this signaling network, which is collectively referred to as the DNA damage response (DDR).
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: ATM is involved in numerous DDR-regulated cellular responses-cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, and apoptosis.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: Disabling mutations in the gene encoding ATM occur frequently in various human tumors, including lung cancer and hematological malignancies.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: We report that ATM deficiency prevents apoptosis in human and murine cancer cells exposed to genotoxic chemotherapy.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: Using genetic and pharmacological approaches, we demonstrate in vitro and in vivo that ATM-defective cells display strong non-oncogene addiction to DNA-PKcs (DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit).
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: Further, this dependence of ATM-defective cells on DNA-PKcs offers a window of opportunity for therapeutic intervention: We show that pharmacological or genetic abrogation of DNA-PKcs in ATM-defective cells leads to the accumulation of DNA double-strand breaks and the subsequent CtBP-interacting protein (CtIP)-dependent generation of large single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) repair intermediates.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: These ssDNA structures trigger proapoptotic signaling through the RPA/ATRIP/ATR/Chk1/p53/Puma axis, ultimately leading to the apoptotic demise of ATM-defective cells exposed to DNA-PKcs inhibitors.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: Finally, we demonstrate that DNA-PKcs inhibitors are effective as single agents against ATM-defective lymphomas in vivo.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: Together, our data implicate DNA-PKcs as a drug target for the treatment of ATM-defective malignancies.
title: Therapeutic targeting of a robust non-oncogene addiction to PRKDC in ATM-defective tumors.

text: Flavopiridol is the first cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor to enter clinical trials.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: Flavopiridol has been shown to mimic, in part, the effect of the cell cycle control gene p16, which is frequently lost or mutated in malignant melanoma, making it an ideal candidate for targeted therapy in this disease.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: In these studies we investigated the effect of flavopiridol, at various concentrations, on the growth and gene expression of nine human melanoma cell lines with intact, absent or mutated p16.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: A cytostatic effect of flavopiridol on the growth of six melanoma cell lines with a mutated or non-expressed p16 (p16-) was seen at low concentrations of flavopiridol (mean 50% inhibitory concentration [IC(50)] = 12.5 nM), while the three melanoma cell lines with intact p16 (p16+) required higher concentrations (mean IC(50) = 25 nM) to produce this effect.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: Apoptotic cell death increased with increasing concentrations of flavopiridol in both p16- and p16+ cells.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: Exposure of cells to high flavopiridol concentrations (>100 nM) resulted in decreased expression of genes downstream in the normal p16 cell cycle control pathway (Rb and E2F) and the anti-apoptotic gene BCL2.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: No change in BCL2 expression was found after exposure to IC(50) concentrations of flavopiridol.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: These data indicate that flavopiridol in low, clinically achievable concentrations may have significant cytostatic effects, particularly in p16- melanoma cells, and may provide new molecular-based therapies for melanoma, particularly when combined with agents that target anti-apoptotic mechanisms.
title: The effect of flavopiridol on the growth of p16+ and p16- melanoma cell lines.

text: PURPOSE: To analyze the prognostic impact of Wilms' tumor 1 (WT1) gene mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML).
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS We studied 196 adults younger than 60 years with newly diagnosed primary CN-AML, who were treated similarly on Cancer and Leukemia Group B (CALGB) protocols 9621 and 19808, for WT1 mutations in exons 7 and 9.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: The patients also were assessed for the presence of FLT3 internal tandem duplications (FLT3-ITD), FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations (FLT3-TKD), MLL partial tandem duplications (MLL-PTD), NPM1 and CEBPA mutations, and for the expression levels of ERG and BAALC.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: RESULTS: Twenty-one patients (10.7%) harbored WT1 mutations.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: Complete remission rates were not significantly different between patients with WT1 mutations and those with unmutated WT1 (P = .36; 76% v 84%).
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: Patients with WT1 mutations had worse disease-free survival (DFS; P < .001; 3-year rates, 13% v 50%) and overall survival (OS; P < .001; 3-year rates, 10% v 56%) than patients with unmutated WT1.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: In multivariable analyses, WT1 mutations independently predicted worse DFS (P = .009; hazard ratio [HR] = 2.7) when controlling for CEBPA mutational status, ERG expression level, and FLT3-ITD/NPM1 molecular-risk group (ie, FLT3-ITD(negative)/NPM1(mutated) as low risk v FLT3-ITD(positive) and/or NPM1(wild-type) as high risk).
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: WT1 mutations also independently predicted worse OS (P < .001; HR = 3.2) when controlling for CEBPA mutational status, FLT3-ITD/NPM1 molecular-risk group, and white blood cell count.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: CONCLUSION: We report the first evidence that WT1 mutations independently predict extremely poor outcome in intensively treated, younger patients with CN-AML.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: Future trials should include testing for WT1 mutations as part of molecularly based risk assessment and risk-adapted treatment stratification of patients with CN-AML.
title: Wilms' tumor 1 gene mutations independently predict poor outcome in adults with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: Somatic mutations in the tyrosine kinase (TK) domain of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene are reportedly associated with sensitivity of lung cancers to gefitinib (Iressa), kinase inhibitor.
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: In-frame deletions occur in exon 19, whereas point mutations occur frequently in codon 858 (exon 21).
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: We found from sequencing the EGFR TK domain that 7 of 10 gefitinib-sensitive tumors had similar types of alterations; no mutations were found in eight gefitinib-refractory tumors (P = 0.004).
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: Five of seven tumors sensitive to erlotinib (Tarceva), a related kinase inhibitor for which the clinically relevant target is undocumented, had analogous somatic mutations, as opposed to none of 10 erlotinib-refractory tumors (P = 0.003).
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: Because most mutation-positive tumors were adenocarcinomas from patients who smoked <100 cigarettes in a lifetime ("never smokers"), we screened EGFR exons 2-28 in 15 adenocarcinomas resected from untreated never smokers.
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: Seven tumors had TK domain mutations, in contrast to 4 of 81 non-small cell lung cancers resected from untreated former or current smokers (P = 0.0001).
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: Immunoblotting of lysates from cells transiently transfected with various EGFR constructs demonstrated that, compared to wild-type protein, an exon 19 deletion mutant induced diminished levels of phosphotyrosine, whereas the phosphorylation at tyrosine 1092 of an exon 21 point mutant was inhibited at 10-fold lower concentrations of drug.
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: Collectively, these data show that adenocarcinomas from never smokers comprise a distinct subset of lung cancers, frequently containing mutations within the TK domain of EGFR that are associated with gefitinib and erlotinib sensitivity.
title: EGF receptor gene mutations are common in lung cancers from "never smokers" and are associated with sensitivity of tumors to gefitinib and erlotinib.

text: OBJECTIVES: Head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCCs) are characterized by marked heterogeneity in their biological behavior and response to treatment.
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Our goal was the identification of biomarkers that can be used to predict response to chemotherapy in these patients.
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: The expression of EGFR, p53, Cyclin D1, p16, p21, p27, p-AKT, HIF-1alpha, Caspase 3 and BCL2 was analyzed by immunohistochemistry in 41 primary laryngeal/hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas of patients that received induction chemotherapy (cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil) as part of their treatment.
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: RESULTS: Positive expression of p27 and BCL2 had a significant predictive value for chemotherapy response in univariate analysis.
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: The combination of both proteins was not superior in predicting the response to chemotherapy.
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Furthermore, p27 expression was the only significant predictor of chemotherapy response in multivariate analysis (P=0.015).
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: CONCLUSION: p27 Expression may serve as predictive biomarker of response to induction chemotherapy in HNSCC patients.
title: p27 and BCL2 expression predicts response to chemotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: AIM: To investigate the role of coding region mutation and promoter hypermethylation of TP53 in adrenocortical cancer formation.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: METHODS: Twenty sporadic adrenocortical cancers (ACCs) and five normal adrenal tissue samples were available for analysis.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: Coding region mutation of TP53 in 20 ACCs was examined by polymerase chain amplification using intronic primers for exons 2-11 and direct sequencing of the product.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: In 10 ACCs and five normal adrenal tissue specimens, methylation of the 16 CpG sites within the TP53 promoter was examined using bisulphite methylation sequencing.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: RESULTS: Coding region mutation in TP53 was demonstrated in 5 of 20 ACCs.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: There were four mis-sense mutations and one frameshift mutation.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: Four of 5 patients with a TP53 mutation had metastases at diagnosis or detected soon thereafter and 3 of 4 died of disease within 12 months of surgical resection.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: No methylation was seen in the TP53 promoter in 10 ACC and the five normal adrenal tissues examined.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: CONCLUSION: Coding region mutation in TP53 occurs in 25% of ACCs with a trend toward a poorer prognosis.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: Promoter methylation of TP53 is not present in ACC as a mechanism for tumour suppressor gene (TSG) inactivation and, therefore, other genes in the 17p13 region are implicated in adrenal carcinogenesis.
title: Mutation and methylation analysis of TP53 in adrenal carcinogenesis.

text: The World Health Organization (WHO) classification of tumors of the hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues was last updated in 2008.
title: The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.

text: Since then, there have been numerous advances in the identification of unique biomarkers associated with some myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemias, largely derived from gene expression analysis and next-generation sequencing that can significantly improve the diagnostic criteria as well as the prognostic relevance of entities currently included in the WHO classification and that also suggest new entities that should be added.
title: The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.

text: Therefore, there is a clear need for a revision to the current classification.
title: The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.

text: The revisions to the categories of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia will be published in a monograph in 2016 and reflect a consensus of opinion of hematopathologists, hematologists, oncologists, and geneticists.
title: The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.

text: The 2016 edition represents a revision of the prior classification rather than an entirely new classification and attempts to incorporate new clinical, prognostic, morphologic, immunophenotypic, and genetic data that have emerged since the last edition.
title: The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.

text: The major changes in the classification and their rationale are presented here.
title: The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia.

text: Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is a B-cell malignancy characterized by a poor response to treatment and prognosis.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Constitutive activation of different signaling pathways in subsets of MCLs, through genetic and/or nongenetic alterations, endows tumor cells with enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: The canonical Wnt pathway (beta-catenin/TCF-LEF), implicated in the pathogenesis of numerous cancers, is constitutively active in half of MCLs.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Here, we show that ZEB1, a transcription factor better known for promoting metastasis in carcinomas, is expressed in primary MCLs with active Wnt signaling.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: ZEB1 expression in MCL cells depends on Wnt, being downregulated by beta-catenin knockdown or blocking of Wnt signaling by salinomycin.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Knockdown of ZEB1 reduces in vitro cell viability and proliferation in MCL cells, and, importantly, tumor growth in mouse xenograft models.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: ZEB1 activates proliferation-associated (HMGB2, UHRF1, CENPF, MYC, MKI67, and CCND1) and anti-apoptotic (MCL1, BCL2, and BIRC5) genes and inhibits pro-apoptotic ones (TP53, BBC3, PMAIP1, and BAX).
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: We show that ZEB1 expression in MCL cells determines differential resistance to chemotherapy drugs and regulates transporters involved in drug influx/efflux.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Downregulation of ZEB1 by salinomycin increases the sensitivity of MCL cells to the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin, cytarabine and gemcitabine.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Lastly, salinomycin and doxorubicin display a synergistic effect in established and primary MCL cells.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: These results identify ZEB1 in MCL where it promotes cell proliferation, enhanced tumor growth and a differential response to chemotherapy drugs.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: ZEB1 could thus potentially become a predictive biomarker and therapeutic target in this lymphoma.
title: The EMT activator ZEB1 promotes tumor growth and determines differential response to chemotherapy in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: PURPOSE: Approximately 1% of lung adenocarcinomas are driven by oncogenic ROS1 rearrangement.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Crizotinib is a potent inhibitor of both ROS1 and ALK kinase domains.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: In the absence of a prospective clinical trial in Europe, we conducted a retrospective study in centers that tested for ROS1 rearrangement.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Eligible patients had stage IV lung adenocarcinoma, had ROS1 rearrangement according to fluorescent in situ hybridization, and had received crizotinib therapy through an individual off-label use.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Best response was assessed locally using RECIST (version 1.1).
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: All other data were analyzed centrally.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: RESULTS: We identified 32 eligible patients.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: One patient was excluded because next-generation sequencing was negative for ROS1 fusion.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Median age was 50.5 years, 64.5% of patients were women, and 67.7% were never-smokers.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Thirty patients were evaluable for progression-free survival (PFS), and 29 patients were evaluable for best response.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: We observed four patients with disease progression, two patients with stable disease, and objective response in 24 patients, including five complete responses (overall response rate, 80%; disease control rate, 86.7%).
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Median PFS was 9.1 months, and the PFS rate at 12 months was 44%.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: No unexpected adverse effects were observed.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Twenty-six patients received pemetrexed (either alone or in combination with platinum and either before or after crizotinib) and had a response rate of 57.7% and a median PFS of 7.2 months.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: CONCLUSION: Crizotinib was highly active at treating lung cancer in patients with a ROS1 rearrangement, suggesting that patients with lung adenocarcinomas should be tested for ROS1.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: Prospective clinical trials with crizotinib and other ROS1 inhibitors are ongoing or planned.
title: Crizotinib therapy for advanced lung adenocarcinoma and a ROS1 rearrangement: results from the EUROS1 cohort.

text: OBJECTIVE: To study the effect of trastuzumab in patients with progressive or recurrent metastatic endometrial carcinoma shown by immunohistochemistry to overexpress the HER2/neu receptor.
title: Trastuzumab treatment in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial carcinoma overexpressing HER2/neu.

text: METHODS: Disease progression was examined in 2 patients who met the study criteria, had c-erbB2 gene amplification by fluorescence in situ hybridization, and were treated with trastuzumab following radiation treatment and/or salvage chemotherapy.
title: Trastuzumab treatment in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial carcinoma overexpressing HER2/neu.

text: RESULTS: The clinical responses to trastuzumab as a single agent or in combination with chemotherapy were confirmed in both patients by serial CT scans and serum CA-125 evaluations.
title: Trastuzumab treatment in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial carcinoma overexpressing HER2/neu.

text: These patients with progressive or recurrent metastatic disease experienced relief from their symptoms and prolonged survival with no significant toxicity observed.
title: Trastuzumab treatment in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial carcinoma overexpressing HER2/neu.

text: CONCLUSION: Trastuzumab may be a viable therapeutic option as single agent or in combination with chemotherapy in patients with advanced, recurrent, and/or metastatic endometrial carcinomas overexpressing HER2/neu.
title: Trastuzumab treatment in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial carcinoma overexpressing HER2/neu.

text: CONTEXT: An activating mutation in the gene BRAF has been correlated with poorer prognosis and more aggressive clinical course in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: We therefore hypothesized that the good prognosis, high 5-year disease-free rate and high survival rate of patients with less aggressive papillary thyroid microcarcinoma (pT1aNo-x) would be associated with a lower incidence of the BRAF(V600E) mutation.
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the frequency of the activating mutation BRAF(V600E) in low-risk papillary thyroid microcarcinoma (pT1aNo-x at the moment of diagnosis) and the association of the mutation with the clinical outcome in a retrospective analysis.
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: STUDY DESIGN: BRAF(V600E) was characterized in 113 PTC patients diagnosed with pT1aNo-x (one PTC focus with a diameter <1 cm, without lymph node or distant metastases according to IUCC/AJCC TNM staging system 2010).
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: Genotyping was performed on DNA extracted from thyroid tumour tissue using direct capillary sequencing, and allele-specific amplification PCR was used to resolve equivocal results.
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: Retrospective analysis of the clinical course of PTC was then correlated with BRAF status in the primary tumour tissue.
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: RESULTS: The BRAF(V600E) mutation was detected in 78 of the 113 pT1aNo-x patients (69.0%).
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: We observed no persistence, locoregional recurrence, lymph node or distant metastases or deaths in the study group during the 12-year study (January 2001 to December 2012).
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: CONCLUSIONS: The presence of the activating BRAF(V) (600E) mutation in a significant percentage of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma indicates that further analyses are required to verify its usefulness as a predictor of clinical outcome in PTC.
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: In this study, there was no correlation between BRAF-positive primary focus of papillary microcarcinoma and more aggressive or recurrent disease.
title: The BRAF(V600E) mutation in papillary thyroid microcarcinoma: does the mutation have an impact on clinical outcome?

text: DNA-damaging agents are commonly used for first-line chemotherapy of advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: As a G2/M checkpoint kinase, Wee1 can phosphorylate CDC2-tyr15 and induce G2/M cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: The correlation of WEE1 polymorphisms to the efficacy of chemotherapy was tested in 663 advanced NSCLC patients.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: WEE1 rs3910384 genotype correlated to overall survival (OS) and progress-free survival (PFS) of NSCLC patients treated with platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Sub-group analysis revealed that rs3910384 was particularly associated with the efficacy of doublet chemotherapy combining two DNA-damaging agents, i e  platinum and gemcitabine.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: NSCLC patients with the WEE1 rs3910384 G/G homozygote genotype showed 13.5 months extended OS, 3.2 months extended PFS, and a 274% relative increase in their 3-year survival rate (from 7.4% to 27.7%) compared to the A/A+A/G genotype after treatment with platinum-gemcitabine regimen.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: This finding was reproduced in the validation cohort.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: We utilized a luciferase reporter assay and Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) to demonstrate that rs3910384-linked WEE1 promoter haplotype can mediate allele-specific transcriptional binding and WEE1 expression in DNA damage response.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: In conclusion, the WEE1 rs3910384 G/G homozygote genotype can be used as a selective biomarker for NSCLC patients to indicate treatment with platinum and gemcitabine regimen.
title: WEE1 kinase polymorphism as a predictive biomarker for efficacy of platinum-gemcitabine doublet chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: The aim of the present study was to investigate the prevalence of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and to determine the correlation between this mutation and indicators of poor prognosis and outcome in patients with PTC.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: The BRAF V600E mutation status was analyzed in 187 tumor samples using the multiplex allele-specific PCR method.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to investigate the association of the BRAF V600E mutation with clinical features and patient outcome.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: The sensitivity of the multiplex allele-specific PCR combined with denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography reached ~1%.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: The BRAF V600E mutation was observed in 63.6% (119/187) of tumor tissues, predominantly in PTC specimens, and no BRAF mutation was identified in other benign-type thyroid diseases.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: The univariate analysis indicated that the BRAF V600E mutation was associated with age, tumor stage and prognosis (P<0.05).
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: In addition, the frequency of the BRAF V600E mutation was significantly different in the central (75.3%) and lateral neck (49.3%) lymph nodes of patients with lymph node metastasis.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: Multivariate logistic regression analysis showed that the BRAF V600E mutation (HR, 2.471; 95% CI, 1.149-5.312) and lymph node metastasis (HR, 3.003; 95% CI, 1.027-8.771) are independent factors that predict tumor prognosis.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: Thus, the BRAF V600E mutation is an independent risk factor that may be used to predict thyroid cancer persistence/recurrence.
title: Prognostic value of the BRAF V600E mutation in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: The androgen-receptor isoform encoded by splice variant 7 lacks the ligand-binding domain, which is the target of enzalutamide and abiraterone, but remains constitutively active as a transcription factor.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: We hypothesized that detection of androgen-receptor splice variant 7 messenger RNA (AR-V7) in circulating tumor cells from men with advanced prostate cancer would be associated with resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: METHODS: We used a quantitative reverse-transcriptase-polymerase-chain-reaction assay to evaluate AR-V7 in circulating tumor cells from prospectively enrolled patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer who were initiating treatment with either enzalutamide or abiraterone.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: We examined associations between AR-V7 status (positive vs. negative) and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) response rates (the primary end point), freedom from PSA progression (PSA progression-free survival), clinical or radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: RESULTS: A total of 31 enzalutamide-treated patients and 31 abiraterone-treated patients were enrolled, of whom 39% and 19%, respectively, had detectable AR-V7 in circulating tumor cells.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: Among men receiving enzalutamide, AR-V7-positive patients had lower PSA response rates than AR-V7-negative patients (0% vs. 53%, P=0.004) and shorter PSA progression-free survival (median, 1.4 months vs. 6.0 months; P<0.001), clinical or radiographic progression-free survival (median, 2.1 months vs. 6.1 months; P<0.001), and overall survival (median, 5.5 months vs. not reached; P=0.002).
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: Similarly, among men receiving abiraterone, AR-V7-positive patients had lower PSA response rates than AR-V7-negative patients (0% vs. 68%, P=0.004) and shorter PSA progression-free survival (median, 1.3 months vs. not reached; P<0.001), clinical or radiographic progression-free survival (median, 2.3 months vs. not reached; P<0.001), and overall survival (median, 10.6 months vs. not reached, P=0.006).
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: The association between AR-V7 detection and therapeutic resistance was maintained after adjustment for expression of full-length androgen receptor messenger RNA.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Detection of AR-V7 in circulating tumor cells from patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer may be associated with resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: These findings require large-scale prospective validation.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: (Funded by the Prostate Cancer Foundation and others.
title: AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.
AR-V7 and resistance to enzalutamide and abiraterone in prostate cancer.

text: A mutant form of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), EGFRvIII, is common in glioblastoma (GBM) and confers enhanced tumorigenic activity and drug resistance.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Nimotuzumab, an anti-EGFR antibody, has shown preclinical and clinical activity to GBM, but its specific activity against EGFRvIII has not been fully investigated.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Human glioma U87MG or LNZ308 cells overexpressing either wild-type (wt) EGFR or EGFRvIII were treated with nimotuzumab, temozolomide, or both.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Expression and phosphorylation status of molecules were determined by Western blot analysis.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Methylation status of promoter region of O(6) -methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) was detected by methylation-specific PCR.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Antitumor activity was tested using nude mice bearing either subcutaneous or intracerebral xenografts along with analyses of EGFR phosphorylation status, proliferation, apoptosis, and vessel density.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Nimotuzumab treatment resulted in reduction of EGFRvIII tyrosine phosphorylation with a decrease in Akt phosphorylation that was greater than that of wtEGFR.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Correspondingly, antitumor effects, growth suppression and survival elongation, were more significant in mice bearing either subcutaneous or intracerebral tumor expressing EGFRvIII than in those expressing wtEGFR.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: These effects were markedly increased when temozolomide was combined with nimotuzumab.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: The post-treatment recurrent brain tumors exhibited a decrease in expression of the mismatch repair (MMR) proteins, MSH6 and MLH1, but their methylated MGMT status did not changed.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: Nimotuzumab has in vivo antitumor activity against GBM, especially those expressing EGFRvIII, when combined with temozolomide.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: This could provide a basis for preselection of patients with GBM by EGFR status who might benefit from the nimotuzumab and temozolomide combination therapy.
title: Nimotuzumab enhances temozolomide-induced growth suppression of glioma cells expressing mutant EGFR in vivo.

text: The role of KRAS mutations in molecular targeted therapy by epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors (EGFR-TKIs) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) has not been fully understood.
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The present investigation is aimed at an elucidation of the role of specific KRAS mutation types in predicting outcomes of patients with advanced NSCLC receiving EGFR-TKI therapy.
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Initially, 448 NSCLC patients were tested for the presence of KRAS mutations, to obtain frequencies of specific KRAS mutation types.
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Subsequently, the clinical outcome of treatment was evaluated in a subgroup of 38 KRAS-positive patients receiving EGFR-TKI therapy.
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: KRAS mutations were detected in 69 of 448 patients (15.4%), mostly in smokers (17.86% vs. 5.8%, P = 0.0048), and appeared more frequently in adenocarcinomas than in squamous cell NSCLC or NSCLC that is not otherwise specified (21% vs. 6.99% vs. 4.4%, P = 0.0004).
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The most frequent type of KRAS mutation was G12C.
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The progression-free survival (PFS) was doubled in a group of non-G12C patients compared with that of the G12C group (9.0 wk vs. 4.3 wk, P = 0.009).
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The overall survival (OS) was not significantly different between non-G12C and G12C groups (12.1 wk vs. 9.3 wk, P = 0.068).
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The G12C KRAS mutation is a strong negative predictor for EGFR-TKI treatment, whereas other KRAS mutation types have not negatively predicted treatment efficacy compared with that for the wild-type KRAS genotype.
title: The dominant role of G12C over other KRAS mutation types in the negative prediction of efficacy of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Potent FLT3 inhibitors, such as quizartinib (AC220), have shown promise in treating acute myeloid leukemia (AML) containing FLT3 internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutations.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: However, responses are not durable and resistance develops within months.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: In this study, we outline a two-step model of resistance whereby extrinsic microenvironmental proteins FLT3 ligand (FL) and fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2) protect FLT3-ITD+ MOLM14 cells from AC220, providing time for subsequent accumulation of ligand-independent resistance mechanisms.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: FL directly attenuated AC220 inhibition of FLT3, consistent with previous reports.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Conversely, FGF2 promoted resistance through activation of FGFR1 and downstream MAPK effectors; these resistant cells responded synergistically to combinatorial inhibition of FGFR1 and FLT3.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Removing FL or FGF2 from ligand-dependent resistant cultures transiently restored sensitivity to AC220, but accelerated acquisition of secondary resistance via reactivation of FLT3 and RAS/MAPK signaling.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: FLT3-ITD AML patients treated with AC220 developed increased FGF2 expression in marrow stromal cells, which peaked prior to overt clinical relapse and detection of resistance mutations.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Overall, these results support a strategy of early combination therapy to target early survival signals from the bone marrow microenvironment, in particular FGF2, to improve the depth of response in FLT3-ITD AML.
title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.
FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

title: FGF2 from Marrow Microenvironment Promotes Resistance to FLT3 Inhibitors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Advanced cholangiocarcinoma continues to harbor a difficult prognosis and therapeutic options have been limited.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: During the course of a clinical trial of whole genomic sequencing seeking druggable targets, we examined six patients with advanced cholangiocarcinoma.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Integrated genome-wide and whole transcriptome sequence analyses were performed on tumors from six patients with advanced, sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (SIC) to identify potential therapeutically actionable events.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Among the somatic events captured in our analysis, we uncovered two novel therapeutically relevant genomic contexts that when acted upon, resulted in preliminary evidence of anti-tumor activity.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Genome-wide structural analysis of sequence data revealed recurrent translocation events involving the FGFR2 locus in three of six assessed patients.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: These observations and supporting evidence triggered the use of FGFR inhibitors in these patients.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: In one example, preliminary anti-tumor activity of pazopanib (in vitro FGFR2 IC50 approximately 350 nM) was noted in a patient with an FGFR2-TACC3 fusion.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: After progression on pazopanib, the same patient also had stable disease on ponatinib, a pan-FGFR inhibitor (in vitro, FGFR2 IC50 approximately 8 nM).
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: In an independent non-FGFR2 translocation patient, exome and transcriptome analysis revealed an allele specific somatic nonsense mutation (E384X) in ERRFI1, a direct negative regulator of EGFR activation.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Rapid and robust disease regression was noted in this ERRFI1 inactivated tumor when treated with erlotinib, an EGFR kinase inhibitor.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: FGFR2 fusions and ERRFI mutations may represent novel targets in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and trials should be characterized in larger cohorts of patients with these aberrations.
title: Integrated genomic characterization reveals novel, therapeutically relevant drug targets in FGFR and EGFR pathways in sporadic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against programmed death 1 (PD-1) that has antitumor activity in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), with increased activity in tumors that express programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1).
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: METHODS: In this open-label, phase 3 trial, we randomly assigned 305 patients who had previously untreated advanced NSCLC with PD-L1 expression on at least 50% of tumor cells and no sensitizing mutation of the epidermal growth factor receptor gene or translocation of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene to receive either pembrolizumab (at a fixed dose of 200 mg every 3 weeks) or the investigator's choice of platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Crossover from the chemotherapy group to the pembrolizumab group was permitted in the event of disease progression.
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The primary end point, progression-free survival, was assessed by means of blinded, independent, central radiologic review.
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Secondary end points were overall survival, objective response rate, and safety.
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Median progression-free survival was 10.3 months (95% confidence interval [CI], 6.7 to not reached) in the pembrolizumab group versus 6.0 months (95% CI, 4.2 to 6.2) in the chemotherapy group (hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.37 to 0.68; P<0.001).
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The estimated rate of overall survival at 6 months was 80.2% in the pembrolizumab group versus 72.4% in the chemotherapy group (hazard ratio for death, 0.60; 95% CI, 0.41 to 0.89; P=0.005).
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The response rate was higher in the pembrolizumab group than in the chemotherapy group (44.8% vs. 27.8%), the median duration of response was longer (not reached [range, 1.9+ to 14.5+ months] vs. 6.3 months [range, 2.1+ to 12.6+]), and treatment-related adverse events of any grade were less frequent (occurring in 73.4% vs. 90.0% of patients), as were grade 3, 4, or 5 treatment-related adverse events (26.6% vs. 53.3%).
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In patients with advanced NSCLC and PD-L1 expression on at least 50% of tumor cells, pembrolizumab was associated with significantly longer progression-free and overall survival and with fewer adverse events than was platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: (Funded by Merck; KEYNOTE-024 ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT02142738 .
title: Pembrolizumab versus Chemotherapy for PD-L1-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Resistance to treatment is the main problem of targeted treatment for cancer.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: We followed ten patients during treatment with vemurafenib, by three-dimensional imaging.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: In all patients, only a subset of lesions progressed.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: Next-generation DNA sequencing was performed on sequential biopsies in four patients to uncover mechanisms of resistance.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: In two patients, we identified mutations that explained resistance to vemurafenib; one of these patients had a secondary BRAF L505H mutation.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: This is the first observation of a secondary BRAF mutation in a vemurafenib-resistant patient-derived melanoma sample, which confirms the potential importance of the BRAF L505H mutation in the development of therapy resistance.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: Moreover, this study hints toward an important role for tumor heterogeneity in determining the outcome of targeted treatments.
title: Detailed imaging and genetic analysis reveal a secondary BRAF(L505H) resistance mutation and extensive intrapatient heterogeneity in metastatic BRAF mutant melanoma patients treated with vemurafenib.

text: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to evaluate the relationship between the expression of basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and fibroblast growth factor receptor-1 (FGFR-1) in cancer cells and fibroblasts at the invasive front of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), and the pathologic and clinical characteristics.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: METHODS: Sections of 61 biopsy specimens of primary OSCC were immunostained to assess the expression of bFGF and FGFR-1 in cancer cells and fibroblasts at the invasive front.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: The bFGF and FGFR-1 expressions in the cancer cells were evident in all specimens, whilst, in fibroblasts, they were detected in 41 (67%) of 61 specimens.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: These expressions in the fibroblasts occurred notably more often in high-invasive OSCC specimens than low-invasive OSCC specimens.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The prevalence of bFGF and FGFR-1 expressions in cases with lymph node metastasis was significantly higher (P < 0.05) than in cases without metastasis.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Moreover, these expressions were well correlated with patient prognosis.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: This study concludes that bFGF and FGFR-1 expressions in fibroblasts at the invasive front are linked to the mode of invasion and the prognosis in OSCC.
title: Correlation of basic fibroblast growth factor expression with the invasion and the prognosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate evidence on the association between CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response through.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: DESIGN: Systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective, cross-sectional and case-control studies published to 2012.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: For each study, relative risks and 95% confidence intervals were extracted and pooled with a fixed and random effects model.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Heterogeneity, publication bias, subgroup, and meta-regression analyses were performed.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: DATA SOURCES: PubMed (inception-2012) and EMBASE (inception-2012).
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR SELECTING STUDIES: Criteria for inclusion were studies reporting breast cancer outcomes in patients treated with tamoxifen and genotyped for polymorphisms in the CYP2D6 gene.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Twenty-five studies of 13,629 individuals were identified, of which 22 investigated the association of CYP2D6 genotype with outcomes in breast cancer women all receiving tamoxifen treatment ("treatment-only" design).
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Three randomized trials evaluated the effect of CYP2D6 genotype on tamoxifen response ("effect modification" design).
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: In analysis of treatment-only studies, the relative risk (RR) of all-cause mortality (>307 events in 4,936 patients) for carriers of a CYP2D6 reduced function allele was 1.11 (95% confidence interval (CI): 0.94 to 1.31) compared to individuals with normal/increased function CYP2D6 alleles.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: When we investigated a composite outcome including all-cause mortality and surrogate endpoints for overall survival (>307 events in 6,721 patients), carriers of a CYP2D6 reduced function allele had a RR of 1.27 (95% CI: 1.11 to 1.45).
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: From two randomized trials that permitted effect-modification analysis, one had only 154 patients and showed evidence of effect modification of tamoxifen by CYP2D6 genotype for distant recurrence but was directionally opposite to that predicted, whereas a larger trial of 2,537 patients failed to show evidence of effect modification for breast cancer-free interval (P values for interaction 0.02 and 0.44, respectively).
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Based on these findings, there is insufficient evidence to recommend CYP2D6 genotyping to guide tamoxifen treatment.
title: CYP2D6 genotype and tamoxifen response for breast cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: The survival of patients with diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma after chemotherapy is influenced by molecular features of the tumors.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: We used the gene-expression profiles of these lymphomas to develop a molecular predictor of survival.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: METHODS: Biopsy samples of diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma from 240 patients were examined for gene expression with the use of DNA microarrays and analyzed for genomic abnormalities.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: Subgroups with distinctive gene-expression profiles were defined on the basis of hierarchical clustering.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: A molecular predictor of risk was constructed with the use of genes with expression patterns that were associated with survival in a preliminary group of 160 patients and was then tested in a validation group of 80 patients.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: The accuracy of this predictor was compared with that of the international prognostic index.
