title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: RESULTS: Three gene-expression subgroups--germinal-center B-cell-like, activated B-cell-like, and type 3 diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma--were identified.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: Two common oncogenic events in diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma, bcl-2 translocation and c-rel amplification, were detected only in the germinal-center B-cell-like subgroup.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: Patients in this subgroup had the highest five-year survival rate.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: To identify other molecular determinants of outcome, we searched for individual genes with expression patterns that correlated with survival in the preliminary group of patients.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: Most of these genes fell within four gene-expression signatures characteristic of germinal-center B cells, proliferating cells, reactive stromal and immune cells in the lymph node, or major-histocompatibility-complex class II complex.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: We used 17 genes to construct a predictor of overall survival after chemotherapy.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: This gene-based predictor and the international prognostic index were independent prognostic indicators.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: DNA microarrays can be used to formulate a molecular predictor of survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.
title: The use of molecular profiling to predict survival after chemotherapy for diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma.

text: Intrinsic cross-resistance to inhibition of different signaling pathways may hamper development of combinatorial treatments in melanoma, but the relative frequency of this phenotype and the strategies to overcome this hurdle remain poorly understood.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: Among 49 BRAF-mutant melanoma cell lines from patients not previously treated with target therapy, 21 (42.9%) showed strong primary resistance (IC50 > 1 muM) to a BRAFV600E inhibitor.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: Most of the BRAF-inhibitor-resistant cell lines showed also strong or intermediate cross-resistance to MEK1/2- and to PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: Primary cross-resistance was confirmed in an independent set of 23 BRAF-mutant short-term melanoma cell cultures.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: MEK1/2 and PI3K/mTOR co-targeting was the most effective approach, compared to BRAF and PI3K/mTOR dual blockade, to counteract primary resistance to BRAF inhibition and the cross-resistant phenotype.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: This was shown by extensive drug interaction analysis, tumor growth inhibition assays in-vivo, p-ERK and p-AKT inhibition, promotion of melanoma apoptosis, apoptosis-related protein modulation, activation of effector caspases and selective modulation of genes involved in melanoma drug resistance and belonging to the ERK/MAPK and PI3K/AKT canonical pathways.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: Compared to co-targeting of mutant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR, the association of a MEK1/2 and a PI3K/mTOR inhibitor was more effective in the activation of Bax and of caspase-3 and in the induction of caspase-dependent melanoma apoptosis.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: Furthermore Bax silencing reduced the latter effects.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: These results suggest that intrinsic resistance to BRAF inhibition is frequently associated with primary cross-resistance to MEK and PI3K/mTOR blockade in BRAF-mutant melanoma and provide pre-clinical evidence for a combinatorial approach to counteract this phenotype.
title: Primary cross-resistance to BRAFV600E-, MEK1/2- and PI3K/mTOR-specific inhibitors in BRAF-mutant melanoma cells counteracted by dual pathway blockade.

text: This portion of the NCCN Guidelines for Colon Cancer focuses on the use of systemic therapy in metastatic disease.
title: Colon Cancer, Version 1.2017, NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology.

text: Considerations for treatment selection among 32 different monotherapies and combination regimens in up to 7 lines of therapy have included treatment history, extent of disease, goals of treatment, the efficacy and toxicity profiles of the regimens, KRAS/NRAS mutational status, and patient comorbidities and preferences.
title: Colon Cancer, Version 1.2017, NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology.

text: Location of the primary tumor, the BRAF mutation status, and tumor microsatellite stability should also be considered in treatment decisions.
title: Colon Cancer, Version 1.2017, NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology.

text: Genes encoding components of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis are frequently mutated in cancer, but few mutations have been characterized in MTOR, the gene encoding the mTOR kinase.
title: A diverse array of cancer-associated MTOR mutations are hyperactivating and can predict rapamycin sensitivity.

text: Using publicly available tumor genome sequencing data, we generated a comprehensive catalog of mTOR pathway mutations in cancer, identifying 33 MTOR mutations that confer pathway hyperactivation.
title: A diverse array of cancer-associated MTOR mutations are hyperactivating and can predict rapamycin sensitivity.

text: The mutations cluster in six distinct regions in the C-terminal half of mTOR and occur in multiple cancer types, with one cluster particularly prominent in kidney cancer.
title: A diverse array of cancer-associated MTOR mutations are hyperactivating and can predict rapamycin sensitivity.

text: The activating mutations do not affect mTOR complex assembly, but a subset reduces binding to the mTOR inhibitor DEPTOR.
title: A diverse array of cancer-associated MTOR mutations are hyperactivating and can predict rapamycin sensitivity.

text: mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1) signaling in cells expressing various activating mutations remains sensitive to pharmacologic mTOR inhibition, but is partially resistant to nutrient deprivation.
title: A diverse array of cancer-associated MTOR mutations are hyperactivating and can predict rapamycin sensitivity.

text: Finally, cancer cell lines with hyperactivating MTOR mutations display heightened sensitivity to rapamycin both in culture and in vivo xenografts, suggesting that such mutations confer mTOR pathway dependency.
title: A diverse array of cancer-associated MTOR mutations are hyperactivating and can predict rapamycin sensitivity.

text: The echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4-anaplastic lymphoma kinase (EML4-ALK) fusion gene has been identified as an oncogene in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC).
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: We used profiling of cancer genomes on an exon array to develop a novel computational method for the global search of gene rearrangements.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: This approach led to the detection of EML4-ALK fusion in breast and colorectal carcinomas in addition to NSCLC.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: Screening of a large collection of patient tumor samples showed the presence of EML4-ALK fusion in 2.4% of breast (5 of 209), 2.4% of colorectal (2 of 83), and in 11.3% of NSCLC (12 of 106).
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: Besides previously known EML4-ALK variants 1 (E13; A20) and 2 (E20; A20), a novel variant E21; A20 was found in colorectal carcinoma.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: The presence of an EML-ALK rearrangement was verified by identifying genomic fusion points in tumor samples representative of breast, colon, and NSCLC.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: EML4-ALK translocation was also confirmed by fluorescence in situ hybridization assay, which revealed its substantial heterogeneity in both primary tumors and tumor-derived cell lines.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: To elucidate the functional significance of EML4-ALK, we examined the growth of cell lines harboring the fusion following EML4 and ALK silencing by small interfering RNA.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: Significant growth inhibition was observed in some but not all cell lines, suggesting their variable dependence on ALK-mediated cell survival signaling.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: Collectively, these findings show the recurrence of EML4-ALK fusion in multiple solid tumors and further substantiate its role in tumorigenesis.
title: Exon array profiling detects EML4-ALK fusion in breast, colorectal, and non-small cell lung cancers.

text: BACKGROUND: The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is frequently amplified, overexpressed, or mutated in glioblastomas, but only 10 to 20 percent of patients have a response to EGFR kinase inhibitors.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: The mechanism of responsiveness of glioblastomas to these inhibitors is unknown.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: METHODS: We sequenced kinase domains in the EGFR and human EGFR type 2 (Her2/neu) genes and analyzed the expression of EGFR, EGFR deletion mutant variant III (EGFRvIII), and the tumor-suppressor protein PTEN in recurrent malignant gliomas from patients who had received EGFR kinase inhibitors.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: We determined the molecular correlates of clinical response, validated them in an independent data set, and identified effects of the molecular abnormalities in vitro.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: Of 49 patients with recurrent malignant glioma who were treated with EGFR kinase inhibitors, 9 had tumor shrinkage of at least 25 percent.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: Pretreatment tissue was available for molecular analysis from 26 patients, 7 of whom had had a response and 19 of whom had rapid progression during therapy.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: No mutations in EGFR or Her2/neu kinase domains were detected in the tumors.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: Coexpression of EGFRvIII and PTEN was significantly associated with a clinical response (P<0.001; odds ratio, 51; 95 percent confidence interval, 4 to 669).
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: These findings were validated in 33 patients who received similar treatment for glioblastoma at a different institution (P=0.001; odds ratio, 40; 95 percent confidence interval, 3 to 468).
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: In vitro, coexpression of EGFRvIII and PTEN sensitized glioblastoma cells to erlotinib.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Coexpression of EGFRvIII and PTEN by glioblastoma cells is associated with responsiveness to EGFR kinase inhibitors.
title: Molecular determinants of the response of glioblastomas to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: BACKGROUND: Dysregulated PI3K/Akt signaling occurs commonly in breast cancers and is due to HER2 amplification, PI3K mutation or PTEN inactivation.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: The objective of this study was to determine the role of Akt activation in breast cancer as a function of mechanism of activation and whether inhibition of Akt signaling is a feasible approach to therapy.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: A selective allosteric inhibitor of Akt kinase was used to interrogate a panel of breast cancer cell lines characterized for genetic lesions that activate PI3K/Akt signaling: HER2 amplification or PI3K or PTEN mutations in order to determine the biochemical and biologic consequences of inhibition of this pathway.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: A variety of molecular techniques and tissue culture and in vivo xenograft models revealed that tumors with mutational activation of Akt signaling were selectively dependent on the pathway.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: In sensitive cells, pathway inhibition resulted in D-cyclin loss, G1 arrest and induction of apoptosis, whereas cells without pathway activation were unaffected.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: Most importantly, the drug effectively inhibited Akt kinase and its downstream effectors in vivo and caused complete suppression of the growth of breast cancer xenografts with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification, including models of the latter selected for resistance to Herceptin.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: Furthermore, chronic administration of the drug was well-tolerated, causing only transient hyperglycemia without gross toxicity to the host despite the pleiotropic normal functions of Akt.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: These data demonstrate that breast cancers with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively dependent on Akt signaling, and that effective inhibition of Akt in tumors is feasible and effective in vivo.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: These findings suggest that direct inhibition of Akt may represent a therapeutic strategy for breast and other cancers that are addicted to the pathway including tumors with resistant to Herceptin.
title: Breast tumor cells with PI3K mutation or HER2 amplification are selectively addicted to Akt signaling.

text: Association studies in large series of breast cancer patients can be used to identify single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) contributing to breast cancer susceptibility.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: Previous studies have suggested associations between variants in TP53 (R72P) and MDM2 (SNP309) and cancer risk.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: Data from molecular studies suggest a functional interaction between these genes.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: We therefore investigated the effect of TP53 R72P and MDM2 SNP309 on breast cancer risk and age at onset of breast cancer in a pooled series of 5,191 cases and 3,834 controls from the Breast Cancer Association Consortium (BCAC).
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: Breast cancer risk was not found to be associated with the combined variant alleles [odds ratio (OR), 1.00; 95% confidence interval (95% CI), 0.81-1.23].
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: Estimated ORs were 1.01 (95% CI, 0.93-1.09) per MDM2 SNP309 allele and 0.98 (95% CI, 0.91-1.04) for TP53 R72P.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: Although we did find evidence for a 4-year earlier age at onset for carriers of both variant alleles in one of the breast cancer patient series of the BCAC (the German series), we were not able to confirm this effect in the pooled analysis.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: Even so, carriers of both variant alleles did not have different risk estimates for bilateral or estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: In conclusion, in this large collaborative study, we did not find an association of MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P, separately or in interaction, with breast cancer.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: This suggests that any effect of these two variants would be very small and possibly confined to subgroups that were not assessed in our present study.
title: Do MDM2 SNP309 and TP53 R72P interact in breast cancer susceptibility? A large pooled series from the breast cancer association consortium.

text: The standard treatment of advanced ovarian cancer is rapidly changing.
title: Advanced ovarian cancer: what should be the standard of care?

text: As we begin to understand that epithelial ovarian cancer is a heterogeneous disease, our treatment strategies are evolving to include novel biologic drugs that specifically exploit altered pathways.
title: Advanced ovarian cancer: what should be the standard of care?

text: Surgery remains an essential component in the treatment of ovarian cancer; however, the importance of surgical specialization and defining "optimal cytoreduction" as no visible residual disease has been further validated.
title: Advanced ovarian cancer: what should be the standard of care?

text: Ongoing studies are defining the role of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in the upfront treatment of advanced ovarian cancer.
title: Advanced ovarian cancer: what should be the standard of care?

text: In addition, clinical trials are evaluating intraperitoneal, dose dense, antiangiogenic drugs as well as targeted maintenance therapies which will establish new standards of care in the near future.
title: Advanced ovarian cancer: what should be the standard of care?

text: PURPOSE: SMAD4 (also called Dpc4) is a tumor suppressor in the TGF-beta signaling pathway that is genetically inactivated in approximately 55% of all pancreatic adenocarcinomas.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: We investigated whether prognosis after surgical resection for invasive pancreatic adenocarcinoma is influenced by SMAD4 status.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Using immunohistochemistry, we characterized the SMAD4 protein status of 249 pancreatic adenocarcinomas resected from patients who underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection) at The Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD, between 1990 and 1997.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: The SMAD4 gene status of 56 of 249 (22%) pancreatic carcinomas was also determined.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: A multivariate Cox proportional hazards model assessed the relative risk of mortality associated with SMAD4 status, adjusting for known prognostic variables.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Patients with pancreatic adenocarcinomas with SMAD4 protein expression had significantly longer survival (unadjusted median survival was 19.2 months as compared with 14.7 months in patients with pancreatic cancers lacking SMAD4 protein expression; P = 0.03).
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: This SMAD4 survival benefit persisted after adjustment for prognostic factors including tumor size, margins, lymph node status, pathological stage, blood loss, and use of adjuvant chemoradiotherapy.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: The relative hazard of mortality for cancers lacking SMAD4 after adjusting for other prognostic factors was 1.36 (95% confidence interval, 1.01-1.83; P = 0.04).
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: Patients undergoing Whipple resection for pancreatic adenocarcinoma survive longer if their cancers express SMAD4.
title: The SMAD4 protein and prognosis of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Histone deacetylases (HDAC) are key players in epigenetic regulation of gene expression and HDAC inhibitor (HDACi) treatment seems to be a promising anticancer therapy in many human tumours, including soft tissue sarcomas.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: HR23b has been shown to be a potential biomarker for sensitivity to HDACi therapy in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma and hepatocellular carcinoma.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: We aimed to evaluate HR23b as a candidate biomarker for HDACi response in sarcomas and gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST).
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Therefore, HR23b expression was analysed comprehensively by western blot in sarcoma and GIST cell lines covering all major clinically relevant subtypes.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: MTT assay and ApoTox-Glo(TM) Triplex assay were performed after treatment with vorinostat, belinostat, mocetinostat and entinostat.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: HR23b protein expression was measured under HDACi treatment.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Furthermore, HR23b expression levels were immunohistochemically determined in a large set of 523 clinical samples from sarcoma and GIST patients.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Western blot analyses showed that sarcomas differ significantly in their expression of HR23b protein.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: All HDACi were able to regulate proliferation and apoptosis in vitro.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Sensitivity to vorinostat correlated significantly with HR23b protein expression.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Immunohistochemical prevalence screening in clinical samples of relevant adult-type tumours revealed that 12.5% of sarcomas (among them malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours, pleomorphic liposarcomas, leiomyosarcomas, dedifferentiated liposarcomas, synovial sarcomas and angiosarcomas) and 23.2% of GIST show high HR23b expression.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Therefore, HDACi have antiproliferative and proapoptotic effects in sarcomas depending on the expression level of HR23b.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: These findings suggest that HR23b represents a candidate biomarker for HDACi sensitivity in certain sarcoma types and in GIST.
title: HR23b expression is a potential predictive biomarker for HDAC inhibitor treatment in mesenchymal tumours and is associated with response to vorinostat.

text: Angiosarcoma is an aggressive malignancy that arises spontaneously or secondarily to ionizing radiation or chronic lymphoedema.
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: Previous work has identified aberrant angiogenesis, including occasional somatic mutations in angiogenesis signaling genes, as a key driver of angiosarcoma.
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: Here we employed whole-genome, whole-exome and targeted sequencing to study the somatic changes underpinning primary and secondary angiosarcoma.
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: We identified recurrent mutations in two genes, PTPRB and PLCG1, which are intimately linked to angiogenesis.
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: The endothelial phosphatase PTPRB, a negative regulator of vascular growth factor tyrosine kinases, harbored predominantly truncating mutations in 10 of 39 tumors (26%).
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: PLCG1, a signal transducer of tyrosine kinases, encoded a recurrent, likely activating p.Arg707Gln missense variant in 3 of 34 cases (9%).
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: Overall, 15 of 39 tumors (38%) harbored at least one driver mutation in angiogenesis signaling genes.
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: Our findings inform and reinforce current therapeutic efforts to target angiogenesis signaling in angiosarcoma.
title: Recurrent PTPRB and PLCG1 mutations in angiosarcoma.

text: von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is an autosomal dominant inherited tumor syndrome characterized by the development of tumors in the eye, brain, spinal cord, inner ear, adrenal gland, pancreas, kidney, and epididymis, associated with germline mutations in the VHL gene.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in Korean VHL patients by multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis.

text: We used sequentially sequencing method and multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) analysis and detected germline mutations in the VHL in 15/15 (100%) of VHL patients fulfilling the clinical criteria.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in Korean VHL patients by multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis.

text: Of the 15 distinct mutations detected, large deletions were detected in 5/15 (33.3%) patients, including 4/15 (26.7%) partial deletions and 1/15 (6.6%) deletion of the entire VHL gene by MLPA and the remainder were point mutations detected by sequencing method, of which five mutations were novel.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in Korean VHL patients by multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis.

text: Using MLPA analysis, we detected large deletions including both partial deletions and complete gene deletion, which has not been reported in Korean VHL patients.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in Korean VHL patients by multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis.

text: In conclusion, sequential application of sequencing method and MLPA analysis might make possible to identify germline mutations in most patients with VHL.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in Korean VHL patients by multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis.

text: PURPOSE: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) occurs most frequently in individuals older than 60 years of age.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Currently, no biological indicators associated with NSCLC in younger patients (30 to 60 y) have been identified.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: To explore epigenetic influences, promoter methylation of selected tumor suppressor genes was analyzed in early-stage NSCLC patients ranging in age from 30 to 87 years at diagnosis.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: The analysis was performed on formalin-fixed tumor tissue from 193 surgically treated NSCLC patients (127, older than 60 y; 66, 60 y and younger).
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Methylation was quantified in p16, MGMT, DAPK, RASSF1, CDH1, LET7-3-a, NORE1(RASSF5), and PTEN promoters by pyrosequencing.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: p16 protein expression was assessed by immunohistochemistry (IHC).
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Outcome, defined by time to recurrence and overall survival, was evaluated by Kaplan-Meier analysis.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: Promoter methylation levels were generally higher in patients older than 60 years of age than in patients 60 years or younger at diagnosis.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Of the genes tested, methylation levels of the p16 promoter showed age-related differences.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Although p16 promoter methylation was significantly lower using cut-points of 50 years or younger and 40 years or younger (P=0.001 to 0.012, respectively), p16 protein expression increased with age.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Patients 60 years or younger with p16 promoter hypermethylation had a significantly shortened time to recurrence (P=0.002) and a shortened survival time (P=0.011).
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: No effect of p16 hypermethylation was seen in patients older than 60 years.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: p16 promoter hypermethylation was associated with a worse outcome in patients with age at diagnosis of 60 years or younger, but was not associated with the outcome in the older than 60-year age group.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: Overall, these data support methylation-dependent and methylation-independent age-related regulation of p16 expression with differential effects on the outcome after surgical resection for early-stage NSCLC.
title: CDKN2A (p16) promoter hypermethylation influences the outcome in young lung cancer patients.

text: BACKGROUND: ALK gene rearrangement defines a new molecular subtype of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: In a recent phase 1 clinical trial, the ALK tyrosine-kinase inhibitor (TKI) crizotinib showed marked antitumour activity in patients with advanced, ALK-positive NSCLC.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: To assess whether crizotinib affects overall survival in these patients, we did a retrospective study comparing survival outcomes in crizotinib-treated patients in the trial and crizotinib-naive controls screened during the same time period.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: METHODS: We examined overall survival in patients with advanced, ALK-positive NSCLC who enrolled in the phase 1 clinical trial of crizotinib, focusing on the cohort of 82 patients who had enrolled through Feb 10, 2010.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: For comparators, we identified 36 ALK-positive patients from trial sites who were not given crizotinib (ALK-positive controls), 67 patients without ALK rearrangement but positive for EGFR mutation, and 253 wild-type patients lacking either ALK rearrangement or EGFR mutation.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: To assess differences in overall survival, we assessed subsets of clinically comparable ALK-positive and ALK-negative patients.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: FINDINGS: Among 82 ALK-positive patients who were given crizotinib, median overall survival from initiation of crizotinib has not been reached (95% CI 17 months to not reached); 1-year overall survival was 74% (95% CI 63-82), and 2-year overall survival was 54% (40-66).
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: Overall survival did not differ based on age, sex, smoking history, or ethnic origin.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: Survival in 30 ALK-positive patients who were given crizotinib in the second-line or third-line setting was significantly longer than in 23 ALK-positive controls given any second-line therapy (median overall survival not reached [95% CI 14 months to not reached] vs 6 months [4-17], 1-year overall survival 70% [95% CI 50-83] vs 44% [23-64], and 2-year overall survival 55% [33-72] vs 12% [2-30]; hazard ratio 0.36, 95% CI 0.17-0.75; p=0.004).
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: Survival in 56 crizotinib-treated, ALK-positive patients was similar to that in 63 ALK-negative, EGFR-positive patients given EGFR TKI therapy (median overall survival not reached [95% CI 17 months to not reached] vs 24 months [15-34], 1-year overall survival 71% [95% CI 58-81] vs 74% [61-83], and 2-year overall survival 57% [40-71] vs 52% [38-65]; p=0.786), whereas survival in 36 crizotinib-naive, ALK-positive controls was similar to that in 253 wild-type controls (median overall survival 20 months [95% CI 13-26] vs 15 months [13-17]; p=0.244).
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: INTERPRETATION: In patients with advanced, ALK-positive NSCLC, crizotinib therapy is associated with improved survival compared with that of crizotinib-naive controls.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: ALK rearrangement is not a favourable prognostic factor in advanced NSCLC.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: FUNDING: Pfizer Inc, V Foundation for Cancer Research.
title: Effect of crizotinib on overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer harbouring ALK gene rearrangement: a retrospective analysis.

text: Expression of the O(6)-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) gene has been shown to correlate with clinical outcomes in patients with glioblastoma multiforme treated with alkylating agents.
title: O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.

text: We evaluated MGMT protein expression in 53 primary glioblastomas by the immunohistochemistry (IHC) and analyzed the correlation between results of immunostaining and patient outcomes.
title: O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.

text: There were 28 MGMT-immunopositive and 25 negative glioblastomas.
title: O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.

text: Patients with MGMT-immunonegative glioblastomas showed significantly longer progression-free survival (PFS) (P = 0.0032), but no statistically significant benefits on overall survival (OS) (P = 0.0825) were shown.
title: O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.

text: In 41 glioblastomas treated with temozolomide (TMZ) therapy (MGMT-immunopositive: n = 22, negative: n = 19), both PFS and OS were significantly better in MGMT-immunonegative glioblastomas.
title: O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.
O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.

text: We conclude that MGMT expression on immunohistochemistry (IHC) correlates with outcomes in patients with primary glioblastoma receiving TMZ and suggest the use of MGMT-IHC as a surrogate marker for predicting tumor chemosensitivity.
title: O6-methylguanine DNA methyltransferase expression in tumor cells predicts outcome of radiotherapy plus concomitant and adjuvant temozolomide therapy in patients with primary glioblastoma.

text: PURPOSE: The phase III, randomized, placebo-controlled Sequential Tarceva in Unresectable NSCLC (SATURN; BO18192) study found that erlotinib maintenance therapy extended progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who had nonprogressive disease following first-line platinum-doublet chemotherapy.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: This study included prospective analysis of the prognostic and predictive value of several biomarkers.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Mandatory diagnostic tumor specimens were collected before initiating first-line chemotherapy and were tested for epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) protein expression by using immunohistochemistry (IHC), EGFR gene copy number by using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), and EGFR and KRAS mutations by using DNA sequencing.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: An EGFR CA simple sequence repeat in intron 1 (CA-SSR1) polymorphism was evaluated in blood.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: All 889 randomly assigned patients provided tumor samples.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: EGFR IHC, EGFR FISH, KRAS mutation, and EGFR CA-SSR1 repeat length status were not predictive for erlotinib efficacy.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: A profound predictive effect on PFS of erlotinib relative to placebo was observed in the EGFR mutation-positive subgroup (hazard ratio [HR], 0.10; P < .001).
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Significant PFS benefits were also observed with erlotinib in the wild-type EGFR subgroup (HR, 0.78; P = .0185).
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: KRAS mutation status was a significant negative prognostic factor for PFS.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: This large prospective biomarker study found that patients with activating EGFR mutations derive the greatest PFS benefit from erlotinib maintenance therapy.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: No other biomarkers were predictive for outcomes with erlotinib, although the study was not powered for clinical outcomes in biomarker subgroups other than EGFR IHC-positive [corrected].
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: KRAS mutations were prognostic for reduced PFS.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The study demonstrated the feasibility of prospective tissue collection for biomarker analyses in NSCLC.
title: Prospective molecular marker analyses of EGFR and KRAS from a randomized, placebo-controlled study of erlotinib maintenance therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: K-Ras somatic mutations are a strong predictive biomarker for resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitors in patients with colorectal and pancreatic cancer.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: We previously showed that the novel Toll-like receptor 9 (TLR9) agonist immunomodulatory oligonucleotide (IMO) has a strong in vivo activity in colorectal cancer models by interfering with EGFR-related signaling and synergizing with the anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody cetuximab.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: In the present study, we investigated, both in vitro and in vivo, the antitumor effect of IMO alone or in combination with cetuximab in subcutaneous colon and orthotopic pancreatic cancer models harboring K-Ras mutations and resistance to EGFR inhibitors.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: RESULTS: We showed that IMO was able to significantly restore the sensitivity of K-Ras mutant cancer cells to cetuximab, producing a marked inhibition of cell survival and a complete suppression of mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphorylation, when used in combination with cetuximab.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: IMO interfered with EGFR-dependent signaling, modulating the functional interaction between TLR9 and EGFR.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: In vivo, IMO plus cetuximab combination caused a potent and long-lasting cooperative antitumor activity in LS174T colorectal cancer and in orthotopic AsPC1 pancreatic cancer.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: The capability of IMO to restore cetuximab sensitivity was further confirmed by using K-Ras mutant colorectal cancer cell models obtained through homologous recombination technology.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We showed that IMO markedly inhibits growth of K-Ras mutant colon and pancreatic cancers in vitro and in nude mice and cooperates with cetuximab via multiple mechanisms of action.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: Therefore, we propose IMO plus cetuximab as a therapeutic strategy for K-Ras wild-type as well for K-Ras mutant, cetuximab-resistant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.
title: Toll-like receptor 9 agonist IMO cooperates with cetuximab in K-ras mutant colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

text: Purpose Molecular diagnostic testing has become an integral part of the evaluation of patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Expanded mutational testing, such as next-generation sequencing (NGS), often identifies mutations with unclear clinical or prognostic implications.
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: One such example is BRAF mutations that occur outside of codon 600 ((non-V600) BRAF mutations).
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Methods We conducted this multicenter, retrospective cohort study to characterize the clinical, pathologic, and survival implications of (non-V600) BRAF mutations in metastatic CRC.
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: We pooled patients in whom (non-V600) BRAF mutations were identified from NGS databases at three large molecular genetics reference laboratories.
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Results A total of 9,643 patients with metastatic CRC underwent NGS testing.
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: We identified 208 patients with (non-V600) BRAF mutations, which occurred in 2.2% of all patients tested and accounted for 22% of all BRAF mutations identified.
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Cancers with (non-V600) BRAF mutations, compared with cancers with V600E BRAF ((V600E) BRAF) mutations, were found in patients who were significantly younger (58 v 68 years, respectively), fewer female patients (46% v 65%, respectively), and patients who had fewer high-grade tumors (13% v 64%, respectively) or right-sided primary tumors (36% v 81%, respectively).
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Median overall survival was significantly longer in patients with (non-V600) BRAF-mutant metastatic CRC compared with those with both (V600E) BRAF-mutant and wild-type BRAF metastatic CRC (60.7 v 11.4 v 43.0 months, respectively; P < .001).
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: In multivariable analysis, (non-V600) BRAF mutation was independently associated with improved overall survival (hazard ratio, 0.18; P < .001).
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: Conclusion (Non-V600) BRAF mutations occur in approximately 2.2% of patients with metastatic CRC and define a clinically distinct subtype of CRC with an excellent prognosis.
title: (Non-V600) BRAF Mutations Define a Clinically Distinct Molecular Subtype of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.

text: The clinical significance of low-frequent RAS pathway-mutated alleles and the optimal sensitivity cutoff value in the prediction of response to anti-EGFR therapy in metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) patients remains controversial.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: We aimed to evaluate the added value of genotyping an extended RAS panel using a robust nanofluidic digital PCR (dPCR) approach.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: A panel of 34 hotspots, including RAS (KRAS and NRAS exons 2/3/4) and BRAF (V600E), was analyzed in tumor FFPE samples from 102 mCRC patients treated with anti-EGFR therapy.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: dPCR was compared with conventional quantitative PCR (qPCR).
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: Response rates, progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS) were correlated to the mutational status and the mutated allele fraction.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: Tumor response evaluations were not available in 9 patients and were excluded for response rate analysis.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: Twenty-two percent of patients were positive for one mutation with qPCR (mutated alleles ranged from 2.1% to 66.6%).
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: Analysis by dPCR increased the number of positive patients to 47%.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: Mutated alleles for patients only detected by dPCR ranged from 0.04% to 10.8%.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: An inverse correlation between the fraction of mutated alleles and radiologic response was observed.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: ROC analysis showed that a fraction of 1% or higher of any mutated alleles offered the best predictive value for all combinations of RAS and BRAF analysis.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: In addition, this threshold also optimized prediction both PFS and OS.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: We conclude that mutation testing using an extended gene panel, including RAS and BRAF with a threshold of 1% improved prediction of response to anti-EGFR therapy.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: Mol Cancer Ther; 15(5); 1106-12.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: Nanofluidic Digital PCR and Extended Genotyping of RAS and BRAF for Improved Selection of Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Patients for Anti-EGFR Therapies.

text: The oncogenic mechanisms underlying acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in adolescents and young adults (AYA; 15-39 years old) remain largely elusive.
title: Recurrent DUX4 fusions in B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia of adolescents and young adults.

text: Here we have searched for new oncogenes in AYA-ALL by performing RNA-seq analysis of Philadelphia chromosome (Ph)-negative AYA-ALL specimens (n = 73) with the use of a next-generation sequencer.
title: Recurrent DUX4 fusions in B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia of adolescents and young adults.

text: Interestingly, insertion of D4Z4 repeats containing the DUX4 gene into the IGH locus was frequently identified in B cell AYA-ALL, leading to a high level of expression of DUX4 protein with an aberrant C terminus.
title: Recurrent DUX4 fusions in B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia of adolescents and young adults.

text: A transplantation assay in mice demonstrated that expression of DUX4-IGH in pro-B cells was capable of generating B cell leukemia in vivo.
title: Recurrent DUX4 fusions in B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia of adolescents and young adults.

text: DUX4 fusions were preferentially detected in the AYA generation.
title: Recurrent DUX4 fusions in B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia of adolescents and young adults.

text: Our data thus show that DUX4 can become an oncogenic driver as a result of somatic chromosomal rearrangements and that AYA-ALL may be a clinical entity distinct from ALL at other ages.
title: Recurrent DUX4 fusions in B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia of adolescents and young adults.

text: The FLT3 gene is mutated by an internal tandem duplication (ITD) in 20-25% of adults with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: We studied 82 adults <60 years of age with primary AML and normal cytogenetics, who received uniform high-dose therapy and found FLT3 ITD in 23 (28%) patients.
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: When the 23 FLT3 ITD+ cases were compared with the 59 cases with wild-type (WT) FLT3, disease-free survival (DFS) was inferior (P = 0.03), yet overall survival (OS) was not different (P = 0.14).
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: However, 8 (35%) of 23 FLT3 ITD/+ cases also lacked a FLT3 WT allele (FLT3(ITD-R)) as determined by PCR and loss of heterozygosity.
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: Thus, three genotypic groups were identified: normal FLT3(WT/WT), heterozygous FLT3(ITD/WT), and hemizygous FLT3(ITD/-).
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: DFS and OS were significantly inferior for patients with FLT3(ITD/-) (P = 0.0017 and P = 0.0014, respectively).
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: Although DFS and OS for FLT3(WT/WT) and FLT3(ITD/WT) groups did not differ (P = 0.32 and P = 0.98, respectively), OS of the FLT3(ITD/-) group was worse than the FLT3(WT/WT) (P = 0.0005) and FLT3(ITD/WT) (P = 0.008) groups.
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: We propose a model in which FLT3(ITD/-) represents a dominant positive, gain-of-function mutation providing AML cells with a greater growth advantage compared with cells having the FLT3(WT/WT) or FLT3(ITD/WT) genotypes.
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: In conclusion, we have identified the FLT3(ITD/-) genotype as an adverse prognostic factor in de novo AML with normal cytogenetics.
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: A poor prognosis of the relatively young FLT3(ITD/-) adults (median age, 37 years), despite treatment with current dose-intensive regimens, suggests that new treatment modalities, such as therapy with a FLT3 tyrosine kinase inhibitor, are clearly needed for this group of patients.
title: Absence of the wild-type allele predicts poor prognosis in adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia with normal cytogenetics and the internal tandem duplication of FLT3: a cancer and leukemia group B study.

text: PURPOSE: Patients with anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene rearrangements often manifest dramatic responses to crizotinib, a small-molecule ALK inhibitor.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Unfortunately, not every patient responds and acquired drug resistance inevitably develops in those who do respond.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: This study aimed to define molecular mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK(+) non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We analyzed tissue obtained from 14 patients with ALK(+) NSCLC showing evidence of radiologic progression while on crizotinib to define mechanisms of intrinsic and acquired resistance to crizotinib.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Eleven patients had material evaluable for molecular analysis.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Four patients (36%) developed secondary mutations in the tyrosine kinase domain of ALK.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: A novel mutation in the ALK domain, encoding a G1269A amino acid substitution that confers resistance to crizotinib in vitro, was identified in two of these cases.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Two patients, one with a resistance mutation, exhibited new onset ALK copy number gain (CNG).
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: One patient showed outgrowth of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutant NSCLC without evidence of a persistent ALK gene rearrangement.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Two patients exhibited a KRAS mutation, one of which occurred without evidence of a persisting ALK gene rearrangement.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: One patient showed the emergence of an ALK gene fusion-negative tumor compared with the baseline sample but with no identifiable alternate driver.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Two patients retained ALK positivity with no identifiable resistance mechanism.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Crizotinib resistance in ALK(+) NSCLC occurs through somatic kinase domain mutations, ALK gene fusion CNG, and emergence of separate oncogenic drivers.
title: Mechanisms of resistance to crizotinib in patients with ALK gene rearranged non-small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: KRAS codons 12 and 13 mutations predict resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies (moAbs) in metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Also, BRAF V600E mutation has been associated with resistance.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Additional KRAS mutations are described in CRC.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: We investigated the role of KRAS codons 61 and 146 and BRAF V600E mutations in predicting resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in a cohort of KRAS codons 12 and 13 wild-type patients.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Among 87 KRAS codons 12 and 13 wild-type patients, KRAS codons 61 and 146 were mutated in 7 and 1 case, respectively.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: None of mutated patients responded vs 22 of 68 wild type (P=0.096).
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Eleven patients were not evaluable.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: KRAS mutations were associated with shorter progression-free survival (PFS, HR: 0.46, P=0.028).
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: None of 13 BRAF-mutated patients responded vs 24 of 74 BRAF wild type (P=0.016).
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: BRAF mutation was associated with a trend towards shorter PFS (HR: 0.59, P=0.073).
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: In the subgroup of BRAF wild-type patients, KRAS codons 61/146 mutations determined a lower response rate (0 vs 37%, P=0.047) and worse PFS (HR: 0.45, P=0.023).
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Patients bearing KRAS or BRAF mutations had poorer response rate (0 vs 37%, P=0.0005) and PFS (HR: 0.51, P=0.006) compared with KRAS and BRAF wild-type patients.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Assessing KRAS codons 61/146 and BRAF V600E mutations might help optimising the selection of the candidate patients to receive anti-EGFR moAbs.
title: KRAS codon 61, 146 and BRAF mutations predict resistance to cetuximab plus irinotecan in KRAS codon 12 and 13 wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Identification of predictive biomarkers is critically needed to improve selection of patients who derive the most benefit from platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We hypothesized that decreased expression of SMARCA4/BRG1, a known regulator of transcription and DNA repair, is a novel predictive biomarker of increased sensitivity to adjuvant platinum-based therapies in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: The prognostic value was tested using a gene-expression microarray from the Director's Challenge Lung Study (n = 440).
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The predictive significance of SMARCA4 was determined using a gene-expression microarray (n = 133) from control and treatment arms of the JBR.10 trial of adjuvant cisplatin/vinorelbine.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Kaplan-Meier method and log-rank tests were used to estimate and test the differences of probabilities in overall survival (OS) and disease-specific survival (DSS) between expression groups and treatment arms.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Multivariate Cox regression models were used while adjusting for other clinical covariates.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: In the Director's Challenge Study, reduced expression of SMARCA4 was associated with poor OS compared with high and intermediate expression (P < 0.001 and P = 0.009, respectively).
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: In multivariate analysis, compared with low, high SMARCA4 expression predicted a decrease in risk of death [HR, 0.6; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.4-0.8; P = 0.002].
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: In the JBR.10 trial, improved 5-year DSS was noted only in patients with low SMARCA4 expression when treated with adjuvant cisplatin/vinorelbine [HR, 0.1; 95% CI, 0.0-0.5, P = 0.002 (low); HR, 1.0; 95% CI, 0.5-2.3, P = 0.92 (high)].
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: An interaction test was highly significant (P = 0.01).
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Low expression of SMARCA4/BRG1 is significantly associated with worse prognosis; however, it is a novel significant predictive biomarker for increased sensitivity to platinum-based chemotherapy in NSCLC.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 22(10); 2396-404.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: (c)2015 AACR.
title: SMARCA4/BRG1 Is a Novel Prognostic Biomarker Predictive of Cisplatin-Based Chemotherapy Outcomes in Resected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We characterized the mutational status of the FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain (FLT3-TLD) in 3082 patients with newly diagnosed AML.
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: FLT3-TKD mutations were detected in 147 of 3082 (4.8%) patients.
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: Similar to the FLT3 juxtamembrane domain mutations (FLT3-LM), there was a high correlation of FLT3-TKD mutations with normal karyotype (88 of 1472; 6.0%).
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: FLT3-TKD mutations were most frequent in the AML FAB subtypes M5b (15 of 114; 13.2%), M3v (6 of 51; 11.8%), and M4 (39 of 484; 8.1%).
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: Similar to FLT3-LM, the FLT3-TKD mutations show elevated peripheral leukocytes compared with FLT3wt AML.
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: FLT3-TKD had a high incidence in cases with NPM1 mutations (23 of 262; 8.8%), CEBPA mutations (6 of 76; 7.9%), and NRAS mutations (6 of 78; 7.7%).
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: FLT3-TKD in combination with FLT3-LM (17 of 594 patients; 2.9%) and KITD816 (1 of 44; 2.3%) was rare.
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: Unlike the FLT3-LM, which are associated with inferior survival, prognosis was not influenced by FLT3-TKD in the total cohort of 1720 cases, where follow-up data were available (97 FLT3-TKD; 1623 FLT3-WT).
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: In t(15;17)/PML-RARA with FLT3-TKD mutations, in FLT3-LM/TKD double-mutated, and in MLL-PTD/TKD double-mutated cases prognosis was unfavorably influenced by FLT3-TKD mutations.
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: In contrast, we found an additional favorable impact of FLT3-TKD on EFS in prognostically favorable AML with NPM1- or CEBPA mutations.
title: Prognostic relevance of FLT3-TKD mutations in AML: the combination matters--an analysis of 3082 patients.

text: Methylation of CpG island in the promoter has been recognized as an important mechanism for regulation of gene expression.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: Although considerable work has been done on the epigenetic control of tumor suppressor genes, little is known about the potential role of promoter CpG demethylation in the activation of oncogenes.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: The cyclin D2 gene is overexpressed in a subset of gastric carcinoma.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: To determine whether hypomethylation of cyclin D2 is involved in stomach carcinogenesis, we studied methylation of CpG islands in the cyclin D2 gene by methylation-specific PCR in 34 gastric carcinoma specimens, 21 corresponding non-neoplastic mucosae, and 8 gastric carcinoma cell lines.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: We also measured levels of cyclin D2 mRNA in 23 of the gastric carcinoma cases and in the gastric carcinoma cell lines.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: Hypomethylation of the cyclin D2 promoter was found in 24 (71%) of the 34 tumor tissues and in 6 (29%) of the 21 corresponding non-neoplastic mucosa, the incidence being significantly different (p=0.002; Fisher's exact test).
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: Moreover, hypomethylation of cyclin D2 was more common in stage III and IV tumors than in stage I and II tumors (p=00.014; Fisher's exact test).
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: All of three cell lines with promoter hypomethylation expressed detectable levels of cyclin D2 mRNA.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: Treatment of cyclin D2-negative cells lines harboring promoter hypermethylation with demethylating agent, 5-Aza-2'-deoxycytidine, led to a reactivation of cyclin D2 expression.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: These results suggest that DNA hypomethylation is a mechanism underlying the increased expression of cyclin D2 in cancer cells and that demethylation of cyclin D2 may be involved in development and progression of gastric carcinoma.
title: Promoter methylation of cyclin D2 gene in gastric carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: This first-in-human dose-escalation trial evaluated the safety, tolerability, maximal-tolerated dose (MTD), dose-limiting toxicities (DLT), pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and preliminary clinical activity of pictilisib (GDC-0941), an oral, potent, and selective inhibitor of the class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinases (PI3K).
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Sixty patients with solid tumors received pictilisib at 14 dose levels from 15 to 450 mg once-daily, initially on days 1 to 21 every 28 days and later, using continuous dosing for selected dose levels.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Pharmacodynamic studies incorporated (18)F-FDG-PET, and assessment of phosphorylated AKT and S6 ribosomal protein in platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and tumor tissue.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: RESULTS: Pictilisib was well tolerated.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: The most common toxicities were grade 1-2 nausea, rash, and fatigue, whereas the DLT was grade 3 maculopapular rash (450 mg, 2 of 3 patients; 330 mg, 1 of 7 patients).
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: The pharmacokinetic profile was dose-proportional and supported once-daily dosing.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Levels of phosphorylated serine-473 AKT were suppressed >90% in PRP at 3 hours after dose at the MTD and in tumor at pictilisib doses associated with AUC >20 h.mumol/L.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.
