text: Significant increase in plasma insulin and glucose levels, and >25% decrease in (18)F-FDG uptake by PET in 7 of 32 evaluable patients confirmed target modulation.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: A patient with V600E BRAF-mutant melanoma and another with platinum-refractory epithelial ovarian cancer exhibiting PTEN loss and PIK3CA amplification demonstrated partial response by RECIST and GCIG-CA125 criteria, respectively.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: CONCLUSION: Pictilisib was safely administered with a dose-proportional pharmacokinetic profile, on-target pharmacodynamic activity at dose levels >/=100 mg and signs of antitumor activity.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: The recommended phase II dose was continuous dosing at 330 mg once-daily.
title: First-in-human phase I study of pictilisib (GDC-0941), a potent pan-class I phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Induction of compensatory mechanisms and ERK reactivation has limited the effectiveness of Raf and MEK inhibitors in RAS-mutant cancers.
title: Long-Term ERK Inhibition in KRAS-Mutant Pancreatic Cancer Is Associated with MYC Degradation and Senescence-like Growth Suppression.

text: We determined that direct pharmacologic inhibition of ERK suppressed the growth of a subset of KRAS-mutant pancreatic cancer cell lines and that concurrent phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibition caused synergistic cell death.
title: Long-Term ERK Inhibition in KRAS-Mutant Pancreatic Cancer Is Associated with MYC Degradation and Senescence-like Growth Suppression.

text: Additional combinations that enhanced ERK inhibitor action were also identified.
title: Long-Term ERK Inhibition in KRAS-Mutant Pancreatic Cancer Is Associated with MYC Degradation and Senescence-like Growth Suppression.

text: Unexpectedly, long-term treatment of sensitive cell lines caused senescence, mediated in part by MYC degradation and p16 reactivation.
title: Long-Term ERK Inhibition in KRAS-Mutant Pancreatic Cancer Is Associated with MYC Degradation and Senescence-like Growth Suppression.

text: Enhanced basal PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling was associated with de novo resistance to ERK inhibitor, as were other protein kinases identified by kinome-wide siRNA screening and a genetic gain-of-function screen.
title: Long-Term ERK Inhibition in KRAS-Mutant Pancreatic Cancer Is Associated with MYC Degradation and Senescence-like Growth Suppression.

text: Our findings reveal distinct consequences of inhibiting this kinase cascade at the level of ERK.
title: Long-Term ERK Inhibition in KRAS-Mutant Pancreatic Cancer Is Associated with MYC Degradation and Senescence-like Growth Suppression.

text: BACKGROUND: Alectinib--a highly selective, CNS-active, ALK inhibitor-showed promising clinical activity in crizotinib-naive and crizotinib-resistant patients with ALK-rearranged (ALK-positive) non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: We aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of alectinib in patients with ALK-positive NSCLC who progressed on previous crizotinib.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: METHODS: We did a phase 2 study at 27 centres in the USA and Canada.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: We enrolled patients aged 18 years or older with stage IIIB-IV, ALK-positive NSCLC who had progressed after crizotinib.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Patients were treated with oral alectinib 600 mg twice daily until progression, death, or withdrawal.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients achieving an objective response by an independent review committee using Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors, version 1.1.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Response endpoints were assessed in the response-evaluable population (ie, patients with measurable disease at baseline who received at least one dose of study drug), and efficacy and safety analyses were done in the intention-to-treat population (all enrolled patients).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01871805.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: The study is ongoing and patients are still receiving treatment.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Sept 4, 2013, and Aug 4, 2014, 87 patients were enrolled into the study (intention-to-treat population).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: At the time of the primary analysis (median follow-up 4.8 months [IQR 3.3-7.1]), 33 of 69 patients with measurable disease at baseline had a confirmed partial response; thus, the proportion of patients achieving an objective response by the independent review committee was 48% (95% CI 36-60).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Adverse events were predominantly grade 1 or 2, most commonly constipation (31 [36%]), fatigue (29 [33%]), myalgia 21 [24%]), and peripheral oedema 20 [23%]).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: The most common grade 3 and 4 adverse events were changes in laboratory values, including increased blood creatine phosphokinase (seven [8%]), increased alanine aminotransferase (five [6%]), and increased aspartate aminotransferase (four [5%]).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Two patients died: one had a haemorrhage (judged related to study treatment), and one had disease progression and a history of stroke (judged unrelated to treatment).
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Alectinib showed clinical activity and was well tolerated in patients with ALK-positive NSCLC who had progressed on crizotinib.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Therefore, alectinib could be a suitable treatment for patients with ALK-positive disease who have progressed on crizotinib.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: FUNDING: F Hoffmann-La Roche.
title: Alectinib in ALK-positive, crizotinib-resistant, non-small-cell lung cancer: a single-group, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Fusion genes derived from the platelet-derived growth factor receptor beta (PDGFRB) or alpha (PDGFRA) play an important role in the pathogenesis of BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders (CMPDs).
title: Durable responses to imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion gene-positive and BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders.

text: These fusion genes encode constitutively activated receptor tyrosine kinases that can be inhibited by imatinib.
title: Durable responses to imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion gene-positive and BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders.

text: Twelve patients with BCR-ABL-negative CMPDs and reciprocal translocations involving PDGFRB received imatinib for a median of 47 months (range, 0.1-60 months).
title: Durable responses to imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion gene-positive and BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders.

text: Eleven had prompt responses with normalization of peripheral-blood cell counts and disappearance of eosinophilia; 10 had complete resolution of cytogenetic abnormalities and decrease or disappearance of fusion transcripts as measured by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
title: Durable responses to imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion gene-positive and BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders.

text: Updates were sought from 8 further patients previously described in the literature; prompt responses were described in 7 and persist in 6.
title: Durable responses to imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion gene-positive and BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders.

text: Our data show that durable hematologic and cytogenetic responses are achieved with imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion-positive, BCR-ABL-negative CMPDs.
title: Durable responses to imatinib in patients with PDGFRB fusion gene-positive and BCR-ABL-negative chronic myeloproliferative disorders.

text: AIMS: The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a tyrosine kinase (TK) involved in the tumour progression of many cancer types and may serve as an important therapeutic target (erlotinib, cetuximab).
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: Heterogeneity of EGFR amplification and expression could represent a major drawback for anti-EGFR therapy.
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: The aim of this study was performed to determine the potential impact of tumour heterogeneity on anti-EGFR therapy in Barrett's adenocarcinoma (BAC).
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: METHODS AND RESULTS: Tissue microarray (TMA) sections of 112 BAC and 45 lymph node metastases were analysed for EGFR amplification and expression using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and immunohistochemistry (IHC).
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: A subset of 20 samples was also sequenced for EGFR exons 18-21 and Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homologue (KRAS) exons 2-3 mutations.
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: EGFR amplification was seen in seven (6.25%) of 112 interpretable BAC and typically high-level with more than 10-20 EGFR copies per tumour cell (EGFR/centromere 7 ratio >3).
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: EGFR amplification was associated with high pT, pN and poor prognosis (P = 0.0004).
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: Identical EGFR amplification status was found in 29 primary tumours and 29 matched lymph node metastases.
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: Moreover, FISH analysis of three to 16 large sections from all amplified BAC and corresponding lymph node metastases did not reveal any heterogeneity of EGFR amplification.
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: No EGFR mutation but one KRAS mutation was found.
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: CONCLUSION: The high level and homogeneity of EGFR amplification in primary tumours and metastases suggests the potential therapeutic utility of anti-EGFR drugs in BAC.
title: Homogeneous EGFR amplification defines a subset of aggressive Barrett's adenocarcinomas with poor prognosis.

text: Approximately 45% of metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) patients with wild-type KRAS exon 2 are resistant to cetuximab treatment.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: We set out to identify additional genetic markers that might predict the response to cetuximab treatment.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Fifty-three wild-type KRAS exon 2 mCRC patients were treated with cetuximab/irinotecan-based chemotherapy as a first- or third-line therapy.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: The mutational statuses of 10 EGFR pathway genes were analyzed in primary tumors using next-generation sequencing.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: BRAF, PIK3CA, KRAS (exons 3 and 4), NRAS, PTEN, and AKT1 mutations were detected in 6, 6, 5, 4, 1, and 1 patient, respectively.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Four of the BRAF mutations were non-V600 variants.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Four tumors harbored multiple co-existing (complex) mutations.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: All patients with BRAF mutations or complex mutation patterns were cetuximab non-responders.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: All patients but one harboring KRAS, NRAS, or BRAF mutations were non-responders.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Mutations in any one of these three genes were associated with a poor response rate (7.1%) and reduced survival (PFS = 8.0 months) compared to wild-type patients (74.4% and 11.6 months).
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Our data suggest that KRAS, NRAS, and BRAF mutations predict response to cetuximab treatment in mCRC patients.
title: Mutations of KRAS/NRAS/BRAF predict cetuximab resistance in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: BACKGROUND: HER2 mutations and amplifications have been identified as oncogenic drivers in lung cancers.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: Dacomitinib, an irreversible inhibitor of HER2, EGFR (HER1), and HER4 tyrosine kinases, has demonstrated activity in cell-line models with HER2 exon 20 insertions or amplifications.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: Here, we studied dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified lung cancers.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: As a prespecified cohort of a phase II study, we included patients with stage IIIB/IV lung cancers with HER2 mutations or amplification.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: We gave oral dacomitinib at 30-45 mg daily in 28-day cycles.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: End points included partial response rate, overall survival, and toxicity.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: RESULTS: We enrolled 30 patients with HER2-mutant (n = 26, all in exon 20 including 25 insertions and 1 missense mutation) or HER2-amplified lung cancers (n = 4).
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: Three of 26 patients with tumors harboring HER2 exon 20 mutations [12%; 95% confidence interval (CI) 2% to 30%] had partial responses lasting 3+, 11, and 14 months.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: No partial responses occurred in four patients with tumors with HER2 amplifications.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: The median overall survival was 9 months from the start of dacomitinib (95% CI 7-21 months) for patients with HER2 mutations and ranged from 5 to 22 months with amplifications.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: Treatment-related toxicities included diarrhea (90%; grade 3/4: 20%/3%), dermatitis (73%; grade 3/4: 3%/0%), and fatigue (57%; grade 3/4: 3%/0%).
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: One patient died on study likely due to an interaction of dacomitinib with mirtazapine.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Dacomitinib produced objective responses in patients with lung cancers with specific HER2 exon 20 insertions.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: This observation validates HER2 exon 20 insertions as actionable targets and justifies further study of HER2-targeted agents in specific HER2-driven lung cancers.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: CLINICALTRIALSGOV: NCT00818441.
title: Targeting HER2 aberrations as actionable drivers in lung cancers: phase II trial of the pan-HER tyrosine kinase inhibitor dacomitinib in patients with HER2-mutant or amplified tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: Trametinib, an oral mitogen/extracellular signal-related kinase (MEK)1/2 inhibitor, holds promise for malignancies with rat sarcoma (RAS) mutations, like pancreas cancer.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: This phase II study was designed to determine overall survival (OS) in patients with pancreas cancer treated with trametinib and gemcitabine.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: Secondary end-points included progression-free survival (PFS), overall response rate (ORR) and duration of response (DOR); safety end-points were also assessed.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: METHODS: Adults with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were randomised (1:1) to receive intravenous gemcitabine 1000 mg/m(2) (weekly x 7 for 8 weeks, then days 1, 8 and 15 of 28-day cycles) plus trametinib or placebo 2mg daily.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: RAS mutations were determined in circulating free DNA (cfDNA) and archival tumour tissue.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: RESULTS: Baseline characteristics for 160 patients were similar in both treatment arms.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: There was no significant difference in OS (hazard ratio (HR) 0.98; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.67-1.44; P=.453); median OS was 8.4 months with gemcitabine plus trametinib and 6.7 months with gemcitabine plus placebo.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: Median PFS (16 versus 15 weeks), ORR (22% versus 18%) and median DOR (23.9 versus 16.1 weeks) were also similar for trametinib and placebo arms, respectively.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: KRAS mutation-positive patients (n=103) showed no difference in OS between arms.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: Thrombocytopenia, diarrhoea, rash and stomatitis were more frequent with trametinib, as was grade 3 anaemia.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The addition of trametinib to gemcitabine did not improve OS, PFS, ORR or DOR in patients with previously untreated metastatic pancreas cancer.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: Outcomes were independent of KRAS mutations determined by cfDNA.
title: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of trametinib, an oral MEK inhibitor, in combination with gemcitabine for patients with untreated metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

text: The identification and clinical validation of cancer driver genes are essential to accelerate the translational transition of cancer genomics, as well as to find clinically confident targets for the therapeutic intervention of cancers.
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: Here we identified recurrent LMNA-NTRK1 and TPM3-NTRK1 fusions in Korean patients with colon cancer (3 out of 147, 2%) through next-generation RNA sequencing (RNA-seq).
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: NTRK1 fusions were mutually exclusive oncogenic drivers of colon cancer that were accompanied with in vitro potential of colony formation and in vivo tumorigenicity comparable to KM12, a human colon cancer cell line harboring TPM3-NTRK1 fusion.
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: NTRK1-encoded TrkA protein was prevalent in 11 out of 216 Korean (5.1%) and 28 out of 472 Chinese patients (5.9%) from independent cohorts, respectively.
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: The expression level of TrkA was significantly correlated with NTRK1 fusion (p = 0.0192), which was verified by a fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: Korean patients with TrkA-positive colon cancer had a marginal but significant shorter overall survival time than TrkA-negative colon cancer [hazard ratio (HR) = 0.5346, 95% confidential interval (CI) = 0.2548-0.9722, p = 0.0411].
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: In addition, KM12 cell line was sensitive to selective TrkA inhibitors.
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: These results demonstrate that NTRK1 fusion is granted as a clinically relevant target for therapeutic intervention of colon cancer.
title: NTRK1 fusions for the therapeutic intervention of Korean patients with colon cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: We evaluated the safety, pharmacokinetic profile, pharmacodynamic effects, and antitumor activity of abemaciclib, an orally bioavailable inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) 4 and 6, in a multicenter study including phase I dose escalation followed by tumor-specific cohorts for breast cancer, non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), glioblastoma, melanoma, and colorectal cancer.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: A total of 225 patients were enrolled: 33 in dose escalation and 192 in tumor-specific cohorts.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: Dose-limiting toxicity was grade 3 fatigue.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: The maximum tolerated dose was 200 mg every 12 hours.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: The most common possibly related treatment-emergent adverse events involved fatigue and the gastrointestinal, renal, or hematopoietic systems.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: Plasma concentrations increased with dose, and pharmacodynamic effects were observed in proliferating keratinocytes and tumors.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: Radiographic responses were achieved in previously treated patients with breast cancer, NSCLC, and melanoma.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: For hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, the overall response rate was 31%; moreover, 61% of patients achieved either response or stable disease lasting >/=6 months.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: Abemaciclib represents the first selective inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6 with a safety profile allowing continuous dosing to achieve sustained target inhibition.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: This first-in-human experience demonstrates single-agent activity for patients with advanced breast cancer, NSCLC, and other solid tumors.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Abemaciclib, an Inhibitor of CDK4 and CDK6, for Patients with Breast Cancer, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, and Other Solid Tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: Myelodysplastic syndromes are a heterogeneous group of hematopoietic stem cell disorders with a high propensity to transform into acute myeloid leukemia.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: Heterozygous missense mutations in IDH1 at position R132 and in IDH2 at positions R140 and R172 have recently been reported in acute myeloid leukemia.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: However, little is known about the incidence and prognostic impact of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: DESIGN AND METHODS: We examined 193 patients with myelodysplastic syndromes and 53 patients with acute myeloid leukemia arising from myelodysplastic syndromes for mutations in IDH1 (R132), IDH2 (R172 and R140), and NPM1 by direct sequencing.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: RESULTS: We found that mutations in IDH1 occurred with a frequency of 3.6% in myelodysplastic syndromes (7 mutations in 193 patients) and 7.5% in acute myeloid leukemia following myelodysplastic syndromes (4 mutations in 53 patients).
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: Three mutations in codon R140 of IDH2 and one mutation in codon R172 were found in patients with acute myeloid leukemia following myelodysplastic syndromes (7.5%).
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: No IDH2 R140 or R172 mutations were identified in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: The presence of IDH1 mutations was associated with a shorter overall survival (HR 3.20; 95% CI 1.47-6.99) and a higher rate of transformation into acute myeloid leukemia (67% versus 28%, P=0.04).
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: In multivariate analysis when considering karyotype, transfusion dependence and International Prognostic Scoring System score, IDH1 mutations remained an independent prognostic marker in myelodysplastic syndromes (HR 3.57; 95% CI 1.59-8.02; P=0.002).
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that IDH1 mutations are recurrent molecular aberrations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes, and may become useful as a poor risk marker in these patients.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: These findings await validation in prospective trials.
title: IDH1 mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes are associated with an unfavorable prognosis.

text: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small approximately 22nt single stranded RNAs that negatively regulate protein expression by binding to partially complementary sequences in the 3' untranslated region (3' UTRs) of target gene messenger RNAs (mRNA).
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: Recently, mutations have been identified in both miRNAs and target genes that disrupt regulatory relationships, contribute to oncogenesis and serve as biomarkers for cancer risk.
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: KIT, an established oncogene with a multifaceted role in melanogenesis and melanoma pathogenesis, has recently been shown to be upregulated in some melanomas, and is also a target of the miRNA miR-221.
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: Here, we describe a genetic variant in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene that correlates with a greater than fourfold increased risk of acral melanoma.
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: This KIT variant results in a mismatch in the seed region of a miR-221 complementary site and reporter data suggests that this mismatch can result in increased expression of the KIT oncogene.
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: Consistent with the hypothesis that this is a functional variant, KIT mRNA and protein levels are both increased in the majority of samples harboring the KIT variant.
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: This work identifies a novel genetic marker for increased heritable risk of melanoma.
title: A Variant in a MicroRNA complementary site in the 3' UTR of the KIT oncogene increases risk of acral melanoma.

text: PURPOSE: Hallmarks of germline BRCA1/2-associated ovarian carcinomas include chemosensitivity and improved survival.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: The therapeutic impact of somatic BRCA1/2 mutations and mutations in other homologous recombination DNA repair genes is uncertain.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Using targeted capture and massively parallel genomic sequencing, we assessed 390 ovarian carcinomas for germline and somatic loss-of-function mutations in 30 genes, including BRCA1, BRCA2, and 11 other genes in the homologous recombination pathway.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: RESULTS: Thirty-one percent of ovarian carcinomas had a deleterious germline (24%) and/or somatic (9%) mutation in one or more of the 13 homologous recombination genes: BRCA1, BRCA2, ATM, BARD1, BRIP1, CHEK1, CHEK2, FAM175A, MRE11A, NBN, PALB2, RAD51C, and RAD51D.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: Nonserous ovarian carcinomas had similar rates of homologous recombination mutations to serous carcinomas (28% vs. 31%, P = 0.6), including clear cell, endometrioid, and carcinosarcoma.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: The presence of germline and somatic homologous recombination mutations was highly predictive of primary platinum sensitivity (P = 0.0002) and improved overall survival (P = 0.0006), with a median overall survival of 66 months in germline homologous recombination mutation carriers, 59 months in cases with a somatic homologous recombination mutation, and 41 months for cases without a homologous recombination mutation.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Germline or somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes are present in almost one third of ovarian carcinomas, including both serous and nonserous histologies.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: Somatic BRCA1/2 mutations and mutations in other homologous recombination genes have a similar positive impact on overall survival and platinum responsiveness as germline BRCA1/2 mutations.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: The similar rate of homologous recombination mutations in nonserous carcinomas supports their inclusion in PARP inhibitor clinical trials.
title: Germline and somatic mutations in homologous recombination genes predict platinum response and survival in ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal carcinomas.

text: TP53 has been implicated in regulation of the cell cycle, DNA repair, and apoptosis.
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: We studied, in primary breast tumors through direct cDNA sequencing of exons 2-11, whether TP53 gene mutations can predict response in patients with advanced disease to either first-line tamoxifen therapy (202 patients, of whom 55% responded) or up-front (poly)chemotherapy (41 patients, of whom 46% responded).
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: TP53 mutations were detected in 90 of 243 (37%) tumors, and one-fourth of these mutations resulted in a premature termination of the protein.
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: The mutations were observed in 32% (65 of 202) of the primary tumors of tamoxifen-treated patients and in 61% (25 of 41) of the primary tumors of the chemotherapy patients.
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: TP53 mutation was significantly associated with a poor response to tamoxifen [31% versus 66%; odds ratio (OR), 0.22; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.12-0.42; P < 0.0001].
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: Patients with TP53 gene mutations in codons that directly contact DNA or with mutations in the zinc-binding domain loop L3 showed the lowest response to tamoxifen (18% and 15% response rates, respectively).
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: TP53 mutations were related, although not significantly, to a poor response to up-front chemotherapy (36% versus 63%; OR, 0.34; 95% CI, 0.09-1.24).
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: In multivariate analysis for response including the classical parameters age and menopausal status, disease-free interval, dominant site of relapse, and levels of estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor, TP53 mutation was a significant predictor of poor response in the tamoxifen-treated group (OR, 0.29; 95% CI, 0.13-0.63; P = 0.0014).
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: TP53-mutated and estrogen receptor-negative (<10 fmol/mg protein) tumors appeared to be the most resistant phenotype.
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: Interestingly, the response of patients with TP53 mutations to chemotherapy after tamoxifen was not worse than that of patients without these mutations (50% versus 42%; OR, 1.35, nonsignificant).
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: The median progression-free survival after systemic treatment was shorter for patients with a TP53 mutation than for patients with wild-type TP53 (6.6 and 0.6 months less for tamoxifen and up-front chemotherapy, respectively).
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: In conclusion, TP53 gene mutation of the primary tumor is helpful in predicting the response of patients with metastatic breast disease to tamoxifen therapy.
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: The type of mutation and its biological function should be considered in the analyses of the predictive value of TP53.
title: Complete sequencing of TP53 predicts poor response to systemic therapy of advanced breast cancer.

text: In a patient who had metastatic anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)-rearranged lung cancer, resistance to crizotinib developed because of a mutation in the ALK kinase domain.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: This mutation is predicted to result in a substitution of cysteine by tyrosine at amino acid residue 1156 (C1156Y).
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: Her tumor did not respond to a second-generation ALK inhibitor, but it did respond to lorlatinib (PF-06463922), a third-generation inhibitor.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: When her tumor relapsed, sequencing of the resistant tumor revealed an ALK L1198F mutation in addition to the C1156Y mutation.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: The L1198F substitution confers resistance to lorlatinib through steric interference with drug binding.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: However, L1198F paradoxically enhances binding to crizotinib, negating the effect of C1156Y and resensitizing resistant cancers to crizotinib.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: The patient received crizotinib again, and her cancer-related symptoms and liver failure resolved.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: (Funded by Pfizer and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01970865.
title: Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.
Resensitization to Crizotinib by the Lorlatinib ALK Resistance Mutation L1198F.

text: BACKGROUND: Adenocarcinomas of the tongue are rare and represent the minority (20 to 25%) of salivary gland tumors affecting the tongue.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: We investigated the utility of massively parallel sequencing to characterize an adenocarcinoma of the tongue, before and after treatment.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: In the pre-treatment tumor we identified 7,629 genes within regions of copy number gain.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: There were 1,078 genes that exhibited increased expression relative to the blood and unrelated tumors and four genes contained somatic protein-coding mutations.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: Our analysis suggested the tumor cells were driven by the RET oncogene.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: Genes whose protein products are targeted by the RET inhibitors sunitinib and sorafenib correlated with being amplified and or highly expressed.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: Consistent with our observations, administration of sunitinib was associated with stable disease lasting 4 months, after which the lung lesions began to grow.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: Administration of sorafenib and sulindac provided disease stabilization for an additional 3 months after which the cancer progressed and new lesions appeared.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: A recurring metastasis possessed 7,288 genes within copy number amplicons, 385 genes exhibiting increased expression relative to other tumors and 9 new somatic protein coding mutations.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: The observed mutations and amplifications were consistent with therapeutic resistance arising through activation of the MAPK and AKT pathways.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We conclude that complete genomic characterization of a rare tumor has the potential to aid in clinical decision making and identifying therapeutic approaches where no established treatment protocols exist.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: These results also provide direct in vivo genomic evidence for mutational evolution within a tumor under drug selection and potential mechanisms of drug resistance accrual.
title: Evolution of an adenocarcinoma in response to selection by targeted kinase inhibitors.

text: PURPOSE: The clinical relevance of targeting the RAS/RAF/MEK/ERK pathway, activated in 70% to 80% of patients with acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), is unknown.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Selumetinib is an oral small-molecule inhibitor of MAP-ERK kinase (MEK)-1/2.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: Forty-seven patients with relapsed/refractory AML or 60 years old or more with untreated AML were enrolled on a phase II study.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: Patients were stratified by FLT3 ITD mutation status.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: The primary endpoint was response rate (complete, partial, and minor).
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: Leukemia cells were analyzed for extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) and mTOR phosphorylation.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: RESULTS: Common drug-related toxicities were grade 1-2 diarrhea, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and skin rash.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: In the FLT3 wild-type cohort, six of 36 (17%) patients had a response [one partial response, three minor responses, two unconfirmed minor responses (uMR)].
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: No patient with FLT3 ITD responded.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: NRAS and KRAS mutations were detected in 7% and 2% of patients, respectively.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: The sole patient with KRAS mutation had uMR with hematologic improvement in platelets.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: Baseline p-ERK activation was observed in 85% of patients analyzed but did not correlate with a response.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: A single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs3733542 in exon 18 of the KIT gene was detected in significantly higher number of patients with response/stable disease compared with nonresponders (60% vs. 23%; P = 0.027).
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Selumetinib is associated with modest single-agent antileukemic activity in advanced AML.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: However, given its favorable toxicity profile, combination with drugs that target other signaling pathways in AML should be considered.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: The potential association of SNP rs3733542 in exon 18 of the KIT gene with antileukemic activity of selumetinib is intriguing, but will require validation in larger trials.
title: Phase II study of the oral MEK inhibitor selumetinib in advanced acute myelogenous leukemia: a University of Chicago phase II consortium trial.

text: Inhibitors of the kinase mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) have shown sporadic activity in cancer trials, leading to confusion about the appropriate clinical setting for their use.
title: Hypoxia-inducible factor determines sensitivity to inhibitors of mTOR in kidney cancer.

text: Here we show that loss of the Von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene (VHL) sensitizes kidney cancer cells to the mTOR inhibitor CCI-779 in vitro and in mouse models.
title: Hypoxia-inducible factor determines sensitivity to inhibitors of mTOR in kidney cancer.

text: Growth arrest caused by CCI-779 correlates with a block in translation of mRNA encoding hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF1A), and is rescued by expression of a VHL-resistant HIF1A cDNA lacking the 5' untranslated region.
title: Hypoxia-inducible factor determines sensitivity to inhibitors of mTOR in kidney cancer.

text: VHL-deficient tumors show increased uptake of the positron emission tomography (PET) tracer fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in an mTOR-dependent manner.
title: Hypoxia-inducible factor determines sensitivity to inhibitors of mTOR in kidney cancer.

text: Our findings provide preclinical rationale for prospective, biomarker-driven clinical studies of mTOR inhibitors in kidney cancer and suggest that FDG-PET scans may have use as a pharmacodynamic marker in this setting.
title: Hypoxia-inducible factor determines sensitivity to inhibitors of mTOR in kidney cancer.

text: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (ALK + DLBCL) is a rare and poorly characterized subtype of lymphoma.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: Reports suggest that this type of tumor responds poorly to standard regimens for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, with rituximab playing no therapeutic role due to the absence of CD20 expression.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: In view of the expression of ALK in this disease, it is plausible that the ALK inhibitor crizotinib may be an effective treatment.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: We report a case of a 21-year-old male ALK + DLBCL patient.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: He initially received five cycles of CHOP-21 (vincristine, pirarubicin, cyclophosphamide and prednisone) and achieved a partial remission (PR) but soon deteriorated.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: He was subsequently treated with five courses of the salvage chemotherapy regimen ICE (ifosfamide, carboplatin and etoposide) and achieved PR again.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: He refused to accept an autologous stem-cell transplantation, after which the disease progressed rapidly.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: We administered two courses of an alternative salvage chemotherapy regimen containing GEMOX and dexamethasone with the addition of the ALK inhibitor crizotinib.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: His symptoms alleviated for a short time but soon worsened and the patient died of massive progressive disease.
title: Promising response of anaplastic lymphoma kinase-positive large B-cell lymphoma to crizotinib salvage treatment: case report and review of literature.

text: The Hedgehog (Hh) signaling pathway is inappropriately activated in certain human cancers, including medulloblastoma, an aggressive brain tumor.
title: Smoothened mutation confers resistance to a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor in medulloblastoma.

text: GDC-0449, a drug that inhibits Hh signaling by targeting the serpentine receptor Smoothened (SMO), has produced promising anti-tumor responses in early clinical studies of cancers driven by mutations in this pathway.
title: Smoothened mutation confers resistance to a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor in medulloblastoma.

text: To evaluate the mechanism of resistance in a medulloblastoma patient who had relapsed after an initial response to GDC-0449, we determined the mutational status of Hh signaling genes in the tumor after disease progression.
title: Smoothened mutation confers resistance to a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor in medulloblastoma.

text: We identified an amino acid substitution at a conserved aspartic acid residue of SMO that had no effect on Hh signaling but disrupted the ability of GDC-0449 to bind SMO and suppress this pathway.
title: Smoothened mutation confers resistance to a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor in medulloblastoma.

text: A mutation altering the same amino acid also arose in a GDC-0449-resistant mouse model of medulloblastoma.
title: Smoothened mutation confers resistance to a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor in medulloblastoma.

text: These findings show that acquired mutations in a serpentine receptor with features of a G protein-coupled receptor can serve as a mechanism of drug resistance in human cancer.
title: Smoothened mutation confers resistance to a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor in medulloblastoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Ibrutinib is an irreversible inhibitor of Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) and is effective in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: Resistance to irreversible kinase inhibitors and resistance associated with BTK inhibition have not been characterized.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: Although only a small proportion of patients have had a relapse during ibrutinib therapy, an understanding of resistance mechanisms is important.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: We evaluated patients with relapsed disease to identify mutations that may mediate ibrutinib resistance.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: METHODS: We performed whole-exome sequencing at baseline and the time of relapse on samples from six patients with acquired resistance to ibrutinib therapy.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: We then performed functional analysis of identified mutations.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: In addition, we performed Ion Torrent sequencing for identified resistance mutations on samples from nine patients with prolonged lymphocytosis.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: RESULTS: We identified a cysteine-to-serine mutation in BTK at the binding site of ibrutinib in five patients and identified three distinct mutations in PLCgamma2 in two patients.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: Functional analysis showed that the C481S mutation of BTK results in a protein that is only reversibly inhibited by ibrutinib.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: The R665W and L845F mutations in PLCgamma2 are both potentially gain-of-function mutations that lead to autonomous B-cell-receptor activity.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: These mutations were not found in any of the patients with prolonged lymphocytosis who were taking ibrutinib.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Resistance to the irreversible BTK inhibitor ibrutinib often involves mutation of a cysteine residue where ibrutinib binding occurs.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: This finding, combined with two additional mutations in PLCgamma2 that are immediately downstream of BTK, underscores the importance of the B-cell-receptor pathway in the mechanism of action of ibrutinib in CLL.
title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

title: Resistance mechanisms for the Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor ibrutinib.

text: BACKGROUND: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)--tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) is used for the patients with EGFR-mutant lung cancer.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: Recently, phase III studies in the patients with EGFR-mutant demonstrated that EGFR-TKI monotherapy improved progression-free survival compared with platinum-doublet chemotherapy.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: The echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4)--anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) fusion oncogene represents one of the newest molecular targets in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: Patients who harbor EML4-ALK fusions have been associated with a lack of EGFR or KRAS mutations.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: CASE PRESENTATION: We report a 39-year-old patient diagnosed as adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: We treated this patient with erlotinib as the third line therapy, but no clinical benefit was obtained.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: CONCLUSION: We experienced a rare case with EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: Any clinical benefit using EGFR-TKI was not obtained in our case.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: The therapeutic choice for the patients with more than one driver mutations is unclear.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: We needs further understanding of the lung cancer molecular biology and the biomarker information.
title: A case of lung adenocarcinoma harboring EGFR mutation and EML4-ALK fusion gene.

text: PURPOSE: FGFR1 gene copy number (GCN) is being evaluated as a biomarker for FGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) response in squamous cell lung cancers (SCC).
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: The exclusive use of FGFR1 GCN for predicting FGFR TKI sensitivity assumes increased GCN is the only mechanism for biologically relevant increases in FGFR1 signaling.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: Herein, we tested whether FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression may serve as better biomarkers of FGFR TKI sensitivity in lung cancer.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Histologically diverse lung cancer cell lines were submitted to assays for ponatinib sensitivity, a potent FGFR TKI.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: A tissue microarray composed of resected lung tumors was submitted to FGFR1 GCN, and mRNA analyses and the results were validated with The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) lung cancer data.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: RESULTS: Among 58 cell lines, 14 exhibited ponatinib sensitivity (IC50 values </= 50 nmol/L) that correlated with FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, but not with FGFR1 GCN or histology.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: Moreover, ponatinib sensitivity associated with mRNA expression of the ligands, FGF2 and FGF9.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: In resected tumors, 22% of adenocarcinomas and 28% of SCCs expressed high FGFR1 mRNA.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: Importantly, only 46% of SCCs with increased FGFR1 GCN expressed high mRNA.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: Lung cancer TCGA data validated these findings and unveiled overlap of FGFR1 mRNA positivity with KRAS and PIK3CA mutations.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: CONCLUSIONS: FGFR1 dependency is frequent across various lung cancer histologies, and FGFR1 mRNA may serve as a better biomarker of FGFR TKI response in lung cancer than FGFR1 GCN.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: The study provides important and timely insight into clinical testing of FGFR TKIs in lung cancer and other solid tumor types.
title: FGFR1 mRNA and protein expression, not gene copy number, predict FGFR TKI sensitivity across all lung cancer histologies.

text: PURPOSE: Oncogenic signaling in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) is sustained via PI3K/AKT pathway.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: We used a panel of six GIST xenograft models to assess efficacy of GDC-0941 as single agent or in combination with imatinib (IMA).
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Nude mice (n = 136) were grafted bilaterally with human GIST carrying diverse KIT mutations.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Mice were orally dosed over four weeks, grouped as follows: (A) control; (B) GDC-0941; (C) imatinib, and (D) GDC+IMA treatments.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Xenografts regrowth after treatment discontinuation was assessed in groups C and D for an additional four weeks.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Tumor response was assessed by volume measurements, micro-PET imaging, histopathology, and immunoblotting.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Moreover, genomic alterations in PTEN/PI3K/AKT pathway were evaluated.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: RESULTS: In all models, GDC-0941 caused tumor growth stabilization, inhibiting tumor cell proliferation, but did not induce apoptosis.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Under GDC+IMA, profound tumor regression, superior to either treatment alone, was observed.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: This effect was associated with the best histologic response, a nearly complete proliferation arrest and increased apoptosis.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Tumor regrowth assays confirmed superior activity of GDC+IMA over imatinib; in three of six models, tumor volume remained reduced and stable even after treatment discontinuation.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: A positive correlation between response to GDC+IMA and PTEN loss, both on gene and protein levels, was found.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: CONCLUSION: GDC+IMA has significant antitumor efficacy in GIST xenografts, inducing more substantial tumor regression, apoptosis, and durable effects than imatinib.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Notably, after treatment withdrawal, tumor regression was sustained in tumors exposed to GDC+IMA, which was not observed under imatinib.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Assessment of PTEN status may represent a useful predictive biomarker for patient selection.
title: A potent combination of the novel PI3K Inhibitor, GDC-0941, with imatinib in gastrointestinal stromal tumor xenografts: long-lasting responses after treatment withdrawal.

text: Programmed cell death 1 ligand 1 (PD-L1) is a promising therapeutic target for cancer immunotherapy.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: However, the correlation between PD-L1 and breast cancer survival remains unclear.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: Here, we present the first meta-analysis to investigate the prognostic value of PD-L1 in breast cancer.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: We searched Pubmed, Embase, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials databases for relevant studies evaluating PD-L1 expression and breast cancer survival.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: Fixed- and random-effect meta-analyses were conducted based on heterogeneity of included studies.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: Publication bias was evaluated by funnel plot and Begg's test.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: Overall, nine relevant studies with 8583 patients were included.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: PD-L1 overexpression was found in 25.8% of breast cancer patients.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: PD-L1 (+) associated with several high-risk prognostic indicators, such as ductal cancer (p = 0.037), high tumor grade (p = 0.000), ER negativity (p = 0.000), PR negativity (p = 0.000), HER2 positivity (p = 0.001) and aggressive molecular subtypes (HER2-rich and Basal-like p = 0.000).
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: PD-L1 overexpression had no significant impact on metastasis-free survival (HR 0.924, 95% CI = 0.747-1.141, p = 0.462), disease-free survival (HR 1.122, 95% CI = 0.878-1.434, p = 0.357) and overall specific survival (HR 0.837, 95% CI = 0.640-1.093, p = 0.191), but significantly correlated with shortened overall survival (HR 1.573, 95% CI = 1.010-2.451, p = 0.045).
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: PD-L1 overexpression in breast cancer associates with multiple clinicopathological parameters that indicated poor outcome, and may increase the risk for mortality.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: Further standardization of PD-L1 assessment assay and well-controlled clinical trials are warranted to clarify its prognostic and therapeutic value.
title: Prognostic Value of PD-L1 in Breast Cancer: A Meta-Analysis.

text: Follicular lymphoma (FL), an indolent neoplasm caused by a t(14;18) chromosomal translocation that juxtaposes the BCL2 gene and immunoglobulin locus, has a variable clinical course and frequently undergoes transformation to an aggressive lymphoma.
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: Although BCL2 mutations have been previously described, their relationship to FL progression remains unclear.
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: In this study, we evaluated the frequency and nature of BCL2 mutations in 2 independent cohorts of grade 1 and 2 FLs, along with the correlation between BCL2 mutations, transformation risk, and survival.
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: The prevalence of BCL2 coding sequence mutations was 12% in FL at diagnosis and 53% at transformation (P < .0001).
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: The presence of these BCL2 mutations at diagnosis correlated with an increased risk of transformation (hazard ratio 3.6; 95% CI, 2.0-6.2; P < .0001) and increased risk of death due to lymphoma (median survival of 9.5 years with BCL2 mutations vs 20.4 years without; P = .012).
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: In a multivariate analysis, BCL2 mutations and high FL international prognostic index were independent risk factors for transformation and death due to lymphoma.
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: Some mutant Bcl-2 proteins exhibited enhanced antiapoptotic capacity in vitro.
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: Accordingly, BCL2 mutations can affect antiapoptotic Bcl-2 function, are associated with increased activation-induced cytidine deaminase expression, and correlate with increased risk of transformation and death due to lymphoma.
title: BCL2 mutations are associated with increased risk of transformation and shortened survival in follicular lymphoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Kinase inhibitors targeting the BRAF V600 mutation have become standard in the treatment of metastatic melanoma.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: Albeit in wide clinical use, the patterns associated with therapy outcome are not fully elucidated.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: The present study was aimed to identify predictive factors of therapy response and survival under the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: This multicenter retrospective study analyzed patient, tumor, and pretreatment characteristics collected in BRAF V600-mutated stage IV melanoma patients before single-agent therapy with the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: RESULTS: A total of 300 patients from 14 centers were included into this study with a median follow-up time of 13.0 months.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: Median progression-free survival (PFS) was 5.1 months; median overall survival (OS) was 7.6 months.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: Best response under vemurafenib was associated with serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH; </= versus >upper normal limit; P = 0.0000001), Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) overall performance status (OPS) (0 versus >/= 1; P = 0.00089), and BRAF mutation subtype (V600E versus V600K; P = 0.016).
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: Multivariate analysis identified ECOG OPS >/= 1 [hazard ratio (HR) = 1.88; P = 0.00005], immunotherapy pretreatment (HR = 0.53; P = 0.0067), elevated serum LDH (HR = 1.45; P = 0.012), age >55 years (HR = 0.72; P = 0.019), and chemotherapy pretreatment (HR = 1.39; P = 0.036) as independent predictors of PFS.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: For OS, elevated serum LDH (HR = 1.99; P = 0.00012), ECOG OPS >/= 1 (HR = 1.90; P = 0.00063), age >55 years (HR = 0.65; P = 0.011), kinase inhibitor pretreatment (HR = 1.86; P = 0.014), immunotherapy pretreatment (HR = 0.57; P = 0.025), chemotherapy pretreatment (HR = 2.17; P = 0.039), and male gender (HR = 0.70; 95% confidence interval 0.50-0.98; P = 0.039) were found as predictors.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: CONCLUSION: Our data demonstrate that the type of pretreatment strongly influences the outcome of vemurafenib therapy, with a precedent immunotherapy showing a positive, and a prior chemotherapy and kinase inhibitors showing a negative impact on survival, respectively.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: Moreover, we show that the patient's OPS, serum LDH, age, and gender independently impact vemurafenib therapy outcome.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: These findings should be taken into account for the future design of therapy sequencing in BRAF V600 mutation-positive melanoma patients.
title: A multicenter DeCOG study on predictors of vemurafenib therapy outcome in melanoma: pretreatment impacts survival.

text: BACKGROUND: Approximately 75% of objective responses to anti-programmed death 1 (PD-1) therapy in patients with melanoma are durable, lasting for years, but delayed relapses have been noted long after initial objective tumor regression despite continuous therapy.
title: Mutations Associated with Acquired Resistance to PD-1 Blockade in Melanoma.

text: Mechanisms of immune escape in this context are unknown.
title: Mutations Associated with Acquired Resistance to PD-1 Blockade in Melanoma.
