text: Frameshift, nonsense, missense mutations, or defects in gene structure were identified in 22 (22.9%) of 96 patients (95% confidence interval [CI], 14.5-31.3 patients).
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: Mutated and unmutated patients did not significantly differ in initial clinical or hematologic parameters.
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: The 5-year OS was 76.9% (95% CI, 49.2%-91.3%) in mutated versus 18.3% (95% CI, 4.2%-41.1%) in unmutated patients (P = .005).
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: The 3-year leukemia-free survival was 89.3% (95% CI, 63.1%-97.0%) in mutated versus 63.7% (95% CI, 48.2%-75.4%) in unmutated patients (P = .035).
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: In univariate analysis (Cox proportional hazard model), the absence of TET2 mutation was associated with a 4.1-fold (95% CI, 1.4-12.0-fold) increased risk of death (P = .009).
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: In multivariate analysis adjusted for age, International Prognostic Scoring System, and transfusion requirement, the presence of TET2 mutation remained an independent factor of favorable prognosis (hazard ratio, 5.2; 95% CI, 1.6-16.3; P = .005).
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: These results indicate that TET2 mutations observed in approximately 20% of patients, irrespective of the World Health Organization or French-American-British subtype, represent a molecular marker for good prognosis in MDS.
title: TET2 mutation is an independent favorable prognostic factor in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDSs).

text: BACKGROUND: Tumor human papillomavirus (HPV) status is an important prognostic factor in locoregionally advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN).
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: Prognostic value in recurrent and/or metastatic (R/M) disease remains to be confirmed.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: This retrospective analysis of the EXTREME trial, comparing chemotherapy plus cetuximab with chemotherapy first line in R/M SCCHN, investigated efficacy and prognosis according to tumor p16 and HPV status.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Paired tissue samples were used: p16INK4A expression was assessed by immunohistochemistry, and HPV status determined in extracted DNA samples using oligonucleotide hybridization assays.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: RESULTS: Altogether, 416 of 442 patients had tumor samples available for p16 and HPV: 10% of tumors were p16 positive and 5% were HPV positive.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: Adding cetuximab to chemotherapy improved survival, irrespective of tumor p16 or HPV status.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: This pattern remained in a combined analysis of p16 and HPV.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: p16 positivity and HPV positivity were associated with prolonged survival compared with p16 negativity and HPV negativity.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: Subgroup analysis of patients with oropharyngeal cancer demonstrated a similar pattern to all evaluable patients.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: CONCLUSION: The results from this analysis suggest that p16 and HPV status have prognostic value in R/M SCCHN and survival benefits of chemotherapy plus cetuximab over chemotherapy alone are independent of tumor p16 and HPV status.
title: Impact of tumor HPV status on outcome in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck receiving chemotherapy with or without cetuximab: retrospective analysis of the phase III EXTREME trial.

text: Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) carries an unfavorable prognosis and requires new treatment strategies.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: The associated t(11:14) translocation results in enhanced cyclin D1 expression and cyclin D1-dependent kinase activity to promote cell-cycle progression.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: A pharmacodynamic study of the selective CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 was conducted in 17 patients with relapsed disease, using 2-deoxy-2-[(18)F]fluoro-D-glucose (FDG) and 3-deoxy-3[(18)F]fluorothymidine (FLT) positron emission tomography (PET) to study tumor metabolism and proliferation, respectively, in concert with pre- and on-treatment lymph node biopsies to assess retinoblastoma protein (Rb) phosphorylation and markers of proliferation and apoptosis.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Substantial reductions in the summed FLT-PET maximal standard uptake value (SUV(max)), as well as in Rb phosphorylation and Ki-67 expression, occurred after 3 weeks in most patients, with significant correlations among these end points.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Five patients achieved progression-free survival time of > 1 year (range, 14.9-30.1+ months), with 1 complete and 2 partial responses (18% objective response rate; 90% confidence interval, 5%-40%).
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: These patients demonstrated > 70%, > 90%, and >/= 87.5% reductions in summed FLT SUV(max) and expression of phospho-Rb and Ki67, respectively, parameters necessary but not sufficient for long-term disease control.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: The results of the present study confirm CDK4/6 inhibition by PD0332991 at a well-tolerated dose and schedule and suggest clinical benefit in a subset of MCL patients.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: This study is registered at www.clinicaltrials.gov under identifier NCT00420056.
title: Selective CDK4/6 inhibition with tumor responses by PD0332991 in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are characterized by the presence of somatic DICER1 hotspot mutations.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: In this study, we sought to define the association between DICER1 hotspot mutations and different morphologic subtypes of ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: Furthermore, we aimed to assess whether DICER1 hotspot mutations occur in other ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors, testicular sex cord-stromal tumors, or other female genital tract tumors with rhabdomyosarcomatous differentiation.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: We subjected a series of ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors (n=32), Sertoli cell tumors (n=5) and gynandroblastomas (n=5), testicular sex cord-stromal tumors (n=15) and a diverse group of female genital tract tumors with rhabdomyosarcomatous morphology (n=10) to DICER1 hotspot mutation analysis using Sanger sequencing.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: We also tested two gynandroblastomas for the presence of FOXL2 hotspot mutations (p.C134W; c.402C>G).
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: Twenty of 32 (63%) Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors harbored a DICER1 hotspot mutation, of which 80% had the p.E1705K mutation.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: No association was found between DICER1 mutation status and the presence of heterologous or retiform differentiation in Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: DICER1 mutations were found at similar frequencies in gynandroblastoma (2/5; 40%) and ovarian Sertoli cell tumors (5/8; 63%; P>0.1), and all mutated tumors harbored a p.E1705K mutation.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: DICER1 hotspot mutations were also identified in a single cervical rhabdomyosarcoma and in the rhabdomyosarcomatous component of a uterine carcinosarcoma.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: No DICER1 mutations were detected in testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: Two DICER1 wild-type gynandroblastomas harbored a p.C134W FOXL2 hotspot mutation in both tumor components.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: In this study we confirmed that DICER1 hotspot mutations occur in over half of ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, and are unrelated to tumor differentiation.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: We also widened the spectrum of ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors with sertoliform differentiation, in which DICER1 mutations are known to occur, to include Sertoli cell tumors and gynandroblastomas.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: Our results suggest that DICER1 mutations may not have a role in testicular sex cord-stromal tumorigenesis.
title: A survey of DICER1 hotspot mutations in ovarian and testicular sex cord-stromal tumors.

text: PURPOSE: mTOR is a validated target in cancer.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: It remains to be determined whether melanoma patients bearing mTOR mutation could be selected for treatment with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibitors.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: A total of 412 melanoma samples were included.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: Gene aberrations in all exons of mTOR were detected by Sanger sequencing and confirmed by using Agilent's SureSelect Target Enrichment System.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: HEK293T cells stably expressing mTOR mutants were constructed by using transcription activator-like effector nucleases technique.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: Function of mTOR mutants and in vitro sensitivity of gain-of-function mTOR mutations to PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibitors were analyzed.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: The overall incidence of somatic nonsynonymous mutations of mTOR was 10.4% (43/412).
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: mTOR nonsynonymous mutations were relatively more frequent in acral (11.0%) and mucosal (14.3%) melanomas than in chronic sun-induced damage (CSD; 6.7%) and non-CSD (3.4%) melanomas.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: Of the 43 cases with mTOR mutations, 41 different mutations were detected, affecting 25 different exons.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: The median survival time for melanoma patients with mTOR nonsynonymous mutation was significantly shorter than that for patients without mTOR nonsynonymous mutation (P = 0.028).
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: Transient expression of mTOR mutants in HEK293T cells strongly activated the mTOR-p70S6K pathway.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: In HEK293T cells with stable expression of H1968Y or P2213S mTOR mutants, LY294002 and AZD5363 showed higher potency than temsirolimus or BYL719 in inhibiting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway and cell proliferation.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: mTOR nonsynonymous mutations are frequent in melanoma patients.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: mTOR nonsynonymous mutation may predict a worse prognosis of melanoma.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: Clinical trials with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibitors may be beneficial for melanoma patients with specific mTOR mutations.
title: Analysis of mTOR Gene Aberrations in Melanoma Patients and Evaluation of Their Sensitivity to PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway Inhibitors.

text: BACKGROUND: Myelodysplastic syndromes are a diverse and common group of chronic hematologic cancers.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: The identification of new genetic lesions could facilitate new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: METHODS: We used massively parallel sequencing technology to identify somatically acquired point mutations across all protein-coding exons in the genome in 9 patients with low-grade myelodysplasia.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: Targeted resequencing of the gene encoding RNA splicing factor 3B, subunit 1 (SF3B1), was also performed in a cohort of 2087 patients with myeloid or other cancers.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: RESULTS: We identified 64 point mutations in the 9 patients.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: Recurrent somatically acquired mutations were identified in SF3B1.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: Follow-up revealed SF3B1 mutations in 72 of 354 patients (20%) with myelodysplastic syndromes, with particularly high frequency among patients whose disease was characterized by ring sideroblasts (53 of 82 [65%]).
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: The gene was also mutated in 1 to 5% of patients with a variety of other tumor types.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: The observed mutations were less deleterious than was expected on the basis of chance, suggesting that the mutated protein retains structural integrity with altered function.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: SF3B1 mutations were associated with down-regulation of key gene networks, including core mitochondrial pathways.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: Clinically, patients with SF3B1 mutations had fewer cytopenias and longer event-free survival than patients without SF3B1 mutations.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Mutations in SF3B1 implicate abnormalities of messenger RNA splicing in the pathogenesis of myelodysplastic syndromes.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: (Funded by the Wellcome Trust and others.
title: Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.
Somatic SF3B1 mutation in myelodysplasia with ring sideroblasts.

text: BACKGROUND: Despite good initial response to chemotherapy, 30% of Ewing's sarcoma (EWS) patients with localised tumours develop recurrent disease, associated with poor prognosis.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: The aim of this study was to address this challenge by conducting preclinical evaluation of a death receptor targeted agent in vitro and in vivo, and by identifying predictive biomarkers.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: METHODS: Cell viability assays, drug dose responses, immunoblots, rescue with gene transfer, mice tumour models, and statistical comparisons of tumour growth and Kaplan-Meier survival curves.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: RESULTS: This study shows that many EWS cell lines are selectively sensitive to a death receptor DR5 antibody and are more resistant to a DR4 antibody.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Preclinical evaluation of these cell lines indicates their sensitivity to human DR5 agonist antibody conatumumab in vitro, which induces rapid activation of caspase-8 and apoptosis.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: We also found that sensitivity to conatumumab correlates with expression of caspase-8.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Furthermore, the catalytic activity of caspase-8 is both necessary and sufficient to confer this sensitivity.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: In vivo, conatumumab is active against an EWS cell line and a patient-derived xenograft with higher caspase-8 expression, but is not effective against another with lower caspase-8 expression.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These studies suggest the potential of conatumumab as a therapeutic agent against EWS and caspase-8 as a predictive biomarker for sensitivity.
title: Caspase-8 expression is predictive of tumour response to death receptor 5 agonist antibody in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate the clinical activity of sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3)-internal tandem duplication (ITD)-positive acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) and monitor the emergence of secondary FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain (TKD) mutations during treatment.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Six children with relapsed/refractory AML were treated with sorafenib in combination with clofarabine and cytarabine, followed by single-agent sorafenib if not a candidate for transplantation.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Sunitinib was initiated after sorafenib relapse.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Bone marrow samples were obtained for assessment of FLT3 TKD mutations by deep amplicon sequencing.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The phase of secondary mutations with ITD alleles was assessed by cloning and sequencing of FLT3 exons 14 through 20.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Identified mutations were modeled in Ba/F3 cells, and the effect of kinase inhibitors on FLT3 signaling and cell viability was assessed.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: RESULTS: Four patients achieved complete remission, but 3 receiving maintenance therapy with sorafenib relapsed after 14 to 37 weeks.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Sunitinib reduced circulating blasts in two patients and marrow blasts in one.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Two patients did not respond to sorafenib combination therapy or sunitinib.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: FLT3 mutations at residues D835 and F691 were observed in sorafenib resistance samples on both ITD-positive and -negative alleles.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Deep sequencing revealed low-level mutations and their evolution during sorafenib treatment.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Sunitinib suppressed leukemic clones with D835H and F691L mutations, but not D835Y.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Cells expressing sorafenib-resistant FLT3 mutations were sensitive to sunitinib in vitro.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Sunitinib has activity in patients that are resistant to sorafenib and harbor secondary FLT3 TKD mutations.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The use of sensitive methods to monitor FLT3 mutations during therapy may allow individualized treatment with the currently available kinase inhibitors.
title: Emergence of polyclonal FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations during sequential therapy with sorafenib and sunitinib in FLT3-ITD-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We have investigated the potential for the p16-cyclin D-CDK4/6-retinoblastoma protein pathway to be exploited as a therapeutic target in melanoma.
title: Loss of CDKN2A expression is a frequent event in primary invasive melanoma and correlates with sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 in melanoma cell lines.

text: In a cohort of 143 patients with primary invasive melanoma, we used fluorescence in situ hybridization to detect gene copy number variations (CNVs) in CDK4, CCND1, and CDKN2A and immunohistochemistry to determine protein expression.
title: Loss of CDKN2A expression is a frequent event in primary invasive melanoma and correlates with sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 in melanoma cell lines.

text: CNVs were common in melanoma, with gain of CDK4 or CCND1 in 37 and 18% of cases, respectively, and hemizygous or homozygous loss of CDKN2A in 56%.
title: Loss of CDKN2A expression is a frequent event in primary invasive melanoma and correlates with sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 in melanoma cell lines.

text: Three-quarters of all patients demonstrated a CNV in at least one of the three genes.
title: Loss of CDKN2A expression is a frequent event in primary invasive melanoma and correlates with sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 in melanoma cell lines.

text: The combination of CCND1 gain with either a gain of CDK4 and/or loss of CDKN2A was associated with poorer melanoma-specific survival.
title: Loss of CDKN2A expression is a frequent event in primary invasive melanoma and correlates with sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 in melanoma cell lines.

text: In 47 melanoma cell lines homozygous loss, methylation or mutation of CDKN2A gene or loss of protein (p16(INK) (4A) ) predicted sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991, while RB1 loss predicted resistance.
title: Loss of CDKN2A expression is a frequent event in primary invasive melanoma and correlates with sensitivity to the CDK4/6 inhibitor PD0332991 in melanoma cell lines.

text: ALK receptor tyrosine kinase has been shown to be a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: Germline ALK activating mutations are responsible for the majority of hereditary neuroblastoma and somatic ALK activating mutations are also frequently observed in sporadic cases of advanced NB.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: Crizotinib, a first-line therapy in the treatment of advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) harboring ALK rearrangements, demonstrates striking efficacy against ALK-rearranged NB.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: However, crizotinib fails to effectively inhibit the activity of ALK when activating mutations are present within its kinase domain, as with the F1174L mutation.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: Here we show that a new ALK inhibitor AZD3463 effectively suppressed the proliferation of NB cell lines with wild type ALK (WT) as well as ALK activating mutations (F1174L and D1091N) by blocking the ALK-mediated PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway and ultimately induced apoptosis and autophagy.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: In addition, AZD3463 enhanced the cytotoxic effects of doxorubicin on NB cells.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: AZD3463 also exhibited significant therapeutic efficacy on the growth of the NB tumors with WT and F1174L activating mutation ALK in orthotopic xenograft mouse models.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: These results indicate that AZD3463 is a promising therapeutic agent in the treatment of NB.
title: Novel ALK inhibitor AZD3463 inhibits neuroblastoma growth by overcoming crizotinib resistance and inducing apoptosis.

text: We analyzed 2502 patients with acute myeloid leukemia at diagnosis for NRAS mutations around the hot spots at codons 12, 13, and 61 and correlated the results to cytomorphology, cytogenetics, other molecular markers, and prognostic relevance of these mutations.
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: Two hundred fifty-seven (10.3%) of 2502 patients had NRAS mutations (NRAS(mut)).
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: Most mutations (112 of 257; 43.6%) were found at codon 12, mostly resulting in changes from glycine to asparagine.
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: The history of AML did not differ significantly in association with NRAS mutations.
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: The subgroups with inv(16)/t(16;16) and inv(3)/t(3;3) showed a significantly higher frequency of NRAS(mut) (50 of 133, 37.6% [P < .001], and 11 of 41, 26.8% [P = .004], respectively) than the total cohort.
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: In addition, in these 2 subgroups, mutations of codon 61 were significantly overrepresented (both P < .001).
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: In contrast, NRAS mutations were significantly underrepresented in t(15;17) (2 of 102; 2%; P = .005) in the subgroup with MLL/11q23 rearrangements (3 of 77; 3.9%; P = .061) and in the complex aberrant karyotype (4 of 258; 1.6%; P < .001).
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: Overall, we did not find a significant prognostic impact of NRAS(mut) for overall survival, event-free survival, and disease-free survival.
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: However, there was a trend to better survival in most subgroups, especially when other molecular markers (FLT3-LM, MLL-PTD, and NPM) were taken into account.
title: Implications of NRAS mutations in AML: a study of 2502 patients.

text: BACKGROUND: The anti-human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) humanized monoclonal antibody trastuzumab improves the outcome in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: However, most cases of advanced disease eventually progress.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: Pertuzumab, an anti-HER2 humanized monoclonal antibody that inhibits receptor dimerization, has a mechanism of action that is complementary to that of trastuzumab, and combination therapy with the two antibodies has shown promising activity and an acceptable safety profile in phase 2 studies involving patients with HER2-positive breast cancer.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: METHODS: We randomly assigned 808 patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer to receive placebo plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel (control group) or pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel (pertuzumab group) as first-line treatment until the time of disease progression or the development of toxic effects that could not be effectively managed.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: The primary end point was independently assessed progression-free survival.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: Secondary end points included overall survival, progression-free survival as assessed by the investigator, the objective response rate, and safety.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: The median progression-free survival was 12.4 months in the control group, as compared with 18.5 months in the pertuzumab group (hazard ratio for progression or death, 0.62; 95% confidence interval, 0.51 to 0.75; P<0.001).
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: The interim analysis of overall survival showed a strong trend in favor of pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: The safety profile was generally similar in the two groups, with no increase in left ventricular systolic dysfunction; the rates of febrile neutropenia and diarrhea of grade 3 or above were higher in the pertuzumab group than in the control group.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The combination of pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel, as compared with placebo plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel, when used as first-line treatment for HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer, significantly prolonged progression-free survival, with no increase in cardiac toxic effects.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: (Funded by F. Hoffmann-La Roche/Genentech; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00567190.
title: Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.
Pertuzumab plus trastuzumab plus docetaxel for metastatic breast cancer.

text: The RUNX1 (AML1, CBFA2) gene is a member of the runt transcription factor family, responsible for DNA binding and heterodimerization of other non-DNA binding transcription factors.
title: A novel inherited mutation of the transcription factor RUNX1 causes thrombocytopenia and may predispose to acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: RUNX1 plays an important part in regulating haematopoiesis and it is frequently disrupted by illegitimate somatic recombination in both acute myeloid and lymphoblastic leukaemia.
title: A novel inherited mutation of the transcription factor RUNX1 causes thrombocytopenia and may predispose to acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Germline mutations of RUNX1 have also recently been described and are dominantly associated with inherited leukaemic conditions.
title: A novel inherited mutation of the transcription factor RUNX1 causes thrombocytopenia and may predispose to acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: We have identified a unique point mutation of the RUNX1 gene (A107P) in members of a family with autosomal dominant inheritance of thrombocytopenia.
title: A novel inherited mutation of the transcription factor RUNX1 causes thrombocytopenia and may predispose to acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: One member has developed acute myeloid leukaemia (AML).
title: A novel inherited mutation of the transcription factor RUNX1 causes thrombocytopenia and may predispose to acute myeloid leukaemia.

text: Recently the World Health Organization (WHO), in collaboration with the European Association for Haematopathology and the Society for Hematopathology, published a revised and updated edition of the WHO Classification of Tumors of the Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tissues.
title: The 2008 revision of the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia: rationale and important changes.

text: The 4th edition of the WHO classification incorporates new information that has emerged from scientific and clinical studies in the interval since the publication of the 3rd edition in 2001, and includes new criteria for the recognition of some previously described neoplasms as well as clarification and refinement of the defining criteria for others.
title: The 2008 revision of the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia: rationale and important changes.

text: It also adds entities-some defined principally by genetic features-that have only recently been characterized.
title: The 2008 revision of the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia: rationale and important changes.

text: In this paper, the classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia is highlighted with the aim of familiarizing hematologists, clinical scientists, and hematopathologists not only with the major changes in the classification but also with the rationale for those changes.
title: The 2008 revision of the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia: rationale and important changes.

text: A nonsynonymous single-nucleotide polymorphism at codon 47 in TP53 exists in African-descent populations (P47S, rs1800371; referred to here as S47).
title: An African-specific polymorphism in the TP53 gene impairs p53 tumor suppressor function in a mouse model.

text: Here we report that, in human cell lines and a mouse model, the S47 variant exhibits a modest decrease in apoptosis in response to most genotoxic stresses compared with wild-type p53 but exhibits a significant defect in cell death induced by cisplatin.
title: An African-specific polymorphism in the TP53 gene impairs p53 tumor suppressor function in a mouse model.

text: We show that, compared with wild-type p53, S47 has nearly indistinguishable transcriptional function but shows impaired ability to transactivate a subset of p53 target genes, including two involved in metabolism:Gls2(glutaminase 2) and Sco2 We also show that human and mouse cells expressing the S47 variant are markedly resistant to cell death by agents that induce ferroptosis (iron-mediated nonapoptotic cell death).
title: An African-specific polymorphism in the TP53 gene impairs p53 tumor suppressor function in a mouse model.

text: We show that mice expressing S47 in homozygous or heterozygous form are susceptible to spontaneous cancers of diverse histological types.
title: An African-specific polymorphism in the TP53 gene impairs p53 tumor suppressor function in a mouse model.

text: Our data suggest that the S47 variant may contribute to increased cancer risk in individuals of African descent, and our findings highlight the need to assess the contribution of this variant to cancer risk in these populations.
title: An African-specific polymorphism in the TP53 gene impairs p53 tumor suppressor function in a mouse model.

text: These data also confirm the potential relevance of metabolism and ferroptosis to tumor suppression by p53.
title: An African-specific polymorphism in the TP53 gene impairs p53 tumor suppressor function in a mouse model.

text: ALK positive diffuse large B-cell lymphomas (DLBCL) are a distinct lymphoma subtype associated with a poor outcome.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: Most of them feature a t(2;17) encoding a clathrin (CLTC)-ALK fusion protein.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: The contribution of deregulated ALK-activity in the pathogenesis and maintenance of these DLBCLs is not yet known.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: We established and characterized the first CLTC-ALK positive DLBCL cell line (LM1).
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: LM1 formed tumors in NOD-SCID mice.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: The selective ALK inhibitor NVP-TAE684 inhibited growth of LM1 cells in vitro at nanomolar concentrations.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: NVP-TAE684 repressed ALK-activated signalling pathways and induced apoptosis of LM1 DLBCL cells.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: Inhibition of ALK-activity resulted in sustained tumor regression in the xenotransplant tumor model.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: These data indicate a role of CLTC-ALK in the maintenance of the malignant phenotype thereby providing a rationale therapeutic target for these otherwise refractory tumors.
title: Inhibition of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) activity provides a therapeutic approach for CLTC-ALK-positive human diffuse large B cell lymphomas.

text: BACKGROUND/AIM: The purpose of the present study was to explore the antiproliferative effect of BYL719, a specific inhibitor for phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) p110alpha, in human head and neck cancer cell lines, as a single agent or in combination with the irreversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, dacomitinib.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: Six head and neck cancer cell lines consisting of two PIK3CA mutant cell lines, SNU-1076 and Detroit562, and four PIK3CA wild-type cell lines, SNU-1066, SNU-1041, FaDu and SCC25, were analyzed.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: RESULTS: The PIK3CA-mutant cell lines were more sensitive to BYL719 than the PIK3CA wild-type cell lines.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: Following BYL719 treatment, all PIK3CA wild-type cell lines, except for the SNU-1066 cell line, exhibited higher IC50 values compared to the PIK3CA mutant cell lines.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: Administration of BYL719 induced cell cycle G0/G1 arrest and resulted in increased apoptosis in a dose-dependant manner.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: Furthermore, the administration of BYL719 reduced the level of p-mTOR, p-AKT and p-S6 expression indicating the down-regulation of downstream signaling.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: BYL719, a PI3K alpha selective blocker, could be a promising factor in the treatment of head and neck cancer either as a single agent or in combination with dacomitinib.
title: In vitro anticancer activity of PI3K alpha selective inhibitor BYL719 in head and neck cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph-positive ALL) is frequently caused by mutations in the BCR-ABL kinase domain.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Ponatinib (AP24534) is a potent oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor that blocks native and mutated BCR-ABL, including the gatekeeper mutant T315I, which is uniformly resistant to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: METHODS: In this phase 1 dose-escalation study, we enrolled 81 patients with resistant hematologic cancers, including 60 with CML and 5 with Ph-positive ALL.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Ponatinib was administered once daily at doses ranging from 2 to 60 mg.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Median follow-up was 56 weeks (range, 2 to 140).
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: RESULTS: Dose-limiting toxic effects included elevated lipase or amylase levels and pancreatitis.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Common adverse events were rash, myelosuppression, and constitutional symptoms.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Among Ph-positive patients, 91% had received two or more approved tyrosine kinase inhibitors, and 51% had received all three approved tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Of 43 patients with chronic-phase CML, 98% had a complete hematologic response, 72% had a major cytogenetic response, and 44% had a major molecular response.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Of 12 patients who had chronic-phase CML with the T315I mutation, 100% had a complete hematologic response and 92% had a major cytogenetic response.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Of 13 patients with chronic-phase CML without detectable mutations, 100% had a complete hematologic response and 62% had a major cytogenetic response.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Responses among patients with chronic-phase CML were durable.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Of 22 patients with accelerated-phase or blast-phase CML or Ph-positive ALL, 36% had a major hematologic response and 32% had a major cytogenetic response.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Ponatinib was highly active in heavily pretreated patients with Ph-positive leukemias with resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, including patients with the BCR-ABL T315I mutation, other mutations, or no mutations.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: (Funded by Ariad Pharmaceuticals and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00660920.
title: Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.
Ponatinib in refractory Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemias.

text: Mutations in genes that encode components of the phosphatidyl-inositol 3-kinase (PI3-kinase) signaling pathway are common in human cancer.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: The recent discovery of nonrandom somatic mutations in the PIK3CA gene of many human tumors suggests an oncogenic role for the mutated enzyme.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: We have determined the growth-regulatory and signaling properties of the three most frequently observed PI3-kinase mutations: E542K, E545K, and H1047R.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: Expressed in chicken embryo fibroblasts, all three mutants induce oncogenic transformation with high efficiency.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: This transforming ability is correlated with elevated catalytic activity in in vitro kinase assays.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: The mutant-transformed cells show constitutive phosphorylation of Akt, of p70 S6 kinase, and of the 4E-binding protein 1.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: Phosphorylation of S6 kinase and of 4E-binding protein 1 is regulated by the target of rapamycin (TOR) kinase and affects rates of protein synthesis.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: The inhibitor of TOR, rapamycin, strongly interferes with cellular transformation induced by the PI3-kinase mutants, suggesting that the TOR and its downstream targets are essential components of the transformation process.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: The oncogenic transforming activity makes the mutated PI3-kinase proteins promising targets for small molecule inhibitors that could be developed into effective and highly specific anticancer drugs.
title: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase mutations identified in human cancer are oncogenic.

text: PURPOSE To assess pharmacodynamic effects and intrinsic and acquired resistance mechanisms of the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib in BRAF(V600)-mutant melanoma, leading to an understanding of the mechanism of action of vemurafenib and ultimately to optimization of metastatic melanoma therapy.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: METHODS In the phase II clinical study NP22657 (BRIM-2), patients received oral doses of vemurafenib (960 mg twice per day).
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: Serial biopsies were collected to study changes in mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling, cell-cycle progression, and factors causing intrinsic or acquired resistance by immunohistochemistry, DNA sequencing, or somatic mutation profiling.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: Results Vemurafenib inhibited MAPK signaling and cell-cycle progression.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: An association between the decrease in extracellular signal-related kinase (ERK) phosphorylation and objective response was observed in paired biopsies (n = 22; P = .013).
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: Low expression of phosphatase and tensin homolog showed a modest association with lower response.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: Baseline mutations in MEK1(P124) coexisting with BRAF(V600) were noted in seven of 92 samples; their presence did not preclude objective tumor responses.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: Acquired resistance to vemurafenib associated with reactivation of MAPK signaling as observed by elevated ERK1/2 phosphorylation levels in progressive lesions and the appearance of secondary NRAS(Q61) mutations or MEK1(Q56P) or MEK1(E203K) mutations.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: These two activating MEK1 mutations had not previously been observed in vivo in biopsies of progressive melanoma tumors.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: CONCLUSION Vemurafenib inhibits tumor proliferation and oncogenic BRAF signaling through the MAPK pathway.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: Acquired resistance results primarily from MAPK reactivation driven by the appearance of secondary mutations in NRAS and MEK1 in subsets of patients.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: The data suggest that inhibition downstream of BRAF should help to overcome acquired resistance.
title: Pharmacodynamic effects and mechanisms of resistance to vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

text: PURPOSE: Contrary to the extensive data accumulated regarding pancreatic carcinogenesis, the clinical and molecular features characteristic of advanced stage (stage III and IV) disease are unknown.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: A comprehensive study of pancreatic cancers from patients who have succumbed to their disease has the potential to greatly expand our understanding of the most lethal stage of this disease and identify novel areas for intervention.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: Rapid autopsies were performed on 76 patients with documented pancreatic cancer.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: The histologic features of end stage disease were determined and correlated to the stage at initial diagnosis, patterns of failure (locally destructive v metastatic disease) and the status of the KRAS2, TP53, and DPC4 genes.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: RESULTS: At autopsy, 30% of patients died with locally destructive pancreatic cancer, and 70% died with widespread metastatic disease.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: These divergent patterns of failure found at autopsy (locally destructive v metastatic) were unrelated to clinical stage at initial presentation, treatment history, or histopathologic features.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: However, Dpc4 immunolabeling status of carcinoma tissues harvested at autopsy, a sensitive marker of DPC4 genetic status, was highly correlated with the presence of widespread metastasis but not with locally destructive tumors (P = .007).
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Pancreatic cancers are represented by distinct genetic subtypes with significantly different patterns of failure.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: Determinations of DPC4 status at initial diagnosis may be of value in stratifying patients into treatment regimens related to local control versus systemic therapy.
title: DPC4 gene status of the primary carcinoma correlates with patterns of failure in patients with pancreatic cancer.

text: Somatic mutations found within the tyrosine kinase domain (TKD) of the human epidermal growth factor (HER) family of receptors have been implicated in the development and progression of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Identification of a novel HER3 activating mutation homologous to EGFR-L858R in lung cancer.

text: However, no conclusive reports have described pathogenic mutations in kinase-impaired HER3.
title: Identification of a novel HER3 activating mutation homologous to EGFR-L858R in lung cancer.

text: Here, we report a case of an advanced chemotherapy-resistant NSCLC, harboring a novel HER3(V855A) somatic mutation homologous to the EGFR(L858R)activating mutation.
title: Identification of a novel HER3 activating mutation homologous to EGFR-L858R in lung cancer.

text: Co-expression of HER3(V855A) and wild-type HER2 enhances ligand-induced transformation of murine and human cell lines, while HER-targeted inhibitors potently suppress mutant HER3 activity.
title: Identification of a novel HER3 activating mutation homologous to EGFR-L858R in lung cancer.

text: Consistent with these observations, in silico computational modeling predicts that mutant V855A alters the kinase domain and c-terminal end of the HER3 protein.
title: Identification of a novel HER3 activating mutation homologous to EGFR-L858R in lung cancer.

text: Taken together, these findings provide a basis for the clinical exploration of targeted therapies in HER3 mutant NSCLC and by extrapolation, in other cancers that more frequently carry somatic HER3 mutations.
title: Identification of a novel HER3 activating mutation homologous to EGFR-L858R in lung cancer.

text: Purpose: The primary cause of death due to head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is local treatment failure.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: The goal of this study was to examine this phenomenon using an unbiased approach.Experimental Design: We utilized human papilloma virus (HPV)-negative cell lines rendered radiation-resistant (RR) via repeated exposure to radiation, a panel of HPV-negative HNSCC cell lines and three cohorts of HPV-negative HNSCC tumors (n = 68, 97, and 114) from patients treated with radiotherapy and subjected to genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic analysis.Results: RR cell lines exhibited upregulation of several proteins compared with controls, including increased activation of Axl and PI3 kinase signaling as well as increased expression of PD-L1.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: Additionally, inhibition of either Axl or PI3 kinase led to decreased PD-L1 expression.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: When clinical samples were subjected to RPPA and mRNA expression analysis, PD-L1 was correlated with both Axl and PI3K signaling as well as dramatically associated with local failure following radiotherapy.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: This finding was confirmed examining a third cohort using immunohistochemistry.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: Indeed, tumors with high expression of PD-L1 had failure rates following radiotherapy of 60%, 70%, and 50% compared with 20%, 25%, and 20% in the PD-L1-low expression group (P = 0.01, 1.9 x 10(-3), and 9 x 10(-4), respectively).
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: This finding remained significant on multivariate analysis in all groups.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: Additionally, patients with PD-L1 low/CD8(+) tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes high had no local failure or death due to disease (P = 5 x 10(-4) and P = 4 x 10(-4), respectively).Conclusions: Taken together, our data point to a targetable Axl-PI3 kinase-PD-L1 axis that is highly associated with radiation resistance.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 23(11); 2713-22.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: (c)2017 AACR.
title: Integrative Analysis Identifies a Novel AXL-PI3 Kinase-PD-L1 Signaling Axis Associated with Radiation Resistance in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Somatic mutations in the gene for the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) are found in adenocarcinomas of the lung and are associated with sensitivity to the kinase inhibitors gefitinib (Iressa) and erlotinib (Tarceva).
title: KRAS mutations and primary resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: Lung adenocarcinomas also harbor activating mutations in the downstream GTPase, KRAS, and mutations in EGFR and KRAS appear to be mutually exclusive.
title: KRAS mutations and primary resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: METHODS AND FINDINGS: We sought to determine whether mutations in KRAS could be used to further enhance prediction of response to gefitinib or erlotinib.
title: KRAS mutations and primary resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: We screened 60 lung adenocarcinomas defined as sensitive or refractory to gefitinib or erlotinib for mutations in EGFR and KRAS.
title: KRAS mutations and primary resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: We show that mutations in KRAS are associated with a lack of sensitivity to either drug.
title: KRAS mutations and primary resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: CONCLUSION: Our results suggest that treatment decisions regarding use of these kinase inhibitors might be improved by determining the mutational status of both EGFR and KRAS.
title: KRAS mutations and primary resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: To evaluate the incidence and clinical impact of WT1 gene mutations in younger adult patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML), sequencing of the complete coding region was performed in diagnostic samples from 617 patients who were treated on 3 German-Austrian AML Study Group protocols.
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: WT1 mutations were identified in 78 (12.6%) of the 617 patients; mutations clustered in exon 7 (54 of 78) and exon 9 (13 of 78), but also occurred in exons 1, 2, 3, and 8.
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: WT1 mutations were significantly associated with younger age, higher serum lactate dehydrogenase levels, higher blood blast counts, and the additional presence of FLT3-ITD (P < .001) and CEBPA mutations (P = .004).
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: There was no difference in relapse-free survival and overall survival between patients with (WT1(mut)) or without WT1 mutations.
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: Subset analysis showed that patients with the genotype WT1(mut)/FLT3-ITD(pos) had a lower complete remission rate (P = .003) and an inferior relapse-free survival (P = .006) and overall survival (P < .001) compared with those with the genotype WT1(mut)/FLT3-ITD(neg).
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: In conclusion, in our large cohort of younger adults with CN-AML, WT1 mutation as a single molecular marker did not impact on outcome.
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: However, our data suggest a negative impact of the genotype WT1(mut)/FLT3-ITD(pos).
title: Prognostic impact of WT1 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: a study of the German-Austrian AML Study Group.

text: The associations between programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1) and the prognosis of various cancers have always been a research topic of considerable interest.
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: However, the prognostic value of PD-L1 in breast cancer patients remains a controversial subject.
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: We aimed to assess the association between PD-L1 protein expression and clinicopathological features and the impact of this relationship on breast cancer survival.
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: We performed a systematic search of the PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane Library databases to determine the correlations among PD-L1 expression, clinicopathological features and overall survival (OS).
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: A total of 5 studies containing 2,546 cases were included in the analysis.
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: The combined hazard ratio (HR) and its 95% confidence interval (CI) for OS were 1.76 (95% CI 1.09-2.82; P=0.02) for patients with tumors exhibiting PD-L1 overexpression.
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: The pooled odds ratios (ORs) indicated that PD-L1 expression was associated with positive lymph node metastasis, higher histological grades, estrogen receptor (ER)-negativity, and triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Our findings indicate that PD-L1 expression is a promising biomarker for the prognosis of breast cancer, and may be helpful to clinicians aiming to select the appropriate immunotherapy for breast cancer.
title: Expression of PD-L1 and prognosis in breast cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: PURPOSE: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) and FGFR2 amplifications are observed in approximately 10% of breast cancers and are related to poor outcomes.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: We evaluated whether dovitinib (TKI258), an inhibitor of FGFR1, FGFR2, and FGFR3, presented antitumor activity in FGFR-amplified breast cancers.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Preclinical activity of dovitinib was evaluated in both breast cancer cell lines and an FGFR1-amplified xenograft model (HBCx2).
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: Dovitinib was then evaluated in a phase II trial that included 4 groups of patients with human EGF receptor 2-negative metastatic breast cancer on the basis of FGFR1 amplification and hormone receptor (HR) status.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: FGFR1 amplification was assessed by silver in situ hybridization.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: Preplanned retrospective analyses assessed predictive value of FGFR1, FGFR2, and FGF3 amplifications by quantitative PCR (qPCR).
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: Dovitinib monotherapy inhibits proliferation in FGFR1- and FGFR2-amplified, but not FGFR-normal, breast cancer cell lines.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: Dovitinib also inhibits tumor growth in FGFR1-amplified breast cancer xenografts.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: Eighty-one patients were enrolled in the trial.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: Unconfirmed response or stable disease for more than 6 months was observed in 5 (25%) and 1 (3%) patient(s) with FGFR1-amplified/HR-positive and FGFR1-nonamplified/HR-positive breast cancer.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: When qPCR-identified amplifications in FGFR1, FGFR2, or FGF3 were grouped to define an FGF pathway-amplified breast cancer in HR-positive patients, the mean reduction in target lesions was 21.1% compared with a 12.0% increase in patients who did not present with FGF pathway-amplified breast cancer.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Dovitinib showed antitumor activity in FGFR-amplified breast cancer cell lines and may have activity in breast cancers with FGF pathway amplification.
title: Targeting FGFR with dovitinib (TKI258): preclinical and clinical data in breast cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Advanced systemic mastocytosis comprises rare hematologic neoplasms that are associated with a poor prognosis and lack effective treatment options.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: The multikinase inhibitor midostaurin inhibits KIT D816V, a primary driver of disease pathogenesis.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: METHODS: We conducted an open-label study of oral midostaurin at a dose of 100 mg twice daily in 116 patients, of whom 89 with mastocytosis-related organ damage were eligible for inclusion in the primary efficacy population; 16 had aggressive systemic mastocytosis, 57 had systemic mastocytosis with an associated hematologic neoplasm, and 16 had mast-cell leukemia.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: The primary outcome was the best overall response.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: RESULTS: The overall response rate was 60% (95% confidence interval [CI], 49 to 70); 45% of the patients had a major response, which was defined as complete resolution of at least one type of mastocytosis-related organ damage.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: Response rates were similar regardless of the subtype of advanced systemic mastocytosis, KIT mutation status, or exposure to previous therapy.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: The median best percentage changes in bone marrow mast-cell burden and serum tryptase level were -59% and -58%, respectively.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: The median overall survival was 28.7 months, and the median progression-free survival was 14.1 months.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: Among the 16 patients with mast-cell leukemia, the median overall survival was 9.4 months (95% CI, 7.5 to not estimated).
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: Dose reduction owing to toxic effects occurred in 56% of the patients; re-escalation to the starting dose was feasible in 32% of those patients.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: The most frequent adverse events were low-grade nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: New or worsening grade 3 or 4 neutropenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia occurred in 24%, 41%, and 29% of the patients, respectively, mostly in those with preexisting cytopenias.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In this open-label study, midostaurin showed efficacy in patients with advanced systemic mastocytosis, including the highly fatal variant mast-cell leukemia.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: (Funded by Novartis Pharmaceuticals and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00782067.
title: Efficacy and Safety of Midostaurin in Advanced Systemic Mastocytosis.

text: BACKGROUND: Patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck (HNSCC) progressing after first-line platinum regimens have a poor prognosis and few treatment options.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Afatinib, an irreversible ERBB family blocker, has shown efficacy in a phase 2 study in this setting.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: We aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of afatinib compared with methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic HNSCC progressing on or after platinum-based therapy.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: METHODS: In this open-label, phase 3, randomised controlled trial conducted in 101 centres in 19 countries, we enrolled patients aged 18 years or older with histologically or cytologically confirmed HNSCC that was recurrent, metastatic, or both who had progressed on or after first-line platinum-based therapy, were not amenable for salvage surgery or radiotherapy, and who had an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Previous treatment with more than one systemic regimen in this setting was not allowed; previous treatment with EGFR-targeted antibody therapy (but not EGFR-targeted tyrosine-kinase inhibitors) was allowed.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: We randomly assigned eligible patients in a 2:1 ratio to receive oral afatinib (40 mg/day) or intravenous methotrexate (40 mg/m(2) per week), stratified by ECOG performance status and previous EGFR-targeted antibody therapy for recurrent or metastatic disease.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Randomisation was done centrally with an interactive voice or web-based response system.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Clinicians and patients were not masked to treatment allocation; independent review of tumour response was done in a blinded manner.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was progression-free survival as assessed by an independent, central imaging review committee.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: Efficacy analyses were done in the intention-to-treat population and safety analyses were done in patients who received at least one dose of study drug.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: This ongoing study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01345682.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Jan 10, 2012, and Dec 12, 2013, we enrolled 483 patients and randomly assigned 322 to afatinib and 161 to methotrexate.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: After a median follow-up of 6.7 months (IQR 3.1-9.0), progression-free survival was longer in the afatinib group than in the methotrexate group (median 2.6 months [95% CI 2.0-2.7] for the afatinib group vs 1.7 months [1.5-2.4] for the methotrexate group; hazard ratio [HR] 0.80 [95% CI 0.65-0.98], p=0.030).
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: The most frequent grade 3 or 4 drug-related adverse events were rash or acne (31 [10%] of 320 patients in the afatinib group vs none of 160 patients in the methotrexate group), diarrhoea (30 [9%] vs three [2%]), stomatitis (20 [6%] vs 13 [8%]), fatigue (18 [6%] vs five [3%]), and neutropenia (1 [<1%] vs 11 [7%]); serious adverse events occurred in 44 (14%) of afatinib-treated patients and 18 (11%) of methotrexate-treated patients.
