title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Afatinib was associated with significant improvements in progression-free survival and had a manageable safety profile.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: These findings provide important new insights into the treatment of this patient population and support further investigations with irreversible ERBB family blockers in HNSCC.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: FUNDING: Boehringer Ingelheim.
title: Afatinib versus methotrexate as second-line treatment in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck progressing on or after platinum-based therapy (LUX-Head & Neck 1): an open-label, randomised phase 3 trial.

text: BACKGROUND: Findings from the phase 3 First-Line ErbituX in lung cancer (FLEX) study showed that the addition of cetuximab to first-line chemotherapy significantly improved overall survival compared with chemotherapy alone (hazard ratio [HR] 0.871, 95% CI 0.762-0.996; p=0.044) in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: To define patients benefiting most from cetuximab, we studied the association of tumour EGFR expression level with clinical outcome in FLEX study patients.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: METHODS: We used prospectively collected tumour EGFR expression data to generate an immunohistochemistry score for FLEX study patients on a continuous scale of 0-300.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: We used response data to select an outcome-based discriminatory threshold immunohistochemistry score for EGFR expression of 200.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: Treatment outcome was analysed in patients with low (immunohistochemistry score <200) and high (>/=200) tumour EGFR expression.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: The primary endpoint in the FLEX study was overall survival.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: We analysed patients from the FLEX intention-to-treat (ITT) population.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: The FLEX study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00148798.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: FINDINGS: Tumour EGFR immunohistochemistry data were available for 1121 of 1125 (99.6%) patients from the FLEX study ITT population.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: High EGFR expression was scored for 345 (31%) evaluable patients and low for 776 (69%) patients.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: For patients in the high EGFR expression group, overall survival was longer in the chemotherapy plus cetuximab group than in the chemotherapy alone group (median 12.0 months [95% CI 10.2-15.2] vs 9.6 months [7.6-10.6]; HR 0.73, 0.58-0.93; p=0.011), with no meaningful increase in side-effects.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: We recorded no corresponding survival benefit for patients in the low EGFR expression group (median 9.8 months [8.9-12.2] vs 10.3 months [9.2-11.5]; HR 0.99, 0.84-1.16; p=0.88).
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: A treatment interaction test assessing the difference in the HRs for overall survival between the EGFR expression groups suggested a predictive value for EGFR expression (p=0.044).
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: INTERPRETATION: High EGFR expression is a tumour biomarker that can predict survival benefit from the addition of cetuximab to first-line chemotherapy in patients with advanced NSCLC.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: Assessment of EGFR expression could offer a personalised treatment approach in this setting.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: FUNDING: Merck KGaA.
title: EGFR expression as a predictor of survival for first-line chemotherapy plus cetuximab in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: analysis of data from the phase 3 FLEX study.

text: BACKGROUND: Immunotherapy can become a crucial therapeutic option to improve prognosis for lung cancer patients.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: First clinical trials with therapies targeting the programmed cell death receptor PD-1 and its ligand PD-L1 have shown promising results in several solid tumors.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: However, in lung cancer the diagnostic, prognostic and predictive value of these immunologic factors remains unclear.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: METHOD: The impact of both factors was evaluated in a study collective of 321 clinically well-annotated patients with non-small lung cancer (NSCLC) using immunohistochemistry.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: RESULTS: PD-1 expression by tumor infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) was found in 22%, whereas tumor cell associated PD-L1 expression was observed in 24% of the NSCLC tumors.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: In Fisher's exact test a positive correlation was found for PD-L1 and Bcl-xl protein expression (p = 0.013).
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: Interestingly, PD-L1 expression on tumor cells was associated with improved overall survival in pulmonary squamous cell carcinomas (SCC, p = 0.042, log rank test), with adjuvant therapy (p = 0.017), with increased tumor size (pT2-4, p = 0.039) and with positive lymph node status (pN1-3, p = 0.010).
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: These observations were confirmed by multivariate cox regression models.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: CONCLUSION: One major finding of our study is the identification of a prognostic implication of PD-L1 in subsets of NSCLC patients with pulmonary SCC, with increased tumor size, with a positive lymph node status and NSCLC patients who received adjuvant therapies.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: This study provides first data for immune-context related risk stratification of NSCLC patients.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: Further studies are necessary both to confirm this observation and to evaluate the predictive value of PD-1 and PD-L1 in NSCLC in the context of PD-1 inhibition.
title: PD-1 and PD-L1 Expression in NSCLC Indicate a Favorable Prognosis in Defined Subgroups.

text: BACKGROUND: To investigate whether TP53 DNA mutational status impacts progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with advanced sarcomas (soft tissue sarcoma) treated with vascular endothelial growth factor receptors (VEGFR) inhibition.
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed 19 cases of patients treated at the Ohio State James Comprehensive Cancer Center with advanced sarcoma treated with VEGFR inhibition who also had next-generation sequencing of their tumors (via FoundationOne Heme panel).
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: We evaluated TP53 as well as mutations that were observed in at least 20% of patients and evaluated its contribution to PFS using the Kaplan-Meier survival analysis of available radiology end points.
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: RESULTS: Mutations that were observed in at least 20% of patients included TP53 and Rb1.
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: Only TP53 was predictive of PFS in the context of VEGFR inhibition.
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: The PFS of patients with TP53 mutations was significantly greater than TP53 wild-type tumors with the median PFS of 208 versus 136 days, respectively [P = 0.036, hazards ratio 0.38 (95% confidence interval 0.09-0.83)].
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Mutations in TP53 may serve as a predictive biomarker of response to VEGFR inhibition in patients with advanced sarcoma.
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: Larger, prospective studies are necessary to confirm these findings.
title: TP53 mutational status is predictive of pazopanib response in advanced sarcomas.

text: BACKGROUND: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is characterized by a high frequency of KRAS mutations and frequent deregulation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and other EGFR family members such as HER2/ErbB2.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: The EGFR inhibitor erlotinib is approved for treatment of pancreatic cancer, but has shown modest activity in most patients.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: OBJECTIVE: Here we investigated the activity of afatinib, a second-generation irreversible pan-EGFR family kinase inhibitor, alone or in combination with ionizing radiation, toward pancreatic cancer cells.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: METHODS: The influence of afatinib on cell proliferation, cell cycle distribution, clonogenic survival, nuclear fragmentation, ploidy, and centrosome amplification following irradiation was determined.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: Expression and phosphorylation of HER receptors, Akt, DNA-PKcs, and ERK1/2 was characterized by Western blot analysis.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: RESULTS: Afatinib was growth-inhibitory for all three cell lines but cytotoxic only toward BxPC3 (KRAS (wt)) and Capan-2 (KRAS (mut)) cells, both of which express high levels of EGFR, HER2, and HER3 receptors.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: Afatinib increased the radiosensitivity of BxPC3 and Capan-2 cells, prevented the radio-induced phosphorylation of Akt, and induced mitotic catastrophe following irradiation.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: In comparison, Panc-1 cells (KRAS (mut)) expressing low levels of EGFR family receptors were resistant to afatinib-induced radiosensitization.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: LIMITATIONS: These results must be confirmed in vivo.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Afatinib showed cytotoxic and radiosensitizing effects toward a subset of pancreatic cancer cells which was closely correlated with expression of EGFR, HER2, and HER3 receptors, but not with KRAS status.
title: Afatinib, an Irreversible EGFR Family Inhibitor, Shows Activity Toward Pancreatic Cancer Cells, Alone and in Combination with Radiotherapy, Independent of KRAS Status.

text: BACKGROUND: High-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma (HGES) is an aggressive disease with dismal prognosis.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: Surgery is the standard treatment, and radiotherapy seems to reduce local relapse.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: No other treatment has proved to be useful in the case of non-resectable diseases.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: CASE: A 41-year-old woman suffering HGES, with positive staining for CD117 (c-kit) and large abdominal and retroperitoneal mass progressing after chemotherapy, was treated with Imatinib Mesylate.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: After 3 months, objective response was documented and radical surgery performed.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: Two years after surgical intervention, she is currently free of the disease.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: CONCLUSION: The response seen with Imatinib should be further investigated in a larger number of cases.
title: A case of c-kit positive high-grade stromal endometrial sarcoma responding to Imatinib Mesylate.

text: The GNAS1 locus encodes the G(alpha)s protein which stimulates the formation of cyclic AMP (cAMP).
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: Subsequently the cAMP pathway mediates various pleiotropic effects including regulation of apoptosis and proliferation.
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: We have recently shown that genotypes of the single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) T393C in the gene GNAS1 are associated with survival of patients suffering from bladder, renal cell and colorectal carcinoma.
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: In the present study, the genotypes of the T393C SNP were determined in 279 patients with invasive breast carcinoma.
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: Comparing the genotypes with the overall survival as well as important clinico-pathological parameters showed that carriers of the T allele had a significantly less favourable course of the disease when compared to carriers of the homozygous CC genotype.
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: In multivariate analysis the homozygous TT genotype was independently associated with a decreased overall survival.
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: Our results suggest that the GNAS1 T393C SNP is a novel genetic host factor for disease progression in patients with invasive breast carcinoma.
title: The T393C polymorphism in the gene GNAS1 of G protein is associated with survival of patients with invasive breast carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: To determine the prognostic and predictive significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in patients with completely resected non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients were randomized preoperatively to receive adjuvant postoperative radiotherapy (Arm A) or radiotherapy plus concurrent chemotherapy (Arm B).
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: p53 protein expression was studied by immunohistochemistry (IHC) and p53 mutations in exons 5 to 8 were evaluated by single-strand conformational analysis.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: K-ras mutations in codons 12, 13, and 61 were determined using engineered restriction fragment length polymorphisms.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: RESULTS: Four hundred eighty-eight patients were entered onto E3590; 197 tumors were assessable for analysis.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: Neither presence nor absence of p53 mutations, p53 protein expression, or K-ras mutations correlated with survival or progression-free survival.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: There was a trend toward improved survival for patients with wildtype K-ras (median, 42 months) compared with survival of patients with mutant K-ras who were randomized to chemotherapy plus radiotherapy (median, 25 months; P = .09).
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: Multivariate analysis revealed only age and tumor stage to be significant prognostic factors, although there was a trend bordering on statistical significance for K-ras (P = .066).
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: Analysis of survival difference by p53 by single-stranded conformational polymorphism and IHC, interaction of p53 and K-ras, interaction of p53 and treatment arm, nodal station, extent of surgery, weight loss, and histology did not reach statistical significance.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: CONCLUSION: p53 mutations and protein overexpression are not significant prognostic or predictive factors in resected stage II or IIIA NSCLC.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: K-ras mutations may be a weak prognostic marker.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: p53 or K-ras should not be routinely used in the clinical management of these patients.
title: Lack of prognostic significance of p53 and K-ras mutations in primary resected non-small-cell lung cancer on E4592: a Laboratory Ancillary Study on an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Prospective Randomized Trial of Postoperative Adjuvant Therapy.

text: Recently, the ARID1A gene has been identified as a novel tumor suppressor in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: The prognostic significance of the loss of ARID1A expression is not known.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: The current study was designed to evaluate whether ARID1A was a prognostic factor for progression, survival, and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: A total of 60 patients, who were surgically treated for primary ovarian clear cell adenocarcinoma, were enrolled.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Surgical specimens were examined for ARID1A protein expression by immunohistochemistry.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: The correlations between the loss of ARID1A expression and clinicopathological characteristics, prognosis, and chemosensitivity were investigated.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Loss of ARID1A expression was identified in 9 (15.0%) of 60 ovarian clear cell carcinoma samples.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Loss of ARID1A staining intensity (0+) was more frequently found in cells of clear cell carcinomas than in high-grade serous carcinomas (P<0.01).
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Loss of ARID1A expression was significantly correlated with advanced FIGO stage and high CA125 levels (P=0.02, 0.01).
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: There were no significant correlations between loss of ARID1A expression and patient age, status of residual tumor, Ki-67 labeling index, or the status of endometriosis.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Loss of ARID1A correlated with shorter progression-free survival of patients with clear cell carcinomas treated with platinum-based chemotherapy (P<0.01).
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Loss of ARID1A expression tended to correlate with shorter overall survival in patients with ovarian clear cell carcinomas treated with platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: When data were stratified for the multivariate analysis, only the loss of ARID1A expression remained a significant (P=0.03) predictor of reduced progression-free survival.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Of the 60 patients with ovarian clear cell carcinomas, 14 patients had measurable residual tumor after primary cytoreductive surgery.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Tumors with loss of ARID1A expression were more likely to be chemoresistant than tumors with positive ARID1A expression (100.0 vs 40.0%, P=0.04).
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: This study demonstrates that loss of ARID1A in ovarian clear cell carcinoma is a negative prognostic factor in patients treated with platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: Measurement of ARID1A expression may be a method to predict resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy in patients with ovarian clear cell carcinoma.
title: Loss of ARID1A expression is related to shorter progression-free survival and chemoresistance in ovarian clear cell carcinoma.

text: The resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib in BCR/ABL-positive leukemias is mostly associated with mutations in the kinase domain of BCR/ABL, which include the most prevalent mutations E255K and T315I.
title: The two major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I enhance the activity of BCR/ABL fusion kinase.

text: Intriguingly, these mutations have also been identified in some patients before imatinib treatment.
title: The two major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I enhance the activity of BCR/ABL fusion kinase.

text: Here we examined the effects of these mutations on the kinase activity of a BCR/ABL kinase domain construct that also contained the SH3 and SH2 domains.
title: The two major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I enhance the activity of BCR/ABL fusion kinase.

text: When expressed in COS7 cells, the BCR/ABL construct with either E255K or T315I exhibited not only the resistance to imatinib but also the increase in activity to induce autophosphorylation as well as tyrosine phosphorylation of various cellular proteins, which included STAT5.
title: The two major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I enhance the activity of BCR/ABL fusion kinase.

text: The mutant kinases also showed increased activities in in vitro kinase assays.
title: The two major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I enhance the activity of BCR/ABL fusion kinase.

text: These results raise a possibility that the major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I may confer the growth advantage on leukemic cells to expand in the absence of selective pressure from imatinib treatment.
title: The two major imatinib resistance mutations E255K and T315I enhance the activity of BCR/ABL fusion kinase.

text: Tissue hypoxia commonly occurs in tumors.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: Hypoxia- inducible factor (HIF)-1 and HIF-2, which are essential mediators of cellular response to hypoxia, regulate gene expression for tumor angiogenesis, glucose metabolism, and resistance to oxidative stress.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: Their key regulatory subunits, HIF1A (HIF-1alpha) and endothelial PAS domain protein 1 (EPAS1; HIF-2alpha), are overexpressed and associated with patient prognosis in a variety of cancers.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: However, prognostic or molecular features of colon cancer with HIF expression remain uncertain.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: Among 731 colorectal cancers in two prospective cohort studies, 142 (19%) tumors showed HIF1A overexpression, and 322 (46%) showed EPAS1 overexpression by immunohistochemistry.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: HIF1A overexpression was significantly associated with higher colorectal cancer-specific mortality in Kaplan-Meier analysis (log-rank test, P < 0.0001), univariate Cox regression (hazard ratio = 1.84; 95% confidence interval, 1.37 to 2.47; P < 0.0001) and multivariate analysis (adjusted hazard ratio = 1.72; 95% confidence interval, 1.26 to 2.36; P = 0.0007) that adjusted for clinical and tumoral features, including microsatellite instability, TP53 (p53), PTGS2 (cyclooxygenase-2), CpG island methylator phenotype, and KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and LINE-1 methylation.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: In contrast, EPAS1 expression was not significantly associated with patient survival.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: In addition, HIF1A expression was independently associated with PTGS2 expression (P = 0.0035), CpG island methylator phenotype-high (P = 0.013), and LINE-1 hypomethylation (P = 0.017).
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: EPAS1 expression was inversely associated with high tumor grade (P = 0.0017) and obesity (body mass index > or = 30 kg/m2) (P = 0.039).
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: In conclusion, HIF1A expression is independently associated with poor prognosis in colorectal cancer, suggesting HIF1A as a biomarker with potentially important therapeutic implications.
title: HIF1A overexpression is associated with poor prognosis in a cohort of 731 colorectal cancers.

text: BACKGROUND: Clear-cell renal-cell carcinomas display divergent clinical behaviours.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: However, the molecular genetic events driving these behaviours are unknown.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: We discovered that BAP1 is mutated in about 15% of clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma, and that BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations are largely mutually exclusive.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: The aim of this study was to investigate the clinicopathological significance of these molecular subtypes and to determine whether patients with BAP1-mutant and PBRM1-mutant tumours had different overall survival.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: METHODS: In this retrospective analysis, we assessed 145 patients with primary clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma and defined PBRM1 and BAP1 mutation status from the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center (UTSW), TX, USA, between 1998 and 2011.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: We classified patients into those with BAP1-mutant tumours and those with tumours exclusively mutated for PBRM1 (PBRM1-mutant).
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: We used a second independent cohort (n=327) from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) for validation.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: In both cohorts, more than 80% of patients had localised or locoregional disease at presentation.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: Overall both cohorts were similar, although the TCGA had more patients with metastatic and higher-grade disease, and more TCGA patients presented before molecularly targeted therapies became available.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: FINDINGS: The median overall survival in the UTSW cohort was significantly shorter for patients with BAP1-mutant tumours (4.6 years; 95% CI 2.1-7.2), than for patients with PBRM1-mutant tumours (10.6 years; 9.8-11.5), corresponding to a HR of 2.7 (95% CI 0.99-7.6, p=0.044).
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: Median overall survival in the TCGA cohort was 1.9 years (95% CI 0.6-3.3) for patients with BAP1-mutant tumours and 5.4 years (4.0-6.8) for those with PBRM1-mutant tumours.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: A HR similar to the UTSW cohort was noted in the TCGA cohort (2.8; 95% CI 1.4-5.9; p=0.004).
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: Patients with mutations in both BAP1 and PBRM1, although a minority (three in UTSW cohort and four in TCGA cohort), had the worst overall survival (median 2.1 years, 95% CI 0.3-3.8, for the UTSW cohort, and 0.2 years, 0.0-1.2, for the TCGA cohort).
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: INTERPRETATION: Our findings identify mutation-defined subtypes of clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma with distinct clinical outcomes, a high-risk BAP1-mutant group and a favourable PBRM1-mutant group.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: These data establish the basis for a molecular genetic classification of clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma that could influence treatment decisions in the future.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: The existence of different molecular subtypes with disparate outcomes should be considered in the design and assessment of clinical studies.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: FUNDING: Cancer Prevention and Research Institution of Texas and National Cancer Institute.
title: Effects on survival of BAP1 and PBRM1 mutations in sporadic clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma: a retrospective analysis with independent validation.

text: Although erlotinib has become an important therapeutic option in addition to gemcitabine, the high frequency of KRAS mutations in pancreatic cancer probably limits the benefits.
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: We retrospectively studied 136 pancreatic cancer patients with available formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor blocks from 2003 to 2009 to understand the clinical significance of KRAS mutations in pancreatic cancer patients treated with gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: KRAS mutations were analyzed by sequencing codons 12, 13, and 61.
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: In this study, 71 (52.2%) of the 136 pancreatic adenocarcinomas examined harbored a point mutation in codons 12 (n = 70) and 61 (n = 1) of KRAS.
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: KRAS mutation was not associated with clinicopathologic parameters.
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: Patients with KRAS mutations showed a worse response (11.3%) than those with wild-type KRAS (26.2%) and poor survival (mutant KRAS, 5.8 months vs. wild-type KRAS, 8.0 months; P = 0.001).
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: Multivariate analysis revealed good prognostic factors for overall survival as well to moderately differentiated histology (P < 0.001; HR = 0.437, 95% CI: 0.301-0.634), locally advanced disease (P < 0.001; HR = 0.417, 95% CI: 0.255-0.681), response to first-line chemotherapy (P = 0.003; HR = 0.482, 95% CI: 0.297-0.780), and wild-type KRAS (P = 0.001; HR = 0.523, 95% CI: 0.355-0.770).
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: However, the observed survival advantage is derived from the subgroup of patients treated with gemcitabine/erlotinib (9.7 vs. 5.2 months; P = 0.002), whereas no survival difference based on KRAS mutation status is obvious in the other subgroup of patients treated without erlotinib (7.0 vs. 7.0 months; P = 0.121).
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: These results need to be further explored in upcoming prospective studies to provide a rationale for personalized medicine in pancreatic cancer.
title: Impact of KRAS mutations on clinical outcomes in pancreatic cancer patients treated with first-line gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Platinum-based doublets (PBDs) remain the cornerstone of treatment in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and may include gemcitabine.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: A biomarker predicting sensitivity to this antimetabolite would represent a major step forward.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: Accordingly, we explored the predictive role of ribonucleotide reductase subunit M (RRM1) in advanced NSCLC.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: A total of 443 patients were randomly assigned to regimen A [paclitaxel (Taxol) and cisplatin with gemcitabine] or regimen B (cisplatin and vinorelbine).
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: Immunohistochemical evaluation of RRM1 was correlated to clinical end-points.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: RESULTS: A total of 261 (58.9%) patients had representative tissue samples for RRM1 evaluation.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: Disease control rate, progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) were substantially improved in patients with RRM-negative (neg) tumors receiving regimen B when compared with patients with RRM-positive (pos) tumors (68.8% versus 31.2%, P = 0.046, 6.90 months versus 3.93 months, P = 0.000 and 11.57 months versus 7.4 months, P = 0.002, respectively).
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: Interaction analysis between RRM1-neg status and adenocarcinomas yielded a hazard ratio (HR) of 0.36 for death (P = 0.000).
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: CONCLUSIONS: RRM1 protein expression was without any predictive impact in patients treated with cisplatin, paclitaxel and gemcitabine.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: Surprisingly, the predictive power was demonstrated in the cisplatin and vinorelbine arm and may suggest that RRM1 is involved in vinorelbine sensitivity warranting further research.
title: Predictive impact of RRM1 protein expression on vinorelbine efficacy in NSCLC patients randomly assigned in a chemotherapy phase III trial.

text: In chronic eosinophilic leukemia, the transforming oncoprotein FIP1L1-PDGFRA is a major target of therapy.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: In most patients, the tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) imatinib induces complete remission.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: For patients who are intolerant or resistant, novel TKIs have been proposed.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: We examined the in vitro effects of 14 kinase blockers on growth and function of EOL-1 cells, a FIP1L1-PDGFRA(+) eosinophil cell line.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: Major growth-inhibitory effects were seen with all PDGFR-blocking agents, with IC50 values in the low nanomolar range: ponatinib, 0.1-0.2 nmol/L; sorafenib, 0.1-0.2 nmol/L; masitinib, 0.2-0.5 nmol/L; nilotinib, 0.2-1.0 nmol/L; dasatinib, 0.5-2.0 nmol/L; sunitinib, 1-2 nmol/L; midostaurin, 5-10 nmol/L.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: These drugs were also found to block activation of PDGFR-downstream signaling molecules, including Akt, S6, and STAT5 in EOL-1 cells.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: All effective TKIs produced apoptosis in EOL-1 cells as determined by microscopy, Annexin-V/PI, and caspase-3 staining.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: In addition, PDGFR-targeting TKIs were found to inhibit cytokine-induced migration of EOL-1 cells.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: In all bioassays used, ponatinib was found to be the most potent compound in EOL-1 cells.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: In addition, ponatinib was found to downregulate expression of the activation-linked surface antigen CD63 on EOL-1 cells and to suppress the growth of primary neoplastic eosinophils.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: We also examined drug effects on Ba/F3 cells expressing two clinically relevant, imatinib-resistant, mutant forms of FIP1L1-PDGFRA, namely T674I and D842V.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: Strong inhibitory effects on both mutants were seen only with ponatinib.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: In summary, novel PDGFR-targeting TKIs may be alternative agents for the treatment of patients with imatinib-resistant chronic eosinophilic leukemia.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: Although several different PDGFR-targeting agents are effective, the most potent drug appears to be ponatinib.
title: Identification of Ponatinib as a potent inhibitor of growth, migration, and activation of neoplastic eosinophils carrying FIP1L1-PDGFRA.

text: Mutations in the IDH1 gene at position R132 coding for the enzyme cytosolic isocitrate dehydrogenase are known in glioma and have recently been detected also in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: These mutations result in an accumulation of alpha-ketoglutarate to R (2)-2-hydroxyglutarate (2HG).
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: To further clarify the role of this mutation in AML, we have analyzed IDH1R132 in 1414 AML patients.
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: We detected IDH1R132 mutations in 93 of 1414 patients (6.6%) with a clear prevalence in intermediate risk karyotype group (10.4%, P < .001).
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: Although IDH1R132 mutations can incidentally occur together with all other molecular markers, there were strong associations with NPM1 mutations (14.2% vs 5.4% in NPM1wt, P < .001) and MLL-PTD (18.2% vs 7.0% in MLLwt, P = .020).
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: IDH1-mutated cases more often had AML without maturation/French-American-British M1 (P < .001), an immature immunophenotype, and female sex (8.7% vs 4.7% in male, P = .003) compared with IDH1wt cases.
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: Prognosis was adversely affected by IDH1 mutations with trend for shorter overall survival (P = .110), a shorter event-free survival (P < .003) and a higher cumulative risk for relapse (P = .001).
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: IDH1 mutations were of independent prognostic relevance for event-free survival (P = .039) especially in the age group < 60 years (P = .028).
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: In conclusion, these data show that IDH1R132 may significantly add information regarding characterization and prognostication in AML.
title: IDH1 mutations are detected in 6.6% of 1414 AML patients and are associated with intermediate risk karyotype and unfavorable prognosis in adults younger than 60 years and unmutated NPM1 status.

text: PURPOSE: Mortality of patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is primarily driven by tumor cell radioresistance leading to locoregional recurrence (LRR).
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: In this study, we use a classification of TP53 mutation (disruptive vs. nondisruptive) and examine impact on clinical outcomes and radiation sensitivity.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Seventy-four patients with HNSCC treated with surgery and postoperative radiation and 38 HNSCC cell lines were assembled; for each, TP53 was sequenced and the in vitro radioresistance measured using clonogenic assays.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: p53 protein expression was inhibited using short hairpin RNA (shRNA) and overexpressed using a retrovirus.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: Radiation-induced apoptosis, mitotic cell death, senescence, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) assays were carried out.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: The effect of the drug metformin on overcoming mutant p53-associated radiation resistance was examined in vitro as well as in vivo, using an orthotopic xenograft model.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: RESULTS: Mutant TP53 alone was not predictive of LRR; however, disruptive TP53 mutation strongly predicted LRR (P = 0.03).
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: Cell lines with disruptive mutations were significantly more radioresistant (P < 0.05).
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: Expression of disruptive TP53 mutations significantly decreased radiation-induced senescence, as measured by SA-beta-gal staining, p21 expression, and release of ROS.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: The mitochondrial agent metformin potentiated the effects of radiation in the presence of a disruptive TP53 mutation partially via senescence.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: Examination of our patient cohort showed that LRR was decreased in patients taking metformin.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Disruptive TP53 mutations in HNSCC tumors predicts for LRR, because of increased radioresistance via the inhibition of senescence.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: Metformin can serve as a radiosensitizer for HNSCC with disruptive TP53, presaging the possibility of personalizing HNSCC treatment.
title: TP53 disruptive mutations lead to head and neck cancer treatment failure through inhibition of radiation-induced senescence.

text: Recurrent mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase isoforms 1 and 2 (IDH1 and IDH2) have recently been studied in adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: A meta-analysis was performed to demonstrate their controversial prognostic impacts.
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: The associations of IDH1 or IDH2 mutations with other molecular abnormalities were also investigated.
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: In patients with AML, IDH1/2 mutations were significantly associated with normal karyotype and isolated trisomy 8 (p < .05).
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: After adjusting for well-studied prognostic factors, IDH1 mutation seems to be associated with subtle but significantly inferior event-free survival (EFS) (p = 0.02) and possible adverse overall survival (OS) (p = 0.13) in patients with AML, especially in the favorable genotype subset with mutated NPM1 but without FLT3-ITD mutation (p < 0.05).
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: Longer OS (p = 0.01) and better EFS tendency (p = 0.18) are implicated in patients with IDH2 mutations, which suggests that IDH2 mutations appear to confer a favorable prognosis.
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: Moreover, IDH1 and IDH2 mutations may play a more important role in abnormal cytogenetics subgroups such as isolated trisomy 8.
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: Screening of IDH1/2 mutations could help to identify patients at high risk within some subsets of AML.
title: Potential application of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations as prognostic indicators in non-promyelocytic acute myeloid leukemia: a meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: MET splice site mutations resulting in an exon 14 deletion have been reported to be present in about 3% of all lung adenocarcinomas.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: Patients with lung adenocarcinoma and a MET splice site mutation who have responded to MET inhibitors have been reported.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: The CRISPR/Cas9 system is a recently developed genome-engineering tool that can easily and rapidly cause small insertions or deletions.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: We created an in vitro model for MET exon 14 deletion using the CRISPR/Cas9 system and the HEK293 cell line.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: The phenotype, which included MET inhibitor sensitivity, was then investigated in vitro.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: Additionally, MET splice site mutations were analyzed in several cancers included in The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) dataset.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: RESULTS: An HEK293 cell line with a MET exon 14 deletion was easily and rapidly created; this cell line had a higher MET protein expression level, enhanced MET phosphorylation, and prolonged MET activation.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: In addition, a direct comparison of phenotypes using this system demonstrated enhanced cellular growth, colony formation, and MET inhibitor sensitivity.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: In the TCGA dataset, lung adenocarcinomas had the highest incidence of MET exon 14 deletions, while other cancers rarely carried such mutations.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: Approximately 10% of the lung adenocarcinoma samples without any of driver gene alterations carried the MET exon 14 deletion.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggested that this system may be useful for experiments requiring the creation of specific mutations, and the present experimental findings encourage the development of MET-targeted therapy against lung cancer carrying the MET exon 14 deletion.
title: MET gene exon 14 deletion created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system enhances cellular growth and sensitivity to a MET inhibitor.

text: Activating KRAS mutations are found in approximately 20% of human cancers but no RAS-directed therapies are currently available.
title: CDK1 Is a Synthetic Lethal Target for KRAS Mutant Tumours.

text: Here we describe a novel, robust, KRAS synthetic lethal interaction with the cyclin dependent kinase, CDK1.
title: CDK1 Is a Synthetic Lethal Target for KRAS Mutant Tumours.

text: This was discovered using parallel siRNA screens in KRAS mutant and wild type colorectal isogenic tumour cells and subsequently validated in a genetically diverse panel of 26 colorectal and pancreatic tumour cell models.
title: CDK1 Is a Synthetic Lethal Target for KRAS Mutant Tumours.

text: This established that the KRAS/CDK1 synthetic lethality applies in tumour cells with either amino acid position 12 (p.G12V, pG12D, p.G12S) or amino acid position 13 (p.G13D) KRAS mutations and can also be replicated in vivo in a xenograft model using a small molecule CDK1 inhibitor.
title: CDK1 Is a Synthetic Lethal Target for KRAS Mutant Tumours.

text: Mechanistically, CDK1 inhibition caused a reduction in the S-phase fraction of KRAS mutant cells, an effect also characterised by modulation of Rb, a master control of the G1/S checkpoint.
title: CDK1 Is a Synthetic Lethal Target for KRAS Mutant Tumours.

text: Taken together, these observations suggest that the KRAS/CDK1 interaction is a robust synthetic lethal effect worthy of further investigation.
title: CDK1 Is a Synthetic Lethal Target for KRAS Mutant Tumours.

text: A large-scale RNA interference screen to discover genes involved in trastuzumab resistance in breast cancer identified only PTEN as a modulator of drug sensitivity.
title: A functional genetic approach identifies the PI3K pathway as a major determinant of trastuzumab resistance in breast cancer.

text: Oncogenic mutants of PIK3CA (activator of the same pathway and frequently mutated in breast cancer) also conferred resistance to trastuzumab in cell culture.
title: A functional genetic approach identifies the PI3K pathway as a major determinant of trastuzumab resistance in breast cancer.

text: In a cohort of 55 breast cancer patients, activation of the PI3K pathway, as judged by the presence of oncogenic PIK3CA mutations or low PTEN expression, was associated with poor prognosis after trastuzumab therapy, and the combined analysis of PTEN and PIK3CA identified twice as many patients at increased risk for progression compared to PTEN alone.
title: A functional genetic approach identifies the PI3K pathway as a major determinant of trastuzumab resistance in breast cancer.

text: Thus, assessment of PI3K pathway activation may provide a biomarker to identify patients unlikely to respond to trastuzumab-based therapy.
title: A functional genetic approach identifies the PI3K pathway as a major determinant of trastuzumab resistance in breast cancer.

text: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is an autosomal dominant familial cancer syndrome caused by germline mutations in VHL tumor suppressor gene.
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: It is characterized by hemangioblastoma in central nervous system and retina, renal cell carcinoma or cyst, pheochromocytoma, pancreatic cyst and tumor, endolymphatic-sac tumor, and papillary cystadenoma in epididymis and broad ligament.
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: Here, we used PCR-direct sequencing and universal primer quantitative fluorescent multiplex PCR (UPQFM-PCR) to detect VHL mutations in 16 patients clinically diagnosed with VHL disease.
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: PCR-direct sequencing detected 12 germline mutations (75%, 12/16), in which a novel mutation of c.451A>T/p.Ile151Phe found in one proband had not been reported previously.
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: UPQFM-PCR found two large deletions (12.5%, 2/16).
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: The two remaining patients carried non-typical disease-causing mutations, including one silent mutation (c.481C>A/p.Arg161Arg) and one mutation in 3'-UTR (c.642+70C>A).
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: Remarkably, 56.3% (9/16) probands did not have family history of VHL disease, suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in Chinese patients.
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: We also summarized Chinese VHL disease patients with VHL mutation findings published in the literature to provide information about the spectrum of VHL mutations in Chinese VHL disease patients.
title: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau disease was uncommon in Chinese patients: suggesting the higher frequency of de novo mutations in VHL gene in these patients.

text: PURPOSE: ERCC1 is the key enzyme of the nucleotide excision repair pathway, which maintains genomic stability.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: ERCC1 has been proposed as a prognostic and predictive biomarker for patients with urothelial carcinoma of the bladder but there are limited data on patients after radical cystectomy.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: ERCC1 was evaluated by immunohistochemistry in radical cystectomy specimens of 432 patients.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: Associations with disease-free and cancer specific survival, and the effect of adjuvant cisplatin based chemotherapy were assessed.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: Further, ERCC1 mRNA expression and in vitro sensitivity to cisplatin were correlated in 25 bladder urothelial carcinoma cell lines.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: RESULTS: ERCC1 was expressed in 308 tumors (71.3%).
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: There was no association with clinicopathological variables (each p >0.3).
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: Median postoperative followup was 128 months.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: On multivariable analyses patients with ERCC1 positive tumors had significantly better disease-free survival (HR 0.70, p = 0.028) and cancer specific survival (HR 0.70, p = 0.032) than those with ERCC1 negative tumors.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: Discrimination of the multivariable models increased by 0.7% to 0.9% following the inclusion of ERCC1.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: There was no modification of the effect of adjuvant cisplatin based combination chemotherapy by ERCC1 status (p = 0.38 and 0.88, respectively).
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: There was also no correlation between ERCC1 and sensitivity to cisplatin in vitro (R(2) = 0.02, p = 0.46).
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: ERCC1 may be a prognostic biomarker for urothelial carcinoma of the bladder.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: Patients with ERCC1 positive tumors may have better survival than those with ERCC1 negative tumors.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: However, the efficacy of adjuvant cisplatin based chemotherapy appears to be unrelated to ERCC1 status.
title: ERCC1 as a Prognostic and Predictive Biomarker for Urothelial Carcinoma of the Bladder following Radical Cystectomy.

text: FLT3 is a receptor tyrosine kinase that may play a role in a significant proportion of leukemias.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: In addition to being aberrantly expressed in acute leukemias, activating mutations of the FLT3 gene have been found in patients with AML, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and more rarely, ALL.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: Internal tandem duplications (ITDs) of the FLT3 gene have been detected in 17-34% of patients with AML and portend a poor prognosis for these patients.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: FLT3 receptors containing ITD mutations (FLT3/ITDs) are constitutively activated in the absence of FLT3 ligand (FL) stimulation leading to the activation of downstream signaling proteins, including ERK and STAT 5.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: FLT3 activity, therefore, is a logical target for therapeutic intervention.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: AG1296 is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor of the tyrphostin class that shows inhibitory activity for wild-type FLT3, in addition to the PDGF and c-KIT receptors.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: We examined the inhibitory effects of AG1296 on FLT3/ITDs isolated from AML patients in the IL-3-dependent cell line, Ba/F3, as well as in primary leukemia samples from AML patients.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: Immunoprecipitation and immunoblotting analyses demonstrated that FLT3/ITDs were constitutively phosphorylated in the absence of FL.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: The auto-phosphorylation of FLT3/ITDs was inhibited by AG1296 with an IC(50) of approximately 1 microM.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: FLT3/ITDs were associated with constitutive phosphorylation of ERK, STAT 5A, STAT 5B, CBL, VAV and SHP2 in Ba/F3 cells.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: The phosphorylation of these downstream signaling molecules was suppressed in a dose-responsive fashion by AG1296.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: AG1296 inhibited IL-3 independent growth and induced apoptosis in Ba/F3 cells transformed by FLT3/ITDs.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: AG1296 also inhibited FLT3 auto-phosphorylation, and induced a cytotoxic effect, in primary AML cells.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: These findings suggest that inhibiting the activity of FLT3 may have a therapeutic value in some leukemias expressing FLT3/ITDs.
title: Inhibition of the transforming activity of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutants from AML patients by a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

text: BACKGROUND: Several lines of evidence indicate that Sirt1, a class III histone deacetylase (HDAC) is implicated in the initiation and progression of malignancies and thus gained attraction as druggable target.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Since data on the role of Sirt1 in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) are sparse, we investigated the expression profile and prognostic significance of Sirt1 in vivo as well as cellular effects of Sirt1 inhibition in vitro.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: METHODS: Sirt1 expression was analyzed by immunohistochemistry in a large cohort of PDACs and correlated with clinicopathological and survival data.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Furthermore, we investigated the impact of overexpression and small molecule inhibition on Sirt1 in pancreatic cancer cell culture models including combinatorial treatment with chemotherapy and EGFR-inhibition.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Cellular events were measured quantitatively in real time and corroborated by conventional readouts including FACS analysis and MTT assays.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: We detected nuclear Sirt1 expression in 36 (27.9%) of 129 PDACs.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: SIRT1 expression was significantly higher in poorly differentiated carcinomas.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Strong SIRT1 expression was a significant predictor of poor survival both in univariate (p = 0.002) and multivariate (HR 1.65, p = 0.045) analysis.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Accordingly, overexpression of Sirt1 led to increased cell viability, while small molecule inhibition led to a growth arrest in pancreatic cancer cells and impaired cell survival.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: This effect was even more pronounced in combinatorial regimens with gefitinib, but not in combination with gemcitabine.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Sirt1 is an independent prognosticator in PDACs and plays an important role in pancreatic cancer cell growth, which can be levered out by small molecule inhibition.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Our data warrant further studies on SIRT1 as a novel chemotherapeutic target in PDAC.
title: High SIRT1 expression is a negative prognosticator in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: The sustained clinical activity of the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib (PLX4032/RG7204) in patients with BRAF(V600) mutant melanoma is limited primarily by the development of acquired resistance leading to tumor progression.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: Clinical trials are in progress using MEK inhibitors following disease progression in patients receiving BRAF inhibitors.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: However, the PI3K/AKT pathway can also induce resistance to the inhibitors of MAPK pathway.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: The sensitivity to vemurafenib or the MEK inhibitor AZD6244 was tested in sensitive and resistant human melanoma cell lines exploring differences in activation-associated phosphorylation levels of major signaling molecules, leading to the testing of co-inhibition of the AKT/mTOR pathway genetically and pharmacologically.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: There was a high degree of cross-resistance to vemurafenib and AZD6244, except in two vemurafenib-resistant cell lines that acquired a secondary mutation in NRAS.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: In other cell lines, acquired resistance to both drugs was associated with persistence or increase in activity of AKT pathway.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: siRNA-mediated gene silencing and combination therapy with an AKT inhibitor or rapamycin partially or completely reversed the resistance.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Primary and acquired resistance to vemurafenib in these in vitro models results in frequent cross resistance to MEK inhibitors, except when the resistance is the result of a secondary NRAS mutation.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.
