text: Resistance to BRAF or MEK inhibitors is associated with the induction or persistence of activity within the AKT pathway in the presence of these drugs.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: This resistance can be potentially reversed by the combination of a RAF or MEK inhibitor with an AKT or mTOR inhibitor.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: These combinations should be available for clinical testing in patients progressing on BRAF inhibitors.
title: Reversing melanoma cross-resistance to BRAF and MEK inhibitors by co-targeting the AKT/mTOR pathway.

text: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the influence of multi-drug resistance 1 (MDR1) gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on response to platinum-based chemotherapeutic regimens for advanced non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: Responses and overall survival were evaluated in a series of patients presenting between March 1, 2005 and December 31, 2010.
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: MDR1 gene C3435T polymorphisms were genotyped using peripheral blood with real time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and relationships between the MDR1 C3435T genetic polymorphism and response rate of chemotherapy were analyzed by SPSS 13.0.
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Overall response to chemotherapy in the eligible 103 patients was 21.4%.
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: Patients with C/C genotype in MDR1 codon 3435 had a significantly higher response rate (24.5%) than those for C/T(19.0%) and T/T(12.5%) (P<0.05).
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: The overall median survival time (MST) of patients was 19 months, values with C/C, C/T and T/T genotype were 21, 15.5 and 17 months, respectively (P=0.487).
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Our research suggested that patents with the C/C genotype in MDR1 codon 3435 could be more sensitive to platinum-based chemotherapy than patients with C/T and T/T; however, no significant difference was found between overall survival and MDR1 codon 3435 genetic polymorphisms.
title: Influence of MDR1 gene codon 3435 polymorphisms on outcome of platinum-based chemotherapy for advanced non small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Previous studies have yielded conflicting results regarding the relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: We therefore performed a meta-analysis to expound the relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy.
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS/FINDINGS: Thirteen previously published eligible studies, including 564 cases, were identified and included in this meta-analysis.
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: p53 positive status (high expression of p53 protein and/or a mutant p53 gene) was associated with improved response in gastric cancer patients who received chemotherapy (good response: risk ratio [RR] = 0.704; 95% confidence intervals [CI] = 0.550-0.903; P = 0.006).
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: In further stratified analyses, association with a good response remained in the East Asian population (RR = 0.657; 95% CI = 0.488-0.884; P = 0.005), while in the European subgroup, patients with p53 positive status tended to have a good response to chemotherapy, although this did not reach statistical significance (RR = 0.828, 95% CI = 0.525-1.305; P = 0.417).
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: As five studies used neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NCT) and one used neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NCRT), we also analyzed these data, and found that p53 positive status was associated with a good response in gastric cancer patients who received chemotherapy-based neoadjuvant treatment (RR = 0.675, 95% CI = 0.463-0.985; P = 0.042).
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSION: This meta-analysis indicated that p53 status may be a useful predictive biomarker for response to chemotherapy in gastric cancer.
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Further prospective studies with larger sample sizes and better study designs are required to confirm our findings.
title: Relationship between p53 status and response to chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND AND METHODS: The nerve growth factor receptor is expressed in some neuroblastomas, in which its primary component is encoded by the TRK protooncogene.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: To determine the relation of the expression of TRK messenger RNA in neuroblastomas to other clinical and laboratory variables, we studied frozen tumor samples from 77 patients.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: In addition, we tested two primary neuroblastomas that expressed TRK for responsiveness to nerve growth factor.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: RESULTS: TRK expression strongly correlated with favorable tumor stage (I, II, and IVS vs. III and IV), younger age (< 1 year vs. > or = 1 year), normal N-myc copy number, and low level of N-myc expression.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: N-myc amplification (indicated by a high copy number) correlated with advanced tumor stage, older age, an adrenal site of the primary tumor, low level of expression of TRK, and high level of expression of N-myc.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: Analysis of five-year cumulative-survival rates demonstrated an association of a very favorable outcome with a high level of TRK expression (86 percent vs. 14 percent) and with normal N-myc copy number (84 percent vs. 0 percent).
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: Univariate analysis showed that these two variables were the most powerful predictors of outcome (chi-square = 51.30, P < 0.001; and chi-square = 93.61, P < 0.001, respectively).
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: TRK expression still had significant prognostic value when the analysis was restricted to tumors without N-myc amplification.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: In primary cultures of neuroblastoma cells expressing TRK, exposure to nerve growth factor induced early gene expression and neurite outgrowth, but deprivation of nerve growth factor led to neuronal cell death.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: A high level of expression of the TRK proto-oncogene in a neuroblastoma is strongly predictive of a favorable outcome.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: A tumor with a functional nerve growth factor receptor may be dependent on the neurotrophin nerve growth factor for survival and may regress in its absence, allowing a new approach to the treatment of certain patients with neuroblastoma.
title: Association between high levels of expression of the TRK gene and favorable outcome in human neuroblastoma.

text: Activating mutations in tyrosine kinases have been identified in hematopoietic and nonhematopoietic malignancies.
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Recently, we and others identified a single recurrent somatic activating mutation (JAK2V617F) in the Janus kinase 2 (JAK2) tyrosine kinase in the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and myeloid metaplasia with myelofibrosis.
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: We used direct sequence analysis to determine if the JAK2V617F mutation was present in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML)/atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia (aCML), myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), B-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), T-cell ALL, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Analysis of 222 patients with AML identified JAK2V617F mutations in 4 patients with AML, 3 of whom had a preceding MPD.
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: JAK2V617F mutations were identified in 9 (7.8%) of 116 CMML/a CML samples, and in 2 (4.2%) of 48 MDS samples.
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: We did not identify the JAK2V617F disease allele in B-lineage ALL (n = 83), T-cell ALL (n = 93), or CLL (n = 45).
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: These data indicate that the JAK2V617F allele is present in acute and chronic myeloid malignancies but not in lymphoid malignancies.
title: The JAK2V617F activating mutation occurs in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia, but not in acute lymphoblastic leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Mutations in the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate(+)-dependent isocitrate dehydrogenase gene 2 (IDH2) have recently been found in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as well as in patients with leukemic transformation of myeloproliferative neoplasms.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We analyzed 272 adult patients with cytogenetically normal AML (CN-AML) for the presence of IDH2 mutations in codons R140 and R172.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: IDH2 mutations of amino acid 140 or 172 could be identified in 12.1% of CN-AML patients, with the majority of mutations (90%) occurring at position R140.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The incidence of IDH2 mutations in AML patients with aberrant karyotypes (n = 130) was significantly lower (3.8%, P = .006).
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: IDH2 mutations were mutually exclusive with mutations in IDH1.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: IDH2 mutation status alone or in combination with IDH1 mutations had no impact on response to therapy, overall survival, and relapse-free survival in patients with CN-AML.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In conclusion, IDH2 mutations are frequently found in CN-AML, but in our analysis these mutations did not influence treatment outcome.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: This study was registered at www.clinicaltrials.gov as #NCT00209833.
title: Prognostic impact of IDH2 mutations in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein alpha (CEBPA) mutations are a favorable prognostic factor in adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients; however, few studies have examined their significance in pediatric AML patients.
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: Here we examined the CEBPA mutation status and clinical outcomes of pediatric AML patients treated in the AML-05 study.
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: We found that 47 (14.9%) of the 315 evaluable patients harbored mutations in CEBPA; 26 cases (8.3%) harbored a single mutation (CEBPA-single) and 21 (6.7%) harbored double or triple mutations (CEBPA-double).
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: After excluding core-binding factor-AML cases, patients harboring CEBPA mutations showed better overall survival (OS; P=0.048), but not event-free survival (EFS; P=0.051), than wild-type patients.
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: Multivariate analysis identified CEBPA-single and CEBPA-double as independent favorable prognostic factors for EFS in the total cohort (hazard ratio (HR): 0.47 and 0.33; P=0.02 and 0.01, respectively).
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: CEBPA-double was also an independent favorable prognostic factor for OS (HR: 0.30; P=0.04).
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: CEBPA-double remained an independent favorable factor for EFS (HR: 0.28; P=0.04) in the normal karyotype cohort.
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: These results suggest that CEBPA mutations, particularly CEBPA-double, are an independent favorable prognostic factor in pediatric AML patients, which will have important implications for risk-stratified therapy.
title: Prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia: a report from the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group.

text: HSP90 inhibition represents a promising route to cancer therapy, taking advantage of cancer cell-inherent proteotoxic stress.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: The HSP90-inhibitor ganetespib showed benefit in advanced clinical trials.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: This raises the need to identify the molecular determinants of treatment response.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: We tested the efficacy of ganetespib on a series of colorectal cancer (CRC)-derived cell lines and correlated their sensitivities with comprehensive gene expression analysis.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: Notably, the drug concentration required for 50% growth inhibition (IC50) varied up to 70-fold (from 36 to 2500 nM) between different cell lines.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: Correlating cell line-specific IC50s with the corresponding gene expression patterns revealed a strong association between ganetespib resistance (IC50>500 nM) and high expression of the UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A (UGT1A) gene cluster.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: Moreover, CRC tumor samples showed a comparable distribution of UGT1A expression levels.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: The members of the UGT1A gene family are known as drug-conjugating liver enzymes involved in drug excretion, but their function in tumor cells is hardly understood.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: Chemically unrelated HSP90 inhibitors, for example, 17-N-allylamino-17-demethoxygeldanamycin (17-AAG), did not show correlation of drug sensitivities with UGT1A levels, whereas the ganetespib-related compound NVP-AUY922 did.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: When the most ganetespib-resistant cell line, HT29, was treated with ganetespib, the levels of HSP90 clients were unaffected.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: However, HT29 cells became sensitized to the drug, and HSP90 client proteins were destabilized by ganetespib upon siRNA-mediated UGT1A knockdown.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: Conversely, the most ganetespib-sensitive cell lines HCT116 and SW480 became more tolerant toward ganetespib upon UGT1A overexpression.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: Mechanistically, ganetespib was rapidly glucuronidated and excreted in resistant but not in sensitive CRC lines.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: We conclude that CRC cell-expressed UGT1A inactivates ganetespib and other resorcinolic Hsp90 inhibitors by glucuronidation, which renders the drugs unable to inhibit Hsp90 and thereby abrogates their biological activity.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: UGT1A levels in tumor tissues may be a suitable predictive biomarker to stratify CRC patients for ganetespib treatment.
title: UDP glucuronosyltransferase 1A expression levels determine the response of colorectal cancer cells to the heat shock protein 90 inhibitor ganetespib.

text: BACKGROUND: Thymidylate synthase (TS) and Topoisomerase I (Topo I) are significant biomarkers in colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: We aimed to study the expression of TS and Topo I in patients with resected CRC who received adjuvant chemotherapy and correlated it with clinical outcome.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: METHODS: All patients diagnosed with CRC between 1989 and 2007 and treated with adjuvant chemotherapy within Hellenic Cooperative Oncology Group's (HeCOG) protocols, were identified.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: Archival paraffin-embedded tumor tissues were used for immunohistochemical detection of TS and Topo I. Immunohistochemistry was performed on tissue microarray slides using monoclonal antibodies against TS and Topo I.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: The results were correlated with survival (OS) and disease free survival (DFS).
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: RESULTS: A cohort of 498 patients with a median age of 61 years and Dukes' stage B (49%) and C (51%) fulfilled the criteria of the study.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: All patients received adjuvant 5-FU-based chemotherapy, 38% irinotecan-containing.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: Positive TS and Topo I expression was found in 43% and 48% of cases, respectively.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: Five-year OS was 74% and DFS was 68%.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: In univariate analysis no association of TS and Topo I expression with OS and DFS was identified.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: In multivariate analysis however, Topo I expression was associated with a reduced risk of death (HR = 0.61, 95% CI 0.42-0.88, p = 0.009).
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: In the irinotecan-treated subgroup, those patients who expressed Topo I had a better OS (HR = 0.47, 95% CI 0.23-0.94, p = 0.033).
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: CONCLUSION: Patients with resected CRC expressing Topo I seem to benefit from irinotecan-containing adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: However randomised prospective trials are needed to confirm these results.
title: Topoisomerase I but not thymidylate synthase is associated with improved outcome in patients with resected colorectal cancer treated with irinotecan containing adjuvant chemotherapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Synovial sarcomas account for up to 10 percent of soft-tissue sarcomas and include two major histologic subtypes, biphasic and monophasic, defined respectively by the presence and absence of glandular epithelial differentiation in a background of spindle tumor cells.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: A characteristic SYT-SSX fusion gene resulting from the chromosomal translocation t(X;18)(p11;q11) is detectable in almost all synovial sarcomas.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: The translocation fuses the SYT gene from chromosome 18 to either of two highly homologous genes at Xp11, SSX1 or SSX2.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: SYT-SSX1 and SYT-SSX2 are thought to tunction as aberrant transcriptional regulators.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: We attempted to determine the influence of the two alternative forms of the SYT-SSX fusion gene on tumor morphology and clinical outcome in patients with this sarcoma.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: METHODS: We analyzed SYT-SSX fusion transcripts in 45 synovial sarcomas (33 monophasic and 12 biphasic) by the reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction and compared the results with relevant clinical and pathological data.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: RESULTS: The SYT-SSX1 and SYT-SSX2 fusion transcripts were detected in 29 (64 percent) and 16 (36 percent) of the tumors, respectively.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: There was a significant relation (P=0.003) between histologic subtype (monophasic vs. biphasic) and SSX1 or SSX2 involvement in the fusion transcript: all 12 biphasic synovial sarcomas had a SYT-SSX1 fusion transcript, and all 16 tumors that were positive for SYT-SSX2 were monophasic.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: Kaplan-Meier analysis of 39 patients with localized tumors showed that the 15 patients with SYT-SSX2 had significantly better metastasis-free survival than the 24 patients with SYT-SSX1 (P=0.03 by multivariate analysis; relative risk, 3.0).
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: There were no significant correlations between the type of SYT-SSX transcript and age, sex, tumor location and size, whether there were metastases at diagnosis, or whether patients underwent chemotherapy.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: Histologic subtype alone was not prognostically important.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The type of SYT-SSX fusion transcript correlates with both the histologic subtype and the clinical behavior of synovial sarcoma.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: SYT-SSX fusion transcripts are a defining diagnostic marker of synovial sarcomas and may also yield important independent prognostic information.
title: SYT-SSX gene fusion as a determinant of morphology and prognosis in synovial sarcoma.

text: Arsenic trioxide (As(2)O(3)) is a highly effective treatment for patients with refractory/relapsed acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), but resistance to As(2)O(3) has recently been seen.
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: In the present study, we report the findings that 2 of 15 patients with refractory/relapsed APL treated with As(2)O(3) were clinically As(2)O(3) resistant.
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: Leukemia cells from these 2 patients harbored missense mutations in promyelocytic leukemia gene-retinoic acid receptor-alpha gene (PML-RARA) transcripts, resulting in amino acid substitutions of A216V and L218P in the PML B2 domain.
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: When wild-type or mutated PML-RARA (PR-WT and PR-B/L-mut, respectively) were overexpressed in HeLa cells, immunoblotting showed SUMOylated and/or oligomerized protein bands in PR-WT but not in PR-B/L-mut after As(2)O(3) treatment.
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: Protein-localization analysis indicated that PR-WT in the soluble fraction was transferred to the insoluble fraction after treatment with As(2)O(3), but PR-B/L-mut was stably detected in fractions both with and without As(2)O(3).
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: Immunofluorescent microscopy analysis showed PR-WT localization as a microgranular pattern in the cytoplasm without As(2)O(3) and as a macrogranular pattern with As(2)O(3).
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: PR-B/L-mut was diffusely observed in the cytoplasm with and without As(2)O(3).
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: Nearly identical localization patterns were observed in patients' primary cells.
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: Therefore, B2 domain mutations may play an important role in aberrant molecular responses toAs(2)O(3) and may be critical for As(2)O(3) resistance in APL.
title: Missense mutations in PML-RARA are critical for the lack of responsiveness to arsenic trioxide treatment.

text: Numerous antiangiogenic agents are approved for the treatment of oncological diseases.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: However, almost all patients develop evasive resistance mechanisms against antiangiogenic therapies.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Currently no predictive biomarker for therapy resistance or response has been established.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Therefore, the aim of our study was to identify biomarkers predicting the development of therapy resistance in patients with hepatocellular cancer (n = 11), renal cell cancer (n = 7) and non-small cell lung cancer (n = 2).
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Thereby we measured levels of angiogenic growth factors, tumor perfusion, circulating endothelial cells (CEC), circulating endothelial progenitor cells (CEP) and tumor endothelial markers (TEM) in patients during the course of therapy with antiangiogenic agents, and correlated them with the time to antiangiogenic progression (aTTP).
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Importantly, at disease progression, we observed an increase of proangiogenic factors, upregulation of CEC/CEP levels and downregulation of TEMs, such as Robo4 and endothelial cell-specific chemotaxis regulator (ECSCR), reflecting the formation of torturous tumor vessels.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Increased TEM expression levels tended to correlate with prolonged aTTP (ECSCR high = 275 days vs. ECSCR low = 92.5 days; p = 0.07 and for Robo4 high = 387 days vs. Robo4 low = 90.0 days; p = 0.08).
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: This indicates that loss of vascular stabilization factors aggravates the development of antiangiogenic resistance.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Thus, our observations confirm that CEP/CEC populations, proangiogenic cytokines and TEMs contribute to evasive resistance in antiangiogenic treated patients.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: Higher TEM expression during disease progression may have clinical and pathophysiological implications, however, validation of our results is warranted for further biomarker development.
title: Biomarkers of evasive resistance predict disease progression in cancer patients treated with antiangiogenic therapies.

text: BACKGROUND: Oncogenic fusion genes consisting of EML4 and anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) are present in a subgroup of non-small-cell lung cancers, representing 2 to 7% of such tumors.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: We explored the therapeutic efficacy of inhibiting ALK in such tumors in an early-phase clinical trial of crizotinib (PF-02341066), an orally available small-molecule inhibitor of the ALK tyrosine kinase.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: After screening tumor samples from approximately 1500 patients with non-small-cell lung cancer for the presence of ALK rearrangements, we identified 82 patients with advanced ALK-positive disease who were eligible for the clinical trial.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Most of the patients had received previous treatment.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: These patients were enrolled in an expanded cohort study instituted after phase 1 dose escalation had established a recommended crizotinib dose of 250 mg twice daily in 28-day cycles.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Patients were assessed for adverse events and response to therapy.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Patients with ALK rearrangements tended to be younger than those without the rearrangements, and most of the patients had little or no exposure to tobacco and had adenocarcinomas.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: At a mean treatment duration of 6.4 months, the overall response rate was 57% (47 of 82 patients, with 46 confirmed partial responses and 1 confirmed complete response); 27 patients (33%) had stable disease.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: A total of 63 of 82 patients (77%) were continuing to receive crizotinib at the time of data cutoff, and the estimated probability of 6-month progression-free survival was 72%, with no median for the study reached.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The drug resulted in grade 1 or 2 (mild) gastrointestinal side effects.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The inhibition of ALK in lung tumors with the ALK rearrangement resulted in tumor shrinkage or stable disease in most patients.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: (Funded by Pfizer and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00585195.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.
Anaplastic lymphoma kinase inhibition in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Fifteen patients with refractory AML were treated in a phase 1 study with SU11248, an oral kinase inhibitor of fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 (Flt3), Kit, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) receptors.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: Separate cohorts of patients received SU11248 for 4-week cycles followed by either a 2- or a 1-week rest period.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: At the starting dose level of 50 mg (n = 13), no dose-limiting toxicities were observed.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: The most frequent grade 2 toxicities were edema, fatigue, and oral ulcerations.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: Two fatal bleedings possibly related to the disease, one from a concomitant lung cancer and one cerebral bleeding, were observed.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: At the 75 mg dose level (n = 2), one case each of grade 4 fatigue, hypertension, and cardiac failure was observed, and this dose level was abandoned.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: All patients with FLT3 mutations (n = 4) had morphologic or partial responses compared with 2 of 10 evaluable patients with wild-type FLT3.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: Responses, although longer in patients with mutated FLT3, were of short duration.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: Reductions of cellularity and numbers of Ki-67(+), phospho-Kit(+), phospho-kinase domain-containing receptor-positive (phospho-KDR(+)), phospho-signal transducer and activator of transcription 5-positive (phospho-STAT5(+)), and phospho-Akt(+) cells were detected in bone marrow histology analysis.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: In summary, monotherapy with SU11248 induced partial remissions of short duration in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: Further evaluation of this compound, for example in combination with chemotherapy, is warranted.
title: A phase 1 study of SU11248 in the treatment of patients with refractory or resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or not amenable to conventional therapy for the disease.

text: PURPOSE: The c-kit protein, also known as CD117, is a member of the type III receptor tyrosine kinase family.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: Kinase activity has been implicated in the pathophysiology of many tumors, including small-cell lung carcinoma (SCLC).
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: Autocrine or paracrine activation of c-kit by its ligand has been postulated for lung cancer, but this receptor can also be activated by mutations of the c-kit gene.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: We examined c-kit expression and mutational status in SCLC to verify its putative expression and genetic alterations, as well as its eventual prognostic impact.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We studied 60 SCLC samples to determine the mutations of the coding region of the gene; the exons 9 and 11 were analyzed by PCR-single-strand conformational polymorphism and automated sequencing.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: Moreover, c-kit expression was evaluated in 55 samples by immunohistochemical method.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: RESULTS: Expression of c-kit was demonstrated in about 40% of SCLC samples.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: Two mutations in exon 9 and three mutations in exon 11 were found.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: Kaplan-Meier analysis revealed no prognostic significance of c-kit expression for survival.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In our series, the expression of c-kit and its mutational status failed to appear relevant or to have a significant impact on survival; this makes the therapeutic approach with an inhibitor of tyrosine kinase more difficult in SCLC until a sure demonstration of c-kit implication is obtained for this tumor.
title: Expression and mutational status of c-kit in small-cell lung cancer: prognostic relevance.

text: A detailed understanding of the mechanisms by which tumors acquire resistance to targeted anticancer agents should speed the development of treatment strategies with lasting clinical efficacy.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: RAF inhibition in BRAF-mutant melanoma exemplifies the promise and challenge of many targeted drugs; although response rates are high, resistance invariably develops.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: Here, we articulate overarching principles of resistance to kinase inhibitors, as well as a translational approach to characterize resistance in the clinical setting through tumor mutation profiling.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: As a proof of principle, we performed targeted, massively parallel sequencing of 138 cancer genes in a tumor obtained from a patient with melanoma who developed resistance to PLX4032 after an initial dramatic response.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: The resulting profile identified an activating mutation at codon 121 in the downstream kinase MEK1 that was absent in the corresponding pretreatment tumor.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: The MEK1(C121S) mutation was shown to increase kinase activity and confer robust resistance to both RAF and MEK inhibition in vitro.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: Thus, MEK1(C121S) or functionally similar mutations are predicted to confer resistance to combined MEK/RAF inhibition.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: These results provide an instructive framework for assessing mechanisms of acquired resistance to kinase inhibition and illustrate the use of emerging technologies in a manner that may accelerate personalized cancer medicine.
title: Dissecting therapeutic resistance to RAF inhibition in melanoma by tumor genomic profiling.

text: BACKGROUND: Neuroblastoma is a pediatric cancer that exhibits a wide clinical spectrum ranging from spontaneous regression in low-risk patients to fatal disease in high-risk patients.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: The identification of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) may help explain the heterogeneity of neuroblastoma and assist in identifying patients at higher risk for poor survival.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: SNPs in the TP53 pathway are of special importance, as several studies have reported associations between TP53 pathway SNPs and cancer.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: Of note, less than 2% of neuroblastoma tumors have a TP53 mutation at diagnosis.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We selected 21 of the most frequently studied SNPs in the TP53 pathway and evaluated their association with outcome in 500 neuroblastoma patients using TaqMan allelic discrimination assays.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: We investigated the impact of 21 SNPs on overall survival, event-free survival, age at diagnosis, MYCN status, and stage of the disease in 500 neuroblastoma patients.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: A missense SNP in exon 10 of the CASP8 gene SNP D302H was associated with worse overall and event-free survival in patients with MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma tumors.
title: CASP8 SNP D302H (rs1045485) is associated with worse survival in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma patients.

text: OBJECTIVES: We investigated the relationship between BRCA1 protein expression by immunohistochemistry (IHC) and clinical outcome following platinum and platinum/taxane chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC).
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: METHODS: BRCA1 IHC was performed on a cohort of 292 ovarian tumours from two UK oncology centres.
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: BRCA1 protein expression levels were correlated with overall survival (OS), progression free survival (PFS) and clinical response to chemotherapy by multivariate analysis.
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: RESULTS: EOC patients with absent/low BRCA1 protein expression (41%) had a better chance of clinical response following chemotherapy as compared to patients with high BRCA1 expression (odds ratio 2.47: 95%CI 1.10-5.55, p=0.029).
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Patients with absent/low BRCA1 had a higher probability of clinical response following single agent platinum compared to high BRCA1 expressing patients (68.5% vs. 46.8%), while addition of a taxane increased response rates independent of BRCA1.
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: Overall, patients with absent/low BRCA1 had a better clinical outcome compared to patients with high BRCA1 protein expression in terms of both OS (HR=0.65: 95%CI 0.48-0.88, p=0.006) and PFS (HR=0.74, 95%CI 0.55-0.98, p=0.040).
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We confirm that absent/low BRCA1 protein expression is a favourable prognostic marker.
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: However, we also provide the first evidence that absent/low BRCA1 protein expression in sporadic EOC patients predicts for an improved clinical response to chemotherapy.
title: BRCA1 is both a prognostic and predictive biomarker of response to chemotherapy in sporadic epithelial ovarian cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: There is a need for improved prognostic markers in melanoma.
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: In this study, the authors tested the prognostic significance and clinicopathologic correlations of v-raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homolog B1 (BRAF) and neuroblastoma RAS viral (v-ras) oncogene homolog (NRAS) mutations in patients with metastatic melanoma.
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: METHODS: Clinical and pathologic data were collected retrospectively on melanoma patients who were clinically tested for BRAF (exon 15) and NRAS (exons 1 and 2) mutations at The University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center.
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: Analyses were performed to identify significant associations of mutations with tumor and patient characteristics and with survival from the diagnosis of stage IV disease.
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: RESULTS: The genotypes of the full cohort (n = 677) were 47% BRAF mutation, 20% NRAS mutation, and 32% wild-type for BRAF and NRAS ("WT").
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: Tumor mutation status was associated (P = .008) with the risk of central nervous system involvement at the diagnosis of stage IV disease, with a higher prevalence observed in BRAF-mutant (24%) and NRAS-mutant (23%) patients than in WT patients (12%).
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: Among patients with nonuveal melanoma who underwent mutation testing within 6 months of stage IV diagnosis (n = 313), patients with NRAS mutations had a median survival of 8.2 months from stage IV diagnosis, which was shorter than the median survival of WT patients (15.1 months; P = .004).
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: Multivariate analysis of this population incorporating age, sex, metastases (M1) category, serum lactate dehydrogenase level, and mutation status confirmed that NRAS mutations are associated independently with decreased overall survival (vs WT; P = .005; hazard ratio, 2.05).
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Patients with BRAF or NRAS mutations were more likely than WT patients to have central nervous system involvement at the time they were diagnosed with distant metastatic disease.
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: NRAS mutation status was identified as an independent predictor of shorter survival after a diagnosis of stage IV melanoma.
title: NRAS mutation status is an independent prognostic factor in metastatic melanoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Epigenetic silencing of the MGMT (O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase) DNA-repair gene by promoter methylation compromises DNA repair and has been associated with longer survival in patients with glioblastoma who receive alkylating agents.
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: METHODS: We tested the relationship between MGMT silencing in the tumor and the survival of patients who were enrolled in a randomized trial comparing radiotherapy alone with radiotherapy combined with concomitant and adjuvant treatment with temozolomide.
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: The methylation status of the MGMT promoter was determined by methylation-specific polymerase-chain-reaction analysis.
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: RESULTS: The MGMT promoter was methylated in 45 percent of 206 assessable cases.
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: Irrespective of treatment, MGMT promoter methylation was an independent favorable prognostic factor (P<0.001 by the log-rank test; hazard ratio, 0.45; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.32 to 0.61).
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: Among patients whose tumor contained a methylated MGMT promoter, a survival benefit was observed in patients treated with temozolomide and radiotherapy; their median survival was 21.7 months (95 percent confidence interval, 17.4 to 30.4), as compared with 15.3 months (95 percent confidence interval, 13.0 to 20.9) among those who were assigned to only radiotherapy (P=0.007 by the log-rank test).
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: In the absence of methylation of the MGMT promoter, there was a smaller and statistically insignificant difference in survival between the treatment groups.
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Patients with glioblastoma containing a methylated MGMT promoter benefited from temozolomide, whereas those who did not have a methylated MGMT promoter did not have such a benefit.
title: MGMT gene silencing and benefit from temozolomide in glioblastoma.

text: Hypoxia-inducible factor-1 alpha (HIF-1alpha) is over-expressed in many cancers including pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and correlated with poor prognosis.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: We aim to determine the effect of germline genetic variants on the regulation of the homeostasis of the miRNA-gene regulatory loop in HIF1A gene and PDAC risk.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: HIF1A rs2057482 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) was genotyped in 410 PDAC cases and 490 healthy controls.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: The CC genotype SNP HIF1A is significantly correlated with PDAC risk (OR = 1.719, 95% CI: 1.293-2.286) and shorter overall survival (OS, P<0.0001) compared with the CT/TT alleles group.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: The C/T variants of rs2057482, a SNP located near the miR-199a binding site in HIF1A, could lead to differential regulation of HIF1A by miR-199a.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: Specifically, the C allele of rs2057482 weakened miR-199a-induced repression of HIF-1alpha expression on both mRNA and protein levels.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: In the PDAC tissue, individuals with the rs2057482-CC genotype expressed significantly higher levels of HIF-1alpha protein than those with the rs2057482-CT/TT genotype (P<0.0001).
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: Both the CC genotype of SNP HIF1A and increased HIF-1alpha expression are significantly associated with shorter OS of patients with PDAC.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: After adjusted by TNM staging, differentiation grade, and the levels of CA19-9, both SNP HIF1A and HIF-1alpha expression retained highly significance on OS (P<0.0001).
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: Taken together, our study demonstrates that host genetic variants could disturb the regulation of the miR-199a/HIF1A regulatory loop and alter PDAC risk and poor prognosis.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: In conclusion, the rs2057482-CC genotype increases the susceptibility to PDAC and associated with cancer progression.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism in the microRNA-199a binding site of HIF1A gene is associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma risk and worse clinical outcomes.

text: The anti-HER2 antibody pertuzumab inhibits HER2 dimerization and affects HER2/HER3 dimer formation and signaling.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: As HER3 and its ligand neuregulin are implicated in pancreatic tumorigenesis, we investigated whether HER3 expression could be a predictive biomarker of pertuzumab efficacy in HER2low-expressing pancreatic cancer.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: We correlated in vitro and in vivo HER3 expression and neuregulin dependency with the inhibitory effect of pertuzumab on cell viability and tumor progression.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: HER3 knockdown in BxPC-3 cells led to resistance to pertuzumab therapy.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: Pertuzumab treatment of HER3-expressing pancreatic cancer cells increased HER3 at the cell membrane, whereas the anti-HER3 monoclonal antibody 9F7-F11 down-regulated it.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: Both antibodies blocked HER3 and AKT phosphorylation and inhibited HER2/HER3 heterodimerization but affected differently HER2 and HER3 homodimers.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: The pertuzumab/9F7-F11 combination enhanced tumor inhibition and the median survival time in mice xenografted with HER3-expressing pancreatic cancer cells.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: Finally, HER2 and HER3 were co-expressed in 11% and HER3 alone in 27% of the 45 pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas analyzed by immunohistochemistry.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: HER3 is essential for pertuzumab efficacy in HER2low-expressing pancreatic cancer and HER3 expression might be a predictive biomarker of pertuzumab efficacy in such cancers.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: Further studies in clinical samples are required to confirm these findings and the interest of combining anti-HER2 and anti-HER3 therapeutic antibodies.
title: HER3 as biomarker and therapeutic target in pancreatic cancer: new insights in pertuzumab therapy in preclinical models.

text: Purpose Detection of specific molecular alterations in tumors guides the selection of effective targeted treatment of patients with several types of cancer.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: These molecular alterations may occur in other tumor types for which the efficacy of targeted therapy remains unclear.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: The MyPathway study evaluates the efficacy and safety of selected targeted therapies in tumor types that harbor relevant genetic alterations but are outside of current labeling for these treatments.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Methods MyPathway ( ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT02091141) is a multicenter, nonrandomized, phase IIa multiple basket study.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Patients with advanced refractory solid tumors harboring molecular alterations in human epidermal growth factor receptor-2, epidermal growth factor receptor, v-raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homolog B1, or the Hedgehog pathway are treated with pertuzumab plus trastuzumab, erlotinib, vemurafenib, or vismodegib, respectively.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: The primary end point is investigator-assessed objective response rate within each tumor-pathway cohort.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Results Between April 1, 2014 and November 1, 2016, 251 patients with 35 different tumor types received study treatment.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: The efficacy population contains 230 treated patients who were evaluated for response or discontinued treatment before evaluation.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Fifty-two patients (23%) with 14 different tumor types had objective responses (complete, n = 4; partial, n = 48).
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Tumor-pathway cohorts with notable objective response rates included human epidermal growth factor receptor-2-amplified/overexpressing colorectal (38% [14 of 37]; 95% CI, 23% to 55%) and v-raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homolog B1 V600-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer (43% [six of 14]; 95% CI, 18% to 71%).
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Conclusion The four currently approved targeted therapy regimens in the MyPathway study produced meaningful responses when administered without chemotherapy in several refractory solid tumor types not currently labeled for these agents.
title: Targeted Therapy for Advanced Solid Tumors on the Basis of Molecular Profiles: Results From MyPathway, an Open-Label, Phase IIa Multiple Basket Study.

text: Activating mutations of KIT receptor tyrosine kinase have been reported in different neoplasms.
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: The M541L KIT substitution (KIT(M541L)) has been described to be associated with pediatric mastocytosis, to enhance growth rate of the affected cells and to confer higher sensitivity to imatinib therapy.
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: We investigated the presence of KIT(M541L) in five males with chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified (CEL, NOS), all negative for Platelet-derived growth factor-alpha (PDGFR) or PDGFRbeta abnormalities, which responded to imatinib therapy.
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: To assess whether the mutation was constitutive or somatic in nature, we evaluated its presence analyzing either the neoplastic or normal cell population (epidermal cells or CD3-positive T lymphocytes).
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: KIT(M541L) substitution was found in 4 out of 5 patients and in all it was somatic in nature.
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: All patients were treated with low dose imatinib (100 mg daily orally), achieving complete and persistent clinical and hematological remission (median follow-up 74 months).
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: One patient relapsed after 50 months.
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: Our study strongly suggests to search for the KIT(M541L) in patients with CEL, NOS, negative for PDGFRalpha and PDGFRbeta abnormalities, to identify a subgroup of cases who may benefit from low dose imatinib therapy.
title: Identification of kit(M541L) somatic mutation in chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified and its implication in low-dose imatinib response.

text: PURPOSE: High epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in lung cancer, but such findings have not been reported for HNSCC.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: A better understanding of the EGFR pathway may improve the use of EGFR inhibitors in HNSCC.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: EGFR status was analyzed in 86 tumor samples from 82 HNSCC patients by fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to determine EGFR gene copy number, by polymerase chain reaction and direct sequencing for activating mutations, and by DNA microarray and immunohistochemistry for RNA and protein expression.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: The results were associated with patient characteristics and clinical end points.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: RESULTS: Forty-three (58%) of 75 samples with FISH results demonstrated EGFR high polysomy and/or gene amplification (FISH positive).
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: The FISH-positive group did not differ from the FISH-negative group with respect to age, sex, race, tumor grade, subsites and stage, or EGFR expression by analyses of RNA or protein.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: No activating EGFR mutations were found.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: However, the FISH-positive group was associated with worse progression-free and overall survival (P < .05 and P < .01, respectively; log-rank test).
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: When microarray data were interrogated using the FISH results as a supervising parameter, ECop (which is known to coamplify with EGFR and regulate nuclear factor-kappa B transcriptional activity) had higher expression in FISH-positive tumors.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: CONCLUSION: High EGFR gene copy number by FISH is frequent in HNSCC and is a poor prognostic indicator.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Additional investigation is indicated to determine the biologic significance and implications for EGFR inhibitor therapies in HNSCC.
title: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor gene copy number is associated with poor prognosis in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Mutation-specific cancer therapy has shown promising clinical efficacy.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: In non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), the presence of mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase correlates with clinical response to small-molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: Here, we show that cells harboring the G776insV_G/C mutation in the related ERBB2 tyrosine kinase (also known as HER2 or Neu), present in a small percentage of NSCLCs, are sensitive to HKI-272, an irreversible dual-specific kinase inhibitor targeting both EGFR and ERBB2.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: In the ERBB2-mutant NCI-H1781 cell line, HKI-272 treatment inhibited proliferation by induction of G(1) arrest and apoptotic cell death.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: Furthermore, HKI-272 abrogated autophosphorylation of both ERBB2 and EGFR.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: Finally, Ba/F3 murine pro-B cells, engineered to express mutant ERBB2, became independent of interleukin-3 and sensitive to HKI-272.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: Thus, the subset of NSCLC patients with tumors carrying the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation may benefit from treatment with HKI-272.
title: Non-small-cell lung cancer and Ba/F3 transformed cells harboring the ERBB2 G776insV_G/C mutation are sensitive to the dual-specific epidermal growth factor receptor and ERBB2 inhibitor HKI-272.

text: The p14ARF/MDM2/ TP53 pathway is known to play an important role in tumor progression by cell cycle control, although the association between this pathway and the prognosis of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is unclear.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: In this study, we explored the association between genetic variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 pathway and prognosis in ESCC patients with radical resection.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: 124 ESCC patients with radical resection were included in this retrospective study and genotyped using the MassArray method.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: According to multivariate Cox hazard analysis and multiple testing, the TC/CC genotype of p14ARF rs3814960 was shown to be strongly related to a decreased overall survival (OS) (HR = 2.77, 95% CI: 1.33-5.75, P = 0.006, Pc = 0.030) and disease-free survival (DFS) (HR = 2.45, 95% CI: 1.30-4.61, P = 0.005, Pc = 0.025).
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: Moreover, patients with the DEL/A +AA genotype of MDM2 rs34886328 had a notably increased OS (HR = 0.27, 95% CI: 0.13-0.56, P = 4.7x10-4, Pc = 0.003) and DFS (HR = 0.22, 95% CI: 0.11-0.43, P = 1.1x10-5, Pc = 6.6x10-5).
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: We also found that these two SNPs had a cumulative effect on the prognosis of ESCC, with the OS (P < 0.001) and DFS (P < 0.001) being shortest for patients carrying both of these unfavorable genotypes.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: In conclusion, genetic variants of the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 pathway are significantly related to OS and DFS, and may be predictors of the prognosis of ESCC after surgery.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: We speculate the individuals with the TC/CC genotype of p14ARF rs3814960 and/or the DEL/DEL genotype of MDMD2 rs34886328 should have more aggressive treatment and may greatly benefit from early prediction and prevention of an unfavorable prognosis by genotyping before the initiation of therapy.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: These findings should be further validated in a larger population.
title: Genetic Variants in the p14ARF/MDM2/TP53 Pathway Are Associated with the Prognosis of Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma Patients Treated with Radical Resection.

text: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is a familial cancer disorder due to inherited loss of function mutations in the LKB1/ STK11 serine/threonine kinase.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: PJS patients develop gastrointestinal hamartomas with 100% penetrance often in the second decade of life, and demonstrate an increased predisposition toward the development of a number of additional malignancies.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Among mitogenic signaling pathways, the mammalian-target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) pathway is hyperactivated in tissues and tumors derived from LKB1-deficient mice.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Consistent with a central role for mTORC1 in these tumors, rapamycin as a single agent results in a dramatic suppression of preexisting GI polyps in LKB1+/- mice.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: However, the key targets of mTORC1 in LKB1-deficient tumors remain unknown.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: We demonstrate here that these polyps, and LKB1- and AMPK-deficient mouse embryonic fibroblasts, show dramatic up-regulation of the HIF-1alpha transcription factor and its downstream transcriptional targets in an rapamycin-suppressible manner.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: The HIF-1alpha targets hexokinase II and Glut1 are up-regulated in these polyps, and using FDG-PET, we demonstrate that LKB1+/- mice show increased glucose utilization in focal regions of their GI tract corresponding to these gastrointestinal hamartomas.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Importantly, we demonstrate that polyps from human Peutz-Jeghers patients similarly exhibit up-regulated mTORC1 signaling, HIF-1alpha, and GLUT1 levels.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Furthermore, like HIF-1alpha and its target genes, the FDG-PET signal in the GI tract of these mice is abolished by rapamycin treatment.
