title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: These findings suggest a number of therapeutic modalities for the treatment and detection of hamartomas in PJS patients, and potential for the screening and treatment of the 30% of sporadic human lung cancers bearing LKB1 mutations.
title: mTOR and HIF-1alpha-mediated tumor metabolism in an LKB1 mouse model of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

text: Somatic mutations that activate phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) have been identified in the p110-alpha catalytic subunit (encoded by PIK3CA).
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: They are most frequently observed in two hotspots: the helical domain (E545K and E542K) and the kinase domain (H1047R).
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: Although the p110-alpha mutants are transforming in vitro, their oncogenic potential has not been assessed in genetically engineered mouse models.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: Furthermore, clinical trials with PI3K inhibitors have recently been initiated, and it is unknown if their efficacy will be restricted to specific, genetically defined malignancies.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: In this study, we engineered a mouse model of lung adenocarcinomas initiated and maintained by expression of p110-alpha H1047R.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: Treatment of these tumors with NVP-BEZ235, a dual pan-PI3K and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor in clinical development, led to marked tumor regression as shown by positron emission tomography-computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging and microscopic examination.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: In contrast, mouse lung cancers driven by mutant Kras did not substantially respond to single-agent NVP-BEZ235.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: However, when NVP-BEZ235 was combined with a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase (MEK) inhibitor, ARRY-142886, there was marked synergy in shrinking these Kras-mutant cancers.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: These in vivo studies suggest that inhibitors of the PI3K-mTOR pathway may be active in cancers with PIK3CA mutations and, when combined with MEK inhibitors, may effectively treat KRAS mutated lung cancers.
title: Effective use of PI3K and MEK inhibitors to treat mutant Kras G12D and PIK3CA H1047R murine lung cancers.

text: PURPOSE: Somatic mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) have been detected in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and are associated with sensitivity to treatment with gefitinib or erlotinib.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: Our study explored the relationship between the two most common types of somatic EGFR mutations, exon 19 deletions and the L858R point mutation, and outcomes of patients following treatment with gefitinib or erlotinib.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumor specimens obtained before treatment with gefitinib or erlotinib were analyzed for EGFR mutations.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: Patients with exon 19 deletion or L858R mutations were identified.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: The response rate, time to progression, and overall survival were determined for the two groups.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: RESULTS: We identified 36 patients with NSCLC and an EGFR mutation who were treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: Patients with an exon 19 deletion had a significantly longer overall survival compared with patients with an L858R mutation (38 versus 17 months; P = 0.04).
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: There were also trends toward higher response rate (73% versus 50%) and improved time to progression (24 versus 10 months) for the patients with an exon 19 deletion, although these were not independently significant in a multivariate analysis.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: A difference in response rate for patients treated with gefitinib compared with erlotinib was also noted [18 of 23 (78%) versus 3 of 9 (33%); P = 0.04].
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: No obvious difference in time to progression or overall survival was noted between gefitinib- and erlotinib-treated patients.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Patients with NSCLC and EGFR exon 19 deletions have a longer survival following treatment with gefitinib or erlotinib compared with those with the L858R mutation.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: Pooling of greater numbers of patients and completion of prospective trials are needed to further define the predictive and prognostic roles of different EGFR mutations with respect to treatment with gefitinib, erlotinib, and other EGFR inhibitors.
title: Exon 19 deletion mutations of epidermal growth factor receptor are associated with prolonged survival in non-small cell lung cancer patients treated with gefitinib or erlotinib.

text: PURPOSE: AKT signaling is frequently deregulated in human cancers.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: MK-2206 is a potent, oral allosteric inhibitor of all AKT isoforms with antitumor activity in preclinical models.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: A phase I study of MK-2206 was conducted to investigate its safety, maximum-tolerated dose (MTD), pharmacokinetics (PKs), pharmacodynamics (PDs), and preliminary antitumor efficacy.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients with advanced solid tumors received MK-2206 on alternate days.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Paired tumor biopsies were mandated at the MTD for biomarker studies.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: RESULTS: Thirty-three patients received MK-2206 at 30, 60, 75, or 90 mg on alternate days.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Dose-limiting toxicities included skin rash and stomatitis, establishing the MTD at 60 mg. Drug-related toxicities included skin rash (51.5%), nausea (36.4%), pruritus (24.2%), hyperglycemia (21.2%), and diarrhea (21.2%).
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: PKs (area under the concentration-time curve from 0 to 48 hours and maximum measured plasma concentration) were dose proportional.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Phosphorylated serine 473 AKT declined in all tumor biopsies assessed (P = .015), and phosphorylated threonine 246 proline-rich AKT substrate 40 was suppressed in hair follicles at 6 hours (P = .008), on days 7 (P = .028) and 15 (P = .025) with MK-2206; reversible hyperglycemia and increases in insulin c-peptide were also observed, confirming target modulation.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: A patient with pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PTEN loss; KRAS G12D mutation) treated at 60 mg on alternate days experienced a decrease of approximately 60% in cancer antigen 19-9 levels and 23% shrinkage in tumor measurements.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Two patients with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors had minor tumor responses.
title: First-in-man clinical trial of the oral pan-AKT inhibitor MK-2206 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: CONCLUSION: MK-2206 was well tolerated, with evidence of AKT signaling blockade.

text: OBJECTIVES: Acquired resistance mutations to anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) inhibitors such as crizotinib and alectinib have been documented in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients harboring ALK rearrangement (ALK+).
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: Of note I1171T/N/S mutations in the ALK kinase domain have recently been described by several groups to confer resistance to alectinib, a second-generation ALK inhibitor.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: Additionally one of these reports demonstrated one ALK+ NSCLC patient harboring an I1171T acquired mutation has responded to ceritinib, another second-generation ALK inhibitor.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: We reported the presence of an ALK I1171N resistance mutation from comprehensive genomic profiling from a liver biopsy of a progressing metastatic lesion in an ALK+ patient on alectinib after an initial partial response.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: The patient then responded to ceritinib 750 mg orally once daily but required dose reduction to 600 mg once daily.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: She initially had grade 3 elevation of liver enzymes from crizotinib necessitating the original switch to alectinib but experienced no transaminase elevations with alectinib or ceritinib.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This is the fifth patient case to date demonstrating that ALK I1171 mutation confers resistance to alectinib and the second reported case of ALK I1171 mutation being sensitivity to ceritinib.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: Substitutions of isoleucine at amino acid 1171 in the ALK kinase domain may distinguish which second generation ALK inhibitor will be effective after crizotinib failure.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: This case also provides evidence that transaminase elevations is likely a unique adverse event associated with crizotinib and unlikely a "class" effect involving all ALK inhibitors.
title: I1171 missense mutation (particularly I1171N) is a common resistance mutation in ALK-positive NSCLC patients who have progressive disease while on alectinib and is sensitive to ceritinib.

text: AIMS: Antibodies targeting the checkpoint molecules programmed cell death 1 (PD-1) and its ligand PD-L1 are emerging cancer therapeutics.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: We systematically investigated PD-1 and PD-L1 expression patterns in the poor-prognosis tumor entity high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: METHODS: PD-1 and PD-L1 protein expression was determined by immunohistochemistry on tissue microarrays from 215 primary cancers both in cancer cells and in tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs).
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: mRNA expression was measured by quantitative reverse transcription PCR.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: An in silico validation of mRNA data was performed in The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) dataset.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: PD-1 and PD-L1 expression in cancer cells, CD3+, PD-1+, and PD-L1+ TILs densities as well as PD-1 and PD-L1 mRNA levels were positive prognostic factors for progression-free (PFS) and overall survival (OS), with all factors being significant for PFS (p < 0.035 each), and most being significant for OS.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: Most factors also had prognostic value that was independent from age, stage, and residual tumor.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: Moreover, high PD-1+ TILs as well as PD-L1+ TILs densities added prognostic value to CD3+TILs (PD-1+: p = 0.002,; PD-L1+: p = 0.002).
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: The significant positive prognostic impact of PD-1 and PD-L1 mRNA expression could be reproduced in the TCGA gene expression datasets (p = 0.02 and p < 0.0001, respectively).
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Despite their reported immune-modulatory function, high PD-1 and PD-L1 levels are indicators of a favorable prognosis in ovarian cancer.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: Our data indicate that PD-1 and PD-L1 molecules are biologically relevant regulators of the immune response in high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma, which is an argument for the evaluation of immune checkpoint inhibiting drugs in this tumor entity.
title: Prognostic impact of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) and PD-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression in cancer cells and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in ovarian high grade serous carcinoma.

text: The EML4 (echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4)-ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) fusion-type tyrosine kinase is an oncoprotein found in 4 to 5% of non-small-cell lung cancers, and clinical trials of specific inhibitors of ALK for the treatment of such tumors are currently under way.
title: EML4-ALK mutations in lung cancer that confer resistance to ALK inhibitors.

text: Here, we report the discovery of two secondary mutations within the kinase domain of EML4-ALK in tumor cells isolated from a patient during the relapse phase of treatment with an ALK inhibitor.
title: EML4-ALK mutations in lung cancer that confer resistance to ALK inhibitors.

text: Each mutation developed independently in subclones of the tumor and conferred marked resistance to two different ALK inhibitors.
title: EML4-ALK mutations in lung cancer that confer resistance to ALK inhibitors.

text: PURPOSE: Endometrioid endometrial cancers (EEC) frequently harbor coexisting mutations in phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway genes, including PTEN, PIK3CA, PIK3R1, and KRAS.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: We sought to define the genetic determinants of PI3K pathway inhibitor response in EEC cells, and whether PTEN-mutant EEC cell lines rely on p110beta signaling for survival.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Twenty-four human EEC cell lines were characterized for their mutation profile and activation state of PI3K and mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway proteins.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: Cells were treated with pan-class I PI3K, p110alpha, and p110beta isoform-specific, allosteric mTOR, mTOR kinase, dual PI3K/mTOR, mitogen-activated protein/extracellular signal-regulated kinase (MEK), and RAF inhibitors.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: RNA interference (RNAi) was used to assess effects of KRAS silencing in EEC cells.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: RESULTS: EEC cell lines harboring PIK3CA and PTEN mutations were selectively sensitive to the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor GDC-0941 and allosteric mTOR inhibitor temsirolimus, respectively.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: Subsets of EEC cells with concurrent PIK3CA and/or PTEN and KRAS mutations were sensitive to PI3K pathway inhibition, and only 2 of 6 KRAS-mutant cell lines showed response to MEK inhibition.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: KRAS RNAi silencing did not induce apoptosis in KRAS-mutant EEC cells.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: PTEN-mutant EEC cell lines were resistant to the p110beta inhibitors GSK2636771 and AZD6482, and only in combination with the p110alpha selective inhibitor A66 was a decrease in cell viability observed.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Targeted pan-PI3K and mTOR inhibition in EEC cells may be most effective in PIK3CA- and PTEN-mutant tumors, respectively, even in a subset of EECs concurrently harboring KRAS mutations.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: Inhibition of p110beta alone may not be sufficient to sensitize PTEN-mutant EEC cells and combination with other targeted agents may be required.
title: PI3K pathway dependencies in endometrioid endometrial cancer cell lines.

text: Members of the fibroblast growth factor receptor family of kinases (FGFR1-4) are dysregulated in multiple cancers.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: Ponatinib (AP24534) is an oral multitargeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor being explored in a pivotal phase II trial in patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia due to its potent activity against BCR-ABL.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: Ponatinib has also been shown to inhibit the in vitro kinase activity of all four FGFRs, prompting us to examine its potential as an FGFR inhibitor.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: In Ba/F3 cells engineered to express activated FGFR1-4, ponatinib potently inhibited FGFR-mediated signaling and viability with IC(50) values <40 nmol/L, with substantial selectivity over parental Ba/F3 cells.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: In a panel of 14 cell lines representing multiple tumor types (endometrial, bladder, gastric, breast, lung, and colon) and containing FGFRs dysregulated by a variety of mechanisms, ponatinib inhibited FGFR-mediated signaling with IC(50) values <40 nmol/L and inhibited cell growth with GI(50) (concentration needed to reduce the growth of treated cells to half that of untreated cells) values of 7 to 181 nmol/L.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: Daily oral dosing of ponatinib (10-30 mg/kg) to mice reduced tumor growth and inhibited signaling in all three tumor models examined.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: Importantly, the potency of ponatinib in these models is similar to that previously observed in BCR-ABL-driven models and plasma levels of ponatinib that exceed the IC(50) values for FGFR1-4 inhibition can be sustained in patients.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: These results show that ponatinib is a potent pan-FGFR inhibitor and provide strong rationale for its evaluation in patients with FGFR-driven cancers.
title: Ponatinib (AP24534), a multitargeted pan-FGFR inhibitor with activity in multiple FGFR-amplified or mutated cancer models.

text: High-risk types of human papilloma virus (HPV) are increasingly associated with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC).
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Strikingly, patients with HPV-positive OPSCC are highly curable with ionizing radiation and have better survival compared with HPV-negative patients, but the underlying molecular mechanisms remain poorly understood.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: We applied an array-based approach to monitor global changes in CpG island hypermethylation between HPV-negative and HPV-positive OPSCCs and identified a specific pattern of differentially methylated regions that critically depends on the presence of viral transcripts.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: HPV-related alterations were confirmed for the majority of candidate gene promoters by mass spectrometric, quantitative methylation analysis.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: There was a significant inverse correlation between promoter hypermethylation of ALDH1A2, OSR2, GATA4, GRIA4, and IRX4 and transcript levels.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Interestingly, Kaplan-Meier analysis revealed that a combined promoter methylation pattern of low methylation levels in ALDH1A2 and OSR2 promoters and high methylation levels in GATA4, GRIA4, and IRX4 promoters was significantly correlated with improved survival in 3 independent patient cohorts.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: ALDH1A2 protein levels, determined by immunohistochemistry on tissue microarrays, confirmed the association with clinical outcome.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: In summary, our study highlights specific alterations in global gene promoter methylation in HPV-driven OPSCCs and identifies a signature that predicts the clinical outcome in OPSCCs.
title: HPV-related methylation signature predicts survival in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

text: Neuroblastoma, an embryonal tumour of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system, accounts for approximately 15% of all deaths due to childhood cancer.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: High-risk neuroblastomas are rapidly progressive; even with intensive myeloablative chemotherapy, relapse is common and almost uniformly fatal.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Here we report the detection of previously unknown mutations in the ALK gene, which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase, in 8% of primary neuroblastomas.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Five non-synonymous sequence variations were identified in the kinase domain of ALK, of which three were somatic and two were germ line.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: The most frequent mutation, F1174L, was also identified in three different neuroblastoma cell lines.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: ALK complementary DNAs encoding the F1174L and R1275Q variants, but not the wild-type ALK cDNA, transformed interleukin-3-dependent murine haematopoietic Ba/F3 cells to cytokine-independent growth.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Ba/F3 cells expressing these mutations were sensitive to the small-molecule inhibitor of ALK, TAE684 (ref  4).
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Furthermore, two human neuroblastoma cell lines harbouring the F1174L mutation were also sensitive to the inhibitor.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Cytotoxicity was associated with increased amounts of apoptosis as measured by TdT-mediated dUTP nick end labelling (TUNEL).
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Short hairpin RNA (shRNA)-mediated knockdown of ALK expression in neuroblastoma cell lines with the F1174L mutation also resulted in apoptosis and impaired cell proliferation.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: Thus, activating alleles of the ALK receptor tyrosine kinase are present in primary neuroblastoma tumours and in established neuroblastoma cell lines, and confer sensitivity to ALK inhibition with small molecules, providing a molecular rationale for targeted therapy of this disease.
title: Activating mutations in ALK provide a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma.

text: The CEBPA gene is mutated in 9% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: Selective expression of a short (30-kDa) CCAAT-enhancer binding protein-alpha (C/EBPalpha) translational isoform, termed p30, represents the most common type of CEBPA mutation in AML.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: The molecular mechanisms underlying p30-mediated transformation remain incompletely understood.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: We show that C/EBPalpha p30, but not the normal p42 isoform, preferentially interacts with Wdr5, a key component of SET/MLL (SET-domain/mixed-lineage leukemia) histone-methyltransferase complexes.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: Accordingly, p30-bound genomic regions were enriched for MLL-dependent H3K4me3 marks.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: The p30-dependent increase in self-renewal and inhibition of myeloid differentiation required Wdr5, as downregulation of the latter inhibited proliferation and restored differentiation in p30-dependent AML models.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: OICR-9429 is a new small-molecule antagonist of the Wdr5-MLL interaction.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: This compound selectively inhibited proliferation and induced differentiation in p30-expressing human AML cells.
title: Pharmacological targeting of the Wdr5-MLL interaction in C/EBPalpha N-terminal leukemia.

text: Our data reveal the mechanism of p30-dependent transformation and establish the essential p30 cofactor Wdr5 as a therapeutic target in CEBPA-mutant AML.

text: PURPOSE: Phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase I (PI3K) inhibition sensitizes a wide range of cancer cell lines to platinum/taxane-based chemotherapy.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: This phase I study combines buparlisib, a pan-class 1A PI3K inhibitor, with two schedules of carboplatin and paclitaxel for patients with advanced solid tumors (ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01297452).
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: METHODS: There were two regimens: Group 1 received carboplatin AUC 5 and paclitaxel 175 mg/m(2), on day 1 of a 21-day cycle with pegfilgrastim support; Group 2 received carboplatin AUC 5 (day 1) and paclitaxel 80 mg/m(2) (days 1, 8, and 15) on a 28-day cycle without growth factor support.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: In both groups, three dose levels of buparlisib were explored: 50, 80, and 100 mg/day.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Primary endpoint was to identify recommended phase II doses of buparlisib in both groups.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: RESULTS: Thirty subjects enrolled, 16 in Group 1 and 14 in Group 2.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: The DLTs were elevated alkaline phosphatase (n = 1) and uncomplicated neutropenia (n = 2).
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: The median numbers of cycles were 5 (Group 1) and 6 (Group 2).
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: The MTDs for buparlisib were 100 mg/day in Group 1 and 80 mg/day in Group 2.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Among 25 patients with measurable disease, the confirmed objective response rate was 20% (one complete response, four partial responses).
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: Among three patients with known loss of PTEN expression, all derived clinical benefit from treatment.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: CONCLUSION: The addition of buparlisib to carboplatin + paclitaxel was well tolerated, and preliminary activity was notable against tumors with loss of PTEN expression.
title: Parallel phase Ib studies of two schedules of buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel (q21 days or q28 days) for patients with advanced solid tumors.

text: In myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), deletions of chromosome 7 or 7q are common and correlate with a poor prognosis.
title: Somatic mutations of the histone methyltransferase gene EZH2 in myelodysplastic syndromes.

title: Somatic mutations of the histone methyltransferase gene EZH2 in myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: We report here that EZH2, located at 7q36.1, is frequently targeted in MDS.
title: Somatic mutations of the histone methyltransferase gene EZH2 in myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: Analysis of EZH2 deletions, missense and frameshift mutations strongly suggests that EZH2 is a tumor suppressor.

text: The Sonic Hedgehog (Shh) pathway drives a subset of medulloblastomas, a malignant neuroectodermal brain cancer, and other cancers.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: Small-molecule Shh pathway inhibitors have induced tumor regression in mice and patients with medulloblastoma; however, drug resistance rapidly emerges, in some cases via de novo mutation of the drug target.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: Here we assess the response and resistance mechanisms to the natural product derivative saridegib in an aggressive Shh-driven mouse medulloblastoma model.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: In this model, saridegib treatment induced tumor reduction and significantly prolonged survival.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: Furthermore, the effect of saridegib on tumor-initiating capacity was demonstrated by reduced tumor incidence, slower growth, and spontaneous tumor regression that occurred in allografts generated from previously treated autochthonous medulloblastomas compared with those from untreated donors.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: Saridegib, a known P-glycoprotein (Pgp) substrate, induced Pgp activity in treated tumors, which likely contributed to emergence of drug resistance.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: Unlike other Smoothened (Smo) inhibitors, the drug resistance was neither mutation-dependent nor Gli2 amplification-dependent, and saridegib was found to be active in cells with the D473H point mutation that rendered them resistant to another Smo inhibitor, GDC-0449.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: The fivefold increase in lifespan in mice treated with saridegib as a single agent compares favorably with both targeted and cytotoxic therapies.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: The absence of genetic mutations that confer resistance distinguishes saridegib from other Smo inhibitors.
title: Hedgehog pathway inhibitor saridegib (IPI-926) increases lifespan in a mouse medulloblastoma model.

text: PURPOSE: JNJ-42756493 is an orally administered pan-fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: This first-in-human study evaluates the safety, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics and defines the recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of JNJ-42756493.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eligible patients with advanced solid tumors received escalating doses of JNJ-42756493 from 0.5 to 12 mg administered continuously daily or JNJ-42756493 10 or 12 mg administered intermittently (7 days on/7 days off).
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: RESULTS: Sixty-five patients were enrolled.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: The most common treatment-emergent adverse events included hyperphosphatemia (65%), asthenia (55%), dry mouth (45%), nail toxicity (35%), constipation (34%), decreased appetite (32%), and dysgeusia (31%).
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Twenty-seven patients (42%) experienced grade >/= 3 treatment-emergent adverse events, and one dose-limiting toxicity of grade 3 ALT elevation was observed at 12 mg daily.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Maximum-tolerated dose was not defined.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Nine milligrams daily was considered as the initial RP2D; however, tolerability was improved with intermittent schedules, and 10 mg administered on a 7-days-on/7-days-off schedule was considered the final RP2D.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Pharmacokinetics were linear, dose proportional, and predictable, with a half-life of 50 to 60 hours.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Dose-dependent elevations in serum phosphate, a manifestation of pharmacodynamic effect, occurred in all patients starting at 4 mg daily.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Among 23 response-evaluable patients with tumor FGFR pathway alterations, four confirmed responses and one unconfirmed partial response were observed in patients with glioblastoma and urothelial and endometrial cancer (all with FGFR2 or FGFR3 translocations); 16 patients had stable disease.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: CONCLUSION: JNJ-42756493 administered at 10 mg on a 7-days-on/7-days-off schedule achieved exposures at which clinical responses were observed, demonstrated pharmacodynamic biomarker activity, and had a manageable safety profile.
title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of JNJ-42756493, an Oral Pan-Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Inhibitor, in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene mutations (G719X, exon 19 deletions/insertions, L858R, and L861Q) predict favorable responses to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) in advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: However, EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations (~10% of all EGFR mutations) are generally associated with insensitivity to available TKIs (gefitinib, erlotinib, and afatinib).
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: The basis of this primary resistance is poorly understood.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: We studied a broad subset of exon 20 insertion mutations, comparing in vitro TKI sensitivity with responses to gefitinib and erlotinib in NSCLC patients, and found that most are resistant to EGFR TKIs.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: The crystal structure of a representative TKI-insensitive mutant (D770_N771insNPG) reveals an unaltered adenosine triphosphate-binding pocket, and the inserted residues form a wedge at the end of the C helix that promotes the active kinase conformation.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: Unlike EGFR-L858R, D770_N771insNPG activates EGFR without increasing its affinity for EGFR TKIs.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: Unexpectedly, we find that EGFR-A763_Y764insFQEA is highly sensitive to EGFR TKIs in vitro, and patients whose NSCLCs harbor this mutation respond to erlotinib.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: Analysis of the A763_Y764insFQEA mutant indicates that the inserted residues shift the register of the C helix in the N-terminal direction, altering the structure in the region that is also affected by the TKI-sensitive EGFR-L858R.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: Our studies reveal intricate differences between EGFR mutations, their biology, and their response to EGFR TKIs.
title: Structural, biochemical, and clinical characterization of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) exon 20 insertion mutations in lung cancer.

text: The fluoropyrimidines are the mainstay chemotherapeutic agents for the treatment of many types of cancers.
title: Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium guidelines for dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase genotype and fluoropyrimidine dosing.

text: Detoxifying metabolism of fluoropyrimidines requires dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD, encoded by the DPYD gene), and reduced or absent activity of this enzyme can result in severe, and sometimes fatal, toxicity.
title: Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium guidelines for dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase genotype and fluoropyrimidine dosing.

text: We summarize evidence from the published literature supporting this association and provide dosing recommendations for fluoropyrimidines based on DPYD genotype (updates at http://www.pharmgkb.org).
title: Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium guidelines for dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase genotype and fluoropyrimidine dosing.

text: BACKGROUND: We designed a single-arm, open-label phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy (#NCT02449538).
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: METHODS: Everolimus was administered orally at a daily dose of 10 mg continuously (28-day cycles).
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Treatment was continued until progression of the disease or intolerable toxicity was observed.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Based on Simon's two-stage optimal design, 10 patients were treated with everolimus during the first stage.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: RESULTS: The median age of the patients was 55.5 years (range, 42-72), and the median Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status (PS) was 2 (range, 1-2).
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Most of the patients (50.0%) had gastric cancer (GC) as the site of their primary tumor followed by colorectal cancer (CRC), pancreatic cancer, and cholangiocarcinoma.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Patients received everolimus as a third-line (3 patients), fourth-line (4 patients), fifth-line (1 patient) or sixth-line (2 patients) treatment.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Complete or partial responses were not observed in any of the patients.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Four patients showed stable disease, resulting in a disease control rate of 40%.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: The median PFS was 1.6 months (95% CI, 0.8-2.4 months).
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Grade 3 or greater hematologic/non-hematologic toxicity was not observed.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Grade 2 diarrhea and stomatitis were reported in one patient each.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: There were no treatment-related deaths.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: There was less than one response out of the 10 initial patients during the first stage, and the study did not progress to the second stage.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The study did not meet its primary objective of demonstrating the anti-tumor activity of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Further investigation using other genomic candidates and new-generation mTOR inhibitors is warranted in patients with treatment-refractory cancer.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: TRIAL REGISTRATION: # NCT02449538 , April 2015.
title: Prospective phase II trial of everolimus in PIK3CA amplification/mutation and/or PTEN loss patients with advanced solid tumors refractory to standard therapy.

text: Imatinib mesylate, as treatment for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST), has dramatically changed the prognosis for survival - not only because it is efficacious, but also because it attracted attention to this malignant disease.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: GIST is now a well-known disease entity and a paradigm for targeted therapies in malignant diseases.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: A now 74-year-old patient presented with recurrence of a primary duodenal GIST (initial diagnosis and primary resection in 1998; diameter 10 cm, KIT exon 11 mutation, PM V559D) and liver metastasis after a second surgical resection was performed in 2000.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Conventional chemotherapy with adriamycin and ifosfamide failed to control growth of the relapsed tumor and liver metastasis.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: In July 2001, compassionate use of imatinib was started.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Tumor regression was observed at continuous follow-ups (every 2 months for the first 6 months, and 6 months thereafter) and persisted until now.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: The patient's physical performance has remained in good condition.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Side effects consisted of periorbital edema and sudden muscle cramps of toes and fingers, pain of bones and joints, an intentional tremor, a paler color of the skin, as well as a slight anemia.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Imatinib is the first orally administered anticancer drug.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Our case shows that a sustained response is possible with continuous therapy over a long time, if the drug is well tolerated.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: This implies a high compliance of the patient and suggests that resistance to imatinib does not have to develop.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Exon 11 (point) mutation might not only represent a positive predictor for imatinib response in general, but especially for imatinib response on long-term.
title: Ten Years of Treatment with 400 mg Imatinib per Day in a Case of Advanced Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor.

text: Alterations in DNA methylation have been implicated in the pathogenesis of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), although the underlying mechanism remains largely unknown.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: Methylation of CpG dinucleotides is mediated by DNA methyltransferases, including DNMT1, DNMT3A and DNMT3B.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: DNMT3A mutations have recently been reported in patients with de novo acute myeloid leukemia (AML), providing a rationale for examining the status of DNMT3A in MDS samples.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: In this study, we report the frequency of DNMT3A mutations in patients with de novo MDS, and their association with secondary AML.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: We sequenced all coding exons of DNMT3A using DNA from bone marrow and paired normal cells from 150 patients with MDS and identified 13 heterozygous mutations with predicted translational consequences in 12/150 patients (8.0%).
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: Amino acid R882, located in the methyltransferase domain of DNMT3A, was the most common mutation site, accounting for 4/13 mutations.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: DNMT3A mutations were expressed in the majority of cells in all tested mutant samples regardless of myeloblast counts, suggesting that DNMT3A mutations occur early in the course of MDS.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: Patients with DNMT3A mutations had worse overall survival compared with patients without DNMT3A mutations (P=0.005) and more rapid progression to AML (P=0.007), suggesting that DNMT3A mutation status may have prognostic value in de novo MDS.
title: Recurrent DNMT3A mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.

text: Therapies inhibiting receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are effective against some human cancers when they lead to simultaneous downregulation of PI3K/AKT and MEK/ERK signaling.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: However, mutant KRAS has the capacity to directly activate ERK and PI3K signaling, and this is thought to underlie the resistance of KRAS mutant cancers to RTK inhibitors.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: Here, we have elucidated the molecular regulation of both the PI3K/AKT and MEK/ERK signaling pathways in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer cells and identified combination therapies that lead to robust cancer cell apoptosis.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: KRAS knockdown using shRNA suppressed ERK signaling in all of the human KRAS mutant colorectal cancer cell lines examined.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: However, no decrease, and actually a modest increase, in AKT phosphorylation was often seen.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: By performing PI3K immunoprecipitations, we determined that RTKs, often IGF-IR, regulated PI3K signaling in the KRAS mutant cell lines.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: This conclusion was also supported by the observation that specific RTK inhibition led to marked suppression of PI3K signaling and biochemical assessment of patient specimens.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: Interestingly, combination of RTK and MEK inhibitors led to concomitant inhibition of PI3K and MEK signaling, marked growth suppression, and robust apoptosis of human KRAS mutant colorectal cancer cell lines in vitro and upon xenografting in mice.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: These findings provide a framework for utilizing RTK inhibitors in the treatment of KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.
title: Receptor tyrosine kinases exert dominant control over PI3K signaling in human KRAS mutant colorectal cancers.

text: INTRODUCTION: Elevated DNA-repair capacity has been related to chemoresistance of platinum doublet chemotherapy in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: We evaluated whether single nucleotide polymorphisms of DN- repair genes excision repair cross-complementing group 1 (ERCC1), ERCC2, x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 (XRCC1), XRCC3, and RRM1 associate with treatment outcome in NSCLC patients receiving gemcitabine plus platinum as their first-line chemotherapy.
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: METHODS: Genotyping for eight polymorphisms in five DNA-repair genes was performed with the GenomeLab nucleotide polymorphismstream Genotyping System in 62 advanced NSCLC patients in a training set and 45 patients in a validation set treated with gemcitabine/platinum.
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: RESULTS: In the training set, the wild-type genotype of XRCC1 Arg399Gln (G/G) was associated with decreased median overall survival (OS) (22 months, 95% confidence interval [CI], 10-34 months versus not reached, log-rank test, p = 0.005) than those carrying variant genotypes (G/A+A/A).
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: In addition, there was a statistically significant longer median OS in patients carrying wild-type ERCC2 Asp312Asn genotype (G/G) (51 months, 95% CI, 19-82 months versus 10 months, log-rank test, p < 0.001) than those carrying heterozygous variant genotypes (G/A).
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: In the multivariate Cox model, we found a significant effect of XRCC1 Arg399Gln (G/A+A/A versus G/G, hazard ratio [HR] 0.290; 95%CI, 0.12-0.705, p = 0.006) and ERCC2 Asp312Asn (G/A versus G/G, HR 14.04; 95% CI, 2.253-87.513, p = 0.005) polymorphisms on patients' OS.
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: In the validation set, only XRCC1 399 CONCLUSIONS: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln may be a candidate for contributing interindividual difference in the OS of gemcitabine/platinum-treated advanced NSCLC patients.
title: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 Arg399Gln is associated with survival in non-small-cell lung cancer patients treated with gemcitabine/platinum.

text: Activating gene rearrangements of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) have been identified as driver mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer, inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors, and other cancers.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: Crizotinib, a dual MET/ALK inhibitor, has demonstrated promising clinical activity in patients with non-small-cell lung cancer and inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors harboring ALK translocations.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: Inhibitors of driver kinases often elicit kinase domain mutations that confer resistance, and such mutations have been successfully predicted using in vitro mutagenesis screens.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: Here, this approach was used to discover an extensive set of ALK mutations that can confer resistance to crizotinib.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: Mutations at 16 residues were identified, structurally clustered into five regions around the kinase active site, which conferred varying degrees of resistance.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: The screen successfully predicted the L1196M, C1156Y, and F1174L mutations, recently identified in crizotinib-resistant patients.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: In separate studies, we demonstrated that crizotinib has relatively modest potency in ALK-positive non-small-cell lung cancer cell lines.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: A more potent ALK inhibitor, TAE684, maintained substantial activity against mutations that conferred resistance to crizotinib.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: Our study identifies multiple novel mutations in ALK that may confer clinical resistance to crizotinib, suggests that crizotinib's narrow selectivity window may underlie its susceptibility to such resistance and demonstrates that a more potent ALK inhibitor may be effective at overcoming resistance.
title: Crizotinib-resistant mutants of EML4-ALK identified through an accelerated mutagenesis screen.

text: von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) is an inherited neoplastic disease characterized by a predisposition to develop retinal angiomas, central nervous system hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinomas, pancreatic cysts, and pheochromocytomas.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: The VHL gene was recently isolated by positional cloning.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: The cDNA encodes 852 nucleotides in 3 exons.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: The VHL gene is unrelated to any known gene families.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: We identified germline mutations in 85/114 (75%) of VHL families.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: Clinical heterogeneity is a well-known feature of VHL.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: VHL families were classified into 2 types based on the presence or absence of pheochromocytoma.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: The types of mutations responsible for VHL without pheochromocytoma (VHL type 1) differed from those responsible for VHL with pheochromocytoma (VHL type 2).
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: Fifty-six % of the mutations responsible for VHL type 1 were microdeletions/insertions, nonsense mutations, or deletions; 96% of the mutations responsible for VHL type 2 were missense mutations.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: Specific mutations in codon 238 accounted for 43% of the mutations responsible for VHL type 2.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: The mutations identified in these families will be useful in presymptomatic diagnosis.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: The identification of mutations associated with phenotypes contributes to the understanding of fundamental genetic mechanisms of VHL disease.
title: Germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene: correlations with phenotype.

text: PURPOSE: This randomized, multicenter trial compared first-line trastuzumab plus docetaxel versus docetaxel alone in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) -positive metastatic breast cancer (MBC).
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients were randomly assigned to six cycles of docetaxel 100 mg/m2 every 3 weeks, with or without trastuzumab 4 mg/kg loading dose followed by 2 mg/kg weekly until disease progression.
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: RESULTS: A total of 186 patients received at least one dose of the study drug.
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel was significantly superior to docetaxel alone in terms of overall response rate (61% v 34%; P = .0002), overall survival (median, 31.2 v 22.7 months; P = .0325), time to disease progression (median, 11.7 v 6.1 months; P = .0001), time to treatment failure (median, 9.8 v 5.3 months; P = .0001), and duration of response (median, 11.7 v 5.7 months; P = .009).
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: There was little difference in the number and severity of adverse events between the arms.
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: Grade 3 to 4 neutropenia was seen more commonly with the combination (32%) than with docetaxel alone (22%), and there was a slightly higher incidence of febrile neutropenia in the combination arm (23% v 17%).
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: One patient in the combination arm experienced symptomatic heart failure (1%).
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: Another patient experienced symptomatic heart failure 5 months after discontinuation of trastuzumab because of disease progression, while being treated with an investigational anthracycline for 4 months.
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: CONCLUSION: Trastuzumab combined with docetaxel is superior to docetaxel alone as first-line treatment of patients with HER2-positive MBC in terms of overall survival, response rate, response duration, time to progression, and time to treatment failure, with little additional toxicity.
title: Randomized phase II trial of the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab combined with docetaxel in patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive metastatic breast cancer administered as first-line treatment: the M77001 study group.

text: The significance of KRAS in advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) treated with bevacizumab (B) is not well understood.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: We conducted a systematic review and pooled analysis of published trials with the aim to assess the predictive and prognostic role of KRAS status in patients treated with B.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: We performed a systematic search of PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science, and Cochrane Register of Controlled Trials.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: The primary endpoints included objective response rate (RR), progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS).
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: The odds ratio (OR) for RR and hazard ratios (HRs) were calculated or extracted by published data either using a fixed effect model or a random effect model.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: A total of 12 studies were included.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: A total of 2,266 patients were analysed (54 % were KRAS wt).
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: The pooled RRs for KRAS wild-type (wt) versus mutated (mut) patients were 54.8 and 48.3 %, respectively (OR 1.42, P = 0.02).
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: Median PFS was significantly longer in KRAS wt patients compared with that in KRAS mut patients (HR = 0.85; 95 % confidence interval (CI) 0.74-0.98; P = 0.02).
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: Similarly, median OS was significantly better in wt KRAS patients compared with that in mut KRAS patients (HR = 0.65; 95 % CI 0.46-0.92; P = 0.01).
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: This pooled analysis of 12 published studies shows that KRAS wt status is a good prognostic factor for B-based chemotherapy.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: Also, KRAS wt CRC is associated with a better RR with B plus chemotherapy than mut counterpart.
title: KRAS as prognostic biomarker in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with bevacizumab: a pooled analysis of 12 published trials.

text: The ALK kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) is clinically effective in patients with ALK-translocated cancers, but its efficacy will ultimately be limited by acquired drug resistance.
title: The neuroblastoma-associated F1174L ALK mutation causes resistance to an ALK kinase inhibitor in ALK-translocated cancers.

text: Here we report the identification of a secondary mutation in ALK, F1174L, as one cause of crizotinib resistance in a patient with an inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT) harboring a RANBP2-ALK translocation who progressed while on crizotinib therapy.
title: The neuroblastoma-associated F1174L ALK mutation causes resistance to an ALK kinase inhibitor in ALK-translocated cancers.

text: When present in cis with an ALK translocation, this mutation (also detected in neuroblastomas) causes an increase in ALK phosphorylation, cell growth, and downstream signaling.
title: The neuroblastoma-associated F1174L ALK mutation causes resistance to an ALK kinase inhibitor in ALK-translocated cancers.

text: Furthermore, the F1174L mutation inhibits crizotinib-mediated downregulation of ALK signaling and blocks apoptosis in RANBP2-ALK Ba/F3 cells.
title: The neuroblastoma-associated F1174L ALK mutation causes resistance to an ALK kinase inhibitor in ALK-translocated cancers.

text: A chemically distinct ALK inhibitor, TAE684, and the HSP90 inhibitor 17-AAG are both effective in models harboring the F1174L ALK mutation.
title: The neuroblastoma-associated F1174L ALK mutation causes resistance to an ALK kinase inhibitor in ALK-translocated cancers.

text: Our findings highlight the importance of studying drug resistance mechanisms in order to develop effective clinical treatments for patients with ALK-translocated cancers.
title: The neuroblastoma-associated F1174L ALK mutation causes resistance to an ALK kinase inhibitor in ALK-translocated cancers.

text: The somatic mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase genes (IDH1 and IDH2) have been identified in a proportion of hematologic malignancies.
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: We examined IDH1 R132 and IDH2 R140/R172 mutations by high resolution melting analysis and direct sequencing in Chinese patients with different myeloid malignancies including 198 acute myeloid leukemia (AML), 82 myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), 85 chronic myeloid leukemia, and 57 myeloproliferative neoplasms.
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: IDH1 and IDH2 mutations were found in four (2.0%) and ten (5.0%) AML and in two (2.4%) and three (3.6%) MDS cases, but not in other patients.
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: IDH1 and IDH2 mutations were heterozygous and mutually exclusive.
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: IDH1/2 mutations were significantly more frequently observed in cytogenetically normal AML or MDS compared to those without mutations.
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: There was no difference in overall survival of both AML and MDS patients with or without IDH1/2 mutations (P = 0.177 and 0.407, respectively).
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: In conclusion, IDH1/2 mutations are recurrent but rare molecular aberrations in Chinese AML and MDS.
title: IDH1 and IDH2 mutation analysis in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: Background The identification of high-risk stage II colon cancers is key to the selection of patients who require adjuvant treatment after surgery.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: Microarray-based multigene-expression signatures derived from stem cells and progenitor cells hold promise, but they are difficult to use in clinical practice.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: Methods We used a new bioinformatics approach to search for biomarkers of colon epithelial differentiation across gene-expression arrays and then ranked candidate genes according to the availability of clinical-grade diagnostic assays.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: With the use of subgroup analysis involving independent and retrospective cohorts of patients with stage II or stage III colon cancer, the top candidate gene was tested for its association with disease-free survival and a benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: Results The transcription factor CDX2 ranked first in our screening test.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: A group of 87 of 2115 tumor samples (4.1%) lacked CDX2 expression.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: In the discovery data set, which included 466 patients, the rate of 5-year disease-free survival was lower among the 32 patients (6.9%) with CDX2-negative colon cancers than among the 434 (93.1%) with CDX2-positive colon cancers (hazard ratio for disease recurrence, 3.44; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.60 to 7.38; P=0.002).
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: In the validation data set, which included 314 patients, the rate of 5-year disease-free survival was lower among the 38 patients (12.1%) with CDX2 protein-negative colon cancers than among the 276 (87.9%) with CDX2 protein-positive colon cancers (hazard ratio, 2.42; 95% CI, 1.36 to 4.29; P=0.003).
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.
