text: In both these groups, these findings were independent of the patient's age, sex, and tumor stage and grade.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: Among patients with stage II cancer, the difference in 5-year disease-free survival was significant both in the discovery data set (49% among 15 patients with CDX2-negative tumors vs. 87% among 191 patients with CDX2-positive tumors, P=0.003) and in the validation data set (51% among 15 patients with CDX2-negative tumors vs. 80% among 106 patients with CDX2-positive tumors, P=0.004).
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: In a pooled database of all patient cohorts, the rate of 5-year disease-free survival was higher among 23 patients with stage II CDX2-negative tumors who were treated with adjuvant chemotherapy than among 25 who were not treated with adjuvant chemotherapy (91% vs. 56%, P=0.006).
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: Conclusions Lack of CDX2 expression identified a subgroup of patients with high-risk stage II colon cancer who appeared to benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: (Funded by the National Comprehensive Cancer Network, the National Institutes of Health, and others.
title: CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.
CDX2 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Stage II and Stage III Colon Cancer.

text: CONTEXT AND OBJECTIVE: Oncocytic thyroid carcinoma, also known as Hurthle cell thyroid carcinoma, accounts for only a small percentage of all thyroid cancers.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: However, this malignancy often presents at an advanced stage and poses unique challenges to patients and clinicians.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Surgical resection of the tumor accompanied in some cases by radioactive iodine treatment, radiation, and chemotherapy are the established modes of therapy.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Knowledge of the perturbed oncogenic pathways can provide better understanding of the mechanism of disease and thus opportunities for more effective clinical management.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: DESIGN AND PATIENTS: Initially, two oncocytic thyroid carcinomas and their matched normal tissues were profiled using whole genome sequencing.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Subsequently, 72 oncocytic thyroid carcinomas, one cell line, and five Hurthle cell adenomas were examined by targeted sequencing for the presence of mutations in the multiple endocrine neoplasia I (MEN1) gene.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Here we report the identification of MEN1 loss-of-function mutations in 4% of patients diagnosed with oncocytic thyroid carcinoma.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Whole genome sequence data also revealed large regions of copy number variation encompassing nearly the entire genomes of these tumors.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: Menin, a ubiquitously expressed nuclear protein, is a well-characterized tumor suppressor whose loss is the cause of MEN1 syndrome.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Menin is involved in several major cellular pathways such as regulation of transcription, control of cell cycle, apoptosis, and DNA damage repair pathways.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Mutations of this gene in a subset of Hurthle cell tumors point to a potential role for this protein and its associated pathways in thyroid tumorigenesis.
title: MEN1 mutations in Hurthle cell (oncocytic) thyroid carcinoma.

text: Enhancer of zeste homologue 2 (EZH2) is a potential independent mechanism for epigenetic silencing of tumor suppressor genes in cancer.
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: We conducted an electronic search on PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science, and Cochrane library to perform this up-to-date meta-analysis.
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: Fifty-one studies with a total of 9444 patients were included.
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: The prevalence of high EZH2 expression was 0.54 (95% CI: 0.47-0.61).
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: High EZH2 expression was significantly associated with poorer prognosis [overall survival: HR 1.54 (95% CI: 1.30-1.78), P < 0.000; disease free survival: HR 1.35 (95% CI: 1.00-1.71), P < 0.000].
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: In breast cancer, high EZH2 expression correlated with histological types [OR: 1.53 (95CI: 1.13-2.06); P < 0.006], histological grade [OR: 1.62 (95CI: 1.35-1.95); P < 0.000], estrogen receptor (ER) negativity [OR: 2.05 (95CI: 1.67-2.52); P < 0.000], progesterone receptor (PgR) negativity [OR: 1.42 (95CI: 1.03-1.96); P = 0.034], HER-2 positivity [OR: 1.35 (95CI: 1.08-1.69); P = 0.009], and high p53 expression [OR: 1.66 (95CI: 1.07-2.59); P = 0.024].
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: These results suggest that high EZH2 expression may be a promising prognostic factor to different cancers.
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: High EZH2 expression tends to correlate with pathological types, histological grade, ER negativity, PgR negativity, HER-2 positivity and p53 high expression in breast cancer.
title: Prognostic value of high EZH2 expression in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review with meta-analysis.

text: 2-Hydroxyglutarate (2HG) exists as two enantiomers, (R)-2HG and (S)-2HG, and both are implicated in tumor progression via their inhibitory effects on alpha-ketoglutarate (alphaKG)-dependent dioxygenases.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: The former is an oncometabolite that is induced by the neomorphic activity conferred by isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1) and IDH2 mutations, whereas the latter is produced under pathologic processes such as hypoxia.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: We report that IDH1/2 mutations induce a homologous recombination (HR) defect that renders tumor cells exquisitely sensitive to poly(adenosine 5'-diphosphate-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitors.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: This "BRCAness" phenotype of IDH mutant cells can be completely reversed by treatment with small-molecule inhibitors of the mutant IDH1 enzyme, and conversely, it can be entirely recapitulated by treatment with either of the 2HG enantiomers in cells with intact IDH1/2 proteins.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: We demonstrate mutant IDH1-dependent PARP inhibitor sensitivity in a range of clinically relevant models, including primary patient-derived glioma cells in culture and genetically matched tumor xenografts in vivo.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: These findings provide the basis for a possible therapeutic strategy exploiting the biological consequences of mutant IDH, rather than attempting to block 2HG production, by targeting the 2HG-dependent HR deficiency with PARP inhibition.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: Furthermore, our results uncover an unexpected link between oncometabolites, altered DNA repair, and genetic instability.
title: 2-Hydroxyglutarate produced by neomorphic IDH mutations suppresses homologous recombination and induces PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

text: Activating mutations in the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene were recently discovered in neuroblastoma, a cancer of the developing autonomic nervous system that is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in the first year of life.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: The most frequent ALK mutations in neuroblastoma cause amino acid substitutions (F1174L and R1275Q) in the intracellular tyrosine kinase domain of the intact ALK receptor.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: Identification of ALK as an oncogenic driver in neuroblastoma suggests that crizotinib (PF-02341066), a dual-specific inhibitor of the ALK and Met tyrosine kinases, will be useful in treating this malignancy.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: Here, we assessed the ability of crizotinib to inhibit proliferation of neuroblastoma cell lines and xenografts expressing mutated or wild-type ALK.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: Crizotinib inhibited proliferation of cell lines expressing either R1275Q-mutated ALK or amplified wild-type ALK.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: In contrast, cell lines harboring F1174L-mutated ALK were relatively resistant to crizotinib.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: Biochemical analyses revealed that this reduced susceptibility of F1174L-mutated ALK to crizotinib inhibition resulted from an increased adenosine triphosphate-binding affinity (as also seen in acquired resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitors).
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: Thus, this effect should be surmountable with higher doses of crizotinib and/or with higher-affinity inhibitors.
title: Differential inhibitor sensitivity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase variants found in neuroblastoma.

text: CONTEXT: For patients with metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) refractory to radioactive iodine (RAI) treatment, systemic chemotherapy has limited efficacy.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: Such tumors frequently harbor BRAF V600E, and this alteration may predict responsiveness to vemurafenib treatment.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: OBJECTIVE: We report a metastatic PTC patient refractory to RAI treatment that underwent genomic profiling by next-generation sequencing.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: The sole genomic alteration identified was BRAF V600E on a near diploid genome with trisomy 1q.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: With vemurafenib treatment, the patient experienced a dramatic radiographic and clinical improvement, with the duration of an ongoing antitumor response exceeding 23 months.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: DESIGN: Hybridization capture of 3,769 exons of 236 cancer-related genes and the introns of 19 genes frequently rearranged in cancer was applied to >50 ng of DNA extracted from a formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded biopsy of a lymph node containing metastatic PTC and was sequenced to a high, uniform coverage of x616.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: RESULTS: A BRAF V600E alteration was identified with no other somatic genomic alterations present within a near diploid tumor genome.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: The patient initially received vemurafenib at 960 mg twice daily that was reduced to 480 mg twice daily due to rash and diarrhea and has experienced an ongoing antitumor response exceeding 23 months by both PET-CT and dedicated CT imaging.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Genomic profiling in metastatic, RAI-refractory PTC can reveal a targetable BRAF V600E alteration without compounding somatic alterations, and such patients may derive a more prolonged benefit from vemurafenib treatment.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: Prospective clinical trials are ongoing to confirm our preliminary observation.
title: Extended Antitumor Response of a BRAF V600E Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma to Vemurafenib.

text: PURPOSE In the phase III INTEREST trial, 1,466 pretreated patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) were randomly assigned to receive gefitinib or docetaxel.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: As a preplanned analysis, we prospectively analyzed available tumor biopsies to investigate the relationship between biomarkers and clinical outcomes.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: METHODS Biomarkers included epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) copy number by fluorescent in situ hybridization (374 assessable samples), EGFR protein expression by immunohistochemistry (n = 380), and EGFR (n = 297) and KRAS (n = 275) mutations.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: Results For all biomarker subgroups analyzed, survival was similar for gefitinib and docetaxel, with no statistically significant differences between treatments and no significant treatment by biomarker status interaction tests.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: EGFR mutation-positive patients had longer progression-free survival (PFS; hazard ratio [HR], 0.16; 95% CI, 0.05 to 0.49; P = .001) and higher objective response rate (ORR; 42.1% v 21.1%; P = .04), and patients with high EGFR copy number had higher ORR (13.0% v 7.4%; P = .04) with gefitinib versus docetaxel.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: CONCLUSION These biomarkers do not appear to be predictive factors for differential survival between gefitinib and docetaxel in this setting of previously treated patients; however, subsequent treatments may have influenced the survival results.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: For secondary end points of PFS and ORR, some advantages for gefitinib over docetaxel were seen in EGFR mutation-positive and high EGFR copy number patients.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: There was no statistically significant difference between gefitinib and docetaxel in biomarker-negative patients.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: This suggests gefitinib can provide similar overall survival to docetaxel in patients across a broad range of clinical subgroups and that EGFR biomarkers such as mutation status may additionally identify which patients are likely to gain greatest PFS and ORR benefit from gefitinib.
title: Molecular predictors of outcome with gefitinib and docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer: data from the randomized phase III INTEREST trial.

text: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a tyrosine kinase that is constitutively activated in certain cancers, following gene alterations such as chromosomal translocation, amplification, or point mutation.
title: CH5424802, a selective ALK inhibitor capable of blocking the resistant gatekeeper mutant.

text: Here, we identified CH5424802, a potent, selective, and orally available ALK inhibitor with a unique chemical scaffold, showing preferential antitumor activity against cancers with gene alterations of ALK, such as nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells expressing EML4-ALK fusion and anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (ALCL) cells expressing NPM-ALK fusion in vitro and in vivo.
title: CH5424802, a selective ALK inhibitor capable of blocking the resistant gatekeeper mutant.

text: CH5424802 inhibited ALK L1196M, which corresponds to the gatekeeper mutation conferring common resistance to kinase inhibitors, and blocked EML4-ALK L1196M-driven cell growth.
title: CH5424802, a selective ALK inhibitor capable of blocking the resistant gatekeeper mutant.

text: Our results support the potential for clinical evaluation of CH5424802 for the treatment of patients with ALK-driven tumors.
title: CH5424802, a selective ALK inhibitor capable of blocking the resistant gatekeeper mutant.

text: BACKGROUND: No targeted therapies are available for KRAS-mutant non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Selumetinib is an inhibitor of MEK1/MEK2, downstream of KRAS, with preclinical evidence of synergistic activity with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant cancers.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: We did a prospective, randomised, phase 2 trial to assess selumetinib plus docetaxel in previously treated patients with advanced KRAS-mutant NSCLC.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: METHODS: Eligible patients were older than 18 years of age; had histologically or cytologically confirmed stage IIIB-IV KRAS-mutant NSCLC; had failed first-line therapy for advanced NSCLC; had WHO performance status of 0-1; had not received previous therapy with either a MEK inhibitor or docetaxel; and had adequate bone marrow, renal, and liver function.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Patients were randomly assigned (in a 1:1 ratio) to either oral selumetinib (75 mg twice daily in a 21 day cycle) or placebo; all patients received intravenous docetaxel (75 mg/m(2) on day 1 of a 21 day cycle).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Randomisation was done with an interactive voice response system and investigators, patients, data analysts, and the trial sponsor were masked to treatment assignment.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: The primary endpoint was overall survival, analysed for all patients with confirmed KRAS mutations.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00890825.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: FINDINGS: Between April 20, 2009, and June 30, 2010, we randomly assigned 44 patients to receive selumetinib and docetaxel (selumetinib group) and 43 to receive placebo and docetaxel (placebo group).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Of these, one patient in the selumetinib group and three in the placebo group were excluded from efficacy analyses because their tumours were not confirmed to be KRAS-mutation positive.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Median overall survival was 9.4 months (6.8-13.6) in the selumetinib group and 5.2 months (95% CI 3.8-non-calculable) in the placebo group (hazard ratio [HR] for death 0.80, 80% CI 0.56-1.14; one-sided p=0.21).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Median progression-free survival was 5.3 months (4.6-6.4) in the selumetinib group and 2.1 months (95% CI 1.4-3.7) in the placebo group (HR for progression 0.58, 80% CI 0.42-0.79; one-sided p=0.014).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: 16 (37%) patients in the selumetinib group and none in the placebo group had an objective response (p<0.0001).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Adverse events of grade 3 or higher occurred in 36 (82%) patients in the selumetinib group and 28 (67%) patients in the placebo group.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: The most common grade 3-4 adverse events were neutropenia (29 [67%] of 43 patients in the selumetinib group vs 23 [55%] of 42 patients in the placebo group), febrile neutropenia (eight [18%] of 44 patients in the selumetinib group vs none in the placebo group), dyspnoea (one [2%] of 44 patients in the selumetinib group vs five [12%] of 42 in the placebo group), and asthenia (four [9%] of 44 patients in the selumetinib group vs none in the placebo group).
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: INTERPRETATION: Selumetinib plus docetaxel has promising efficacy, albeit with a higher number of adverse events than with docetaxel alone, in previously treated advanced KRAS-mutant NSCLC.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: These findings warrant further clinical investigation of selumetinib plus docetaxel in KRAS-mutant NSCLC.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: FUNDING: AstraZeneca.
title: Selumetinib plus docetaxel for KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: a randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled, phase 2 study.

text: Pediatric midline high-grade astrocytomas (mHGAs) are incurable with few treatment targets identified.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: Most tumors harbor mutations encoding p.Lys27Met in histone H3 variants.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: In 40 treatment-naive mHGAs, 39 analyzed by whole-exome sequencing, we find additional somatic mutations specific to tumor location.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: Gain-of-function mutations in ACVR1 occur in tumors of the pons in conjunction with histone H3.1 p.Lys27Met substitution, whereas FGFR1 mutations or fusions occur in thalamic tumors associated with histone H3.3 p.Lys27Met substitution.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: Hyperactivation of the bone morphogenetic protein (BMP)-ACVR1 developmental pathway in mHGAs harboring ACVR1 mutations led to increased levels of phosphorylated SMAD1, SMAD5 and SMAD8 and upregulation of BMP downstream early-response genes in tumor cells.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: Global DNA methylation profiles were significantly associated with the p.Lys27Met alteration, regardless of the mutant histone H3 variant and irrespective of tumor location, supporting the role of this substitution in driving the epigenetic phenotype.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: This work considerably expands the number of potential treatment targets and further justifies pretreatment biopsy in pediatric mHGA as a means to orient therapeutic efforts in this disease.
title: Recurrent somatic mutations in ACVR1 in pediatric midline high-grade astrocytoma.

text: IMPORTANCE: The PIK3CA mutation is one of the most common mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: Through this research we attempt to elicit the role of oncogene dependence and effects of targeted therapy on this PIK3CA mutation.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: OBJECTIVES: (1) To determine the role of oncogene dependence on PIK3CA-one of the more common and targetable oncogenes in HNSCC, and (2) to evaluate the consequence of this oncogene on the effectiveness of newly developed targeted therapies.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: This was a cell culture-based, in vitro study performed at an academic research laboratory assessing the viability of PIK3CA-mutated head and neck cell lines when treated with targeted therapy.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: EXPOSURES: PIK3CA-mutated head and neck cell lines were treated with 17-AAG, GDC-0941, trametinib, and BEZ-235.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Assessment of cell viability of HNSCC cell lines characterized for PIK3CA mutations or SCC25 cells engineered to express the PIK3CA hotspot mutations E545K or H1047R.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: RESULTS: Surprisingly, in engineered cell lines, the hotspot E545K and H1047R mutations conferred increased, rather than reduced, IC50 assay measurements when treated with the respective HSP90, PI3K, and MEK inhibitors, 17-AAG, GDC-0941, and trametinib, compared with the SCC25 control cell lines.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: When treated with BEZ-235, H1047R-expressing cell lines showed increased sensitivity to inhibition compared with control, whereas those expressing E545K showed slightly increased sensitivity of unclear significance.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: (1) The PIK3CA mutations within our engineered cell model did not lead to enhanced oncogene-dependent cell death when treated with direct inhibition of the PI3K enzyme yet did show increased sensitivity compared with control with dual PI3K/mTOR inhibition.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: (2) Oncogene addiction to PIK3CA hotspot mutations, if it occurs, is likely to evolve in vivo in the context of additional molecular changes that remain to be identified.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: Additional study is required to develop new model systems and approaches to determine the role of targeted therapy in the treatment of PI3K-overactive HNSCC tumors.
title: Response of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cells carrying PIK3CA mutations to selected targeted therapies.

text: BACKGROUND: Osimertinib is an epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor (EGFR-TKI) that is selective for both EGFR-TKI sensitizing and T790M resistance mutations in patients with non-small-cell lung cancer.
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: The efficacy of osimertinib as compared with platinum-based therapy plus pemetrexed in such patients is unknown.
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: METHODS: In this randomized, international, open-label, phase 3 trial, we assigned 419 patients with T790M-positive advanced non-small-cell lung cancer, who had disease progression after first-line EGFR-TKI therapy, in a 2:1 ratio to receive either oral osimertinib (at a dose of 80 mg once daily) or intravenous pemetrexed (500 mg per square meter of body-surface area) plus either carboplatin (target area under the curve, 5 [AUC5]) or cisplatin (75 mg per square meter) every 3 weeks for up to six cycles; maintenance pemetrexed was allowed.
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: In all the patients, disease had progressed during receipt of first-line EGFR-TKI therapy.
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: The primary end point was investigator-assessed progression-free survival.
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: The median duration of progression-free survival was significantly longer with osimertinib than with platinum therapy plus pemetrexed (10.1 months vs. 4.4 months; hazard ratio; 0.30; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.23 to 0.41; P<0.001).
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: The objective response rate was significantly better with osimertinib (71%; 95% CI, 65 to 76) than with platinum therapy plus pemetrexed (31%; 95% CI, 24 to 40) (odds ratio for objective response, 5.39; 95% CI, 3.47 to 8.48; P<0.001).
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: Among 144 patients with metastases to the central nervous system (CNS), the median duration of progression-free survival was longer among patients receiving osimertinib than among those receiving platinum therapy plus pemetrexed (8.5 months vs. 4.2 months; hazard ratio, 0.32; 95% CI, 0.21 to 0.49).
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: The proportion of patients with adverse events of grade 3 or higher was lower with osimertinib (23%) than with platinum therapy plus pemetrexed (47%).
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Osimertinib had significantly greater efficacy than platinum therapy plus pemetrexed in patients with T790M-positive advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (including those with CNS metastases) in whom disease had progressed during first-line EGFR-TKI therapy.
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: (Funded by AstraZeneca; AURA3 ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT02151981 .
title: Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.
Osimertinib or Platinum-Pemetrexed in EGFR T790M-Positive Lung Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: KRAS mutations are detected in 25% of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and no targeted therapies are approved for this subset population.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: Trametinib, a selective allosteric inhibitor of MEK1/MEK2, demonstrated preclinical and clinical activity in KRAS-mutant NSCLC.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: We report a phase II trial comparing trametinib with docetaxel in patients with advanced KRAS-mutant NSCLC.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eligible patients with histologically confirmed KRAS-mutant NSCLC previously treated with one prior platinum-based chemotherapy were randomly assigned in a ratio of 2 : 1 to trametinib (2 mg orally once daily) or docetaxel (75 mg/m(2) i v  every 3 weeks).
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: Crossover to the other arm after disease progression was allowed.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: Primary end point was progression-free survival (PFS).
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: The study was prematurely terminated after the interim analysis of 92 PFS events, which showed the comparison of trametinib versus docetaxel for PFS crossed the futility boundary.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: RESULTS: One hundred and twenty-nine patients with KRAS-mutant NSCLC were randomized; of which, 86 patients received trametinib and 43 received docetaxel.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: Median PFS was 12 weeks in the trametinib arm and 11 weeks in the docetaxel arm (hazard ratio [HR] 1.14; 95% CI 0.75-1.75; P = 0.5197).
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: Median overall survival, while the data are immature, was 8 months in the trametinib arm and was not reached in the docetaxel arm (HR 0.97; 95% CI 0.52-1.83; P = 0.934).
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: There were 10 (12%) partial responses (PRs) in the trametinib arm and 5 (12%) PRs in the docetaxel arm (P = 1.0000).
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: The most frequent adverse events (AEs) in >/=20% of trametinib patients were rash, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and fatigue.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: The most frequent grade 3 treatment-related AEs in the trametinib arm were hypertension, rash, diarrhea, and asthenia.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: CONCLUSION: Trametinib showed similar PFS and a response rate as docetaxel in patients with previously treated KRAS-mutant-positive NSCLC.
title: A randomized phase II study of the MEK1/MEK2 inhibitor trametinib (GSK1120212) compared with docetaxel in KRAS-mutant advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)dagger.

text: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: The adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-binding cassette, sub-family B, member 1 (ABCB1) gene encodes P-glycoprotein (Pgp), which plays an important role in drug disposition by limiting intracellular uptake of paclitaxel.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: ABCB1 gene polymorphisms may alter the expression and function of Pgp, thereby influencing the response to chemotherapy.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: A panel of 17 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines was used to investigate whether alterations in the ABCB1 gene or its mRNA expression correlated with in vitro chemosensitivity to paclitaxel.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: METHODS: Polymorphisms in the ABCB1 gene were evaluated by direct sequencing.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: mRNA expression levels were assessed by quantitative real-time reverse transcription PCR.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: In vitro chemosensitivity to paclitaxel was expressed as half-maximal inhibitory concentration values, using a tetrazolium (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide)-based colorimetric assay.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: RESULTS: The variant allele frequencies for four ABCB1 gene polymorphisms were 14.71% for 2677G>T/A, 32.35% for 2734T>C, 23.53% for 3396C>T and 76.47% for 3435C>T.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: There was a significant positive correlation between ABCB1 mRNA expression and half-maximal inhibitory concentration values for paclitaxel (r=0.5322, P=0.0279).
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: None of the four ABCB1 gene polymorphisms were associated with paclitaxel chemosensitivity or ABCB1 mRNA expression in the 17 cell lines.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These in vitro results suggest that high ABCB1 mRNA expression may be a predictive biomarker for poor chemosensitivity to paclitaxel.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: The panel of NSCLC cell lines may provide clues and indications for establishing clinically useful relationships between a given polymorphism or level of gene expression and chemosensitivity to an anti-cancer agent.
title: ATP-binding cassette B1 gene polymorphisms, mRNA expression and chemosensitivity to paclitaxel in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL), an aggressive subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, is characterized by the hallmark translocation t(11;14)(q13;q32) and the resulting overexpression of cyclin D1 (CCND1).
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Our current knowledge of this disease encompasses frequent secondary cytogenetic aberrations and the recurrent mutation of a handful of genes, such as TP53, ATM, and CCND1.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: However, these findings insufficiently explain the biologic underpinnings of MCL.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Here, we performed whole transcriptome sequencing on a discovery cohort of 18 primary tissue MCL samples and 2 cell lines.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: We found recurrent mutations in NOTCH1, a finding that we confirmed in an extension cohort of 108 clinical samples and 8 cell lines.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: In total, 12% of clinical samples and 20% of cell lines harbored somatic NOTCH1 coding sequence mutations that clustered in the PEST domain and predominantly consisted of truncating mutations or small frame-shifting indels.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: NOTCH1 mutations were associated with poor overall survival (P = .003).
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: Furthermore, we showed that inhibition of the NOTCH pathway reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in 2 MCL cell lines.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: In summary, we have identified recurrent NOTCH1 mutations that provide the preclinical rationale for therapeutic inhibition of the NOTCH pathway in a subset of patients with MCL.
title: Whole transcriptome sequencing reveals recurrent NOTCH1 mutations in mantle cell lymphoma.

text: PURPOSE: Genetic alterations affecting the MAPK/ERK pathway are common in lung adenocarcinoma (LAD).
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Early steps of the signaling pathway are most often affected with EGFR, KRAS, and BRAF mutations encompassing more than 70% of all alterations.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Somatic mutations in MEK1, located downstream of BRAF, are rare and remain poorly defined as a distinct molecular subset.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumors harboring MEK1 mutations were identified through targeted screening of a large LAD cohort concurrently interrogated for recurrent mutations in MEK1, EGFR, KRAS, BRAF, ERBB2/HER2, NRAS, PIK3CA, and AKT.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Additional cases were identified through a search of publically available cancer genomic datasets.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Mutations were correlated with patient characteristics and treatment outcomes.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Overall survival was compared with stage-matched patients with KRAS- and EGFR-mutant LADs.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: RESULTS: We identified 36 MEK1-mutated cases among 6,024 LAD (0.6%; 95% confidence interval, 0.42-0.85).
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: The majority of patients were smokers (97%, n = 35/36).
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: There was no association with age, sex, race, or stage.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: The most common mutations were K57N (64%, 23/36) followed by Q56P (19%, 7/36), all mutually exclusive with other driver mutations in the targeted panel.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Transversions G:C>T:A were predominant (89%, 31/35), in keeping with smoking-associated DNA damage.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Additional less common somatic mutations were identified in the kinase domain, all of which are predicted to converge into a single interaction area based on in silico 3D modeling.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: CONCLUSIONS: MEK1 mutations define a distinct subset of lung cancers ( approximately 1%) with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Mutations are predominantly transversions, in keeping with a strong association with smoking.
title: MAP2K1 (MEK1) Mutations Define a Distinct Subset of Lung Adenocarcinoma Associated with Smoking.

text: Aberrant sonic hedgehog signalling, mostly due to PTCH1 mutations, has been shown to play a central role in the pathogenesis of basal cell carcinoma (BCC), as well as in basal cell naevus syndrome (BCNS).
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: Mutations in smoothened (SMO) encoding a receptor for sonic hedgehog have been reported in sporadic BCCs but not in BCNS.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: We report a case with multiple BCCs, pits and comedones in a segmental distribution over the upper part of the body, along with other findings compatible with BCNS.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: Histopathologically, there were different types of BCC.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: A heterozygous mutation (c.1234C>T, p.L412F) in SMO was detected in three BCCs but not in peripheral blood lymphocytes or the uninvolved skin.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: These were compatible with the type 1 mosaic form of BCNS.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: The p.L412F mutation was found experimentally to result in increased SMO transactivating activity, and the patient responded to vismodegib therapy.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: Activating mutations in SMO may cause BCNS.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: The identification of a gain-of-function mutation in SMO causing a type 1 mosaic form of BCNS further expands our understanding of the pathogenesis of BCC, with implications for the treatment of these tumours, whether sporadic or inherited.
title: Segmental basal cell naevus syndrome caused by an activating mutation in smoothened.

text: ATP-competitive mTOR kinase inhibitors (mTorKIs) are a new generation of mTOR-targeted agents with more potent anticancer activity than rapamycin in several tumor models.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: However, the sensitivity and resistance of cancer cells to mTorKIs remain poorly understood.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: In this study, we tested mTorKIs against a large panel of colorectal cancer (CRC) cell lines, and found that mTorKIs displayed broader anti-CRC activity than rapamycin, including CRC cells with K-Ras or B-Raf mutations, suggesting that these mTorKIs are particularly useful for CRCs resistant to EGFR inhibitors.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: Unexpectedly, we found that 40% CRC cell lines were intrinsically drug resistant.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: Moreover, we discovered an mTOR-independent 4EBP1 phosphorylation that was correlated with mTorKI resistance.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: Altogether, our findings provide compelling preclinical support for testing mTorKIs in human CRC clinical trials.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: They further reveal the existence of significant intrinsic mTorKI drug resistance in cancer cells and suggest that 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is a predictive biomarker for mTorKI sensitivity and resistance.
title: mTOR-independent 4E-BP1 phosphorylation is associated with cancer resistance to mTOR kinase inhibitors.

text: Matching molecularly targeted therapies with cancer subtype-specific gene mutations is revolutionizing oncology care.
title: Personalized treatment of Sezary syndrome by targeting a novel CTLA4:CD28 fusion.

text: However, for rare cancers this approach is problematic due to the often poor understanding of the disease's natural history and phenotypic heterogeneity, making treatment of these cancers a particularly unmet medical need in clinical oncology.
title: Personalized treatment of Sezary syndrome by targeting a novel CTLA4:CD28 fusion.

text: Advanced Sezary syndrome (SS), an aggressive, exceedingly rare variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a prototypical example of a rare cancer.
title: Personalized treatment of Sezary syndrome by targeting a novel CTLA4:CD28 fusion.

text: Through whole genome and RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) of a SS patient's tumor we discovered a highly expressed gene fusion between CTLA4 (cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen 4) and CD28 (cluster of differentiation 28), predicting a novel stimulatory molecule on the surface of tumor T cells.
title: Personalized treatment of Sezary syndrome by targeting a novel CTLA4:CD28 fusion.

text: Treatment with the CTLA4 inhibitor ipilimumab resulted in a rapid clinical response.
title: Personalized treatment of Sezary syndrome by targeting a novel CTLA4:CD28 fusion.

text: Our findings suggest a novel driver mechanism for SS, and cancer in general, and exemplify an emerging model of cancer treatment using exploratory genomic analysis to identify a personally targeted treatment option when conventional therapies are exhausted.
title: Personalized treatment of Sezary syndrome by targeting a novel CTLA4:CD28 fusion.

text: The prognosis for patients with mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is poor, and at present there is no truly effective therapy.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: Gene translocation-mediated constitutive expression of cyclin D1 seems to play the key role in the pathogenesis of MCL.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: Here we report that although 3 of 4 MCL cell lines expressed the recently identified, highly oncogenic cyclin D1b isoform, as well as the canonical cyclin D1a, 8 MCL patient samples expressed only the cyclin D1a protein despite expressing detectable cyclin D1b mRNA.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: Cell lines and tissue samples displayed constitutive activation of the cyclin D1 signaling cascade, as evidenced by strong expression of CDK4, Rb phosphorylation, and cyclin D1/CDK4 coassociation.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: All MCL cell lines and tissues examined displayed nondetectable to diminished expression of the cyclin D1 inhibitor p16.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: Novel small molecule CDK4/CDK6 inhibitor PD0332991 profoundly suppressed--at low nanomolar concentrations--Rb phosphorylation, proliferation, and cell cycle progression at the G0/G1 phase of MCL cells.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: These findings provide evidence that MCL should be very sensitive to targeted therapy aimed at functional inhibition of the cyclin D1/CDK4 complex.
title: Mantle cell lymphoma cells express predominantly cyclin D1a isoform and are highly sensitive to selective inhibition of CDK4 kinase activity.

text: Spindle cell sarcomas often present the surgical pathologist with a considerable diagnostic challenge.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, leiomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and monophasic synovial sarcoma may all appear similar histologically.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: The application of ancillary diagnostic modalities, such as immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy, may be helpful in the differentiation of these tumors, but in cases in which these adjunctive techniques fail to demonstrate any more definitive evidence of differentiation, tumor categorization may remain difficult.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: Cytogenetic and molecular genetic characterization of tumors have provided the basis for the application of molecular assays as the newest components of the diagnostic armamentarium.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: Because the chromosomal translocation t(X;18) has been observed repeatedly in many synovial sarcomas, it has been heralded as a diagnostic hallmark of synovial sarcoma.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: To formally test the specificity of this translocation for the diagnosis of synovial sarcoma, RNA extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue from a variety of soft tissue and spindle cell tumors was evaluated for the presence of t(X;18) by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: Although 85% of the synovial sarcomas studied demonstrated t(X;18), 75% of the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in our cohort also demonstrated this translocation.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: We conclude that the translocation t(X;18) is not specific to synovial sarcoma and discuss the implications of the demonstration of t(X;18) in a majority of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors.
title: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors with t(X;18). A pathologic and molecular genetic study.

text: Purpose AKT1 E17K mutations are oncogenic and occur in many cancers at a low prevalence.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: We performed a multihistology basket study of AZD5363, an ATP-competitive pan-AKT kinase inhibitor, to determine the preliminary activity of AKT inhibition in AKT-mutant cancers.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Patients and Methods Fifty-eight patients with advanced solid tumors were treated.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: The primary end point was safety; secondary end points were progression-free survival (PFS) and response according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST).
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Tumor biopsies and plasma cell-free DNA (cfDNA) were collected in the majority of patients to identify predictive biomarkers of response.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Results In patients with AKT1 E17K-mutant tumors (n = 52) and a median of five lines of prior therapy, the median PFS was 5.5 months (95% CI, 2.9 to 6.9 months), 6.6 months (95% CI, 1.5 to 8.3 months), and 4.2 months (95% CI, 2.1 to 12.8 months) in patients with estrogen receptor-positive breast, gynecologic, and other solid tumors, respectively.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: In an exploratory biomarker analysis, imbalance of the AKT1 E17K-mutant allele, most frequently caused by copy-neutral loss-of-heterozygosity targeting the wild-type allele, was associated with longer PFS (hazard ratio [HR], 0.41; P = .04), as was the presence of coincident PI3K pathway hotspot mutations (HR, 0.21; P = .045).
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Persistent declines in AKT1 E17K in cfDNA were associated with improved PFS (HR, 0.18; P = .004) and response ( P = .025).
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Responses were not restricted to patients with detectable AKT1 E17K in pretreatment cfDNA.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: The most common grade >/= 3 adverse events were hyperglycemia (24%), diarrhea (17%), and rash (15.5%).
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Conclusion This study provides the first clinical data that AKT1 E17K is a therapeutic target in human cancer.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: The genomic context of the AKT1 E17K mutation further conditioned response to AZD5363.
title: AKT Inhibition in Solid Tumors With AKT1 Mutations.

text: Introduction.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: BRAF kinase inhibitors such as Vemurafenib have shown improvement in overall survival, progression-free survival, and response rates in patients with metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600K mutation.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: However, there were no cases of complete remission reported in patients with V600K mutation before.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: Case Presentation.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: A 53-year-old man with metastatic melanoma and dialysis dependent end stage renal failure was treated safely with Vemurafenib for a BRAF V600K mutation positive melanoma and the case was reported elsewhere.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: After a long follow-up of the same patient treated with Vemurafenib, a complete radiological response was observed and the renal functions remained stable throughout the treatment.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: Main toxicities reported were grade 1 photosensitivity and skin cancers.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: Vemurafenib was discontinued but patient remains disease free 12 months after stopping treatment and the clinical review is ongoing.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: Conclusion.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: This is the first reported case of complete radiological response to a BRAF inhibitor in metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600K mutation and remains disease free even after discontinuation of treatment.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: This also shows clinical safety of Vemurafenib in end stage renal failure and highlights the need for closer look at the subgroup of patients with BRAF V600K mutation and its tumour biology.
title: Long Term Survival and Continued Complete Response of Vemurafenib in a Metastatic Melanoma Patient with BRAF V600K Mutation.

text: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) is an oncogene that can potentially be targeted by tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: We aimed to investigate the prevalence and prognostic significance of alterations in FGFR1 copy number in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: FGFR1 status was evaluated by chromogenic silver in situ hybridisation (ISH) in tissue microarray sections from a retrospective cohort of 304 surgically resected NSCLCs and results were correlated with the clinicopathological features and overall survival.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: High FGFR1 gene copy number (amplification or high-level polysomy) was significantly more frequent in squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) (24.8%) and large cell carcinomas (LCC) (25%) compared to adenocarcinomas (11.3%) (p = 0.01 and p = 0.03 respectively).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Among NSCLC there was no significant correlation between FGFR1-positive status and other clinicopathological features including age, gender, smoking history, tumour size, lymph node status, stage, grade, vascular, lymphatic or perineural invasion.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: FGFR1-positive patients showed a tendency to longer overall survival in univariate analysis (p = 0.14).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Multivariate survival analysis using Cox regression model confirmed FGFR1-positive patients had a significant reduction in the risk of death compared to FGFR1-negative patients (HR 0.6; p = 0.02).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: High FGFR1 gene copy number is a common finding in SCC and LCC and is an independent favourable prognostic factor.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) copy number is an independent prognostic factor in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The serine-threonine kinase gene AURORA-A is commonly amplified in epithelial malignancies.
title: AURORA-A amplification overrides the mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, inducing resistance to Taxol.

text: Here we show that elevated Aurora-A expression at levels that reflect cancer-associated gene amplification overrides the checkpoint mechanism that monitors mitotic spindle assembly, inducing resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent paclitaxel (Taxol).
title: AURORA-A amplification overrides the mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, inducing resistance to Taxol.

text: Cells overexpressing Aurora-A inappropriately enter anaphase despite defective spindle formation, and the persistence of Mad2 at the kinetochores, marking continued activation of the spindle assembly checkpoint.
title: AURORA-A amplification overrides the mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, inducing resistance to Taxol.

text: Mitosis is subsequently arrested by failure to complete cytokinesis, resulting in multinucleation.
title: AURORA-A amplification overrides the mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, inducing resistance to Taxol.

text: This abnormality is relieved by an inhibitory mutant of BUB1, linking the mitotic abnormalities provoked by Aurora-A overexpression to spindle checkpoint activity.
title: AURORA-A amplification overrides the mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, inducing resistance to Taxol.

text: Consistent with this conclusion, elevated Aurora-A expression causes resistance to apoptosis induced by Taxol in a human cancer cell line.
title: AURORA-A amplification overrides the mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, inducing resistance to Taxol.

text: BRAF(V600E) is the most frequent genetic mutation in papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) and has been reported as an independent predictor of poor prognosis of these patients.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: Current guidelines do not recommend the use of BRAF(V600E) mutational analysis on cytologic specimens from fine needle aspiration due to several reasons.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: Recently, immunohistochemistry using VE1, a mouse anti-human BRAF(V600E) antibody, has been reported as a highly reliable technique in detecting BRAF-mutated thyroid and nonthyroid cancers.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: The aim of this study was to test the reliability of VE1 immunohistochemistry on microhistologic samples from core needle biopsy (CNB) in identifying BRAF-mutated PTC.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: A series of 30 nodules (size ranging from 7 to 22 mm) from 30 patients who underwent surgery following CNB were included in the study.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: All these lesions had had inconclusive cytology.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: In all cases, both VE1 and BRAF(V600E) genotypes were evaluated.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: After surgery, final histology demonstrated 21 cancers and 9 benign lesions.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: CNB correctly diagnosed 20/20 PTC and 5/5 adenomatous nodules.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: One follicular thyroid cancer and 4 benign lesions were assessed at CNB as uncertain follicular neoplasm.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: VE1 immunohistochemistry revealed 8 mutated PTC and 22 negative cases.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: A 100% agreement was found when positive and negative VE1 results were compared with BRAF mutational status.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: These data are the first demonstration that VE1 immunohistochemistry performed on thyroid CNB samples perfectly matches with genetic analysis of BRAF status.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: Thus, VE1 antibody can be used on thyroid microhistologic specimens to detect BRAF(V600E)-mutated PTC before surgery.
title: Immunohistochemistry for BRAF(V600E) antibody VE1 performed in core needle biopsy samples identifies mutated papillary thyroid cancers.

text: Familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia (FPD/AML) is an autosomal dominant familial platelet disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia and a propensity to develop AML.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: Mutation analyses of RUNX1 in 3 families with FPD/AML showing linkage to chromosome 21q22.1 revealed 3 novel heterozygous point mutations (K83E, R135fsX177 (IVS4 + 3delA), and Y260X).
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: Functional investigations of the 7 FPD/AML RUNX1 Runt domain point mutations described to date (2 frameshift, 2 nonsense, and 3 missense mutations) were performed.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: Consistent with the position of the mutations in the Runt domain at the RUNX1-DNA interface, DNA binding of all mutant RUNX1 proteins was absent or significantly decreased.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: In general, missense and nonsense RUNX1 proteins retained the ability to heterodimerize with PEBP2beta/CBFbeta and inhibited transactivation of a reporter gene by wild-type RUNX1.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: Colocalization of mutant RUNX1 and PEBP2beta/CBFbeta in the cytoplasm was observed.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: These results suggest that the sequestration of PEBP2beta/CBFbeta by mutant RUNX1 may cause the inhibitory effects.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: While haploinsufficiency of RUNX1 causes FPD/AML in some families (deletions and frameshifts), mutant RUNX1 proteins (missense and nonsense) may also inhibit wild-type RUNX1, possibly creating a higher propensity to develop leukemia.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: This is consistent with the hypothesis that a second mutation has to occur, either in RUNX1 or another gene, to cause leukemia among individuals harboring RUNX1 FPD/AML mutations and that the propensity to acquire these additional mutations is determined, at least partially, by the initial RUNX1 mutation.
title: In vitro analyses of known and novel RUNX1/AML1 mutations in dominant familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myelogenous leukemia: implications for mechanisms of pathogenesis.

text: Growth factor receptor-mediated signal transduction has been implicated in conferring resistance to conventional chemotherapy on cancer cells.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: We describe a pathway that involves AKT/PI3K to mediate chemoresistance in gastric cancer patients.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: Primary gastric carcinoma tissues and corresponding normal mucosa were obtained from 76 gastric cancer patients who underwent surgery in the Department of Surgery II in Kyushu University Hospital from the years 1996-2000.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: AKT activation was investigated by immunostaining with a phosphorylation-specific antibody, and LOH (loss of heterozygosity) of PTEN was studied in the same samples.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: AKT was phosphorylated in 22 cases (28.9%) of gastric cancer cases.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: AKT and phosphorylated AKT were not correlated with any clinicopathological factor.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: We found that the gastric cancer patients who had higher AKT phosphorylation (activated AKT) seemed to have LOH of PTEN (p = 0.0008).
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: When the chemotherapeutic sensibilities of these patients were studied in an MTT assay, it was found that the activated AKT was associated with increased resistance to multiple chemotherapeutic agents (5-fluorouracil, adriamycin, mitomycin C and cis-platinum).
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: The results of our study indicate that AKT activation and LOH of PTEN plays an important role in conferring a broad-spectrum chemoresistance in gastric cancer patients.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: It also indicates that AKT may therefore be a novel molecular target for therapies or chemosensitivity tests that improve the outcomes of gastric cancer patients.
title: Akt phosphorylation associates with LOH of PTEN and leads to chemoresistance for gastric cancer.

text: Follicular lymphoma (FL) and the GCB subtype of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) derive from germinal center B cells.
title: Somatic mutations altering EZH2 (Tyr641) in follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas of germinal-center origin.

text: Targeted resequencing studies have revealed mutations in various genes encoding proteins in the NF-kappaB pathway that contribute to the activated B-cell (ABC) DLBCL subtype, but thus far few GCB-specific mutations have been identified.
title: Somatic mutations altering EZH2 (Tyr641) in follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas of germinal-center origin.

text: Here we report recurrent somatic mutations affecting the polycomb-group oncogene EZH2, which encodes a histone methyltransferase responsible for trimethylating Lys27 of histone H3 (H3K27).
title: Somatic mutations altering EZH2 (Tyr641) in follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas of germinal-center origin.

text: After the recent discovery of mutations in KDM6A (UTX), which encodes the histone H3K27me3 demethylase UTX, in several cancer types, EZH2 is the second histone methyltransferase gene found to be mutated in cancer.
title: Somatic mutations altering EZH2 (Tyr641) in follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas of germinal-center origin.

text: These mutations, which result in the replacement of a single tyrosine in the SET domain of the EZH2 protein (Tyr641), occur in 21.7% of GCB DLBCLs and 7.2% of FLs and are absent from ABC DLBCLs.
title: Somatic mutations altering EZH2 (Tyr641) in follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas of germinal-center origin.

text: Our data are consistent with the notion that EZH2 proteins with mutant Tyr641 have reduced enzymatic activity in vitro.
title: Somatic mutations altering EZH2 (Tyr641) in follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas of germinal-center origin.

text: Therapeutic options for malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM) are limited despite the increasing incidence globally.
title: BRCA1 is an essential mediator of vinorelbine-induced apoptosis in mesothelioma.

text: The vinca alkaloid vinorelbine exhibits clinical activity; however, to date, treatment optimization has not been achieved using biomarkers.
title: BRCA1 is an essential mediator of vinorelbine-induced apoptosis in mesothelioma.

text: BRCA1 regulates sensitivity to microtubule poisons; however, its role in regulating vinorelbine-induced apoptosis in mesothelioma is unknown.
title: BRCA1 is an essential mediator of vinorelbine-induced apoptosis in mesothelioma.
