title: FOLFOX4 Plus Cetuximab for Patients With Previously Untreated Metastatic Colorectal Cancer According to Tumor RAS and BRAF Mutation Status: Updated Analysis of the CECOG/CORE 1.2.002 Study.

text: CONCLUSION: These findings support those from recent studies that RAS and BRAF mutations are associated with poor outcome in patients receiving an epidermal growth factor receptor-targeted monoclonal antibody in combination with oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy.
title: FOLFOX4 Plus Cetuximab for Patients With Previously Untreated Metastatic Colorectal Cancer According to Tumor RAS and BRAF Mutation Status: Updated Analysis of the CECOG/CORE 1.2.002 Study.

text: Furthermore, mutation testing should not only include RAS codons 12 and 13 but should also be extended to the entire coding regions.
title: FOLFOX4 Plus Cetuximab for Patients With Previously Untreated Metastatic Colorectal Cancer According to Tumor RAS and BRAF Mutation Status: Updated Analysis of the CECOG/CORE 1.2.002 Study.

text: BACKGROUND: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is an autosomal dominantly inherited, multisystemic tumor syndrome caused by mutations in the VHL gene.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: To date, more than 1,000 germline and somatic mutations of the VHL gene have been reported.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: We present a novel mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene that presented with gestational diabetes mellitus.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: METHODS: A 30-year-old woman presented with gestational diabetes mellitus.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: She sequentially showed multiple pancreatic cysts, spinal cord hemangioblastoma, cerebellar hemangioblastoma, and clear cell type renal cell carcinomas.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: Also, her father and brother had brain hemangioblastomas.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: Each of the three exons of the VHL gene was individually amplified by polymerase chain reaction and direct sequencing was performed using an ABI 3730 DNA analyzer.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: RESULTS: DNA sequence analysis to determine the presence of VHL mutation in her family revealed del291C, a novel frameshift mutation.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: CONCLUSION: We found a novel mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene that presented with gestational diabetes mellitus.
title: A novel mutation in the von hippel-lindau tumor suppressor gene identified in a patient presenting with gestational diabetes mellitus.

text: BACKGROUND: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA)/anthracycline chemotherapy is beneficial in newly diagnosed acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL); however, it is important to identify patients with high-risk disease to increase the cure rate.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: We investigated the outcome of ATRA/anthracycline chemotherapy and clinicobiological correlations of FLT3/ITD and NPM1 mutations in APL patients.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: METHODS: Induction therapy included oral ATRA (45 mg/m(2)/day) and idarubicin (12 mg/m(2)/day, intravenous, on days 2, 4, and 6).
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Patients achieving complete remission (CR) received 3 courses of ATRA combined with reinforced consolidation therapy.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Mutations were analyzed using GeneScan and polymerasae chain reaction assays of bone marrow samples obtained from patients at diagnosis.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: RESULTS: Forty-five (84.9%) of 53 eligible patients achieved CR.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: The overall relapse rate was 8.9%, and the 3-year overall survival (OS) and leukemia-free survival (LFS) were 84.9+/-4.9% and 77.5+/-6.0%, respectively.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: The NPM1 mutation was not found in any patient, while the FLT3/ITD mutation was found in 10 (20.0%) patients.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Of the FLT3/ITD+ patients, 80% belonged to the high-risk group, defined according to the presenting WBC and platelet counts.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Among the patients who achieved CR, those who were FLT3/ITD+ had a higher relapse rate than those FLT3/ITD-.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: FLT3/ITD+ patients also had a significantly lower 3-year LFS than FLT3/ITD- patients.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Multivariate analysis of the LFS showed that the FLT3/ITD mutation was independently associated with a shorter overall LFS, after adjusting for pretreatment risk stratification.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: CONCLUSION: This study investigated the clinical outcome of newly diagnosed APL patients treated with ATRA/anthracycline chemotherapy.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Patients carrying the FLT3/ITD mutation had more aggressive clinical features and a poorer clinical outcome.
title: Treatment outcome of all-trans retinoic acid/anthracycline combination chemotherapy and the prognostic impact of FLT3/ITD mutation in acute promyelocytic leukemia patients.

text: Oncogenic c-ros oncogene1 (ROS1) fusion kinases have been identified in a variety of human cancers and are attractive targets for cancer therapy.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: The MET/ALK/ROS1 inhibitor crizotinib (Xalkori, PF-02341066) has demonstrated promising clinical activity in ROS1 fusion-positive non-small cell lung cancer.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: However, emerging clinical evidence has shown that patients can develop resistance by acquiring secondary point mutations in ROS1 kinase.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: In this study we characterized the ROS1 activity of PF-06463922, a novel, orally available, CNS-penetrant, ATP-competitive small-molecule inhibitor of ALK/ROS1.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: In vitro, PF-06463922 exhibited subnanomolar cellular potency against oncogenic ROS1 fusions and inhibited the crizotinib-refractory ROS1(G2032R) mutation and the ROS1(G2026M) gatekeeper mutation.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: Compared with crizotinib and the second-generation ALK/ROS1 inhibitors ceritinib and alectinib, PF-06463922 showed significantly improved inhibitory activity against ROS1 kinase.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: A crystal structure of the PF-06463922-ROS1 kinase complex revealed favorable interactions contributing to the high-affinity binding.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: In vivo, PF-06463922 showed marked antitumor activity in tumor models expressing FIG-ROS1, CD74-ROS1, and the CD74-ROS1(G2032R) mutation.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: Furthermore, PF-06463922 demonstrated antitumor activity in a genetically engineered mouse model of FIG-ROS1 glioblastoma.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: Taken together, our results indicate that PF-06463922 has potential for treating ROS1 fusion-positive cancers, including those requiring agents with CNS-penetrating properties, as well as for overcoming crizotinib resistance driven by ROS1 mutation.
title: PF-06463922 is a potent and selective next-generation ROS1/ALK inhibitor capable of blocking crizotinib-resistant ROS1 mutations.

text: Oncogenic BRAF mutations are found in several tumor types, including melanomas and colorectal cancers.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Tumors with BRAF mutations have increased mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway activity and heightened sensitivity to BRAF and MEK (mitogen-activated or extracellular signal-regulated protein kinase kinase) inhibitors.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: To identify potential mechanisms of acquired drug resistance, we generated clones resistant to the allosteric MEK inhibitor AZD6244 from two BRAF V600E mutant colorectal cancer cell lines that are highly sensitive to MEK or BRAF inhibition.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: These AZD6244-resistant (AR) clones, which exhibited cross-resistance to BRAF inhibitors, acquired resistance through amplification of the BRAF gene.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: A small percentage of treatment-naive parental cells showed preexisting BRAF amplification.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: We observed similar amplification in a subset of cells in a BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: In cell lines, BRAF amplification increased the abundance of phosphorylated MEK and impaired the ability of AZD6244 to inhibit ERK (extracellular signal-regulated kinase) phosphorylation.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: The ability of AZD6244 to inhibit ERK phosphorylation in AR cells was restored by treatment with a BRAF inhibitor at low concentrations that reduced the abundance of phosphorylated MEK to amounts observed in parental cells.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Combined MEK and BRAF inhibition fully overcame resistance to MEK or BRAF inhibitors alone and was also more effective in parental cells compared to treatment with either inhibitor alone.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: These findings implicate BRAF amplification as a mechanism of resistance to both MEK and BRAF inhibitors and suggest combined MEK and BRAF inhibition as a clinical strategy to overcome, or possibly prevent, this mechanism of resistance.
title: BRAF gene amplification can promote acquired resistance to MEK inhibitors in cancer cells harboring the BRAF V600E mutation.

text: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI), including crizotinib, are effective treatments in preclinical models and in cancer patients with ALK-translocated cancers.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: However, their efficacy will ultimately be limited by the development of acquired drug resistance.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: Here we report two mechanisms of ALK TKI resistance identified from a crizotinib-treated non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patient and in a cell line generated from the resistant tumor (DFCI076) as well as from studying a resistant version of the ALK TKI (TAE684)-sensitive H3122 cell line.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: The crizotinib-resistant DFCI076 cell line harbored a unique L1152R ALK secondary mutation and was also resistant to the structurally unrelated ALK TKI TAE684.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: Although the DFCI076 cell line was still partially dependent on ALK for survival, it also contained concurrent coactivation of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) signaling.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: In contrast, the TAE684-resistant (TR3) H3122 cell line did not contain an ALK secondary mutation but instead harbored coactivation of EGFR signaling.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: Dual inhibition of both ALK and EGFR was the most effective therapeutic strategy for the DFCI076 and H3122 TR3 cell lines.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: We further identified a subset (3/50; 6%) of treatment naive NSCLC patients with ALK rearrangements that also had concurrent EGFR activating mutations.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: Our studies identify resistance mechanisms to ALK TKIs mediated by both ALK and by a bypass signaling pathway mediated by EGFR.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: These mechanisms can occur independently, or in the same cancer, suggesting that the combination of both ALK and EGFR inhibitors may represent an effective therapy for these subsets of NSCLC patients.
title: A novel ALK secondary mutation and EGFR signaling cause resistance to ALK kinase inhibitors.

text: Recently, we identified 3' end deletions in the EPCAM gene as a novel cause of Lynch syndrome.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: These truncating EPCAM deletions cause allele-specific epigenetic silencing of the neighboring DNA mismatch repair gene MSH2 in tissues expressing EPCAM.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: Here we screened a cohort of unexplained Lynch-like families for the presence of EPCAM deletions.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: We identified 27 novel independent MSH2-deficient families from multiple geographical origins with varying deletions all encompassing the 3' end of EPCAM, but leaving the MSH2 gene intact.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: Within The Netherlands and Germany, EPCAM deletions appeared to represent at least 2.8% and 1.1% of the confirmed Lynch syndrome families, respectively.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: MSH2 promoter methylation was observed in epithelial tissues of all deletion carriers tested, thus confirming silencing of MSH2 as the causative defect.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: In a total of 45 families, 19 different deletions were found, all including the last two exons and the transcription termination signal of EPCAM.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: All deletions appeared to originate from Alu-repeat mediated recombination events.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: In 17 cases regions of microhomology around the breakpoints were found, suggesting nonallelic homologous recombination as the most likely mechanism.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: We conclude that 3' end EPCAM deletions are a recurrent cause of Lynch syndrome, which should be implemented in routine Lynch syndrome diagnostics.
title: Recurrence and variability of germline EPCAM deletions in Lynch syndrome.

text: BACKGROUND: PD-0332991 is an inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) 4 and 6, and was evaluated to determine its anti-proliferative effects in 25 renal cell carcinoma (RCC) cell lines.
title: PD-0332991, a potent and selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6, demonstrates inhibition of proliferation in renal cell carcinoma at nanomolar concentrations and molecular markers predict for sensitivity.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: Half-maximal inhibitory concentrations (IC50) of PD-0332991 were determined with cell line proliferation assays, as were its effects on the cell cycle, apoptosis, and retinoblastoma (RB) phosphorylation.
title: PD-0332991, a potent and selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6, demonstrates inhibition of proliferation in renal cell carcinoma at nanomolar concentrations and molecular markers predict for sensitivity.

text: Molecular markers for response prediction, including p16, p15, cyclin D1 (CCND1), cyclin E1 (CCNE1), E2F transcription factor 1 (E2F1), RB, CDK4 and CDK6, were studied using array comparative genomic hybridization (CGH) and gene expression.
title: PD-0332991, a potent and selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6, demonstrates inhibition of proliferation in renal cell carcinoma at nanomolar concentrations and molecular markers predict for sensitivity.

text: RESULTS: IC50 values for PD-0332991 ranged from 25.0 nM to 700 nM, and the agent demonstrated G0/G1 cell-cycle arrest, induction of late apoptosis, and blockade of RB phosphorylation.
title: PD-0332991, a potent and selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6, demonstrates inhibition of proliferation in renal cell carcinoma at nanomolar concentrations and molecular markers predict for sensitivity.

text: Through genotype and expression data p16, p15 and E2F1 were identified as having significant association between loss and sensitivity to PD-0332991: p16 (p=0.021), p15 (p=0.047), and E2F1 (p=0.041).
title: PD-0332991, a potent and selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6, demonstrates inhibition of proliferation in renal cell carcinoma at nanomolar concentrations and molecular markers predict for sensitivity.

text: CONCLUSION: PD-0332991 has antiproliferative activity in RCC cell lines, and molecular markers predict for sensitivity to this agent.
title: PD-0332991, a potent and selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6, demonstrates inhibition of proliferation in renal cell carcinoma at nanomolar concentrations and molecular markers predict for sensitivity.

text: PURPOSE: The causes of the aggressive nature of BCR-ABL1-positive adult acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) are unknown.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: To identify, at the submicroscopic level, oncogenic lesions that cooperate with BCR-ABL1 to induce ALL, we performed an investigation of genomic copy number alterations using single nucleotide polymorphism array, genomic polymerase chain reaction, and sequencing of candidate genes.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eighty-three patients with de novo adult Philadelphia chromosome (Ph) -positive ALL were enrolled onto institutional (n = 17) or Gruppo Italiano Malattie Ematologiche Maligne dell'Adulto Working Party delle Leucemia Acute (n = 66) clinical trials.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: Treatments included tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) alone, conventional chemotherapy, or a combination of TKI and chemotherapy.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: RESULTS: A 7p12 deletion of IKZF1 (Ikaros) was identified in 52 (63%) of 83 patients.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: The pattern of deletion varied among different patients, but the two most common deletion types were loss of exons 4 to 7 in 31 (37%) of 83 patients and loss of exons 2 to 7 in 17 (20%) of 83 patients.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: Disease-free survival (DFS) was shorter in patients with IKZF1 deletion versus patients with IKZF1 wild type (10 v 32 months, respectively; P = .02).
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: Furthermore, a significantly shorter cumulative incidence of relapse was recorded in patients with IKZF1 deletion versus patients with IKZF1 wild type (10.1 v 56.1 months, respectively; P = .001).
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: Multivariate analysis confirmed the negative prognostic impact of IKZF1 deletion on DFS (P = .04).
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: CONCLUSION: We conclude that IKZF1 deletions are likely to be a genomic alteration that significantly affects the prognosis of Ph-positive ALL in adults.
title: IKZF1 (Ikaros) deletions in BCR-ABL1-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia are associated with short disease-free survival and high rate of cumulative incidence of relapse: a GIMEMA AL WP report.

text: High-risk mutations in several genes predispose to both colorectal cancer (CRC) and endometrial cancer (EC).
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: We therefore hypothesised that some lower-risk genetic variants might also predispose to both CRC and EC.
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: Using CRC and EC genome-wide association series, totalling 13,265 cancer cases and 40,245 controls, we found that the protective allele [G] at one previously-identified CRC polymorphism, rs2736100 near TERT, was associated with EC risk (odds ratio (OR) = 1.08, P = 0.000167); this polymorphism influences the risk of several other cancers.
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: A further CRC polymorphism near TERC also showed evidence of association with EC (OR = 0.92; P = 0.03).
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: Overall, however, there was no good evidence that the set of CRC polymorphisms was associated with EC risk, and neither of two previously-reported EC polymorphisms was associated with CRC risk.
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: A combined analysis revealed one genome-wide significant polymorphism, rs3184504, on chromosome 12q24 (OR = 1.10, P = 7.23 x 10(-9)) with shared effects on CRC and EC risk.
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: This polymorphism, a missense variant in the gene SH2B3, is also associated with haematological and autoimmune disorders, suggesting that it influences cancer risk through the immune response.
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: Another polymorphism, rs12970291 near gene TSHZ1, was associated with both CRC and EC (OR = 1.26, P = 4.82 x 10(-8)), with the alleles showing opposite effects on the risks of the two cancers.
title: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common susceptibility polymorphisms for colorectal and endometrial cancer near SH2B3 and TSHZ1.

text: Lynch syndrome (LS) is caused by germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes, resulting in microsatellite-unstable tumours.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Approximately 35% of suspected LS (sLS) patients test negative for germline MMR gene mutations, hampering conclusive LS diagnosis.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: The aim of this study was to investigate somatic MMR gene aberrations in microsatellite-unstable colorectal and endometrial cancers of sLS patients negative for germline MMR gene mutations.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Suspected LS cases were selected from a retrospective Clinical Genetics Department diagnostic cohort and from a prospective multicentre population-based study on LS in The Netherlands.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: In total, microsatellite-unstable tumours of 40 sLS patients (male/female 20/20, median age 57 years) were screened for somatic MMR gene mutations by next-generation sequencing.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: In addition, loss of heterozygosity (LOH) of the affected MMR genes in these tumours as well as in 68 LS-associated tumours and 27 microsatellite-unstable tumours with MLH1 promoter hypermethylation was studied.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Of the sLS cases, 5/40 (13%) tumours had two pathogenic somatic mutations and 16/40 (40%) tumours had a (likely) pathogenic mutation and LOH.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Overall, LOH of the affected MMR gene locus was observed in 24/39 (62%) tumours with informative LOH markers.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Of the LS cases and the tumours with MLH1 promoter hypermethylation, 39/61 (64%) and 2/21 (10%) tumours, respectively, demonstrated LOH.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Half of microsatellite-unstable tumours of sLS patients without germline MMR gene mutations had two (likely) deleterious somatic MMR gene aberrations, indicating their sporadic origin.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: Therefore, we advocate adding somatic mutation and LOH analysis of the MMR genes to the molecular diagnostic workflow of LS.
title: Somatic aberrations of mismatch repair genes as a cause of microsatellite-unstable cancers.

text: PURPOSE: In patients whose lung adenocarcinomas harbor epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase domain mutations, acquired resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) gefitinib (Iressa) and erlotinib (Tarceva) has been associated with a second-site EGFR mutation, which leads to substitution of methionine for threonine at position 790 (T790M).
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: We aimed to elucidate the frequency and nature of secondary EGFR mutations in patients with acquired resistance to TKI monotherapy.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumor cells from patients with acquired resistance were examined for secondary EGFR kinase domain mutations by molecular analyses.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: Eight of 16 patients (50% observed rate; 95% confidence interval, 25-75%) had tumor cells with second-site EGFR mutations.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: Seven mutations were T790M and one was a novel D761Y mutation found in a brain metastasis.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: When combined with a drug-sensitive L858R mutation, the D761Y mutation modestly reduced the sensitivity of mutant EGFR to TKIs in both surrogate kinase and cell viability assays.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: In an autopsy case, the T790M mutation was found in multiple visceral metastases but not in a brain lesion.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The T790M mutation is common in patients with acquired resistance.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: The limited spectrum of TKI-resistant mutations in EGFR, which binds to erlotinib in the active conformation, contrasts with a wider range of second-site mutations seen with acquired resistance to imatinib, which binds to ABL and KIT, respectively, in closed conformations.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: Collectively, our data suggest that the type and nature of kinase inhibitor resistance mutations may be influenced by both anatomic site and mode of binding to the kinase target.
title: Novel D761Y and common secondary T790M mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor-mutant lung adenocarcinomas with acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors.

text: INTRODUCTION: The characteristics of different types of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) are not extensively studied.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: The distribution of EGFR mutations is known, with the most frequent in exon 19 (deletions) or exon 21 (point mutations).
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: Aberrations in exon 18 or 20 are infrequently found.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: Point mutations in exon 20 confer resistance against tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs), whereas the effect of the rare exon 20 insertions is, to a lesser extent, known.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: We present clinicopathological characteristics of patients with EGFR mutations in the four exons, with emphasis on exon 20 positive patients.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: METHODS: NSCLC patients who tested positively for EGFR mutations at the Oslo University Hospital, Oslo, Norway in the period between May 2010 and February 2012 were selected.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: Clinical information was collected for mutated patients, and response information for patients with exon 20 insertions treated with TKI is reported.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: RESULTS: Of 119 patients with EGFR mutation, 62.2% were women.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: The median age was 66.0 years.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: The frequency of exon 18, 19, 20, and 21 was 7%, 45%, 7%, and 38%, respectively.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: Four patients (3.3%) had double mutations, and exon 20 was involved in three of these.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: Seven of 11 exon 20 positive patients were treated with TKI.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: All five single-mutated exon 20 positive TKI-treated patients had progressive disease at first evaluation, whereas both TKI-treated exon 20 involving double-mutated patients had partial response.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: CONCLUSION: Exon 20 mutations seem to confer insensitivity to TKI treatment.
title: Clinicopathological characteristics of 11 NSCLC patients with EGFR-exon 20 mutations.

text: BACKGROUND: The genetic alterations responsible for an adverse outcome in most patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) are unknown.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: METHODS: Using massively parallel DNA sequencing, we identified a somatic mutation in DNMT3A, encoding a DNA methyltransferase, in the genome of cells from a patient with AML with a normal karyotype.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We sequenced the exons of DNMT3A in 280 additional patients with de novo AML to define recurring mutations.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: RESULTS: A total of 62 of 281 patients (22.1%) had mutations in DNMT3A that were predicted to affect translation.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We identified 18 different missense mutations, the most common of which was predicted to affect amino acid R882 (in 37 patients).
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We also identified six frameshift, six nonsense, and three splice-site mutations and a 1.5-Mbp deletion encompassing DNMT3A.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: These mutations were highly enriched in the group of patients with an intermediate-risk cytogenetic profile (56 of 166 patients, or 33.7%) but were absent in all 79 patients with a favorable-risk cytogenetic profile (P<0.001 for both comparisons).
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The median overall survival among patients with DNMT3A mutations was significantly shorter than that among patients without such mutations (12.3 months vs. 41.1 months, P<0.001).
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: DNMT3A mutations were associated with adverse outcomes among patients with an intermediate-risk cytogenetic profile or FLT3 mutations, regardless of age, and were independently associated with a poor outcome in Cox proportional-hazards analysis.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: DNMT3A mutations are highly recurrent in patients with de novo AML with an intermediate-risk cytogenetic profile and are independently associated with a poor outcome.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: (Funded by the National Institutes of Health and others.
title: DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.
DNMT3A mutations in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: Chemotherapy is standard neoadjuvant treatment of LA BC.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: Patients with HER2-positive BC require targeted therapy.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: Trastuzumab and pertuzumab, which target HER2, with chemotherapy are approved as neoadjuvant therapy, however, treatments with different mechanisms of action might provide a broader range of activity.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: In this study we evaluated the efficacy and safety of the irreversible ErbB family blocker afatinib, versus trastuzumab or lapatinib in the neoadjuvant treatment of HER2-positive, LA BC.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Treatment-naive, HER2-positive BC patients with stage IIIA, B, C or inflammatory disease were randomized 1:1:1 to daily afatinib (50 mg), lapatinib (1500 mg), or weekly trastuzumab (4 mg/kg loading dose, then 2 mg/kg/wk) for 6 weeks until surgery or follow-up neoadjuvant treatment.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: The primary end point was objective response rate according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (version 1.0).
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: Recruitment was stopped early because of slow patient enrollment; 29 patients were randomized to afatinib (n = 10), lapatinib (n = 8), or trastuzumab (n = 11).
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: Objective response was seen in 8 afatinib-, 6 lapatinib-, and 4 trastuzumab-treated patients.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: Eleven patients had stable disease (best response); 1 lapatinib- and 1 trastuzumab-treated patient had progressive disease.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: All 10 afatinib-treated patients experienced drug-related adverse events (commonly diarrhea, dermatitis acneiform, and paronychia) versus 6 of 8 lapatinib- (diarrhea and rash) and 5 of 11 trastuzumab-treated patients (vomiting and arthralgia).
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Afatinib demonstrated clinical activity that compared favorably to trastuzumab and lapatinib for neoadjuvant treatment of HER2-positive BC, with a safety profile consistent with epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: A neoadjuvant, randomized, open-label phase II trial of afatinib versus trastuzumab versus lapatinib in patients with locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: A pathologic complete response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) containing platinum is a strong prognostic determinant for patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC).
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: Despite comprehensive molecular characterization of bladder cancer, associations of molecular alterations with treatment response are still largely unknown.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: We selected pathologic complete responders (ypT0N0; n=38) and nonresponders (higher than ypT2; n=33) from a cohort of high-grade MIBC patients treated with NAC.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: DNA was isolated from prechemotherapy tumor tissue and used for next-generation sequencing of 178 cancer-associated genes (discovery cohort) or targeted sequencing (validation cohort).
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: We found that 9 of 38 complete responders had erb-b2 receptor tyrosine kinase 2 (ERBB2) missense mutations, whereas none of 33 nonresponders had ERBB2 mutations (p=0.003).
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: ERBB2 missense mutations in complete responders were mostly confirmed activating mutations.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: ERCC2 missense mutations, recently found associated with response to NAC, were more common in complete responders; however, this association did not reach statistical significance in our cohort.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: We conclude that ERBB2 missense mutations characterize a subgroup of MIBC patients with an excellent response to NAC.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: PATIENT SUMMARY: In this report we looked for genetic alterations that can predict the response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) in bladder cancer.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: We found that mutations in the gene ERBB2 are exclusively present in patients responding to NAC.
title: ERBB2 Mutations Characterize a Subgroup of Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancers with Excellent Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy.

text: PURPOSE: To determine the frequency of TET2 mutations, their associations with clinical and molecular characteristics and outcome, and the associated gene- and microRNA-expression signatures in patients with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML).
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Four-hundred twenty-seven patients with CN-AML were analyzed for TET2 mutations by polymerase chain reaction and direct sequencing and for established prognostic gene mutations.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: Gene- and microRNA-expression profiles were derived using microarrays.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: RESULTS: TET2 mutations, found in 23% of patients, were associated with older age (P < .001) and higher pretreatment WBC (P = .04) compared with wild-type TET2 (TET2-wt).
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: In the European LeukemiaNet (ELN) favorable-risk group (patients with CN-AML who have mutated CEBPA and/or mutated NPM1 without FLT3 internal tandem duplication [FLT3-ITD]), TET2-mutated patients had shorter event-free survival (EFS; P < .001) because of a lower complete remission (CR) rate (P = .007), and shorter disease-free survival (DFS; P = .003), and also had shorter overall survival (P = .001) compared with TET2-wt patients.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: TET2 mutations were not associated with outcomes in the ELN intermediate-I-risk group (CN-AML with wild-type CEBPA and wild-type NPM1 and/or FLT3-ITD).
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: In multivariable models, TET2 mutations were associated with shorter EFS (P = .004), lower CR rate (P = .03), and shorter DFS (P = .05) only among favorable-risk CN-AML patients.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: We identified a TET2 mutation-associated gene-expression signature in favorable-risk but not in intermediate-I-risk patients and found distinct mutation-associated microRNA signatures in both ELN groups.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: CONCLUSION: TET2 mutations improve the ELN molecular-risk classification in primary CN-AML because of their adverse prognostic impact in an otherwise favorable-risk patient subset.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: Our data suggest that these patients may be candidates for alternative therapies.
title: TET2 mutations improve the new European LeukemiaNet risk classification of acute myeloid leukemia: a Cancer and Leukemia Group B study.

text: BACKGROUND: Activating mutations in serine-threonine protein kinase B-RAF (BRAF) are found in 50% of patients with advanced melanoma.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Selective BRAF-inhibitor therapy improves survival, as compared with chemotherapy, but responses are often short-lived.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: In previous trials, MEK inhibition appeared to be promising in this population.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: METHODS: In this phase 3 open-label trial, we randomly assigned 322 patients who had metastatic melanoma with a V600E or V600K BRAF mutation to receive either trametinib, an oral selective MEK inhibitor, or chemotherapy in a 2:1 ratio.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Patients received trametinib (2 mg orally) once daily or intravenous dacarbazine (1000 mg per square meter of body-surface area) or paclitaxel (175 mg per square meter) every 3 weeks.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Patients in the chemotherapy group who had disease progression were permitted to cross over to receive trametinib.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Progression-free survival was the primary end point, and overall survival was a secondary end point.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: RESULTS: Median progression-free survival was 4.8 months in the trametinib group and 1.5 months in the chemotherapy group (hazard ratio for disease progression or death in the trametinib group, 0.45; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.33 to 0.63; P<0.001).
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: At 6 months, the rate of overall survival was 81% in the trametinib group and 67% in the chemotherapy group despite crossover (hazard ratio for death, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.32 to 0.92; P=0.01).
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Rash, diarrhea, and peripheral edema were the most common toxic effects in the trametinib group and were managed with dose interruption and dose reduction; asymptomatic and reversible reduction in the cardiac ejection fraction and ocular toxic effects occurred infrequently.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: Secondary skin neoplasms were not observed.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Trametinib, as compared with chemotherapy, improved rates of progression-free and overall survival among patients who had metastatic melanoma with a BRAF V600E or V600K mutation.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: (Funded by GlaxoSmithKline; METRIC ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01245062.
title: Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.
Improved survival with MEK inhibition in BRAF-mutated melanoma.

text: PURPOSE: Subclones bearing the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) T790M mutation concomitant with deletional mutation in exon 19 (Del19) or a point mutation in exon 21 (L858R) have been reported in non-small cell lung cancer patients before any EGFR tyrosine-kinase inhibitor (TKI) treatment.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: The effect of pretreatment T790M mutation on the survival of patients with both mutations treated with EGFR TKI is still being debated.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: A meta-analysis was undertaken to pool eligible trials to better elucidate whether pretreatment T790M mutation predicts a poorer outcome of EGFR TKI treatment.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: Hazard ratios and their 95% confidence intervals for progression-free survival (PFS) were extracted and used under the random-effects model.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: A total of 246 patients with activating EGFR mutation such as Del19 or L858R participated in four selected trials from 350 articles.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: The overall incidence of patients with pretreatment T790M mutation was 43.10% (106/246), ranging from 34.88% to 80.00% in the individual trials.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: The combined hazard ratio for PFS in all four eligible studies was 2.602 (95% confidence interval 1.011-6.695; P=0.047), indicating a shorter PFS in patients who had the T790M mutation before receiving EGFR TKI treatment.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: Heterogeneity testing indicated significant heterogeneity but the absence of publication bias.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSION: The meta-analysis reported here found that pretreatment T790M mutation had a negative impact on the PFS of non-small cell lung cancer patients with a Del19 or L858R EGFR mutation who received EGFR TKI treatment.
title: The predictive role of pretreatment epidermal growth factor receptor T790M mutation on the progression-free survival of tyrosine-kinase inhibitor-treated non-small cell lung cancer patients: a meta-analysis.

text: Osimertinib (Tagrisso(), AZD9291) is an oral, third-generation epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor (EGFR TKI) that is being developed by AstraZeneca for the treatment of advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Osimertinib: First Global Approval.

text: Osimertinib has been designed to target the EGFR T790M mutation that is often present in NSCLC patients with acquired EGFR TKI resistance, while sparing wild-type EGFR.
title: Osimertinib: First Global Approval.

text: In November 2015, the tablet formulation of osimertinib was granted accelerated approval in the USA for the treatment of patients with metastatic EGFR T790M mutation-positive NSCLC (as detected by an FDA-approved test) who have progressed on or after EGFR TKI therapy.
title: Osimertinib: First Global Approval.

text: Osimertinib has also been granted accelerated assessment status for this indication in the EU, and is in phase III development for first- and second-line and adjuvant treatment of advanced EGFR mutation-positive NSCLC in several countries.
title: Osimertinib: First Global Approval.

text: Phase I trials in patients with advanced solid tumours are also being conducted.
title: Osimertinib: First Global Approval.

text: This article summarizes the milestones in the development of osimertinib leading to this first approval for NSCLC.
title: Osimertinib: First Global Approval.

text: BACKGROUND: Deregulation of the MAPK genes signalling caused by somatic mutations have been implied in leukaemia pathogenesis, including RAS mutation (RASmut) in acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), which has been associated with intra-uterine chemical exposures.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: A case-case study was conducted in order to explore maternal and child exposures to tobacco smoking associations with early age leukaemia (EAL).
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: METHODS: Covariables of reference were MLL rearrangements (MLL-r), RASmut and NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T).
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: Samples from 150 acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and 85 AML were included.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: Maternal exposures were assessed using a structured questionnaire with demographic, personal habits and residence history information.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: Restriction fragment length polymorphism and denaturing high performance liquid chromatography were used to screen FLT3, KRAS, and NRAS mutations; direct sequencing was performed to validate the results.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: NQO1 polymorphism was detected by real-time allelic discrimination technique.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: RESULTS: Overall, RASmut were detected in 28.7% of EAL cases; BRAFmut was found only in one AML patient.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: Higher rate of KRASmut was found in ALL (30.3%) compared to AML (20.8%) with MLL-r; RASmut showed an association with second-hand tobacco smoking exposures (OR, 3.06, 95% CI, 1.03-9.07).
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: A considerable increased risk for EAL with the combination of RASmut and NQO1 609CT (OR, 4.24, 95% CI, 1.24-14.50) was observed.
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our data demonstrated the increased risk association between maternal smoking and EAL with MLL-r. Additionally, suggests that children second-hand tobacco exposures are associated with increased risk of EAL with RASmut modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T).
title: RAS mutations in early age leukaemia modulated by NQO1 rs1800566 (C609T) are associated with second-hand smoking exposures.

text: Adjuvant fluoropyrimidine-based (5-FU) chemotherapy is a mainstay of treatment for colorectal cancer (CRC), but only provides benefit for a subset of patients.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: To improve stratification we examined (for the first time in CRC), whether analysis of GRP78 expression provides a predictive biomarker and performed functional studies to examine the role of GRP78 in sensitivity to 5-FU.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: 396 CRC patient samples were collected in a prospective uniform manner and GRP78 expression was determined by immunohistochemistry on tissue microarrays using a well-validated antibody.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: Expression was correlated with clinicopathological parameters and survival.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: The role of GRP78 in 5-FU sensitivity was examined in CRC cells using siRNA, drug inhibition and flow cytometry.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: GRP78 expression was significantly elevated in cancer tissue (p < 0.0001), and correlated with depth of invasion (p = 0.029) and stage (p = 0.032).
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: Increased overall 5-year survival was associated with high GRP78 expression (p = 0.036).
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: Patients with stage II cancers treated by surgery alone, with high GRP78 also had improved survival (71% v 50%; p = 0.032).
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: Stage III patients with high GRP78 showed significant benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy (52% vs. 28%; p = 0.026), whereas patients with low GRP78 failed to benefit (28% vs. 32%; p = 0.805).
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: Low GRP78 was an independent prognostic indicator of reduced overall 5-year survival (p = 0.004; HR = 1.551; 95%CI 1.155-2.082).
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: In vitro, inhibition of GRP78 reduces apoptosis in response to 5-FU in p53 wild-type cells.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: GRP78 expression may provide a simple additional risk stratification to inform the adjuvant treatment of CRC and future studies should combine analysis with determination of p53 status.
title: The unfolded protein response regulator GRP78 is a novel predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer.

text: Purpose: Checkpoint inhibitors demonstrate salutary anticancer effects, including long-term remissions.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: PD-L1 expression/amplification, high mutational burden, and mismatch repair deficiency correlate with response.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: We have, however, observed a subset of patients who appear to be "hyperprogressors," with a greatly accelerated rate of tumor growth and clinical deterioration compared with pretherapy, which was also recently reported by Institut Gustave Roussy.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: The current study investigated potential genomic markers associated with "hyperprogression" after immunotherapy.Experimental Design: Consecutive stage IV cancer patients who received immunotherapies (CTLA-4, PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors or other [investigational] agents) and had their tumor evaluated by next-generation sequencing were analyzed (N = 155).
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: We defined hyperprogression as time-to-treatment failure (TTF) <2 months, >50% increase in tumor burden compared with preimmunotherapy imaging, and >2-fold increase in progression pace.Results: Amongst 155 patients, TTF <2 months was seen in all six individuals with MDM2/MDM4 amplification.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: After anti-PD1/PDL1 monotherapy, four of these patients showed remarkable increases in existing tumor size (55% to 258%), new large masses, and significantly accelerated progression pace (2.3-, 7.1-, 7.2- and 42.3-fold compared with the 2 months before immunotherapy).
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: In multivariate analysis, MDM2/MDM4 and EGFR alterations correlated with TTF <2 months.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: Two of 10 patients with EGFR alterations were also hyperprogressors (53.6% and 125% increase in tumor size; 35.7- and 41.7-fold increase).Conclusions: Some patients with MDM2 family amplification or EGFR aberrations had poor clinical outcome and significantly increased rate of tumor growth after single-agent checkpoint (PD-1/PD-L1) inhibitors.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: Genomic profiles may help to identify patients at risk for hyperprogression on immunotherapy.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: Further investigation is urgently needed.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 23(15); 4242-50.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: (c)2017 AACR.
title: Hyperprogressors after Immunotherapy: Analysis of Genomic Alterations Associated with Accelerated Growth Rate.

text: BACKGROUND: The presence of EGFR kinase domain mutations in a subset of NSCLC patients correlates with the response to treatment with the EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors gefitinib and erlotinib.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: Although most EGFR mutations detected are short deletions in exon 19 or the L858R point mutation in exon 21, more than 75 different EGFR kinase domain residues have been reported to be altered in NSCLC patients.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: The phenotypical consequences of different EGFR mutations may vary dramatically, but the majority of uncommon EGFR mutations have never been functionally evaluated.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: RESULTS: We demonstrate that the relative kinase activity and erlotinib sensitivity of different EGFR mutants can be readily evaluated using transfection of an YFP-tagged fragment of the EGFR intracellular domain (YFP-EGFR-ICD), followed by immunofluorescence microscopy analysis.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: Using this assay, we show that the exon 20 insertions Ins770SVD and Ins774HV confer increased kinase activity, but no erlotinib sensitivity.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: We also show that, in contrast to the common L858R mutation, the uncommon exon 21 point mutations P848L and A859T appear to behave like functionally silent polymorphisms.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: CONCLUSION: The ability to rapidly obtain functional information on EGFR variants of unknown relevance using the YFP-EGFR-ICD assay might prove important in the future for the management of NSCLC patients bearing uncommon EGFR mutations.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: In addition, our assay may be used to determine the response of resistant EGFR mutants to novel second-generation TKIs.
title: Functional analysis of cancer-associated EGFR mutants using a cellular assay with YFP-tagged EGFR intracellular domain.

text: BACKGROUND: Regular use of aspirin reduces the risk of a colorectal neoplasm, but the mechanism by which aspirin affects carcinogenesis in the colon is not well understood.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: METHODS: We estimated cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) expression by immunohistochemical assay of sections from paraffin-embedded colorectal-cancer specimens from two large cohorts of participants who provided data on aspirin use from a questionnaire every 2 years.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: We applied Cox regression to a competing-risks analysis to compare the effects of aspirin use on the relative risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2 in the tumor.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: RESULTS: During 2,446,431 person-years of follow-up of 82,911 women and 47,363 men, we found 636 incident colorectal cancers that were accessible for determination of COX-2 expression.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: Of the tumors, 423 (67%) had moderate or strong COX-2 expression.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: The effect of aspirin use differed significantly in relation to COX-2 expression (P for heterogeneity=0.02).
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: Regular aspirin use conferred a significant reduction in the risk of colorectal cancers that overexpressed COX-2 (multivariate relative risk, 0.64; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.52 to 0.78), whereas regular aspirin use had no influence on tumors with weak or absent expression of COX-2 (multivariate relative risk, 0.96; 95% CI, 0.73 to 1.26).
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: The age-standardized incidence rate for cancers that overexpressed COX-2 was 37 per 100,000 person-years among regular aspirin users, as compared with 56 per 100,000 person-years among those who did not use aspirin regularly; in contrast, the rate for cancers with weak or absent COX-2 expression was 27 per 100,000 person-years among regular aspirin users, as compared with 28 per 100,000 person-years among nonregular aspirin users.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Regular use of aspirin appears to reduce the risk of colorectal cancers that overexpress COX-2 but not the risk of colorectal cancers with weak or absent expression of COX-2.
title: Aspirin and the risk of colorectal cancer in relation to the expression of COX-2.

text: BACKGROUND: To evaluate the activity and safety of everolimus and identify potential biomarkers for efficacy of everolimus in patients with advanced gastric cancer (AGC), who failed both fluoropyrimidine and platinum.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: METHODS: Fifty-four patients received everolimus (10 mg day(-1)).
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: The primary objective was to determine the 4-month progression-free survival (PFS) rate, assumed to be 30%.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: We additionally investigated the potential biomarkers for everolimus as an exploratory endpoint in those who underwent tumour biopsies.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: RESULTS: Two patients (3.7%) achieved partial response and the disease control rate (DCR) was 38.9%.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: At a median follow-up duration of 8.7 months, the 4-month PFS rate was 18.4%, not fulfilling the primary hypothesis, with a median PFS of 1.7 months and a median overall survival of 8.3 months.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: The high expression of pS6(Ser240/4) at baseline was significantly associated with higher DCR (P=0.043) and prolonged PFS (P=0.001).
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: Grade 1/2 asthenia (96.3%) recorded as the leading toxicity and hyperglycaemia (20.4%) was the most common non-hematological grade 3/4 toxicity.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: Three patients experienced grade 3/4 pneumonitis.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: Notably, two experienced treatment-related deaths.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: CONCLUSION: Everolimus is active against a limited number of patients with AGC.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: pS6(Ser240/4) may be a potential predictive biomarker for everolimus, which requires validation.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: Careful monitoring is necessary despite generally favourable toxicity profile.
title: Phase II study of everolimus with biomarker exploration in patients with advanced gastric cancer refractory to chemotherapy including fluoropyrimidine and platinum.

text: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a tyrosine kinase receptor involved in both solid and hematological tumors.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: About 80% of ALK-positive anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (ALCL) cases are characterized by the t(2;5)(p23;q35) translocation, encoding for the aberrant fusion protein nucleophosmin (NPM)-ALK, whereas 5% of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients carry the inv(2)(p21;p23) rearrangement, encoding for the echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4)-ALK fusion.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: The ALK/c-MET/ROS inhibitor crizotinib successfully improved the treatment of ALK-driven diseases.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: However, several cases of resistance appeared in NSCLC patients, and ALK amino acid substitutions were identified as a leading cause of resistance to crizotinib.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: Second-generation ALK inhibitors have been developed in order to overcome crizotinib resistance.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: In this work, we profiled in vitro the activity of crizotinib, AP26113, ASP3026, alectinib, and ceritinib against six mutated forms of ALK associated with clinical resistance to crizotinib (C1156Y, L1196M, L1152R, G1202R, G1269A, and S1206Y) and provide a classification of mutants according to their level of sensitivity/resistance to the drugs.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: Since the biological activity of ALK mutations extends beyond the specific type of fusion, both NPM-ALK- and EML4-ALK-positive cellular models were used.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: Our data revealed that most mutants may be targeted by using different inhibitors.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: One relevant exception is represented by the G1202R substitution, which was highly resistant to all drugs (>10-fold increased IC50 compared to wild type) and may represent the most challenging mutation to overcome.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.
