text: These results provide a prediction of cross-resistance of known crizotinib-resistant mutations against all second-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) clinically available, and therefore could be a useful tool to help clinicians in the management of crizotinib-resistance cases.
title: Activity of second-generation ALK inhibitors against crizotinib-resistant mutants in an NPM-ALK model compared to EML4-ALK.

text: FLT3 (fms-like tyrosine kinase 3) is constitutively activated in about 30% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and represents a disease-specific molecular marker.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: Although FLT3-LM (length mutation) and TKD (tyrosine kinase domain) mutations have been considered to be mutually exclusive, 1% to 2% of patients carry both mutations.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: However, the functional and clinical significance of this observation is unclear.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: We demonstrate that FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants induce drug resistance toward PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents in in vitro model systems.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: As molecular mechanisms of resistance, we found that FLT3-ITD-TKD mutants cause hyperactivation of STAT5 (signal transducer and activator of transcription-5), leading to upregulation of Bcl-x(L) and RAD51 and arrest in the G(2)M phase of the cell cycle.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: Overexpression of Bcl-x(L) was identified as the critical mediator of drug resistance and recapitulates the PTK inhibitor and daunorubicin-resistant phenotype in FLT3-ITD cells.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: The combination of rapamycin, a selective mTOR inhibitor, and FLT3 PTK inhibitors restored the drug sensitivity in FLT3 dual mutant-expressing cells.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: Our data provide the molecular basis for understanding clinical FLT3 PTK inhibitor resistance and point to therapeutical strategies to overcome drug resistance in patients with AML.
title: FLT3-ITD-TKD dual mutants associated with AML confer resistance to FLT3 PTK inhibitors and cytotoxic agents by overexpression of Bcl-x(L).

text: PURPOSE: Though the efficacy of MEK inhibitors is being investigated in KRAS-mutant colorectal cancers (CRC), early clinical trials of MEK inhibitor monotherapy did not reveal significant antitumor activity.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: Resistance to MEK inhibitor monotherapy developed through a variety of mechanisms converging in ERK reactivation.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: Since ERK increases cyclin D expression and increases entry into the cell cycle, we hypothesized that the combination of MEK inhibitors and CDK4/6 inhibitors would have synergistic antitumor activity and cause tumor regression in vivo.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: RESULTS: The combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors synergistically inhibited cancer cell growth in vitro and caused tumor regression in vivo in cell line and patient-derived xenograft models.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: Combination therapy markedly decreased levels of phosphorylated ribosomal protein S6 both in vitro and in vivo and decreased Ki67 staining in vivo.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We performed in vitro proliferation, colony formation, apoptosis, and senescence assays, and Western blots, on a panel of 11 KRAS mutant CRC cell lines treated with the MEK inhibitor MEK162, the CDK4/6 inhibitor palbociclib, or the combination.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: We also treated 4 KRAS mutant CRC cell line and patient-derived xenografts with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, the CDK4/6 inhibitor palbociclib, or the combination, and performed immunohistochemical and reverse phase protein array analysis.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Combined inhibition of both MEK and CDK4/6 is effective in preclinical models of KRAS mutant CRC and justifies a planned phase II clinical trial in patients with refractory KRAS-mutant CRC.Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.
title: Efficacy of the combination of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo in KRAS mutant colorectal cancer models.

text: The gene for the transducer of transforming growth factor-beta/bone morphogenetic protein signalling SMAD4, a potential suppressor of colorectal carcinogenesis, is located at the chromosomal region 18q21.
title: SMAD4 is a predictive marker for 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: In order to evaluate the clinical relevance of SMAD4 deletion, gene copy alterations were determined by copy dosage using real-time quantitative PCR in 202 colorectal tumour biopsies from a previous randomised study of adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: SMAD4 is a predictive marker for 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Patients with normal SMAD4 diploidy turned out to have a three-fold higher benefit of 5-fluorouracil-based adjuvant chemotherapy with a border line significance (overall survival: 3.23, P=0.056; disease-free survival: 2.89, P=0.045).
title: SMAD4 is a predictive marker for 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: These data are consistent with the previous observation that patients whose cancer had retention of the 18q21 region had a significantly higher benefit from 5-fluorouracil-based therapy.
title: SMAD4 is a predictive marker for 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Moreover, these results may provide a refinement at the gene level of the clinical relevance of 18q21 deletion, thereby suggesting SMAD4 as a predictive marker in colorectal cancer.
title: SMAD4 is a predictive marker for 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: This data also indicate that integrity of this component of the transforming growth factor-beta/bone morphogenetic protein signalling pathway may be a critical factor for benefit of chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.
title: SMAD4 is a predictive marker for 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy in patients with colorectal cancer.

text: Mutations in codon 317 after treatment with imatinib and dasatinib have been reported.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: We reviewed patients with chronic myeloid leukemia and mutations after tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapy.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: F317L was detected in 20, including 12/99 (12%) with mutation after imatinib failure, and 8/16 (50%) after dasatinib (P = .001).
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Median follow-up from mutation detection was 25 months.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: At the time of F317L, 8 patients were in chronic phase (CP), 6 in accelerated phase, and 6 in blast phase.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: There was no difference in characteristics between patients with or without F317L mutations, or with no mutations.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: A complete cytogenetic response was achieved in 3 of 6 patients treated with nilotinib, 2 of 2 with imatinib, and 0 of 3 with dasatinib.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Survival of patients with F317L was similar to those with other mutations (P = .45).
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Patients in CP had better outcome, with a 2-year survival of 75%.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: F317L mutation is resistant to dasatinib but sensitive to other TKIs.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: The prognosis is dependent mostly on the disease stage.
title: Characteristics and outcome of chronic myeloid leukemia patients with F317L BCR-ABL kinase domain mutation after therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: EGFR mutated lung cancer accounts for a significant subgroup of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Over the last decade, multiple EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (EGFR-TKIs) have been developed to target mutated EGFR.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: However, there is little information regarding mutation specific potency of EGFR-TKIs against various types of EGFR mutations.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The purpose of this study is to establish an in vitro model to determine the "therapeutic window" of EGFR-TKIs against various types of EGFR mutations, including EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The potency of 1st (erlotinib), 2nd (afatinib) and 3rd (osimertinib and rociletinib) generation EGFR-TKIs was compared in vitro for human lung cancer cell lines and Ba/F3 cells, which exogenously express mutated or wild type EGFR.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: An in vitro model of mutation specificity was created by calculating the ratio of IC50 values between mutated and wild type EGFR.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The in vitro model identified a wide therapeutic window of afatinib for exon 19 deletions and L858R and of osimertinib and rociletinib for T790M positive mutations.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The results obtained with our models matched well with previously reported preclinical and clinical data.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Interestingly, for EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations, most of which are known to be resistant to 1st and 2nd generation EGFR-TKIS, osimertinib was potent and presented a wide therapeutic window.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: To our knowledge, this is the first report that has identified the therapeutic window of osimertinib for EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In conclusion, this model will provide a preclinical rationale for proper selection of EGFR-TKIs against clinically-relevant EGFR mutations.
title: In vitro modeling to determine mutation specificity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors against clinically relevant EGFR mutants in non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: The p53 tumor suppressor gene plays a central role in cell cycle regulation and induction of apoptosis.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: We analyzed p53 alterations and their impact on response to chemotherapy and clinical outcome in ovarian cancer patients.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: One hundred seventy-eight ovarian carcinomas, snap frozen and stored at -80 degrees C, were analyzed for mutations of the p53 gene (exons 2-11) by single-strand conformation polymorphism and DNA sequencing and for p53 overexpression by immunohistochemistry (monoclonal antibody DO7).
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: RESULTS: p53 mutations were found in 56% (99 of 178) of the tumors, and 62% of these were located in evolutionary highly conserved domains of the gene.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: Time to progression and overall survival were significantly shortened in patients with p53 mutations compared with wild-type p53 (P = 0.029 and P = 0.014) and patients with mutations in highly conserved domains as opposed to nonconserved domains or wild-type p53 (P = 0.010 and P = 0.007).
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: p53 protein overexpression (>10% positively stained nuclei) was found in 62% (110 of 178).
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: Time to progression and overall survival were shorter in cases with p53 overexpression (cutpoint, 10%: P = 0.071 and P = 0.056) but only marginally significant.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: Resistance to adjuvant cisplatin or carboplatin chemotherapy was significantly more frequent in patients with p53 overexpression (P = 0.001) or p53 missense mutations (P = 0.008) than patients with normal p53.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: p53 alterations correlate significantly with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy, early relapse, and shortened overall survival in ovarian cancer patients in univariate analysis.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: In multivariable analysis though, p53 was not an independent prognostic factor.
title: Correlation of p53 mutations with resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy and shortened survival in ovarian cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: KRAS mutations are clinically important predictors of resistance to EGFR-directed therapies in colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Oncogenic activation of the RAS/RAF/MEK/ERK signaling cascade mediates proliferation independent of growth factor signaling.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: One grade 3 acneiform rash and one grade 4 hypomagnesemia occurred.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: The most common grade 1 and 2 adverse events included rash, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, and fatigue.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: The maximum tolerated dose was established at selumetinib 75 mg p.o.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: BID and cetuximab 250 mg/m(2) weekly following a 400 mg/m(2) load.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: Best clinical response in the dose escalation group included 1 unconfirmed partial response in a patient with CRC and stable disease (SD) in 5 patients (1 squamous cell carcinoma of the tonsil, 1 non-small cell lung cancer, and 3 CRC), and in the KRAS-mutant CRC dose expansion cohort, of the 14 patients who were evaluable for response, 5 patients had SD and 9 patients had progressive disease.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The combination of selumetinib and cetuximab is safe and well tolerated.
title: A phase I study of selumetinib (AZD6244/ARRY-142866), a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with cetuximab in refractory solid tumors and KRAS mutant colorectal cancer.

text: We analyzed deoxyribonucleic acids from blood samples of five Japanese von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease families (three familial cases, two new mutations) for the presence of VHL gene mutations by single-strand conformational polymorphism analysis and direct sequencing.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: Four of the five families showed germ line mutations in VHL gene, comprising 2 missense mutations, 1 deletion, and 1 splice-site mutation.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: Two families had VHL gene mutations at exon 1; 1 family at exon 3; and 1 family at the splice-site adjacent to exon 3.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: Presymptomatic patients were accurately diagnosed by these methods.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: However, one family did not show a VHL gene mutation in the germ line but showed a somatic mutation at exon 2 in the hemangioblastoma tissue.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: The consequence of the somatic mutation was a microdeletion leading to a frameshift mutation.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: Our study is the first report of VHL gene analyses of Japanese VHL disease families, and suggests that not only germ line mutation, but also somatic mutation can lead to development of a tumor associated with the VHL disease.
title: Molecular genetic diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease: analysis of five Japanese families.

text: In vitro, EGFR inhibition, combined with the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib, causes synergistic cytotoxicity for BRAF(V600E) metastatic colorectal cancer, further augmented by irinotecan.
title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

text: In this 3+3 phase I study, patients with BRAF(V600E)-advanced solid cancers received cetuximab and irinotecan with escalating doses of vemurafenib.
title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

text: Six of 17 evaluable patients (35%) achieved a radiographic response by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors 1.1 criteria, consistent with in vivo models demonstrating tumor regressions with the triplet regimen.
title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

text: BRAF(V600E) circulating cell-free DNA (cfDNA) trends correlated with radiographic changes, and acquired mutations from cfDNA in genes reactivating MAPK signaling were observed at progression.
title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: Vemurafenib, in combination with irinotecan and cetuximab, was well tolerated in patients with refractory, BRAF-mutated metastatic colorectal cancer, and both survival outcomes and response rates exceeded prior reports for vemurafenib and for irinotecan plus cetuximab in BRAF(V600E) metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: Phase IB Study of Vemurafenib in Combination with Irinotecan and Cetuximab in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer with BRAFV600E Mutation.

text: BACKGROUND: Gain of function mutations in B-RAF and N-RAS occur frequently in melanoma, leading to mitogen activating protein kinase (MAPK) pathway activation, and this pathway is the target of drugs in development.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: Our purpose was to study clinical characteristics of patients with mutations in this pathway and to determine activity of inhibitors of B-RAF and MEK in short term cultures grown from tumors of some of these patients.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: METHODS: Clinical and pathologic data were collected retrospectively on melanoma patients tested for B-RAF and N-RAS mutations at the Yale Cancer Center and associations with survival were determined.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: We studied in vitro activity of the pan-RAF inhibitor, RAF265, and the MEK inhibitor, MEK162, in 22 melanoma short term cultures.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: We further characterized the effect of MEK inhibition on apoptosis and growth of melanoma cultures.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: RESULTS: In a cohort of 144 metastatic melanoma patients we found that patients with N-RAS mutant melanoma had a worse prognosis.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: These patients were more likely to have brain metastases at the time of presentation with metastatic disease than their N-RAS-wild-type counterparts.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: All N-RAS mutant melanoma cultures tested in our study (n = 7) were sensitive to MEK inhibition 162.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: Exposure to MEK162 reduced ERK1/2 phosphorylation, and induced apoptosis.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: Clonogenic survival was significantly reduced in sensitive melanoma cell cultures.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The prognosis of patients with melanoma expressing constitutively active N-RAS is poor, consistent with studies performed at other institutions.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: N-RAS mutant melanoma cultures appear to be particularly sensitive to MEK162, supporting ongoing clinical trials with MEK162 in N-RAS mutated melanoma.
title: MEK targeting in N-RAS mutated metastatic melanoma.

text: PURPOSE: Inactivation of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene in clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) leads to increased levels of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIF) and overexpression of HIF target genes, such as VEGF and others.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: VEGF-targeted agents are standard in advanced clear-cell RCC but biomarkers of activity are lacking.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We analyzed tumor tissue samples from metastatic clear-cell RCC patients who received pazopanib as part of clinical trial VEG102616.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: We evaluated several components of the VHL/HIF pathway: VHL gene inactivation (mutation and/or methylation), HIF-1alpha and HIF-2alpha immunohistochemistry staining, and HIF-1alpha transcriptional signature.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: We evaluated the association of these biomarkers with best overall response rate (ORR) and progression-free survival (PFS) to pazopanib, a standard first-line VEGF-targeted agent.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: The VEG102616 trial enrolled 225 patients, from whom 78 samples were available for tumor DNA extraction.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Of these, 70 patients had VHL mutation or methylation.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: VHL gene status did not correlate with ORR or PFS.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Similarly, HIF-1alpha (65 samples) and HIF-2alpha (66 samples) protein levels (high vs. low) did not correlate with ORR or PFS to pazopanib.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The HIF-1alpha transcriptional signature (46 samples) was enriched in tumors expressing high HIF-1alpha levels.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: However, the HIF-1alpha gene expression signature was not associated with clinical outcome to pazopanib.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In patients with advanced clear-cell RCC, several potential biomarkers along the VHL/HIF-1alpha/HIF-2alpha axis were not found to be predictive for pazopanib activity.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Additional efforts must continue to identify biomarkers associated with clinical outcome to VEGF-targeted agents in metastatic RCC.
title: The role of aberrant VHL/HIF pathway elements in predicting clinical outcome to pazopanib therapy in patients with metastatic clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: BACKGROUND: More than half of colorectal tumors harbor activating mutations in RAS/RAF proteins.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) is a small molecule kinase inhibitor targeting MEK kinase, downstream of RAS.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: We examined the efficacy and safety of selumetinib with irinotecan in second-line therapy.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: Patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer, progressing on first-line oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy with bevacizumab, were eligible for this multicenter open-label phase I/II trial.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: In part A, a dose was determined using a standard "3 + 3" design; in part B, efficacy was determined.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: The primary endpoint was RECIST response rate.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Historical data for irinotecan were used as reference.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Secondary endpoints included progression-free survival and overall survival.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Thirty-two patients entered the study, and 31 were treated.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: All had K-RAS exon 2 mutated tumors.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: In phase I, the recommended oral dose of selumetinib was 75 mg twice per day with intravenous (IV) irinotecan, 180 mg/m(2) every 2 weeks.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Three patients (9.7 %) had partial response .
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Sixteen patients (51.6 %) had stable disease for >/=4 weeks, including three >1 year.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: The most common grade 3 adverse events included diarrhea, neutropenia, fatigue, anemia, nausea, and dehydration.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: The study was terminated before a pre-planned accrual of 45 subjects.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Despite termination before full accrual, the point estimates of RR and median PFS show promising results, suggesting that further investigations of MEK inhibition in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer are warranted.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Studies combining MEK inhibitors with cytotoxics or other targeted agents may lead to improved clinical activity based on the emerging preclinical data.
title: Phase II study of selumetinib (AZD6244, ARRY-142886) plus irinotecan as second-line therapy in patients with K-RAS mutated colorectal cancer.

text: Platinum-based chemotherapeutics is the most common regimens for advanced NSCLC patients.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: However, it is difficult to identify platinum resistance in clinical treatment.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Genetic factors are thought to represent important determinants of drug efficacy.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: In this study, we investigated whether single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in Xeroderma pigmentosum group G (XPG) and X-ray repair cross complementing group 1 (XRCC1) were associated with the tumor response in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients treated with platinum-based chemotherapy in Chinese population.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Totally 82 patients with advanced NSCLC were routinely treated with cisplatin or carboplatin-based chemotherapy, and clinical response was evaluated after 2-3 cycles.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: And 3D (three dimensions) polyacrylamide gel-based DNA microarray method was used to evaluate the genotypes of XRCC1 194 Arg/Trp, XRCC1 399Arg/Gln, XPG 46His/His and XPG 1104His/Asp in DNA from peripheral lymphocytes.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: We found that there was a significantly increased chance of treatment response to platinum-based chemotherapy with the XRCC1 194Arg/Trp genotype (odds ratio 0.429; 95% CI 0.137-1.671; P=0.035).
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: The polymorphism of XPG 46His/His was found to be associated with clinical response in NSCLC patients P=0.047, not detected between chemotherapy response and SNPs of XRCC1 399Arg/Gln or XPG 1104His/Asp (P=0.997 0.561, respectively).
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Our study showed that the polymorphic status of XRCC1 194Arg/Trp might be a predictive marker of treatment response for advanced NSCLC patients and those of XPG His46His was associated with susceptibility of chemotherapy.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: The 3D polyacrylamide gel-based DNA microarray method was accurate, high-throughput and inexpensive, especially suitable for a large scale of SNP genotyping in population.
title: Polymorphisms in XRCC1 and XPG and response to platinum-based chemotherapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer patients.

text: Cutaneous melanoma is a devastating form of skin cancer and its incidence is increasing faster than any other preventable cancer in the United States.
title: Targeting mutant NRAS signaling pathways in melanoma.

text: The mutant NRAS subset of melanoma is more aggressive and associated with poorer outcomes compared to non-NRAS mutant melanoma.
title: Targeting mutant NRAS signaling pathways in melanoma.

text: The aggressive nature and complex molecular signaling conferred by this transformation has evaded clinically effective treatment options.
title: Targeting mutant NRAS signaling pathways in melanoma.

text: This review examines the major downstream effectors of NRAS relevant in melanoma and the associated advances made in targeted therapies that focus on these effector pathways.
title: Targeting mutant NRAS signaling pathways in melanoma.

text: We outline the history of MEK inhibition in mutant NRAS melanoma and recent advances with newer MEK inhibitors.
title: Targeting mutant NRAS signaling pathways in melanoma.

text: Since MEK inhibitors will likely be optimized when combined with other targeted therapies, we focus on recently identified targets that can be used in combination with MEK inhibitors.
title: Targeting mutant NRAS signaling pathways in melanoma.

text: The protein kinase B-Raf proto-oncogene, serine/threonine kinase (BRAF) is an oncogenic driver and therapeutic target in melanoma.
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Inhibitors of BRAF (BRAFi) have shown high response rates and extended survival in patients with melanoma who bear tumors that express mutations encoding BRAF proteins mutant at Val600, but a vast majority of these patients develop drug resistance.
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Here we show that loss of stromal antigen 2 (STAG2) or STAG3, which encode subunits of the cohesin complex, in melanoma cells results in resistance to BRAFi.
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: We identified loss-of-function mutations in STAG2, as well as decreased expression of STAG2 or STAG3 proteins in several tumor samples from patients with acquired resistance to BRAFi and in BRAFi-resistant melanoma cell lines.
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Knockdown of STAG2 or STAG3 expression decreased sensitivity of BRAF(Val600Glu)-mutant melanoma cells and xenograft tumors to BRAFi.
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Loss of STAG2 inhibited CCCTC-binding-factor-mediated expression of dual specificity phosphatase 6 (DUSP6), leading to reactivation of mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling (via the MAPKs ERK1 and ERK2; hereafter referred to as ERK).
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Our studies unveil a previously unknown genetic mechanism of BRAFi resistance and provide new insights into the tumor suppressor function of STAG2 and STAG3.
title: Loss of cohesin complex components STAG2 or STAG3 confers resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: We studied the effect of everolimus, an inhibitor of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) on human gastric cancer cell lines.
title: Phosphorylation of 4E-BP1 predicts sensitivity to everolimus in gastric cancer cells.

text: Cell proliferation in 3 of 8 cell lines was effectively inhibited by everolimus.
title: Phosphorylation of 4E-BP1 predicts sensitivity to everolimus in gastric cancer cells.

text: Basal phosphorylation level of 4E-BP1 (T37/46, T70) was significantly higher in everolimus-sensitive cells than in everolimus-resistant cells.
title: Phosphorylation of 4E-BP1 predicts sensitivity to everolimus in gastric cancer cells.

text: In subcutaneous xenograft model, immunohistochemistry analysis revealed that everolimus-sensitive cells expressed high levels of phospho-4E-BP1 (T37/46).
title: Phosphorylation of 4E-BP1 predicts sensitivity to everolimus in gastric cancer cells.

text: In conclusion, phosphorylation of 4E-BP1 may be a predictive biomarker of everolimus sensitivity in gastric cancer.
title: Phosphorylation of 4E-BP1 predicts sensitivity to everolimus in gastric cancer cells.

text: BACKGROUND: Alectinib, a highly selective inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), has shown systemic and central nervous system (CNS) efficacy in the treatment of ALK-positive non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We investigated alectinib as compared with crizotinib in patients with previously untreated, advanced ALK-positive NSCLC, including those with asymptomatic CNS disease.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: METHODS: In a randomized, open-label, phase 3 trial, we randomly assigned 303 patients with previously untreated, advanced ALK-positive NSCLC to receive either alectinib (600 mg twice daily) or crizotinib (250 mg twice daily).
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The primary end point was investigator-assessed progression-free survival.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Secondary end points were independent review committee-assessed progression-free survival, time to CNS progression, objective response rate, and overall survival.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: During a median follow-up of 17.6 months (crizotinib) and 18.6 months (alectinib), an event of disease progression or death occurred in 62 of 152 patients (41%) in the alectinib group and 102 of 151 patients (68%) in the crizotinib group.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The rate of investigator-assessed progression-free survival was significantly higher with alectinib than with crizotinib (12-month event-free survival rate, 68.4% [95% confidence interval (CI), 61.0 to 75.9] with alectinib vs. 48.7% [95% CI, 40.4 to 56.9] with crizotinib; hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.47 [95% CI, 0.34 to 0.65]; P<0.001); the median progression-free survival with alectinib was not reached.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The results for independent review committee-assessed progression-free survival were consistent with those for the primary end point.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A total of 18 patients (12%) in the alectinib group had an event of CNS progression, as compared with 68 patients (45%) in the crizotinib group (cause-specific hazard ratio, 0.16; 95% CI, 0.10 to 0.28; P<0.001).
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A response occurred in 126 patients in the alectinib group (response rate, 82.9%; 95% CI, 76.0 to 88.5) and in 114 patients in the crizotinib group (response rate, 75.5%; 95% CI, 67.8 to 82.1) (P=0.09).
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Grade 3 to 5 adverse events were less frequent with alectinib (41% vs. 50% with crizotinib).
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: As compared with crizotinib, alectinib showed superior efficacy and lower toxicity in primary treatment of ALK-positive NSCLC.
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: (Funded by F. Hoffmann-La Roche; ALEX ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT02075840 .
title: Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.
Alectinib versus Crizotinib in Untreated ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: PURPOSE: EML4-ALK is a fusion-type protein tyrosine kinase that is generated by inv(2)(p21p23) in the genome of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: To allow sensitive detection of EML4-ALK fusion transcripts, we have now developed a multiplex reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) system that captures all in-frame fusions between the two genes.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Primers were designed to detect all possible in-frame fusions of EML4 to exon 20 of ALK, and a single-tube multiplex RT-PCR assay was done with total RNA from 656 solid tumors of the lung (n = 364) and 10 other organs.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: RESULTS: From consecutive lung adenocarcinoma cases (n = 253), we identified 11 specimens (4.35%) positive for fusion transcripts, 9 of which were positive for the previously identified variants 1, 2, and 3.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: The remaining two specimens harbored novel transcript isoforms in which exon 14 (variant 4) or exon 2 (variant 5) of EML4 was connected to exon 20 of ALK.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: No fusion transcripts were detected for other types of lung cancer (n = 111) or for tumors from 10 other organs (n = 292).
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: Genomic rearrangements responsible for the fusion events in NSCLC cells were confirmed by genomic PCR analysis and fluorescence in situ hybridization.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: The novel isoforms of EML4-ALK manifested marked oncogenic activity, and they yielded a pattern of cytoplasmic staining with fine granular foci in immunohistochemical analysis of NSCLC specimens.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These data reinforce the importance of accurate diagnosis of EML4-ALK-positive tumors for the optimization of treatment strategies.
title: Multiplex reverse transcription-PCR screening for EML4-ALK fusion transcripts.

text: To identify predictive molecular markers for gemcitabine resistance, we investigated changes in the expression of four genes associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism during the development of acquired gemcitabine resistance of pancreatic cancer cell lines.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: The expression levels of human equilibrative nucleoside transporter-1 (hENT1), deoxycytidine kinase (dCK), RRM1, and RRM2 mRNA were analysed by real-time light cycler-PCR in various subclones during the development of acquired resistance to gemcitabine.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: Real-time light cycler-PCR demonstrated that the expression levels of either RRM1 or RRM2 progressively increased during the development of gemcitabine resistance.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: Expression of dCK was slightly increased in cells resistant to lower concentrations of gemcitabine, but was decreased below the undetectable level in higher concentration-resistant subclones.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: Expression of hENT1 was increased in the development of gemcitabine resistance.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: As acquired resistance to gemcitabine seems to correlate with the balance of these four factors, we calculated the ratio of hENT1 x dCK/RRM1 x RRM2 gene expression in gemcitabine-resistant subclones.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: The ratio of gene expression decreased progressively with development of acquired resistance in gemcitabine-resistant subclones.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: Furthermore, the expression ratio significantly correlated with gemcitabine sensitivity in eight pancreatic cancer cell lines, whereas no single gene expression level correlated with the sensitivity.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: These results suggest that the sensitivity of pancreatic cancer cells to gemcitabine is determined by the ratio of four factors involved in gemcitabine transport and metabolism.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: The ratio of the four gene expression levels correlates with acquired gemcitabine-resistance in pancreatic cancer cells, and may be useful as a predictive marker for the efficacy of gemcitabine therapy in pancreatic cancer patients.
title: Gemcitabine chemoresistance and molecular markers associated with gemcitabine transport and metabolism in human pancreatic cancer cells.

text: Small-molecule inhibitors of poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) have shown considerable promise in the treatment of homologous recombination (HR)-defective tumors, such as BRCA1- and BRCA2-deficient breast and ovarian cancers.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: We previously reported that mantle cell lymphoma cells with deficiency in ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM) are sensitive to PARP-1 inhibitors in vitro and in vivo.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: Here, we report that PARP inhibitors can potentially target ATM deficiency arising in a solid malignancy.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: We show that ATM protein expression varies between gastric cancer cell lines, with NUGC4 having significantly reduced protein levels.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: Significant correlation was found between ATM protein expression and sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, with NUGC4 being the most sensitive.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: Moreover, reducing ATM kinase activity using a small-molecule inhibitor (KU55933) or shRNA-mediated depletion of ATM protein enhanced olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines with depletion or inactivation of p53.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: Our results demonstrate that ATM is a potential predictive biomarker for PARP-1 inhibitor activity in gastric cancer harboring disruption of p53, and that combined inhibition of ATM and PARP-1 is a rational strategy for expanding the utility of PARP-1 inhibitors to gastric cancer with p53 disruption.
title: Low ATM protein expression and depletion of p53 correlates with olaparib sensitivity in gastric cancer cell lines.

text: Uveal melanoma patients with metastatic disease usually die within one year, emphasizing an urgent need to develop new treatment strategies for this cancer.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: MEK inhibitors improve survival in cutaneous melanoma patients but show only modest efficacy in metastatic uveal melanoma patients.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: In this study, we screened for growth factors that elicited resistance in newly characterized metastatic uveal melanoma cell lines to clinical-grade MEK inhibitors, trametinib and selumetinib.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: We show that neuregulin 1 (NRG1) and hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) provide resistance to MEK inhibition.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: Mechanistically, trametinib enhances the responsiveness to NRG1 and sustained HGF-mediated activation of AKT.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: Individually targeting ERBB3 and cMET, the receptors for NRG1 and HGF, respectively, overcome resistance to trametinib provided by these growth factors and by conditioned medium from fibroblasts that produce NRG1 and HGF.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: Inhibition of AKT also effectively reverses the protective effect of NRG1 and HGF in trametinib-treated cells.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: Uveal melanoma xenografts growing in the liver in vivo and a subset of liver metastases of uveal melanoma patients express activated forms of ERBB2 (the coreceptor for ERBB3) and cMET.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: Together, these results provide preclinical evidence for the use of MEK inhibitors in combination with clinical-grade anti-ERBB3 or anti-cMET monoclonal antibodies in metastatic uveal melanoma.
title: Paracrine Effect of NRG1 and HGF Drives Resistance to MEK Inhibitors in Metastatic Uveal Melanoma.

text: Antibodies against epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)--cetuximab and panitumumab--are widely used to treat colorectal cancer.
title: Identification of a mutation in the extracellular domain of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor conferring cetuximab resistance in colorectal cancer.

text: Unfortunately, patients eventually develop resistance to these agents.
title: Identification of a mutation in the extracellular domain of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor conferring cetuximab resistance in colorectal cancer.

text: We describe an acquired EGFR ectodomain mutation (S492R) that prevents cetuximab binding and confers resistance to cetuximab.
title: Identification of a mutation in the extracellular domain of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor conferring cetuximab resistance in colorectal cancer.

text: Cells with this mutation, however, retain binding to and are growth inhibited by panitumumab.
title: Identification of a mutation in the extracellular domain of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor conferring cetuximab resistance in colorectal cancer.

text: Two of ten subjects studied here with disease progression after cetuximab treatment acquired this mutation.
title: Identification of a mutation in the extracellular domain of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor conferring cetuximab resistance in colorectal cancer.

text: A subject with cetuximab resistance harboring the S492R mutation responded to treatment with panitumumab.
title: Identification of a mutation in the extracellular domain of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor conferring cetuximab resistance in colorectal cancer.

text: PURPOSE: HER2-positive breast cancer is heterogeneous.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Some tumors express mutations, like activating PIK3CA mutations or reduced PTEN expression, that negatively correlate with response to HER2-targeted therapies.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: In this exploratory analysis, we investigated whether the efficacy of trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1), an antibody-drug conjugate comprised of the cytotoxic agent DM1 linked to the HER2-targeted antibody trastuzumab, was correlated with the expression of specific biomarkers in the phase III EMILIA study.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumors were evaluated for HER2 (n = 866), EGFR (n = 832), and HER3 (n = 860) mRNA expression by quantitative reverse transcriptase PCR; for PTEN protein expression (n = 271) by IHC; and for PIK3CA mutations (n = 259) using a mutation detection kit.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Survival outcomes were analyzed by biomarker subgroups.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: T-DM1 was also tested on cell lines and in breast cancer xenograft models containing PIK3CA mutations.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Longer progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) were observed with T-DM1 compared with capecitabine plus lapatinib in all biomarker subgroups.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: PIK3CA mutations were associated with shorter median PFS (mutant vs. wild type: 4.3 vs. 6.4 months) and OS (17.3 vs. 27.8 months) in capecitabine plus lapatinib-treated patients, but not in T-DM1-treated patients (PFS, 10.9 vs. 9.8 months; OS, not reached in mutant or wild type).
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: T-DM1 showed potent activity in cell lines and xenograft models with PIK3CA mutations.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Although other standard HER2-directed therapies are less effective in tumors with PI3KCA mutations, T-DM1 appears to be effective in both PI3KCA-mutated and wild-type tumors.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 22(15); 3755-63.
title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

title: Relationship between Tumor Biomarkers and Efficacy in EMILIA, a Phase III Study of Trastuzumab Emtansine in HER2-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: MEK is a member of the MAPK signalling cascade that is commonly activated in melanoma.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Direct inhibition of MEK blocks cell proliferation and induces apoptosis.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: We aimed to analyse safety, efficacy, and genotyping data for the oral, small-molecule MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with melanoma.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: METHODS: We undertook a multicentre, phase 1 three-part study (dose escalation, cohort expansion, and pharmacodynamic assessment).
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The main results of this study are reported elsewhere; here we present data relating to patients with melanoma.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: We obtained tumour samples to assess BRAF mutational status, and available tissues underwent exploratory genotyping analysis.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Disease response was measured by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors, and adverse events were defined by common toxicity criteria.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00687622.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: FINDINGS: 97 patients with melanoma were enrolled, including 81 with cutaneous or unknown primary melanoma (36 BRAF mutant, 39 BRAF wild-type, six BRAF status unknown), and 16 with uveal melanoma.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The most common treatment-related adverse events were rash or dermatitis acneiform (n=80; 82%) and diarrhoea (44; 45%), most of which were grade 2 or lower.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: No cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas were recorded.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Of 36 patients with BRAF mutations, 30 had not received a BRAF inhibitor before; two complete responses (both confirmed) and ten partial responses (eight confirmed) were noted in this subgroup (confirmed response rate, 33%).
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Median progression-free survival of this subgroup was 5.7 months (95% CI 4.0-7.4).
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Of the six patients who had received previous BRAF inhibition, one unconfirmed partial response was recorded.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Of 39 patients with BRAF wild-type melanoma, four partial responses were confirmed (confirmed response rate, 10%).
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Our data show substantial clinical activity of trametinib in melanoma and suggest that MEK is a valid therapeutic target.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Differences in response rates according to mutations indicate the importance of mutational analyses in the future.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: FUNDING: GlaxoSmithKline.
title: Activity of the oral MEK inhibitor trametinib in patients with advanced melanoma: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: BACKGROUND: Many studies on thyroid follicular tumors have reported the presence of somatic mutations to three forms of RAS: HRAS, KRAS, and NRAS.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: However, the frequency and clinical significance of these RAS mutations remain unclear, in large part due to the different methodologies being used for mutation analysis and the limited number of cases featured in studies.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: To clarify the significance of RAS mutations, we examined a large number of follicular adenomas and carcinomas obtained from a single institute using established methods for the analysis of RAS.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: METHODS: Tumor samples from 40 follicular adenoma and 58 follicular carcinoma patients treated at the Kanagawa Cancer Center Hospital were analyzed.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: The three RAS mutations at codons 12 and 61 were assessed with a polymerase chain reaction-based loop-hybrid mobility shift assay followed by confirmation with direct sequencing.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: The relationships between mutation status and clinicopathological features at the time of the initial operation and the prognosis of the patients were also analyzed.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: RESULTS: Twelve out of 40 (30%) adenomas harbored RAS mutations.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: In contrast, 33 out of 58 (57%) follicular carcinomas harbored RAS mutations, and the mutation was predominantly found in the NRAS codon 61 (22/33, 67%, p<0.01).
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: The rate of gene mutations was significantly higher in the carcinomas than in the adenomas (p<0.01).
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: The NRAS codon 61 mutation in follicular carcinomas was positively associated with distant metastases through the entire clinical course of the patients (p<0.05), and RAS mutations were associated with poor overall patient survival (p<0.05).
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We investigated the frequency of RAS mutations in follicular thyroid tumors from a large number of cases obtained from a single institute.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: The predominance of NRAS codon 61 mutations as a feature of carcinomas indicates that the diagnosis of adenoma alongside the presence of this mutation should be made cautiously.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: Our study raises the possibility that follicular adenomas with the RAS mutations have an inherent malignant potential; however, the clinical significance of this finding should be further investigated in more patients and over a longer follow-up period.
title: The associations between RAS mutations and clinical characteristics in follicular thyroid tumors: new insights from a single center and a large patient cohort.

text: PURPOSE: KRAS mutations are found in approximately 25% of lung adenocarcinomas in Western countries and, as a group, have been strongly associated with cigarette smoking.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: These mutations are predictive of poor prognosis in resected disease as well as resistance to treatment with erlotinib or gefitinib.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We determined the frequency and type of KRAS codon 12 and 13 mutations and characterized their association with cigarette smoking history in patients with lung adenocarcinomas.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: RESULTS: KRAS mutational analysis was done on 482 lung adenocarcinomas, 81 (17%) of which were obtained from patients who had never smoked cigarettes.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: KRAS mutations were found in 15% (12 of 81; 95% confidence intervals, 8-24%) of tumors from never smokers.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Similarly, 22% (69 of 316; 95% confidence intervals, 17-27%) of tumors from former smokers, and 25% (21 of 85; 95% confidence intervals, 16-35%) of tumors from current smokers had KRAS mutations.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: The frequency of KRAS mutation was not associated with age, gender, or smoking history.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: The number of pack years of cigarette smoking did not predict an increased likelihood of KRAS mutations.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Never smokers were significantly more likely than former or current smokers to have a transition mutation (G-->A) rather than the transversion mutations known to be smoking-related (G-->T or G-->C; P < 0.0001).
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Based on our data, KRAS mutations are not rare among never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma and such patients have a distinct KRAS mutation profile.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: The etiologic and biological heterogeneity of KRAS mutant lung adenocarcinomas is worthy of further study.
title: Frequency and distinctive spectrum of KRAS mutations in never smokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

text: IMPORTANCE: More than 90% of well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcomas (WD/DDLS) have CDK4 amplification.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: The selective CDK4 and CDK6 inhibitor palbociclib inhibits growth and induces senescence in liposarcoma cell lines and xenografts.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: Our prior phase 2 study demonstrated that treatment with palbociclib (200 mg daily for 14 days every 21 days) resulted in clinical benefit in WD/DDLS but moderate hematologic toxic effects.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: It is important to understand whether palbociclib at a new dose and schedule-125 mg daily for 21 days every 28 days-results in clinical benefit and manageable toxic effects.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: OBJECTIVE: To determine the progression-free survival (PFS) at 12 weeks of patients with WD/DDLS treated with palbociclib (PD0332991).
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: In this phase 2, nonrandomized, open-label clinical trial conducted at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 60 patients 18 years and older with advanced WD/DDLS and measurable disease by RECIST 1.1 were enrolled from December 2011 to January 2014 and followed to March 2015.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: Patients received oral palbociclib at 125 mg daily for 21 days in 28-day cycles.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Primary end point was PFS.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: Secondary end points included response rate and toxic effects.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: RESULTS: Overall, 30 patients were enrolled in the initial cohort and 30 more in an expansion cohort.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: Median (range) age was 61.5 (35-87) years; 31 patients (52%) were male; median (range) Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group score was 0 (0-1).
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: Progression-free survival at 12 weeks was 57.2% (2-sided 95% CI, 42.4%-68.8%), and the median PFS was 17.9 weeks (2-sided 95% CI, 11.9-24.0 weeks).
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: There was 1 complete response.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: Toxic effects were primarily hematologic and included neutropenia (grade 3, n = 20 [33%]; grade 4, n = 2 [3%]) but no neutropenic fever.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: In patients with advanced WD/DDLS, treatment with palbociclib was associated with a favorable PFS and occasional tumor response.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: This dose and schedule appears active and may have less toxic effects than 200 mg for 14 days.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.

text: TRIAL REGISTRATION: clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT01209598.
title: Progression-Free Survival Among Patients With Well-Differentiated or Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma Treated With CDK4 Inhibitor Palbociclib: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial.
