text: AIM OF THE STUDY: To evaluate the frequency of MRE11/RAD50/NBS1 (MRN)-complex loss of protein expression in endometrial cancers (EC) and to determine whether loss of MRE11 renders the cancer cells sensitive to Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP)-inhibitory treatment.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: METHODS: MRN expression was examined in 521 samples of endometrial carcinomas and in 10 cancer cell lines.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: A putative mutation hotspot in the form of an intronic poly(T) allele in MRE11 was sequenced in selected cases (n = 26).
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: Sensitivity to the PARP-inhibitor, BMN673 was tested in colony formation assays before and after MRE11 silencing using siRNA.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: Homologous recombination (HR) DNA repair was evaluated by RAD51-foci formation assay upon irradiation and drug treatment.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: RESULTS: Loss of MRE11 protein was found in 30.7% of EC tumours and significantly associated with loss of RAD50, NBS1 and mismatch repair protein expression.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: One endometrial cell line showed a markedly reduced MRE11 expression due to a homozygous poly(T) mutation of MRE11, thereby exhibiting an increased sensitivity to BMN673.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: MRE11 depletion sensitizes MRE11 expressing EC cell lines to the treatment with BMN673.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: The increased sensitivity to PARP-inhibition correlates with reduced RAD51 foci formation upon ionizing radiation in MRE11-depleted cells.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: CONCLUSION: Loss of the MRE11 protein predicts sensitivity to PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in vitro, defining it as an additional synthetic lethal gene with PARP.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: The high incidence of MRE11 loss in ECs can be potentially exploited for PARP-inhibitor therapy.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: Furthermore, MRE11 protein expression using immunohistochemistry could be investigated as a predictive biomarker for PARP-inhibitor treatment.
title: Effect of MRE11 loss on PARP-inhibitor sensitivity in endometrial cancer in vitro.

text: BACKGROUND: Oncologic patients who are extreme responders to molecularly targeted therapy provide an important opportunity to better understand the biologic basis of response and, in turn, inform clinical decision making.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Malignant neoplasms with an uncertain histologic and immunohistochemical characterization present challenges both on initial diagnostic workups and then later in management, as current treatment algorithms are based on a morphologic diagnosis.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Herein, we report a case of a difficult to characterize sarcoma-like lesion for which genomic profiling with clinical next generation sequencing (NGS) identified the molecular underpinnings of arrested progression(stable disease) under combination targeted therapy within a phase I clinical trial.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: METHODS: Genomic profiling with clinical next generation sequencing was performed on the FoundationOne platform (Foundation Medicine, Cambridge MA).
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Histopathology and immunohistochemical studies were performed in the Department of Pathology, MD Anderson Cancer Center (Houston, TX).
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Treatment was administered in the context of a phase I clinical trial ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: (NCT01187199).
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: RESULTS: The histology of the tumor was that of a spindle cell neoplasm, grade 2 by FNCLCC standards.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Immunohistochemical staining was positive for S100 and CD34.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Genomic profiling identified the following alterations: a KIAA1549-BRAF gene fusion resulting from a tandem duplication event, a homozygous deletion of PTEN, and frameshift insertion/deletions in CDKN2A A68fs*51, SUFU E283fs*3, and MAP3K1 N325fs*3.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: The patient had a 25% reduction in tumor (RECIST v1.1) following combination therapy consisting of sorafenib, temsirolimus, and bevazicumab within a phase I clinical trial.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The patient responded to combination targeted therapy that fortuitously targeted KIAA1549-BRAF and PTEN loss within a spindle cell neoplasm, as revealed by genomic profiling based on NGS.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: This is the first report of a tumor driven by a KIAA1549-BRAF fusion responding to sorafenib-based combination therapy.
title: Targeted therapy by combined inhibition of the RAF and mTOR kinases in malignant spindle cell neoplasm harboring the KIAA1549-BRAF fusion protein.

text: Melanoma is a disease characterized by lesions that activate ERK.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: Although 70% of cutaneous melanomas harbor activating mutations in the BRAF and NRAS genes, the alterations that drive tumor progression in the remaining 30% are largely undefined.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: Vemurafenib, a selective inhibitor of RAF kinases, has clinical utility restricted to BRAF-mutant tumors.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: MEK inhibitors, which have shown clinical activity in NRAS-mutant melanoma, may be effective in other ERK pathway-dependent settings.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: Here, we investigated a panel of melanoma cell lines wild type for BRAF and NRAS to determine the genetic alteration driving their transformation and their dependence on ERK signaling in order to elucidate a candidate set for MEK inhibitor treatment.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: A cohort of the BRAF/RAS wild type cell lines with high levels of RAS-GTP had loss of NF1, a RAS GTPase activating protein.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: In these cell lines, the MEK inhibitor PD0325901 inhibited ERK phosphorylation, but also relieved feedback inhibition of RAS, resulting in induction of pMEK and a rapid rebound in ERK signaling.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: In contrast, the MEK inhibitor trametinib impaired the adaptive response of cells to ERK inhibition, leading to sustained suppression of ERK signaling and significant antitumor effects.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: Notably, alterations in NF1 frequently co-occurred with RAS and BRAF alterations in melanoma.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: In the setting of BRAF(V600E), NF1 loss abrogated negative feedback on RAS activation, resulting in elevated activation of RAS-GTP and resistance to RAF, but not MEK, inhibitors.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: We conclude that loss of NF1 is common in cutaneous melanoma and is associated with RAS activation, MEK-dependence, and resistance to RAF inhibition.
title: Loss of NF1 in cutaneous melanoma is associated with RAS activation and MEK dependence.

text: Glioblastomas (GBM) are devastating tumors in which there has been little clinical improvement in the last decades.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: New molecularly directed therapies are under development.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: EGFR is one of the most promising targets, as this receptor is mutated and/or overexpressed in nearly half of the GBMs.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: However, the results obtained with first-generation tyrosine-kinase inhibitors have been disappointing with no clear predictive markers of tumor response.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: Here, we have tested the antitumoral efficacy of a second-generation inhibitor, dacomitinib (PF299804, Pfizer), that binds in an irreversible way to the receptor.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: Our results confirm that dacomitinib has an effect on cell viability, self-renewal, and proliferation in EGFR-amplified +/- EGFRvIII GBM cells.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: Moreover, systemic administration of dacomitinib strongly impaired the in vivo tumor growth rate of these EGFR-amplified cell lines, with a decrease in the expression of stem cell-related markers.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: However, continuous administration of the compound was required to maintain the antitumor effect.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: The data presented here confirm that dacomitinib clearly affects receptor signaling in vivo and that its strong antitumoral effect is independent of the presence of mutant receptor isoforms although it could be affected by the PTEN status (as it is less effective in a PTEN-deleted GBM line).
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: Dacomitinib is being tested in second line for EGFR-amplified GBMs.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: We hope that our results could help to select retrospectively molecular determinants of this response and to implement future trials with dacomitinib (alone or in combination with other inhibitors) in newly diagnosed GBMs.
title: Preclinical Test of Dacomitinib, an Irreversible EGFR Inhibitor, Confirms Its Effectiveness for Glioblastoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) tumours harbouring a RAS mutation are associated with a lack of treatment benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies (mAbs).
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: However, observational evidence has led to speculation that mCRC patients with KRAS G13D mutant (MT) tumours may derive a benefit from treatment with anti-EGFR mAbs.
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: METHODS: We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to evaluate whether the efficacy of anti-EGFR mAbs for mCRC differs between tumours harbouring a KRAS G13D mutation (KRAS G13D) and KRAS mutations other than G13D (other KRAS MT).
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: RESULTS: Eight RCTs (n = 5967) met the inclusion criteria for assessment of both overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS).
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: For other KRAS MT the hazard ratio for OS benefit with addition of anti-EGFR mAb therapy was 1.06 (95% confidence interval [CI]; 0.96, 1.17), compared to 1.08 (95% CI; 0.73, 1.60) for KRAS G13D [test for interaction p=0.99].
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: In contrast, the hazard ratio for KRAS wild-type (WT) tumours was 0.85 (95% CI; 0.76, 0.95).
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: Regarding PFS benefit with anti-EGFR mAbs, the hazard ratio was 1.07 (95% CI; 0.92, 1.26) for other KRAS MT, 0.96 (95% CI; 0.73, 1.27) for KRAS G13D, and 0.68 (95% CI; 0.54, 0.85) for KRAS WT.
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: Again, the test for interaction (p=0.46) demonstrated no significant difference in PFS benefit for anti-EGFR mAb therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS MT.
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: CONCLUSION: This meta-analysis demonstrates no significant difference between KRAS G13D and other KRAS MT tumours in terms of treatment benefit from anti-EGFR mAbs for mCRC.
title: Meta-analysis comparing the efficacy of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy between KRAS G13D and other KRAS mutant metastatic colorectal cancer tumours.

text: The cytogenetic findings in 31 liposarcomas from 26 patients are reported.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: Four other tumors did not grow.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: Three histologic types are represented in this analysis.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: The well-differentiated liposarcomas were characterized by telomeric associations, large marker chromosomes and ring chromosomes, and in some cases, double minutes.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: The pleomorphic liposarcomas contained very high clonal chromosomal numbers with near-tetraploid modes and numerous variable, often unidentifiable, chromosomal abnormalities.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: The myxoid liposarcomas were characterized primarily by a t(12;16)(q13;p11) as the sole abnormality or additional changes.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: These results indicate that cytogenetic findings may provide a new criterion, not only for establishing the diagnosis of liposarcoma, but also for differentiating confusing histologic types of liposarcoma and these lesions from other types of sarcomas.
title: Cytogenetic findings in liposarcoma correlate with histopathologic subtypes.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate dabrafenib, a selective BRAF inhibitor, combined with trametinib, a selective MEK inhibitor, in patients with BRAF V600-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: A total of 43 patients with BRAF V600-mutant mCRC were treated with dabrafenib (150 mg twice daily) plus trametinib (2 mg daily), 17 of whom were enrolled onto a pharmacodynamic cohort undergoing mandatory biopsies before and during treatment.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Archival tissues were analyzed for microsatellite instability, PTEN status, and 487-gene sequencing.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Patient-derived xenografts were established from core biopsy samples.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Of 43 patients, five (12%) achieved a partial response or better, including one (2%) complete response, with duration of response > 36 months; 24 patients (56%) achieved stable disease as best confirmed response.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Ten patients (23%) remained in the study > 6 months.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: All nine evaluable during-treatment biopsies had reduced levels of phosphorylated ERK relative to pretreatment biopsies (average decrease +/- standard deviation, 47% +/- 24%).
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Mutational analysis revealed that the patient achieving a complete response and two of three evaluable patients achieving a partial response had PIK3CA mutations.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Neither PTEN loss nor microsatellite instability correlated with efficacy.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Responses to dabrafenib plus trametinib were comparable in patient-derived xenograft-bearing mice and the biopsied lesions from each corresponding patient.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: The combination of dabrafenib plus trametinib has activity in a subset of patients with BRAF V600-mutant mCRC.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Mitogen-activated protein kinase signaling was inhibited in all patients evaluated, but to a lesser degree than observed in BRAF-mutant melanoma with dabrafenib alone.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: PIK3CA mutations were identified in responding patients and thus do not preclude response to this regimen.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Additional studies targeting the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway in this disease are warranted.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK Inhibition With Dabrafenib and Trametinib in BRAF V600-Mutant Colorectal Cancer.

text: Smoothened (SMO) inhibitors recently entered clinical trials for sonic-hedgehog-driven medulloblastoma (SHH-MB).
title: Genome sequencing of SHH medulloblastoma predicts genotype-related response to smoothened inhibition.

text: Clinical response is highly variable.
title: Genome sequencing of SHH medulloblastoma predicts genotype-related response to smoothened inhibition.

text: To understand the mechanism(s) of primary resistance and identify pathways cooperating with aberrant SHH signaling, we sequenced and profiled a large cohort of SHH-MBs (n = 133).
title: Genome sequencing of SHH medulloblastoma predicts genotype-related response to smoothened inhibition.

text: SHH pathway mutations involved PTCH1 (across all age groups), SUFU (infants, including germline), and SMO (adults).
title: Genome sequencing of SHH medulloblastoma predicts genotype-related response to smoothened inhibition.

text: Children >3 years old harbored an excess of downstream MYCN and GLI2 amplifications and frequent TP53 mutations, often in the germline, all of which were rare in infants and adults.
title: Genome sequencing of SHH medulloblastoma predicts genotype-related response to smoothened inhibition.

text: Functional assays in different SHH-MB xenograft models demonstrated that SHH-MBs harboring a PTCH1 mutation were responsive to SMO inhibition, whereas tumors harboring an SUFU mutation or MYCN amplification were primarily resistant.
title: Genome sequencing of SHH medulloblastoma predicts genotype-related response to smoothened inhibition.

text: BACKGROUND: Mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC) is a recently described pathologic entity.
title: What hides behind the MASC: clinical response and acquired resistance to entrectinib after ETV6-NTRK3 identification in a mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC).

text: We report the case of a patient with an initial diagnosis of salivary acinic cell carcinoma later reclassified as MASC after next-generation sequencing revealed an ETV6-NTRK3 fusion.
title: What hides behind the MASC: clinical response and acquired resistance to entrectinib after ETV6-NTRK3 identification in a mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC).

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: This alteration was targeted with the pan-Trk inhibitor entrectinib (Ignyta), which possesses potent in vitro activity against cell lines containing various NTRK1/2/3 fusions.
title: What hides behind the MASC: clinical response and acquired resistance to entrectinib after ETV6-NTRK3 identification in a mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC).

text: RESULTS: A dramatic and durable response was achieved with entrectinib in this patient, followed by acquired resistance that correlated with the appearance of a novel NTRK3 G623R mutation.
title: What hides behind the MASC: clinical response and acquired resistance to entrectinib after ETV6-NTRK3 identification in a mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC).

text: Structural modeling predicts that this alteration sterically interferes with drug binding, correlating to decreased sensitivity to drug inhibition observed in cell-based assays.
title: What hides behind the MASC: clinical response and acquired resistance to entrectinib after ETV6-NTRK3 identification in a mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC).

text: CONCLUSIONS: This first report of clinical activity with TrkC inhibition and the development of acquired resistance in an NTRK3-rearranged cancer emphasize the utility of comprehensive molecular profiling and targeted therapy for rare malignancies (NCT02097810).
title: What hides behind the MASC: clinical response and acquired resistance to entrectinib after ETV6-NTRK3 identification in a mammary analogue secretory carcinoma (MASC).

text: PURPOSE: RG7112 is a small-molecule MDM2 antagonist.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: MDM2 is a negative regulator of the tumor suppressor p53 and frequently overexpressed in leukemias.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Thus, a phase I study of RG7112 in patients with hematologic malignancies was conducted.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Primary study objectives included determination of the dose and safety profile of RG7112.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Secondary objectives included evaluation of pharmacokinetics; pharmacodynamics, such as TP53-mutation status and MDM2 expression; and preliminary clinical activity.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Patients were divided into two cohorts: Stratum A [relapsed/refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML; except acute promyelocytic leukemia), acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and chronic myelogenous leukemia] and Stratum B (relapsed/refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small cell lymphocytic leukemia; CLL/sCLL).
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Some Stratum A patients were treated at the MTD to assess clinical activity.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: RESULTS: RG7112 was administered to 116 patients (96 patients in Stratum A and 20 patients in Stratum B).
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: All patients experienced at least 1 adverse event, and 3 dose-limiting toxicities were reported.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Pharmacokinetic analysis indicated that twice-daily dosing enhanced daily exposure.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Antileukemia activity was observed in the 30 patients with AML assessed at the MTD, including 5 patients who met International Working Group (IWG) criteria for response.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Exploratory analysis revealed TP53 mutations in 14% of Stratum A patients and in 40% of Stratum B patients.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Two patients with TP53 mutations exhibited clinical activity.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: p53 target genes were induced only in TP53 wild-type leukemic cells.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: Baseline expression levels of MDM2 correlated positively with clinical response.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: RG7112 demonstrated clinical activity against relapsed/refractory AML and CLL/sCLL.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: MDM2 inhibition resulted in p53 stabilization and transcriptional activation of p53-target genes.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: We provide proof-of-concept that MDM2 inhibition restores p53 function and generates clinical responses in hematologic malignancies.
title: Results of the Phase I Trial of RG7112, a Small-Molecule MDM2 Antagonist in Leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: The value of p53 status for predicting response to chemotherapy-based treatment in patients with esophageal cancer has been controversial.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: We conducted a meta-analysis to elucidate the correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: Studies were searched in PubMed, Embase, and Web of Science (up to September 2012).
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: The p53 status and response to therapy were defined and standardized.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Subgroup analyses based on the treatment and histopathology were performed to explore the usefulness of p53 status for predicting response to therapy in esophageal cancer.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Sensitivity analyses were conducted by removing specific studies to assess the effects of study quality.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: We included 28 studies with 1497 cases in our meta-analysis.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Wild-type form of p53 status (low expression of p53 protein and/or wild-type p53 gene) was associated with high response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer (total major response [MR]: risk ratio [RR] = 1.09, 95 % CI = 1.03-1.16, P = .003; pathological MR: RR = 1.15, 95 % CI = 1.06-1.25, P = .001; total complete response [CR]: RR = 1.08, 95 % CI = 1.00-1.17, P = .040).
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: The similar correlation between the wild-type form p53 and response to therapy were also detected in subgroup analyses (total MR, pathological MR, and total CR in chemoradiotherapy subgroup; total MR in chemotherapy subgroup; total MR and pathological CR in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma [ESCC]).
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Additionally, patients with wild-type form p53 status had high pathological complete response rate to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in ESCC.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The current meta-analysis suggested that p53 status might be a predictive biomarker for response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer.
title: Correlation of p53 status with the response to chemotherapy-based treatment in esophageal cancer: a meta-analysis.

text: Mutation and deletion of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene occurs in about 40% of endometrial carcinomas.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: The purpose of this study was to determine whether PTEN mutations also are present in endometrial hyperplasias, which are premalignant precursors of invasive endometrial adenocarcinomas.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: Genomic DNA from 51 endometrial hyperplasias was extracted from paraffin blocks, and PCR was used to amplify the nine exons of the PTEN gene.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: These products were screened using single-strand conformation analysis, and variant bands were sequenced.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: Somatic mutations in the PTEN gene were seen in 10 of 51 cases (20%), and two mutations were found in one case.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: An identical 4-bp deletion in exon 8 was seen in three cases, and 8 of 11 PTEN mutations predicted truncated protein products.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: There was no higher frequency of PTEN mutations in endometrial hyperplasias with atypia (6 of 32; 19%) relative to those without atypia (4 of 19; 21%).
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: These data suggest that inactivation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene is an early event in the development of some endometrial cancers.
title: Mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene in endometrial hyperplasias.

text: UNLABELLED: BRAF mutations occur in approximately 10% of colorectal cancers.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: Although RAF inhibitor monotherapy is highly effective in BRAF-mutant melanoma, response rates in BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer are poor.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: Recent clinical trials of combined RAF/EGFR or RAF/MEK inhibition have produced improved efficacy, but patients ultimately develop resistance.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: To identify molecular alterations driving clinical acquired resistance, we performed whole-exome sequencing on paired pretreatment and postprogression tumor biopsies from patients with BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer treated with RAF inhibitor combinations.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: We identified alterations in MAPK pathway genes in resistant tumors not present in matched pretreatment tumors, including KRAS amplification, BRAF amplification, and a MEK1 mutation.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: These alterations conferred resistance to RAF/EGFR or RAF/MEK combinations through sustained MAPK pathway activity, but an ERK inhibitor could suppress MAPK activity and overcome resistance.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: Identification of MAPK pathway reactivating alterations upon clinical acquired resistance underscores the MAPK pathway as a critical target in BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer and suggests therapeutic options to overcome resistance.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: RAF inhibitor combinations represent promising approaches in clinical development for BRAF-mutant colorectal cancer.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: Initial characterization of clinical acquired resistance mechanisms to these regimens identified several MAPK pathway alterations driving resistance by reactivating MAPK signaling, highlighting the critical dependence of BRAF-mutant colorectal cancers on MAPK signaling and offering potential strategies to overcome resistance.
title: Clinical Acquired Resistance to RAF Inhibitor Combinations in BRAF-Mutant Colorectal Cancer through MAPK Pathway Alterations.

text: Although the BRAF V600E base substitution is an approved target for the BRAF inhibitors in melanoma, BRAF gene fusions have not been investigated as anticancer drug targets.
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: In our study, a wide variety of tumors underwent comprehensive genomic profiling for hundreds of known cancer genes using the FoundationOne or FoundationOne Heme comprehensive genomic profiling assays.
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: BRAF fusions involving the intact in-frame BRAF kinase domain were observed in 55 (0.3%) of 20,573 tumors, across 12 distinct tumor types, including 20 novel BRAF fusions.
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: These comprised 29 unique 5' fusion partners, of which 31% (9) were known and 69% (20) were novel.
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: BRAF fusions included 3% (14/531) of melanomas; 2% (15/701) of gliomas; 1.0% (3/294) of thyroid cancers; 0.3% (3/1,062) pancreatic carcinomas; 0.2% (8/4,013) nonsmall-cell lung cancers and 0.2% (4/2,154) of colorectal cancers, and were enriched in pilocytic (30%) vs. nonpilocytic gliomas (1%; p < 0.0001), Spitzoid (75%) vs. nonSpitzoid melanomas (1%; p = 0.0001), acinar (67%) vs. nonacinar pancreatic cancers (<1%; p < 0.0001) and papillary (3%) vs. nonpapillary thyroid cancers (0%; p < 0.03).
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: Clinical responses to trametinib and sorafenib are presented.
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: In conclusion, BRAF fusions are rare driver alterations in a wide variety of malignant neoplasms, but enriched in Spitzoid melanoma, pilocytic astrocytomas, pancreatic acinar and papillary thyroid cancers.
title: The distribution of BRAF gene fusions in solid tumors and response to targeted therapy.

text: BACKGROUND: The purpose of this article was to study the association of human papillomavirus (HPV) with clinical outcomes in patients with recurrent or metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN).
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Archival baseline tumor specimens were obtained from patients treated on two clinical trials in recurrent or metastatic SCCHN: E1395, a phase III trial of cisplatin and paclitaxel versus cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil, and E3301, a phase II trial of irinotecan and docetaxel.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: HPV DNA was detected by in situ hybridization (ISH) with a wide-spectrum probe.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: p16 status was evaluated by immunohistochemistry.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: Clinical outcomes of interest were objective response, progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS).
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: RESULTS: We analyzed 64 patients for HPV ISH and 65 for p16.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: Eleven tumors (17%) were HPV+, 12 (18%) were p16+, whereas 52 (80%) were both HPV- and p16-.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: The objective response rate was 55% for HPV-positive versus 19% for HPV-negative (P = 0.022), and 50% for p16-positive versus 19% for p16-negative (P = 0.057).
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: The median survival was 12.9 versus 6.7 months for HPV-positive versus HPV-negative patients (P = 0.014), and 11.9 versus 6.7 months for p16-positive versus p16-negative patients (P = 0.027).
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: After adjusting for other covariates, hazard ratio for OS was 2.69 (P = 0.048) and 2.17 (P = 0.10), favoring HPV-positive and p16-positive patients, respectively.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: The other unfavorable risk factor for OS was loss of >/=5% weight in previous 6 months (P = 0.0021 and 0.023 for HPV and p16 models, respectively).
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: CONCLUSION: HPV is a favorable prognostic factor in recurrent or metastatic SCCHN that should be considered in the design of clinical trials in this setting.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: CLINICAL TRIAL IDENTIFIER: NCT01487733 Clinicaltrials.gov.
title: Prognostic significance of human papillomavirus in recurrent or metastatic head and neck cancer: an analysis of Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group trials.

text: Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) typically presents at an advanced stage and is associated with a poor oncological outcome.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: The median survival for metastatic ICC is less than 1 year with standard chemotherapy.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: ICC is associated with distinct oncogenic drivers including IDH (isocitrate dehydrogenase), HER-2 (human epidermal growth factor 2), and BRAF (v-Raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homolog B), which may benefit from matching targeted therapies.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: Hereby we report 2 cases of BRAF V600E refractory ICC treated with dual BRAF and MEK inhibitors (dabrafenib and trametinib) with excellent clinical and radiological response to therapy and with protracted duration of disease control.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: Our first patient achieved CR (complete remission) at 6 months of treatment with ultimate disease progression at 9 months.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: The second patient achieved a PR (partial response) at 2 months from starting treatment and remains progression free at 5 months.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: Our results confirm the activity of dual BRAF and MEK targeting in BRAF mutated ICC, adding further support to 3 additional case-reports in the literature.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: Dual targeting appears superior to other case reports with BRAF inhibition alone and appear favorable to historic data with cytotoxic chemotherapy.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: Given the poor outlook and refractoriness of BRAF mutant ICC, future studies should focus on early integration of BRAF/MEK inhibition.
title: Impressive response to dual BRAF and MEK inhibition in patients with BRAF mutant intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma-2 case reports and a brief review.

text: Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) easily recurs with multidrug resistance phenotype.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: However, standard therapeutic strategies for relapsed-SCLC remain unestablished.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) expression correlates with poor prognosis in extensive disease-SCLC.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: We have reported previously that HER2 expression is upregulated when HER2-positive SCLC cells acquire chemoresistance, and also demonstrated that trastuzumab exerts significant antitumor activity toward HER2-upregulated chemoresistant SCLC, mainly via antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity mechanism.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: Based on these preclinical data, we treated two patients with HER2-positive SCLC by combination of trastuzumab (6 mg/kg, day 1) and irinotecan (80 mg/m(2), days 1 and 8) every 21 days as the third-line chemotherapy following two prior regimens, first-line carboplatin plus etoposide and second-line amrubicin.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: One patient achieved partial response after the first cycle and received 6 cycles in total without disease progression for 4.5 months.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: The other also received 4 cycles and kept stable disease for 3.5 months.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: This treatment can be continued safely at an outpatient clinic without any severe adverse event.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: In conclusion, trastuzumab plus irinotecan chemotherapy is promising and feasible against HER2-positive relapsed SCLC.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: Further clinical studies are encouraged to confirm the antitumor efficacy of trastuzumab in SCLC.
title: Favorable response to trastuzumab plus irinotecan combination therapy in two patients with HER2-positive relapsed small-cell lung cancer.

text: NVP-BEZ235 is a newly developed dual PI3K/mTOR inhibitor, being tested in multiple clinical trials, including breast cancer.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: NVP-BEZ235 selectively induces cell growth inhibition in a subset, but not all, breast cancer cell lines.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: However, it remains a challenge to distinguish between sensitive and resistant tumors, particularly in the pretreatment setting.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: Here, we used ten breast cancer cell lines to compare NVP-BEZ235 sensitivity and in the context of androgen receptor (AR) activation during NVP-BEZ235 treatment.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: We also used female SCID mice bearing breast tumor xenografts to investigate the beneficial effect of dihydrotestosterone/NVP-BEZ235 combination treatment compared with each alone.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: We found that AR-positive breast cancer cell lines are much more sensitive to NVP-BEZ235 compared with AR-negative cells, regardless of PTEN or PI3KCA status.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: Reintroducing AR expression in NVP-BEZ235 nonresponsive AR-negative cells restored the response.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: DHT/NVP-BEZ235 combination not only resulted in a more significant growth inhibition than either drug alone, but also achieved tumor regression and complete responses for AR(+)/ER(+) tumors.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: This beneficial effect was mediated by dihydrotestosterone (DHT)-induced PTEN and KLLN expression.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: Furthermore, DHT could also reverse NVP-BEZ235-induced side effects such as skin rash and weight loss.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: Our data suggest that AR expression may be an independent predictive biomarker for response to NVP-BEZ235.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: AR induction could add benefit during NVP-BEZ235 treatment in patients, especially with AR(+)/ER(+) breast carcinomas.
title: Activation of AR sensitizes breast carcinomas to NVP-BEZ235's therapeutic effect mediated by PTEN and KLLN upregulation.

text: BACKGROUND: BRAF mutations act as an oncogenic driver via the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: BRAF inhibition has shown antitumour activity in patients with BRAF(V600E)-mutant NSCLC.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Dual MAPK pathway inhibition with BRAF and MEK inhibitors in BRAF(V600E)-mutant NSCLC might improve efficacy over BRAF inhibitor monotherapy based on observations in BRAF(V600)-mutant melanoma.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: We aimed to assess the antitumour activity and safety of dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with BRAF(V600E)-mutant NSCLC.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: METHODS: In this phase 2, multicentre, non-randomised, open-label study, we enrolled adult patients (aged >/=18 years) with pretreated metastatic stage IV BRAF(V600E)-mutant NSCLC who had documented tumour progression after at least one previous platinum-based chemotherapy and had had no more than three previous systemic anticancer therapies.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Patients with previous BRAF or MEK inhibitor treatment were ineligible.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Patients with brain metastases were allowed to enrol only if the lesions were asymptomatic, untreated (or stable more than 3 weeks after local therapy if treated), and measured less than 1 cm.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Enrolled patients received oral dabrafenib (150 mg twice daily) plus oral trametinib (2 mg once daily) in continuous 21-day cycles until disease progression, unacceptable adverse events, withdrawal of consent, or death.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was investigator-assessed overall response, which was assessed by intention to treat in the protocol-defined population (patients who received second-line or later treatment); safety was also assessed in this population and was assessed at least once every 3 weeks, with adverse events, laboratory values, and vital signs graded according to the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events version 4.0.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: The study is ongoing but no longer recruiting patients.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01336634.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Dec 20, 2013, and Jan 14, 2015, 59 patients from 30 centres in nine countries across North America, Europe, and Asia met eligibility criteria.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Two patients who had previously been untreated due to protocol deviation were excluded; thus, 57 eligible patients were enrolled.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: 36 patients (63.2% [95% CI 49.3-75.6]) achieved an investigator-assessed overall response.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Serious adverse events were reported in 32 (56%) of 57 patients and included pyrexia in nine (16%), anaemia in three (5%), confusional state in two (4%), decreased appetite in two (4%), haemoptysis in two (4%), hypercalcaemia in two (4%), nausea in two (4%), and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma in two (4%).
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: The most common grade 3-4 adverse events were neutropenia in five patients (9%), hyponatraemia in four (7%), and anaemia in three (5%).
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: Four patients died during the study from fatal adverse events judged to be unrelated to treatment (one retroperitoneal haemorrhage, one subarachnoid haemorrhage, one respiratory distress, and one from disease progression that was more severe than typical progression, as assessed by the investigator).
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Dabrafenib plus trametinib could represent a new targeted therapy with robust antitumour activity and a manageable safety profile in patients with BRAF(V600E)-mutant NSCLC.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: FUNDING: GlaxoSmithKline.
title: Dabrafenib plus trametinib in patients with previously treated BRAF(V600E)-mutant metastatic non-small cell lung cancer: an open-label, multicentre phase 2 trial.

text: BACKGROUND: Currently, crizotinib is the only drug that has been approved for treatment of ALK-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: We aimed to study the activity and safety of CH5424802, a potent, selective, and orally available ALK inhibitor.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: METHODS: In this multicentre, single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study of CH5424802, we recruited ALK inhibitor-naive patients with ALK-rearranged advanced NSCLC from 13 hospitals in Japan.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: In the phase 1 portion of the study, patients received CH5424802 orally twice daily by dose escalation.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: The primary endpoints of the phase 1 were dose limiting toxicity (DLT), maximum tolerated dose (MTD), and pharmacokinetic parameters.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: In the phase 2 portion of the study, patients received CH5424802 at the recommended dose identified in the phase 1 portion of the study orally twice a day.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: The primary endpoint of the phase 2 was the proportion of patients who had an objective response.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: Treatment was continued in 21-day cycles until disease progression, intolerable adverse events, or withdrawal of consent.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: The analysis was done by intent to treat.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: This study is registered with the Japan Pharmaceutical Information Center, number JapicCTI-101264.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: FINDINGS: Patients were enrolled between Sept 10, 2010, and April 18, 2012.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: The data cutoff date was July 31, 2012.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: In the phase 1 portion, 24 patients were treated at doses of 20-300 mg twice daily.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: No DLTs or adverse events of grade 4 were noted up to the highest dose; thus 300 mg twice daily was the recommended phase 2 dose.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: In the phase 2 portion of the study, 46 patients were treated with the recommended dose, of whom 43 achieved an objective response (93.5%, 95% CI 82.1-98.6) including two complete responses (4.3%, 0.5-14.8) and 41 partial responses (89.1%, 76.4-96.4).
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: Treatment-related adverse events of grade 3 were recorded in 12 (26%) of 46 patients, including two patients each experiencing decreased neutrophil count and increased blood creatine phosphokinase.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: Serious adverse events occurred in five patients (11%).
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: No grade 4 adverse events or deaths were reported.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: The study is still ongoing, since 40 of the 46 patients in the phase 2 portion remain on treatment.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: INTERPRETATION: CH5424802 is well tolerated and highly active in patients with advanced ALK-rearranged NSCLC.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: FUNDING: Chugai Pharmaceutical Co, Ltd.
title: CH5424802 (RO5424802) for patients with ALK-rearranged advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (AF-001JP study): a single-arm, open-label, phase 1-2 study.

text: BACKGROUND: The most accurate predictor of disease recurrence in patients treated for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma is, at present, the extent of regional lymph node metastasis.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: Since elevated levels of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and of its ligand, transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-alpha), have been detected in primary tumors of patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, we determined whether tumor levels of these proteins were of prognostic importance.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: METHODS: Monoclonal antibodies specific for EGFR and TGF-alpha were used for immunohistochemical detection of each protein in tissue sections of primary tumors from 91 patients who were treated by surgical resection.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: Levels of immunoreactive EGFR and TGF-alpha were quantified by use of a computerized image analysis system and were normalized to appropriate standards.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: The logrank test and proportional hazards regression analysis were used to calculate the probability that EGFR and TGF-alpha levels were associated with disease-free survival (i.e., no recurrence of cancer) and cause-specific survival (i.e., patients do not die of their disease).
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: All P values were two-sided.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: RESULTS: When tumor levels of EGFR or TGF-alpha were analyzed as continuous variables, disease-free survival and cause-specific survival were reduced among patients with higher levels of EGFR (both P = .0001) or TGF-alpha (both P = .0001).
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: In a multivariate analysis, tumor site, tumor level of EGFR, and tumor level of TGF-alpha were statistically significant predictors of disease-free survival; in a similar analysis, regional lymph node stage and tumor levels of EGFR and of TGF-alpha were significant predictors of cause-specific survival.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: CONCLUSION: Quantitation of EGFR and TGF-alpha protein levels in primary head and neck squamous cell carcinomas may be useful in identifying subgroups of patients at high risk of tumor recurrence and in guiding therapy.
title: Levels of TGF-alpha and EGFR protein in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and patient survival.

text: AIM: To determine whether BAP1 gene and protein expression associates with different prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and whether BAP1 expression correctly identifies patients as being at risk for metastases, following enucleation of the primary tumour.
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: METHODS: Thirty cases of uveal melanoma obtained by enucleation between 1999 and 2004 were analysed for a variety of prognostic markers, including histological characteristics, chromosome aberrations obtained by fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) analysis and gene expression profiling.
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: These parameters were compared with BAP1 gene expression and BAP1 immunostaining.
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: RESULTS: The presence of monosomy of chromosome 3 as identified by the different chromosome 3 tests showed significantly increased HRs (FISH on isolated nuclei cut-off 30%: HR 11.6, p=0.002; SNP analysis: HR 20.3, p=0.004) for death due to metastasis.
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: The gene expression profile class 2, based on the 15-gene expression profile, similarly provided a significantly increased HR for a poor outcome (HR 8.5, p=0.005).
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: Lower BAP1 gene expression and negative BAP1 immunostaining (50% of 28 tumours were immunonegative) were both associated with these markers for prognostication: FISH cut-off 30% monosomy 3 (BAP1 gene expression: p=0.037; BAP1 immunostaining: p=0.001), SNP-monosomy 3 (BAP1 gene expression: p=0.008; BAP1 immunostaining: p=0.002) and class 2 profile (BAP1 gene expression: p<0.001; BAP1 immunostaining: p=0.001) and were themselves associated with an increased risk of death due to metastasis (BAP1 gene expression dichotomised: HR 8.7, p=0.006; BAP1 immunostaining: HR 4.0, p=0.010).
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Loss of BAP1 expression associated well with all of the methods currently used for prognostication and was itself predictive of death due to metastasis in uveal melanoma after enucleation, thereby emphasising the importance of further research on the role of BAP1 in uveal melanoma.
title: Prognostic parameters in uveal melanoma and their association with BAP1 expression.

text: In contrast to other primary epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations in lung adenocarcinomas, insertions in exon 20 of EGFR have been generally associated with resistance to EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Their molecular spectrum, clinicopathologic characteristics, and prevalence are not well established.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Tumors harboring EGFR exon 20 insertions were identified through an algorithmic screen of 1,500 lung adenocarcinomas.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Cases were first tested for common mutations in EGFR (exons 19 and 21) and KRAS (exon 2) and, if negative, further analyzed for EGFR exon 20 insertions.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: All samples underwent extended genotyping for other driver mutations in EGFR, KRAS, BRAF, ERBB2/HER2, NRAS, PIK3CA, MEK1, and AKT by mass spectrometry; a subset was evaluated for ALK rearrangements.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: We identified 33 EGFR exon 20 insertion cases [2.2%, 95% confidence interval (CI), 1.6-3.1], all mutually exclusive with mutations in the other genes tested (except PIK3CA).
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: They were more common among never-smokers (P < 0.0001).
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: There was no association with age, sex, race, or stage.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Morphologically, tumors were similar to those with common EGFR mutations but with frequent solid histology.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Insertions were highly variable in position and size, ranging from 3 to 12 bp, resulting in 13 different insertions, which, by molecular modeling, are predicted to have potentially different effects on erlotinib binding.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: EGFR exon 20 insertion testing identifies a distinct subset of lung adenocarcinomas, accounting for at least 9% of all EGFR-mutated cases, representing the third most common type of EGFR mutation after exon 19 deletions and L858R.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Insertions are structurally heterogeneous with potential implications for response to EGFR inhibitors.
title: EGFR exon 20 insertion mutations in lung adenocarcinomas: prevalence, molecular heterogeneity, and clinicopathologic characteristics.

text: Loss of PTEN protein results in upregulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, which appears dependent on the PI3Kbeta isoform.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: Inhibitors of PI3Kbeta have potential to reduce growth of tumors in which loss of PTEN drives tumor progression.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of PI3Kbeta and PI3Kdelta (AZD8186) and assessed its antitumor activity across a panel of cell lines.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: We have then explored the antitumor effects as single agent and in combination with docetaxel in triple-negative breast (TNBC) and prostate cancer models.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: In vitro, AZD8186 inhibited growth of a range of cell lines.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: Sensitivity was associated with inhibition of the AKT pathway.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: Cells sensitive to AZD8186 (GI50 < 1 mumol/L) are enriched for, but not exclusively associated with, PTEN deficiency.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: In vivo, AZD8186 inhibits PI3K pathway biomarkers in prostate and TNBC tumors.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: Scheduling treatment with AZD8186 shows antitumor activity required only intermittent exposure, and that increased tumor control is achieved when AZD8186 is used in combination with docetaxel.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: AZD8186 is a potent inhibitor of PI3Kbeta with activity against PI3Kdelta signaling, and has potential to reduce growth of tumors dependent on dysregulated PTEN for growth.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: Moreover, AZD8186 can be combined with docetaxel, a chemotherapy commonly used to treat advanced TBNC and prostate tumors.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: The ability to schedule AZD8186 and maintain efficacy offers opportunity to combine AZD8186 more effectively with other drugs.
title: Inhibition of PI3Kbeta signaling with AZD8186 inhibits growth of PTEN-deficient breast and prostate tumors alone and in combination with docetaxel.

text: Heat shock protein (HSP) expression is induced by the exposure to stress, such as fever, oxidative stress, chemical exposure, and irradiation.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: In cancer, HSP promotes the survival of malignant cells by inhibiting the induction of apoptosis.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: In colorectal cancer, a loss-of-function mutation of HSP110 (HSP110DeltaE9) has been identified.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: HSP110DeltaE9 inhibits the nuclear translocation of wild-type HSP110, which is important for its chaperone activity and anti-apoptotic effects.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: The patients carrying HSP110DeltaE9 mutation exhibit high sensitivity to anticancer agents, such as oxaliplatin and 5-fluorouracil.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: There is still insufficient information about HSP110 localization, the clinicopathological significance of HSP110 expression, and its association with chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: Here, we found that high nuclear expression of HSP110 in gastric cancer tissues is associated with cancer progression, poor prognosis, and recurrence after adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: In vitro results showed that HSP110 suppression increases the sensitivity to 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin of human gastric cancer cell lines.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: Our results suggest that nuclear HSP110 may be a new drug sensitivity marker for gastric cancer and a potential molecular therapeutic target for the treatment of gastric cancer patients with acquired anticancer drug resistance.
title: Nuclear heat shock protein 110 expression is associated with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance in gastric cancer.

text: The anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (anti-EGFR) cetuximab has been proven to be efficient in metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: The molecular mechanisms underlying the clinical response to this drug remain unknown.
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: Genetic alterations of the intracellular effectors involved in EGFR-related signaling pathways may have an effect on response to this targeted therapy.
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: In this study, tumors from 30 metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated by cetuximab were screened for KRAS, BRAF, and PIK3CA mutation by direct sequencing and for EGFR copy number by chromogenic in situ hybridization.
