title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: Eleven of the 30 patients (37%) responded to cetuximab.
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: A KRAS mutation was found in 13 tumors (43%) and was significantly associated with the absence of response to cetuximab (KRAS mutation in 0% of the 11 responder patients versus 68.4% of the 19 nonresponder patients; P = 0.0003).
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: The overall survival of patients without KRAS mutation in their tumor was significantly higher compared with those patients with a mutated tumor (P = 0.016; median, 16.3 versus 6.9 months).
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: An increased EGFR copy number was found in 3 patients (10%) and was significantly associated with an objective tumor response to cetuximab (P = 0.04).
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: In conclusion, in this study, KRAS mutations are a predictor of resistance to cetuximab therapy and are associated with a worse prognosis.
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: The EGFR amplification, which is not as frequent as initially reported, is also associated with response to this treatment.
title: KRAS mutation status is predictive of response to cetuximab therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: To assess the prognostic relevance of mutations in the NPM1 gene encoding a nucleocytoplasmic shuttle protein in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and normal cytogenetics, sequencing of NPM1 exon 12 was performed in diagnostic samples from 300 patients entered into 2 consecutive multicenter trials of the AML Study Group (AMLSG).
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: Treatment included intensive double-induction therapy and consolidation therapy with high cumulative doses of high-dose cytarabine.
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: NPM1 mutations were identified in 48% of the patients including 12 novel sequence variants, all leading to a frameshift in the C-terminus of the nucleophosmin 1 (NPM1) protein.
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: Mutant NPM1 was associated with specific clinical, phenotypical, and genetic features.
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: Statistical analysis revealed a significant interaction of NPM1 and FLT3 internal tandem duplications (ITDs).
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: NPM1 mutations predicted for better response to induction therapy and for favorable overall survival (OS) only in the absence of FLT3 ITD.
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: Multivariable analysis for OS revealed combined NPM1-mutated/FLT3 ITD-negative status, CEBPA mutation status, availability of a human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-compatible donor, secondary AML, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) as prognostic factors.
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: In conclusion, NPM1 mutations in the absence of FLT3 ITD define a distinct molecular and prognostic subclass of young-adult AML patients with normal cytogenetics.
title: Mutant nucleophosmin (NPM1) predicts favorable prognosis in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: interaction with other gene mutations.

text: RIT1, (Ras-like without CAAX1), the founding member of a novel branch of the Ras subfamily, mediates a wide variety of cellular functions, including cell proliferation, survival, and differentiation, and it may play crucial oncogenic role in human cancer.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: The purpose of the current study was to characterize the expression pattern of RIT1 and assess the clinical significance of RIT1 expression in endometrial cancer patients.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: The mRNA and protein expression of RIT1 was significantly overexpressed in 7 endometrial cancer cell lines by qPCR and Western blot, respectively.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: In addition, RIT1 mRNA expression was elevated in 36 freshly frozen endometrial cancer tissues compared to 21 non-cancerous endometrial tissue samples.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: Similar results were observed by analyzing GEO datasets.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: Immunohistochemistry was used to examine the protein expression of RIT1 in two tissue microarrays containing 257 cases of tumor and 31 non-tumor tissues, which showed that elevated expression of RIT1 was significantly correlated with pathological type, clinical stage, grade and vascular invasion.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: Importantly, Kaplan-Meier survival analysis indicated that RIT1 expression was associated with overall survival of endometrial cancer patients.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: Multivariate Cox regression analysis revealed that RIT1 expression was one of the independent prognostic factors for endometrial cancer patients.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: Furthermore, RIT1 combined with other clinicopathological risk factors was a more significant model in ROC curve comparison.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: In conclusion, elevated expression of RIT1 may contribute to the progression of endometrial cancer and thus may serve as a novel prognostic marker and a promising molecular target for the treatment of endometrial cancer.
title: Elevated expression of RIT1 correlates with poor prognosis in endometrial cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Approved anti-EGFR antibodies cetuximab and panitumumab provide significant clinical benefit in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (MCRC).
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: However, patients ultimately develop disease progression, often driven by acquisition of mutations in the extracellular domain (ECD) of EGFR.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Sym004 is a novel 1:1 mixture of two nonoverlapping anti-EGFR mAbs that recently showed promising clinical activity in a phase I trial in MCRC.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Our aim was to determine the efficacy of Sym004 to circumvent cetuximab resistance driven by EGFR ECD mutations.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Functional studies were performed to assess drug-receptor binding as well as ligand-dependent activation of individual EGFR mutants in the presence of cetuximab, panitumumab, and Sym004.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Cell viability and molecular effects of the drugs were assayed in cetuximab-resistant cell lines and in tumor xenograft models.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Efficacy of Sym004 was evaluated in patients progressing to cetuximab that harbored EGFR mutation in the post-cetuximab tumor sample.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Contrary to cetuximab and panitumumab, Sym004 effectively bound and abrogated ligand-induced phosphorylation of all individual EGFR mutants.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Cells resistant to cetuximab harboring mutations in EGFR maintained sensitivity to Sym004, which was consistent with an effective suppression of EGFR downstream signaling, translating into profound and sustained tumor regression in the xenograft model.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: As proof-of-principle, a patient with a tumor harboring an EGFR mutation (G465R) following cetuximab therapy benefited from Sym004 therapy.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Sym004 is an active drug in MCRC resistant to cetuximab/panitumumab mediated by EGFR mutations.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: EGFR mutations are potential biomarkers of response to Sym004 to be evaluated in ongoing large clinical trials.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 22(13); 3260-7.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: The First-in-class Anti-EGFR Antibody Mixture Sym004 Overcomes Cetuximab Resistance Mediated by EGFR Extracellular Domain Mutations in Colorectal Cancer.

text: Class III beta-tubulin (beta3) is associated with tumor aggressiveness, resistance to therapy, and patient relapse.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: To elucidate its action, we tested beta3's effect on cell migration.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: Expression of beta3 in HeLa and MCF-7 did not alter the intrinsic rate of cell migration, but it prevented the inhibition of migration by low, nontoxic concentrations of paclitaxel.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: The effects on cell motility were confirmed in CHO cells with tetracycline regulated expression of beta3.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: Cell migration and microtubule dynamics were inhibited by similar concentrations of paclitaxel, but required a 5-10 fold higher drug concentration when beta3 was expressed.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: The directionality of migration was normal in paclitaxel, but cells spent more time in a "paused" state during which there was no net movement.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: These studies support a model in which paclitaxel inhibits cell migration by suppressing microtubule dynamics and beta3-tubulin counteracts paclitaxel action by maintaining microtubule dynamic activity.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: The results provide a potential explanation for the aggressiveness of beta3-expressing tumors.
title: Class III beta-tubulin counteracts the ability of paclitaxel to inhibit cell migration.

text: We analyzed 47 primary sporadic human renal cell carcinomas (39 clear cell and 8 non-clear cell) for mutations of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene using the polymerase chain reaction and single strand conformational polymorphism analysis of DNA.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: All of the positive cases in single strand conformational polymorphism analyses were further characterized by direct sequencing.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: Somatic mutations were detected in 22 (56%) of 39 clear cell renal carcinomas including 15 deletions, 3 insertions, 3 missense mutations, and 1 nonsense mutation.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: Nineteen of these mutations predicted to produce truncation of the VHL protein.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: These mutations mainly occurred in the last one-third region of exons 1, 2, and 3.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: In addition, loss of heterozygosity of the VHL gene was observed in 16 (84%) of 19 informative clear cell renal carcinomas.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: No somatic mutations were detected in 8 non-clear cell carcinomas.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: These results show that the VHL tumor suppressor gene is one of the major tumor suppressor genes in human renal cell carcinomas, especially in the clear cell subtype renal cell carcinoma.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: Clear cell carcinoma might be distinguished from other pathological types of renal cell carcinomas by molecular genetic techniques.
title: Frequent somatic mutations and loss of heterozygosity of the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene in primary human renal cell carcinomas.

text: PURPOSE: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) commonly harbor oncogenic mutations of the KIT or platelet-derived growth factor alpha (PDGFRA) kinases, which are targets for imatinib.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: In clinical studies, 75% to 90% of patients with advanced GISTs experience clinical benefit from imatinib.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: However, imatinib resistance is an increasing clinical problem.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: One hundred forty-seven patients with advanced, unresectable GISTs were enrolled onto a randomized, phase II clinical study of imatinib.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Specimens from pretreatment and/or imatinib-resistant tumors were analyzed to identify molecular correlates of imatinib resistance.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Secondary kinase mutations of KIT or PDGFRA that were identified in imatinib-resistant GISTs were biochemically profiled for imatinib sensitivity.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: RESULTS: Molecular studies were performed using specimens from 10 patients with primary and 33 patients with secondary resistance.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Imatinib-resistant tumors had levels of activated KIT that were similar to or greater than those typically found in untreated GISTs.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Secondary kinase mutations were rare in GISTs with primary resistance but frequently found in GISTs with secondary resistance (10% v 67%; P = .002).
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Evidence for clonal evolution and/or polyclonal secondary kinase mutations was seen in three (18.8%) of 16 patients.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Secondary kinase mutations were nonrandomly distributed and were associated with decreased imatinib sensitivity compared with typical KIT exon 11 mutations.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: Using RNAi technology, we demonstrated that imatinib-resistant GIST cells remain dependent on KIT kinase activity for activation of critical downstream signaling pathways.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: CONCLUSION: Different molecular mechanisms are responsible for primary and secondary imatinib resistance in GISTs.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: These findings have implications for future approaches to the growing problem of imatinib resistance in patients with advanced GISTs.
title: Molecular correlates of imatinib resistance in gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: Outcome of pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) after cytoreductive surgery (CRS) and hypertermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) is heterogeneous even after adjusting for clinico-pathological prognostic variables.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: The identification of additional prognostic or even predictive biomarkers is an unmet clinical need.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Forty patients with mucinous appendiceal tumors and PMP were clinically eligible and had evaluable tumor samples obtained after CRS and HIPEC.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: We carried out next-generations sequencing (NGS) of 50 gene's hotspot regions contained in the Hotspot Cancer Panel v2 using the Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine platform (Life Technologies).
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: RESULTS: KRAS and GNAS mutations were found in 72% and 52%, and their allelic frequency was below 10% in 55% and 43% of samples, respectively.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: KRAS and GNAS mutations were associated with worse progression-free survival (PFS) at univariate analysis (P = 0.006 and 0.011, respectively).
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: At multivariate analysis, only KRAS mutations were independently associated with PFS (P = 0.012); GNAS mutations were not-being significantly associated with other poor prognostic features such as incomplete cytoreduction or KRAS mutations.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: Validation of results was carried out in an independent bi-institutional cohort of 25 patients and the prognostic effect of KRAS mutations was again confirmed in the multivariate model (P = 0.029).
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: NGS approach allowed the discovery of other potentially druggable mutations such as those in PI3K, AKT, LKB1, FGFR3 and PDGFRA.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Given the homogeneity of this series and the sensitivity of NGS in this low-cellularity tumor, we demonstrated for the first time a poor prognostic role of KRAS mutations.
title: Toward the molecular dissection of peritoneal pseudomyxoma.

text: Decitabine, a cancer therapeutic that inhibits DNA methylation, produces variable antitumor response rates in patients with solid tumors that might be leveraged clinically with identification of a predictive biomarker.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: In this study, we profiled the response of human ovarian, melanoma, and breast cancer cells treated with decitabine, finding that RAS/MEK/ERK pathway activation and DNMT1 expression correlated with cytotoxic activity.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: Further, we showed that KRAS genomic status predicted decitabine sensitivity in low-grade and high-grade serous ovarian cancer cells.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: Pretreatment with decitabine decreased the cytotoxic activity of MEK inhibitors in KRAS-mutant ovarian cancer cells, with reciprocal downregulation of DNMT1 and MEK/ERK phosphorylation.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: In parallel with these responses, decitabine also upregulated the proapoptotic BCL-2 family member BNIP3, which is known to be regulated by MEK and ERK, and heightened the activity of proapoptotic small-molecule navitoclax, a BCL-2 family inhibitor.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: In a xenograft model of KRAS-mutant ovarian cancer, combining decitabine and navitoclax heightened antitumor activity beyond administration of either compound alone.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: Our results define the RAS/MEK/DNMT1 pathway as a determinant of sensitivity to DNA methyltransferase inhibition, specifically implicating KRAS status as a biomarker of drug response in ovarian cancer.
title: KRAS Genomic Status Predicts the Sensitivity of Ovarian Cancer Cells to Decitabine.

text: Somatic mutations in the isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1) gene have been frequently found in low-grade glioma and secondary glioblastoma and are associated with a significantly younger age at diagnosis and a superior overall survival.
title: Correlation between IDH1 gene mutation status and survival of patients treated for recurrent glioma.

text: We investigated the IDH1 gene mutation status by nested PCR and denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) on DNA extracted from archival tumor blocks of 63 glioma patients who were treated following recurrence with the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-targeted blocking monoclonal antibody cetuximab, or the vascular endothelial growth factor (receptor) (VEGF(R))-targeted agents sunitinib malate and bevacizumab.
title: Correlation between IDH1 gene mutation status and survival of patients treated for recurrent glioma.

text: In our study population, IDH1 mutation was significantly correlated with a longer overall survival (OS) from the time of initial diagnosis.
title: Correlation between IDH1 gene mutation status and survival of patients treated for recurrent glioma.

text: Patients with IDH1 mutation also had a superior OS from the time of recurrence when treated with sunitinib or bevacizumab but a worse OS when treated with cetuximab.
title: Correlation between IDH1 gene mutation status and survival of patients treated for recurrent glioma.

text: Our observations support the hypothesis that IDH1 mutation may correlate with the benefit from VEGF(R)- versus EGFR-targeted therapy at the time of recurrence in glioma patients.
title: Correlation between IDH1 gene mutation status and survival of patients treated for recurrent glioma.

text: AIMS: To evaluate the usefulness of molecular markers in predicting histopathological and clinical response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy (HDCT) and survival of patients with advanced gastric cancer.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: METHODS: In a phase II trial, 25 patients with metastatic gastric cancer received preoperative tandem HDCT consisting of etoposide, cisplatin, and mitomycin, followed by autologous bone marrow transplantation to achieve surgical resectability.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: Samples before and after treatment, from normal and tumour tissue, were characterised histopathologically, and both p53 and BAX expression was analysed by immunohistochemistry.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: Pretreatment formalin fixed, paraffin wax embedded samples from normal and tumour tissue were microdissected, and the extracted DNA was preamplified using improved primer extension preamplification polymerase chain reaction.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: Detection of microsatellite instability (MSI) or loss of heterozygosity (LOH) was performed using markers for p53, BAX, BAT25, BAT26, D2S123, D17S250, and APC.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: Exons 5-9 of the p53 gene were sequenced directly on ABI 373.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: RESULTS: Four parameters were significantly associated with response to chemotherapy and prolonged overall survival: positive p53 immunostaining, positive p53 mutation status before chemotherapy, strong histological regression induced by preoperative HDCT, and surgical treatment.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: Patients's sex or age, tumour location or stage, lymph node status, Lauren classification, MSI, or LOH did not influence duration of survival significantly in this high risk population.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Positive p53 immunostaining and p53 mutation status in pretreatment tumour biopsies might be useful molecular predictors of response and prognosis in patients with advanced gastric cancer treated by preoperative HDCT.
title: Alterations in p53 predict response to preoperative high dose chemotherapy in patients with gastric cancer.

text: This report describes clinical characteristics in families with a Type 2A phenotype and functional properties of a novel von Hippel Lindau variant (X214L).
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: Pedigrees were analyzed.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: Analysis of von Hippel Lindau (VHL) coding exons and flanking intronic sequences in DNA from a proband with pheochromocytoma and islet cell tumor was performed.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: Western blot assays for VHL protein (pVHL), HIFalpha, and Jun B were conducted using VHL null renal clear carcinoma cell lines that were engineered to produce wild-type or X214L mutant pVHL.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: Pedigree analysis indicated that the variant tracked with disease and the same or similar VHL point mutations were identified in several Type 2A families.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: The predicted 14 amino acid extended pVHL variant, when reintroduced into VHL null cells, was stable and retained the ability to downregulate HIFalpha in a hydroxylationdependent manner.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: In contrast, the variant was defective with respect to downregulation of JunB.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: pVHL X214L, like other pVHL variants associated with a low risk of clear cell renal carcinoma, largely preserves the ability to downregulate HIF.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: In contrast, this variant, like other pVHL variants linked to Type 2A disease, fails to suppress JunB.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: This underscores that JunB may play a role in the pathogenesis of Type 2A VHL disease.
title: Clinical and functional properties of novel VHL mutation (X214L) consistent with Type 2A phenotype and low risk of renal cell carcinoma.

text: Small-molecule inhibitors of the CDK4/6 cell-cycle kinases have shown clinical efficacy in estrogen receptor (ER)-positive metastatic breast cancer, although their cytostatic effects are limited by primary and acquired resistance.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Here we report that ER-positive breast cancer cells can adapt quickly to CDK4/6 inhibition and evade cytostasis, in part, via noncanonical cyclin D1-CDK2-mediated S-phase entry.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: This adaptation was prevented by cotreatment with hormone therapies or PI3K inhibitors, which reduced the levels of cyclin D1 (CCND1) and other G1-S cyclins, abolished pRb phosphorylation, and inhibited activation of S-phase transcriptional programs.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Combined targeting of both CDK4/6 and PI3K triggered cancer cell apoptosis in vitro and in patient-derived tumor xenograft (PDX) models, resulting in tumor regression and improved disease control.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Furthermore, a triple combination of endocrine therapy, CDK4/6, and PI3K inhibition was more effective than paired combinations, provoking rapid tumor regressions in a PDX model.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Mechanistic investigations showed that acquired resistance to CDK4/6 inhibition resulted from bypass of cyclin D1-CDK4/6 dependency through selection of CCNE1 amplification or RB1 loss.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Notably, although PI3K inhibitors could prevent resistance to CDK4/6 inhibitors, they failed to resensitize cells once resistance had been acquired.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: However, we found that cells acquiring resistance to CDK4/6 inhibitors due to CCNE1 amplification could be resensitized by targeting CDK2.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Overall, our results illustrate convergent mechanisms of early adaptation and acquired resistance to CDK4/6 inhibitors that enable alternate means of S-phase entry, highlighting strategies to prevent the acquisition of therapeutic resistance to these agents.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.
Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: Early Adaptation and Acquired Resistance to CDK4/6 Inhibition in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Breast Cancer.

text: Somatic mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 and 2 (IDH1 and IDH2) were recently demonstrated in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), but their prevalence and prognostic impact remain to be explored in large extensively characterized AML series, and also in various other hematologic malignancies.
title: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value.

text: Here, we demonstrate in 893 newly diagnosed cases of AML mutations in the IDH1 (6%) and IDH2 (11%) genes.
title: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value.

text: Moreover, we identified IDH mutations in 2 JAK2 V617F myeloproliferative neoplasias (n = 96), a single case of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (n = 96), and none in chronic myeloid leukemias (n = 81).
title: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value.

text: In AML, IDH1 and IDH2 mutations are more common among AML with normal karyotype and NPM1(mutant) genotypes.
title: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value.

text: IDH1 mutation status is an unfavorable prognostic factor as regards survival in a composite genotypic subset lacking FLT3(ITD) and NPM1(mutant).
title: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value.

text: Thus, IDH1 and IDH2 mutations are common genetic aberrations in AML, and IDH1 mutations may carry prognostic value in distinct subtypes of AML.
title: Acquired mutations in the genes encoding IDH1 and IDH2 both are recurrent aberrations in acute myeloid leukemia: prevalence and prognostic value.

text: De novo lipogenesis is activated in most cancers.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase (ACLY), the enzyme that catalyzes the first step of de novo lipogenesis, leads to growth suppression and apoptosis in a subset of human cancer cells.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Herein, we found that ACLY depletion increases the level of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS), whereas addition of an antioxidant reduced ROS and attenuated the anticancer effect.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: ACLY depletion or exogenous hydrogen peroxide induces phosphorylation of AMP-activated protein kinase (p-AMPK), a crucial regulator of lipid metabolism, independently of energy status.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Analysis of various cancer cell lines revealed that cancer cells with a higher susceptibility to ACLY depletion have lower levels of basal ROS and p-AMPK.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Mitochondrial-deficient rho(0) cells retained high levels of ROS and p-AMPK and were resistant to ACLY depletion, whereas the replenishment of normal mitochondrial DNA reduced the levels of ROS and p-AMPK and restored the sensitivity to ACLY depletion, indicating that low basal levels of mitochondrial ROS are critical for the anticancer effect of ACLY depletion.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Finally, p-AMPK levels were significantly correlated to the levels of oxidative DNA damage in colon cancer tissues, suggesting that p-AMPK reflects cellular ROS levels in vitro and in vivo.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Together, these data suggest that ACLY inhibition exerts an anticancer effect via increased ROS, and p-AMPK could be a predictive biomarker for its therapeutic outcome.
title: Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase induces an anticancer effect via reactive oxygen species: AMPK as a predictive biomarker for therapeutic impact.

text: Accumulated evidence indicates that rare variants exert a vital role on predisposition and progression of human diseases, which provides neoteric insights into disease etiology.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: In the current study, based on three independently retrospective studies of 5,016 lung cancer patients and 5,181 controls, we analyzed the associations between five rare polymorphisms (i.e., p.Glu116Lys, p.Asn118Ser, p.Arg138Cys, p.Ala195Thr and p.Leu259Phe) in MKK7 and lung cancer risk and prognosis.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: To decipher the precise mechanisms of MKK7 rare variants on lung cancer, a series of biological experiments was further performed.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: We found that the MKK7 p.Glu116Lys rare polymorphism was significantly associated with lung cancer risk, progression and prognosis.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: Compared with Glu/Glu common genotype, the 116Lys rare variants (Lys/Glu/+ Lys/Lys) presented an adverse effect on lung cancer susceptibility (odds ratio [OR] = 3.29, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 2.70-4.01).
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: These rare variants strengthened patients' clinical progression that patients with 116Lys variants had a significantly higher metastasis rate and advanced N, M stages at diagnosis.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: In addition, the patients with 116Lys variants also contributed to worse cancer prognosis than those carriers with Glu/Glu genotype (hazard ratio [HR] = 1.53, 95% CI = 1.32-1.78).
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: Functional experiments further verified that the MKK7 p.116Lys variants altered the expression of several cancer-related genes and thus affected lung cancer cells proliferation, tumor growth and metastasis in vivo and in vitro.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: Taken together, our findings proposed that the MKK7 p.Glu116Lys rare polymorphism incurred a pernicious impact on lung cancer risk and prognosis through modulating expressions of a serial of cancer-related genes.
title: The MKK7 p.Glu116Lys Rare Variant Serves as a Predictor for Lung Cancer Risk and Prognosis in Chinese.

text: We aimed to analyze clinical impacts of the U2AF1 mutation on patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and its stability during disease progression.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: We checked mutation status of the U2AF1 by direct sequencing in 478 de novo MDS patients and correlated with the clinical characteristics and outcomes.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: We also sequentially analyzed the U2AF1 mutation in 421 samples from 142 patients to determine its stability during the disease courses.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: Thirty-six patients (7.5%) were found to have U2AF1 mutations, which occurred more frequently in younger patients (P = 0.033).
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: U2AF1 mutation was an independent poor-risk factor for overall survival (OS) in all patients (P = 0.030) and younger patients (P = 0.041).
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: U2AF1 mutation could also predict shorter time-to-leukemia transformation (TTL) in younger patients (P = 0.020).
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: In addition, U2AF1 mutation was associated with shorter TTL in lower-risk MDS patients.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: Sequential analyses showed all original U2AF1 mutations in U2AF1-mutated patients were retained during follow-ups unless complete remission was achieved, whereas none of the U2AF1-wild patients acquired a novel mutation during disease evolution.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: U2AF1 mutation is more prevalent in younger MDS patients and associated with inferior outcomes although it is stable during the clinical course.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: The mutation may be used as a biomarker for risk stratification.
title: Clinical implications of U2AF1 mutation in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and its stability during disease progression.

text: BACKGROUND: Treatment with cetuximab, a monoclonal antibody directed against the epidermal growth factor receptor, improves overall and progression-free survival and preserves the quality of life in patients with colorectal cancer that has not responded to chemotherapy.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: The mutation status of the K-ras gene in the tumor may affect the response to cetuximab and have treatment-independent prognostic value.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: We analyzed tumor samples, obtained from 394 of 572 patients (68.9%) with colorectal cancer who were randomly assigned to receive cetuximab plus best supportive care or best supportive care alone, to look for activating mutations in exon 2 of the K-ras gene.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: We assessed whether the mutation status of the K-ras gene was associated with survival in the cetuximab and supportive-care groups.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Of the tumors evaluated for K-ras mutations, 42.3% had at least one mutation in exon 2 of the gene.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: The effectiveness of cetuximab was significantly associated with K-ras mutation status (P=0.01 and P<0.001 for the interaction of K-ras mutation status with overall survival and progression-free survival, respectively).
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: In patients with wild-type K-ras tumors, treatment with cetuximab as compared with supportive care alone significantly improved overall survival (median, 9.5 vs. 4.8 months; hazard ratio for death, 0.55; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.41 to 0.74; P<0.001) and progression-free survival (median, 3.7 months vs. 1.9 months; hazard ratio for progression or death, 0.40; 95% CI, 0.30 to 0.54; P<0.001).
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: Among patients with mutated K-ras tumors, there was no significant difference between those who were treated with cetuximab and those who received supportive care alone with respect to overall survival (hazard ratio, 0.98; P=0.89) or progression-free survival (hazard ratio, 0.99; P=0.96).
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: In the group of patients receiving best supportive care alone, the mutation status of the K-ras gene was not significantly associated with overall survival (hazard ratio for death, 1.01; P=0.97).
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Patients with a colorectal tumor bearing mutated K-ras did not benefit from cetuximab, whereas patients with a tumor bearing wild-type K-ras did benefit from cetuximab.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: The mutation status of the K-ras gene had no influence on survival among patients treated with best supportive care alone.
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00079066.)
title: K-ras mutations and benefit from cetuximab in advanced colorectal cancer.

text: The majority of uveal melanomas carry oncogenic mutations in the G proteins GNAQ and GNA11, with consequent activation of the MAPK pathway.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: Selective MEK inhibitors, such as selumetinib, have shown clinical benefit in uveal melanoma.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: However, mechanisms of drug resistance limit their efficacy in some patients.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: Analysis of MEK inhibitor-resistant uveal melanoma cell lines revealed the induction of RAS protein expression and activity.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: This effect was mediated by the RNA helicase DDX43, which was remarkably overexpressed in these cells.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: Depletion of DDX43 in MEK inhibitor-resistant cells decreased RAS proteins and inhibited ERK and AKT pathways.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: On the contrary, ectopic expression of DDX43 in parental uveal melanoma cells induced RAS protein levels and rendered cells resistant to MEK inhibition.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: Similar to DDX43 depletion, downregulation of KRAS, HRAS, and NRAS inhibited downstream pathways in the resistant cells, overcoming mutant GNAQ signaling.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: We also analyzed the expression of DDX43 in liver metastases of patients with uveal melanoma by RT-PCR, and found a significant overexpression of DDX43 in patients who did not benefit from selumetinib therapy.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: In conclusion, DDX43 induces RAS protein expression and signaling, mediating a novel mechanism of MEK inhibitor resistance.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: The detection of DDX43 in patients with uveal melanoma could lead to more targeted therapies for this disease.
title: Overexpression of DDX43 mediates MEK inhibitor resistance through RAS Upregulation in uveal melanoma cells.

text: BACKGROUND: Human pancreatic adenocarcinomas are highly resistant to chemotherapy.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: The p16 tumor-suppressor protein is inactivated in more than 90% of human pancreatic cancers.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: The p16 protein transcriptionally inhibits expression of retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene pRB.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: The pRB protein transcriptionally inhibits expression of the p16 gene.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: Because pRB normally prevents apoptosis, we investigated whether pRB is involved in resistance to chemotherapy-induced apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: METHODS: pRB expression was examined by immunohistochemistry in 106 human pancreatic tissue specimens.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: The human pancreatic tumor cell line Capan-1 (pRB+/p16-) was stably transfected with p16 to functionally inactivate pRB.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: pRB gene expression was examined by western and northern blot analyses, and pRB function was assessed by electrophoretic mobility shift assays and promoter transactivation studies for the transcription factor E2F.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: Changes in cell sensitivity to chemotherapy were measured by assays for cytotoxicity and apoptosis.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: RESULTS: pRB was overexpressed in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas but was hardly detectable in other pancreatic malignancies, chronic pancreatitis, or nontransformed human pancreatic tissue.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: Expression of p16 in Capan-1 cells resulted in the loss of pRB gene and protein expression concomitant with increased activity of the transcription factor E2F, which was not detected in wild-type or control-transfected Capan-1 cells.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: Wild-type and control-transfected Capan-1 cells were resistant to chemotherapy-induced apoptosis, but pRB-depleted (i.e., p16-transfected) Capan-1 cells were highly sensitive.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: The effect was specific to pRB depletion because two other human pancreatic cancer cell lines that retained high pRB expression after p16 transfection were resistant to chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Overexpression of pRB is associated with human pancreatic duct-cell cancer and may allow pancreatic cancer cells to evade chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.
title: Overexpression of pRB in human pancreatic carcinoma cells: function in chemotherapy-induced apoptosis.

text: Myeloproliferative neoplasms are clonal disorders characterized by the presence of several gene mutations associated with particular hematologic parameters, clinical evolution, and prognosis.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: Few therapeutic options are available, among which interferon alpha (IFNalpha) presents interesting properties like the ability to induce hematologic responses (HRs) and molecular responses (MRs) in patients with JAK2 mutation.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: We report on the response to IFNalpha therapy in a cohort of 31 essential thrombocythemia (ET) patients with CALR mutations (mean follow-up of 11.8 years).
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: HR was achieved in all patients.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: Median CALR mutant allelic burden (%CALR) significantly decreased from 41% at baseline to 26% after treatment, and 2 patients even achieved complete MR.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: In contrast, %CALR was not significantly modified in ET patients treated with hydroxyurea or aspirin only.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: Next-generation sequencing identified additional mutations in 6 patients (affecting TET2, ASXL1, IDH2, and TP53 genes).
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: The presence of additional mutations was associated with poorer MR on CALR mutant clones, with only minor or no MRs in this subset of patients.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: Analysis of the evolution of the different variant allele frequencies showed that the mutated clones had a differential sensitivity to IFNalpha in a given patient, but no new mutation emerged during treatment.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: In all, this study shows that IFNalpha induces high rates of HRs and MRs in CALR-mutated ET, and that the presence of additional nondriver mutations may influence the MR to therapy.
title: Clinical and molecular response to interferon-alpha therapy in essential thrombocythemia patients with CALR mutations.

text: ETS gene fusions involving ERG, ETV1, ETV4, ETV5, and FLI1 define a distinct class of prostate cancer (PCa), and this might have a bearing on diagnosis, prognosis, and rational therapeutic targeting.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: In the current study, we focused on the clinicopathological significance of ETV4 in Chinese PCa patients and the mechanisms whereby ETV4 overexpression mediates tumor invasion in the prostate.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Overall, ETV4 overexpression was identified in 30.4 % (45/148) of PCa cases by immunohistochemistry.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Accordingly, ETV4 was rearranged in only 1.6 % (2/128) of PCa patients.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Clinically, ETV4 overexpression was significantly correlated with Gleason score (P = 0.045) and pathological tumor stage (P = 0.041).
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Multivariate Cox regression analysis indicated that ETV4 is an unfavorable independent prognostic factor (P = 0.040).
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Functional studies further showed that small interfering RNA (siRNA) knockdown of ETV4 significantly decreases proliferation and invasion of PC-3 cell and partially reverses epithelial-mesenchymal transition in vitro.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Notably, ETV4 knockdown significantly downregulated expression of urokinase plasminogen activator (uPA) and its receptor (uPAR) at messenger RNA (mRNA) and protein levels.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Chromatin immunoprecipitation assay demonstrated that ETV4 regulates uPA expression through direct binding to its promoter region.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Additionally, ETV4 knockdown was also observed to significantly inhibit expression of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-2 and MMP-9.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: In conclusion, for the first time, our study suggested that ETV4 is an independent poor prognostic factor in Chinese PCa patients.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Silencing of ETV4 suppresses invasion of PCa cells by inhibiting the expression of uPA/uPAR as well as MMPs.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: Further studies will be needed to determine whether ETV4 could be regarded as a potential target for the management and prevention of PCa.
title: Overexpression of ETV4 is associated with poor prognosis in prostate cancer: involvement of uPA/uPAR and MMPs.

text: A main limitation of therapies that selectively target kinase signalling pathways is the emergence of secondary drug resistance.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: Cetuximab, a monoclonal antibody that binds the extracellular domain of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), is effective in a subset of KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancers.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: After an initial response, secondary resistance invariably ensues, thereby limiting the clinical benefit of this drug.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: The molecular bases of secondary resistance to cetuximab in colorectal cancer are poorly understood.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: Here we show that molecular alterations (in most instances point mutations) of KRAS are causally associated with the onset of acquired resistance to anti-EGFR treatment in colorectal cancers.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: Expression of mutant KRAS under the control of its endogenous gene promoter was sufficient to confer cetuximab resistance, but resistant cells remained sensitive to combinatorial inhibition of EGFR and mitogen-activated protein-kinase kinase (MEK).
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: Analysis of metastases from patients who developed resistance to cetuximab or panitumumab showed the emergence of KRAS amplification in one sample and acquisition of secondary KRAS mutations in 60% (6 out of 10) of the cases.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: KRAS mutant alleles were detectable in the blood of cetuximab-treated patients as early as 10 months before radiographic documentation of disease progression.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: In summary, the results identify KRAS mutations as frequent drivers of acquired resistance to cetuximab in colorectal cancers, indicate that the emergence of KRAS mutant clones can be detected non-invasively months before radiographic progression and suggest early initiation of a MEK inhibitor as a rational strategy for delaying or reversing drug resistance.
title: Emergence of KRAS mutations and acquired resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

text: BRAF inhibitors elicit rapid antitumor responses in the majority of patients with BRAF(V600)-mutant melanoma, but acquired drug resistance is almost universal.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: We sought to identify the core resistance pathways and the extent of tumor heterogeneity during disease progression.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: We show that mitogen-activated protein kinase reactivation mechanisms were detected among 70% of disease-progressive tissues, with RAS mutations, mutant BRAF amplification, and alternative splicing being most common.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: We also detected PI3K-PTEN-AKT-upregulating genetic alterations among 22% of progressive melanomas.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: Distinct molecular lesions in both core drug escape pathways were commonly detected concurrently in the same tumor or among multiple tumors from the same patient.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: Beyond harboring extensively heterogeneous resistance mechanisms, melanoma regrowth emerging from BRAF inhibitor selection displayed branched evolution marked by altered mutational spectra/signatures and increased fitness.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: Thus, melanoma genomic heterogeneity contributes significantly to BRAF inhibitor treatment failure, implying upfront, cotargeting of two core pathways as an essential strategy for durable responses.
title: Acquired resistance and clonal evolution in melanoma during BRAF inhibitor therapy.

text: Midostaurin was recently approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of FLT3-mutant acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Midostaurin approved for FLT3-mutated AML.

text: This is the first drug to receive regulatory approval for AML in the United States since the year 2000.
title: Midostaurin approved for FLT3-mutated AML.

text: Midostaurin is a small-molecule kinase inhibitor with activity against the receptor tyrosine kinase FLT3, and its approval will hopefully mark the beginning of an era of targeted agents for the treatment of molecularly defined subtypes of AML.
title: Midostaurin approved for FLT3-mutated AML.

text: HER2 is reported to be overexpressed in 20% of cases of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), principally adenocarcinoma.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against HER2 that, when combined with a taxane, improves survival compared with chemotherapy alone in advanced breast cancer.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: In view of these observations, we conducted a phase II HER2 screening and efficacy trial of trastuzumab plus weekly docetaxel in cases of advanced NSCLC in which primary platinum-based therapy had failed.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Patients with advanced or metastatic NSCLC were screened for HER2 overexpression by immunohistochemistry.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Patients with HER2-positive tumors (2+ or 3+) were initially randomized to either single-agent trastuzumab or docetaxel.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: After completing 2 treatment cycles, all patients went on to receive the trastuzumab/docetaxel combination regardless of response to the single agents.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Treatment consisted of docetaxel 30 mg/m2 weekly for 6 weeks followed by a 2-week break and trastuzumab 4 mg/kg intravenously on week 1 followed by 2 mg/kg per week thereafter.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Cycle length was 8 weeks.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Sixty-nine patients with NSCLC (33 men, 36 women) were screened between August 1999 and March 2001.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Only 13 patients (19%) had HER2-positive disease; all 13 enrolled in the efficacy trial.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Of 9 patients receiving docetaxel alone, 1 partial response (PR) was seen.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: None responded to trastuzumab alone.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: The overall outcomes to the sequence of single-agent therapy followed by combination therapy included a PR rate in 8% of cases, stable disease in 23%, progression in 46%, and nonassessable disease in 23%.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Estimated event-free and overall survival times were 4.3 and 5.7 months, respectively.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Treatment was well tolerated.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: The screening component of this trial demonstrated that the target population for trastuzumab therapy in NSCLC is relatively small.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Because of the limited clinical activity of trastuzumab-based therapy in this cohort and the similar disappointing reports from other studies of trastuzumab in NSCLC, this trial was closed to further accrual.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: In view of the limited target population for HER2 inhibition, future efforts and resources should be directed toward molecular targets other than HER2 in NSCLC.
title: Trastuzumab plus docetaxel in HER2/neu-positive non-small-cell lung cancer: a California Cancer Consortium screening and phase II trial.

text: Because oncogene MET and EGF receptor (EGFR) inhibitors are in clinical development against several types of cancer, including glioblastoma, it is important to identify predictive markers that indicate patient subgroups suitable for such therapies.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: We investigated in vivo glioblastoma models characterized by hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine or paracrine activation, or by MET or EGFR amplification, for their susceptibility to MET inhibitors.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: HGF autocrine expression correlated with high phospho-MET levels in HGF autocrine cell lines, and these lines showed high sensitivity to MET inhibition in vivo.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: An HGF paracrine environment may enhance glioblastoma growth in vivo but did not indicate sensitivity to MET inhibition.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: EGFRvIII amplification predicted sensitivity to EGFR inhibition, but in the same tumor, increased copies of MET from gains of chromosome 7 did not result in increased MET activity and did not predict sensitivity to MET inhibitors.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: Thus, HGF autocrine glioblastoma bears an activated MET signaling pathway that may predict sensitivity to MET inhibitors.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: Moreover, serum HGF levels may serve as a biomarker for the presence of autocrine tumors and their responsiveness to MET therapeutics.
title: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) autocrine activation predicts sensitivity to MET inhibition in glioblastoma.

text: Peritoneal mesothelioma is a rare and sometimes lethal malignancy that presents a clinical challenge for both diagnosis and management.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Recent studies have led to a better understanding of the molecular biology of peritoneal mesothelioma.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Translation of the emerging data into better treatments and outcome is needed.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: From two patients with peritoneal mesothelioma, we derived whole genome sequences, RNA expression profiles, and targeted deep sequencing data.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Molecular data were made available for translation into a clinical treatment plan.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Treatment responses and outcomes were later examined in the context of molecular findings.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Molecular studies presented here provide the first reported whole genome sequences of peritoneal mesothelioma.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Mutations in known mesothelioma-related genes NF2, CDKN2A, LATS2, amongst others, were identified.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: Activation of MET-related signaling pathways was demonstrated in both cases.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: A hypermutated phenotype was observed in one case (434 vs. 18 single nucleotide variants) and was associated with a favourable outcome despite sarcomatoid histology and multifocal disease.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: This study represents the first report of whole genome analyses of peritoneal mesothelioma, a key step in the understanding and treatment of this disease.
title: Personalized oncogenomics: clinical experience with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma using whole genome sequencing.

text: OBJECTIVE: A difference in survival rates between black and white patients with cancer of the corpus uteri is well established.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: This study was conducted to determine whether the overexpression of HER2/neu oncogene is associated with poor outcome in uterine serous papillary endometrial cancer, which is a highly aggressive variant of endometrial cancer, and whether a racial difference in the frequency of HER2/neu overexpression may contribute to the disparity in endometrial cancer survival.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: STUDY DESIGN: Immunohistochemical evaluation was used to examine HER2/neu expression in paraffin blocks from 27 women with stage IA to IV uterine serous papillary endometrial cancer.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: Univariable analysis was performed and followed by multivariable analysis with Cox's proportional hazard model to evaluate whether HER2/neu expression was associated with poor outcome in uterine serous papillary endometrial cancer.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: RESULTS: Black patients tended to be younger (P = .02) and have higher HER2/neu expression than white patients (trend P = .02).
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: Seven of 10 black patients (70%) showed heavy (3+) expression, compared with 4 of 17 white patients (24%; P = .04).
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: The association of heavy HER2/neu expression with race persisted after age was controlled through stratification (P = .05).
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: Earlier deaths from uterine serous papillary endometrial cancer were seen among heavy HER2/neu expressers (P = .002), black patients (P = .04), and patients < or = 65 years old (P = .04).
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: However, multivariate Cox regression showed that short survival was associated significantly with heavy HER2/neu expression (P = .02) but not with age (P = .07) or race (P = .35), which indicates that HER2/neu expression accounted for much of the race disparity in survival in this patient population.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Overexpression of HER2/neu in uterine serous papillary endometrial cancer is an independent variable that is associated with poor outcome, occurs more frequently in black women, and may contribute to racial disparity in survival.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: HER2/neu expression may guide clinical treatment of patients with uterine serous papillary endometrial cancer and may have implications for the implementation of novel treatment strategies.
title: Racial differences in the overexpression of epidermal growth factor type II receptor (HER2/neu): a major prognostic indicator in uterine serous papillary cancer.

text: Recurrent chromosomal rearrangements have not been well characterized in common carcinomas.
title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: We used a bioinformatics approach to discover candidate oncogenic chromosomal aberrations on the basis of outlier gene expression.
