title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: Two ETS transcription factors, ERG and ETV1, were identified as outliers in prostate cancer.
title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: We identified recurrent gene fusions of the 5' untranslated region of TMPRSS2 to ERG or ETV1 in prostate cancer tissues with outlier expression.
title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: By using fluorescence in situ hybridization, we demonstrated that 23 of 29 prostate cancer samples harbor rearrangements in ERG or ETV1.
title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: Cell line experiments suggest that the androgen-responsive promoter elements of TMPRSS2 mediate the overexpression of ETS family members in prostate cancer.
title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: These results have implications in the development of carcinomas and the molecular diagnosis and treatment of prostate cancer.
title: Recurrent fusion of TMPRSS2 and ETS transcription factor genes in prostate cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: The EGFR T790M mutation is the most common mechanism of drug resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients who have lung cancer with an EGFR mutation (EGFR-mutated lung cancer).
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In preclinical models, the EGFR inhibitor AZD9291 has been shown to be effective against both EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor-sensitizing and T790M resistance mutations.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: We administered AZD9291 at doses of 20 to 240 mg once daily in patients with advanced lung cancer who had radiologically documented disease progression after previous treatment with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The study included dose-escalation cohorts and dose-expansion cohorts.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In the expansion cohorts, prestudy tumor biopsies were required for central determination of EGFR T790M status.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Patients were assessed for safety, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: A total of 253 patients were treated.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among 31 patients enrolled in the dose-escalation cohorts, no dose-limiting toxic effects occurred at the doses evaluated.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: An additional 222 patients were treated in five expansion cohorts.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The most common all-cause adverse events were diarrhea, rash, nausea, and decreased appetite.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The overall objective tumor response rate was 51% (95% confidence interval [CI], 45 to 58).
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Among 127 patients with centrally confirmed EGFR T790M who could be evaluated for response, the response rate was 61% (95% CI, 52 to 70).
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In contrast, among 61 patients without centrally detectable EGFR T790M who could be evaluated for response, the response rate was 21% (95% CI, 12 to 34).
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The median progression-free survival was 9.6 months (95% CI, 8.3 to not reached) in EGFR T790M-positive patients and 2.8 months (95% CI, 2.1 to 4.3) in EGFR T790M-negative patients.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: AZD9291 was highly active in patients with lung cancer with the EGFR T790M mutation who had had disease progression during prior therapy with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: (Funded by AstraZeneca; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01802632.
title: AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.
AZD9291 in EGFR inhibitor-resistant non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Oncogenic BRAF and NRAS mutations are frequent in malignant melanoma.
title: BRAF and NRAS mutations in melanoma: potential relationships to clinical response to HSP90 inhibitors.

text: BRAF that is activated by the common V600E and other mutations, as well as by upstream NRAS mutations, has been shown to require the molecular chaperone heat shock protein 90 (HSP90) for stabilization and is depleted by the HSP90 inhibitor 17-allylamino-17-demethoxygeldanamycin (17-AAG)].
title: BRAF and NRAS mutations in melanoma: potential relationships to clinical response to HSP90 inhibitors.

text: Here, we explore the possible relationship between tumor BRAF and NRAS mutations and clinical response to 17-AAG in six patients with metastatic malignant melanoma who received pharmacologically active doses of 17-AAG as part of a phase I clinical trial.
title: BRAF and NRAS mutations in melanoma: potential relationships to clinical response to HSP90 inhibitors.

text: One patient with disease stabilization for 49 months had a (G13D)NRAS mutation and (WT)BRAF.
title: BRAF and NRAS mutations in melanoma: potential relationships to clinical response to HSP90 inhibitors.

text: A second patient who had stable disease for 15 months had a (V600E)BRAF mutation and (WT)NRAS.
title: BRAF and NRAS mutations in melanoma: potential relationships to clinical response to HSP90 inhibitors.

text: These preliminary results suggest that BRAF and NRAS mutation status should be determined in prospective phase II studies of HSP90 inhibitors in melanoma.
title: BRAF and NRAS mutations in melanoma: potential relationships to clinical response to HSP90 inhibitors.

text: Mutations in the HER2 kinase domain have been identified in human clinical lung cancer specimens.
title: HER2YVMA drives rapid development of adenosquamous lung tumors in mice that are sensitive to BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination therapy.

text: Here we demonstrate that inducible expression of the most common HER2 mutant (HER2(YVMA)) in mouse lung epithelium causes invasive adenosquamous carcinomas restricted to proximal and distal bronchioles.
title: HER2YVMA drives rapid development of adenosquamous lung tumors in mice that are sensitive to BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination therapy.

text: Continuous expression of HER2(YVMA) is essential for tumor maintenance, suggesting a key role for HER2 in lung adenosquamous tumorigenesis.
title: HER2YVMA drives rapid development of adenosquamous lung tumors in mice that are sensitive to BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination therapy.

text: Preclinical studies assessing the in vivo effect of erlotinib, trastuzumab, BIBW2992, and/or rapamycin on HER2(YVMA) transgenic mice or H1781 xenografts with documented tumor burden revealed that the combination of BIBW2992 and rapamycin is the most effective treatment paradigm causing significant tumor shrinkage.
title: HER2YVMA drives rapid development of adenosquamous lung tumors in mice that are sensitive to BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination therapy.

text: Immunohistochemical analysis of lung tumors treated with BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination revealed decreased phosphorylation levels for proteins in both upstream and downstream arms of MAPK and Akt/mTOR signaling axes, indicating inhibition of these pathways.
title: HER2YVMA drives rapid development of adenosquamous lung tumors in mice that are sensitive to BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination therapy.

text: Based on these findings, clinical testing of the BIBW2992/rapamycin combination in non-small cell lung cancer patients with tumors expressing HER2 mutations is warranted.
title: HER2YVMA drives rapid development of adenosquamous lung tumors in mice that are sensitive to BIBW2992 and rapamycin combination therapy.

text: PURPOSE: Recurrent "driver" mutations at specific loci in BRAF, NRAS, KIT, GNAQ, and GNA11 define clinically relevant molecular subsets of melanoma, but more than 30% are "pan-negative" for these recurrent mutations.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: We sought to identify additional potential drivers in "pan-negative" melanoma.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Using a targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) assay (FoundationOne) and targeted RNA sequencing, we identified a novel PAPSS1-BRAF fusion in a "pan-negative" melanoma.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: We then analyzed NGS data from 51 additional melanomas genotyped by FoundationOne, as well as melanoma RNA, whole-genome and whole-exome sequencing data in The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), to determine the potential frequency of BRAF fusions in melanoma.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: We characterized the signaling properties of confirmed molecular alterations by ectopic expression of engineered cDNAs in 293H cells.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: RESULTS: Activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway in cells by ectopic expression of PAPSS1-BRAF was abrogated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase (MEK) inhibition but not by BRAF inhibition.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: NGS data analysis of 51 additional melanomas revealed a second BRAF fusion (TRIM24-BRAF) in a "pan-negative" sample; MAPK signaling induced by TRIM24-BRAF was also MEK inhibitor sensitive.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: Through mining TCGA skin cutaneous melanoma dataset, we further identified two potential BRAF fusions in another 49 "pan-negative" cases.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: CONCLUSIONS: BRAF fusions define a new molecular subset of melanoma, potentially comprising 4% to 8% of "pan-negative" cases.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: Their presence may explain an unexpected clinical response to MEK inhibitor therapy or assist in selecting patients for MEK-directed therapy.
title: BRAF fusions define a distinct molecular subset of melanomas with potential sensitivity to MEK inhibition.

text: CONTEXT: Germline loss-of-function phosphatase and tensin homolog gene (PTEN) mutations cause 80% of Cowden syndrome, a rare autosomal-dominant disorder (1 in 200,000 live births), characterized by high risks of breast, thyroid, and other cancers.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: A large heterogeneous group of individuals with Cowden-like syndrome, who have various combinations of Cowden syndrome features but who do not meet Cowden syndrome diagnostic criteria, have PTEN mutations less than 10% of the time, making molecular diagnosis, prediction, genetic counseling, and risk management challenging.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: Other mechanisms of loss of function such as hypermethylation, which should result in underexpression of PTEN or of KILLIN, a novel tumor suppressor transcribed in the opposite direction, may account for the remainder of Cowden syndrome and Cowden-like syndrome.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether germline methylation is found in Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome in individuals lacking germline PTEN mutations.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Nucleic acids from prospective nested series of 123 patients with Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome and 50 unaffected individuals without PTEN variants were analyzed for germline methylation and expression of PTEN and KILLIN at the Cleveland Clinic, August 2008-June 2010.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: Prevalence of component cancers between groups was compared using the Fisher exact test.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Frequency of germline methylation in PTEN mutation-negative Cowden syndrome and Cowden syndrome-like individuals.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: Prevalence of component cancers in methylation-positive and PTEN mutation-positive individuals.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: RESULTS: Of 123 patients with Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome, 45 (37%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 29%-45%) showed hypermethylation upstream of PTEN but no transcriptional repression.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: The germline methylation was found to transcriptionally down-regulate KILLIN by 250-fold (95% CI, 45-14 286; P = .007) and exclusively disrupted TP53 activation of KILLIN by 30% (95% CI, 7%-45%; P = .008).
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: Demethylation treatment increased only KILLIN expression 4.88-fold (95% CI, 1.4-18.1; P = .05).
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: Individuals with KILLIN -promoter methylation had a 3-fold increased prevalence of breast cancer (35/42 vs 24/64; P < .0001) and a greater than 2-fold increase of kidney cancer (4/45 vs 6/155; P = .004) over individuals with germline PTEN mutations.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Germline KILLIN methylation is common among patients with Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome and is associated with increased risks of breast and renal cancer over PTEN mutation-positive individuals.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: These observations need to be replicated.
title: Germline epigenetic regulation of KILLIN in Cowden and Cowden-like syndrome.

text: Purpose We previously reported the phase I dose escalation study of buparlisib, a pan-class 1A PI3K inhibitor, combined with platinum/taxane-based chemotherapy in patients with advanced solid tumors.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: The combination was well tolerated and promising preliminary efficacy was observed in PTEN deficient tumors.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: This phase I dose expansion study now evaluates buparlisib plus high dose carboplatin and paclitaxel in unselected patients with advanced solid tumors and buparlisib plus standard dose carboplatin and paclitaxel in patients with PTEN deficient tumors (ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01297452).
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Methods There were two expansion cohorts: Cohort A received continuous buparlisib (100 mg/daily) orally plus high dose carboplatin AUC 6 and paclitaxel 200 mg/m2; Cohort B treated patients with PTEN deficient tumors only and they received the recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of continuous buparlisib (100 mg/daily) orally plus standard dose carboplatin AUC 5 and paclitaxel 175 mg/m2.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Both cohorts received chemotherapy intravenously on day 1 of the 21-day cycle with pegfilgrastim support.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Primary endpoint in Cohort A was to evaluate the safety and tolerability of chemotherapy dose intensification with buparlisib and in Cohort B was to describe preliminary efficacy of the combination among patients with tumors harboring a PTEN mutation or homozygous deletion.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Results 14 subjects were enrolled, 7 in Cohort A and 7 in Cohort B.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Dose reductions were required in 5 (71%) and 3 (43%) patients, in cohort A and B respectively.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Grade 3 adverse events in Cohort A included lymphopenia (n = 5 [71%]), hyperglycemia (n = 2, [29%]), diarrhea (n = 2, [29%]) and rash (n = 2, [29%]) and in cohort B included lymphopenia (n = 5 [71%]), hyperglycemia (n = 4 [57%]) and neutropenia (n = 2 [29%].
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: The mean number of cycles on protocol was 6.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: The overall objective response rate was 14% (2 /14).
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: No objective responses were observed in the PTEN deficient cohort.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Four out of 6 patients with stable disease (SD) had SD or better for >/=6 cycles, 2 of which had PTEN deficient tumors.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: Conclusion The addition of buparlisib to high dose carboplatin and paclitaxel was not tolerable.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: The combination did not reveal significant clinical activity amongst a small and heterogenous group of PTEN deficient tumors.
title: A phase 1b dose expansion study of the pan-class I PI3K inhibitor buparlisib (BKM120) plus carboplatin and paclitaxel in PTEN deficient tumors and with dose intensified carboplatin and paclitaxel.

text: BACKGROUND: KIF23 (kinesin family member 23) is a kinesin-like motor protein and plays an important role in cytokinesis.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: In search for genes associated with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) by cDNA microarray, we found that KIF23 was upregulated in HCC tissues.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: At present, much less is known about its expression and functions in tumor cells.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: In this work, we aimed to investigate the expression of KIF23 in HCC and the correlation between its expression and clinical features.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: METHODS: Total RNA was extracted from 16 HCC and paired adjacent non-cancerous tissues.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: The expressions of the two KIF23 splice variants (KIF23 V1 and KIF23 V2) in normal and HCC tissues were determined by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Polyclonal antibody specific to KIF23 V1 was prepared, and the specificity of the antibody was confirmed by siRNA knockdown and Western blotting experiments.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: KIF23 protein expression in HCC was examined by immunohistochemistry staining with anti-KIF23 V1 or anti-KIF23 (commercially available for recognizing both KIF23 V1 and V2) antibodies, respectively.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Univariate and Multivariate Cox regression analyses were used to determine the correlation between KIF23 protein expression and overall survival of HCC patients.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: The two splicing variants of KIF23 mRNA were not detected in normal liver tissue by RT-PCR, but they were aberrantly expressed in HCC tissues.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Immunohistochemistry staining with anti-KIF23 V1 antibody revealed that KIF23 V1 was mainly distributed in the nucleus, whereas the positive staining signals were predominantly in the cytoplasm when using anti-KIF23 antibody, suggesting that KIF23 V2 might localize in the cytoplasm of HCC cells.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: KIF23 V1 protein was detected in 57.6% (83/144) HCC patients and the mean H-score was 42, while KIF23 V2 was detected in 94.4% (135/143) HCC samples and the mean H-score was 68.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Follow-up study showed that HCC patients with expression of KIF23 V1 had a longer 5-year survival (p=0.0052), however, expression of KIF23 V2 protein did not associate with 3- and 5-year survival.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: In this study we show for the first time that KIF23 V1 and V2 have different localizations in HCC cells.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Furthermore, KIF23 V1 protein expression might be a marker of longer overall survival in HCC patients.
title: Evaluation of KIF23 variant 1 expression and relevance as a novel prognostic factor in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: The higher incidence of breast cancer in developed countries has been tempered by reductions in mortality, largely attributable to mammographic screening programmes and advances in adjuvant therapy.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: Optimal systemic management requires consideration of clinical, pathological and biological parameters.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: Oestrogen receptor alpha (ERalpha), progesterone receptor (PgR) and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) are established biomarkers evaluated at diagnosis, which identify cardinal subtypes of breast cancer.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: Their prognostic and predictive utility effectively guides systemic treatment with endocrine, anti-HER2 and chemotherapy.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: Hence, accurate and reliable determination remains of paramount importance.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: However, the goals of personalized medicine and targeted therapies demand further information regarding residual risk and potential benefit of additional treatments in specific circumstances.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: The need for biomarkers which are fit for purpose, and the demands placed upon them, is therefore expected to increase.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: Technological advances, in particular high-throughput global gene expression profiling, have generated multi-gene signatures providing further prognostic and predictive information.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: The rational integration of routinely evaluated clinico-pathological parameters with key indicators of biological activity, such as proliferation markers, also provides a ready opportunity to improve the information available to guide systemic therapy decisions.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: The additional value of such information and its proper place in patient management is currently under evaluation in prospective clinical trials.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: Expanding the utility of biomarkers to lower resource settings requires an emphasis on cost effectiveness, quality assurance and possible international variations in tumor biology; the potential for improved clinical outcomes should be justified against logistical and economic considerations.
title: Biomarkers for the clinical management of breast cancer: international perspective.

text: BACKGROUND: Cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas and keratoacanthomas are common findings in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: METHODS: We performed a molecular analysis to identify oncogenic mutations (HRAS, KRAS, NRAS, CDKN2A, and TP53) in the lesions from patients treated with the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: An analysis of an independent validation set and functional studies with BRAF inhibitors in the presence of the prevalent RAS mutation was also performed.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: Among 21 tumor samples, 13 had RAS mutations (12 in HRAS).
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: In a validation set of 14 samples, 8 had RAS mutations (4 in HRAS).
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: Thus, 60% (21 of 35) of the specimens harbored RAS mutations, the most prevalent being HRAS Q61L.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: Increased proliferation of HRAS Q61L-mutant cell lines exposed to vemurafenib was associated with mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK)-pathway signaling and activation of ERK-mediated transcription.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: In a mouse model of HRAS Q61L-mediated skin carcinogenesis, the vemurafenib analogue PLX4720 was not an initiator or a promoter of carcinogenesis but accelerated growth of the lesions harboring HRAS mutations, and this growth was blocked by concomitant treatment with a MEK inhibitor.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Mutations in RAS, particularly HRAS, are frequent in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas and keratoacanthomas that develop in patients treated with vemurafenib.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: The molecular mechanism is consistent with the paradoxical activation of MAPK signaling and leads to accelerated growth of these lesions.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: (Funded by Hoffmann-La Roche and others; ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00405587, NCT00949702, NCT01001299, and NCT01006980.
title: RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.
RAS mutations in cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas in patients treated with BRAF inhibitors.

text: BACKGROUND: Fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) gene amplification has been reported in different types of cancer.
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: We performed an up-to-date meta-analysis to further characterize the prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with cancer.
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: A search of several databases, including MEDLINE (PubMed), EMBASE, Web of Science, and China National Knowledge Infrastructure, was conducted to identify studies examining the association between FGFR gene amplification and cancer.
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: A total of 24 studies met the inclusion criteria, and overall incidence rates, hazard risk (HR), overall survival, disease-free survival, and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated employing fixed- or random-effects models depending on the heterogeneity of the included studies.
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: In the meta-analysis of 24 studies, the prevalence of FGFR gene amplification was FGFR1: 0.11 (95% CI: 0.08-0.13) and FGFR2: 0.04 (95% CI: 0.02-0.06).
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Overall survival was significantly worse among patients with FGFR gene amplification: FGFR1 [HR 1.57 (95% CI: 1.23-1.99); p = 0.0002] and FGFR2 [HR 2.27 (95% CI: 1.73-3.00); p<0.00001].
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Current evidence supports the conclusion that the outcomes of patients with FGFR gene amplified cancers is worse than for those with non-FGFR gene amplified cancers.
title: Prognostic value of FGFR gene amplification in patients with different types of cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Uveal melanoma (UM) is an aggressive intraocular malignancy with limited therapeutic options.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: Both primary and metastatic UM are characterized by oncogenic mutations in the G-protein alpha subunit q and 11.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: Furthermore, nearly 40% of UM has amplification of the chromosomal arm 8q and monosomy of chromosome 3, with consequent anomalies of MYC copy number.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: Chromatin regulators have become attractive targets for cancer therapy.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: In particular, the bromodomain and extra-terminal (BET) inhibitor JQ1 has shown selective inhibition of c-Myc expression with antiproliferative activity in hematopoietic and solid tumors.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: Here we provide evidence that JQ1 had cytotoxic activity in UM cell lines carrying Gnaq/11 mutations, while in cells without the mutations had little effects.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: Using microarray analysis, we identified a large subset of genes modulated by JQ1 involved in the regulation of cell cycle, apoptosis and DNA repair.
title: BRD4-targeted therapy induces Myc-independent cytotoxicity in Gnaq/11-mutatant uveal melanoma cells.

text: Further analysis of selected genes determined that the concomitant silencing of Bcl-xL and Rad51 represented the minimal requirement to mimic the apoptotic effects of JQ1 in the mutant cells, independently of c-Myc.

text: Most women with estrogen receptor expressing breast cancers receiving anti-estrogens such as tamoxifen may not need or benefit from them.
title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

text: Besides the estrogen receptor, there are no predictive biomarkers to help select breast cancer patients for tamoxifen treatment.
title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

text: CCND1 (cyclin D1) gene amplification is a putative candidate tamoxifen predictive biomarker.
title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

text: 672 women were followed for a median of 8.4 years.
title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

text: We were able to measure the DNA copy number of CCND1 in 442 patients and RSF1 in 413 patients.
title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

title: RSF1 and not cyclin D1 gene amplification may predict lack of benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen in high-risk pre-menopausal women in the MA.12 randomized clinical trial.

text: Infection with human papillomaviruses (HPVs) characterizes a distinct subset of head and neck squamous cell cancers (HNSCCs).
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: HPV-positive HNSCC preferentially affect the oropharynx and tonsils.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: Localized HPV-positive HNSCCs have a favorable prognosis and treatment outcome.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: However, the impact of HPV in advanced or metastatic HNSCC remains to be defined.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: In particular, it is unclear whether HPV modulates the response to cetuximab, an antibody targeting the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is a mainstay of treatment of advanced HNSCC.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: To this end, we have examined the sensitivity of HPV-positive and -negative HNSCC models to cetuximab and cytotoxic drugs in vitro and in vivo.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: In addition, we have stably expressed the HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 in cetuximab-sensitive cancer cell lines to specifically investigate their role in the antibody response.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: The endogenous HPV status or the expression of HPV oncogenes had no significant impact on cetuximab-mediated suppression of EGFR signaling and proliferation in vitro.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: Cetuximab effectively inhibited the growth of E6- and E7-expressing tumors grafted in NOD/SCID mice.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: In support, formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples from cetuximab-treated patients with recurrent or metastatic HNSCC were probed for p16(INK4a) expression, an established biomarker of HPV infection.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: Response rates (45.5% versus 45.5%) and median progression-free survival (97 versus 92 days) following cetuximab-based therapy were similar in patients with p16(INK4A)-positive and p16(INK4A)-negative tumors.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: In conclusion, HPV oncogenes do not modulate the anti-EGFR antibody response in HSNCC.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: Cetuximab treatment should be administered independently of HPV status.
title: Impact of human papilloma virus infection on the response of head and neck cancers to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody therapy.

text: CCNE1 gene amplification is present in 15-20% ovary tumor specimens.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: Here, we showed that Cyclin E1 (CCNE1) was overexpressed in 30% of established ovarian cancer cell lines.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: We also showed that CCNE1 was stained positive in over 40% of primary ovary tumor specimens regardless of their histological types while CCNE1 staining was either negative or low in normal ovary and benign ovary tumor tissues.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: However, the status of CCNE1 overexpression was not associated with the tumorigenic potential of ovarian cancer cell lines and also did not correlate with pathological grades of ovary tumor specimens.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: Subsequent experiments with CCNE1 siRNAs showed that knockdown of CCNE1 reduced cell growth only in cells with inherent CCNE1 overexpression, indicating that these cells may have developed an addiction to CCNE1 for growth/survival.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: As CCNE1 is a regulatory factor of cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (Cdk2), we investigated the effect of Cdk2 inhibitor on ovary tumorigenecity.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: Ovarian cancer cells with elevated CCNE1 expression were 40 times more sensitive to Cdk2 inhibitorSNS-032 than those without inherent CCNE1 overexpression.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: Moreover, SNS-032 greatly prolonged the survival of mice bearing ovary tumors with inherent CCNE1 overexpression.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: This study suggests that ovary tumors with elevated CCNE1 expression may be staged for Cdk2-targeted therapy.
title: Cyclin-dependent kinase 2 is an ideal target for ovary tumors with elevated cyclin E1 expression.

text: PURPOSE: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is a unique disorder characterized by the development of hamartomas in the gastrointestinal tract as well as increased risks for variety of malignancies.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: Germ-line mutations of LKB1 cause PJS.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: We have generated Lkb1+/- mice, which model human PJS.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: Rapamycin and its analogues are promising preventive and therapeutic agents that specifically inhibit signaling from mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR).
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: Hyperactivation of mTOR signaling has been associated with PJS.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: The objective of the study is to investigate the efficacy of mTOR inhibition in suppressing Peutz-Jeghers polyposis in Lkb1+/- mice.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We initiated a trial of rapamycin in Lkb1+/- mice at 9 months of age (after the onset of polyposis) at the dose of 2 mg/kg/d for a 2-month period.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: We assessed the efficacy of rapamycin by measuring polyp sizes and tumor burden.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: To examine the effect of rapamycin on mTOR signaling, phosphorylation levels of S6 were evaluated by immunostaining.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: RESULTS: We observed a significant decrease in mean tumor burden (Student's t test, P = 0.023) as well as total tumor burden in rapamycin-treated group compared with control group.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: Comparison of the polyp size observed in both rapamycin-treated and control groups showed that rapamycin efficiently decreased the tumor burden of large polyps (> 8 mm).
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: This inhibition of rapamycin was associated with a decrease in phosphorylated S6 levels in the polyps.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Rapamycin effectively suppresses Peutz-Jeghers polyposis in a mouse model, suggesting that rapamycin or its analogues may represent a new targeted therapy for the treatment of PJS.
title: Suppression of Peutz-Jeghers polyposis by targeting mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.

text: PURPOSE: Mutations leading to constitutive activation of the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) occur in blasts of 30% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: Midostaurin (PKC412; N-benzoylstaurosporin) is a multitargeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, with demonstrated activity in patients with AML/myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with FLT3 mutations.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Ninety-five patients with AML or MDS with either wild-type (n = 60) or mutated (n = 35) FLT3 were randomly assigned to receive oral midostaurin at 50 or 100 mg twice daily.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: The drug was discontinued in the absence of response at 2 months, disease progression, or unacceptable toxicity.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: Response was defined as complete response, partial response (PR), hematologic improvement, or reduction in peripheral blood or bone marrow blasts by >/= 50% (BR).
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: RESULTS: The rate of BR for the population in whom efficacy could be assessed (n = 92) was 71% in patients with FLT3-mutant and 42% in patients with FLT3 wild-type.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: One PR occurred in a patient with FLT3-mutant receiving the 100-mg dose regimen.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: Both doses were well-tolerated; there were no differences in toxicity or response rate according to the dose of midostaurin.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: CONCLUSION: These results suggest that midostaurin has hematologic activity in both patients with FLT3-mutant and wild-type.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: The degree of clinical activity observed supports additional studies that combine midostaurin and other agents such as chemotherapy especially in FLT3-mutant AML.
title: Phase IIB trial of oral Midostaurin (PKC412), the FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 receptor (FLT3) and multi-targeted kinase inhibitor, in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and high-risk myelodysplastic syndrome with either wild-type or mutated FLT3.

text: Adenocarcinoma accounts for approximately 40% of lung cancer, equating to approximately 88 500 new patients in 2015, most of who will succumb to this disease, thus, the public health burden is evident.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: Unfortunately, few early biomarkers as well as effective therapies exist, hence the need for novel targets in lung cancer treatment.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: We previously identified epiregulin (Ereg), an EGF-like ligand, as a biomarker in several mouse lung cancer models.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: In the present investigation we used a primary two-stage initiation/promotion model to test our hypothesis that Ereg deficiency would reduce lung tumor promotion in mice.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: We used 3-methylcholanthrene (initiator) or oil vehicle followed by multiple weekly exposures to butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT; promoter) in mice lacking Ereg (Ereg(-/-) ) and wildtype controls (BALB/ByJ; Ereg(+/+) ) and examined multiple time points and endpoints (bronchoalveolar lavage analysis, tumor analysis, mRNA expression, ELISA, wound assay) during tumor promotion.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: At the early time points (4 and 12 wk), we observed significantly reduced amounts of inflammation (macrophages, PMNs) in the Ereg(-/-) mice compared to controls (Ereg(+/+) ).
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: At 20 wk, tumor multiplicity was also significantly decreased in the Ereg(-/-) mice versus controls (Ereg(+/+) ).
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: IL10 expression, an anti-inflammatory mediator, and downstream signaling events (Stat3) were significantly increased in the Ereg(-/-) mice in response to BHT, supporting both reduced inflammation and tumorigenesis.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: Lastly, wound healing was significantly increased with recombinant Ereg in both human and mouse lung epithelial cell lines.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: These results indicate that Ereg has proliferative potential and may be utilized as an early cancer biomarker as well as a novel potential therapeutic target.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: (c) 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
title: Epiregulin is required for lung tumor promotion in a murine two-stage carcinogenesis model.

text: HRAS is a frequently mutated oncogene in cancer.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: However, mutant HRAS as drug target has not been investigated so far.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: Here, we show that mutant HRAS hyperactivates the RAS and the mTOR pathway in various cancer cell lines including lung, bladder and esophageal cancer.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: HRAS mutation sensitized toward growth inhibition by the MEK inhibitors AZD6244, MEK162 and PD0325901.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: Further, we found that MEK inhibitors induce apoptosis in mutant HRAS cell lines but not in cell lines lacking RAS mutations.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: In addition, knockdown of HRAS by siRNA blocked cell growth in mutant HRAS cell lines.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: Inhibition of the PI3K pathway alone or in combination with MEK inhibitors did not alter signaling nor had an impact on viability.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: However, inhibition of mTOR or combined inhibition of MEK and mTOR reduced cell growth in a synergistic manner.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: Finally, Ba/F3 cells transformed with mutant HRAS isoforms Q61L, Q61R and G12V demonstrated equal sensitivity towards MEK and mTOR inhibition.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: Our results show that HRAS mutations in cancer activate the RAS and mTOR pathways which might serve as a therapeutic option for patients with HRAS mutant tumors.
title: Mutant HRAS as novel target for MEK and mTOR inhibitors.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate the safety, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of BAY 86-9766, a selective, potent, orally available, small-molecule allosteric inhibitor of mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 in patients with advanced solid tumors.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: BAY 86-9766 was administered orally daily in 28-day courses, with doses escalated to establish the maximum-tolerated dose (MTD).
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: An expanded cohort was evaluated at the MTD.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameters were assessed, with extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) phosphorylation evaluated in paired biopsies from a subset of the expanded MTD cohort.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: Tumor specimens were evaluated for mutations in select genes.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: RESULTS: Sixty-nine patients were enrolled, including 20 patients at the MTD.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: The MTD was 100 mg given once-daily or in two divided doses.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: BAY 86-9766 was well-tolerated.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: The most common treatment-related toxicities were acneiform rash and gastrointestinal toxicity.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: BAY 86-9766 was well-absorbed after oral administration (plasma half-life ~12 hours), and displayed dose proportional pharmacokinetics throughout the tested dose range.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: Continuous daily dosing resulted in moderate accumulation at most dose levels.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: BAY 86-9766 suppressed ERK phosphorylation in biopsied tissue and tetradecanoylphorbol acetate-stimulated peripheral blood leukocytes.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: Of 53 evaluable patients, one patient with colorectal cancer achieved a partial response and 11 patients had stable disease for 4 or more courses.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: An ocular melanoma specimen harbored a GNAQ-activating mutation and exhibited reduced ERK phosphorylation in response to therapy.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: This phase I study showed that BAY 86-9766 was well-tolerated, with good oral absorption, dose proportional pharmacokinetics, target inhibition at the MTD, and some evidence of clinical benefit across a range of tumor types.
title: Multicenter phase I trial of the mitogen-activated protein kinase 1/2 inhibitor BAY 86-9766 in patients with advanced cancer.

text: The aim of this study was to establish new biliary tract carcinoma (BTC) cell lines and identify predictive biomarkers for the potential effectiveness of gemcitabine therapy.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: Surgical specimens of BTC were transplanted directly into immunodeficient mice to establish xenografts, then subjected to in vitro cell culture.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: The gemcitabine sensitivity of each cell line was determined and compared with the genome-wide gene expression profile.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: A new predictive biomarker candidate was validated using an additional cohort of gemcitabine-treated BTC cases.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: From 55 BTC cases, we established 19 xenografts and six new cell lines.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: Based on their gemcitabine sensitivity, 10 BTC cell lines (including six new and four publicly available ones) were clearly categorized into two groups, and MAGEH1 mRNA expression in the tumor cells showed a significant negative correlation with their sensitivity to gemcitabine.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: Immunohistochemically, MAGEH1 protein was detected in three (50%) out of six sensitive cell lines, and four (100%) out of four resistant cell lines.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: In the validation cohort of gemcitabine-treated recurrence cases, patients were categorized into "effective" and "non-effective" groups according to the RECIST guidelines for assessment of chemotherapeutic effects.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: MAGEH1 protein expression was detected in two (40%) out of five "effective" cases and all four (100%) "non-effective" cases.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: We have established a new BTC bioresource that covers a wide range of biological features, including drug sensitivity, and is linked with clinical information.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: Negative expression of MAGEH1 protein serves as a potential predictive marker for the effectiveness of gemcitabine therapy in BTC.
title: Establishment of six new human biliary tract carcinoma cell lines and identification of MAGEH1 as a candidate biomarker for predicting the efficacy of gemcitabine treatment.

text: Activating internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutations in the fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) gene (FLT3-ITD) are associated with poor outcome in acute myeloid leukemia, but their prognostic impact in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) remains controversial.
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: Here, we screened for FLT3-ITD mutations in 171 APL patients, treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: We identified FLT3-ITD mutations in 35 patients (20 %).
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: FLT3-ITD mutations were associated with higher white blood cell counts (P < 0.0001), relapse-risk score (P = 0.0007), higher hemoglobin levels (P = 0.0004), higher frequency of the microgranular morphology (M3v) subtype (P = 0.03), and the short PML/RARA (BCR3) isoform (P < 0.0001).
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: After a median follow-up of 38 months, FLT3-ITD(positive) patients had a lower 3-year overall survival rate (62 %) compared with FLT3-ITD(negative) patients (82 %) (P = 0.006).
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: The prognostic impact of FLT3-ITD on survival was retained in multivariable analysis (hazard ratio: 2.39, 95 % confidence interval [CI] 1.17-4.89; P = 0.017).
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: Nevertheless, complete remission (P = 0.07), disease-free survival (P = 0.24), and the cumulative incidence of relapse (P = 0.94) rates were not significantly different between groups.
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: We can conclude that FLT3-ITD mutations are associated with several hematologic features in APL, in particular with high white blood cell counts.
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: In addition, FLT3-ITD may independently predict a shorter survival in patients with APL treated with ATRA and anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
title: Internal tandem duplication of the FLT3 gene confers poor overall survival in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid and anthracycline-based chemotherapy: an International Consortium on Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia study.

text: We assessed the frequency and clinicopathologic significance of 19 genes currently identified as significantly mutated in myeloid neoplasms, RUNX1, ASXL1, TET2, CEBPA, IDH1, IDH2, DNMT3A, FLT3, NPM1, TP53, NRAS, EZH2, CBL, U2AF1, SF3B1, SRSF2, JAK2, CSF3R, and SETBP1, across 93 cases of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) using capture target enrichment and next-generation sequencing.
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: Of these cases, 79% showed at least one nonsynonymous mutation, and cases of AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities showed a lower frequency of mutations versus AML with myelodysplasia-related changes (P<0.001).
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: Mutational analysis further demonstrated that TP53 mutations are associated with complex karyotype AML, whereas ASXL1 and U2AF1 mutations are associated with AML with myelodysplasia-related changes.
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: Furthermore, U2AF1 mutations were specifically associated with trilineage morphologic dysplasia.
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: Univariate analysis demonstrated that U2AF1 and TP53 mutations are associated with absence of clinical remission, poor overall survival (OS), and poor disease-free survival (DFS; P<0.0001), whereas TET2 and ASXL1 mutations are associated with poor OS (P<0.03).
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: In multivariate analysis, U2AF1 and TP53 mutations retained independent prognostic significance in OS and DFS, respectively.
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: Our results demonstrate unique relationships between mutations in AML, clinicopathologic prognosis, subtype categorization, and morphologic dysplasia.
title: Next-generation sequencing of acute myeloid leukemia identifies the significance of TP53, U2AF1, ASXL1, and TET2 mutations.

text: BACKGROUND: Standard clinical parameters cannot accurately differentiate indolent from aggressive prostate cancer.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: Our previous work showed that immunohistochemical (IHC) Ki-67 improved prediction of prostate cancer death in a cohort of conservatively treated clinically localised prostate cancers diagnosed by transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: Here, we present results in a more clinically relevant needle biopsy cohort.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: METHODS: Biopsy specimens were microarrayed.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: The percentage of Ki-67 positively stained malignant cells per core was measured and the maximum score per individual used in analysis of time to death from prostate cancer using a Cox proportional hazards model.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: RESULTS: In univariate analysis (n=293), the hazard ratio (HR) (95% confidence intervals) for dichotomous Ki-67 (</= 10%, >10%) was 3.42 (1.76, 6.62) chi(2) (1 df)=9.8, P=0.002.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: In multivariate analysis, Ki-67 added significant predictive information to that provided by Gleason score and prostate-specific antigen (HR=2.78 (1.42, 5.46), chi(2) (1 df)=7.0, P=0.008).
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: CONCLUSION: The IHC Ki-67 scoring on prostate needle biopsies is practicable and yielded significant prognostic information.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: It was less informative than in the previous TURP cohort where tumour samples were larger and more comprehensive, but in more contemporary cohorts with larger numbers of biopsies per patient, Ki-67 may prove a more powerful biomarker.
title: Prognostic value of Ki-67 for prostate cancer death in a conservatively managed cohort.

text: BACKGROUND: Olaparib is a poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibitor and cediranib is an anti-angiogenic agent with activity against VEGF receptor (VEGFR) 1, VEGFR2, and VEGFR3.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: Both oral agents have antitumour activity in women with recurrent ovarian cancer, and their combination was active and had manageable toxicities in a phase 1 trial.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: We investigated whether this combination could improve progression-free survival (PFS) compared with olaparib monotherapy in women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: METHODS: In our randomised, open-label, phase 2 study, we recruited women (aged >/=18 years) who had measurable platinum-sensitive, relapsed, high-grade serous or endometrioid ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer, or those with deleterious germline BRCA1/2 mutations from nine participating US academic medical centres.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: We randomly allocated participants (1:1) according to permuted blocks, stratified by germline BRCA status and previous anti-angiogenic therapy, to receive olaparib capsules 400 mg twice daily or the combination at the recommended phase 2 dose of cediranib 30 mg daily and olaparib capsules 200 mg twice daily.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: The primary endpoint was progression-free survival analysed in the intention-to-treat population.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: The phase 2 trial is no longer accruing patients.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: An interim analysis was conducted in November, 2013, after 50% of expected events had occurred and efficacy results were unmasked.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: The primary analysis was performed on March 31, 2014, after 47 events (66% of those expected).
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: The trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01116648.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: FINDINGS: Between Oct 26, 2011, and June 3, 2013, we randomly allocated 46 women to receive olaparib alone and 44 to receive the combination of olaparib and cediranib.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: Median PFS was 17.7 months (95% CI 14.7-not reached) for the women treated with cediranib plus olaparib compared with 9.0 months (95% CI 5.7-16.5) for those treated with olaparib monotherapy (hazard ratio 0.42, 95% CI 0.23-0.76; p=0.005).
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: Grade 3 and 4 adverse events were more common with combination therapy than with monotherapy, including fatigue (12 patients in the cediranib plus olaparib group vs five patients in the olaparib monotherapy group), diarrhoea (ten vs none), and hypertension (18 vs none).
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: INTERPRETATION: Cediranib plus olaparib seems to improve PFS in women with recurrent platinum-sensitive high-grade serous or endometrioid ovarian cancer, and warrants study in a phase 3 trial.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: The side-effect profile suggests such investigations should include assessments of quality of life and patient-reported outcomes to understand the effects of a continuing oral regimen with that of intermittent chemotherapy.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: FUNDING: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act grant from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) (3 U01 CA062490-16S2); Intramural Program of the Center for Cancer Research; and the Division of Cancer Treatment and Diagnosis, National Cancer Institute, NIH.
title: Combination cediranib and olaparib versus olaparib alone for women with recurrent platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer: a randomised phase 2 study.

text: Mutation/loss of alpha-thalassemia/mental retardation syndrome X-linked (ATRX) expression has been described in anaplastic gliomas.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: The present study explored the role of ATRX status in the molecular classification of anaplastic gliomas and its impact on survival in the biomarker cohort of the NOA-04 anaplastic glioma trial.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: Patients (n = 133) of the NOA-04 trial were analyzed for ATRX expression using immunohistochemistry.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: ATRX status was correlated with age, histology, isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), 1p/19q, alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) and O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) status, and the trial efficacy endpoints.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: Loss of ATRX expression was detected in 45 % of anaplastic astrocytomas (AA), 27 % of anaplastic oligoastrocytomas (AOA) and 10 % of anaplastic oligodendrogliomas (AO).
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: It was mostly restricted to IDH mutant tumors and almost mutually exclusive with 1p/19q co-deletion.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.
