text: The ALT phenotype was significantly correlated with ATRX loss.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: ATRX and 1p/19q status were used to re-classify AOA: AOA harboring ATRX loss shared a similar clinical course with AA, whereas AOA carrying 1p/19q co-deletion shared a similar course with AO.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: Accordingly, in a Cox regression model including ATRX and 1p/19q status, histology was no longer significantly associated with time to treatment failure.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: Survival analysis showed a marked separation of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors into two groups based on ATRX status: tumors with ATRX loss had a significantly better prognosis (median time to treatment failure 55.6 vs. 31.8 months, p = 0.0168, log rank test).
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: ATRX status helps better define the clinically and morphologically mixed group of AOA, since ATRX loss is a hallmark of astrocytic tumors.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: Furthermore, ATRX loss defines a subgroup of astrocytic tumors with a favorable prognosis.
title: ATRX loss refines the classification of anaplastic gliomas and identifies a subgroup of IDH mutant astrocytic tumors with better prognosis.

text: UNLABELLED: Oncogenic TRK fusions induce cancer cell proliferation and engage critical cancer-related downstream signaling pathways.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: These TRK fusions occur rarely, but in a diverse spectrum of tumor histologies.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: LOXO-101 is an orally administered inhibitor of the TRK kinase and is highly selective only for the TRK family of receptors.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: Preclinical models of LOXO-101 using TRK-fusion-bearing human-derived cancer cell lines demonstrate inhibition of the fusion oncoprotein and cellular proliferation in vitro, and tumor growth in vivo.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: The tumor of a 41-year-old woman with soft-tissue sarcoma metastatic to the lung was found to harbor an LMNA-NTRK1 gene fusion encoding a functional LMNA-TRKA fusion oncoprotein as determined by an in situ proximity ligation assay.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: In a phase I study of LOXO-101 (ClinicalTrials.gov no.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: NCT02122913), this patient's tumors underwent rapid and substantial tumor regression, with an accompanying improvement in pulmonary dyspnea, oxygen saturation, and plasma tumor markers.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: TRK fusions have been deemed putative oncogenic drivers, but their clinical significance remained unclear.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: A patient with a metastatic soft-tissue sarcoma with an LMNA-NTRK1 fusion had rapid and substantial tumor regression with a novel, highly selective TRK inhibitor, LOXO-101, providing the first clinical evidence of benefit from inhibiting TRK fusions.
title: An Oncogenic NTRK Fusion in a Patient with Soft-Tissue Sarcoma with Response to the Tropomyosin-Related Kinase Inhibitor LOXO-101.

text: BACKGROUND: Resistance to therapy with BRAF kinase inhibitors is associated with reactivation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: To address this problem, we conducted a phase 1 and 2 trial of combined treatment with dabrafenib, a selective BRAF inhibitor, and trametinib, a selective MAPK kinase (MEK) inhibitor.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: METHODS: In this open-label study involving 247 patients with metastatic melanoma and BRAF V600 mutations, we evaluated the pharmacokinetic activity and safety of oral dabrafenib (75 or 150 mg twice daily) and trametinib (1, 1.5, or 2 mg daily) in 85 patients and then randomly assigned 162 patients to receive combination therapy with dabrafenib (150 mg) plus trametinib (1 or 2 mg) or dabrafenib monotherapy.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: The primary end points were the incidence of cutaneous squamous-cell carcinoma, survival free of melanoma progression, and response.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: Secondary end points were overall survival and pharmacokinetic activity.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: RESULTS: Dose-limiting toxic effects were infrequently observed in patients receiving combination therapy with 150 mg of dabrafenib and 2 mg of trametinib (combination 150/2).
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: Cutaneous squamous-cell carcinoma was seen in 7% of patients receiving combination 150/2 and in 19% receiving monotherapy (P=0.09), whereas pyrexia was more common in the combination 150/2 group than in the monotherapy group (71% vs. 26%).
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: Median progression-free survival in the combination 150/2 group was 9.4 months, as compared with 5.8 months in the monotherapy group (hazard ratio for progression or death, 0.39; 95% confidence interval, 0.25 to 0.62; P<0.001).
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: The rate of complete or partial response with combination 150/2 therapy was 76%, as compared with 54% with monotherapy (P=0.03).
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Dabrafenib and trametinib were safely combined at full monotherapy doses.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: The rate of pyrexia was increased with combination therapy, whereas the rate of proliferative skin lesions was nonsignificantly reduced.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: Progression-free survival was significantly improved.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: (Funded by GlaxoSmithKline; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01072175.
title: Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.
Combined BRAF and MEK inhibition in melanoma with BRAF V600 mutations.

text: PURPOSE: DNA methylation contributes to carcinogenesis by mediating transcriptional regulation and chromatin remodelling, which may influence the effect of DNA-damaging drugs.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: We examined the prognostic and predictive impact of DNA methyltransferase (DNMT) 1 and 3b expression in gastric carcinomas (GC) treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: In vitro, DNMT1 expression and chemosensitivity were investigated for a functional relationship and the DNMT inhibitor decitabine (DAC) was tested as an alternative treatment option.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: DNMT1/3b expression was analysed immunohistochemically in 127 pretherapeutic biopsies of neoadjuvant (platinum/5-fluorouracil)-treated GC patients and correlated with response and overall survival (OS).
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: Short hairpin RNA technology was used to knockdown DNMT1 in the GC cell line, AGS.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: The chemosensitivity of GC cell lines to DAC alone and to DAC in combination with cisplatin was analysed by XTT or colony formation assays.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: RESULTS: High DNMT1 and DNMT3b expression was found in 105/127 (83%) and 79/127 (62%) carcinomas, respectively.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: Patients with low DNMT1 expression demonstrated a significantly better histopathological/clinical response (P=0.03/P=0.008) and OS (P(log-rank)=0.001).
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: In vitro, knockdown of DNMT1 caused an increased chemosensitivity towards cisplatin.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: Combined treatment with cisplatin and DAC showed a synergistic effect leading to increased cytotoxicity in the cisplatin-resistant cell line AGS.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Low DNMT1 expression defines a subgroup of GC patients with better outcomes following platinum/5FU-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: In vitro data support a functional relationship between DNMT1 and cisplatin sensitivity.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: Besides its potential use as a predictive biomarker, DNMT1 may represent a promising target for alternative therapeutic strategies for a subset of GC patients.
title: DNA methyltransferase 1 as a predictive biomarker and potential therapeutic target for chemotherapy in gastric cancer.

text: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) targeting the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) have shown promising clinical efficacy in non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC); however, resistance is frequently observed in malignant cells, operating through a mechanism that remains largely unknown.
title: TOPK promotes lung cancer resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors by phosphorylating and activating c-Jun.

text: The present study shows that T-lymphokine-activated killer cell-originated protein kinase (TOPK) is upregulated in NSCLC and excessively activated in TKI-refractory cells.
title: TOPK promotes lung cancer resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors by phosphorylating and activating c-Jun.

text: TOPK dictates the responsiveness of lung cancers to the EGFR-targeted TKI gefitinib through the transcription factor AP-1 component c-Jun.
title: TOPK promotes lung cancer resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors by phosphorylating and activating c-Jun.

text: TOPK binds directly to and phosphorylates c-Jun, which consequently activates the transcription of AP-1 target genes, including CCND1 and CDC2.
title: TOPK promotes lung cancer resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors by phosphorylating and activating c-Jun.

text: TOPK silencing sensitizes EGFR-TKI-resistant lung cancer cells to gefitinib and increases gefitinib efficacy in preclinical lung adenocarcinoma xenograft models.
title: TOPK promotes lung cancer resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors by phosphorylating and activating c-Jun.

text: These findings represent a novel mechanism of lung cancer resistance to TKIs and suggest that TOPK may have value both as a predictive biomarker and as a therapeutic target: TOPK-targeted therapy may synergize with EGFR-targeted therapy in lung cancers.
title: TOPK promotes lung cancer resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors by phosphorylating and activating c-Jun.

text: Different chemotherapeutic agents currently available are effective only in certain subsets of patients.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: Predictive biomarkers will be helpful in choosing those agents and can improve the clinical efficiency by a more personalized chemotherapeutic approach.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: Raltitrexed is a novel water-soluble quinazoline folate analogue and can improve the efficiency of gastric cancer treatment, but its predictive biomarker remains unclear.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: The aim of our study was to investigate the role of plasma and tumor thymidylate synthase (TS) mRNA levels as predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed in gastric cancer.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: In total, 125 freshly removed gastric tumor specimens and corresponding blood samples before surgery were collected.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: Raltitrexed sensitivity was determined by histoculture drug response assay procedures.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: TS mRNA levels in tumor and plasma were determined by quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: Plasma TS mRNA level in cancer patients was significantly higher than in healthy subjects (p = 0.009) and was significantly correlated with TS mRNA level in tumor tissues (r = 0.665, p < 0.001).
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: Tumor and plasma TS mRNA expression levels were significantly lower in raltitrexed-sensitive group than in resistant group (p = 0.007 and 0.013, respectively).
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: The sensitivity and accuracy of raltitrexed sensitivity prediction based on plasma TS mRNA levels were 82 and 60%, respectively, whereas the prediction based on tumor TS mRNA reached 70% sensitivity and 68% accuracy.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: These results indicate that TS mRNA level in plasma can mirror tumor TS mRNA level, and both of them can be used to predict raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.
title: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in plasma and tumor as potential predictive biomarkers for raltitrexed sensitivity in gastric cancer.

text: PURPOSE: We assessed the prognostic impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and a known single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) located in the same exon of the IDH1 gene in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML) in the context of other prognostic markers.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: IDH1 exon four was directly sequenced in 275 CN-AML patients from two subsequent AML multicenter treatment trials and 120 healthy volunteers.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: Moreover, mutations in NPM1, FLT3, CEBPA, and WT1 were analyzed, and mRNA expression of IDH1 was quantified.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: RESULTS: IDH1 R132 mutations were found in 10.9% of CN-AML patients.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: IDH1 SNP rs11554137 was found in 12% of CN-AML patients and 11.7% of healthy volunteers.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: IDH1 R132 mutations had no impact on prognosis.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: In contrast, IDH1 SNP rs11554137 was an adverse prognostic factor for overall survival in univariate and multivariate analysis.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: Other significant factors were age, NPM1/FLT3 mutational status, WT1 SNP rs16754, and platelet count.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: The impact of IDH1 SNP rs11554137 was most pronounced in the NPM1/FLT3 high-risk patients (either NPM1 wild-type or FLT3-internal tandem duplication positive).
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: Patients with IDH1 SNP rs11554137 had a higher expression of IDH1 mRNA than patients with two wild-type alleles.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: CONCLUSION: IDH1 SNP rs11554137 but not IDH1 R132 mutations are associated with an inferior outcome in CN-AML.
title: Impact of IDH1 R132 mutations and an IDH1 single nucleotide polymorphism in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia: SNP rs11554137 is an adverse prognostic factor.

text: Synovial sarcomas are high grade spindle cell tumors that are divided into two major histologic subtypes, biphasic and monophasic, according to the respective presence or absence of a well-developed glandular epithelial component.
title: Fusions of the SYT and SSX genes in synovial sarcoma.

text: They contain in essentially all cases a t(X;18) representing the fusion of SYT (at 18q11) with either SSX1 or SSX2 (both at Xp11).
title: Fusions of the SYT and SSX genes in synovial sarcoma.

text: Neither SYT, nor the SSX proteins contain DNA-binding domains.
title: Fusions of the SYT and SSX genes in synovial sarcoma.

text: Instead, they appear to be transcriptional regulators whose actions are mediated primarily through protein-protein interactions, with BRM in the case of SYT, and with Polycomb group repressors in the case of SSX.
title: Fusions of the SYT and SSX genes in synovial sarcoma.

text: Ongoing work on the SYT-SSX fusion and synovial sarcoma should yield a variety of data of broader biological interest, in areas such as BRM and Polycomb group function and dysfunction, transcriptional targets of SYT-SSX proteins and their native counterparts, differential gene regulation by SYT-SSX1 and SYT-SSX2, control of glandular morphogenesis, among others.
title: Fusions of the SYT and SSX genes in synovial sarcoma.

text: PURPOSE: A low mutation rate seems to be a general feature of pediatric cancers, in particular in oncofusion gene-driven tumors.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Genetically, Ewing sarcoma is defined by balanced chromosomal EWS/ETS translocations, which give rise to oncogenic chimeric proteins (EWS-ETS).
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Other contributing somatic mutations involved in disease development have only been observed at low frequency.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Tumor samples of 116 Ewing sarcoma patients were analyzed here.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Whole-genome sequencing was performed on two patients with normal, primary, and relapsed tissue.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Whole-exome sequencing was performed on 50 Ewing sarcoma and 22 matched normal tissues.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: A discovery dataset of 14 of these tumor/normal pairs identified 232 somatic mutations.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Recurrent nonsynonymous mutations were validated in the 36 remaining exomes.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Transcriptome analysis was performed in a subset of 14 of 50 Ewing sarcomas and DNA copy number gain and expression of FGFR1 in 63 of 116 Ewing sarcomas.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: RESULTS: Relapsed tumors consistently showed a 2- to 3-fold increased number of mutations.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: We identified several recurrently mutated genes at low frequency (ANKRD30A, CCDC19, KIAA0319, KIAA1522, LAMB4, SLFN11, STAG2, TP53, UNC80, ZNF98).
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: An oncogenic fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) mutation (N546K) was detected, and the FGFR1 locus frequently showed copy number gain (31.7%) in primary tumors.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: Furthermore, high-level FGFR1 expression was noted as a characteristic feature of Ewing sarcoma.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: RNA interference of FGFR1 expression in Ewing sarcoma lines blocked proliferation and completely suppressed xenograft tumor growth.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: FGFR1 tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapy in a patient with Ewing sarcoma relapse significantly reduced 18-FDG-PET activity.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: FGFR1 may constitute a promising target for novel therapeutic approaches in Ewing sarcoma.
title: Deep Sequencing in Conjunction with Expression and Functional Analyses Reveals Activation of FGFR1 in Ewing Sarcoma.

text: PURPOSE: Amplifications and mutations in the KIT proto-oncogene in subsets of melanomas provide therapeutic opportunities.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We conducted a multicenter phase II trial of imatinib in metastatic mucosal, acral, or chronically sun-damaged (CSD) melanoma with KIT amplifications and/or mutations.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Patients received imatinib 400 mg once per day or 400 mg twice per day if there was no initial response.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Dose reductions were permitted for treatment-related toxicities.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Additional oncogene mutation screening was performed by mass spectroscopy.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: RESULTS: Twenty-five patients were enrolled (24 evaluable).
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Eight patients (33%) had tumors with KIT mutations, 11 (46%) with KIT amplifications, and five (21%) with both.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Median follow-up was 10.6 months (range, 3.7 to 27.1 months).
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Best overall response rate (BORR) was 29% (21% excluding nonconfirmed responses) with a two-stage 95% CI of 13% to 51%.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: BORR was significantly greater than the hypothesized null of 5% and statistically significantly different by mutation status (7 of 13 or 54% KIT mutated v 0% KIT amplified only).
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: There were no statistical differences in rates of progression or survival by mutation status or by melanoma site.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: The overall disease control rate was 50% but varied significantly by KIT mutation status (77% mutated v 18% amplified).
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Four patients harbored pretreatment NRAS mutations, and one patient acquired increased KIT amplification after treatment.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: CONCLUSION: Melanomas that arise on mucosal, acral, or CSD skin should be assessed for KIT mutations.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: Imatinib can be effective when tumors harbor KIT mutations, but not if KIT is amplified only.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: NRAS mutations and KIT copy number gain may be mechanisms of therapeutic resistance to imatinib.
title: Imatinib for melanomas harboring mutationally activated or amplified KIT arising on mucosal, acral, and chronically sun-damaged skin.

text: High-grade serous cancer (HGSC), the most common subtype of ovarian cancer, often becomes resistant to chemotherapy, leading to poor patient outcomes.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: Intratumoral heterogeneity occurs in nearly all solid cancers, including ovarian cancer, contributing to the development of resistance mechanisms.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: In this study, we examined the spatial and temporal genomic variation in HGSC using high-resolution single-nucleotide polymorphism arrays.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: Multiple metastatic lesions from individual patients were analyzed along with 22 paired pretreatment and posttreatment samples.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: We documented regions of differential DNA copy number between multiple tumor biopsies that correlated with altered expression of genes involved in cell polarity and adhesion.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: In the paired primary and relapse cohort, we observed a greater degree of genomic change in tumors from patients that were initially sensitive to chemotherapy and had longer progression-free interval compared with tumors from patients that were resistant to primary chemotherapy.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: Notably, deletion or downregulation of the lipid transporter LRP1B emerged as a significant correlate of acquired resistance in our analysis.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: Functional studies showed that reducing LRP1B expression was sufficient to reduce the sensitivity of HGSC cell lines to liposomal doxorubicin, but not to doxorubicin, whereas LRP1B overexpression was sufficient to increase sensitivity to liposomal doxorubicin.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: Together, our findings underscore the large degree of variation in DNA copy number in spatially and temporally separated tumors in HGSC patients, and they define LRP1B as a potential contributor to the emergence of chemotherapy resistance in these patients.
title: LRP1B deletion in high-grade serous ovarian cancers is associated with acquired chemotherapy resistance to liposomal doxorubicin.

text: BACKGROUND: The insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) pathway is known to play a role in the acquisition of resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-specific tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: However, its exact role in TKI resistance has so far remained unclear.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Here, we interrogated the hypothesis that the IGF-1R may serve as a biomarker for, and may play a role in, intrinsic resistance to the EGFR-specific TKI gefitinib in NSCLC.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: Total-IGF-1R and phosphorylated (p)-IGF-1R expression levels were related to gefitinib sensitivity in 23 NSCLC cell lines.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: This sensitivity was re-evaluated after knocking down IGF-1R expression and after IGF-1R up-regulation through exogenous IGF-1 expression.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The utility of IGF-1R expression as a predictive biomarker was also evaluated by immunohistochemistry (IHC) in 98 primary NSCLC samples from patients treated with gefitinib.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Seventeen of the cell lines tested were resistant to gefitinib, whereas 3 cell lines were sensitive.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The three remaining cell lines showed intermediate values.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Thirteen resistant cell lines were found to be positive for total-IGF-1R expression, while all the sensitive cell lines were negative, resulting in a positive predictive value (PPV) of 81% for total-IGF-1R to predict resistance.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Seven resistant cell lines exhibited high p-IGF-1R levels, whereas all 3 sensitive cell lines were negative for p-IGF-1R, resulting in a PPV of 100% for p-IGF-1R to predict resistance.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Neither a knock-down of IGF-1R expression nor an activation of the IGF1-R pathway through exogenous IGF-1 expression affected gefitinib sensitivity.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In primary NSCLC tissues, IGF-1R expression was found to be significantly higher in patients with progressive disease, i.e., showing gefitinib resistance, as compared to those with a complete or partial response.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: IGF-1R acts as a predictor for resistance to gefitinib in NSCLC cell lines and NSCLC patients, but does not seem to play a role in the intrinsic resistance to this drug.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: High total-IGF-1R and p-IGR-1R levels may predict such a resistance.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Since the underlying mechanism does not appear to be related to proliferation induction, alternative pathways should be explored.
title: Insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF-1R) as a biomarker for resistance to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND & AIMS: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability (MSI) have better prognoses than patients with tumors without MSI, but have a poor response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: A dominant-negative form of heat shock protein (HSP)110 (HSP110DE9) expressed by cancer cells with MSI, via exon skipping caused by somatic deletions in the T(17) intron repeat, sensitizes the cells to 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin.We investigated whether HSP110 T(17) could be used to identify patients with colorectal cancer who would benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: METHODS: We characterized the interaction between HSP110 and HSP110DE9 using surface plasmon resonance.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: By using polymerase chain reaction and fragment analysis, we examined how the size of somatic allelic deletions in HSP110 T(17) affected the HSP110 protein expressed by tumor cells.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: We screened 329 consecutive patients with stage II-III colorectal tumors with MSI who underwent surgical resection at tertiary medical centers for HSP110 T(17).
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: RESULTS: HSP110 and HSP110DE9 interacted in a1:1 ratio.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: Tumor cells with large deletions in T(17) had increased ratios of HSP110DE9:HSP110, owing to the loss of expression of full-length HSP110.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: Deletions in HSP110 T(17) were mostly biallelic in primary tumor samples with MSI.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: Patients with stage II-III cancer who received chemotherapy and had large HSP110 T(17) deletions (>/=5 bp; 18 of 77 patients, 23.4%) had longer times of relapse-free survival than patients with small or no deletions (</=4 bp; 59 of 77 patients, 76.6%) in multivariate analysis (hazard ratio, 0.16; 95% confidence interval, 0.012-0.8; P = .03).
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: We found a significant interaction between chemotherapy and T17 deletion (P =.009).
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: About 25% of patients with stages II-III colorectal tumors with MSI have an excellent response to chemotherapy, due to large, biallelic deletions in the T(17) intron repeat of HSP110 in tumor DNA.
title: Patients with colorectal tumors with microsatellite instability and large deletions in HSP110 T17 have improved response to 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Despite therapeutic innovations, metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) is still characterized by poor prognosis and few molecular markers predict the risk of progression.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Polycomb group genes (PcGs) are epigenetic modifiers involved in tumor suppressor gene silencing.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: PcG member EZH2 mediates gene silencing through histone-H3 lysine-27 methylation.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: In colorectal cancer (CRC), EZH2 overexpression predicts shorter survival.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Recently, four EZH2 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) have been described.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: The present study was aimed at evaluating the correlation between EZH2 SNPs and outcome parameters in mCRC patients.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: DNA was extracted from blood samples of 110 mCRC patients treated with first-line 5-fluorouracil, folinic acid, irinotecan (FOLFIRI) and bevacizumab.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Genotyping was carried out by real-time PCR.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Genotype was used to predict objective response, progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS).
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: EZH2 messenger RNA levels were evaluated on lymphocytes of a parallel cohort of 50 CRC patients.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: One allelic variant (rs3757441 C/C versus C/T or T/T) was significantly associated with shorter PFS and OS (P < 0.01 and P < 0.05, respectively).
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: At multivariate analysis, the same variant resulted an independent predictor of PFS and OS (P < 0.05).
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: The C/C variant was associated with significantly higher EZH2 expression (P < 0.05).
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSION: An EZH2 SNP may be useful to predict clinical outcome in mCRC patients.
title: An EZH2 polymorphism is associated with clinical outcome in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

text: Resistance to chemotherapy represents a major obstacle for long-term remission, and effective strategies to overcome drug resistance would have significant clinical impact.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: We report that recurrent ovarian carcinomas after paclitaxel/carboplatin treatment have higher levels of spleen tyrosine kinase (SYK) and phospho-SYK.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: In vitro, paclitaxel-resistant cells expressed higher SYK, and the ratio of phospho-SYK/SYK positively associated with paclitaxel resistance in ovarian cancer cells.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: Inactivation of SYK by inhibitors or gene knockdown sensitized paclitaxel cytotoxicity in vitro and in vivo.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: Analysis of the phosphotyrosine proteome in paclitaxel-resistant tumor cells revealed that SYK phosphorylates tubulins and microtubule-associated proteins.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: Inhibition of SYK enhanced microtubule stability in paclitaxel-resistant tumor cells that were otherwise insensitive.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: Thus, targeting SYK pathway is a promising strategy to enhance paclitaxel response.
title: Inhibition of Spleen Tyrosine Kinase Potentiates Paclitaxel-Induced Cytotoxicity in Ovarian Cancer Cells by Stabilizing Microtubules.

text: Activin A (ActA)/follistatin (FST) signaling has been shown to be deregulated in different tumor types including lung adenocarcinoma (LADC).
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Here, we report that serum ActA protein levels are significantly elevated in LADC patients (n=64) as compared to controls (n=46, p=0.015).
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: ActA levels also correlated with more advanced disease stage (p<0.0001) and T (p=0.0035) and N (p=0.0002) factors.
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: M1 patients had significantly higher ActA levels than M0 patients (p<0.001).
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: High serum ActA level was associated with poor overall survival (p<0.0001) and was confirmed as an independent prognostic factor (p=0.004).
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Serum FST levels were increased only in female LADC patients (vs. female controls, p=0.031).
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Two out of five LADC cell lines secreted biologically active ActA, while FST was produced in all of them.
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Transcripts of both type I and II ActA receptors were detected in all five LADC cell lines.
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: In conclusion, our study does not only suggest that measuring blood ActA levels in LADC patients might improve the prediction of prognosis, but also indicates that this parameter might be a novel non-invasive biomarker for identifying LADC patients with organ metastases.
title: High circulating activin A level is associated with tumor progression and predicts poor prognosis in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: UNLABELLED: KRAS gain-of-function mutations occur in approximately 30% of all human cancers.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: Despite more than 30 years of KRAS-focused research and development efforts, no targeted therapy has been discovered for cancers with KRAS mutations.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: Here, we describe ARS-853, a selective, covalent inhibitor of KRAS(G12C) that inhibits mutant KRAS-driven signaling by binding to the GDP-bound oncoprotein and preventing activation.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: Based on the rates of engagement and inhibition observed for ARS-853, along with a mutant-specific mass spectrometry-based assay for assessing KRAS activation status, we show that the nucleotide state of KRAS(G12C) is in a state of dynamic flux that can be modulated by upstream signaling factors.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: These studies provide convincing evidence that the KRAS(G12C) mutation generates a "hyperexcitable" rather than a "statically active" state and that targeting the inactive, GDP-bound form is a promising approach for generating novel anti-RAS therapeutics.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: A cell-active, mutant-specific, covalent inhibitor of KRAS(G12C) is described that targets the GDP-bound, inactive state and prevents subsequent activation.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: Using this novel compound, we demonstrate that KRAS(G12C) oncoprotein rapidly cycles bound nucleotide and responds to upstream signaling inputs to maintain a highly active state.
title: Selective Inhibition of Oncogenic KRAS Output with Small Molecules Targeting the Inactive State.

text: BACKGROUND: An increasing number of studies have examined the ability of programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) to function as a marker for tumor prognosis.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: However, whether PD-L1 expression is a prognostic factor for the poor outcomes in many human cancers remains controversial.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: This study aims to investigate the prognostic role of PD-L1 expression through a meta-analysis update of 60 studies.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: The studies were identified by searching PubMed, Embase, Google Scholar, and Cochrane Library, and were assessed by further quality evaluation.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: The pooled hazard ratios (HRs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for total and stratified analyses were calculated to investigate the association between the PD-L1 expression and the overall (OS) and disease-free (DFS) or progression-free survivals (PFS) of cancer patients.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: Heterogeneity and publication bias were also investigated.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: The results indicated that PD-L1 overexpression can predict a poor OS (HR = 1.58, 95% CI = 1.38-1.81, P <.000) and DFS/PFS (HR = 1.72, 95% CI = 1.26-2.33, P = .001).
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: Subgroup analyses showed that PD-L1 overexpression was significantly related to the poor OS in patients with breast (HR = 1.98, 95% CI = 1.15-3.41, P = .014), urothelial (HR = 2.24, 95% CI = 1.61-3.12, P <.000), renal (HR = 3.30, 95% CI = 2.23-4.86, P <.000), and gastric cancers (HR = 1.56, 95% CI = 1.02-2.37, P = .040).
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: Furthermore, PD-L1 overexpresion was significantly associated with poor DFS/PFS in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (HR = 1.72, 95% CI = 1.21-2.46, P = .003), melanoma (HR = 3.39, 95% CI = 2.02-5.69, P <.000), and renal carcinoma, (HR = 5.04, 95% CI = 2.87-8.86, P <.000).
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: The adverse prognostic impact of PD-L1 was observed in patients of different ethnicities.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The findings of this meta-analysis suggest the correlation of PD-L1 overexpression with worse OS in patients with solid tumors.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: However, the correlations differed according to tumor types.
title: Prognostic significance of PD-L1 in solid tumor: An updated meta-analysis.

text: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are KIT expressing spindle cell, epithelioid and rarely pleomorphic mesenchymal tumors.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: The majority of GISTs show gain-of-function KIT mutations.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: However, GISTs without KIT mutations and GISTs with weak or lack of immunohistochemical KIT expression have also been reported.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: Recently, gain-of-function mutations in exon 18 (activation loop) and exon 12 (juxtamembrane domain) of the PDGFRA were identified in such tumors.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: The purpose of this study was to test the hypothesis that PDGFRA mutation may define a specific clinicopathologic subgroup of GISTs.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: A total of 447 KIT exon 11 (juxtamembrane domain) mutation-negative GISTs were studied.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: DNA samples were obtained from formaldehyde-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: Genomic sequences of PDGFRA exons 18 and 12 were evaluated for the mutations by PCR amplification and direct sequencing.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: PDGFRA exon 18 mutations were identified in 122 of 346 (35.3%) gastric GISTs and two of 75 (2.7%) intestinal GISTs.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: A great majority of these mutations represented simple T to A missense mutation at the codon 842 leading to substitution of the valine for aspartic acid (D842 V).
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: However, in-frame deletions and deletions with point mutations clustering between codons 841-847 were found in approximately 23% of all exon 18 mutations.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: Mutations in PDGFRA exon 12 were found only in 10 of 170 (5.8%) gastric and one of 54 (1.9%) intestinal GISTs negative for KIT exon 11 and PDGFRA exon 18 mutations.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: There were seven substitutions of aspartic acid for valine at codon 561 (V561D) and four in-frame deletions with point mutations clustering between codons 566 and 571.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: The majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations had pure or predominant epithelioid morphology.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: Based on long-term follow-up (average 135 months), a majority (83.5%) of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations followed a benign course.
title: A great majority of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations represent gastric tumors of low or no malignant potential.

text: BACKGROUND: During early clinical development, prospective identification of a predictive biomarker and validation of an assay method may not always be feasible.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Dichotomizing a continuous biomarker measure to classify responders also leads to challenges.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We present a case study of a prospective-retrospective approach for a continuous biomarker identified after patient enrollment but defined prospectively before the unblinding of data.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: An analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of this approach and the challenges encountered in its practical application are also provided.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: METHODS: HERALD (NCT02134015) was a double-blind, phase 2 study in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) randomized to erlotinib with placebo or with high or low doses of patritumab, a monoclonal antibody targeted against human epidermal growth factor receptor 3 (HER3).
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: While the primary objective was to assess safety and progression-free survival (PFS), a secondary objective was to determine a single predictive biomarker hypothesis to identify subjects most likely to benefit from the addition of patritumab.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Although not identified as the primary biomarker in the study protocol, on the basis of preclinical results from 2 independent laboratories, expression levels of the HER3 ligand heregulin (HRG) were prospectively declared the predictive biomarker before data unblinding but after subject enrollment.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: An assay to measure HRG mRNA was developed and validated.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Other biomarkers, such as epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutation status, were also evaluated in an exploratory fashion.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The cutoff value for high vs. low HRG mRNA levels was set at the median delta threshold cycle.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A maximum likelihood analysis was performed to evaluate the provisional cutoff.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The relationship of HRG values to PFS hazard ratios (HRs) was assessed as a measure of internal validation.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Additional NSCLC samples were analyzed to characterize HRG mRNA distribution.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: The subgroup of patients with high HRG mRNA levels ("HRG-high") demonstrated clinical benefit from patritumab treatment with HRs of 0.37 (P = 0.0283) and 0.29 (P = 0.0027) in the high- and low-dose patritumab arms, respectively.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Maximum likelihood analysis showed that the provisional cutoff was within the optimal range.

text: In the placebo arm, the HRG-high subgroup demonstrated worse prognosis compared with HRG-low.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A continuous relationship was observed between increased HRG mRNA levels and lower HR.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Additional NSCLC samples (N = 300) demonstrated a similar unimodal distribution to that observed in this study, suggesting that the defined cutoff may be applicable to future NSCLC studies.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The prospective-retrospective approach was successful in clinically validating a probable predictive biomarker.
title: Clinical Translation and Validation of a Predictive Biomarker for Patritumab, an Anti-human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 3 (HER3) Monoclonal Antibody, in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: However, limitations of this analysis include the incomplete collection of adequate tumor tissue and a lack of stratification.

text: In 2012, ponatinib (Iclusig((R))), an orally available pan-BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) developed by ARIAD Pharmaceuticals, Inc., was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for use in resistant or intolerant chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph(+)ALL).
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: Ponatinib is the only approved TKI capable of inhibiting BCR-ABL with the gatekeeper T315I kinase domain mutation, known to be the cause for 20% of resistant or relapsed CML cases.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: In 2013, ponatinib sales were temporarily suspended due to serious side effects seen in nearly 12% of the patient population.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: These side effects are thought to stem from the potent nature and pan-activity of this TKI.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: ARIAD Pharmaceuticals, Inc. has since been permitted to resume sales and marketing of ponatinib to a limited patient population with an expanded black box warning.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: In the following review, the use of ponatinib in CML and Ph(+)ALL will be discussed.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: Mechanisms of resistance in CML are discussed, which provide insight and background into the need for this third generation TKI, followed by the molecular design and pharmacology of ponatinib, which lead to its success as a therapeutic.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: Finally, the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of ponatinib will be highlighted, including summaries of the important clinical trials involving ponatinib as well as its current place in therapy.
title: Resistant mutations in CML and Ph(+)ALL - role of ponatinib.

text: The introduction of trastuzumab as adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer changed the natural course of early-stage disease.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Currently, one year of trastuzumab given concurrently with a taxane and following an anthracycline regimen is the preferred standard of care in Europe.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: The first attempt to escalate this approach, though the implementation of dual HER2 blockade with lapatinib added to trastuzumab, as assessed by the ALTTO trial, failed to improve further clinical outcomes; clinical assessment of the adjuvant trastuzumab/pertuzumab regimen is still ongoing in the APHINITY trial.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Negative results were also reported for the addition of bevacizumab to adjuvant trastuzumab treatment within the context of the BETH study.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Similarly, efforts to de-escalate through shortening the duration of adjuvant trastuzumab treatment failed (the PHARE trial), whereas others are still ongoing.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Of note, evidence supports the use of lighter chemotherapy regimens with one year of adjuvant trastuzumab as backbone, for women with small HER2-positive breast tumors, where the omission of anthracyclines did not compromise the clinical outcome.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Despite the successes achieved so far, a proportion of women with early-stage HER2-positive breast cancer, will still experience disease recurrence.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: The identification of these women is urgently needed, as well as the identification of predictive biomarkers to dictate the optimal treatment strategy.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: So far, HER2 expression status has been the only validated predictive biomarker for this patient population.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Despite the clear association of pCR achieved through neoadjuvant trastuzumab-based chemotherapy with clinical outcome, results from neoadjuvant trials have not been always consistent with what was seen in the adjuvant setting.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Similarly, inconsistent results have been reported for the predictive ability of alterations affecting the PI3K signaling pathway or the quantification of tumor infiltrating lymphocytes.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: In the era of personalized oncology, rigorous translational and clinical collaborative efforts are needed to further advance the field of treatment of patients with HER2-positive breast cancer.
title: Optimal adjuvant treatment for patients with HER2-positive breast cancer in 2015.

text: Paclitaxel frequently serves as the first-line chemotherapeutic agent for castration-resistant prostate cancer (PCa) patients.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: However, acquired paclitaxel-resistance almost always occurs after initial responses, and the mechanisms by which this occurs remain largely unknown.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: The goal of the present study was to identify differentially expressed protein(s) associated with paclitaxel-resistance and further explore the potential mechanisms involved in drug resistance.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: By comparing the nuclear matrix protein (NMP) patterns of DU145-TxR cells, the previously established stable paclitaxel-resistant PCa cells, with that of the parental DU145 cells using two-dimensional electrophoresis, we found that cytokeratin 18 (CK18) is downregulated in DU145-TxR cells.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: The downregulation of CK18 in DU145-TxR cells at mRNA, NMP and total cellular protein levels was validated by real-time RT-PCR, immunoblotting and immunofluorescence, indicating that the downregulation of CK18 was a global effect in DU145-TxR cells due to paclitaxel-resistance.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: Furthermore, in vivo assay of xenograft transplantation confirmed the higher tumorigenicity of DU145-TxR cells, suggesting that these paclitaxel-resistant PCa cells possessed potent cancer stem cell (CSC)-like properties and eventually developed paclitaxel-resistance.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: Moreover, we determined by immunohistochemistry that CK18 expression in PCa tissues was inversely correlated with tumor grade in a statistically significant fashion, indicating a potential association of the downregulation of CK18 with tumor aggressiveness.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: Therefore, further study to define the potential role of CK18 may lead to novel therapy strategies as well as clinically useful biomarker for PCa patients.
title: Downregulation of cytokeratin 18 is associated with paclitaxelresistance and tumor aggressiveness in prostate cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Targeting the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/AKT/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway is of increasing interest as a therapeutic strategy in many tumors.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: The aim of this study was to identify molecular markers associated with mTOR inhibitor activity in women with metastatic endometrial cancer.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: METHODS: Archival tumor samples were collected from 94 women with recurrent or metastatic endometrial cancer who participated in 3 National Cancer Insitute of Canada Clinical Trials Group phase 2 trials investigating single-agent mTOR inhibitors: IND160A and IND160B (temsirolimus) and IND192 (ridaforolimus).
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: Analyses included mutational profiling using the OncoCarta Panel version 1.0 and immunohistochemical expression of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homologue) and stathmin, a marker of PI3K activation.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: Associations between biomarker results and clinical outcomes were assessed.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: RESULTS: Mutations were found in 32 of 73 analyzed tumors, PIK3CA (21 patients) was the most common mutated gene.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: Co-mutations were seen in 8 tumors, most frequently KRAS and PIK3CA (4 cases).
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: PTEN loss was observed in 46 of 85 samples analyzed and increased stathmin expression was observed in 15 of 65 analyzed samples.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: No correlation was observed between biomarkers and response or progression.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: In patients taking concurrent metformin, there was a trend toward lower progression, of 11.8% versus 32.5% (P = .14).
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: No predictive biomarker or combination of biomarkers for mTOR inhibitor activity were identified in this study.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: Restriction and enrichment of study entry, especially based on archival tumor tissue, should be undertaken with caution in trials using these agents.
title: Molecular determinants of outcome with mammalian target of rapamycin inhibition in endometrial cancer.

text: Mutation of the nucleophosmin (NPM) gene has been reported as the most frequent mutation in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), especially in the presence of a normal karyotype.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: In this subgroup of intermediate-risk AML, the identification of other gene mutations (eg, FLT3, CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein-alpha [CEBPA]) has helped to refine the prognosis.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: This study explored the prevalence and the prognostic impact of NPM mutations in a cohort of 106 patients with normal-karyotype AML.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: NPM exon 12 mutations were detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and fragment analysis for the insertion/deletion globally resulting in a 4-bp insertion.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: NPM mutations were detected in 47% of patients and were associated with a high white blood cell count, involvement of the monocytic lineage (M4/M5), and a decreased prevalence of CEBPA mutations.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: Complete remission rate and long-term outcome did not differ between NPM-mutated and -nonmutated patients.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: Prospective studies are needed to confirm the definitive place of NPM mutation detection to predict AML response to therapy.
title: Prevalence, clinical profile, and prognosis of NPM mutations in AML with normal karyotype.

text: BACKGROUND: Considering the high prevalence of female genital tract neoplasms, non-specific nature of the initial symptoms, higher possibility of metastasis by the time of diagnosis, importance of differentiating metastatic Mullerian tumors or metastatic breast cancer in the female genital tract, especially in the ovary, and lack of diagnostic markers with high sensitivity and specificity, the purpose of the current study was to evaluate the utility of Paired box protein8 (PAX8) expression in Mullerian and non-Mullerian neoplasms.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: In this descriptive-analytic, cross-sectional study, paraffin-embedded tissues of patients with definitive pathologic diagnosis of Mullerian and non-Mullerian tumors were selected.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: PAX8 immunohistochemical (IHC) staining was performed for all selected blocks.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: Immunopositivity of the slides for PAX8 was reviewed.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: It was defined as the presence of nuclear staining in at least 10% of the tumor cell nuclei.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: RESULTS: Thirty-seven Mullerian (including 18 ovarian epithelial tumors, 17 endometrial carcinoma and two endocervical adenocarcinoma) and 37 non-Mullerian tumors were studied for PAX8 expression.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: Twenty-nine of 37 (78.4%) and one of 37 (2.7%) of the Mullerian and non-Mullerian tumors were positive for PAX8, respectively.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: The sensitivity and specificity of PAX8 by IHC for differentiation of Mullerian from non-Mullerian tumors was 78.4% and 97.3%, respectively.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: CONCLUSION: Our findings indicated that PAX8 could be used as a useful IHC marker for diagnosing Mullerian tumors.
