title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: It has moderate to high sensitivity, but high specificity, for diagnosing carcinomas of Mullerian origin.
title: Diagnostic utility of PAX8 in differentiation of mullerian from non-mullerian tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: KRAS mutations in NSCLC are associated with a lack of response to epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitors.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: Selumetinib (AZD6244; ARRY-142886) is an oral selective MEK kinase inhibitor of the Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK pathway.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients failing one to two prior regimens underwent KRAS profiling.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: KRAS wild-type patients were randomized to erlotinib (150 mg daily) or a combination of selumetinib (150 mg daily) with erlotinib (100 mg daily).
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: KRAS mutant patients were randomized to selumetinib (75 mg b.i.d.)
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: or the combination.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: The primary end points were progression-free survival (PFS) for the KRAS wild-type cohort and objective response rate (ORR) for the KRAS mutant cohort.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: Biomarker studies of ERK phosphorylation and immune subsets were carried out.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: From March 2010 to May 2013, 89 patients were screened; 41 KRAS mutant and 38 KRAS wild-type patients were enrolled.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: Median PFS in the KRAS wild-type arm was 2.4 months [95% confidence interval (CI) 1.3-3.7] for erlotinib alone and 2.1 months (95% CI 1.8-5.1) for the combination.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: The ORR in the KRAS mutant group was 0% (95% CI 0.0% to 33.6%) for selumetinib alone and 10% (95% CI 2.1% to 26.3%) for the combination.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: Combination therapy resulted in increased toxicities, requiring dose reductions (56%) and discontinuation (8%).
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: Programmed cell death-1 expression on regulatory T cells (Tregs), Tim-3 on CD8+ T cells and Th17 levels were associated with PFS and overall survival in patients receiving selumetinib.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This study failed to show improvement in ORR or PFS with combination therapy of selumetinib and erlotinib over monotherapy in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced NSCLC.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: The association of immune subsets and immune checkpoint receptor expression with selumetinib may warrant further studies.
title: Selumetinib with and without erlotinib in KRAS mutant and KRAS wild-type advanced nonsmall-cell lung cancer.

text: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is frequently overexpressed in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) and cetuximab, a monoclonal antibody targeting this receptor, is widely used to treat these patients.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: In the following investigation, we examined the role of SMAD4 down-regulation in mediating epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and cetuximab resistance in HNSCC.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: We determined that SMAD4 downregulation was significantly associated with increased cell motility, increased expression of vimentin, and cetuximab resistance in HNSCC cell lines.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: In the HNSCC genomic dataset obtained from The Cancer Genome Atlas, SMAD4 was altered in 20/279 (7%) of HNSCC via homozygous deletion, and nonsense, missense, and silent mutations.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: When SMAD4 expression was compared with respect to human papillomavirus (HPV) status, HPV-positive tumors had higher expression compared to HPV-negative tumors.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Furthermore, higher SMAD4 expression also correlated with higher CDKN2A (p16) expression.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Our data suggest that SMAD4 down-regulation plays an important role in the induction of EMT and cetuximab resistance.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Patients with higher SMAD4 expression may benefit from cetuximab use in the clinic.
title: Decreased SMAD4 expression is associated with induction of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: OBJECTIVES: The aim of the study was to assess whether the genetic polymorphisms were associated with the tumor response in patients treated with platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) for bulky cervical cancer.
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed the clinical data and recruited paraffin-embedded, formalin-fixed tissues of 36 patients with bulky cervical carcinoma.
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: All patients underwent two or three cycles of platinum-based NAC followed by radical hysterectomy.
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: We determined the genotypes of each single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) of ERCC1, ERCC2, GGH, GSTP1, MTHFR, SLC19A1 and XRCC1 using single base primer extension assay.
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: RESULTS: The response to platinum-based NAC was higher in patients with SNP of XRCC1 R399Q (P=0.015), and there was a significant increased chance of treatment response in women with the G/G genotype (OR 38.0; 95% CI 1.66-870.45; P=0.023).
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: The probability of response was also higher in patients with SNP of SLC19A1 6318C/T (P=0.032).
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: There were dose-dependent influence of the number of alleles on the response to platinum-based chemotherapy (chi2 test for linear-by-linear association; P=0.009 for XRCC1 R399Q and P=0.017 for SLC19A1 6318C/T, respectively).
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: Moreover, the multifactor dimensionality reduction (MDR) analysis documented that the combinations of XRCC1 R399Q and GGH-401C/T genetic polymorphisms were significantly associated with response to chemotherapy (P<0.0001).
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Genetic polymorphism of XRCC1 R399Q is associated with response to platinum-based NAC in bulky cervical cancer, and MDR analysis documented association between gene-gene interaction of XRCC1 R399Q and treatment response.
title: XRCC1 R399Q polymorphism is associated with response to platinum-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy in bulky cervical cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: The impact of thymidylate synthase (TYMS) and UDP-glucoronosyltransferase 1A (UGT1A) germline polymorphisms on the outcome of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients treated with irinotecan plus 5-fluorouracil (irinotecan/5FU) is still controversial.
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: Our objective was to define a genetic-based algorithm to select patients to be treated with irinotecan/5FU.
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: METHODS: Genotyping of TYMS (5'TRP and 3'UTR), UGT1A1(*)28, UGT1A9(*)22 and UGT1A7(*)3 was performed in 149 metastatic CRC patients treated with irinotecan/5FU as first-line chemotherapy enrolled in a randomised phase 3 study.
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: Their association with response, toxicity and survival was investigated by univariate and multivariate statistical analysis.
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: RESULTS: TYMS 3TRP/3TRP genotype was the only independent predictor of tumour response (OR=5.87, 95% confidence interval (CI)=1.68-20.45; P=0.005).
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: UGT1A1(*)28/(*)28 was predictive for haematologic toxicity (OR=6.27, 95% CI=1.09-36.12; P=0.04), specifically for neutropenia alone (OR=6.40, 95% CI=1.11-37.03; P=0.038) or together with diarrhoea (OR=18.87, 95% CI=2.14-166.67; P=0.008).
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: UGT1A9(*)1/(*)1 was associated with non-haematologic toxicity (OR=2.70, 95% CI=1.07-6.82; P=0.035).
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: Haplotype VII (all non-favourable alleles) was associated with non-haematologic toxicity (OR=2.11, 95% CI=1.12-3.98; P=0.02).
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: CONCLUSION: TYMS and UGT1A polymorphisms influence on tumour response and toxicities derived from irinotecan/5FU treatment in CRC patients.
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: A genetic-based algorithm to optimise treatment individualisation is proposed.
title: UGT1A and TYMS genetic variants predict toxicity and response of colorectal cancer patients treated with first-line irinotecan and fluorouracil combination therapy.

text: Mutations of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene are considered critical for the initiation of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The VHL protein is involved in regulation of the cell cycle and neo-vascularization.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: In this study, the association of VHL mutations with tumour cell proliferation, angiogenesis, and clinical outcome was analysed in 113 clear cell renal cell carcinomas.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The degree of angiogenesis and tumour cell proliferation was immunohistochemically determined by counting microvessels (microvessel density, anti-CD34 antibody) and cells with proliferating activity (Ki-67 labelling index, MIB-1 antibody).
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Forty-eight different VHL sequence alterations were found in 38 of 113 patients (34%) by direct sequencing.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Nineteen VHL mutations were frameshifts and nonsense mutations, predicted to change the open reading frame of VHL.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: These 'loss-of-function' mutations correlated with worse prognosis in univariate analysis (p=0.02).
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Tumour grade, stage, microvessel density, and tumour cell proliferation were not associated with VHL alterations.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: These findings may indicate that 'loss-of-function' VHL mutations are involved in the progression of a clear cell renal cell carcinoma subset, whereas regulation of angiogenesis and proliferation of renal carcinoma in vivo is apparently not directly influenced by VHL alterations.
title: VHL mutations and their correlation with tumour cell proliferation, microvessel density, and patient prognosis in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Metastasis-associated phosphatase of regenerating liver-3 (PRL-3) has pleiotropic effects in driving cancer progression, yet the signaling mechanisms of PRL-3 are still not fully understood.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: Here, we provide evidence for PRL-3-induced hyperactivation of EGFR and its downstream signaling cascades in multiple human cancer cell lines.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: Mechanistically, PRL-3-induced activation of EGFR was attributed primarily to transcriptional downregulation of protein tyrosine phosphatase 1B (PTP1B), an inhibitory phosphatase for EGFR.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: Functionally, PRL-3-induced hyperactivation of EGFR correlated with increased cell growth, promigratory characteristics, and tumorigenicity.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: Moreover, PRL-3 induced cellular addiction to EGFR signaling, as evidenced by the pronounced reversion of these oncogenic attributes upon EGFR-specific inhibition.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: Of clinical significance, we verified elevated PRL-3 expression as a predictive marker for favorable therapeutic response in a heterogeneous colorectal cancer (CRC) patient cohort treated with the clinically approved anti-EGFR antibody cetuximab.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: The identification of PRL-3-driven EGFR hyperactivation and consequential addiction to EGFR signaling opens new avenues for inhibiting PRL-3-driven cancer progression.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: We propose that elevated PRL-3 expression is an important clinical predictive biomarker for favorable anti-EGFR cancer therapy.
title: Metastasis-associated PRL-3 induces EGFR activation and addiction in cancer cells.

text: INTRODUCTION: This study compared the efficacy of pemetrexed in patients with anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)-positive versus ALK-negative (epidermal growth factor receptor [EGFR] mutant or wild type [WT] for both ALK and EGFR) non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: Patients with advanced NSCLC who received second-line pemetrexed and beyond between March 2007 and April 2010 were screened for EGFR mutations and ALK rearrangements at Seoul National University Hospital.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The clinical and in vitro efficacy of pemetrexed was evaluated for each genotypic group.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Ninety-five NSCLC patients were genotyped as follows: 43 (45%) EGFR mutation, 15 (16%) ALK translocation, and 37 (39%) WT.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The overall response rate was superior in ALK-translocated patients compared with EGFR mutant or WT patients (46.7 versus 4.7 versus 16.2%, p = 0.001).
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: ALK-positive patients showed longer time to progression than EGFR mutant or WT patients (9.2 versus 1.4 versus 2.9 months, p = 0.001).
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: ALK positivity alone was a significant predictor for overall response rate (hazard ratio [HR] = 0.07, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.01-0.32; p = 0.001) and time to progression (HR = 0.44, 95% CI: 0.24-0.80; p = 0.007).
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: ALK positivity remained independently significant regardless of treatment line (HR = 0.43, 95% CI: 0.24-0.77; p = 0.005).
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Thymidylate synthase mRNA levels in ALK-positive cells were significantly lower compared with control cells (p < 0.05).
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Pemetrexed is an effective treatment in patients with ALK-positive NSCLC.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: ALK positivity was independently predictive of pemetrexed efficacy in NSCLC patients.
title: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase translocation: a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Human enhancer of filamentation 1 (HEF1), a scaffold protein, is highly expressed in a variety of cancer types and is involved cancer cell growth, migration and invasion.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: The prognostic value of HEF1 in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) remains to be elucidated.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: The aim of the present study was to assess the association between the expression of HEF1, the clinical/pathological parameters and survival in HCC.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: In the present study, immunohistochemistry was performed to investigate the protein expression of HEF1 in 123 hepatocellular carcinoma tissues and their adjacent normal liver tissues.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: Spearman's rank correlation, Kaplan-Meier plots and Cox regression model were used to analyze the data.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: Overexpression of HEF1 protein was observed in HCC tissue when compared with their adjacent non-malignant liver tissue.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: High expression of HEF1 correlated with higher advanced tumor, node, metastasis (TNM) stage and vascular invasion (P<0.05).
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: In univariate and multivariate analysis, the expression of HEF1 was identified as an independent prognostic factor in the 123 patients with HCC.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: In subgroup analysis, high expression of HEF1 correlated with a poorer prognosis in advanced (TNM III+IV) stages (P<0.05).
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: These findings demonstrated the potential value of detecting the expression of HEF1 by immunohistochemistry as a prognostic biomarker and therapeutic target for patients with HCC.
title: High expression of HEF1 predicts a poorer prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma: A retrospective study.

text: Secondary point mutations in the Fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) tyrosine kinase domain (KD) are common causes of acquired clinical resistance to the FLT3 inhibitors AC220 (quizartinib) and sorafenib.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: Ponatinib (AP24534) is a multikinase inhibitor with in vitro and clinical activity in tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI)-resistant chronic myeloid leukemia, irrespective of BCR-ABL KD mutation.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: Ponatinib has demonstrated early clinical efficacy in chemotherapy-resistant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients with internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutations in FLT3.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: We assessed the in vitro activity of ponatinib against clinically relevant FLT3-ITD mutant isoforms that confer resistance to AC220 or sorafenib.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: Substitution of the FLT3 "gatekeeper" phenylalanine with leucine (F691L) conferred mild resistance to ponatinib, but substitutions at the FLT3 activation loop (AL) residue D835 conferred a high degree of resistance.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: Saturation mutagenesis of FLT3-ITD exclusively identified FLT3 AL mutations at positions D835, D839, and Y842.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: The switch control inhibitor DCC-2036 was similarly inactive against FLT3 AL mutations.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: On the basis of its in vitro activity against FLT3 TKI-resistant F691 substitutions, further clinical evaluation of ponatinib in TKI-naive and select TKI-resistant FLT3-ITD+ AML patients is warranted.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: Alternative strategies will be required for patients with TKI-resistant FLT3-ITD D835 mutations.
title: Activity of ponatinib against clinically-relevant AC220-resistant kinase domain mutants of FLT3-ITD.

text: Survivin, a structurally unique protein expressed in most common human neoplasms, is thought to support cell cycle progression and suppress apoptosis.
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Survivin expression is highly correlated with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and poor prognosis.
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In this retrospective study of banked pathology tissue of patients with advanced NSCLC, we tested for correlations of N-survivin expression in tumor tissues and responsiveness to treatment with platinum-based regimens containing paclitaxel or docetaxel.
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The 48 patients with NSCLC included 32 (66.7 %) males and 16 (33.3 %) females.
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Mean age at diagnosis was 59.4 years (range 36-83 years), and median follow-up time was 20.4 months (range 3.4-59.0 months).
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Patients with high tumor N-survivin expression had significantly better responses to taxane-platinum chemotherapy than those with low tumor N-survivin expression (P < 0.001).
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Adjusted multivariate modeling found high tumor N-survivin expression to be an independent prognostic factor for a clinical response to chemotherapy (high vs. low, OR 6.14, 95 % CI 1.62-23.29; P = 0.008).
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Median overall survival differed significantly between those with high tumor N-survivin expression who did/did not respond to chemotherapy and between those with low tumor N-survivin expression who did/did not respond to chemotherapy (P < 0.05).
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Tumor N-survivin expression shows promise as a predictive biomarker in the chemotherapy setting as a surrogate marker of high proliferation status.
title: Nuclear survivin expression: a prognostic factor for the response to taxane-platinum chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: INTRODUCTION: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) targeted to MET are undergoing clinical trials in patients with solid tumors, but the precise mechanism of the antitumor activity of these drugs remains unclear.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: We examined the antitumor action of the MET-TKI crizotinib (PF-02341066) in lung cancer cells that are positive or negative for MET amplification or mutation.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: METHODS: The antitumor action of crizotinib was evaluated on the basis of signal transduction, cell proliferation, apoptosis, and progression of tumor xenografts.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: RESULTS: Inhibition of MET signaling by crizotinib or by RNA interference-mediated MET depletion resulted in the induction of apoptosis accompanied by inhibition of AKT and extracellular signal-regulated kinase phosphorylation in lung cancer cells with MET amplification but not in cells with a MET mutation or in those without amplification or mutation of MET.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: These results suggest that MET signaling is essential for the survival of cells with MET amplification but not for that of cells without this genetic change, including those with a MET mutation.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: Crizotinib up-regulated the expression of BIM, a proapoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family, and down-regulated that of survivin, a member of the inhibitor of apoptosis protein family, in cells with MET amplification.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: Forced depletion of BIM and expression of survivin each inhibited crizotinib-induced apoptosis, suggesting that both up-regulation of BIM and down-regulation of survivin contribute to the proapoptotic effect of crizotinib.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Crizotinib shows a marked antitumor action in MET amplification-positive lung cancer cells but not in cells without MET amplification, including those with a MET mutation.
title: MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor crizotinib (PF-02341066) shows differential antitumor effects in non-small cell lung cancer according to MET alterations.

text: Lung cancers caused by activating mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) are initially responsive to small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs), but the efficacy of these agents is often limited because of the emergence of drug resistance conferred by a second mutation, T790M.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: Threonine 790 is the "gatekeeper" residue, an important determinant of inhibitor specificity in the ATP binding pocket.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: The T790M mutation has been thought to cause resistance by sterically blocking binding of TKIs such as gefitinib and erlotinib, but this explanation is difficult to reconcile with the fact that it remains sensitive to structurally similar irreversible inhibitors.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: Here, we show by using a direct binding assay that T790M mutants retain low-nanomolar affinity for gefitinib.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: Furthermore, we show that the T790M mutation activates WT EGFR and that introduction of the T790M mutation increases the ATP affinity of the oncogenic L858R mutant by more than an order of magnitude.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: The increased ATP affinity is the primary mechanism by which the T790M mutation confers drug resistance.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: Crystallographic analysis of the T790M mutant shows how it can adapt to accommodate tight binding of diverse inhibitors, including the irreversible inhibitor HKI-272, and also suggests a structural mechanism for catalytic activation.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: We conclude that the T790M mutation is a "generic" resistance mutation that will reduce the potency of any ATP-competitive kinase inhibitor and that irreversible inhibitors overcome this resistance simply through covalent binding, not as a result of an alternative binding mode.
title: The T790M mutation in EGFR kinase causes drug resistance by increasing the affinity for ATP.

text: BACKGROUND: Expression of programmed cell death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) is known to be a mechanism whereby cancer can escape immune surveillance, but little is known about factors predictive of efficacy in patients with locally advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: We investigated the predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression and CD8+ tumour-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) density in patients with locally advanced NSCLC receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT).
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed 74 consecutive patients with stage III NSCLC who had received CCRT.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: PD-L1 expression and CD8+ TIL density were evaluated by immunohistochemical analysis.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: RESULTS: Univariate and multivariate analyses demonstrated that CD8+ TIL density was an independent and significant predictive factor for progression-free survival (PFS) and OS, whereas PD-L1 expression was not correlated with PFS and OS.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: Sub-analysis revealed that the PD-L1+/CD8 low group had the shortest PFS (8.6 months, p = 0.02) and OS (13.9 months, p = 0.11), and that the PD-L1-/CD8 high group had the longest prognosis (median PFS and OS were not reached) by Kaplan-Meier curves of the four sub-groups.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Among stage III NSCLC patients who received CCRT, there was a trend for poor survival in those who expressed PD-L1.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: Our analysis indicated that a combination of lack of PD-L1 expression and CD8+ TIL density was significantly associated with favourable survival in these patients.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: It is proposed that PD-L1 expression in combination with CD8+ TIL density could be a useful predictive biomarker in patients with stage III NSCLC.
title: Predictive relevance of PD-L1 expression combined with CD8+ TIL density in stage III non-small cell lung cancer patients receiving concurrent chemoradiotherapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene cause multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A), and prophylactic thyroidectomy has generally been recommended before the age of 5 years.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: Patients with codon 609 mutations develop MTC at a later age and therefore the timing of prophylactic thyroidectomy is less clear.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: We report a three-generation family with C609Y RET mutation where members having prophylactic or therapeutic thyroidectomy call the current recommendations for age at thyroidectomy into question.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: METHODS: Sixteen family members underwent thyroidectomy, for which clinical, laboratory, and pathological data were analyzed.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: A literature review of RET codon 609 mutations was carried out.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: RESULTS: Data were collected from 16 patients from this 38-member kindred.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: None of these affected members had pheochromocytoma, and one had a parathyroid adenoma.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: Nine of 16 patients had MTC (mean age 44.7 years, range 29-59 years) and elevated basal calcitonin levels; 6 of these 9 had lymph node metastases.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: Two patients had C-cell hyperplasia (CCH) at ages 18 and 37 years, and five patients had normal thyroid pathology (mean age 16 years, range 5-37 years).
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: In the literature, a family with C609Y mutation was reported, with 15 members having MTC (mean age 42 years, range 21-59 years), and 6 with CCH (mean age 24 years, range 15-37 years).
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: CONCLUSION: The youngest patient with C609Y RET mutation and MTC was 21 years old, and the youngest patient with CCH was 15 years old at diagnosis.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: These data suggest that patients with RET C609Y mutations can delay thyroidectomy until 10-15 years of age, with annual calcitonin screening prior to thyroidectomy.
title: When is prophylactic thyroidectomy indicated for patients with the RET codon 609 mutation?

text: Isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1) is a metabolic enzyme implicated in cancer cell metabolic reprogramming.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: This is underscored by the detection of functional, somatic IDH1 mutations frequently found in secondary glioblastoma.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: To our knowledge, there has never been a reported, validated case of an IDH1 mutation in a pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA).
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: Herein, we present a case of a patient with metastatic PDA that harbored a potentially actionable, albeit rare, IDH1 mutation.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: As part of the Know Your Tumor project (Pancreatic Cancer Action Network), a 48-year-old female was diagnosed with metastatic PDA and subsequently started on standard of care chemotherapy, during which her hepatic lesions progressed.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: Detailed molecular profiling was performed on a biopsy from a liver lesion that demonstrated an IDH1 mutation, R132H.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: This mutation was confirmed by an independent sequencing reaction from the tumor sample, and by immunohistochemistry using an antibody specific for the IDH1 R132H mutation.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: The patient subsequently received a mutant IDH1 inhibitor (AG-120, Agios Pharmaceuticals, Cambridge, MA), but with no response.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: IDH1 mutations are common in certain cancer types, but have not been reported in PDA.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: We report the first case of an IDH1 mutation in this tumor type, perhaps providing a rare opportunity for a targeted therapy as a treatment option for PDA.
title: Identification of a novel metabolic-related mutation (IDH1) in metastatic pancreatic cancer.

text: Internal tandem duplication (ITD) of the fms-related tyrosine kinase-3 (FLT3) gene occurs in 30% of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) and confers a poor prognosis.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: Thirteen relapsed or chemo-refractory FLT3-ITD(+) AML patients were treated with sorafenib (200-400 mg twice daily).
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: Twelve patients showed clearance or near clearance of bone marrow myeloblasts after 27 (range 21-84) days with evidence of differentiation of leukemia cells.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: The sorafenib response was lost in most patients after 72 (range 54-287) days but the FLT3 and downstream effectors remained suppressed.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: Gene expression profiling showed that leukemia cells that have become sorafenib resistant expressed several genes including ALDH1A1, JAK3, and MMP15, whose functions were unknown in AML.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: Nonobese diabetic/severe combined immunodeficiency mice transplanted with leukemia cells from patients before and during sorafenib resistance recapitulated the clinical results.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: Both ITD and tyrosine kinase domain mutations at D835 were identified in leukemia initiating cells (LICs) from samples before sorafenib treatment.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: LICs bearing the D835 mutant have expanded during sorafenib treatment and dominated during the subsequent clinical resistance.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: These results suggest that sorafenib have selected more aggressive sorafenib-resistant subclones carrying both FLT3-ITD and D835 mutations, and might provide important leads to further improvement of treatment outcome with FLT3 inhibitors.
title: Sorafenib treatment of FLT3-ITD(+) acute myeloid leukemia: favorable initial outcome and mechanisms of subsequent nonresponsiveness associated with the emergence of a D835 mutation.

text: The prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse large cell lymphomas (DLCL) is controversial.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Bcl-2 protein expression prevents apoptosis and may have an important role in clinical drug resistance.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: The presence of a bcl-2 gene rearrangement in de novo DLCL suggests a possible follicle center cell origin and perhaps a distinct clinical behavior more akin to low-grade non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL).
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: The purpose of this study was to determine the impact of Bcl-2 protein expression and bcl-2 gene rearrangement (mbr and mcr) on survival of a cohort of patients with DLCL who were uniformly evaluated and treated with effective chemotherapy.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Patients included the original MACOP-B cohort (n = 121) and the initial 18 patients treated with the VACOP-B regimen (total = 139).
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: All patients had advanced-stage disease, were 16 to 70 years old, and corresponded to Working Formulation categories F, G, or H. No patients had prior treatment, discordant lymphoma, or human immunodeficiency virus seropositivity.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Paraffin sections from diagnostic biopsies were analyzed for bcl-2 gene rearrangement including mbr and mcr breakpoints by polymerase chain reaction and Bcl-2 protein expression by immunohistochemistry.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: With a median follow-up of 81 months, overall (OS), disease-free (DFS), and relapse-free survival (RFS) were measured to determine the prognostic significance of these parameters.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Analyzable DNA was present in 118 of 139 (85%) cases, with 14 demonstrating a bcl-2 rearrangement (11 mbr, 3 mcr).
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: All 14 of these bcl-2 gene rearrangement-positive cases were found in the 102 patients with a B-cell immunophenotype, but the presence of this rearrangement had no significant influence on survival.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Bcl-2 protein expression was interpretable in 116 of 139 (83%) cases, with immunopositivity detected in 54 of 116 (47%).
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Using a cut-off of greater than 10% Bcl-2 immunopositive tumor cells for analysis, positive Bcl-2 protein expression was seen in 28 of 116 (24%) patients and the presence of this expression correlated with decreased 8-year OS (34% v 60%, P < .01), DFS (32% v 66%, P < .001), and RFS (25% v 59%, P < .001).
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: Bcl-2 protein expression remained significant in multivariate analysis that included the clinical international prognostic index factors and immunophenotype (P < .02).
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: In conclusion, although bcl-2 gene rearrangement status could not be shown to have an impact on outcome, Bcl-2 protein expression is a strong significant predictor of OS, DFS, and RFS in DLCLs.
title: Prognostic significance of Bcl-2 protein expression and Bcl-2 gene rearrangement in diffuse aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitors have activity in ovarian carcinomas with homologous recombination deficiency.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Along with BRCA1 and BRCA2 (BRCA) mutations genomic loss of heterozygosity (LOH) might also represent homologous recombination deficiency.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: In ARIEL2, we assessed the ability of tumour genomic LOH, quantified with a next-generation sequencing assay, to predict response to rucaparib, an oral PARP inhibitor.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: METHODS: ARIEL2 is an international, multicentre, two-part, phase 2, open-label study done at 49 hospitals and cancer centres in Australia, Canada, France, Spain, the UK, and the USA.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: In ARIEL2 Part 1, patients with recurrent, platinum-sensitive, high-grade ovarian carcinoma were classified into one of three predefined homologous recombination deficiency subgroups on the basis of tumour mutational analysis: BRCA mutant (deleterious germline or somatic), BRCA wild-type and LOH high (LOH high group), or BRCA wild-type and LOH low (LOH low group).
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: We prespecified a cutoff of 14% or more genomic LOH for LOH high.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Patients began treatment with oral rucaparib at 600 mg twice per day for continuous 28 day cycles until disease progression or any other reason for discontinuation.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was progression-free survival.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: All patients treated with at least one dose of rucaparib were included in the safety analyses and all treated patients who were classified were included in the primary endpoint analysis.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01891344.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Enrolment into ARIEL2 Part 1 is complete, although an extension (Part 2) is ongoing.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: FINDINGS: 256 patients were screened and 206 were enrolled between Oct 30, 2013, and Dec 19, 2014.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: At the data cutoff date (Jan 18, 2016), 204 patients had received rucaparib, with 28 patients remaining in the study.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: 192 patients could be classified into one of the three predefined homologous recombination deficiency subgroups: BRCA mutant (n=40), LOH high (n=82), or LOH low (n=70).
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Tumours from 12 patients were established as BRCA wild-type, but could not be classified for LOH, because of insufficient neoplastic nuclei in the sample.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: The median duration of treatment for the 204 patients was 5.7 months (IQR 2.8-10.1).
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: 24 patients in the BRCA mutant subgroup, 56 patients in the LOH high subgroup, and 59 patients in the LOH low subgroup had disease progression or died.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Median progression-free survival after rucaparib treatment was 12.8 months (95% CI 9.0-14.7) in the BRCA mutant subgroup, 5.7 months (5.3-7.6) in the LOH high subgroup, and 5.2 months (3.6-5.5) in the LOH low subgroup.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Progression-free survival was significantly longer in the BRCA mutant (hazard ratio 0.27, 95% CI 0.16-0.44, p<0.0001) and LOH high (0.62, 0.42-0.90, p=0.011) subgroups compared with the LOH low subgroup.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: The most common grade 3 or worse treatment-emergent adverse events were anaemia or decreased haemoglobin (45 [22%] patients), and elevations in alanine aminotransferase or aspartate aminotransferase (25 [12%]).
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Common serious adverse events included small intestinal obstruction (10 [5%] of 204 patients), malignant neoplasm progression (10 [5%]), and anaemia (nine [4%]).
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Three patients died during the study (two because of disease progression and one because of sepsis and disease progression).
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: No treatment-related deaths occurred.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: In patients with BRCA mutant or BRCA wild-type and LOH high platinum-sensitive ovarian carcinomas treated with rucaparib, progression-free survival was longer than in patients with BRCA wild-type LOH low carcinomas.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Our results suggest that assessment of tumour LOH can be used to identify patients with BRCA wild-type platinum-sensitive ovarian cancers who might benefit from rucaparib.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: These results extend the potential usefulness of PARP inhibitors in the treatment setting beyond BRCA mutant tumours.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: FUNDING: Clovis Oncology, US Department of Defense Ovarian Cancer Research Program, Stand Up To Cancer-Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Alliance-National Ovarian Cancer Coalition Dream Team Translational Research Grant, and V Foundation Translational Award.
title: Rucaparib in relapsed, platinum-sensitive high-grade ovarian carcinoma (ARIEL2 Part 1): an international, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Follicular lymphoma (FL) and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) are the two most common non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs).
title: Frequent mutation of histone-modifying genes in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: Here we sequenced tumour and matched normal DNA from 13 DLBCL cases and one FL case to identify genes with mutations in B-cell NHL.
title: Frequent mutation of histone-modifying genes in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: We analysed RNA-seq data from these and another 113 NHLs to identify genes with candidate mutations, and then re-sequenced tumour and matched normal DNA from these cases to confirm 109 genes with multiple somatic mutations.
title: Frequent mutation of histone-modifying genes in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: Genes with roles in histone modification were frequent targets of somatic mutation.
title: Frequent mutation of histone-modifying genes in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: For example, 32% of DLBCL and 89% of FL cases had somatic mutations in MLL2, which encodes a histone methyltransferase, and 11.4% and 13.4% of DLBCL and FL cases, respectively, had mutations in MEF2B, a calcium-regulated gene that cooperates with CREBBP and EP300 in acetylating histones.
title: Frequent mutation of histone-modifying genes in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: Our analysis suggests a previously unappreciated disruption of chromatin biology in lymphomagenesis.
title: Frequent mutation of histone-modifying genes in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

text: PURPOSE: To assess the prognostic relevance of mutations in the CEBPA gene encoding CCAAT/enhancer binding protein alpha (C/EBP alpha) in a large prospective series of younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and normal cytogenetics.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: The entire CEBPA coding region was sequenced in diagnostic samples from 236 AML patients 16 to 60 years of age with normal cytogenetics who were uniformly treated on two consecutive protocols of the AML Study Group Ulm, and CEBPA mutation status was correlated with clinical outcome.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: RESULTS: CEBPA mutations were detected in 36 (15%) of 236 patients.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: Twenty-one (9%) of 236 patients had mutations predicted to result in loss of C/EBP alpha function.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: Remission duration and overall survival (OS) were significantly longer for the 36 patients with CEBPA mutations (P =.01 and P =.05, respectively).
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: On multivariate analysis, wild-type CEBPA was an independent prognostic marker affecting remission duration (hazard ratio, 2.85; P =.01) and OS (hazard ratio, 1.87; P =.04).
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: Analysis of cooperating mutations (both types of activating FLT3 mutations and MLL partial tandem duplications) showed that FLT3 mutations had no significant prognostic influence in patients with CEBPA mutations.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: Furthermore, there was no significant overlap between the subgroup of patients with CEBPA mutation with predicted loss of C/EBP alpha function and patients with FLT3 or MLL mutations, suggesting that CEBPA loss-of-function mutations define a distinct biologic subclass of AML with normal cytogenetics.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: CONCLUSION: Mutant CEBPA predicts favorable prognosis and may improve risk stratification in AML patients with normal cytogenetics.
title: CEBPA mutations in younger adults with acute myeloid leukemia and normal cytogenetics: prognostic relevance and analysis of cooperating mutations.

text: The role of HER4 in breast cancer is controversial and its role in relation to trastuzumab resistance remains unclear.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: We showed that trastuzumab treatment and its acquired resistance induced HER4 upregulation, cleavage and nuclear translocation.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: However, knockdown of HER4 by specific siRNAs increased trastuzumab sensitivity and reversed its resistance in HER2 positive breast cancer cells.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: Preventing HER4 cleavage by a gamma-secretase inhibitor and inhibiting HER4 tyrosine kinase activity by neratinib decreased trastuzumab-induced HER4 nuclear translocation and enhanced trastuzumab response.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: There was also increased nuclear HER4 staining in the tumours from BT474 xenograft mice and human patients treated with trastuzumab.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: Furthermore, nuclear HER4 predicted poor clinical response to trastuzumab monotherapy in patients undergoing a window study and was shown to be an independent poor prognostic factor in HER2 positive breast cancer.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: Our data suggest that HER4 plays a key role in relation to trastuzumab resistance in HER2 positive breast cancer.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: Therefore, our study provides novel findings that HER4 activation, cleavage and nuclear translocation influence trastuzumab sensitivity and resistance in HER2 positive breast cancer.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: Nuclear HER4 could be a potential prognostic and predictive biomarker and understanding the role of HER4 may provide strategies to overcome trastuzumab resistance in HER2 positive breast cancer.
title: Nuclear HER4 mediates acquired resistance to trastuzumab and is associated with poor outcome in HER2 positive breast cancer.

text: Hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha is a transcription factor that supports the adaptation of human cancer cells to hypoxia and tumor growth and progression.
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: The overexpression of HIF-1alpha protein has been reported to be associated with a worse prognosis in various cancers.
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: However, the expression of HIF-1alpha in soft-tissue sarcomas has not yet been characterized.
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: The expression of HIF-1alpha protein was immunohistochemically determined in 49 specimens of soft-tissue sarcomas including malignant fibrous histiocytoma (29 patients), synovial sarcoma (12 patients), leiomyosarcoma (four patients), and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (four patients).
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: The 49 samples consisted of 40 primary lesions and nine local recurrences.
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: An immunohistochemical analysis showed the nuclear accumulation of HIF-1alpha protein in 35 (71.4%) samples.
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: The expression of HIF-1alpha was negative in 14 (28.6%) cases, weak in nine (18.4%), moderate in 17 (35.4%), and strong in nine (18.4%).
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: The patients with a strong or moderate expression of HIF-1alpha had a significantly shorter overall survival rate in comparison with those with a weak or negative expression in a univariate analysis (P = 0.029; log-rank test) and multivariate analysis (P = 0.018).
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: This is the first report that demonstrated an overexpression of HIF-1alpha protein to be an independent prognostic factor for soft-tissue sarcomas.
title: Expression of hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1alpha as a biomarker of outcome in soft-tissue sarcomas.

text: BACKGROUND: Dabrafenib is an inhibitor of BRAF kinase that is selective for mutant BRAF.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: We aimed to assess its safety and tolerability and to establish a recommended phase 2 dose in patients with incurable solid tumours, especially those with melanoma and untreated, asymptomatic brain metastases.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: METHODS: We undertook a phase 1 trial between May 27, 2009, and March 20, 2012, at eight study centres in Australia and the USA.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Eligible patients had incurable solid tumours, were 18 years or older, and had adequate organ function.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: BRAF mutations were mandatory for inclusion later in the study because of an absence of activity in patients with wild-type BRAF.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: We used an accelerated dose titration method, with the first dose cohort receiving 12 mg dabrafenib daily in a 21-day cycle.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Once doses had been established, we expanded the cohorts to include up to 20 patients.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: On the basis of initial data, we chose a recommended phase 2 dose.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Efficacy at the recommended phase 2 dose was studied in patients with BRAF-mutant tumours, including those with non-Val600Glu mutations, in three cohorts: metastatic melanoma, melanoma with untreated brain metastases, and non-melanoma solid tumours.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00880321.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: FINDINGS: We enrolled 184 patients, of whom 156 had metastatic melanoma.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: The most common treatment-related adverse events of grade 2 or worse were cutaneous squamous-cell carcinoma (20 patients, 11%), fatigue (14, 8%), and pyrexia (11, 6%).
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Dose reductions were necessary in 13 (7%) patients.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: No deaths or discontinuations resulted from adverse events, and 140 (76%) patients had no treatment-related adverse events worse than grade 2.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Doses were increased to 300 mg twice daily, with no maximum tolerated dose recorded.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: On the basis of safety, pharmacokinetic, and response data, we selected a recommended phase 2 dose of 150 mg twice daily.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: At the recommended phase 2 dose in 36 patients with Val600 BRAF-mutant melanoma, responses were reported in 25 (69%, 95% CI 51.9-83.7) and confirmed responses in 18 (50%, 32.9-67.1).
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: 21 (78%, 57.7-91.4) of 27 patients with Val600Glu BRAF-mutant melanoma responded and 15 (56%, 35.3-74.5) had a confirmed response.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: In Val600 BRAF-mutant melanoma, responses were durable, with 17 patients (47%) on treatment for more than 6 months.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: Responses were recorded in patients with non-Val600Glu BRAF mutations.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: In patients with melanoma and untreated brain metastases, nine of ten patients had reductions in size of brain lesions.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: In 28 patients with BRAF-mutant non-melanoma solid tumours, apparent antitumour activity was noted in a gastrointestinal stromal tumour, papillary thyroid cancers, non-small-cell lung cancer, ovarian cancer, and colorectal cancer.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Dabrafenib is safe in patients with solid tumours, and an active inhibitor of Val600-mutant BRAF with responses noted in patients with melanoma, brain metastases, and other solid tumours.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: FUNDING: GlaxoSmithKline.
title: Dabrafenib in patients with melanoma, untreated brain metastases, and other solid tumours: a phase 1 dose-escalation trial.

text: OBJECTIVE: The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitors monoclonal antibodies (MoAbs) have already shown the therapeutic effectiveness in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: But many patients resist to the treatment.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: The aim of this meta-analysis was to assess EGFR gene copy number (GCN) as a candidate predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR MoAbs in mCRC treatment.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: Systematic computerized searches of the PubMed, EMBase and Cochrane Library were performed.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: The primary endpoint was objective response rate (ORR).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: The second endpoints included progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: The pooled odd ratio (OR) and pooled sensitivity, specificity, and summary receiver operator characteristic (SROC) for ORR were estimated.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: The pooled hazard ratios (HR) for PFS and OS were also calculated.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Fourteen studies with 1,021 patients were included.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: Increased EGFR GCN was associated with increased ORR (OR=6.905; 95% CI: 4.489-10.620).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: It was also found in wild-type KRAS mCRC patients, with the pooled OR of 8.133 (95% CI: 4.316-15.326).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: GCN has medium value for predicting ORR, with the pooled sensitivity of 0.79 (95% CI: 0.73-0.84), the pooled specificity of 0.59 (95% CI: 0.55-0.62).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: In wild-type KRAS mCRC patients, the sensitivity and the specificity were 0.80 (95% CI: 0.70-0.87) and 0.60 (95% CI: 0.53-0.66), respectively.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: Increased EGFR GCN was associated with increased PFS (HR=0.557; 95% CI: 0.382-0.732) and OS (HR=0.579; 95% CI: 0.422-0.737).
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This meta-analysis suggests that EGFR GCN represents a predictive biomarker for tumor response in mCRC patients treated with MoAbs regardless of KRAS mutation.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: mCRC patients with increased EGFR GCN are more likely to have a better response, PFS, and OS when treated with cetuximab or panitumumab.
title: EGFR gene copy number as a predictive biomarker for resistance to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies in metastatic colorectal cancer treatment: a meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: Nucleophosmin (NPM), a nucleocytoplasmic shuttling protein with prominent nucleolar localization, regulates the ARF-p53 tumor-suppressor pathway.
