title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: Translocations involving the NPM gene cause cytoplasmic dislocation of the NPM protein.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: METHODS: We used immunohistochemical methods to study the subcellular localization of NPM in bone marrow-biopsy specimens from 591 patients with primary acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: We then correlated the presence of cytoplasmic NPM with clinical and biologic features of the disease.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: RESULTS: Cytoplasmic NPM was detected in 208 (35.2 percent) of the 591 specimens from patients with primary AML but not in 135 secondary AML specimens or in 980 hematopoietic or extrahematopoietic neoplasms other than AML.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: It was associated with a wide spectrum of morphologic subtypes of the disease, a normal karyotype, and responsiveness to induction chemotherapy, but not with recurrent genetic abnormalities.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: There was a high frequency of FLT3 internal tandem duplications and absence of CD34 and CD133 in AML specimens with a normal karyotype and cytoplasmic dislocation of NPM, but not in those in which the protein was restricted to the nucleus.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: AML specimens with cytoplasmic NPM carried mutations of the NPM gene that were predicted to alter the protein at its C-terminal; this mutant gene caused cytoplasmic localization of NPM in transfected cells.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Cytoplasmic NPM is a characteristic feature of a large subgroup of patients with AML who have a normal karyotype, NPM gene mutations, and responsiveness to induction chemotherapy.
title: Cytoplasmic nucleophosmin in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: Activation of the MET proto-oncogene (MET) highly sensitive to MET inhibition has recently been described in NSCLC through two mechanisms: high-level amplification of the MNNG HOS Transforming gene (MET) (usually expressed relative to the chromosome 7 centromere [CEP7] when using fluorescence in situ hybridization) and exon 14 alterations.
title: Responses to Crizotinib Can Occur in High-Level MET-Amplified Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Independent of MET Exon 14 Alterations.

text: As partial overlap of these biomarkers occurs, whether one is purely a surrogate for the other or both can represent true oncogenic driver states continues to be explored.
title: Responses to Crizotinib Can Occur in High-Level MET-Amplified Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Independent of MET Exon 14 Alterations.

text: Cases of MET inhibitor-sensitive NSCLC harboring exon 14 alterations without coincident amplification have already been described.
title: Responses to Crizotinib Can Occur in High-Level MET-Amplified Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Independent of MET Exon 14 Alterations.

text: Here we report two cases of MET inhibitor-sensitive NSCLC harboring high-level MET amplification (MET/CEP7 ratio >/=5) without coincident exon 14 alterations, suggesting that these two methods of MET activation can produce independent MET-addicted states in NSCLC.
title: Responses to Crizotinib Can Occur in High-Level MET-Amplified Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Independent of MET Exon 14 Alterations.

text: Molecular profiling designed to capture all cases of potentially MET-addicted NSCLC should address both activation mechanisms.
title: Responses to Crizotinib Can Occur in High-Level MET-Amplified Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Independent of MET Exon 14 Alterations.

text: Most patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis (SM) are characterized by somatic mutations in additional genes.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: We sought to clarify the prognostic impact of such mutations.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: Genotype and clinical characteristics of 70 multi-mutated KIT D816V(+) advanced SM patients were included in univariate and multivariate analyses.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: The most frequently identified mutated genes were TET2 (n=33 of 70 patients), SRSF2 (n=30), ASXL1 (n=20), RUNX1 (n=16) and JAK2 (n=11).
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: In univariate analysis, overall survival (OS) was adversely influenced by mutations in SRSF2 (P<0.0001), ASXL1 (P=0.002) and RUNX1 (P=0.03), but was not influenced by mutations in TET2 or JAK2.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: In multivariate analysis, SRSF2 and ASXL1 remained the most predictive adverse indicators concerning OS.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: Furthermore, we found that inferior OS and adverse clinical characteristics were significantly influenced by the number of mutated genes in the SRSF2/ASXL1/RUNX1 (S/A/R) panel (P<0.0001).
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: In conclusion, the presence and number of mutated genes within the S/A/R panel are adversely associated with advanced disease and poor survival in KIT D816V(+) SM.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: On the basis of these findings, inclusion of molecular markers should be considered in upcoming prognostic scoring systems for patients with SM.
title: Additional mutations in SRSF2, ASXL1 and/or RUNX1 identify a high-risk group of patients with KIT D816V(+) advanced systemic mastocytosis.

text: Epigenetic proteins are intently pursued targets in ligand discovery.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: So far, successful efforts have been limited to chromatin modifying enzymes, or so-called epigenetic 'writers' and 'erasers'.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: Potent inhibitors of histone binding modules have not yet been described.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: Here we report a cell-permeable small molecule (JQ1) that binds competitively to acetyl-lysine recognition motifs, or bromodomains.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: High potency and specificity towards a subset of human bromodomains is explained by co-crystal structures with bromodomain and extra-terminal (BET) family member BRD4, revealing excellent shape complementarity with the acetyl-lysine binding cavity.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: Recurrent translocation of BRD4 is observed in a genetically-defined, incurable subtype of human squamous carcinoma.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: Competitive binding by JQ1 displaces the BRD4 fusion oncoprotein from chromatin, prompting squamous differentiation and specific antiproliferative effects in BRD4-dependent cell lines and patient-derived xenograft models.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: These data establish proof-of-concept for targeting protein-protein interactions of epigenetic 'readers', and provide a versatile chemical scaffold for the development of chemical probes more broadly throughout the bromodomain family.
title: Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains.

text: BACKGROUND: Genomic studies in small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) lag far behind those carried out in nonsmall-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: To date, most SCLC studies have evaluated patients with surgically resectable disease.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: Here we sought to evaluate the genomic mutation spectrum of 'every-day' SCLC patient tumors with extensive stage disease (ES-SCLC) and to correlate mutations with the main clinical outcomes of response to chemotherapy, progression-free (PFS) and overall (OS) survival.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: A total of 50 SCLC patient tumors were examined in this study; targeted exome sequencing was obtained on 42 patients and whole-exome sequencing on 8 patients.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: Mutated genes were correlated with clinical outcomes using Kaplan-Meier methods (PFS, OS) and logistic regression (chemo-response).
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: RB1 protein expression was detected by either western blotting of cultured cell lysates or immunohistochemistry of tumor specimens.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: RESULTS: In all, 39 patients had ES-SCLC; 15 patients had either primary refractory/resistant disease and 21 patients had sensitive disease.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: The two most frequently mutated genes were TP53 (86%) and RB1 (58%); other frequently mutated genes (>10% patients) were involved in epigenetic regulation as well as the mTOR pathway.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: We identified a number of low-frequency, targetable mutations, including RICTOR, FGFR1, KIT, PTCH1 and RET.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: Using multivariate analysis, RB1 was the only significant factor (P = 0.038) in predicting response to first-line chemotherapy, with an odds ratio of 5.58 comparing mutant RB1 with wild-type.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: Patients with mutant RB1 had both better OS (11.7 versus 9.1 months P = 0.04) and PFS (11.2 versus 8.6 months, P = 0.06) compared with patients with wild-type RB1.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: Interestingly, approximately 25% of SCLC cell lines and tumor specimens expressed RB1 protein, possibly representing the subgroup with wild-type RB1.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We found that SCLC tumors harboring no mutation in RB1 had a poor response to chemotherapy.
title: Clinical correlation of extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer genomics.

text: Expression of cyclins D1 and D2, as well as cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (cdk4), was investigated by means of immunohistochemistry in 455 gastric cancer cases.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Additional western blotting was performed for four breast cancer and four gastric cancer cell lines and 35 fresh frozen gastric cancer samples, to confirm the cyclin D1, D2, and cdk4 data.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Cyclin D1 was restricted to the nucleus of cancer cells with a few exceptions, whereas cyclin D2 was present in both cell compartments, but predominantly in the cytoplasm.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Cdk4 was intermediately expressed.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Cyclin D1 was overexpressed in 93 cases (20.4 per cent) and cyclin D2 in 105 (23.0 per cent).
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: In the cyclin D2 cases, this correlated with greater age (p=0.0004), better differentiation (p=0.0023), greater depth of cancer invasion (p=0.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: 003), the presence of lymph node metastasis (p=0.0014), vascular invasion by cancer cells (p< 0.0001), and poor prognosis (p< 0.0001), while cyclin D1 did not correlate with any of these except age (p=0.00193).
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Multivariate analysis revealed cyclin D2 overexpression to be an independent prognostic factor, in addition to depth of cancer invasion and lymph node status.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Cdk4 overexpression was linked to cyclin D1, but not cyclin D2 overexpression.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: The results indicate that cyclin D2 up-regulation plays an important role in the progression and prognosis of gastric cancer independently of cdk4, whereas cyclin D1 overexpression does not.
title: Cyclin D2, but not cyclin D1, overexpression closely correlates with gastric cancer progression and prognosis.

text: Increased nuclear accumulation of beta-catenin, a mediator of canonical Wnt signaling, is found in numerous tumors and is frequently associated with tumor progression and metastasis.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: Inhibition of Wnt/beta-catenin signaling therefore is an attractive strategy for anticancer drugs.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: In this study, we have identified a novel small molecule inhibitor of the beta-catenin signaling pathway, JW55, that functions via inhibition of the PARP domain of tankyrase 1 and tankyrase 2 (TNKS1/2), regulators of the beta-catenin destruction complex.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: Inhibition of TNKS1/2 poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation activity by JW55 led to stabilization of AXIN2, a member of the beta-catenin destruction complex, followed by increased degradation of beta-catenin.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: In a dose-dependent manner, JW55 inhibited canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells that contained mutations in either the APC (adenomatous polyposis coli) locus or in an allele of beta-catenin.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: In addition, JW55 reduced XWnt8-induced axis duplication in Xenopus embryos and tamoxifen-induced polyposis formation in conditional APC mutant mice.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: Together, our findings provide a novel chemotype for targeting canonical Wnt/beta-catenin signaling through inhibiting the PARP domain of TNKS1/2.
title: A novel tankyrase inhibitor decreases canonical Wnt signaling in colon carcinoma cells and reduces tumor growth in conditional APC mutant mice.

text: The clinical presentation and characterization of the mutation in members of a large kindred with von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHLD) and pheochromocytoma were examined.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: Twenty-five proven cases of VHLD occurring in four generations of a large kindred have been followed since 1964, and pheochromocytoma has occurred in 17.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: Symptoms of pheochromocytoma developed at an early age, on average at 12.5 +/- 1.3 yr, and definitive diagnosis and treatment of pheochromocytoma occurred at 19.9 +/- 2.6 yr.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: Significantly higher urine catecholamine concentrations were observed in younger patients than in older ones.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: Mutation analysis was performed in 14 family members, and a new mutation in the VHLD gene was identified in 11; this mutation is a G to T change at nucleotide 658 that results in the substitution of a serine for an alanine residue at position 149 of the polypeptide chain.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: Seven of the 11 patients with the mutation have VHLD; four, all 10 yr old or less, are asymptomatic and have no evidence of disease, but are at high risk for developing VHLD.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: These children are being followed closely for clinical and biochemical manifestations.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: The characterization of this new mutation has permitted identification of family members who are likely to develop VHLD.
title: Pheochromocytoma in von Hippel-Lindau disease: clinical presentation and mutation analysis in a large, multigenerational kindred.

text: Breast cancer is the most prevalent cancer in women, and over two-thirds of cases express estrogen receptor-alpha (ER-alpha, encoded by ESR1).
title: Activating ESR1 mutations in hormone-resistant metastatic breast cancer.

text: Through a prospective clinical sequencing program for advanced cancers, we enrolled 11 patients with ER-positive metastatic breast cancer.
title: Activating ESR1 mutations in hormone-resistant metastatic breast cancer.

text: Whole-exome and transcriptome analysis showed that six cases harbored mutations of ESR1 affecting its ligand-binding domain (LBD), all of whom had been treated with anti-estrogens and estrogen deprivation therapies.
title: Activating ESR1 mutations in hormone-resistant metastatic breast cancer.

text: A survey of The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) identified four endometrial cancers with similar mutations of ESR1.
title: Activating ESR1 mutations in hormone-resistant metastatic breast cancer.

text: The five new LBD-localized ESR1 mutations identified here (encoding p.Leu536Gln, p.Tyr537Ser, p.Tyr537Cys, p.Tyr537Asn and p.Asp538Gly) were shown to result in constitutive activity and continued responsiveness to anti-estrogen therapies in vitro.
title: Activating ESR1 mutations in hormone-resistant metastatic breast cancer.

text: Taken together, these studies suggest that activating mutations in ESR1 are a key mechanism in acquired endocrine resistance in breast cancer therapy.
title: Activating ESR1 mutations in hormone-resistant metastatic breast cancer.

text: AIM OF THE STUDY: The BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib has improved progression-free survival and overall survival in patients with BRAFV600-mutation-positive metastatic melanoma.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: Here we present the results of an open-label safety study with vemurafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma enrolled in Polish oncological centres.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: MATERIAL AND METHODS: Patients with untreated or previously treated Stage IIIC/IV BRAFV600 mutation-positive melanoma were treated with oral vemurafenib in an initial dose of 960 mg twice daily.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: Assessments for safety and efficacy were made every 28 days.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: For the survival analysis the Kaplan-Meier estimator was used with the log-rank tests for bivariate comparisons.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: RESULTS: In total, 75 Polish patients were enrolled in the safety study across four centres.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: At data cut-off, 28 patients died (37%), mainly (26) due to disease progression; 33 (44%) patients continued vemurafenib after disease progression.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: The objective response rate was 46%, including two patients with a complete response and 29 with a partial response.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: Median progression-free survival was 7.4 months.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: The one-year overall survival rate was 61.9% (median overall survival was not reached).
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: Seventy-three (97.3%) patients reported adverse events (AEs), and grade 3-5 toxicity was reported in 49.4% (37) patients.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: The most common AEs were: skin lesions (including rash and photosensitivity), arthralgia, and fatigue.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The overall safety profile and response rate of vemurafenib were comparable to those reported in previous studies of this drug.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: Our study confirmed the value of well-established prognostic features for overall survival, such as initial LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) level and AJCC staging.
title: The outcomes of Polish patients with advanced BRAF-positive melanoma treated with vemurafenib in a safety clinical trial.

text: PURPOSE: FBXW7 is a tumor suppressor gene responsible for the degradation of several proto-oncogenes.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: Preclinical data suggest that FBXW7 mutations sensitize cells to mTOR inhibitors.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: Clinicopathologic characteristics of cancer patients with FBXW7 mutations and their responses to mTOR inhibitors remain unknown.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: METHODS: Using multiplex gene panels we evaluated how the FBXW7 mutation affected the cancer phenotype of patients referred to a phase I clinic starting January 2012.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: Whenever possible patients positive for FBXW7 mutation were treated with regimens containing an mTOR inhibitors and their outcomes were reviewed.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: RESULTS: FBXW7 mutations were detected in 17 of 418 patients (4.0%).
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: Among tumor types with more than 10 patients tested, FBXW7 mutations occurred in colorectal cancer (7/49; 14.3%), squamous cell cancer of head and neck (2/18; 11.1%), liver (1/13; 7.7%), and ovarian cancers (1/40; 2.5%).
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: No one clinical, pathological or demographic feature was characteristic of the FBXW7-mutated patient population.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: The mutation occurred in isolation in only 2/17 (12%) patients, and KRAS was frequently found as a concomitant mutation, especially in patients with colorectal cancer (6/7; 86%).
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: Ten patients were treated on a protocol containing an mTOR inhibitor, with a median time to treatment failure of 2.8 months (range, 1.3-6.8).
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: One patient with liver cancer (fibrolamellar subtype) continues to have a prolonged stable disease for 6.8+ months.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: CONCLUSION: In patients with advanced cancers, somatic mutations in FBXW7 usually occur with other simultaneous molecular aberrations, which can contribute to limited therapeutic efficacy of mTOR inhibitors.
title: FBXW7 mutations in patients with advanced cancers: clinical and molecular characteristics and outcomes with mTOR inhibitors.

text: Small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT) is a rare, highly aggressive form of ovarian cancer primarily diagnosed in young women.
title: Recurrent SMARCA4 mutations in small cell carcinoma of the ovary.

text: We identified inactivating biallelic SMARCA4 mutations in 100% of the 12 SCCOHT tumors examined.
title: Recurrent SMARCA4 mutations in small cell carcinoma of the ovary.

text: Protein studies confirmed loss of SMARCA4 expression, suggesting a key role for the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex in SCCOHT.
title: Recurrent SMARCA4 mutations in small cell carcinoma of the ovary.

text: INTRODUCTION: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibition is the preferred first-line treatment of advanced adenocarcinoma of the lung that harbors EGFR activating tyrosine kinase domain mutations.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: Most data available pertain to Asian populations in which such mutations are more prevalent.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: We report on the long-term results of first-line treatment with erlotinib in Caucasian patients with advanced adenocarcinoma of the lung that have a somatic EGFR mutation in their tumor.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: METHODS: Multicenter academic prospective phase II study with erlotinib in patients with an activating EGFR tyrosine kinase (TK) domain somatic mutation (any exon encoding the kinase domain) in the tumor and no prior treatment for their advanced disease.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: RESULTS: Phenotypic preselecting of 229 patients led to a high EGFR mutation detection rate of 24% of which 46 patients were included in the phase II study.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: With a progression free survival (PFS) of 81% at three months the study met its primary endpoint for presumed superiority over chemotherapy.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: With an overall median PFS of 11 months and a median overall survival (OS) of 23 months, the results compare favorably with results obtained in randomized studies using TKI in first line in EGFR mutation positive adenocarcinoma of the lung.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: CONCLUSION: The present study reinforces the use of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibition (TKI) as a first line treatment of choice for advanced adenocarcinoma of the lung carrying an activating EGFR mutation.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: The mutation rate in preselected Caucasian patients is higher than previously reported.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: Issues relevant for clinical practice are discussed.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00339586.
title: Prospective Evaluation of First-Line Erlotinib in Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) Carrying an Activating EGFR Mutation: A Multicenter Academic Phase II Study in Caucasian Patients (FIELT).

text: BACKGROUND: Prostate cancer is a heterogeneous disease, but current treatments are not based on molecular stratification.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: We hypothesized that metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancers with DNA-repair defects would respond to poly(adenosine diphosphate [ADP]-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibition with olaparib.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: METHODS: We conducted a phase 2 trial in which patients with metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer were treated with olaparib tablets at a dose of 400 mg twice a day.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: The primary end point was the response rate, defined either as an objective response according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors, version 1.1, or as a reduction of at least 50% in the prostate-specific antigen level or a confirmed reduction in the circulating tumor-cell count from 5 or more cells per 7.5 ml of blood to less than 5 cells per 7.5 ml.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: Targeted next-generation sequencing, exome and transcriptome analysis, and digital polymerase-chain-reaction testing were performed on samples from mandated tumor biopsies.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Overall, 50 patients were enrolled; all had received prior treatment with docetaxel, 49 (98%) had received abiraterone or enzalutamide, and 29 (58%) had received cabazitaxel.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: Sixteen of 49 patients who could be evaluated had a response (33%; 95% confidence interval, 20 to 48), with 12 patients receiving the study treatment for more than 6 months.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: Next-generation sequencing identified homozygous deletions, deleterious mutations, or both in DNA-repair genes--including BRCA1/2, ATM, Fanconi's anemia genes, and CHEK2--in 16 of 49 patients who could be evaluated (33%).
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: Of these 16 patients, 14 (88%) had a response to olaparib, including all 7 patients with BRCA2 loss (4 with biallelic somatic loss, and 3 with germline mutations) and 4 of 5 with ATM aberrations.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: The specificity of the biomarker suite was 94%.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: Anemia (in 10 of the 50 patients [20%]) and fatigue (in 6 [12%]) were the most common grade 3 or 4 adverse events, findings that are consistent with previous studies of olaparib.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Treatment with the PARP inhibitor olaparib in patients whose prostate cancers were no longer responding to standard treatments and who had defects in DNA-repair genes led to a high response rate.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: (Funded by Cancer Research UK and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01682772; Cancer Research UK number, CRUK/11/029.
title: DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.
DNA-Repair Defects and Olaparib in Metastatic Prostate Cancer.

text: INTRODUCTION: KRAS mutations are present in 30% of lung adenocarcinomas.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: Salirasib prevents Ras membrane binding thereby blocking the function of all Ras isoforms.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: This phase II study determined the activity of salirasib in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: METHODS: Two cohorts of patients with stage IIIB/IV lung adenocarcinoma were eligible: patients with tumors with KRAS mutations who were previously treated with chemotherapy and patients receiving initial therapy who had >/=15 pack-year smoking history.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: Salirasib was given orally from days 1 to 28 of a 35-day cycle.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: The primary end point was the rate of nonprogression at 10 weeks.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: RESULTS: Thirty-three patients were enrolled.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: Thirty patients had KRAS mutations (23 patients who were previously treated and 7/10 patients who had no prior therapy).
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: Of the previously treated patients, 7 of 23 (30%) had stable disease at 10 weeks, and 4 of 10 (40%) previously untreated patients had stable disease at 10 weeks.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: No patient had a radiographic partial response (0% observed rate, 95% confidence interval 0-12%).
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: The median overall survival was not reached (>9 months) for previously untreated patients and it was 15 months for patients who received prior chemotherapy.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: Diarrhea, nausea, and fatigue were the most common toxicities.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Salirasib at the current dose and schedule has insufficient activity in the treatment of KRAS mutant lung adenocarcinoma to warrant further evaluation.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: The successful enrollment of 30 patients with tumors with KRAS mutant lung adenocarcinoma over 15 months at a single site demonstrates that drug trials directed at a KRAS-specific genotype in lung cancer are feasible.
title: A phase II trial of Salirasib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas with KRAS mutations.

text: PURPOSE: Platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRA) is a target for tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI)-based targeted therapy.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: Dysregulation of PDGFRA has been reported in many cancers.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: However, PDGFRA mutations in melanomas have not been well studied.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: We analyzed the genetic mutations of PDGFRA in Chinese patients with melanoma and determined the inhibitory potency of TKIs, such as imatinib and crenolanib, on mutant PDGFRA.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Of note, 351 melanoma tissue samples were examined for genetic mutations in exons 12, 14, and 18 of PDGFRA.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: Activities of mutations in response to imatinib and crenolanib were analyzed by Western blotting of tyrosine-phosphorylated PDGFRA and cell proliferation assays.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: RESULTS: PDGFRA mutations were observed in 4.6% (16 of 351) of melanomas, and these mutations were mainly detected in acral and mucosal melanomas.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: PDGFRA mutations seem to be mutually exclusive with KIT mutations, but may coexist with BRAF and NRAS mutations.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: The genetic mutations of PDGFRA were unrelated to the age, thickness, and ulceration status of primary melanomas.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: Thirteen mutations were not reported before, and five (P577S, V658A, R841K, H845Y, and G853D) of them resulted in strong autophosphorylation of PDGFRA.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: Crenolanib showed higher potency than imatinib in inhibiting the kinase activity of PDGFRA.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: Except that V658A mutation was imatinib-resistant, all the other mutations were sensitive to both imatinib and crenolanib.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: PDGFRA mutations are detected in a small population of melanoma patients.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: Our study suggests that patients with melanoma harboring certain PDGFRA mutations may benefit from imatinib and crenolanib treatment.
title: Large-scale analysis of PDGFRA mutations in melanomas and evaluation of their sensitivity to tyrosine kinase inhibitors imatinib and crenolanib.

text: BACKGROUND: The immune system has important roles in tumor development and outcomes after cancer treatment.
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We evaluated whether single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the gene encoding casitas B-lineage lymphoma b protein (Cbl-b), an E3 ubiquitin ligase that maintains immune tolerance by negatively regulating T-cell activation and function, were associated with outcomes after treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Samples from 393 patients with NSCLC treated with definitive radiotherapy at a single institution between March 1998 and February 2009 were used to genotype 3 potentially functional SNPs in CBLB (rs1042852 C>T, rs2305035 G>A, and rs7649466 C>G).
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We evaluated associations between these SNPs and local recurrence-free survival, distant metastasis-free survival, overall survival, and risk of radiation pneumonitis (RP).
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Having the rs2305035 A variant genotypes (AA or AG) was associated with better local recurrence-free survival (median 15.8 vs. 15.3 months; adjusted hazard ratio [HR], 0.76; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.60-0.98; P = .033), distant metastasis-free survival (median 15.4 vs. 14.0 months; adjusted HR, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.57-0.96; P = .024) and overall survival (median 23.5 vs. 22.8 months; adjusted HR, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.56-0.93; P = .013) after adjustment in a Cox proportional hazard model.
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Patients with these genotypes were also at greater risk of developing grade 3 or higher RP than were patients with GG genotypes in an adjusted Cox proportional hazard model.
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: This is the first report that rs2305035 genotypes in CBLB were associated with clinical and RP risk among patients with NSCLC treated with definitive radiotherapy.
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: These findings could assist in generating hypothesis for further mechanistic studies.
title: Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms in CBLB, a Regulator of T-Cell Response, Predict Radiation Pneumonitis and Outcomes After Definitive Radiotherapy for Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: The identification of somatic mutations in the gene encoding the serine-threonine protein kinase B-RAF (BRAF) in the majority of melanomas offers an opportunity to test oncogene-targeted therapy for this disease.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: METHODS: We conducted a multicenter, phase 1, dose-escalation trial of PLX4032 (also known as RG7204), an orally available inhibitor of mutated BRAF, followed by an extension phase involving the maximum dose that could be administered without adverse effects (the recommended phase 2 dose).
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: Patients received PLX4032 twice daily until they had disease progression.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: Pharmacokinetic analysis and tumor-response assessments were conducted in all patients.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: In selected patients, tumor biopsy was performed before and during treatment to validate BRAF inhibition.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: RESULTS: A total of 55 patients (49 of whom had melanoma) were enrolled in the dose-escalation phase, and 32 additional patients with metastatic melanoma who had BRAF with the V600E mutation were enrolled in the extension phase.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: The recommended phase 2 dose was 960 mg twice daily, with increases in the dose limited by grade 2 or 3 rash, fatigue, and arthralgia.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: In the dose-escalation cohort, among the 16 patients with melanoma whose tumors carried the V600E BRAF mutation and who were receiving 240 mg or more of PLX4032 twice daily, 10 had a partial response and 1 had a complete response.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: Among the 32 patients in the extension cohort, 24 had a partial response and 2 had a complete response.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: The estimated median progression-free survival among all patients was more than 7 months.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Treatment of metastatic melanoma with PLX4032 in patients with tumors that carry the V600E BRAF mutation resulted in complete or partial tumor regression in the majority of patients.
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: (Funded by Plexxikon and Roche Pharmaceuticals.)
title: Inhibition of mutated, activated BRAF in metastatic melanoma.

text: BACKGROUND: There is lack of evidence about systemic treatment of pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) relapsing after cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: There is also lack of biomarkers able to predict outcomes beyond known clinical and pathological prognostic features.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: METHODS: Fifteen patients with relapsed PMP and progressive disease within the last 6 months were included and received metronomic capecitabine (625 mg/mq/day b.i.d.)
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: and bevacizumab (7.5 mg/Kg three-weekly) until progressive disease/unacceptable toxicity.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: The primary endpoint was progression-free survival (PFS).
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: Ion Torrent((R)) next generation sequencing technology (Hot-spot Cancer Panel) was used to characterize molecular features.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: RESULTS: At a median follow up of 12 months, median PFS was 8.2 months and 1-year overall survival was 91 %.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: Partial responses were observed in 20 % of cases, but a significant reduction of tumor markers in up to 79 %.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: Treatment was very well tolerated without no new safety signals.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: All tumor samples except one had KRAS mutations.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: Patients with GNAS mutations had a significantly shorter median PFS as compared to GNAS wild-type ones (5.3 months vs. not reached; p < 0.007).
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: The results were externally validated on our previous series of PMP patients.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: GNAS mutations were rare in a parallel cohort of 121 advanced colorectal cancers (2.5 %), but were associated with peculiar clinical-pathological features and aggressive course.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab is an active and well tolerated option in patients with relapsed PMP.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: The negative prognostic effect of GNAS mutations in gastrointestinal cancers warrants further confirmatory studies and may prompt the development of effective targeted strategies.
title: GNAS mutations as prognostic biomarker in patients with relapsed peritoneal pseudomyxoma receiving metronomic capecitabine and bevacizumab: a clinical and translational study.

text: BACKGROUND: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB-family blocker, has shown preclinical activity when tested in EGFR mutant models with mutations that confer resistance to EGFR tyrosine-kinase inhibitors.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: We aimed to assess its efficacy in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinoma with previous treatment failure on EGFR tyrosine-kinase inhibitors.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: METHODS: In this phase 2b/3 trial, we enrolled patients with stage IIIB or IV adenocarcinoma and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance (ECOG) performance score of 0-2 who had received one or two previous chemotherapy regimens and had disease progression after at least 12 weeks of treatment with erlotinib or gefitinib.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: We used a computer-generated sequence to randomly allocate patients (2:1) to either afatinib (50 mg per day) or placebo; all patients received best supportive care.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: Randomisation was done in blocks of three and was stratified by sex and baseline ECOG performance status (0-1 vs 2).
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: Investigators, patients, and the trial sponsor were masked to treatment assignment.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: The primary endpoint was overall survival (from date of randomisation to death), analysed on an intention-to-treat basis.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00656136.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between May 26, 2008, and Sept 21, 2009, we identified 697 patients, 585 of whom were randomly allocated to treatment (390 to afatinib, 195 to placebo).
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: Median overall survival was 10.8 months (95% CI 10.0-12.0) in the afatinib group and 12.0 months (10.2-14.3) in the placebo group (hazard ratio 1.08, 95% CI 0.86-1.35; p=0.74).
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: Median progression-free survival was longer in the afatinib group (3.3 months, 95% CI 2.79-4.40) than it was in the placebo group (1.1 months, 0.95-1.68; hazard ratio 0.38, 95% CI 0.31-0.48; p<0.0001).
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: No complete responses to treatment were noted; 29 (7%) patients had a partial response in the afatinib group, as did one patient in the placebo group.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: Subsequent cancer treatment was given to 257 (68%) patients in the afatinib group and 153 (79%) patients in the placebo group.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: The most common adverse events in the afatinib group were diarrhoea (339 [87%] of 390 patients; 66 [17%] were grade 3) and rash or acne (305 [78%] patients; 56 [14%] were grade 3).
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: These events occurred less often in the placebo group (18 [9%] of 195 patients had diarrhoea; 31 [16%] had rash or acne), all being grade 1 or 2.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: Drug-related serious adverse events occurred in 39 (10%) patients in the afatinib group and one (<1%) patient in the placebo group.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: We recorded two possibly treatment-related deaths in the afatinib group.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Although we recorded no benefit in terms of overall survival with afatinib (which might have been affected by cancer treatments given after progression in both groups), our findings for progression-free survival and response to treatment suggest that afatinib could be of some benefit to patients with advanced lung adenocarcinoma who have failed at least 12 weeks of previous EGFR tyrosine-kinase inhibitor treatment.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: FUNDING: Boehringer Ingelheim Inc.
title: Afatinib versus placebo for patients with advanced, metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer after failure of erlotinib, gefitinib, or both, and one or two lines of chemotherapy (LUX-Lung 1): a phase 2b/3 randomised trial.

text: PRDM1/BLIMP-1, a master regulator of plasma-cell differentiation, is frequently inactivated in activated B-cell-like (ABC) diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) patients.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: Little is known about its genetic aberrations and relevant clinical implications.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: A large series of patients with de novo DLBCL was effectively evaluated for PRDM1/BLIMP-1 deletion, mutation, and protein expression.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: BLIMP-1 expression was frequently associated with the ABC phenotype and plasmablastic morphologic subtype of DLBCL, yet 63% of the ABC-DLBCL patients were negative for BLIMP-1 protein expression.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: In these patients, loss of BLIMP-1 was associated with Myc overexpression and decreased expression of p53 pathway molecules.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: In addition, homozygous PRDM1 deletions and PRDM1 mutations within exons 1 and 2, which encode for domains crucial for transcriptional repression, were found to show a poor prognostic impact in patients with ABC-DLBCL but not in those with germinal center B-cell-like DLBCL (GCB-DLBCL).
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: Gene expression profiling revealed that loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 expression correlated with a decreased plasma-cell differentiation signature and upregulation of genes involved in B-cell receptor signaling and tumor-cell proliferation.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: In conclusion, these results provide novel clinical and biological insight into the tumor-suppressive role of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 in ABC-DLBCL patients and suggest that loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to the overall poor prognosis of ABC-DLBCL patients.
title: Loss of PRDM1/BLIMP-1 function contributes to poor prognosis of activated B-cell-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

text: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) elicit high response rates among individuals with kinase-driven malignancies, including chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and epidermal growth factor receptor-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer (EGFR NSCLC).
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: However, the extent and duration of these responses are heterogeneous, suggesting the existence of genetic modifiers affecting an individual's response to TKIs.
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: Using paired-end DNA sequencing, we discovered a common intronic deletion polymorphism in the gene encoding BCL2-like 11 (BIM).
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: BIM is a pro-apoptotic member of the B-cell CLL/lymphoma 2 (BCL2) family of proteins, and its upregulation is required for TKIs to induce apoptosis in kinase-driven cancers.
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: The polymorphism switched BIM splicing from exon 4 to exon 3, which resulted in expression of BIM isoforms lacking the pro-apoptotic BCL2-homology domain 3 (BH3).
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: The polymorphism was sufficient to confer intrinsic TKI resistance in CML and EGFR NSCLC cell lines, but this resistance could be overcome with BH3-mimetic drugs.
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: Notably, individuals with CML and EGFR NSCLC harboring the polymorphism experienced significantly inferior responses to TKIs than did individuals without the polymorphism (P = 0.02 for CML and P = 0.027 for EGFR NSCLC).
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: Our results offer an explanation for the heterogeneity of TKI responses across individuals and suggest the possibility of personalizing therapy with BH3 mimetics to overcome BIM-polymorphism-associated TKI resistance.
title: A common BIM deletion polymorphism mediates intrinsic resistance and inferior responses to tyrosine kinase inhibitors in cancer.

text: EGF receptor (EGFR)-targeted monoclonal antibodies are effective in a subset of metastatic colorectal cancers.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: Inevitably, all patients develop resistance, which occurs through emergence of KRAS mutations in approximately 50% of the cases.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: We show that amplification of the MET proto-oncogene is associated with acquired resistance in tumors that do not develop KRAS mutations during anti-EGFR therapy.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: Amplification of the MET locus was present in circulating tumor DNA before relapse was clinically evident.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: Functional studies show that MET activation confers resistance to anti-EGFR therapy both in vitro and in vivo.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: Notably, in patient-derived colorectal cancer xenografts, MET amplification correlated with resistance to EGFR blockade, which could be overcome by MET kinase inhibitors.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: These results highlight the role of MET in mediating primary and secondary resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer and encourage the use of MET inhibitors in patients displaying resistance as a result of MET amplification.
title: Amplification of the MET receptor drives resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer.

text: Somatic gain-of-function mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenases (IDH) 1 and 2 are found in multiple hematologic and solid tumors, leading to accumulation of the oncometabolite (R)-2-hydroxyglutarate (2HG).
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: 2HG competitively inhibits alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases, including histone demethylases and methylcytosine dioxygenases of the TET family, causing epigenetic dysregulation and a block in cellular differentiation.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: In vitro studies have provided proof of concept for mutant IDH inhibition as a therapeutic approach.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: We report the discovery and characterization of AG-221, an orally available, selective, potent inhibitor of the mutant IDH2 enzyme.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: AG-221 suppressed 2HG production and induced cellular differentiation in primary human IDH2 mutation-positive acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells ex vivo and in xenograft mouse models.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: AG-221 also provided a statistically significant survival benefit in an aggressive IDH2(R140Q)-mutant AML xenograft mouse model.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: These findings supported initiation of the ongoing clinical trials of AG-221 in patients with IDH2 mutation-positive advanced hematologic malignancies.Significance: Mutations in IDH1/2 are identified in approximately 20% of patients with AML and contribute to leukemia via a block in hematopoietic cell differentiation.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: We have shown that the targeted inhibitor AG-221 suppresses the mutant IDH2 enzyme in multiple preclinical models and induces differentiation of malignant blasts, supporting its clinical development.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.

text: Cancer Discov; 7(5); 478-93.
title: AG-221, a First-in-Class Therapy Targeting Acute Myeloid Leukemia Harboring Oncogenic IDH2 Mutations.
