text: Patients with HER2+ breast cancer treated with trastuzumab and chemotherapy have superior survival compared with patients treated with chemotherapy alone.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: Polymorphisms within FCGR2A and FCGR3A are associated with binding affinity of natural killer cells to the IgG1 portion of trastuzumab, and a polymorphism in FCGR2B (I232T) is associated with impaired regulatory activity.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: The association of these polymorphisms with clinical response among trastuzumab-treated patients is equivocal, with both positive and negative associations.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: We performed genotyping analysis on the FCGR3A V158F, FCGR2A R131H, and FCGR2B I232T polymorphisms in 1,325 patients from the N9831 clinical trial.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: Patients in arm A (N = 419) received chemotherapy only.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: Patients in arms B (N = 469) and C (N = 437) were treated with chemotherapy and trastuzumab (sequentially in arm B and concurrently in arm C).
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: Using log-rank test and Cox proportional hazard models, we compared disease-free survival (DFS) among genotypic groups within pooled arms B/C.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: We found no differences in DFS between trastuzumab-treated patients who had the FCGR3A 158 V/V and/or FCGR2A 131 H/H high-affinity genotypes and patients without those genotypes.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: Furthermore, there was no significant interaction between FCGR3A and FCGR2A and treatment.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: However, there was a difference in DFS for FCGR2B I232T, with I/I patients deriving benefit from trastuzumab (P < 0.001), compared with the T carriers who did not (P = 0.81).
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: The interaction between FCGR2B genotype and treatment was statistically significant (P = 0.03).
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: Our analysis did not reveal an association between FcgammaR high-affinity genotypes and outcomes.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: However, it seems that the FCGR2B inhibitory gene may be predictive of adjuvant trastuzumab benefit.
title: Association studies of Fcgamma receptor polymorphisms with outcome in HER2+ breast cancer patients treated with trastuzumab in NCCTG (Alliance) Trial N9831.

text: The G protein G(alpha)s pathway is linked to proapoptotic signaling in cancer cell lines.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: To assess the role of the GNAS1 locus encoding G(alpha)s as a genetic factor for disease progression of transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder, we genotyped the synonymous T393C polymorphism in 254 patients with TCC (minor allele frequency: 0.43) to examine a potential association between genotypes and disease progression.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: Using Kaplan-Meier estimates to calculate 5-year probabilities of follow-up, we could show that progression-free survival, metastasis-free survival, and cancer-specific survival was significantly increased in TT genotypes (56%, 84%, 82%) compared with CC genotypes (35%, 53%, 58%).
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: In multivariate Cox proportional hazard analysis, the T393C polymorphism was an independent prognostic factor for clinical outcome.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: Homozygous CC patients were at highest risk for progression [odds ratio (OR), 1.94; P = 0.020], metastasis (OR, 3.49; P = 0.005), and tumor-related death (OR, 2.49; P = 0.031) compared with TT genotypes.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: Heterozygous patients had an intermediate risk compatible with a gene-dose effect.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: Real-time PCR analysis of urothelial tumor tissue as well as adipose and heart tissue revealed that G(alpha)s mRNA expression was highest in TT genotypes, indicating a proapoptotic effect in these genotypes.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: In conclusion, the GNAS1 T393C status associated with differential G(alpha)s mRNA expression is a novel independent prognostic marker for clinical outcome supporting a functional role of G(alpha)s in bladder cancer progression.
title: The T393C polymorphism of the G alpha s gene (GNAS1) is a novel prognostic marker in bladder cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: Melanoma is a devastating form of skin cancer with limited therapeutic options.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: Fifteen to 20% of patients with melanoma have an activating mutation in the GTPase, NRAS.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: The major downstream effectors of RAS are RAFs (ARAF, BRAF, and CRAF), phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K), and the Ral guanine exchange factors (RalGEF).
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) is an atypical IkappaB kinase family member that acts downstream of RalGEFs.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: Whereas many studies have analyzed RAF and PI3K signaling in mutant NRAS melanoma, the role of RalGEF/Ral is understudied and TBK1 has not been examined.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: To address this, TBK1 was modulated with knockdown approaches and targeted therapies to determine the role of TBK1 in motility, apoptosis, and signaling.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: In melanoma, NRAS overexpression increased TBK1 phosphorylation.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: TBK1 depletion inhibited migration and invasion, whereas its constitutive overexpression led to an increase in invasion.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: In three-dimensional systems that mimic the dermal microenvironment, TBK1 depletion or inhibition cooperated with MEK inhibitors to promote apoptosis, particularly in the context of MEK-insensitive mutant NRAS.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: This effect was absent in melanoma cells that are wild-type for NRAS.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: These results suggest the utility of TBK1 inhibitors as part of a treatment regimen for patients with mutant NRAS melanoma, for whom there are no current effective therapies.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: IMPLICATIONS: TBK1 promotes the malignant properties of NRAS-mutant melanoma and its targeting, in combination with MEK, promotes apoptosis, thus providing a potential novel targeted therapeutic option.
title: Targeting TBK1 inhibits migration and resistance to MEK inhibitors in mutant NRAS melanoma.

text: Class Ia phosphatidylinositol 3 kinase (PI3K) is required for oncogenic receptor-mediated transformation; however, the individual roles of the two commonly expressed class Ia PI3K isoforms in oncogenic receptor signaling have not been elucidated in vivo.
title: The p110alpha and p110beta isoforms of PI3K play divergent roles in mammary gland development and tumorigenesis.

text: Here, we show that genetic ablation of p110alpha blocks tumor formation in both polyoma middle T antigen (MT) and HER2/Neu transgenic models of breast cancer.
title: The p110alpha and p110beta isoforms of PI3K play divergent roles in mammary gland development and tumorigenesis.

text: Surprisingly, p110beta ablation results in both increased ductal branching and tumorigenesis.
title: The p110alpha and p110beta isoforms of PI3K play divergent roles in mammary gland development and tumorigenesis.

text: Biochemical analyses suggest a competition model in which the less active p110beta competes with the more active p110alpha for receptor binding sites, thereby modulating the level of PI3K activity associated with activated receptors.
title: The p110alpha and p110beta isoforms of PI3K play divergent roles in mammary gland development and tumorigenesis.

text: Our findings demonstrate a novel p110beta-based regulatory role in receptor-mediated PI3K activity and identify p110alpha as an important target for treatment of HER2-positive disease.
title: The p110alpha and p110beta isoforms of PI3K play divergent roles in mammary gland development and tumorigenesis.

text: PURPOSE: B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (B-CLL) is characterized by the accumulation of monoclonal mature B cells.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: The G protein Galphas subunit has been linked to proapoptotic processes in cancer cell lines.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: The TT genotype of the GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with increased Galphas transcript levels and a more favorable clinical course in different solid cancers.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We retrospectively genotyped 144 patients with B-CLL to examine a potential association between T393C genotypes with progression-free survival (time from diagnosis to initiation of chemotherapy) and overall survival.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: RESULTS: The C-allele frequency in the patient group was 0.57 and not significantly different from that of healthy blood donors.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Median progression-free survival was significantly different between genotypes (TT 130 months; TC 100 months; CC 31 months; P = 0.0066).
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Multivariable analysis showed that besides of ZAP-70 (P = 0.005) and Binet stage (P < 0.001), the T393C polymorphism was an independent prognostic factor for progression-free survival [hazard ratio (HR) CC versus TT 2.7; P = 0.010].
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In Binet A stages, ZAP-70-positive patients with CC genotypes had a HR of 4.4 to receive first therapy compared with ZAP-70-negative patients with T-alleles (P = 0.0001).
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Regarding overall survival, CC genotypes (median overall survival, 197 months) were at highest risk for death compared with T-alleles (median overall survival, 310 months) in both univariate (HR, 4.8; P < 0.0001) and multivariable analysis (HR, 5.6; P = 0.002).
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Here, we show that the GNAS1 T393C status is a novel independent prognostic marker in patients with B-CLL.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: These results could help to define patients who could benefit from an early individualized therapy.
title: The GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with disease progression and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: Several promising molecular-targeted drugs are used for advanced renal cancers.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: However, complete remission is rarely achieved, because none of the drugs targets a key molecule that is specific to the cancer, or is associated with "oncogene addiction" (dependence on one or a few oncogenes for cell survival) of renal cancer.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: Recently, an anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) fusion, vinculin-ALK, has been reported in pediatric renal cell carcinoma (RCC) cases who have a history of sickle cell trait.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: In this context, ALK inhibitor therapy would constitute a therapeutic advance, as has previously been demonstrated with lung cancer, inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors, and anaplastic large cell lymphomas.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: METHODS: Anti-ALK immunohistochemistry was used to screen 355 tumor tissues, using the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer (iAEP) method.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: The cohort consisted of 255 clear cell RCCs, 32 papillary RCCs, 34 chromophobe RCCs, 6 collecting duct carcinomas, 10 unclassified RCCs, 6 sarcomatoid RCCs, and 12 other tumors.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: RESULTS: Two patients (36- and 53-year-old females) were positive for ALK as determined by iAEP immunohistochemistry.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: Using 5'- rapid amplification of complementary DNA ends, we detected TPM3-ALK and EML4-ALK in these tumors.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: The results of this study were confirmed by fluorescence in situ hybridization assays.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: The 2 ALK-positive RCCs were unclassified (mixed features of papillary, mucinous cribriform, and solid patterns with rhabdoid cells) and papillary subtype.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: They comprised 2.3% of non-clear cell RCCs (2 of 88) and 3.7% of non-clear cell and nonchromophobe RCCs (2 of 54).
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The results of this study indicate that ALK fusions also exist in adult RCC cases without uncommon backgrounds.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: These findings confirm the potential of ALK inhibitor therapy for selected cases of RCC.
title: Identification of anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions in renal cancer: large-scale immunohistochemical screening by the intercalated antibody-enhanced polymer method.

text: Melanoma treatment is being revolutionized by the development of effective immunotherapeutic approaches.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: These strategies include blockade of immune-inhibitory receptors on activated T cells; for example, using monoclonal antibodies against CTLA-4, PD-1, and PD-L1 (refs 3-5).
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: However, only a subset of patients responds to these treatments, and data suggest that therapeutic benefit is preferentially achieved in patients with a pre-existing T-cell response against their tumour, as evidenced by a baseline CD8(+) T-cell infiltration within the tumour microenvironment.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: Understanding the molecular mechanisms that underlie the presence or absence of a spontaneous anti-tumour T-cell response in subsets of cases, therefore, should enable the development of therapeutic solutions for patients lacking a T-cell infiltrate.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: Here we identify a melanoma-cell-intrinsic oncogenic pathway that contributes to a lack of T-cell infiltration in melanoma.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: Molecular analysis of human metastatic melanoma samples revealed a correlation between activation of the WNT/beta-catenin signalling pathway and absence of a T-cell gene expression signature.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: Using autochthonous mouse melanoma models we identified the mechanism by which tumour-intrinsic active beta-catenin signalling results in T-cell exclusion and resistance to anti-PD-L1/anti-CTLA-4 monoclonal antibody therapy.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: Specific oncogenic signals, therefore, can mediate cancer immune evasion and resistance to immunotherapies, pointing to new candidate targets for immune potentiation.
title: Melanoma-intrinsic beta-catenin signalling prevents anti-tumour immunity.

text: T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is an aggressive and heterogeneous disease.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: The diagnosis is predominantly based on immunophenotyping.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: In addition to known cytogenetic abnormalities molecular mutations were recently identified.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: Here, 90 adult T-ALL cases were investigated for mutations in NOTCH1, FBXW7, PHF6, CDKN2A, DNMT3A, FLT3, PTEN, and RUNX1 using 454 next-generation amplicon sequencing and melting curve analyses.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: These data were further complemented by FISH, chromosome banding, array CGH, and CDKN2B promoter methylation analyses.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: NOTCH1 was the most frequently mutated gene with a 71.1% frequency followed by FBXW7 (18.9%), PHF6 (39.5%), DNMT3A (17.8%), RUNX1 (15.5%), PTEN (10.0%), CDKN2A (4.4%), FLT3-ITD (2.2%), and FLT3-TKD (1.1%).
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: In total, 84/90 (93.3%) cases harbored at least one mutation.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: Combining these data with CDKN2A/B deletions and CDKN2B methylation status, we detected minimum one aberration in 89/90 (98.9%) patients.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: Survival analyses revealed the subtype as defined by the immunophenotype as the strongest independent prognostic factor.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: When restricting the survival analysis to the early T-ALL subtype, a strong association of RUNX1 (P = 0.027) and DNMT3A (P = 0.005) mutations with shorter overall survival was observed.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: In conclusion, RUNX1 and DNMT3A are frequently mutated in T-ALL and are associated with poor prognosis in early T-ALL.
title: The molecular profile of adult T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: mutations in RUNX1 and DNMT3A are associated with poor prognosis in T-ALL.

text: BACKGROUND: Following the discovery that mutant KRAS is associated with resistance to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) antibodies, the tumours of patients with metastatic colorectal cancer are now profiled for seven KRAS mutations before receiving cetuximab or panitumumab.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: However, most patients with KRAS wild-type tumours still do not respond.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: We studied the effect of other downstream mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab in, to our knowledge, the largest cohort to date of patients with chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer treated with cetuximab plus chemotherapy in the pre-KRAS selection era.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: METHODS: 1022 tumour DNA samples (73 from fresh-frozen and 949 from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue) from patients treated with cetuximab between 2001 and 2008 were gathered from 11 centres in seven European countries.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: 773 primary tumour samples had sufficient quality DNA and were included in mutation frequency analyses; mass spectrometry genotyping of tumour samples for KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA was done centrally.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: We analysed objective response, progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival in molecularly defined subgroups of the 649 chemotherapy-refractory patients treated with cetuximab plus chemotherapy.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: FINDINGS: 40.0% (299/747) of the tumours harboured a KRAS mutation, 14.5% (108/743) harboured a PIK3CA mutation (of which 68.5% [74/108] were located in exon 9 and 20.4% [22/108] in exon 20), 4.7% (36/761) harboured a BRAF mutation, and 2.6% (17/644) harboured an NRAS mutation.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: KRAS mutants did not derive benefit compared with wild types, with a response rate of 6.7% (17/253) versus 35.8% (126/352; odds ratio [OR] 0.13, 95% CI 0.07-0.22; p<0.0001), a median PFS of 12 weeks versus 24 weeks (hazard ratio [HR] 1.98, 1.66-2.36; p<0.0001), and a median overall survival of 32 weeks versus 50 weeks (1.75, 1.47-2.09; p<0.0001).
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: In KRAS wild types, carriers of BRAF and NRAS mutations had a significantly lower response rate than did BRAF and NRAS wild types, with a response rate of 8.3% (2/24) in carriers of BRAF mutations versus 38.0% in BRAF wild types (124/326; OR 0.15, 95% CI 0.02-0.51; p=0.0012); and 7.7% (1/13) in carriers of NRAS mutations versus 38.1% in NRAS wild types (110/289; OR 0.14, 0.007-0.70; p=0.013).
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: PIK3CA exon 9 mutations had no effect, whereas exon 20 mutations were associated with a worse outcome compared with wild types, with a response rate of 0.0% (0/9) versus 36.8% (121/329; OR 0.00, 0.00-0.89; p=0.029), a median PFS of 11.5 weeks versus 24 weeks (HR 2.52, 1.33-4.78; p=0.013), and a median overall survival of 34 weeks versus 51 weeks (3.29, 1.60-6.74; p=0.0057).
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: Multivariate analysis and conditional inference trees confirmed that, if KRAS is not mutated, assessing BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA exon 20 mutations (in that order) gives additional information about outcome.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: Objective response rates in our series were 24.4% in the unselected population, 36.3% in the KRAS wild-type selected population, and 41.2% in the KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA exon 20 wild-type population.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: INTERPRETATION: While confirming the negative effect of KRAS mutations on outcome after cetuximab, we show that BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA exon 20 mutations are significantly associated with a low response rate.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: Objective response rates could be improved by additional genotyping of BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA exon 20 mutations in a KRAS wild-type population.
title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

title: Effects of KRAS, BRAF, NRAS, and PIK3CA mutations on the efficacy of cetuximab plus chemotherapy in chemotherapy-refractory metastatic colorectal cancer: a retrospective consortium analysis.

text: UNLABELLED: Cholangiocarcinoma is an intractable cancer, with limited therapeutic options, in which the molecular mechanisms underlying tumor development remain poorly understood.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Identification of a novel driver oncogene and applying it to targeted therapies for molecularly defined cancers might lead to improvements in the outcome of patients.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: We performed massively parallel whole transcriptome sequencing in eight specimens from cholangiocarcinoma patients without KRAS/BRAF/ROS1 alterations and identified two fusion kinase genes, FGFR2-AHCYL1 and FGFR2-BICC1.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: In reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) screening, the FGFR2 fusion was detected in nine patients with cholangiocarcinoma (9/102), exclusively in the intrahepatic subtype (9/66, 13.6%), rarely in colorectal (1/149) and hepatocellular carcinoma (1/96), and none in gastric cancer (0/212).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: The rearrangements were mutually exclusive with KRAS/BRAF mutations.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Expression of the fusion kinases in NIH3T3 cells activated MAPK and conferred anchorage-independent growth and in vivo tumorigenesis of subcutaneous transplanted cells in immune-compromised mice.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: This transforming ability was attributable to its kinase activity.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Treatment with the fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) kinase inhibitors BGJ398 and PD173074 effectively suppressed transformation.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: FGFR2 fusions occur in 13.6% of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: The expression pattern of these fusions in association with sensitivity to FGFR inhibitors warrant a new molecular classification of cholangiocarcinoma and suggest a new therapeutic approach to the disease.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase fusions define a unique molecular subtype of cholangiocarcinoma.

text: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) have emerged as a promising treatment option in the fight against advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: KRAS is the most frequently mutated oncogene in NSCLC.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: We performed this meta-analysis to investigate if KRAS mutation status affects survival benefits of ICIs in patients with advanced NSCLC.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: Electronic databases were searched for eligible studies.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: We included randomized trials with the data of overall survival stratified by KRAS mutation status.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: From 3 eligible studies, 138 patients with KRAS mutant NSCLC and 371 with KRAS wild-type tumor were included in the meta-analysis.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: Compared to chemotherapy with docetaxel, ICIs improved overall survival in patients with previously treated KRAS mutant NSCLC (hazard ratio = 0.64 [95% confidence interval, 0.43-0.96], P = 0.03).
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: For patients with KRAS wild-type NSCLC, however, ICIs did not prolong overall survival over that with chemotherapy (hazard ratio = 0.88 [95% confidence interval, 0.68-1.13], P = 0.30).
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: In conclusion, ICIs as a salvage therapy improved overall survival over that with docetaxel in advanced NSCLC patients with KRAS mutation, but not in those with KRAS wild-type tumor.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: These results suggest that KRAS mutation status may be a potential biomarker for survival benefits to ICIs.
title: Prognostic value of KRAS mutation in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors: A meta-analysis and review.

text: Because there is no known genetic abnormality common to all patients with myeloma, it is important to understand how genetic heterogeneity may lead to differences in signal transduction, cell cycle, and response to therapy.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: Model cell lines have been used to study the effect that mutations in p53 and ras can have on growth properties and responses of myeloma cells.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: The U266 cell line has a single mutant p53 allele.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: Stable expression of wild-type (wt) p53 in U266 cells results in a significant suppression of interleukin (IL)-6 gene expression and in the concomitant suppression of cell growth that could be restored by the addition of exogenous IL-6.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: Expression of wt p53 also leads to cell cycle arrest and protection from doxorubicin (Dox)- and melphalan (Mel)-induced apoptosis.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: The addition of IL-6 resulted in cell cycle progression and blocked p53-mediated protection from apoptosis.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: ANBL6 is an IL-6-dependent cell line that is sensitive to dexamethasone (Dex), Dox, and Mel.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: IL-6 is able to protect ANBL6 cells from Dex- and Mel- but not Dox-induced apoptosis.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: To study the effect of an activating mutation in ras, the ANBL6 cell line transfected with either a constitutively activated N- or K-ras gene was used.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: Both N-ras12 and K-ras12 genes were able to protect ANBL6 cells from apoptosis induced by Dex, Dox, and Mel.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: These data show that changes in ras or p53 can alter the myeloma cell response to IL-6 and demonstrate that the genetic background can alter therapeutic responses.
title: Heterogeneity in therapeutic response of genetically altered myeloma cell lines to interleukin 6, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and melphalan.

text: PURPOSE: The LUX-Lung 3 study investigated the efficacy of chemotherapy compared with afatinib, a selective, orally bioavailable ErbB family blocker that irreversibly blocks signaling from epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR/ErbB1), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2/ErbB2), and ErbB4 and has wide-spectrum preclinical activity against EGFR mutations.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: A phase II study of afatinib in EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma demonstrated high response rates and progression-free survival (PFS).
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: In this phase III study, eligible patients with stage IIIB/IV lung adenocarcinoma were screened for EGFR mutations.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: Mutation-positive patients were stratified by mutation type (exon 19 deletion, L858R, or other) and race (Asian or non-Asian) before two-to-one random assignment to 40 mg afatinib per day or up to six cycles of cisplatin plus pemetrexed chemotherapy at standard doses every 21 days.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: The primary end point was PFS by independent review.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: Secondary end points included tumor response, overall survival, adverse events, and patient-reported outcomes (PROs).
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: RESULTS: A total of 1,269 patients were screened, and 345 were randomly assigned to treatment.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: Median PFS was 11.1 months for afatinib and 6.9 months for chemotherapy (hazard ratio [HR], 0.58; 95% CI, 0.43 to 0.78; P = .001).
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: Median PFS among those with exon 19 deletions and L858R EGFR mutations (n = 308) was 13.6 months for afatinib and 6.9 months for chemotherapy (HR, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.34 to 0.65; P = .001).
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: The most common treatment-related adverse events were diarrhea, rash/acne, and stomatitis for afatinib and nausea, fatigue, and decreased appetite for chemotherapy.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: PROs favored afatinib, with better control of cough, dyspnea, and pain.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: CONCLUSION: Afatinib is associated with prolongation of PFS when compared with standard doublet chemotherapy in patients with advanced lung adenocarcinoma and EGFR mutations.
title: Phase III study of afatinib or cisplatin plus pemetrexed in patients with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutations.

text: PI-103, the first synthetic multitargeted compound which simultaneously inhibits PI3Kalpha and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) shows high antitumor activity in glioma xenografts.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: In the present study, clear antitumor activity was observed with PI-103 treatment in two gefitinib-resistant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines, A549 and H460, by simultaneously inhibiting p70s6k phosporylation and Akt phosphorylation in response to mTOR inhibition.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: In addition, H460 cells with activating mutations of PIK3CA were more sensitive to PI-103 than A549 cells with wild-type PIK3CA.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: PI-103 was found to inhibit growth by causing G0-G1 arrest in A549 and H460 cells.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: Western blotting showed that PI-103 induced down-regulation of cyclin D1 and E1 and simultaneously up-regulated p21 and p27, associated with arrest in the G0-G1 phase of the cell cycle.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: Furthermore, p53, the tumor suppressor which transcriptionally regulates p21, was also upregulated with PI-103 treatment.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: Collectively, our results suggest that multitargeted intervention is the most effective tumor therapy, and the cooperative blockade of PI3Kalpha and mTOR with PI-103 shows promise for treating gefitinib-resistant NSCLC.
title: A novel dual PI3Kalpha/mTOR inhibitor PI-103 with high antitumor activity in non-small cell lung cancer cells.

text: UNLABELLED: A 48 year-old female with chemo-refractory metastatic gastric cancer to the liver was treated on a Phase I clinical trial with MetMAb, a monoclonal antibody targeting the Met tyrosine kinase receptor.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: The primary tumor had high MET gene polysomy and evidence for an autocrine production of HGF, the growth factor ligand of Met.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: A complete response was obtained lasting two years; the cancer recurred as a peritoneal deposit invading into the transverse colon and a gastrohepatic ligament node.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: Compassionate use of MetMAb therapy at recurrence achieved a mixed response--a partial response of the two initial lesions, but with development of multiple new foci of carcinomatosis.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: Tissue and serum studies evaluating the Met signaling pathway did correlate with MetMAb treatment response initially and at the time of recurrence.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: This research brief is the first to describe a durable complete response obtained with a molecularly targeted monoclonal antibody, MetMAb, to the receptor tyrosine kinase, Met, in a patient with chemorefractory metastatic gastric cancer.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: It is also the first to report biomarkers that predicted therapeutic response to Met inhibition.
title: Durable complete response of metastatic gastric cancer with anti-Met therapy followed by resistance at recurrence.

text: BACKGROUND: The phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt pathway plays a fundamental role in cell proliferation and survival in human tumorigenesis, including gastric cancer.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: PIK3CA mutations and amplification are two major causes of overactivation of this pathway in human cancers.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: However, until this work, there was no sound investigation on the association of PIK3CA mutations and amplification with clinical outcome in gastric cancer, particularly the latter.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: METHODS: Using direct sequencing and real-time quantitative PCR, we examined PIK3CA mutations and amplification, and their association with clinicopathological characteristics and clinical outcome of gastric cancer patients.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: RESULTS: PIK3CA mutations and amplification were found in 8/113 (7.1%) and 88/131 (67%) gastric cancer patients, respectively.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: PIK3CA amplification was closely associated with increased phosphorylated Akt (p-Akt) level.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: No relationship was found between PIK3CA mutations and clinicopathological characteristics and clinical outcome in gastric cancer.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: PIK3CA amplification was significantly positively associated with cancer-related death.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: Importantly, Kaplan-Meier survival curves revealed that the patients with PIK3CA amplification had significantly shorter survival times than the patients without PIK3CA amplification.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our data showed that PIK3CA mutations were not common, but its amplification was very common in gastric cancer and may be a major mechanism in activating the PI3K/Akt pathway in gastric cancer.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: Importantly, Kaplan-Meier survival curves revealed that PIK3CA amplification was significantly positively associated with poor survival of gastric cancer patients.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: Collectively, the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway may be an effective therapeutic target in gastric cancer.
title: Highly frequent PIK3CA amplification is associated with poor prognosis in gastric cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Effective medical therapies are lacking for the treatment of neurofibromatosis type 1-related plexiform neurofibromas, which are characterized by elevated RAS-mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: METHODS: We conducted a phase 1 trial of selumetinib (AZD6244 or ARRY-142886), an oral selective inhibitor of MAPK kinase (MEK) 1 and 2, in children who had neurofibromatosis type 1 and inoperable plexiform neurofibromas to determine the maximum tolerated dose and to evaluate plasma pharmacokinetics.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Selumetinib was administered twice daily at a dose of 20 to 30 mg per square meter of body-surface area on a continuous dosing schedule (in 28-day cycles).
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: We also tested selumetinib using a mouse model of neurofibromatosis type 1-related neurofibroma.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Response to treatment (i.e., an increase or decrease from baseline in the volume of plexiform neurofibromas) was monitored by using volumetric magnetic resonance imaging analysis to measure the change in size of the plexiform neurofibroma.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: RESULTS: A total of 24 children (median age, 10.9 years; range, 3.0 to 18.5) with a median tumor volume of 1205 ml (range, 29 to 8744) received selumetinib.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Patients were able to receive selumetinib on a long-term basis; the median number of cycles was 30 (range, 6 to 56).
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: The maximum tolerated dose was 25 mg per square meter (approximately 60% of the recommended adult dose).
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: The most common toxic effects associated with selumetinib included acneiform rash, gastrointestinal effects, and asymptomatic creatine kinase elevation.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: The results of pharmacokinetic evaluations of selumetinib among the children in this trial were similar to those published for adults.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Treatment with selumetinib resulted in confirmed partial responses (tumor volume decreases from baseline of >/=20%) in 17 of the 24 children (71%) and decreases from baseline in neurofibroma volume in 12 of 18 mice (67%).
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Disease progression (tumor volume increase from baseline of >/=20%) has not been observed to date.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Anecdotal evidence of decreases in tumor-related pain, disfigurement, and functional impairment was observed.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our early-phase data suggested that children with neurofibromatosis type 1 and inoperable plexiform neurofibromas benefited from long-term dose-adjusted treatment with selumetinib without having excess toxic effects.
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: (Funded by the National Institutes of Health and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01362803 .
title: Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.
Activity of Selumetinib in Neurofibromatosis Type 1-Related Plexiform Neurofibromas.

text: Somatic PIK3CA mutations are frequently found in solid tumors, raising the hypothesis that selective inhibition of PI3Kalpha may have robust efficacy in PIK3CA-mutant cancers while sparing patients the side-effects associated with broader inhibition of the class I phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) family.
title: Characterization of the novel and specific PI3Kalpha inhibitor NVP-BYL719 and development of the patient stratification strategy for clinical trials.

text: Here, we report the biologic properties of the 2-aminothiazole derivative NVP-BYL719, a selective inhibitor of PI3Kalpha and its most common oncogenic mutant forms.
title: Characterization of the novel and specific PI3Kalpha inhibitor NVP-BYL719 and development of the patient stratification strategy for clinical trials.

text: The compound selectivity combined with excellent drug-like properties translates to dose- and time-dependent inhibition of PI3Kalpha signaling in vivo, resulting in robust therapeutic efficacy and tolerability in PIK3CA-dependent tumors.
title: Characterization of the novel and specific PI3Kalpha inhibitor NVP-BYL719 and development of the patient stratification strategy for clinical trials.

text: Novel targeted therapeutics such as NVP-BYL719, designed to modulate aberrant functions elicited by cancer-specific genetic alterations upon which the disease depends, require well-defined patient stratification strategies in order to maximize their therapeutic impact and benefit for the patients.
title: Characterization of the novel and specific PI3Kalpha inhibitor NVP-BYL719 and development of the patient stratification strategy for clinical trials.

text: Here, we also describe the application of the Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia as a preclinical platform to refine the patient stratification strategy for NVP-BYL719 and found that PIK3CA mutation was the foremost positive predictor of sensitivity while revealing additional positive and negative associations such as PIK3CA amplification and PTEN mutation, respectively.
title: Characterization of the novel and specific PI3Kalpha inhibitor NVP-BYL719 and development of the patient stratification strategy for clinical trials.

text: These patient selection determinants are being assayed in the ongoing NVP-BYL719 clinical trials.
title: Characterization of the novel and specific PI3Kalpha inhibitor NVP-BYL719 and development of the patient stratification strategy for clinical trials.

text: BACKGROUND: HER-2 represents a relatively new therapeutic target for non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: The incidence for reported HER-2 overexpression/amplification/mutations ranges from 2 to 20% in NSCLC.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: Moreover, HER-2 amplification is a potential mechanism of resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR-TKI) (about 10% of cases).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: T-DM1, trastuzumab emtansine is an antibody-drug conjugate composed by the monoclonal antibody trastuzumab and the microtubule polymerization inhibitor DM1.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: The activity of T-DM1 has been studied in breast cancer but the role of T-DM1 in lung cancer remains unexplored.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: METHODS: Antiproliferative and proapoptotic effects of T-DM1 have been investigated in different NSCLC cell lines by MTT, crystal violet staining, morphological study and Western blotting.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: HER-2 expression and cell cycle were evaluated by flow cytometry and Western blotting.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: Antibody dependent cell cytotoxicity (ADCC) was measured with a CytoTox assay.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: Xenografted mice model has been generated using a NSCLC cell line to evaluate the effect of T-DM1 on tumor growth.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: Moreover, a morphometric and immunohistochemical analysis of tumor xenografts was conducted.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: RESULTS: In this study we investigated the effect of T-DM1 in a panel of NSCLC cell lines with different HER-2 expression levels, in H1781 cell line carrying HER-2 mutation and in gefitinib resistant HER-2 overexpressing PC9/HER2cl1 cell clone.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: T-DM1 efficiently inhibited proliferation with arrest in G2-M phase and induced cell death by apoptosis in cells with a significant level of surface expression of HER-2.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: Antibody-dependent cytotoxicity assay documented that T-DM1 maintained the same activity of trastuzumab.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: Our data also suggest that targeting HER-2 with T-DM1 potentially overcomes gefitinib resistance.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: In addition a correlation between cell density/tumor size with both HER-2 expression and T-DM1 activity was established in vitro and in an in vivo xenograft model.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our results indicate that targeting HER-2 with T-DM1 may offer a new therapeutic approach in HER-2 over-expressing lung cancers including those resistant to EGFR TKIs.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine is active on HER-2 overexpressing NSCLC cell lines and overcomes gefitinib resistance.

text: PURPOSE: To investigate the impact of newly identified chromosome 3p21 epigenetic tumor suppressors PBRM1, SETD2, and BAP1 on cancer-specific survival (CSS) of 609 patients with clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) from 2 distinct cohorts.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Select sequencing on 3p tumor suppressors of 188 patients who underwent resection of primary ccRCC at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) was conducted to interrogate the genotype-phenotype associations.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: These findings were compared with analyses of the genomic and clinical dataset from our nonoverlapping The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) cohort of 421 patients with primary ccRCC.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: RESULTS: 3p21 tumor suppressors are frequently mutated in both the MSKCC (PBRM1, 30.3%; SETD2, 7.4%; BAP1, 6.4%) and the TCGA (PBRM1, 33.5%; SETD2, 11.6%; BAP1, 9.7%) cohorts.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: BAP1 mutations are associated with worse CSS in both cohorts [MSKCC, P = 0.002; HR 7.71; 95% confidence interval (CI)2.08-28.6; TCGA, P = 0.002; HR 2.21; 95% CI 1.35-3.63].
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: SETD2 are associated with worse CSS in the TCGA cohort (P = 0.036; HR 1.68; 95% CI 1.04-2.73).
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: On the contrary, PBRM1 mutations, the second most common gene mutations of ccRCC, have no impact on CSS.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: CONCLUSION: The chromosome 3p21 locus harbors 3 frequently mutated ccRCC tumor suppressor genes.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: BAP1 and SETD2 mutations (6%-12%) are associated with worse CSS, suggesting their roles in disease progression.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: PBRM1 mutations (30%-34%) do not impact CSS, implicating its principal role in the tumor initiation.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: Future efforts should focus on therapeutic interventions and further clinical, pathologic, and molecular interrogation of this novel class of tumor suppressors.
title: Adverse outcomes in clear cell renal cell carcinoma with mutations of 3p21 epigenetic regulators BAP1 and SETD2: a report by MSKCC and the KIRC TCGA research network.

text: Here we studied cell-free plasma DNA (cfDNA) collected from subjects with advanced lung cancer whose tumors had developed resistance to the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) AZD9291.
title: Acquired EGFR C797S mutation mediates resistance to AZD9291 in non-small cell lung cancer harboring EGFR T790M.

text: We first performed next-generation sequencing of cfDNA from seven subjects and detected an acquired EGFR C797S mutation in one; expression of this mutant EGFR construct in a cell line rendered it resistant to AZD9291.
title: Acquired EGFR C797S mutation mediates resistance to AZD9291 in non-small cell lung cancer harboring EGFR T790M.

text: We then performed droplet digital PCR on serial cfDNA specimens collected from 15 AZD9291-treated subjects.
title: Acquired EGFR C797S mutation mediates resistance to AZD9291 in non-small cell lung cancer harboring EGFR T790M.

text: All were positive for the T790M mutation before treatment, but upon developing AZD9291 resistance three molecular subtypes emerged: six cases acquired the C797S mutation, five cases maintained the T790M mutation but did not acquire the C797S mutation and four cases lost the T790M mutation despite the presence of the underlying EGFR activating mutation.
title: Acquired EGFR C797S mutation mediates resistance to AZD9291 in non-small cell lung cancer harboring EGFR T790M.

text: Our findings provide insight into the diversity of mechanisms through which tumors acquire resistance to AZD9291 and highlight the need for therapies that are able to overcome resistance mediated by the EGFR C797S mutation.
title: Acquired EGFR C797S mutation mediates resistance to AZD9291 in non-small cell lung cancer harboring EGFR T790M.

text: Activation of oncogenes by mechanisms other than genetic aberrations such as mutations, translocations, or amplifications is largely undefined.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: Here we report a novel isoform of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) that is expressed in approximately 11% of melanomas and sporadically in other human cancer types, but not in normal tissues.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: The novel ALK transcript initiates from a de novo alternative transcription initiation (ATI) site in ALK intron 19, and was termed ALK(ATI).
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: In ALK(ATI)-expressing tumours, the ATI site is enriched for H3K4me3 and RNA polymerase II, chromatin marks characteristic of active transcription initiation sites.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: ALK(ATI) is expressed from both ALK alleles, and no recurrent genetic aberrations are found at the ALK locus, indicating that the transcriptional activation is independent of genetic aberrations at the ALK locus.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: The ALK(ATI) transcript encodes three proteins with molecular weights of 61.1, 60.8 and 58.7 kilodaltons, consisting primarily of the intracellular tyrosine kinase domain.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: ALK(ATI) stimulates multiple oncogenic signalling pathways, drives growth-factor-independent cell proliferation in vitro, and promotes tumorigenesis in vivo in mouse models.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: ALK inhibitors can suppress the kinase activity of ALK(ATI), suggesting that patients with ALK(ATI)-expressing tumours may benefit from ALK inhibitors.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: Our findings suggest a novel mechanism of oncogene activation in cancer through de novo alternative transcription initiation.
title: Alternative transcription initiation leads to expression of a novel ALK isoform in cancer.

text: Mutational inactivation of the VHL gene is the cause of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, an autosomal dominant hereditary cancer syndrome predisposing to haemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas and clear-cell renal carcinomas.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: The gene product (pVHL) functions as an adapter in cellular processes including cell growth and apoptosis.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: VHL mutation analysis was carried out in 426 unrelated subjects with phenotypes ranging from VHL syndrome, to isolated VHL-related tumours that could represent the first manifestation of the disease.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: A total of 111 individuals were found to carry alterations, with large deletions representing 40% of the variants.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: Eighteen of the 95 detected variants were novel, seemingly disease-causing mutations; their pathogenic role has been evaluated in silico for effects on protein folding and interactions.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: Putative regions of interaction between pVHL and proteins involved in common pathways have been identified, assessing possible implications for the presence of mutations in these regions.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: All new variants predicted to truncate or cause complete pVHL loss of structure were associated with phenotypes consistent with VHL type 1.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: Seven of the new amino acid substitutions are disease-causing mutations, one is a neutral variant, whereas the results for two remain ambiguous.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: Our combined molecular and in silico approach for the evaluation of putative disease-causing mutations contributes to the interpretation of the potential pathogenicity of these novel variants.
title: Identification and in silico analysis of novel von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene variants from a large population.

text: For breast cancer patients with lymph node metastasis, paclitaxel is the first-line chemotherapy drug.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Clinical studies showed that some patients with breast cancer were insensitive to paclitaxel, which led to chemotherapy failure.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Today, no validated markers exist for the prediction of chemotherapy sensitivity in this patient group.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases-1 (TIMP-1) has been shown to protect against apoptosis.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Epidemiological studies have also associated elevated tumor tissue TIMP-1 levels with a poor response to cyclophosphamide/methotrexate/5-fluorouracil and anthracycline-based chemotherapy.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Additionally, our previous study proved that TIMP-1 significantly decreased the sensitivity of breast cancer cells to paclitaxel-induced apoptosis by enhancing degradation of cyclin B1.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: These data imply that TIMP-1 may be a useful predictive biomarker for chemotherapy resistance.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: In this retrospective study, we investigated the association between expression levels of TIMP-1 protein in the primary tumor and objective response to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy in 99 patients with breast cancer.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: With Kaplan-Meier survival analysis, the patients with high TIMP-1 levels were found to have significantly worse 5-year DFS (71.1 %) than the patients with low levels (88.5 %; P = 0.020).
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Similarly, the patients with high TIMP-1 levels had significantly worse 5-year OS (78.9 %) than patients with low levels (96.7 %; P = 0.004).
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: In Cox's univariate and multivariate analyses, TIMP-1 was prognostic for both DFS and OS.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: Our data showed that elevated tumor tissue TIMP-1 levels were significantly associated with a poor response to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy, and TIMP-1 might be a potential biomarker for predicting response of breast cancer patients to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.
title: High expression of TIMP-1 in human breast cancer tissues is a predictive of resistance to paclitaxel-based chemotherapy.

text: The antibody trastuzumab is approved for treatment of patients with HER2 (ERBB2)-overexpressing breast cancer.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: A significant fraction of these tumors are either intrinsically resistant or acquire resistance rendering the drug ineffective.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: The development of resistance has been attributed to failure of the antibody to inhibit phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K), which is activated by the HER2 network.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: Herein, we examined the effects of PI3K blockade in trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer cell lines.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: Treatment with the pan-PI3K inhibitor XL147 and trastuzumab reduced proliferation and pAKT levels, triggering apoptosis of trastuzumab-resistant cells.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: Compared with XL147 alone, the combination exhibited a superior antitumor effect against trastuzumab-resistant tumor xenografts.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: Furthermore, treatment with XL147 and trastuzumab reduced the cancer stem-cell (CSC) fraction within trastuzumab-resistant cells both in vitro and in vivo.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: These effects were associated with FoxO-mediated inhibition of transcription of the antiapoptosis gene survivin (BIRC5) and the CSC-associated cytokine interleukin-8.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: RNA interference-mediated or pharmacologic inhibition of survivin restored sensitivity to trastuzumab in resistant cells.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: In a cohort of patients with HER2-overexpressing breast cancer treated with trastuzumab, higher pretreatment tumor levels of survivin RNA correlated with poor response to therapy.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: Together, our results suggest that survivin blockade is required for therapeutic responses to trastuzumab and that by combining trastuzumab and PI3K inhibitors, CSCs can be reduced within HER2(+) tumors, potentially preventing acquired resistance to anti-HER2 therapy.
title: Trastuzumab-resistant cells rely on a HER2-PI3K-FoxO-survivin axis and are sensitive to PI3K inhibitors.

text: Since the prognosis of advanced cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) remains poor with traditional chemotherapy, attention has shifted to molecularly targeted agents.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Results of available clinical studies reveal little or no benefit of using targeted agents in advanced CCA.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Limitations of these trials could be the lack of comprehensive molecular and genetic characterization of CCA samples in order to identify potential drug targets.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Here we report a case of a 59-year-old female with chemotherapy-refractor, metastatic extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (EHCCA).
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: After failure of first-line chemotherapy with cisplatin plus gemcitabine, next generation sequencing (NGS) based tumor molecular profiling was performed on aspiration cytological sample, that revealed BRAF V600E mutation.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Multidisciplinary team decided on the initiation of combined treatment with BRAF and MEK inhibitors.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Dabrafenib was started orally 150 mg twice a day, adding trametinib 2 mg once a day.
