title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Right from the initiation of targeted therapy, significant clinical improvement had been observed.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Even though the first restaging computed tomography (CT) scan at 8 weeks revealed spectacular decrease in all metastatic sites, a new hepatic mass of 67 mm x 40 mm was identified and interpreted as new metastatic lesion.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: As the clinical and radiological response was contradictory, CT-guided biopsy was taken from the hepatic lesion while the therapy was continued on.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Histopathologic evaluation excluded the hepatic lesion from being a metastasis, instead described it as a fibrotic, inflammatory lesion.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: At 12 week, PET CT confirmed further tumor regression with complete regression of the multiple cerebral metastases.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: The therapy has been extremely well tolerated by the patient.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: According to our knowledge, this is the first reported case on a successful treatment of EHCCA with the combination of dabrafenib and trametinib.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: Our case highlights the importance of molecular profiling in CCA, in order to find potential actionable driver mutations for personalised treatment.
title: Combined dabrafenib and trametinib treatment in a case of chemotherapy-refractory extrahepatic BRAF V600E mutant cholangiocarcinoma: dramatic clinical and radiological response with a confusing synchronic new liver lesion.

text: The MEK1 and MEK2 inhibitor GSK1120212 is currently in phase II/III clinical development.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: To identify predictive biomarkers, sensitivity to GSK1120212 was profiled for 218 solid tumor cell lines and 81 hematologic malignancy cell lines.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: For solid tumors, RAF/RAS mutation was a strong predictor of sensitivity.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: Among RAF/RAS mutant lines, co-occurring PIK3CA/PTEN mutations conferred a cytostatic response instead of a cytotoxic response for colon cancer cells that have the biggest representation of the comutations.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: Among KRAS mutant cell lines, transcriptomics analysis showed that cell lines with an expression pattern suggestive of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition were less sensitive to GSK1120212.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: In addition, a proportion of cell lines from certain tissue types not known to carry frequent RAF/RAS mutations also seemed to be sensitive to GSK1120212.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: Among these were breast cancer cell lines, with triple negative breast cancer cell lines being more sensitive than cell lines from other breast cancer subtypes.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: We identified a single gene DUSP6, whose expression was associated with sensitivity to GSK1120212 and lack of expression associated with resistance irrelevant of RAF/RAS status.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: Among hematologic cell lines, acute myeloid leukemia and chronic myeloid leukemia cell lines were particularly sensitive.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: Overall, this comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis identified additional efficacy biomarkers for GSK1120212 in RAF/RAS mutant solid tumors and expanded the indication for GSK1120212 to patients who could benefit from this therapy despite the RAF/RAS wild-type status of their tumors.
title: Comprehensive predictive biomarker analysis for MEK inhibitor GSK1120212.

text: As a cell cycle inhibitor and tumor suppressor, p27 is frequently misregulated in human cancers.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: Increased degradation is the most common mechanism of misregulation, however in some cancers, p27 is mislocalized from its cell cycle inhibitory location in the nucleus, to the cytoplasm.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: In normal cells cytoplasmic p27 has functions that are distinct from its cell cycle-regulatory nuclear functions.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: Therefore, an important question is whether localization of p27 to the cytoplasm in tumor cells is primarily a mechanism for cancelling its inhibitory effect on cell proliferation, or whether cytoplasmic p27 has more direct oncogenic actions.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: To study p27 mislocalization in human cancers we screened a panel of common breast cancer cell lines.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: We observed that p27 accumulated in the cytoplasm exclusively in cell lines that are Her2+.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: To address the significance of p27 mislocalization in Her2+ breast cancer cells we interrogated the cellular response to the dual-Her2/EGFR kinase inhibitor, lapatinib.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: Knockdown of p27 using shRNA sensitized Her2+ cells to lapatinib-induced apoptosis.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: Moreover, expression of a constitutively cytoplasmic form of p27 (p27DeltaNLS) reversed the lapatinib-induced apoptosis, suggesting that cytoplasmic p27 contributed to lapatinib resistance in Her2+ breast cancer cells by suppressing apoptosis.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: Our results suggest that p27 localization may be useful as a predictive biomarker of therapeutic response in patients with Her2+ breast cancers.
title: Mislocalization of p27 to the cytoplasm of breast cancer cells confers resistance to anti-HER2 targeted therapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) mutational status is recognized factor related to the results of tyrosine kinase inhibitors therapy such as imatinib (IM) or sunitinib (SU).
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Arterial hypertension (AH) is common adverse event related to SU, reported as predictive factor in renal cell carcinoma.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: The aim of the study was to analyze the outcomes and factors predicting results of SU therapy in inoperable/metastatic CD117(+) GIST patients after IM failure.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: METHODS: We identified 137 consecutive patients with advanced inoperable/metastatic GIST treated in one center with SU (2nd line treatment).
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Median follow-up time was 23 months.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Additionally, in 39 patients there were analyzed selected constitutive single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of VEGFA and VEGFR2 genes.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: RESULTS: One year progression-free survival (PFS; calculated from the start of SU) rate was 42% and median PFS was 43 weeks.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: The estimated overall survival (OS, calculated both from start of SU or IM) was 74 weeks and 51 months, respectively.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: One-year PFS was 65% (median 74 weeks) in 55 patients with AH vs. 22% (median 17 weeks) in patients without AH.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Patients with primary tumors carrying mutations in KIT exon 9 or wild-type had substantially better 1-year PFS (68% and 57%; median 65.5 and 50.5 weeks, respectively) than patients having tumors with KIT exon 11 or PDGFRA mutations (34% and 15%; median 36.8 and 9 weeks, respectively).
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: We identified two independent factors with significant impact on PFS and OS in univariate and multivariate analysis: primary tumor genotype and presence of AH.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: The most common adverse events during therapy were: fatigue, AH, hypothyroidism, hand and foot syndrome, mucositis, skin reactions, dyspepsia, and diarrhea.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Two deaths were assessed as related to tumor rupture caused by reaction to SU therapy.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: The presence of C-allele in rs833061 and the T-allele in rs3025039 polymorphism of VEGFA were associated with significantly higher risk of hypothyroidism (OR: 10.0 p = 0.041 and OR: 10.5; p = 0.015, respectively).
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We confirmed that many advanced GIST patients benefit from SU therapy with OS > 1.5 year.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Primary tumor KIT/PDGFRA genotype and SU-induced AH, as surrogate of its antiangiogenic activity are two independent factors influencing both PFS and OS.
title: The outcome and predictive factors of sunitinib therapy in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) after imatinib failure - one institution study.

text: Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is associated with a chromosomal translocation t(15;17) and successfully differentiated by all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) in vivo as well as in vitro.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: The PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) oncoprotein, which is generated by the translocation, blocks the differentiation, and ATRA is thought to modulate the dominant negative function of PML-RARA.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: However, the molecular effect of ATRA on PML-RARA is unknown.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: In this study, we showed by means of immunoblotting that the expression of PML-RARA decreased within 12 h in APL cells treated with ATRA at concentrations greater than 0.1 microM.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: The decrease of PML-RARA was associated with restoration of the normal subcellular PML localization.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: PML-RARA transcripts were not down-regulated by ATRA.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: However, lactacystin, a specific inhibitor of the proteasome, almost completely inhibited the decrease of PML-RARA.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: These data indicate that the PML-RARA degradation is accelerated by pharmacological concentrations of ATRA, suggesting that ATRA allows APL cells to differentiate by relieving the differentiation block.
title: Accelerated degradation of PML-retinoic acid receptor alpha (PML-RARA) oncoprotein by all-trans-retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemia: possible role of the proteasome pathway.

text: We describe a mechanism of tumorigenesis mediated by kinase-dead BRAF in the presence of oncogenic RAS.
title: Kinase-dead BRAF and oncogenic RAS cooperate to drive tumor progression through CRAF.

text: We show that drugs that selectively inhibit BRAF drive RAS-dependent BRAF binding to CRAF, CRAF activation, and MEK-ERK signaling.
title: Kinase-dead BRAF and oncogenic RAS cooperate to drive tumor progression through CRAF.

text: This does not occur when oncogenic BRAF is inhibited, demonstrating that BRAF inhibition per se does not drive pathway activation; it only occurs when BRAF is inhibited in the presence of oncogenic RAS.
title: Kinase-dead BRAF and oncogenic RAS cooperate to drive tumor progression through CRAF.

text: Kinase-dead BRAF mimics the effects of the BRAF-selective drugs and kinase-dead Braf and oncogenic Ras cooperate to induce melanoma in mice.
title: Kinase-dead BRAF and oncogenic RAS cooperate to drive tumor progression through CRAF.

text: Our data reveal another paradigm of BRAF-mediated signaling that promotes tumor progression.
title: Kinase-dead BRAF and oncogenic RAS cooperate to drive tumor progression through CRAF.

text: They highlight the importance of understanding pathway signaling in clinical practice and of genotyping tumors prior to administering BRAF-selective drugs, to identify patients who are likely to respond and also to identify patients who may experience adverse effects.
title: Kinase-dead BRAF and oncogenic RAS cooperate to drive tumor progression through CRAF.

text: PURPOSE: The class I phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase (PI3K) plays a major role in proliferation and survival in a wide variety of human cancers.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: A key factor in successful development of drugs targeting this pathway is likely to be the identification of responsive patient populations with predictive diagnostic biomarkers.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: This study sought to identify candidate biomarkers of response to the selective PI3K inhibitor GDC-0941.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We used a large panel of breast cancer cell lines and in vivo xenograft models to identify candidate predictive biomarkers for a selective inhibitor of class I PI3K that is currently in clinical development.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: The approach involved pharmacogenomic profiling as well as analysis of gene expression data sets from cells profiled at baseline or after GDC-0941 treatment.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: RESULTS: We found that models harboring mutations in PIK3CA, amplification of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2, or dual alterations in two pathway components were exquisitely sensitive to the antitumor effects of GDC-0941.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: We found that several models that do not harbor these alterations also showed sensitivity, suggesting a need for additional diagnostic markers.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: Gene expression studies identified a collection of genes whose expression was associated with in vitro sensitivity to GDC-0941, and expression of a subset of these genes was found to be intimately linked to signaling through the pathway.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: CONCLUSION: Pathway focused biomarkers and the gene expression signature described in this study may have utility in the identification of patients likely to benefit from therapy with a selective PI3K inhibitor.
title: Predictive biomarkers of sensitivity to the phosphatidylinositol 3' kinase inhibitor GDC-0941 in breast cancer preclinical models.

text: The phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) signaling axis impacts on cancer cell growth, survival, motility, and metabolism.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: This pathway is activated by several different mechanisms in cancers, including somatic mutation and amplification of genes encoding key components.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: In addition, PI3K signaling may serve integral functions for noncancerous cells in the tumor microenvironment.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: Consequently, therapeutics targeting the PI3K pathway are being developed at a rapid pace, and preclinical and early clinical studies are beginning to suggest specific strategies to effectively use them.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: However, the central role of PI3K signaling in a large array of diverse biologic processes raises concerns about its use in therapeutics and increases the need to develop sophisticated strategies for its use.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: In this review, we will discuss how PI3K signaling affects the growth and survival of tumor cells.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: From this vantage, we will consider how inhibitors of the PI3K signaling cascade, either alone or in combination with other therapeutics, can most effectively be used for the treatment of cancer.
title: The PI3K pathway as drug target in human cancer.

text: PURPOSE: To determine the clinical relevance of Wilms' tumor 1 (WT1) gene mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with normal karyotype (NK).
title: Mutation of the Wilms' tumor 1 gene is a poor prognostic factor associated with chemotherapy resistance in normal karyotype acute myeloid leukemia: the United Kingdom Medical Research Council Adult Leukaemia Working Party.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Exons 7 and 9 of WT1 were screened in samples from 470 young adult NK AMLs using a combination of direct sequencing and high-resolution capillary electrophoresis.
title: Mutation of the Wilms' tumor 1 gene is a poor prognostic factor associated with chemotherapy resistance in normal karyotype acute myeloid leukemia: the United Kingdom Medical Research Council Adult Leukaemia Working Party.

text: RESULTS: Overall, 51 mutations were detected in 47 cases (10%): 46 frameshift mutations with insertion/deletion of one to 28 base pairs in exon 7 (n = 45) or exon 9 (n = 1), with a median mutant level of 45% (range, 8% to 86%), and five substitutions in exon 9: D396N (n = 3), H397Y (n = 1) and H397Q (n = 1).
title: Mutation of the Wilms' tumor 1 gene is a poor prognostic factor associated with chemotherapy resistance in normal karyotype acute myeloid leukemia: the United Kingdom Medical Research Council Adult Leukaemia Working Party.

text: Patients with WT1 mutations had an inferior response to induction chemotherapy compared with wild-type cases (complete remission rate, 79% v 90%, odds ratio [OR] = 3.02; 95% CI, 1.17 to 7.82; P = .02), a higher rate of resistant disease (15% v 4%; OR = 9.33; 95% CI, 2.38 to 36.6; P = .001), an increased cumulative incidence of relapse (67% v 43%, hazard ratio [HR] = 3.02; 95% CI, 1.69 to 5.38; P = .0008), with a reduction in both relapse-free survival (22% v 44%; HR = 2.16; 95% CI, 1.32 to 3.55; P = .005) and overall survival (26% v 47%; HR = 1.91; 95% CI, 1.23 to 2.95; P = .007) at 5 years.
title: Mutation of the Wilms' tumor 1 gene is a poor prognostic factor associated with chemotherapy resistance in normal karyotype acute myeloid leukemia: the United Kingdom Medical Research Council Adult Leukaemia Working Party.

text: In multivariate analysis, which included FLT3 internal tandem duplication and NPM1 mutation status, the presence of a WT1 mutation remained an independent adverse prognostic factor.
title: Mutation of the Wilms' tumor 1 gene is a poor prognostic factor associated with chemotherapy resistance in normal karyotype acute myeloid leukemia: the United Kingdom Medical Research Council Adult Leukaemia Working Party.

text: CONCLUSION: WT1 mutations are a negative prognostic indicator in NK AML and may be suitable for the development of targeted therapy.
title: Mutation of the Wilms' tumor 1 gene is a poor prognostic factor associated with chemotherapy resistance in normal karyotype acute myeloid leukemia: the United Kingdom Medical Research Council Adult Leukaemia Working Party.

text: PURPOSE: The phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway plays a central role in cell proliferation and survival in human cancer.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: PIK3CA mutations, which are found in many cancer patients, activate the PI3K pathway, resulting in cancer development and progression.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: We previously identified CH5132799 as a novel PI3K inhibitor.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: Thus, this study aimed to clarify the biochemical and antitumor activity of CH5132799 and elucidate the correlation between CH5132799 response and genetic alterations in the PI3K pathway.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Kinase inhibitory activity was profiled in cell-free assays.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: A large panel of human breast, ovarian, prostate, and endometrial cancer cell lines, as well as xenograft models, were used to evaluate the antitumor activity of CH5132799, followed by analysis for genetic alterations.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: Effects on Akt phosphorylation induced by mTORC1 inhibition were tested with CH5132799 and compared with mTORC1 and PI3K/mTOR inhibitors.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: RESULTS: CH5132799 selectively inhibited class I PI3Ks and PI3Kalpha mutants in in vitro kinase assays.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: Tumors harboring PIK3CA mutations were significantly sensitive to CH5132799 in vitro and were remarkably regressed by CH5132799 in in vivo mouse xenograft models.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: In combination with trastuzumab, tumors disappeared in the trastuzumab-insensitive breast cancer model with the PIK3CA mutation.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: Moreover, CH5132799 did not reverse a negative feedback loop of PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling and induced regression against tumors regrown after long-term mTORC1 inhibitor treatment.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: CH5132799 is a selective class I PI3K inhibitor with potent antitumor activity against tumors harboring the PIK3CA mutations.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: Prediction of CH5132799 response on the basis of PIK3CA mutations could enable patient stratification in clinical settings.
title: The selective class I PI3K inhibitor CH5132799 targets human cancers harboring oncogenic PIK3CA mutations.

text: BACKGROUND: In a previous randomized trial, AML HD98B, we showed that administration of all-trans retinoic acid in addition to intensive chemotherapy improved the outcome of older patients with acute myeloid leukemia.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: The objectives of this study were to evaluate the prognostic impact of gene mutations and to identify predictive genetic factors for the all-trans retinoic acid treatment effect.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: DESIGN AND METHODS: Data from mutation analyses of the NPM1, CEBPA, FLT3, and MLL genes were correlated with outcome in patients 61 years and older treated within the AML HD98B trial.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: RESULTS: The frequencies of mutations were: NPM1, 23%; CEBPA, 8.5% (analysis restricted to patients with a normal karyotype); FLT3 internal tandem duplications (ITD), 17%; FLT3 tyrosine kinase domain mutations, 5%; and MLL partial tandem duplications, 4.5%.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: The genotype mutant NPM1 was positively and adverse cytogenetics as well as higher white blood cell count negatively correlated with achievement of complete remission.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: In Cox regression analysis, a significant interaction between the genotype mutant NPM1 without FLT3-ITD and treatment with all-trans retinoic acid was identified, in that the beneficial effect of all-trans retinoic acid on relapse-free and overall survival was restricted to this subgroup of patients.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: Other significant factors for survival were age, adverse cytogenetics, and logarithm of white cell count.
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia, NPM1 mutations are associated with achievement of complete remission, and the genotype 'mutant NPM1 without FLT3-ITD' appears to be a predictive marker for response to all-trans retinoic acid given as an adjunct to intensive chemotherapy (ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT00151242).
title: Gene mutations and response to treatment with all-trans retinoic acid in elderly patients with acute myeloid leukemia. Results from the AMLSG Trial AML HD98B.

text: BACKGROUND & AIMS: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (FLC) is a rare primary hepatic cancer that develops in children and young adults without cirrhosis.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Little is known about its pathogenesis, and it can be treated only with surgery.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: We performed an integrative genomic analysis of a large series of patients with FLC to identify associated genetic factors.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: METHODS: By using 78 clinically annotated FLC samples, we performed whole-transcriptome (n = 58), single-nucleotide polymorphism array (n = 41), and next-generation sequencing (n = 48) analyses; we also assessed the prevalence of the DNAJB1-PRKACA fusion transcript associated with this cancer (n = 73).
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: We performed class discovery using non-negative matrix factorization, and functional annotation using gene-set enrichment analyses, nearest template prediction, ingenuity pathway analyses, and immunohistochemistry.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: The genomic identification of significant targets in a cancer algorithm was used to identify chromosomal aberrations, MuTect and VarScan2 were used to identify somatic mutations, and the random survival forest was used to determine patient prognoses.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Findings were validated in an independent cohort.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Unsupervised gene expression clustering showed 3 robust molecular classes of tumors: the proliferation class (51% of samples) had altered expression of genes that regulate proliferation and mammalian target of rapamycin signaling activation; the inflammation class (26% of samples) had altered expression of genes that regulate inflammation and cytokine enriched production; and the unannotated class (23% of samples) had a gene expression signature that was not associated previously with liver tumors.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Expression of genes that regulate neuroendocrine function, as well as histologic markers of cholangiocytes and hepatocytes, were detected in all 3 classes.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: FLCs had few copy number variations; the most frequent were focal amplification at 8q24.3 (in 12.5% of samples), and deletions at 19p13 (in 28% of samples) and 22q13.32 (in 25% of samples).
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: The DNAJB1-PRKACA fusion transcript was detected in 79% of samples.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: FLC samples also contained mutations in cancer-related genes such as BRCA2 (in 4.2% of samples), which are uncommon in liver neoplasms.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: However, FLCs did not contain mutations most commonly detected in liver cancers.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: We identified an 8-gene signature that predicted survival of patients with FLC.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In a genomic analysis of 78 FLC samples, we identified 3 classes based on gene expression profiles.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: FLCs contain mutations and chromosomal aberrations not previously associated with liver cancer, and almost 80% contain the DNAJB1-PRKACA fusion transcript.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: By using this information, we identified a gene signature that is associated with patient survival time.
title: Unique genomic profile of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are characterized by a strong KIT receptor activation most often resulting from KIT mutations.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: In a smaller subgroup of tumors without KIT mutations, analogous activating mutations are found in the platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRalpha) gene.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: Both PDGFRalpha and KIT receptors are targets of the tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib (Glivec) which has improved the treatment of advanced GISTs significantly.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: However, a subgroup of tumors show a secondary progress under therapy with imatinib after initial response.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: One possible mechanism of secondary resistance is the development of newly acquired KIT mutations.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: In the present study, we evaluated the frequency of such secondary KIT mutations in a series of GIST patients in which tumor tissue was resected under treatment.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: We examined one to seven different tumor areas in 32 cases (total of 104 samples) and found up to four newly acquired KIT mutations in 14 patients (43.8%).
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: These were always located in exons encoding the first or second tyrosine kinase domain (exon 13, 14, or 17).
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: Mutations were found only in a subset of samples analyzed from each case whereas others retained the wild-type sequence in the same region.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: There was never more than one new mutation in the same sample.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: Consistent with a secondary clonal evolution, the primary mutation was always detectable in all samples from each tumor.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: According to our results, the identification of newly acquired KIT mutations in addition to the primary mutation is dependent on the number of tissue samples analyzed and has high implications for further therapeutic strategies.
title: Polyclonal evolution of multiple secondary KIT mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors under treatment with imatinib mesylate.

text: Notch signaling regulates cell specification and homeostasis of stem cell compartments, and it is counteracted by the cell fate determinant Numb.
title: Alterations of the Notch pathway in lung cancer.

text: Both Numb and Notch have been implicated in human tumors.
title: Alterations of the Notch pathway in lung cancer.

text: Here, we show that Notch signaling is altered in approximately one third of non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs), which are the leading cause of cancer-related deaths: in approximately 30% of NSCLCs, loss of Numb expression leads to increased Notch activity, while in a smaller fraction of cases (around 10%), gain-of-function mutations of the NOTCH-1 gene are present.
title: Alterations of the Notch pathway in lung cancer.

text: Activation of Notch correlates with poor clinical outcomes in NSCLC patients without TP53 mutations.
title: Alterations of the Notch pathway in lung cancer.

text: Finally, primary epithelial cell cultures, derived from NSCLC harboring constitutive activation of the Notch pathway, are selectively killed by inhibitors of Notch (gamma-secretase inhibitors), showing that the proliferative advantage of these tumors is dependent upon Notch signaling.
title: Alterations of the Notch pathway in lung cancer.

text: Our results show that the deregulation of the Notch pathway is a relatively frequent event in NSCLCs and suggest that it might represent a possible target for molecular therapies in these tumors.
title: Alterations of the Notch pathway in lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Signaling via the G protein Galpha s pathway is linked to proapoptotic processes in cancer cell lines.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: We have recently shown an association between the GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and disease progression in patients with bladder cancer with homozygous TT genotypes displaying increased transcription of Galpha s and a more favorable clinical course compared with C-allele carriers.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: In the present study, 151 patients with sporadic colorectal cancer were retrospectively genotyped to examine a potential association between T393C genotypes and survival.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: Moreover, two other single-nucleotide polymorphisms in common haplotype blocks within the gene GNAS1 and their interaction with the T393C polymorphism were investigated.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: The allele frequency in the patients group was not significantly different from that of healthy blood donors.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: Kaplan-Meier curves for overall survival (mean follow-up, 43 months) showed that in International Union Against Cancer (UICC) stages I to II, the 5-year survival rate was significantly higher in TT genotypes (87.8%) compared with TC (71.0%) and CC genotypes (50.0%; P = 0.009), whereas no genotype effect could be observed for UICC stages III to IV.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: In multivariate Cox proportional analysis the T393C polymorphism was an independent prognostic factor for survival.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: Homozygous CC patients were at highest risk for death (hazard ratio, 12.1; P = 0.006) compared with TT genotypes.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: Heterozygous patients had an intermediate risk compatible with a gene-dose effect.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: The two haplotype blocks investigated were not associated with clinical outcome.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The results support the role of the T393C polymorphism as a marker for survival in patients with colorectal cancer stages I to II and in the identification of patients who may benefit from adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and survival in patients with sporadic colorectal cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) that harbours a BRAF V600E mutation (BRAF MT) is associated with poorer outcomes.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: However, whether this mutation is predictive of treatment benefit from anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) is uncertain.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: METHODS: We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published up to July 2014 that evaluated the effect of BRAF MT on the treatment benefit from anti-EGFR mAbs for mCRC.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Seven RCTs met the inclusion criteria for assessment of overall survival (OS), whereas eight RCTs met the inclusion criteria for assessment of progression-free survival (PFS).
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: For RAS WT/BRAF MT tumours, the hazard ratio for OS benefit with anti-EGFR mAbs was 0.97 (95% CI; 0.67-1.41), whereas the hazard ratio was 0.81 (95% CI; 0.70-0.95) for RAS WT/BRAF WT tumours.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: However, the test of interaction (P=0.43) was not statistically significant, highlighting that the observed differences in the effect of anti-EGFR mAbs on OS according to the BRAF mutation status may be due to chance alone.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Regarding PFS benefit with anti-EGFR mAbs, the hazard ratio was 0.86 (95% CI; 0.61-1.21) for RAS WT/BRAF MT tumours as compared with 0.62 (95% CI; 0.50-0.77) for RAS WT/BRAF WT tumours (test of interaction, P=0.07).
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: INTERPRETATION: This meta-analysis demonstrates that there is insufficient evidence to definitively state that RAS WT/BRAF MT individuals attain a different treatment benefit from anti-EGFR mAbs for mCRC compared with RAS WT/BRAF WT individuals.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: As such, there are insufficient data to justify the exclusion of anti-EGFR mAb therapy for patients with RAS WT/BRAF MT mCRC.
title: Meta-analysis of BRAF mutation as a predictive biomarker of benefit from anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy for RAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: The role of a polymorphism at position 72 of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in the development of cervical cancer is not well established.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: The arginine variant of the p53 protein could be more susceptible to degradation by human papillomavirus (HPV) E6 protein than the protein containing proline.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: Recent studies show controversial results.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: We investigated a possible association between TP53 polymorphism and cervical cancer in a Peruvian population with high prevalence of HPV infection.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: HPV status and TP53 polymorphism were determined for 119 cases of invasive cervical cancer and 127 control women from Peru.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: HPV infection was detected by PCR of cervical cells or tumor biopsies.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: For determination of TP53 polymorphism, exon 4 of the TP53 gene was amplified by PCR, and DNA was subsequently subjected to restriction enzyme digest.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: Associations between TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and cervical cancer were assessed using logistic regression.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: Women homozygotes for arginine had a 2.2-fold increased risk (95% confidence interval: 0.6-7.6) for cervical cancer.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: The odds ratio for women heterozygotes for Arg/Pro was 3.5 (95% confidence interval: 0.9-14).
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: Similarly increased risks were found when restricting analysis to HPV-positive women only.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: The distribution of TP53 genotypes in this Peruvian population was comparable with that found in Caucasians.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: Our results cannot rule out an association between the TP53 polymorphism at codon 72, HPV infection, and the etiology of cervical cancer.
title: TP53 polymorphism, HPV infection, and risk of cervical cancer.

text: Fetal liver tyrosine kinase 3 internal tandem duplication (FLT3 ITD) mutations are the most common molecular abnormality associated with adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: To exploit this molecular target, a number of potent and specific FLT3 kinase inhibitors have been developed and are currently being tested in early phase clinical trials of patients with refractory AML.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: To explore the efficacy of combining a FLT3 inhibitor with standard AML chemotherapy drugs, we tested the effect of combining the FLT3 inhibitor SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on the proliferation and survival of cell lines expressing either mutant (FLT3 ITD or FLT3 D835V) or wild-type (WT) FLT3.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: SU11248 had additive-to-synergistic inhibitory effects on FLT3-dependent leukemic cell proliferation when combined with cytarabine or daunorubicin.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: The synergistic interaction of SU11248 and the traditional antileukemic agents was more pronounced for induction of apoptosis.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: SU11248 inhibited the proliferation of primary AML myeloblasts expressing mutant FLT3 ITD but not WT FLT3 protein.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: Combining SU11248 and cytarabine synergistically inhibited the proliferation of primary AML myeloblasts expressing FLT3 ITD but not WT FLT3 protein.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: These data suggest that the addition of potent FLT3 inhibitors such as SU11248 to AML chemotherapy regimens could result in improved treatment results.
title: Synergistic effect of SU11248 with cytarabine or daunorubicin on FLT3 ITD-positive leukemic cells.

text: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) frequently involves amplification and alteration of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene, resulting in overexpression of varied mutations, including the most common mutation, EGFRvIII, as well as wild-type EGFR (EGFRwt).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: To test the prognostic value of EGFR, we retrospectively analyzed the relationship between treatment outcomes and the EGFR gene in 87 newly diagnosed adult patients with supratentorial GBM enrolled in clinical trials.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: The EGFR gene status was assessed by Southern blots and EGFR expression by immunohistochemistry using three monoclonal antibodies (EGFR.25 for EGFR, EGFR.113 for EGFRwt, and DH8.3 for EGFRvIII).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: EGFR amplification was detected in 40 (46%) of the 87 GBM patients; in 39 (97.5%) of these, EGFR was overexpressed.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: On the other hand, in 46 of 47 patients without EGFR amplification (97.9%), no EGFR overexpression was present.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: There was a close correlation between EGFR amplification and EGFR overexpression (P < 0.0001).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: EGFRwt was overexpressed in 27 of the 40 (67.5%) patients with, and in none without, EGFR amplification (P < 0.0001).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: Similarly, EGFRvIII was overexpressed in 18 (45.0%) of 40 patients with and in 4 (8.5%) of 47 patients without EGFR amplification (P < 0.0001).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: The finding that 8 (20%) of the patients with EGFR amplification/EGFR overexpression manifested overexpression of neither EGFRwt nor EGFRvIII indicates that they overexpressed other types of EGFR.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: Multivariate analysis demonstrated that EGFR amplification was an independent, significant, unfavorable predictor for overall survival (OS) in all patients (P = 0.038, HR = 1.67).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: With respect to the relationship of age to EGFR prognostication, the EGFR gene status was a more significant prognosticator in younger patients, particularly in those <60 years (P = 0.0003, HR = 3.15), whereas not so in older patients.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: EGFRvIII overexpression, on the other hand, was not predictive for OS.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: However, in patients with EGFR amplification, multivariate analysis revealed that EGFRvIII overexpression was an independent, significant, poor prognostic factor for OS (P = 0.0044, HR = 2.71).
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: This finding indicates that EGFRvIII overexpression in the presence of EGFR amplification is the strongest indicator of a poor survival prognosis.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: In GBM patients, EGFR is of significant prognostic value for predicting survival, and the overexpression of EGFRvIII with amplification plays an important role in enhanced tumorigenicity.
title: Prognostic value of epidermal growth factor receptor in patients with glioblastoma multiforme.

text: BACKGROUND: Patients with advanced HER2-positive breast cancer frequently develop CNS metastases.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: The metastases that progress after brain radiotherapy and HER2-targeted systemic therapy are a difficult therapeutic challenge.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: We aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of afatinib, an irreversible blocker of the ErbB protein family, alone or combined with vinorelbine, compared with treatment of the investigator's choice in women with HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases during or after treatment with trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: METHODS: We did this randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial in 40 hospitals in Canada, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, South Korea, and the USA.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Women older than 18 years with histologically confirmed HER2-overexpressing breast cancer and CNS recurrence or progression as determined by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST version 1.1) during or after treatment with trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both, were eligible.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: We randomly assigned patients (1:1:1) centrally to afatinib 40 mg orally once per day, afatinib 40 mg per day plus intravenous vinorelbine 25 mg/m(2) once per week, or investigator's choice of treatment in cycles of 3 weeks until disease progression, patient withdrawal, or unacceptable toxicity.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Treatment assignment was not masked for clinicians or patients, but the trial team was masked until database lock to reduce bias.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: The primary endpoint, assessed in the intention-to-treat population, was patient benefit at 12 weeks, defined by an absence of CNS or extra-CNS disease progression, no tumour-related worsening of neurological signs or symptoms, and no increase in corticosteroid dose.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Safety was assessed in all patients who received at least one dose of a study drug.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: This completed trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01441596.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Dec 22, 2011, and Feb 12, 2013, we screened 132 patients, of whom 121 were eligible and randomly assigned to treatment: 40 to afatinib alone, 38 to afatinib plus vinorelbine, and 43 to investigator's choice.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: All patients discontinued study treatment before the data collection cutoff on Oct 16, 2014.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: Patient benefit was achieved in 12 (30.0%; 95% CI 16.6-46.5) patients given afatinib alone (difference vs investigator's choice: -11.9% [95% CI -32.9 to 9.7], p=0.37), 13 (34.2%; 19.6-51.4) given afatinib plus vinorelbine (difference vs investigator's choice: -7.6% [-28.9 to 14.2], p=0.63), and 18 (41.9%; 27.0-57.9) given investigator's choice.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: The most common treatment-related grade 3 or 4 adverse events were diarrhoea (seven [18%] of 40 patients in the afatinib only group vs nine [24%] of 37 patients in the afatinib plus vinorelbine group vs two [5%] of 42 patients in the investigator's choice group) and neutropenia (none vs 14 [38%] vs four [10%]).
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Patient benefit with afatinib-containing treatments was not different from that in patients given investigator's choice of treatments; however, adverse events were frequent and afatinib-containing treatments seemed to be less well tolerated.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: No further development of afatinib for HER2-positive breast cancer is currently planned.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: FUNDING: Boehringer Ingelheim.
title: Afatinib alone or afatinib plus vinorelbine versus investigator's choice of treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer with progressive brain metastases after trastuzumab, lapatinib, or both (LUX-Breast 3): a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase 2 trial.

text: PURPOSE: Non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLCs) harboring mutations in MET exon 14 and its flanking introns may respond to c-Met inhibitors.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: We sought to describe the clinical, pathologic, and genomic characteristics of patients with cancer with MET exon 14 mutations.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We interrogated next-generation sequencing results from 6,376 cancers to identify those harboring MET exon 14 mutations.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: Clinical characteristics of MET exon 14 mutated NSCLCs were compared with those of NSCLCs with activating mutations in KRAS and EGFR.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: Co-occurring genomic mutations and copy number alterations were identified.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: c-Met immunohistochemistry and real-time polymerase chain reaction to detect exon 14 skipping were performed where sufficient tissue was available.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: RESULTS: MET exon 14 mutations were identified in 28 of 933 nonsquamous NSCLCs (3.0%) and were not seen in other cancer types in this study.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: Patients with MET exon 14-mutated NSCLC were significantly older (median age, 72.5 years) than patients with EGFR-mutant (median age, 61 years; P < .001) or KRAS-mutant NSCLC (median age, 65 years; P < .001).
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: Among patients with MET exon 14 mutations, 68% were women, and 36% were never-smokers.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: Stage IV MET exon 14-mutated NSCLCs were significantly more likely to have concurrent MET genomic amplification (mean ratio of MET to chromosome 7, 4.3) and strong c-Met immunohistochemical expression (mean H score, 253) than stage IA to IIIB MET exon 14-mutated NSCLCs (mean ratio of MET to chromosome 7, 1.4; P = .007; mean H score, 155; P = .002) and stage IV MET exon 14-wild-type NSCLCs (mean ratio of MET to chromosome 7, 1.2; P < .001; mean H score, 142; P < .001).
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: A patient whose lung cancer harbored a MET exon 14 mutation with concurrent genomic amplification of the mutated MET allele experienced a major partial response to the c-Met inhibitor crizotinib.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: CONCLUSION: MET exon 14 mutations represent a clinically unique molecular subtype of NSCLC.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: Prospective clinical trials with c-Met inhibitors will be necessary to validate MET exon 14 mutations as an important therapeutic target in NSCLC.
title: MET Exon 14 Mutations in Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Are Associated With Advanced Age and Stage-Dependent MET Genomic Amplification and c-Met Overexpression.

text: We identified new gene fusions in patients with lung cancer harboring the kinase domain of the NTRK1 gene that encodes the high-affinity nerve growth factor receptor (TRKA protein).
title: Oncogenic and drug-sensitive NTRK1 rearrangements in lung cancer.

text: Both the MPRIP-NTRK1 and CD74-NTRK1 fusions lead to constitutive TRKA kinase activity and are oncogenic.
title: Oncogenic and drug-sensitive NTRK1 rearrangements in lung cancer.

text: Treatment of cells expressing NTRK1 fusions with inhibitors of TRKA kinase activity inhibited autophosphorylation of TRKA and cell growth.
title: Oncogenic and drug-sensitive NTRK1 rearrangements in lung cancer.

text: Tumor samples from 3 of 91 patients with lung cancer (3.3%) without known oncogenic alterations assayed by next-generation sequencing or fluorescence in situ hybridization demonstrated evidence of NTRK1 gene fusions.
title: Oncogenic and drug-sensitive NTRK1 rearrangements in lung cancer.

text: Histone deacetylases are important targets for cancer therapeutics, but their regulation is poorly understood.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: Our data show coordinated transcription of HDAC1 and HDAC2 in lung cancer cell lines, but suggest HDAC2 protein expression is cell-context specific.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: Through an unbiased siRNA screen we found that BRCA1-associated protein 1 (BAP1) regulates their expression, with HDAC2 reduced and HDAC1 increased in BAP1 depleted cells.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: BAP1 loss-of-function is increasingly reported in cancers including thoracic malignancies, with frequent mutation in malignant pleural mesothelioma.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: Endogenous HDAC2 directly correlates with BAP1 across a panel of lung cancer cell lines, and is downregulated in mesothelioma cell lines with genetic BAP1 inactivation.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: We find that BAP1 regulates HDAC2 by increasing transcript abundance, rather than opposing its ubiquitylation.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: Importantly, although total cellular HDAC activity is unaffected by transient depletion of HDAC2 or of BAP1 due to HDAC1 compensation, this isoenzyme imbalance sensitizes MSTO-211H cells to HDAC inhibitors.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: However, other established mesothelioma cell lines with low endogenous HDAC2 have adapted to become more resistant to HDAC inhibition.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: Our work establishes a mechanism by which BAP1 loss alters sensitivity of cancer cells to HDAC inhibitors.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: Assessment of BAP1 and HDAC expression may ultimately help identify patients likely to respond to HDAC inhibitors.
title: Loss of the deubiquitylase BAP1 alters class I histone deacetylase expression and sensitivity of mesothelioma cells to HDAC inhibitors.

text: We have unveiled a synthetic lethal interaction between K-Ras oncogenes and Cdk4 in a mouse tumor model that closely recapitulates human non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).
title: A synthetic lethal interaction between K-Ras oncogenes and Cdk4 unveils a therapeutic strategy for non-small cell lung carcinoma.

text: Ablation of Cdk4, but not Cdk2 or Cdk6, induces an immediate senescence response only in lung cells that express an endogenous K-Ras oncogene.
title: A synthetic lethal interaction between K-Ras oncogenes and Cdk4 unveils a therapeutic strategy for non-small cell lung carcinoma.

text: No such response occurs in lungs expressing a single Cdk4 allele or in other K-Ras-expressing tissues.
title: A synthetic lethal interaction between K-Ras oncogenes and Cdk4 unveils a therapeutic strategy for non-small cell lung carcinoma.

text: More importantly, targeting Cdk4 alleles in advanced tumors detectable by computed tomography scanning also induces senescence and prevents tumor progression.
title: A synthetic lethal interaction between K-Ras oncogenes and Cdk4 unveils a therapeutic strategy for non-small cell lung carcinoma.

text: These observations suggest that robust and selective pharmacological inhibition of Cdk4 may provide therapeutic benefit for NSCLC patients carrying K-RAS oncogenes.
title: A synthetic lethal interaction between K-Ras oncogenes and Cdk4 unveils a therapeutic strategy for non-small cell lung carcinoma.

text: Suspected metastatic site lesions that are poorly differentiated present a diagnostic challenge when morphologic and immunohistochemical profiling cannot establish the primary tumor site.
title: A Poorly Differentiated Malignant Neoplasm Lacking Lung Markers Harbors an EML4-ALK Rearrangement and Responds to Crizotinib.

text: Here we present a patient diagnosed with both a malignant neoplasm in the lung and a right upper extremity (RUE) neoplasm of unclear histogenetic origin.
title: A Poorly Differentiated Malignant Neoplasm Lacking Lung Markers Harbors an EML4-ALK Rearrangement and Responds to Crizotinib.

text: Immunohistochemical staining performed on the latter specimen was inconclusive in determining the site of origin.
title: A Poorly Differentiated Malignant Neoplasm Lacking Lung Markers Harbors an EML4-ALK Rearrangement and Responds to Crizotinib.

text: Although the lung biopsy sample was insufficient for molecular testing, hybrid capture-based comprehensive genomic profiling (FoundationOne) identified an EML4-ALK rearrangement in the RUE lesion.
title: A Poorly Differentiated Malignant Neoplasm Lacking Lung Markers Harbors an EML4-ALK Rearrangement and Responds to Crizotinib.

text: Crizotinib treatment resulted in a major response in both the RUE and the lung lesions.
title: A Poorly Differentiated Malignant Neoplasm Lacking Lung Markers Harbors an EML4-ALK Rearrangement and Responds to Crizotinib.

text: This report illustrates the utility of comprehensive genomic profiling employed at the initial presentation of an unknown primary malignant neoplasm, which resulted in the front-line use of targeted therapy and a significant and sustained antitumor response.
title: A Poorly Differentiated Malignant Neoplasm Lacking Lung Markers Harbors an EML4-ALK Rearrangement and Responds to Crizotinib.

text: BACKGROUND: Since head and neck cancer is characterized by poor survival rates, there is a demand for novel therapeutic targets and prognostic biomarkers.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: An upcoming therapeutic target is the fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) family.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: However, their prognostic role in head and neck cancer remains unclear.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: OBJECTIVE: To systematically review current evidence on the prognostic value of FGFR family members in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: METHODS: A systematic search of PubMed, Embase, and the Cochrane Library was performed for publications up to 14 May 2014.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Two reviewers screened all articles and included prognostic studies on the molecular biomarkers FGFR1-5 in any type of HNSCC.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Relevant studies were assessed on risk of bias using the Quality in Prognostic Studies (QUIPS) tool.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Data on FGFR aberrations and survival outcome were extracted from relevant studies.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: The prognostic value of FGFR aberrations was compared among studies.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: RESULTS: The initial search yielded 1568 publications of which 12 fulfilled the inclusion criteria.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Four studies reported FGFR1 gene amplification (9.3-17.4 %) and FGFR1 protein overexpression (11.8 %) in HNSCC.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: FGFR1 protein expression by cancer-associated fibroblasts correlated with poor survival outcome in one study (p < 0.01).
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Eight studies reported high rates of FGFR4 Gly388Arg polymorphisms (32.5-54.2 %) and FGFR4 protein overexpression (16-35 %), with varying correlations with survival.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: So far, no studies assessed the prognostic role of FGFR2, FGFR3, or FGFR5 in HNSCC.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: LIMITATIONS: Significant risk of bias has been identified among included studies.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Therefore, cautious interpretation of the results is recommended.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: CONCLUSION: In conclusion, evidence was found for prognostic value of FGFR1 expression in cancer-associated fibroblasts in HNSCC.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: Prognostic evidence on the other FGFR family members in HNSCC is limited and conflicting.
title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: This emphasizes the need for future well-conducted prognostic studies.
