title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor Family Members as Prognostic Biomarkers in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Systematic Review.

text: PURPOSE: PIK3CA mutation appears to predict a lack of response to anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody (mAb) treatment in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: However, the predictive value of PIK3CA mutations for survival remains inconclusive.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: Here, we pooled the data from published studies to estimate the association between PIK3CA mutation and survival outcomes in mCRC patients treated with anti-EGFR mAbs.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: Studies investigating the association of PIK3CA mutations with clinical survival outcomes of mCRC patients treated with anti-EGFR mAbs were systematically identified.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: The overall hazard ratio (HR) was estimated by using fixed effect model or random effect model according to heterogeneity between trails.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Eight studies that reported survival outcome in 839 mCRC patients were included.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: In unselected patients, we found that PIK3CA mutations were significantly associated with poorer PFS [8 studies, 839 patients; HR = 1.53; 95 % confidence interval (CI) 1.28-1.84; P < 0.001] and OS (5 studies; 587 patients; HR = 1.28; 95 % CI 1.05-1.56; P = 0.015).
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: With increased predictive power in KRAS wild-type patients (3 studies; 275 patients), the overall HR for PFS was 2.44 (95 % CI 1.33-4.48; P = 0.004) and was statistically significant.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: We also observed a worse OS in KRAS wild-type patients with PIK3CA mutations (2 studies; 163 patients; HR = 1.37; 95 % CI 0.80-2.35; P = 0.258), although the result was not statistically significant due to small sample size.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: PIK3CA mutation is a promising predictive biomarker for poor survival in mCRC patients treated with anti-EGFR mAbs, particularly in KRAS wild-type patients.
title: PIK3CA mutation is associated with poor survival among patients with metastatic colorectal cancer following anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody therapy: a meta-analysis.

text: The gene mutated in ataxia telangiectasia, ATM, on human chromosome 11q22-q23 is implicated in cell cycle control and DNA repair.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Ataxia telangiectasia patients as well as ATM-deficient mice are immune deficient and develop lymphoproliferative disease.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Abnormalities in 11q22.3-q23.1 have also been described in B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (B-CLL).
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: We analyzed B-CLL samples for loss of heterozygosity (LOH) using microsatellite markers located at the ATM (D11S2179), mixed-lineage leukemia (MLL; D11S1356), and BCL1 (D11S987) loci, all of which are located around 11q23.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Five (14%) of 36 informative cases showed LOH at the ATM gene, and two of these five cases had LOH at the MLL gene.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: No LOH was detected at the BCL1 locus, and none of the cases showed LOH at the MLL gene without LOH at the ATM gene.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Four of these five cases with LOH at the ATM gene were studied for ATM protein expression by Western blot analysis.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: All four cases lacked ATM protein.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: An additional 111 cases of B-CLL were studied for expression of ATM protein by Western blot analysis and RIA.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Thirty-eight (34%) of these cases showed ATM levels <50% of that seen in normal lymphoid cells.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: No morphological or immunophenotypic difference was observed between ATM-deficient B-CLL cases and cases with normal ATM expression.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: However, patients with ATM deficiency had significantly shorter survival times (35.66 versus 97.3 months; P = 0.003) and more aggressive disease, suggesting that ATM is involved in the leukemogenesis of B-CLL.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: These data also suggest that the ATM gene may play a role in the reported 11q23 abnormality in B-CLL, which also characterizes an aggressive disease.
title: Deficiency of the ATM protein expression defines an aggressive subgroup of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Desmoid fibromatosis is a rare, nonmetastatic neoplasm marked by local invasiveness and relentless recurrence.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Molecular determinants of desmoid recurrence remain obscure.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: beta-Catenin deregulation has been commonly identified in sporadic desmoids although the incidence of CTNNB1 (the gene encoding beta-catenin) mutations is uncertain.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Consequently, we evaluated the prevalence of CTNNB1 mutations in a large cohort of sporadic desmoids and examined whether mutation type was relevant to desmoid outcome.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Desmoid specimens (195 tumors from 160 patients, 1985 to 2005) and control dermal scars were assembled into a clinical data-linked tissue microarray.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: CTNNB1 genotyping was performed on a 138-sporadic desmoid subset.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Immunohistochemical scoring was performed per standard criteria and data were analyzed using Kaplan-Meier and other indicated methods.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: CTNNB1 mutations were observed in 117 of 138 (85%) of desmoids.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Three discrete mutations in two codons of CTNNB1 exon 3 were identified: 41A (59%), 45F (33%), and 45P (8%, excluded from further analysis because of rarity).
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Five-year recurrence-free survival was significantly poorer in 45F-mutated desmoids (23%, P < 0.0001) versus either 41A (57%) or nonmutated tumors (65%).
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Nuclear beta-catenin expression was observed in 98% of specimens and intensity was inversely correlated with incidence of desmoid recurrence (P < 0.01).
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: In conclusion, CTNNB1 mutations are highly common in desmoid tumors.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: Furthermore, patients harboring CTNNB1 (45F) mutations are at particular risk for recurrence and therefore may especially benefit from adjuvant therapeutic approaches.
title: Specific mutations in the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) correlate with local recurrence in sporadic desmoid tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: A recent pooled analysis of the LUX-LUNG3 and LUX-LUNG6 trials suggested that afatinib (an irreversible epidermal growth factor receptor-tyrosine kinase inhibitor (EGFR-TKI)) is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.
title: Afatinib is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: Stable viral transfectant HEK293 cell lines carrying an exon 19 deletion (HEK293/19 del) or exon 21 L858R mutation (HEK293/ L858R)) were created and their drug sensitivities to AG1478 (a reversible EGFR-TKI) and afatinib were examined using an MTT assay.
title: Afatinib is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.

text: Western blot analyses were performed to estimate the phosphorylation of EGFR.
title: Afatinib is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.

text: RESULTS: In the HEK293/19 del, the 50% inhibitory concentration (IC50) of afatinib was significantly lower than that in the HEK293/ L858R.
title: Afatinib is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.

text: In addition, afatinib inhibited the phosphorylation of EGFR to a greater degree in the HEK293/19 del than in the HEK293/L858R.
title: Afatinib is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.

text: CONCLUSION: Our experimental findings suggest that afatinib is especially effective against NSCLC carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.
title: Afatinib is especially effective against non-small cell lung cancer carrying an EGFR exon 19 deletion.

text: OBJECTIVE: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deleted on chromosome 10, a tumor suppressor that negatively regulates the phosphoinositide-3-kinase(PI3K) which has been implicated in a number of human malignancies including prostate cancer.
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: However the prognostic value of PTEN deletion in prostate cancer patient's diagnosis and the mechanism of PTEN deletion in prostate cancer development still remain unclear.
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: METHOD: A meta-analysis of 26 published studies including 8097 prostate cancer patients was performed.
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Compared to PTEN normal patients, PTEN deletion patients showed a higher aggressive Gleason score(OR: 1.284, 95%CI=1.145-1.439) and pathological stage(OR: 1.628, 95%CI=1.270-2.087) which generally had a higher risk in prostate replace(HR: 1.738, 95%CI=1.264-2.390).
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: Significant association between PTEN deletion and ERG rearrangements in prostate cancer development was also proved that compared to PTEN normal patients, patients with PTEN deletion showed a higher risk in ERG rearrangements(OR: 1.345, 95%CI=1.102-1.788).
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSION: This study indicated that patients with PTEN deletion were associated with higher pathological stage or Gleason score and a higher risk in prostate cancer replace potentially represent a novel clinically relevant event to identify individuals at increased risk for the occurrence, progression and prognosis of prostate cancer.
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: Prostate cancer patients with PTEN deletion usually had a higher risk in ERG rearrangements than other patients may be a potential new area for identifying poor prognosis patients and selecting patients for targeted therapies which required confirmation through adequately designed prospective studies.
title: The association of Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) deletion and prostate cancer risk: A meta-analysis.

text: p16(INK4) and RB1 are two potent cell cycle regulators to control the G1/S transition by interacting with CDK4/6, E2F, and D-type cyclins, respectively.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Depending on the tumour type, genetic alterations resulting in the functional inactivation have frequently been reported in both genes.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: By contrast, much less is known regarding the overexpression of these proteins in the tumor cells.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: In this study, expressions of p16(INK4) RB1, and CDKN2A copy number variances (CNV) in the tumor cells were assessed by immunohistochemistry and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), respectively, in 73 nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with known 5-year survivals.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The histologic type (P = 0.01), p16(INK4) (P = 0.004), and RB1 (P < 0.001) were predictive of survivals.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The CDKN2A CNV (P < 0.05) was also significant when compared to those cases without CNV.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Therefore, among the molecular genetic prognostic factors, expressions of RB1 and p16(INK4) in the tumor cells were the most strongly predictive of adverse outcomes in stage I and II nonsquamous NSCLC.
title: Altered p16(INK4) and RB1 Expressions Are Associated with Poor Prognosis in Patients with Nonsmall Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Activation of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 (cdk4/6) occurs in the majority of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) tumors, and represents a promising molecular target for the development of small molecule inhibitors.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: In the current study, we investigated the molecular determinants and in vivo response of diverse GBM cell lines and xenografts to PD-0332991, a cdk4/6-specific inhibitor.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: In vitro testing of PD-0332991 against a panel of GBM cell lines revealed a potent G(1) cell cycle arrest and induction of senescence in each of 16 retinoblastoma protein (Rb)-proficient cell lines regardless of other genetic lesions, whereas 5 cell lines with homozygous inactivation of Rb were completely resistant to treatment.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: Short hairpin RNA depletion of Rb expression conferred resistance of GBM cells to PD-0332991, further demonstrating a requirement of Rb for sensitivity to cdk4/6 inhibition.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: PD-0332991 was found to efficiently cross the blood-brain barrier and proved highly effective in suppressing the growth of intracranial GBM xenograft tumors, including those that had recurred after initial therapy with temozolomide.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: Remarkably, no mice receiving PD-0332991 died as a result of disease progression while on therapy.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: Additionally, the combination of PD-0332991 and radiation therapy resulted in significantly increased survival benefit compared with either therapy alone.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: In total, our results support clinical trial evaluation of PD-0332991 against newly diagnosed as well as recurrent GBM, and indicate that Rb status is the primary determinant of potential benefit from this therapy.
title: Pharmacologic inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 arrests the growth of glioblastoma multiforme intracranial xenografts.

text: The studies concerning clinical implications of TET2 mutation in patients with primary acute myeloid leukemia (AML) are scarce.
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: We analyzed TET2 mutation in 486 adult patients with primary AML.
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: TET2 mutation occurred in 13.2% of our patients and was closely associated with older age, higher white blood cell and blast counts, lower platelet numbers, normal karyotype, intermediate-risk cytogenetics, isolated trisomy 8, NPM1 mutation, and ASXL1 mutation but mutually exclusive with IDH mutation.
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics, and its negative impact was further enhanced when the mutation was combined with FLT3-ITD, NPM1-wild, or unfavorable genotypes (other than NPM1(+)/FLT3-ITD(-) or CEBPA(+)).
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: A scoring system integrating TET2 mutation with FLT3-ITD, NPM1, and CEBPA mutations could well separate AML patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics into 4 groups with different prognoses (P < .0001).
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: Sequential analysis revealed that TET2 mutation detected at diagnosis was frequently lost at relapse; rarely, the mutation was acquired at relapse in those without TET2 mutation at diagnosis.
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: In conclusion, TET2 mutation is associated with poor prognosis in AML patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics, especially when it is combined with other adverse molecular markers.
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: TET2 mutation appeared to be unstable during disease evolution.
title: TET2 mutation is an unfavorable prognostic factor in acute myeloid leukemia patients with intermediate-risk cytogenetics.

text: UNLABELLED: AIB1 (amplified in breast cancer 1) is an estrogen receptoralpha (ERalpha) co-activator, known to be amplified and overexpressed in a fraction of breast cancers.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: It has been linked to prognosis and tamoxifen resistance.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: However, results have been ambiguous.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: The different functions of AIB1 in ERalpha-positive and -negative disease are poorly understood.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: Therefore, we analyzed the clinical significance of AIB1 in breast cancer with respect to ERalpha-status and characterized the subgroups.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: 2,197 breast carcinomas sampled on a pre-existing tissue microarray (TMA) were analyzed for AIB1 expression and amplification by immunohistochemistry (IHC) and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: AIB1 expression was detected in 60 % of the tumors.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: It was associated with tumor size (p = 0.003), high histological grade (p < 0.0001), poor disease-specific, and overall survival (p = 0.0018 and p = 0.003).
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: There was a strong inverse relationship between AIB1 and ERalpha expression (p < 0.0001).
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: AIB1 overexpression was associated with increased Ki67 labeling index (p < 0.0001), even if analyzed for different ER expression levels.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: AIB1 amplification was found in 11 % of the carcinomas.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: It was associated with high histological grade (p = 0.0012), lymph node involvement (p = 0.0163), and poor disease-specific survival (p = 0.0032) but not with overall survival (p = 0.1672) or ER status (p = 0.4456).
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: If ER-positive tumors were stratified according to their AIB1 amplification status, there was a significant worse disease-specific survival in cases showing AIB1 amplification (p = 0.0017).
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: AIB1 expression is associated with unfavorable prognosis and tumor phenotype.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: It seems to unfold its oncogenic potential at least in part independent from its role as an ERalpha co-activator.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: AIB1 has an impact on cell cycle regulation in ERalpha-positive as well as ERalpha-negative tumors.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: Furthermore, AIB1 amplification characterizes a subgroup of ERalpha-positive breast cancer with worse outcome.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: Therefore, AIB1 might be helpful to identify those ERalpha-positive breast cancers patients who are candidates for adjuvant chemotherapy.
title: Prognostic relevance of AIB1 (NCoA3) amplification and overexpression in breast cancer.

text: Several molecular markers have been described that help to classify patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a heterogeneous hematopoietic tissue neoplasm, into risk groups.
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: We determined the frequency of DNMT3A mutations, their associations with clinical and molecular characteristics and outcome, in primary, cytogenetically-normal AML (CN-AML) and CN-myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: A total of 63 CN-AML and 16 CN-MDS patients were analyzed for mutations in DNMT3A, codon R822 by direct sequencing and mutation of NPM1 and FLT3/ITD.
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: DNMT3A mutations were found in 17/63 (27%) of CN-AML and in 1/16 (6.3%) of CN-MDS patients.
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: Patients with DNMT3A mutations were older (p=0.047), had higher white blood cell (WBC) counts (p=0.046), more often belonged to FAB groups M4 and M5 (p=0.017), and were more associated with NPM1 mutations (p=0.017), than those with wild-type DNMT3A.
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: DNMT3A-mutated patients had shorter overall disease survival (p<0.001) and disease-free survival (p=0.014) when the entire patient cohort was considered, which remained significant in multivariate analysis.
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: We conclude that DNMT3A R882 mutations are recurrent molecular aberrations in CN-AML, less frequent in CN-MDS, and that testing for R882 mutations may provide a useful tool for refining risk classification of CN-AML.
title: DNMT3A R882 mutations in patients with cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: UNLABELLED: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with activating EGF receptor (EGFR) mutations initially respond to first-generation reversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: However, clinical efficacy is limited by acquired resistance, frequently driven by the EGFR(T790M) mutation.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: CO-1686 is a novel, irreversible, and orally delivered kinase inhibitor that specifically targets the mutant forms of EGFR, including T790M, while exhibiting minimal activity toward the wild-type (WT) receptor.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: Oral administration of CO-1686 as single agent induces tumor regression in EGFR-mutated NSCLC tumor xenograft and transgenic models.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: Minimal activity of CO-1686 against the WT EGFR receptor was observed.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: In NSCLC cells with acquired resistance to CO-1686 in vitro, there was no evidence of additional mutations or amplification of the EGFR gene, but resistant cells exhibited signs of epithelial-mesenchymal transition and demonstrated increased sensitivity to AKT inhibitors.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: These results suggest that CO-1686 may offer a novel therapeutic option for patients with mutant EGFR NSCLC.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: We report the preclinical development of a novel covalent inhibitor, CO-1686, that irreversibly and selectively inhibits mutant EGFR, in particular the T790M drug-resistance mutation, in NSCLC models.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: CO-1686 is the fi rst drug of its class in clinical development for the treatment of T790M-positive NSCLC, potentially offering potent inhibition of mutant EGFR while avoiding the on-target toxicity observed with inhibition of the WT EGFR.
title: Discovery of a mutant-selective covalent inhibitor of EGFR that overcomes T790M-mediated resistance in NSCLC.

text: BACKGROUND: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) targeting epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) represent novel, effective tools in the management of advanced-stage non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: We aimed to evaluate the incidence and predictive role of EGFR gene amplification in patients with advanced-stage NSCLC treated with EGFR-TKIs.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: The study included 290 patients with advanced-stage (IIIB or IV) NSCLC.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were used for detection of EGFR gene amplification and EGFR mutations, respectively.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: RESULTS: EGFR amplification was detected in 26 (9.0%) patients.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: EGFR amplification was found more frequently in patients harboring the EGFR mutation (p<0.001).
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: No significant corelation between EGFR gene amplification and survival was observed.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: CONCLUSION: EGFR gene amplification is associated with EGFR gene mutation.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: EGFR gene amplification is not a feasible predictive biomarker for treatment with EGFR-TKIs in patients with advanced-stage NSCLC.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Gene Amplification in Patients with Advanced-stage NSCLC.

text: The prevalence, the prognostic effect, and interaction with other molecular markers of DNMT3A mutations was studied in 415 patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) younger than 60 years.
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We show mutations in DNMT3A in 96 of 415 patients with newly diagnosed AML (23.1%).
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Univariate Cox regression analysis showed that patients with DNMT3A(mutant) AML show significantly worse overall survival (OS; P = .022; hazard ratio [HR], 1.38; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.04-1.81), and relapse-free survival (RFS; P = .005; HR, 1.52; 95% CI, 1.13-2.05) than DNMT3A(wild-type) AMLs.
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In a multivariable analysis, DNMT3A mutations express independent unfavorable prognostic value for OS (P = .003; HR, 1.82; 95% CI, 1.2-2.7) and RFS (P < .001; HR, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.4-3.3).
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In a composite genotypic subset of cytogenetic intermediate-risk AML without FLT3-ITD and NPM1 mutations, this association is particularly evident (OS: P = .013; HR, 2.09; 95% CI, 1.16-3.77; RFS: P = .001; HR, 2.65; 95% CI, 1.48-4.89).
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The effect of DNMT3A mutations in human AML remains elusive, because DNMT3A(mutant) AMLs did not express a methylation or gene expression signature that discriminates them from patients with DNMT3A(wild-type) AML.
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We conclude that DNMT3A mutation status is an important factor to consider for risk stratification of patients with AML.
title: Mutant DNMT3A: a marker of poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia.

text: INTRODUCTION: Chromosomal rearrangements involving neurotrophic tyrosine kinase 1 (NTRK1) occur in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLCs) and other solid tumor malignancies, leading to expression of an oncogenic TrkA fusion protein.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Entrectinib (RXDX-101) is an orally available tyrosine kinase inhibitor, including TrkA.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We sought to determine the frequency of NTRK1 rearrangements in NSCLC and to assess the clinical activity of entrectinib.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: METHODS: We screened 1378 cases of NSCLC using anchored multiplex polymerase chain reaction (AMP).
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A patient with an NTRK1 gene rearrangement was enrolled onto a Phase 1 dose escalation study of entrectinib in adult patients with locally advanced or metastatic tumors (NCT02097810).
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: We assessed safety and response to treatment.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: We identified NTRK1 gene rearrangements at a frequency of 0.1% in this cohort.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A patient with stage IV lung adenocrcinoma with an SQSTM1-NTRK1 fusion transcript expression was treated with entrectinib.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Entrectinib was well tolerated, with no grade 3-4 adverse events.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Within three weeks of starting on treatment, the patient reported resolution of prior dyspnea and pain.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Restaging CT scans demonstrated a RECIST partial response (PR) and complete resolution of all brain metastases.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: This patient has continued on treatment for over 6 months with an ongoing PR.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Entrectinib demonstrated significant anti-tumor activity in a patient with NSCLC harboring an SQSTM1-NTRK1 gene rearrangement, indicating that entrectinib may be an effective therapy for tumors with NTRK gene rearrangements, including those with central nervous system metastases.
title: Durable Clinical Response to Entrectinib in NTRK1-Rearranged Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Antiangiogenic therapy is commonly used for the treatment of colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: Although patients derive some clinical benefit, treatment resistance inevitably occurs.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: The MET signaling pathway has been proposed to be a major contributor of resistance to antiangiogenic therapy.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: MET is upregulated in response to vascular endothelial growth factor pathway inhibition and plays an essential role in tumorigenesis and progression of tumors.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: In this study, we set out to determine the efficacy of cabozantinib in a preclinical CRC patient-derived tumor xenograft model.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: We demonstrate potent inhibitory effects on tumor growth in 80% of tumors treated.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: The greatest antitumor effects were observed in tumors that possess a mutation in the PIK3CA gene.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: The underlying antitumor mechanisms of cabozantinib consisted of inhibition of angiogenesis and Akt activation and significantly decreased expression of genes involved in the PI3K pathway.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: These findings support further evaluation of cabozantinib in patients with CRC.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: PIK3CA mutation as a predictive biomarker of sensitivity is intriguing and warrants further elucidation.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: A clinical trial of cabozantinib in refractory metastatic CRC is being activated.
title: Potent antitumor activity of cabozantinib, a c-MET and VEGFR2 inhibitor, in a colorectal cancer patient-derived tumor explant model.

text: PURPOSE: Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene and vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR) activity are critical in the pathogenesis of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC).
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Sorafenib, a multikinase inhibitor targeting Ret and VEGFR, showed antitumor activity in preclinical studies of MTC.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: In this phase II trial of sorafenib in patients with advanced MTC, the primary end point was objective response.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Secondary end points included toxicity assessment and response correlation with tumor markers, functional imaging, and RET mutations.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Using a two-stage design, 16 or 25 patients were to be enrolled onto arms A (hereditary) and B (sporadic).
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Patients received sorafenib 400 mg orally twice daily.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: RESULTS: Of 16 patients treated in arm B, one achieved partial response (PR; 6.3%; 95% CI, 0.2% to 30.2%), 14 had stable disease (SD; 87.5%; 95% CI, 61.7% to 99.5%), and one was nonevaluable.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: In a post hoc analysis of 10 arm B patients with progressive disease (PD) before study, one patient had PR of 21+ months, four patients had SD >or= 15 months, four patients had SD <or= 6 months, and one patient had clinical PD.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Median progression-free survival was 17.9 months.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Arm A was prematurely terminated because of slow accrual.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Common adverse events (AEs) included diarrhea, hand-foot-skin reaction, rash, and hypertension.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Although serious AEs were rare, one death was seen.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Tumor markers decreased in the majority of patients, and RET mutations were detected in 10 of 12 sporadic MTCs analyzed.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Sorafenib is reasonably well tolerated, with suggestion of clinical benefit for patients with sporadic MTC.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: Caution should be taken because of the rare but fatal toxicity potentially associated with sorafenib.
title: Phase II clinical trial of sorafenib in metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

text: PTEN: hamartoma tumor syndrome (PHTS) is a group of syndromes caused by mutations in PTEN.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Gorham-Stout phenomenon (GSP) is a rare condition characterized by proliferation of vascular structures in bones, resulting in progressive osteolysis.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Here we present a 1-year-old boy with PHTS and GSP.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: The lesion that later proved to be GSP was evident from the age of 4 months, and became symptomatic at the age of 1 year.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Eventually, he developed a fatal chylothorax.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Mutation analysis revealed a germline heterozygous mutation c.517 C>T (p.Arg173Cys) in exon 6 of PTEN.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Analysis of the lymphatic malformation (LM) tissue revealed no loss of heterozygosity (LOH) nor a second, somatic PTEN mutation of the remaining wild type allele.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: The germline p.Arg173Cys mutation was also present in the mother and the propositus' younger sister and brother.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Further molecular work-up showed a heterozygous variant c.2180C>T (p.Ala727Val) FLT4 in the LM tissue, which was also present in the germline of mother and two siblings.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: GSP has not been reported before in a patient with a PTEN mutation.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: Up to this date, this mutation is the only genetic defect possibly involved in the etiology of GSP which is plausible given the known function of PTEN in angiogenic signaling.
title: PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome and Gorham-Stout phenomenon.

text: BACKGROUND: Cetuximab has shown clinical benefit in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) harboring wild-type RAS.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) amplification may be a mechanism of cetuximab resistance.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: We evaluated the association between HER2 amplification and cetuximab efficacy in patients with mCRC harboring wild-type RAS and BRAF.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Between December 2003 and June 2013, we identified 142 patients with mCRC whose tumors harbored both wild-type exons 2, 3, and 4 in KRAS and NRAS, and wild-type exon 15 in BRAF using high throughput sequencing (OncoMap version 4.0).
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: All patients received cetuximab after oxaliplatin, irinotecan, and fluoropyrimidine failure.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: HER2 status was determined using immunohistochemistry and silver in situ hybridization (SISH) and correlated with cetuximab efficacy.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: RESULTS: Of 142 RAS and BRAF wild-type tumors, we observed 7 cases (4.9%) of HER2 amplification by SISH.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: After a median follow-up of 13.2 months (range, 1.4-78.1 months), median progression-free survival (PFS) was significantly different according to HER2 status: 3.1 months in patients with HER2 amplification compared with 5.6 months in those with non-amplified HER2 (hazard ratio, 2.73; 95% confidence interval, 1.18-6.31; P = .019).
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: Overall survival (OS) was not significantly different between groups, although there was a tendency towards shorter OS in patients with HER2-amplified tumors (hazard ratio, 1.31; 95% confidence interval, 0.61-2.82; 10.1 vs. 13.5 months; P = .488).
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: CONCLUSIONS: HER2 amplification is predictive of shorter PFS after cetuximab treatment in patients with mCRC harboring wild-type RAS and BRAF.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: Further study is warranted for this patient population.
title: HER2 Amplification and Cetuximab Efficacy in Patients With Metastatic Colorectal Cancer Harboring Wild-type RAS and BRAF.

text: Entrectinib, a potent oral inhibitor of the tyrosine kinases TRKA/B/C, ROS1, and ALK, was evaluated in two phase I studies in patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors, including patients with active central nervous system (CNS) disease.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: Here, we summarize the overall safety and report the antitumor activity of entrectinib in a cohort of patients with tumors harboring NTRK1/2/3, ROS1, or ALK gene fusions, naive to prior TKI treatment targeting the specific gene, and who were treated at doses that achieved therapeutic exposures consistent with the recommended phase II dose.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: Entrectinib was well tolerated, with predominantly Grades 1/2 adverse events that were reversible with dose modification.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: Responses were observed in non-small cell lung cancer, colorectal cancer, mammary analogue secretory carcinoma, melanoma, and renal cell carcinoma, as early as 4 weeks after starting treatment and lasting as long as >2 years.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: Notably, a complete CNS response was achieved in a patient with SQSTM1-NTRK1-rearranged lung cancer.Significance: Gene fusions of NTRK1/2/3, ROS1, and ALK (encoding TRKA/B/C, ROS1, and ALK, respectively) lead to constitutive activation of oncogenic pathways.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: Entrectinib was shown to be well tolerated and active against those gene fusions in solid tumors, including in patients with primary or secondary CNS disease.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: Cancer Discov; 7(4); 400-9.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: (c)2017 AACR.This article is highlighted in the In This Issue feature, p. 339.
title: Safety and Antitumor Activity of the Multitargeted Pan-TRK, ROS1, and ALK Inhibitor Entrectinib: Combined Results from Two Phase I Trials (ALKA-372-001 and STARTRK-1).

text: PURPOSE: Somatic mutations of PIK3CA, which encodes the p110alpha catalytic subunit of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase, have recently been shown to play an important role in the pathogenesis and progression of human breast cancers.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: In this study, the frequency of PIK3CA mutations and their relationship with clinicopathologic and biological variables were investigated in Japanese breast cancers.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Mutational analysis of PIK3CA was done in 188 primary breast cancers of Japanese women.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: Relationship of these mutations with various clinicopathologic variables [histologic type, tumor size, histologic grade, lymph node status, estrogen receptor (ER)-alpha and progesterone receptor status, and prognosis], biological variables [phospho-AKT (pAKT) and HER2 expression determined by immunohistochemistry], and p53 mutation status was studied.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: RESULTS: Missense mutations of PIK3CA were found in 44 of 158 invasive ductal carcinomas, 4 of 10 invasive lobular carcinomas, 1 of 4 mucinous carcinomas, 2 of 2 squamous carcinomas, and 2 of 2 apocrine carcinomas, but no mutation was found in 12 noninvasive ductal carcinomas.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: PIK3CA-mutated tumors were found to be more likely to be ER-alpha positive (P < 0.05) and pAKT positive (P < 0.05).
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: There was no significant association between PIK3CA mutations and p53 mutation status.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: PIK3CA mutations were significantly (P < 0.05) associated with a favorable prognosis, and multivariate analysis showed that PIK3CA mutation status was a significant (P < 0.05) prognostic factor independent of the other conventional prognostic factors.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The frequency of PIK3CA mutations in Japanese breast cancers is similar to that of Caucasian breast cancers.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: Association of PIK3CA mutations with positive pAKT and positive ER-alpha suggests that PIK3CA mutations might exert their effects through activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/AKT/ER-alpha pathway.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: PIK3CA mutations seem to have a potential to be used as an indicator of favorable prognosis.
title: Clinicopathologic analysis of breast cancers with PIK3CA mutations in Japanese women.

text: BACKGROUND: Patients with progressive disease after two or more HER2-directed regimens for recurrent or metastatic breast cancer have few effective therapeutic options.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: We aimed to compare trastuzumab emtansine, an antibody-drug conjugate comprising the cytotoxic agent DM1 linked to trastuzumab, with treatment of physician's choice in this population of patients.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: METHODS: This randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial took place in medical centres in 22 countries across Europe, North America, South America, and Asia-Pacific.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Eligible patients (>/=18 years, left ventricular ejection fraction >/=50%, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status 0-2) with progressive HER2-positive advanced breast cancer who had received two or more HER2-directed regimens in the advanced setting, including trastuzumab and lapatinib, and previous taxane therapy in any setting, were randomly assigned (in a 2:1 ratio) to trastuzumab emtansine (3.6 mg/kg intravenously every 21 days) or physician's choice using a permuted block randomisation scheme by an interactive voice and web response system.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Patients were stratified according to world region (USA vs western Europe vs other), number of previous regimens (excluding single-agent hormonal therapy) for the treatment of advanced disease (two to three vs more than three), and presence of visceral disease (any vs none).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Coprimary endpoints were investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival in the intention-to-treat population.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: We report the final PFS analysis and the first interim overall survival analysis.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01419197.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: FINDINGS: From Sept 14, 2011, to Nov 19, 2012, 602 patients were randomly assigned (404 to trastuzumab emtansine and 198 to physician's choice).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: At data cutoff (Feb 11, 2013), 44 patients assigned to physician's choice had crossed over to trastuzumab emtansine.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: After a median follow-up of 7.2 months (IQR 5.0-10.1 months) in the trastuzumab emtansine group and 6.5 months (IQR 4.1-9.7) in the physician's choice group, 219 (54%) patients in the trastuzumab emtansine group and 129 (65%) of patients in the physician's choice group had PFS events.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: PFS was significantly improved with trastuzumab emtansine compared with physician's choice (median 6.2 months [95% CI 5.59-6.87] vs 3.3 months [2.89-4.14]; stratified hazard ratio [HR] 0.528 [0.422-0.661]; p<0.0001).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Interim overall survival analysis showed a trend favouring trastuzumab emtansine (stratified HR 0.552 [95% CI 0.369-0.826]; p=0.0034), but the stopping boundary was not crossed.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: A lower incidence of grade 3 or worse adverse events was reported with trastuzumab emtansine than with physician's choice (130 events [32%] in 403 patients vs 80 events [43%] in 184 patients).
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Neutropenia (ten [2%] vs 29 [16%]), diarrhoea (three [<1%] vs eight [4%]), and febrile neutropenia (one [<1%] vs seven [4%]) were grade 3 or worse adverse events that were more common in the physician's choice group than in the trastuzumab emtansine group.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: Thrombocytopenia (19 [5%] vs three [2%]) was the grade 3 or worse adverse event that was more common in the trastuzumab emtansine group.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: 74 (18%) patients in the trastuzumab emtansine group and 38 (21%) in the physician's choice group reported a serious adverse event.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Trastuzumab emtansine should be considered as a new standard for patients with HER2-positive advanced breast cancer who have previously received trastuzumab and lapatinib.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: FUNDING: Genentech.
title: Trastuzumab emtansine versus treatment of physician's choice for pretreated HER2-positive advanced breast cancer (TH3RESA): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.

text: UNLABELLED: Kinase inhibitors are accepted treatment for metastatic melanomas that harbor specific driver mutations in BRAF or KIT, but only 40% to 50% of cases are positive.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: To uncover other potential targetable mutations, we conducted whole-genome sequencing of a highly aggressive BRAF (V600) and KIT (W557, V559, L576, K642, and D816) wild-type melanoma.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: Surprisingly, we found a somatic BRAF(L597R) mutation in exon 15.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: Analysis of BRAF exon 15 in 49 tumors negative for BRAF(V600) mutations as well as driver mutations in KIT, NRAS, GNAQ, and GNA11, showed that two (4%) harbored L597 mutations and another two involved BRAF D594 and K601 mutations.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: In vitro signaling induced by L597R/S/Q mutants was suppressed by mitogen-activated protein (MAP)/extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) kinase (MEK) inhibition.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: A patient with BRAF(L597S) mutant metastatic melanoma responded significantly to treatment with the MEK inhibitor, TAK-733.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: Collectively, these data show clinical significance to BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: This study shows that cells harboring BRAF(L597R) mutants are sensitive to MEK inhibitor treatment, providing a rationale for routine screening and therapy of BRAF(L597R)-mutant melanoma.
title: BRAF(L597) mutations in melanoma are associated with sensitivity to MEK inhibitors.

text: BACKGROUND: There have been conflicting data regarding the prevalence and clinicopathological characteristics of BRAF and NRAS mutations in primary cutaneous melanoma.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: OBJECTIVES: To solve this controversy, this study used a meta-analysis to evaluate the frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations, and the relationship between these mutations and clinicopathological parameters of cutaneous melanoma.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: Data from studies published between 1989 and 2010 were combined.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: The BRAF and NRAS mutations were reported in 36 and 31 studies involving 2521 and 1972 patients, respectively.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: The effect sizes of outcome parameters were calculated by odds ratios (OR).
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: BRAF and NRAS mutations were reported in 41% and 18% of cutaneous melanomas, respectively.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: The mutations were associated with histological subtype and tumour site, but not with age and sex.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: The BRAF mutation was frequently detected in patients with superficial spreading melanoma (OR=2.021; P<0.001) and in melanomas arising in nonchronic sun-damaged skin (OR=2.043; P=0.001).
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: In contrast, the NRAS mutation was frequently evident in patients with nodular melanoma (OR=1.894; P<0.001) and in melanomas arising in chronic sun-damaged skin (OR=1.887; P=0.018).
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This pooled analysis shows that the incidences of BRAF and NRAS mutations in cutaneous melanomas differ according to histological type and tumour location based on the degree of sun exposure.
title: Frequencies of BRAF and NRAS mutations are different in histological types and sites of origin of cutaneous melanoma: a meta-analysis.

text: Relapse is the most common cause of treatment failure in pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and is often difficult to predict.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: To explore the prognostic impact of recurrent DNA copy number abnormalities on relapse, we performed high-resolution genomic profiling of 34 paired diagnosis and relapse ALL samples.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: Recurrent lesions detected at diagnosis, including PAX5, CDKN2A and EBF1, were frequently absent at relapse, indicating that they represent secondary events that may be absent in the relapse-prone therapy-resistant progenitor cell.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: In contrast, deletions and nonsense mutations in IKZF1 (IKAROS) were highly enriched and consistently preserved at the time of relapse.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: A targeted copy number screen in an unselected cohort of 131 precursor B-ALL cases, enrolled in the dexamethasone-based Dutch Childhood Oncology Group treatment protocol ALL9, revealed that IKZF1 deletions are significantly associated with poor relapse-free and overall survival rates.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: Separate analysis of ALL9-treatment subgroups revealed that non-high-risk (NHR) patients with IKZF1 deletions exhibited a approximately 12-fold higher relative relapse rate than those without IKZF1 deletions.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: Consequently, IKZF1 deletion status allowed the prospective identification of 53% of the relapse-prone NHR-classified patients within this subgroup and, therefore, serves as one of the strongest predictors of relapse at the time of diagnosis with high potential for future risk stratification.
title: IKZF1 deletions predict relapse in uniformly treated pediatric precursor B-ALL.

text: BACKGROUND: EGFR mutation is a strong predictive factor of EGFR-TKIs therapy.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: However, at least 10% of patients with EGFR wild-type are responsive to TKIs, suggesting that other determinants of outcome besides EGFR mutation might exist.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: We hypothesized that activation of phosphorylated EGFR could be a potential predictive biomarker to EGFR-TKIs treatment among patients in wild-type EGFR.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: METHOD: Total of 205 stage IIIb and IV NSCLC patients, tissue samples of whom were available for molecular analysis, were enrolled in this study.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: The phosphorylation of EGFR at tyrosine 1068 (pTyr1068) and 1173 (pTyr1173) were assessed by immunohistochemistry, and EGFR mutations were detected by denaturing high performance liquid chromatograph (DHPLC).
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: RESULTS: Among 205 patients assessable for EGFR mutation and phosphorylation analysis, 92 (44.9%) were EGFR mutant and 165 patients (57.6%) had pTyr1173 expression.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: Superior progression-free survival (PFS) was seen after EGFR-TKIs therapy in patients with pTyr1068 expression compared to pTyr1068 negative ones (median PFS 7.0 months vs. 1.2 months, P < 0.001).
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: Inversely, patients with pTyr1173 had a shorter PFS (4.8 months VS. 7.7 months, P = 0.016).
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: In subgroup of patients with wild-type EGFR, pTyr1068 expression positive ones had a significantly prolonged PFS (4.2 months vs.1.2 months P < 0.001) compared with those without pTyr1068 expression.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: Sixteen patients with both wild-type EGFR and pTyr1068 who responded to EGFR-TKIs had median PFS of 15.6 months (95%CI: 7.28-23.9).
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: CONCLUSION: pTyr1068 may be a predictive biomarker for screening the population for clinical response to EGFR-TKIs treatment; especially for patients with wild-type EGFR.
title: Phosphorylated EGFR expression may predict outcome of EGFR-TKIs therapy for the advanced NSCLC patients with wild-type EGFR.

text: BACKGROUND: Mutations occur in several genes in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells: the nucleophosmin gene (NPM1), the fms-related tyrosine kinase 3 gene (FLT3), the CCAAT/enhancer binding protein alpha gene (CEPBA), the myeloid-lymphoid or mixed-lineage leukemia gene (MLL), and the neuroblastoma RAS viral oncogene homolog (NRAS).
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We evaluated the associations of these mutations with clinical outcomes in patients.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: METHODS: We compared the mutational status of the NPM1, FLT3, CEBPA, MLL, and NRAS genes in leukemia cells with the clinical outcome in 872 adults younger than 60 years of age with cytogenetically normal AML.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Patients had been entered into one of four trials of therapy for AML.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In each study, patients with an HLA-matched related donor were assigned to undergo stem-cell transplantation.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: RESULTS: A total of 53% of patients had NPM1 mutations, 31% had FLT3 internal tandem duplications (ITDs), 11% had FLT3 tyrosine kinase-domain mutations, 13% had CEBPA mutations, 7% had MLL partial tandem duplications (PTDs), and 13% had NRAS mutations.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The overall complete-remission rate was 77%.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The genotype of mutant NPM1 without FLT3-ITD, the mutant CEBPA genotype, and younger age were each significantly associated with complete remission.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Of the 663 patients who received postremission therapy, 150 underwent hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation from an HLA-matched related donor.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Significant associations were found between the risk of relapse or the risk of death during complete remission and the leukemia genotype of mutant NPM1 without FLT3-ITD (hazard ratio, 0.44; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.32 to 0.61), the mutant CEBPA genotype (hazard ratio, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.30 to 0.75), and the MLL-PTD genotype (hazard ratio, 1.56; 95% CI, 1.00 to 2.43), as well as receipt of a transplant from an HLA-matched related donor (hazard ratio, 0.60; 95% CI, 0.44 to 0.82).
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The benefit of the transplant was limited to the subgroup of patients with the prognostically adverse genotype FLT3-ITD or the genotype consisting of wild-type NPM1 and CEBPA without FLT3-ITD.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Genotypes defined by the mutational status of NPM1, FLT3, CEBPA, and MLL are associated with the outcome of treatment for patients with cytogenetically normal AML.
title: Mutations and treatment outcome in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: Although it has been suggested that a high level of thymidylate synthase (TYMS) gene expression in malignant tumors is related to reduced sensitivity to the antifolate drug pemetrexed, no direct evidence for such an association has been demonstrated in routine clinical samples from patients treated with the drug.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The purpose of this study was to quantitatively assess the impact of TYMS gene expression in tumor cells as a predictor of the efficacy of pemetrexed therapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) treated at our institution.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: Sixty-two NSCLC patients were included in this study: 16 patients received platins-pemetrexed as first-line NSCLC, and 46 pemetrexed in monotherapy as second- or subsequent-line treatment.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Total mRNA was isolated and the expression of TYMS was analyzed by RT-qPCR.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: TYMS levels were calibrated against expression in normal lung tissue.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: TYMS overexpression was detected in 61 % of patients and low expression in 39 %.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The response rate for patients with low TYMS expression was 0.29 compared with 0.03 in patients with overexpression (P = 0.025).
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: A significant benefit was observed in patients with low expression both in time to progression (average TTP = 56 vs. 23 months, P = 0.001) and in overall survival (average OS = 60 vs. 25 months, P = 0.002).
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: TYMS overexpression in tumor cells correlated with a reduced response to pemetrexed-containing chemotherapy and might be used as a predictive biomarker in advanced NSCLC patients.
title: Thymidylate synthase expression as a predictive biomarker of pemetrexed sensitivity in advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate the usefulness and the pitfalls inherent to the assessment of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene copy number (GCN) by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) for outcome prediction to cetuximab in metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: Clinical usefulness of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive marker in colorectal cancer patients treated with cetuximab: a fluorescent in situ hybridization study.

text: The value of testing KRAS mutation status, in addition to EGFR GCN, was also explored.
title: Clinical usefulness of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive marker in colorectal cancer patients treated with cetuximab: a fluorescent in situ hybridization study.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: FISH analysis of 87 metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with cetuximab was done, recording individual GCN per cell and using different samples per tumor.
title: Clinical usefulness of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive marker in colorectal cancer patients treated with cetuximab: a fluorescent in situ hybridization study.

text: Performances of published cutoff points and different summaries of EGFR GCN distribution were assessed for response prediction.
title: Clinical usefulness of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive marker in colorectal cancer patients treated with cetuximab: a fluorescent in situ hybridization study.

text: RESULTS: In our data set, two published cutoff points performed less well than in their training set, yielding positive predictive values and negative predictive values between 40.0% and 48.3% and between 81.0% and 86.5%, respectively.
title: Clinical usefulness of EGFR gene copy number as a predictive marker in colorectal cancer patients treated with cetuximab: a fluorescent in situ hybridization study.
