title: A systematic profile of clinical inhibitors responsive to EGFR somatic amino acid mutations in lung cancer: implication for the molecular mechanism of drug resistance and sensitivity.

text: There are few effective treatments for recurrent glioblastoma multiforme (GBM).
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: We present a patient with recurrent GBM who achieved a prolonged response to treatment with afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, plus temozolomide.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: A 58-year-old female patient was diagnosed with multifocal primary GBM.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: After surgical resection, first-line therapy comprised radiotherapy and temozolomide.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: Following disease progression after 3 temozolomide cycles, the patient entered a phase I/II clinical trial of afatinib (20-40 mg daily for 28 days) plus temozolomide (50 mg/m2 every 21/28 days).
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: Next-generation sequencing analysis of the brain tumor specimen was performed.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: At the last assessment, 63 treatment cycles had been completed and the patient had survived for ~5 years since recurrence.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: Significant disease regression was observed after 5 cycles and was maintained during long-term follow-up.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: Adverse events were consistent with the known tolerability profile of afatinib and were managed by treatment interruption/dose reduction.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: The patient had several epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) aberrations, including gene amplification and EGFRvIII positivity.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: Three somatic mutations were identified, including an unprecedented extracellular-domain substitution (D247Y).
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: The patient has survived ~6-fold longer than normally expected in patients with recurrent GBM.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: The complex EGFR genotype may underlie sustained response to afatinib plus temozolomide.
title: Afatinib, an irreversible ErbB family blocker, with protracted temozolomide in recurrent glioblastoma: a case report.

text: Linkage analysis suggests that mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are responsible for cancer predisposition in more than 80% of the families with high incidence of breast/ovarian cancer.
title: De novo Alu element insertions targeted to a sequence common to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

text: However, pathogenic mutations in the BRCA1/2 genes are generally identified in much less than half of the families investigated in a diagnostic setting with the currently used PCR-based screening protocols.
title: De novo Alu element insertions targeted to a sequence common to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

text: Here we report the identification of two different de novo Alu element insertions within the BRCA1/2 coding sequences in three out of the 50 families in which we found a cancer predisposing mutation, suggesting that this type of mutation is much more common than suggested by their occurrence in mutation databases.
title: De novo Alu element insertions targeted to a sequence common to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

text: The Alu insertion in the BRCA2 gene resulted in the removal of the targeted exon from the corresponding mRNA molecule.
title: De novo Alu element insertions targeted to a sequence common to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

text: Unexpectedly the Target Site Duplications generated by both Alu element insertions contained a specific 9 bp long segment, which might eventually serve as a recognition site for the transposition machinery.
title: De novo Alu element insertions targeted to a sequence common to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

text: Finally, in contrast to the disease causing Alu insertions reported to date, the transposon identified in the BRCA1 gene does not belong to a "young" AluY but to an AluS subfamily, indicating that some of these "old" Alu elements, which are supposed to be non-functional fossil relics, are still able to retrotranspose in vivo.
title: De novo Alu element insertions targeted to a sequence common to the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes.

text: PURPOSE: Although the safety and feasibility of partial adrenalectomy in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome have been established, long-term outcomes have not been examined.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: In this study we evaluate the recurrence and functional outcomes in a von Hippel-Lindau syndrome cohort treated for pheochromocytoma with partial adrenalectomy with a followup of at least 5 years.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: We reviewed the records of patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome treated with partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma at the National Cancer Institute.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Demographic, germline mutation status, surgical indication, oncologic and functional outcome data were collected.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Local recurrence was defined as radiographic evidence of recurrent tumor on the ipsilateral side of partial adrenalectomy.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Patients were considered steroid dependent if they required steroids at most recent followup.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: RESULTS: A total of 36 partial adrenalectomies for pheochromocytoma were performed in 26 patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome between September 1995 and December 2003.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Of these cases 23 were performed open and 13 were performed laparoscopically.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Prior surgical history was obtained for all patients.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: At a median followup of 9.25 years (range 5 to 46) metastatic pheochromocytoma had not developed in any patients.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: In 3 patients (11%) there were 5 local recurrences treated with surgical extirpation or active surveillance.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: All recurrences were asymptomatic and detected by radiographic imaging on followup.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: In addition, 3 of 26 patients (11%) subsequently required partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma on the contralateral adrenal gland.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: In the entire cohort only 3 patients became steroid dependent (11%).
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Outcomes of partial adrenalectomy in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome with pheochromocytoma are encouraging at long-term followup and should be recommended as a primary surgical approach whenever possible.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Adrenal sparing surgery can obviate the need for steroid replacement in the majority of patients.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: Local recurrence rates appear to be infrequent and can be managed successfully with subsequent observation or intervention.
title: Functional and oncologic outcomes of partial adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome after at least 5 years of followup.

text: BACKGROUND: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)-rearranged non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is markedly sensitive to the ALK inhibitor crizotinib.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: However, acquired resistance to crizotinib is inevitable through several mechanisms.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: Therefore, this study was conducted to identify genetic alterations associated with crizotinib resistance.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: METHODS: Tumor samples were derived from seven ALK-positive NSCLC patients who showed acquired resistance to crizotinib, and these patients were analyzed for ALK, EGFR, and KRAS mutations and ALK and EGFR gene amplifications.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: In vitro cytotoxicity of crizotinib and ALK downstream signals were compared between crizotinib-naive and -resistant NSCLC cells.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: After a median duration of 6 months (range, 4-12 months), seven ALK-positive NSCLC patients developed acquired resistance to crizotinib.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: Three patients harbored secondary ALK mutations, including one patient with both mutations: L1196M (n = 2) and G1269A (n = 2).
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: Of note, one patient displayed ALK gene copy number gain (4.1-fold increase compared with the pre-crizotinib specimen) and EGFR L858R mutation with high polysomy.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: The amphiregulin concentration was high in the supernatant fluid from five patients with malignant pleural effusion (116.4-18934.0 pg/ml).
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: SNU-2535 cells derived from a patient who harbored the G1269 mutation were resistant to crizotinib treatment similar to H3122 CR1 cells.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: L1196M and G1269A mutant clones were less sensitive to crizotinib and ALK downstream signals were ineffectively suppressed in these clones.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Genetic changes associated with crizotinib resistance are heterogeneous in ALK-rearranged NSCLC patients who respond to crizotinib and subsequently develop resistance.
title: Heterogeneity of genetic changes associated with acquired crizotinib resistance in ALK-rearranged lung cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Metastasis is responsible for the death of most cancer patients, yet few therapeutic agents are available which specifically target the molecular events that lead to metastasis.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: We recently showed that inactivating mutations in the tumor suppressor gene BAP1 are closely associated with loss of melanocytic differentiation in uveal melanoma (UM) and metastasis.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: The purpose of this study was to identify therapeutic agents that reverse the phenotypic effects of BAP1 loss in UM.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: In silico screens were done to identify therapeutic compounds predicted to differentiate UM cells using Gene Set Enrichment Analysis and Connectivity Map databases.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: Valproic acid (VPA), trichostatin A, LBH-589, and suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid were evaluated for their effects on UM cells using morphologic evaluation, MTS viability assays, bromodeoxyuridine incorporation, flow cytometry, clonogenic assays, gene expression profiling, histone acetylation and ubiquitination assays, and a murine xenograft tumorigenicity model.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: RESULTS: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors induced morphologic differentiation, cell-cycle exit, and a shift to a differentiated, melanocytic gene expression profile in cultured UM cells.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: VPA inhibited the growth of UM tumors in vivo.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggest that HDAC inhibitors may have therapeutic potential for inducing differentiation and prolonged dormancy of micrometastatic disease in UM.
title: Histone deacetylase inhibitors induce growth arrest and differentiation in uveal melanoma.

text: PURPOSE: The first-generation ALK tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) crizotinib is a standard therapy for patients with ALK-rearranged non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: Several next-generation ALK-TKIs have entered the clinic and have shown promising activity in crizotinib-resistant patients.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: As patients still relapse even on these next-generation ALK-TKIs, we examined mechanisms of resistance to the next-generation ALK-TKI alectinib and potential strategies to overcome this resistance.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We established a cell line model of alectinib resistance, and analyzed a resistant tumor specimen from a patient who had relapsed on alectinib.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: We developed Ba/F3 models harboring alectinib-resistant ALK mutations and evaluated the potency of other next-generation ALK-TKIs in these models.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: We tested the antitumor activity of the next-generation ALK-TKI ceritinib in the patient with acquired resistance to alectinib.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: To elucidate structure-activity relationships of ALK mutations, we performed computational thermodynamic simulation with MP-CAFEE.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: RESULTS: We identified a novel V1180L gatekeeper mutation from the cell line model and a second novel I1171T mutation from the patient who developed resistance to alectinib.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: Both ALK mutations conferred resistance to alectinib as well as to crizotinib, but were sensitive to ceritinib and other next-generation ALK-TKIs.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: Treatment of the patient with ceritinib led to a marked response.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: Thermodynamics simulation suggests that both mutations lead to distinct structural alterations that decrease the binding affinity with alectinib.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We have identified two novel ALK mutations arising after alectinib exposure that are sensitive to other next-generation ALK-TKIs.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: The ability of ceritinib to overcome alectinib-resistance mutations suggests a potential role for sequential therapy with multiple next-generation ALK-TKIs.
title: Two novel ALK mutations mediate acquired resistance to the next-generation ALK inhibitor alectinib.

text: BACKGROUND: Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia is an incurable, IgM-secreting lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (LPL).
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: The underlying mutation in this disorder has not been delineated.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: METHODS: We performed whole-genome sequencing of bone marrow LPL cells in 30 patients with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia, with paired normal-tissue and tumor-tissue sequencing in 10 patients.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: Sanger sequencing was used to validate the findings in samples from an expanded cohort of patients with LPL, those with other B-cell disorders that have some of the same features as LPL, and healthy donors.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: RESULTS: Among the patients with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia, a somatic variant (T-->C) in LPL cells was identified at position 38182641 at 3p22.2 in the samples from all 10 patients with paired tissue samples and in 17 of 20 samples from patients with unpaired samples.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: This variant predicted an amino acid change (L265P) in MYD88, a mutation that triggers IRAK-mediated NF-kappaB signaling.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: Sanger sequencing identified MYD88 L265P in tumor samples from 49 of 54 patients with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia and in 3 of 3 patients with non-IgM-secreting LPL (91% of all patients with LPL).
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: MYD88 L265P was absent in paired normal tissue samples from patients with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia or non-IgM LPL and in B cells from healthy donors and was absent or rarely expressed in samples from patients with multiple myeloma, marginal-zone lymphoma, or IgM monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: Inhibition of MYD88 signaling reduced IkappaBalpha and NF-kappaB p65 phosphorylation, as well as NF-kappaB nuclear staining, in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia cells expressing MYD88 L265P.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: Somatic variants in ARID1A in 5 of 30 patients (17%), leading to a premature stop or frameshift, were also identified and were associated with an increased disease burden.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: In addition, 2 of 3 patients with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia who had wild-type MYD88 had somatic variants in MLL2.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: MYD88 L265P is a commonly recurring mutation in patients with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia that can be useful in differentiating Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia and non-IgM LPL from B-cell disorders that have some of the same features.
title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

title: MYD88 L265P somatic mutation in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

text: L-Asparaginase (l-ASP), a bacterial enzyme used since the 1970s to treat acute lymphoblastic leukemia, selectively starves cells that cannot synthesize sufficient asparagine for their own needs.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Molecular profiling of the NCI-60 cancer cell lines using five different microarray platforms showed strong negative correlations of asparagine synthetase (ASNS) expression and DNA copy number with sensitivity to l-ASP in the leukemia and ovarian cancer cell subsets.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: To assess whether the ovarian relationship is causal, we used RNA interference to silence ASNS in three ovarian lines and observed 4- to 5-fold potentiation of sensitivity to l-ASP with two of the lines.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: For OVCAR-8, the line that expresses the least ASNS, the potentiation was >500-fold.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Significantly, that potentiation was >700-fold in the multidrug-resistant derivative OVCAR-8/ADR, showing that the causal relationship between ASNS expression and l-ASP activity survives development of classical multidrug resistance.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Tissue microarrays confirmed low ASNS expression in a subset of clinical ovarian cancers as well as other tumor types.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Overall, this pharmacogenomic/pharmacoproteomic study suggests the use of l-ASP for treatment of a subset of ovarian cancers (and perhaps other tumor types), with ASNS as a biomarker for patient selection.
title: Asparagine synthetase as a causal, predictive biomarker for L-asparaginase activity in ovarian cancer cells.

text: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (FL-HCC) is a rare liver tumor affecting adolescents and young adults with no history of primary liver disease or cirrhosis.
title: Detection of a recurrent DNAJB1-PRKACA chimeric transcript in fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: We identified a chimeric transcript that is expressed in FL-HCC but not in adjacent normal liver and that arises as the result of a ~400-kilobase deletion on chromosome 19.
title: Detection of a recurrent DNAJB1-PRKACA chimeric transcript in fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: The chimeric RNA is predicted to code for a protein containing the amino-terminal domain of DNAJB1, a homolog of the molecular chaperone DNAJ, fused in frame with PRKACA, the catalytic domain of protein kinase A. Immunoprecipitation and Western blot analyses confirmed that the chimeric protein is expressed in tumor tissue, and a cell culture assay indicated that it retains kinase activity.
title: Detection of a recurrent DNAJB1-PRKACA chimeric transcript in fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Evidence supporting the presence of the DNAJB1-PRKACA chimeric transcript in 100% of the FL-HCCs examined (15/15) suggests that this genetic alteration contributes to tumor pathogenesis.
title: Detection of a recurrent DNAJB1-PRKACA chimeric transcript in fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: AKT is a key node in the most frequently deregulated signaling network in human cancer.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: AZD5363, a novel pyrrolopyrimidine-derived compound, inhibited all AKT isoforms with a potency of 10 nmol/L or less and inhibited phosphorylation of AKT substrates in cells with a potency of approximately 0.3 to 0.8 mumol/L.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: AZD5363 monotherapy inhibited the proliferation of 41 of 182 solid and hematologic tumor cell lines with a potency of 3 mumol/L or less.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: Cell lines derived from breast cancers showed the highest frequency of sensitivity.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: There was a significant relationship between the presence of PIK3CA and/or PTEN mutations and sensitivity to AZD5363 and between RAS mutations and resistance.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: Oral dosing of AZD5363 to nude mice caused dose- and time-dependent reduction of PRAS40, GSK3beta, and S6 phosphorylation in BT474c xenografts (PRAS40 phosphorylation EC(50) ~ 0.1 mumol/L total plasma exposure), reversible increases in blood glucose concentrations, and dose-dependent decreases in 2[18F]fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose ((18)F-FDG) uptake in U87-MG xenografts.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: Chronic oral dosing of AZD5363 caused dose-dependent growth inhibition of xenografts derived from various tumor types, including HER2(+) breast cancer models that are resistant to trastuzumab.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: AZD5363 also significantly enhanced the antitumor activity of docetaxel, lapatinib, and trastuzumab in breast cancer xenografts.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: It is concluded that AZD5363 is a potent inhibitor of AKT with pharmacodynamic activity in vivo, has potential to treat a range of solid and hematologic tumors as monotherapy or a combinatorial agent, and has potential for personalized medicine based on the genetic status of PIK3CA, PTEN, and RAS.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: AZD5363 is currently in phase I clinical trials.
title: Preclinical pharmacology of AZD5363, an inhibitor of AKT: pharmacodynamics, antitumor activity, and correlation of monotherapy activity with genetic background.

text: Pancreatic islet cell tumors (ICTs) occur as sporadic neoplasias or as a manifestation of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) and von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL).
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: Molecular classification of ICTs is mandatory for timely diagnosis and surveillance.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: Systematic comparison of VHL-ICTs and sporadic ICTs has been lacking.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: Our registry-based approaches used the German NET-Registry with 259 patients with neuroendocrine tumors (NETs), who were primarily diagnosed with NETs, and the German VHL-Registry with 485 molecular genetically confirmed patients who had undergone magnetic resonance imaging or computed tomography of the abdomen.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: All patients provided blood DNA for testing of the MEN1 and VHL genes for intragenic mutations and large deletions.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: In the NET-Registry, 9/101 patients (8.9%) with ICTs had germline mutations, 8 in MEN1 and 1 in VHL.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: In the VHL-Registry, prevalence of NETs was 52/487 (10.6%), and all were ICTs.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: Interestingly, of those with VHL p.R167W, 47% developed ICTs, compared to 2% of those with p.Y98H.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: In total, there were 92 truly sporadic, i e  mutation-negative ICT patients.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: Comparing these with the 53 VHL-ICT patients, the statistically significant differences were predominance of female gender (P=0.01), multifocal ICTs (P=0.0029), and lower malignancy rate (P<0.001) in VHL-ICTs compared to sporadic cases.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: VHL was prevalent in <0.5% of NETs, while NETs occur in approximately 10% of VHL, virtually exclusively as ICTs, which are rarely the first presentation.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: Patients with NETs should not be subjected to genetic testing of the VHL gene, unless they have multifocal ICTs, other VHL-associated tumors, and/or a family history for VHL.
title: Systematic comparison of sporadic and syndromic pancreatic islet cell tumors.

text: PURPOSE Mutations in the DNA damage response gene ATR (exon 10 A10 mononucleotide repeat) have been previously described in endometrial and other cancers with defective DNA mismatch repair.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: In vitro studies showed that endometrial cancer cell lines with A10 repeat tract truncating mutations have a failure in the ATR-dependent DNA damage response.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: Cell lines carrying A10 mutations fail to trigger Chk1 activation in response to ionizing radiation and topoisomerase inhibitors.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: We sought to determine the frequency and clinicopathologic significance of ATR mutations in patients with endometrioid endometrial cancer.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS The ATR exon 10 A10 repeat was analyzed by direct sequencing in 141 tumors with microsatellite instability (MSI-positive) and 107 microsatellite stable (MSI-negative) tumors.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: The relationships between mutations and clinicopathologic variables, including overall and disease-free survival, were assessed using contingency table tests and Cox proportional hazard models.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: Results ATR mutations were identified in 12 cases (4.8%; three cases with insertions and nine cases with deletions).
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: Mutations occurred exclusively in MSI-positive tumors (P = .02), with an overall mutation rate of 8.5%.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: Mutation was not associated with age, race, surgical stage, International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics grade, or adjuvant treatment.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: Multivariate analyses revealed a significant association with reduced overall survival (hazard ratio [HR] = 3.88; 95% CI, 1.64 to 9.18; P = .002) and disease-free survival (HR = 4.29; 95% CI, 1.48 to 12.45; P = .007).
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: CONCLUSION Truncating ATR mutations in endometrial cancers are associated with biologic aggressiveness as evidenced by reduced disease-free and overall survival.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: Knowledge of ATR mutation status may hold promise for individualized treatment and targeted therapies in patients with endometrial cancer.
title: ATR mutation in endometrioid endometrial cancer is associated with poor clinical outcomes.

text: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to elucidate clinical implications of ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer (MBC) after taxane plus trastuzumab (TH) chemotherapy.
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: METHODS: Using genomic DNA samples extracted from mononuclear cells of consecutive patients with HER2-positive MBC who received first-line TH, we analyzed five polymorphisms (ABCB1 1236C>T, ABCB1 2677G>T/A, ABCB1 3435C>T, FCGR2A 131H/R, and FCGR3A 158V/F) and then correlated them with the response rate, progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and adverse events of patients.
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: RESULTS: A total of 57 women were analyzed.
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: The median age was 46 years (range 27-72).
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: ABCB1 2677T carriers had a longer PFS (p = 0.037) along with a tendency toward a longer OS (p = 0.057).
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: ABCB1 3435CC genotype carriers had a shorter PFS (p = 0.039) along with a tendency toward a shorter OS (p = 0.093).
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: In combined analysis, PFS was significantly longer in ABCB1 1236CC and/or 2677TT carriers compared to the others (p = 0.006).
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: FCGR2A 131H/R and FCGR3A 158V/F polymorphisms were not significantly associated with response rate, PFS, and OS.
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our data support that ABCB1 polymorphisms may predict PFS after first-line TH chemotherapy in patients with HER2-positive MBC.
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: In contrast, FCGR2A 131H/R and FCGR3A 158V/F polymorphisms could not predict treatment outcomes.
title: ABCB1, FCGR2A, and FCGR3A polymorphisms in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer who were treated with first-line taxane plus trastuzumab chemotherapy.

text: PURPOSE: Intracranial efficacy of first-line crizotinib versus chemotherapy was compared prospectively in the phase III PROFILE 1014 study in ALK-positive non-small-cell lung cancer.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients were randomly assigned to receive crizotinib (250 mg twice daily; n = 172) or chemotherapy (pemetrexed 500 mg/m(2) plus cisplatin 75 mg/m(2) or carboplatin at area under the curve 5 to 6, every 3 weeks for </= six cycles; n = 171).
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: Patients with stable treated brain metastases (tBM) were eligible.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: Intracranial efficacy was assessed at baseline and every 6 or 12 weeks in patients with or without known brain metastases (BM), respectively; intracranial time to tumor progression (IC-TTP; per protocol) and intracranial disease control rate (IC-DCR; post hoc) were measured.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: The intent-to-treat population was also assessed.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: RESULTS: Of 343 patients in the intent-to-treat population, 23% had tBM at baseline.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: A nonsignificant IC-TTP improvement was observed with crizotinib in the intent-to-treat population (hazard ratio [HR], 0.60; P = .069), patients with tBM (HR, 0.45; P = .063), and patients without BM (HR, 0.69; P = .323).
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: Among patients with tBM, IC-DCR was significantly higher with crizotinib versus chemotherapy at 12 weeks (85% v 45%, respectively; P < .001) and 24 weeks (56% v 25%, respectively; P = .006).
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: Progression-free survival was significantly longer with crizotinib versus chemotherapy in both subgroups (tBM present: HR, 0.40; P < .001; median, 9.0 v 4.0 months, respectively; BM absent: HR, 0.51; P < .001; median, 11.1 v 7.2 months, respectively) and in the intent-to-treat population (HR, 0.45; P < .001; median, 10.9 v 7.0 months, respectively).
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: CONCLUSION: Compared with chemotherapy, crizotinib demonstrated a significantly higher IC-DCR in patients with tBM.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: Improvements in IC-TTP were not statistically significant in patients with or without tBM, although sensitivity to detect treatment differences in or between the two subgroups was low.
title: Intracranial Efficacy of Crizotinib Versus Chemotherapy in Patients With Advanced ALK-Positive Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Results From PROFILE 1014.

text: Dabrafenib and trametinib were approved for use as monotherapies in BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 2013, and most recently, their use in combination has received accelerated FDA approval.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: Both drugs target the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway: dabrafenib selectively inhibits mutant BRAF that constitutively activates the pathway, and trametinib selectively inhibits MEK1 and MEK2 proteins activated by RAF kinases.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: The phase III study of dabrafenib in BRAF(V600E) metastatic melanoma reported rapid tumor regression in most patients and a 59% objective RECIST response rate.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: The median progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) were improved compared with dacarbazine.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: Toxicities were well tolerated and different from those reported for vemurafenib, the first FDA-approved BRAF inhibitor.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: Efficacy has been demonstrated in other BRAF-mutant genotypes.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: The phase III study of trametinib in BRAF inhibitor-naive patients with BRAF(V600E) or BRAF(V600K) also showed benefit with a prolonged median PFS and OS compared with chemotherapy.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: Trametinib is ineffective in patients who have progressed on BRAF inhibitors.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: A phase II trial of combined dabrafenib and trametinib demonstrated higher response rates and longer median PFS than dabrafenib monotherapy, with less cutaneous toxicity.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: Here, we review the clinical development of both drugs as monotherapies and in combination, and discuss their role in the management of BRAF-mutant melanoma.
title: Dabrafenib and trametinib, alone and in combination for BRAF-mutant metastatic melanoma.

text: The outcome of patients with acute myeloid leukemia who are older than 60 years has remained poor because of unfavorable disease characteristics and patient-related factors.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: The randomized German-Austrian AML Study Group 06-04 protocol was designed on the basis of in vitro synergistic effects of valproic acid (VPA) and all-trans retinoic acid with chemotherapy.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: Between 2004 and 2006, 186 patients were randomly assigned to receive 2 induction cycles with idarubicin, cytarabine, and all-trans retinoic acid either with VPA or without (STANDARD).
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: In all patients, consolidation therapy was intended.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: Complete remission rates after induction tended to be lower in VPA compared with STANDARD (40% vs 52%; P = .14) as a result of a higher early death rate (26% vs 14%; P = .06).
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: The main toxicities attributed to VPA were delayed hematologic recovery and grade 3/4 infections, observed predominantly during the second induction cycle.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: After restricting VPA to the first induction cycle and reducing the dose of idarubicin, these toxicities dropped to rates observed in STANDARD.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: After a median follow-up time of 84 months, event-free and overall survival were not different between the 2 groups (P = .95 and P = .57, respectively).
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: However, relapse-free-survival was significantly superior in VPA compared with STANDARD (24.4% vs 6.4% at 5 years; P = .02).
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: Explorative subset analyses revealed that AML with mutated Nucleophosmin 1 (NPM1) may particularly benefit from VPA.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: This trial was registered at www.clinicaltrials.gov as #NCT00151255.
title: Valproic acid in combination with all-trans retinoic acid and intensive therapy for acute myeloid leukemia in older patients.

text: Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) receptors (PDGFR) and their ligands play critical roles in several human malignancies.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: Sunitinib is a clinically approved multitargeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor that inhibits vascular endothelial growth factor receptor, c-KIT, and PDGFR, and has shown clinical activity in various solid tumors.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: Activation of PDGFR signaling has been described in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (PDGFRA mutations) as well as in chronic myeloid leukemia (BCR-PDGFRA translocation), and sunitinib can yield clinical benefit in both settings.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: However, the discovery of PDGFR activating mutations or gene rearrangements in other tumor types could reveal additional patient populations who might benefit from treatment with anti-PDGFR therapies, such as sunitinib.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: Using a high-throughput cancer cell line screening platform, we found that only 2 of 637 tested human tumor-derived cell lines show significant sensitivity to single-agent sunitinib exposure.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: These two cell lines [a non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and a rhabdomyosarcoma] showed expression of highly phosphorylated PDGFRA.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: In the sunitinib-sensitive adenosquamous NSCLC cell line, PDGFRA expression was associated with focal PFGRA gene amplification, which was similarly detected in a small fraction of squamous cell NSCLC primary tumor specimens.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: Moreover, in this NSCLC cell line, focal amplification of the gene encoding the PDGFR ligand PDGFC was also detected, and silencing PDGFRA or PDGFC expression by RNA interference inhibited proliferation.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: A similar codependency on PDGFRA and PDGFC was observed in the sunitinib-sensitive rhabdomyosarcoma cell line.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: These findings suggest that, in addition to gastrointestinal stromal tumors, rare tumors that show PDGFC-mediated PDGFRA activation may also be clinically responsive to pharmacologic PDGFRA or PDGFC inhibition.
title: Ligand-dependent platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)-alpha activation sensitizes rare lung cancer and sarcoma cells to PDGFR kinase inhibitors.

text: PURPOSE: The antibody-drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 (T-DM1) combines the biologic activity of trastuzumab with targeted delivery of a potent antimicrotubule agent, DM1, to human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-overexpressing cancer cells.
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: Based on results from a phase I study that showed T-DM1 was well tolerated at the maximum-tolerated dose of 3.6 mg/kg every 3 weeks, with evidence of efficacy, in patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer (MBC) who were previously treated with trastuzumab, we conducted a phase II study to further define the safety and efficacy of T-DM1 in this patient population.
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: This report describes a single-arm phase II study (TDM4258g) that assessed efficacy and safety of intravenous T-DM1 (3.6 mg/kg every 3 weeks) in patients with HER2-positive MBC who had tumor progression after prior treatment with HER2-directed therapy and who had received prior chemotherapy.
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: RESULTS: With a follow-up of >/= 12 months among 112 treated patients, the objective response rate by independent assessment was 25.9% (95% CI, 18.4% to 34.4%).
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: Median duration of response was not reached as a result of insufficient events (lower limit of 95% CI, 6.2 months), and median progression-free survival time was 4.6 months (95% CI, 3.9 to 8.6 months).
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: The response rates were higher among patients with confirmed HER2-positive tumors (immunohistochemistry 3+ or fluorescent in situ hybridization positive) by retrospective central testing (n = 74).
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: Higher response rates were also observed in patients whose tumors expressed >/= median HER2 levels by quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction for HER2 expression, compared with patients who had less than median HER2 levels.
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: T-DM1 was well tolerated with no dose-limiting cardiotoxicity.
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: Most adverse events (AEs) were grade 1 or 2; the most frequent grade >/= 3 AEs were hypokalemia (8.9%), thrombocytopenia (8.0%), and fatigue (4.5%).
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: CONCLUSION: T-DM1 has robust single-agent activity in patients with heavily pretreated, HER2-positive MBC and is well tolerated at the recommended phase II dose.
title: Phase II study of the antibody drug conjugate trastuzumab-DM1 for the treatment of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-positive breast cancer after prior HER2-directed therapy.

text: BACKGROUND: Cyclin E, a regulator of the cell cycle, affects the behavior of breast-cancer cells.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: We investigated whether levels of cyclin E in the tumor correlated with survival among patients with breast cancer.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: METHODS: Tumor tissue from 395 patients with breast cancer was assayed for cyclin E, cyclin D1, cyclin D3, and the HER-2/neu oncogene with the use of Western blot analysis.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: Full-length, low-molecular-weight, and total cyclin E were measured.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: Immunohistochemical assessments of cyclin E were also made of 256 tumors.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: We sought correlations between levels of these molecular markers and disease-specific and overall survival.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: The median follow-up was 6.4 years.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: A high level of the low-molecular-weight isoforms of cyclin E, as detected by Western blotting, correlated strongly with disease-specific survival whether axillary lymph nodes were negative or positive for metastases (P<0.001).
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: Among 114 patients with stage I breast cancer, none of the 102 patients with low levels of cyclin E in the tumor had died of breast cancer by five years after diagnosis, whereas all 12 patients with a high level of low-molecular-weight cyclin E had died of breast cancer within that period.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: In multivariate analysis, a high total cyclin E level or high levels of the low-molecular-weight forms of cyclin E were significantly correlated with poor outcome.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: The hazard ratio for death from breast cancer for patients with high total cyclin E levels as compared with those with low total cyclin E levels was 13.3--about eight times as high as the hazard ratios associated with other independent clinical and pathological risk factors.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Levels of total cyclin E and low-molecular-weight cyclin E in tumor tissue, as measured by Western blot assay, correlate strongly with survival in patients with breast cancer.
title: Cyclin E and survival in patients with breast cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 and 2 (IDH1 and IDH2) have been implicated in tumorigenesis of gliomas.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: Patients with high-grade astrocytomas with IDH1 or IDH2 mutations were reported to have a better survival, but it is unknown if this improved survival also holds for low-grade astrocytoma and whether these mutations predict outcome to specific treatment.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: METHODS: We retrospectively investigated the correlation of IDH1 and IDH2 mutations with overall survival and response to temozolomide in a cohort of patients with dedifferentiated low-grade astrocytomas treated with temozolomide at the time of progression after radiotherapy.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: RESULTS: IDH1 mutations were present in 86% of the 49 progressive astrocytomas.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: No mutations in IDH2 were found.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: Presence of IDH1 mutations were early events and significantly improved overall survival (median survival 48 vs 98 months), but did not affect outcome of temozolomide treatment.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: CONCLUSION: These results indicate that IDH1 mutations identify a subgroup of gliomas with an improved survival, but are unrelated to the temozolomide response.
title: IDH1 mutations in low-grade astrocytomas predict survival but not response to temozolomide.

text: BACKGROUND: The phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) tumor suppressor gene is deregulated in many advanced prostate cancers, leading to activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)-Akt-mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway and thus increased cell survival.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate everolimus, an inhibitor of mTOR, in patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC), and to explore potentially predictive serum biomarkers by proteomics, the significance of PTEN status in tumor tissue, and the impact of everolimus on immune cell subpopulations and function.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: A total of 37 chemotherapy-naive patients with mCRPC and progressive disease were recruited to this single-arm phase 2 trial (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00976755).
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: INTERVENTION: Everolimus was administered continuously at a dose of 10mg daily.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: The primary end point was progression-free survival (PFS) at 12 wk defined as the absence of prostate-specific antigen (PSA), radiographic progression, or clinical progression.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Groups were compared using Wilcoxon rank-sum tests or Fisher exact tests for continuous and discrete variables, respectively.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Time-to-event end points were analyzed using the Kaplan-Meier method and univariate Cox regression.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: RESULTS AND LIMITATIONS: A total of 13 patients (35%; 95% confidence interval, 20-53) met the primary end point.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Confirmed PSA response >/=50% was seen in two (5%), and four further patients (11%) had a PSA decline >/=30%.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Higher serum levels of carboxypeptidase M and apolipoprotein B were predictive for reaching the primary end point.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Deletion of PTEN was associated with longer PFS and response.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Treatment was associated with a dose-dependent decrease of CD3, CD4, and CD8 T lymphocytes and CD8 proliferation and an increase in regulatory T cells.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Small sample size was the major limitation of the study.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: CONCLUSIONS: Everolimus activity in unselected patients with mCRPC is moderate, but PTEN deletion could be predictive for response.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Several serum glycoproteins were able to predict PFS at 12 wk.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Prospective validation of these potential biomarkers is warranted.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: TRIAL REGISTRATION: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov with the identifier NCT00976755.
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: Results of this study were presented in part at the 47th Annual Meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (June 3-7, 2011; Chicago, IL, USA) and the annual meeting of the German, Austrian, and Swiss Societies for Oncology and Hematology (September 30-October 4, 2011; Basel, Switzerland).
title: Phase 2 trial of single-agent everolimus in chemotherapy-naive patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer (SAKK 08/08).

text: BACKGROUND: A patient suffering from metastatic colorectal cancer, treatment-related toxicity and resistance to standard chemotherapy and radiation was assessed as part of a personalized oncogenomics initiative to derive potential alternative therapeutic strategies.
title: Response to angiotensin blockade with irbesartan in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Whole-genome and transcriptome sequencing was used to interrogate a metastatic tumor refractory to standard treatments of a patient with mismatch repair-deficient metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: Response to angiotensin blockade with irbesartan in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Integrative genomic analysis indicated overexpression of the AP-1 transcriptional complex suggesting experimental therapeutic rationales, including blockade of the renin-angiotensin system.
title: Response to angiotensin blockade with irbesartan in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: This led to the repurposing of the angiotensin II receptor antagonist, irbesartan, as an anticancer therapy, resulting in the patient experiencing a dramatic and durable response.
title: Response to angiotensin blockade with irbesartan in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This case highlights the utility of comprehensive integrative genomic profiling and bioinformatics analysis to provide hypothetical rationales for personalized treatment options.
title: Response to angiotensin blockade with irbesartan in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: To realize the full potential of targeted protein kinase inhibitors for the treatment of cancer, it is important to address the emergence of drug resistance in treated patients.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: Mutant forms of BCR-ABL, KIT, and the EGF receptor (EGFR) have been found that confer resistance to the drugs imatinib, gefitinib, and erlotinib.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: The mutations weaken or prevent drug binding, and interestingly, one of the most common sites of mutation in all three kinases is a highly conserved "gatekeeper" threonine residue near the kinase active site.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: We have identified existing clinical compounds that bind and inhibit drug-resistant mutant variants of ABL, KIT, and EGFR.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: We found that the Aurora kinase inhibitor VX-680 and the p38 inhibitor BIRB-796 inhibit the imatinib- and BMS-354825-resistant ABL(T315I) kinase.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: The KIT/FLT3 inhibitor SU-11248 potently inhibits the imatinib-resistant KIT(V559D/T670I) kinase, consistent with the clinical efficacy of SU-11248 against imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal tumors, and the EGFR inhibitors EKB-569 and CI-1033, but not GW-572016 and ZD-6474, potently inhibit the gefitinib- and erlotinib-resistant EGFR(L858R/T790M) kinase.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: EKB-569 and CI-1033 are already in clinical trials, and our results suggest that they should be considered for testing in the treatment of gefitinib/erlotinib-resistant non-small cell lung cancer.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: The results highlight the strategy of screening existing clinical compounds against newly identified drug-resistant mutant variants to find compounds that may serve as starting points for the development of next-generation drugs, or that could be used directly to treat patients that have acquired resistance to first-generation targeted therapy.
title: Inhibition of drug-resistant mutants of ABL, KIT, and EGF receptor kinases.

text: Since the introduction of all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O3) for the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), the overall survival rate has improved dramatically.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: However, relapse/refractory patients showing resistance to ATRA and/or As2O3 are recognized as a clinically significant problem.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Genetic mutations resulting in amino acid substitution in the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARalpha) ligand binding domain (LBD) and the PML-B2 domain of PML-RARalpha, respectively, have been reported as molecular mechanisms underlying resistance to ATRA and As2O3.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: In the LBD mutation, ATRA binding with LBD is generally impaired, and ligand-dependent co-repressor dissociation and degradation of PML-RARalpha by the proteasome pathway, leading to cell differentiation, are inhibited.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: The PML-B2 mutation interferes with the direct binding of As2O3 with PML-B2, and PML-RARalpha SUMOylation with As2O3 followed by multimerization and degradation is impaired.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: To overcome ATRA resistance, utilization of As2O3 provides a preferable outcome, and recently, a synthetic retinoid Am80, which has a higher binding affinity with PML-RARalpha than ATRA, has been tested in the clinical setting.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: However, no strategy attempted to date has been successful in overcoming As2O3 resistance.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Detailed genomic analyses using patient samples harvested repeatedly may help in predicting the prognosis, selecting the effective targeting drugs, and designing new sophisticated strategies for the treatment of APL.
title: Mechanisms of action and resistance to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (As2O 3) in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: UNLABELLED: Mutations in the MET exon 14 RNA splice acceptor and donor sites, which lead to exon skipping, deletion of the juxtamembrane domain containing the CBL E3-ubiquitin ligase-binding site, and decreased turnover of the resultant aberrant MET protein, were previously reported to be oncogenic in preclinical models.
title: Response to MET inhibitors in patients with stage IV lung adenocarcinomas harboring MET mutations causing exon 14 skipping.

text: We now report responses to the MET inhibitors crizotinib and cabozantinib in four patients with stage IV lung adenocarcinomas harboring mutations leading to MET exon 14 skipping, highlighting a new therapeutic strategy for the 4% of lung adenocarcinoma patients whose tumors harbor this previously underappreciated genetic alteration.
title: Response to MET inhibitors in patients with stage IV lung adenocarcinomas harboring MET mutations causing exon 14 skipping.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: Oncogenic mutations in the MET exon 14 splice sites that cause exon 14 skipping occur in 4% of lung adenocarcinomas.
title: Response to MET inhibitors in patients with stage IV lung adenocarcinomas harboring MET mutations causing exon 14 skipping.

text: We report responses to the MET inhibitors crizotinib and cabozantinib in patients with lung adenocarcinomas harboring MET exon 14 splice site mutations, identifying a new potential therapeutic target in this disease.
title: Response to MET inhibitors in patients with stage IV lung adenocarcinomas harboring MET mutations causing exon 14 skipping.

text: BACKGROUND: We aimed to assess the effect of afatinib on overall survival of patients with EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma through an analysis of data from two open-label, randomised, phase 3 trials.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: METHODS: Previously untreated patients with EGFR mutation-positive stage IIIB or IV lung adenocarcinoma were enrolled in LUX-Lung 3 (n=345) and LUX-Lung 6 (n=364).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: These patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive afatinib or chemotherapy (pemetrexed-cisplatin [LUX-Lung 3] or gemcitabine-cisplatin [LUX-Lung 6]), stratified by EGFR mutation (exon 19 deletion [del19], Leu858Arg, or other) and ethnic origin (LUX-Lung 3 only).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: We planned analyses of mature overall survival data in the intention-to-treat population after 209 (LUX-Lung 3) and 237 (LUX-Lung 6) deaths.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: These ongoing studies are registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, numbers NCT00949650 and NCT01121393.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: FINDINGS: Median follow-up in LUX-Lung 3 was 41 months (IQR 35-44); 213 (62%) of 345 patients had died.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: Median follow-up in LUX-Lung 6 was 33 months (IQR 31-37); 246 (68%) of 364 patients had died.
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: In LUX-Lung 3, median overall survival was 28.2 months (95% CI 24.6-33.6) in the afatinib group and 28.2 months (20.7-33.2) in the pemetrexed-cisplatin group (HR 0.88, 95% CI 0.66-1.17, p=0.39).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: In LUX-Lung 6, median overall survival was 23.1 months (95% CI 20.4-27.3) in the afatinib group and 23.5 months (18.0-25.6) in the gemcitabine-cisplatin group (HR 0.93, 95% CI 0.72-1.22, p=0.61).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: However, in preplanned analyses, overall survival was significantly longer for patients with del19-positive tumours in the afatinib group than in the chemotherapy group in both trials: in LUX-Lung 3, median overall survival was 33.3 months (95% CI 26.8-41.5) in the afatinib group versus 21.1 months (16.3-30.7) in the chemotherapy group (HR 0.54, 95% CI 0.36-0.79, p=0.0015); in LUX-Lung 6, it was 31.4 months (95% CI 24.2-35.3) versus 18.4 months (14.6-25.6), respectively (HR 0.64, 95% CI 0.44-0.94, p=0.023).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: By contrast, there were no significant differences by treatment group for patients with EGFR Leu858Arg-positive tumours in either trial: in LUX-Lung 3, median overall survival was 27.6 months (19.8-41.7) in the afatinib group versus 40.3 months (24.3-not estimable) in the chemotherapy group (HR 1.30, 95% CI 0.80-2.11, p=0.29); in LUX-Lung 6, it was 19.6 months (95% CI 17.0-22.1) versus 24.3 months (19.0-27.0), respectively (HR 1.22, 95% CI 0.81-1.83, p=0.34).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: In both trials, the most common afatinib-related grade 3-4 adverse events were rash or acne (37 [16%] of 229 patients in LUX-Lung 3 and 35 [15%] of 239 patients in LUX-Lung 6), diarrhoea (33 [14%] and 13 [5%]), paronychia (26 [11%] in LUX-Lung 3 only), and stomatitis or mucositis (13 [5%] in LUX-Lung 6 only).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: In LUX-Lung 3, neutropenia (20 [18%] of 111 patients), fatigue (14 [13%]) and leucopenia (nine [8%]) were the most common chemotherapy-related grade 3-4 adverse events, while in LUX-Lung 6, the most common chemotherapy-related grade 3-4 adverse events were neutropenia (30 [27%] of 113 patients), vomiting (22 [19%]), and leucopenia (17 [15%]).
title: Afatinib versus cisplatin-based chemotherapy for EGFR mutation-positive lung adenocarcinoma (LUX-Lung 3 and LUX-Lung 6): analysis of overall survival data from two randomised, phase 3 trials.

text: INTERPRETATION: Although afatinib did not improve overall survival in the whole population of either trial, overall survival was improved with the drug for patients with del19 EGFR mutations.
