text: In the high EGFR expression group (immunohistochemistry score of >/=200), a survival benefit for the addition of cetuximab to chemotherapy was demonstrated in patients with EGFR wild-type (including T790M mutant) tumors.
title: Relationship between EGFR expression, EGFR mutation status, and the efficacy of chemotherapy plus cetuximab in FLEX study patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Although patient numbers were small, those in the high EGFR expression group whose tumors carried EGFR mutations may also have derived a survival benefit from the addition of cetuximab to chemotherapy.
title: Relationship between EGFR expression, EGFR mutation status, and the efficacy of chemotherapy plus cetuximab in FLEX study patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Response data suggested a cetuximab benefit in the high EGFR expression group regardless of EGFR mutation status.
title: Relationship between EGFR expression, EGFR mutation status, and the efficacy of chemotherapy plus cetuximab in FLEX study patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The survival benefit associated with the addition of cetuximab to first-line chemotherapy for advanced non-small-cell lung cancer expressing high levels of EGFR is not limited by EGFR mutation status.
title: Relationship between EGFR expression, EGFR mutation status, and the efficacy of chemotherapy plus cetuximab in FLEX study patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Broad and deep tumour genome sequencing has shed new light on tumour heterogeneity and provided important insights into the evolution of metastases arising from different clones.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: There is an additional layer of complexity, in that tumour evolution may be influenced by selective pressure provided by therapy, in a similar fashion to that occurring in infectious diseases.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: Here we studied tumour genomic evolution in a patient (index patient) with metastatic breast cancer bearing an activating PIK3CA (phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate 3-kinase, catalytic subunit alpha, PI(3)Kalpha) mutation.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: The patient was treated with the PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor BYL719, which achieved a lasting clinical response, but the patient eventually became resistant to this drug (emergence of lung metastases) and died shortly thereafter.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: A rapid autopsy was performed and material from a total of 14 metastatic sites was collected and sequenced.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: All metastatic lesions, when compared to the pre-treatment tumour, had a copy loss of PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homolog) and those lesions that became refractory to BYL719 had additional and different PTEN genetic alterations, resulting in the loss of PTEN expression.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: To put these results in context, we examined six other patients also treated with BYL719.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: Acquired bi-allelic loss of PTEN was found in one of these patients, whereas in two others PIK3CA mutations present in the primary tumour were no longer detected at the time of progression.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: To characterize our findings functionally, we examined the effects of PTEN knockdown in several preclinical models (both in cell lines intrinsically sensitive to BYL719 and in PTEN-null xenografts derived from our index patient), which we found resulted in resistance to BYL719, whereas simultaneous PI(3)K p110beta blockade reverted this resistance phenotype.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: We conclude that parallel genetic evolution of separate metastatic sites with different PTEN genomic alterations leads to a convergent PTEN-null phenotype resistant to PI(3)Kalpha inhibition.
title: Convergent loss of PTEN leads to clinical resistance to a PI(3)Kalpha inhibitor.

text: The present study was performed to investigate the association of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) located in the miRNA target sites with the clinical outcomes of first line paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in advanced NSCLC.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Eighty SNPs in miRNA binding sites of cancer related genes selected from 18,500 miRNA:target bindings in crosslinking, ligation, and sequencing of hybrids (CLASH) data were investigated in 379 advanced NSCLC patients using a sequenom mass spectrometry-based genotype assay.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: qRT-PCR and luciferase assay were conducted to examine functional relevance of potentially functional SNPs in miRNA binding sites.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Of the 80 SNPs analyzed, 16 SNPs were significantly associated with the clinical outcomes after chemotherapy.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Among these, ANAPC1 rs3814026C>T, ETS2 rs461155A>G, SORBS1 rs7081076C>A and POLR2A rs2071504C>T could predict both chemotherapy response and survival.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Notably, ETS2 rs461155A>G was significantly associated with decreased ETS2 mRNA expression in both tumor and paired normal lung tissues (Ptrend = 4 x 10-7, and 3 x 10-4, respectively).
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Consistently, a decreased expression of the reporter gene for the G allele of rs461155 compared with the A allele was observed by luciferase assay.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: These findings suggest that the four SNPs, especially ETS2 rs461155A>G, could be used as biomarkers predicting the clinical outcomes of NSCLC patients treated with first-line paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy.
title: A genetic variation in microRNA target site of ETS2 is associated with clinical outcomes of paclitaxel-cisplatin chemotherapy in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) are highly aggressive sarcomas that develop sporadically or in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) patients.
title: BET bromodomain inhibition triggers apoptosis of NF1-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors through Bim induction.

text: There is no effective treatment for MPNSTs and they are typically fatal.
title: BET bromodomain inhibition triggers apoptosis of NF1-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors through Bim induction.

text: To gain insights into MPNST pathogenesis, we utilized an MPNST mouse model that allowed us to study the evolution of these tumors at the transcriptome level.
title: BET bromodomain inhibition triggers apoptosis of NF1-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors through Bim induction.

text: Strikingly, in MPNSTs we found upregulation of a chromatin regulator, Brd4, and show that BRD4 inhibition profoundly suppresses both growth and tumorigenesis.
title: BET bromodomain inhibition triggers apoptosis of NF1-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors through Bim induction.

text: Our findings reveal roles for BET bromodomains in MPNST development and report a mechanism by which bromodomain inhibition induces apoptosis through induction of proapoptotic Bim, which may represent a paradigm shift in therapy for MPNST patients.
title: BET bromodomain inhibition triggers apoptosis of NF1-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors through Bim induction.

text: Moreover, these findings indicate epigenetic mechanisms underlying the balance of anti- and proapoptotic molecules and that bromodomain inhibition can shift this balance in favor of cancer cell apoptosis.
title: BET bromodomain inhibition triggers apoptosis of NF1-associated malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors through Bim induction.

text: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors gefitinib and erlotinib are effective treatments for a subset of non-small cell lung cancers.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: In particular, cancers with specific EGFR-activating mutations seem to be the most sensitive to these agents.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: However, despite their initial response, such cancers almost invariably develop resistance.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: In 50% of such cancers, a secondary EGFR mutation, T790M, has been identified that renders gefitinib and erlotinib ineffective inhibitors of EGFR kinase activity.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: Thus, there is a clinical need to develop novel EGFR inhibitors that can effectively inactivate T790M-containing EGFR proteins.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: In this study, we evaluate the effectiveness of a novel compound, PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: The results from these studies show that PF00299804 is a potent inhibitor of EGFR-activating mutations as well as the EGFR T790M resistance mutation both in vitro and in vivo.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: Additionally, PF00299804 is a highly effective inhibitor of both the wild-type ERBB2 and the gefitinib-resistant oncogenic ERBB2 mutation identified in lung cancers.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: These preclinical evaluations support further clinical development of PF00299804 for cancers with mutations and/or amplifications of ERBB family members.
title: PF00299804, an irreversible pan-ERBB inhibitor, is effective in lung cancer models with EGFR and ERBB2 mutations that are resistant to gefitinib.

text: von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) is an inherited neoplastic disorder characterized by the development of tumors in the eyes, brain, spinal cord, inner ear, adrenal gland, pancreas, kidney, and epididymis.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: The VHL tumor suppressor gene was identified in 1993.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: Initial studies reported the detection of germline mutations in the VHL gene in 39-75% of VHL families.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: We used tests that detect different types of mutations to improve the frequency of detection of germline mutations in VHL families.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: The methods included quantitative Southern blotting to detect deletions of the entire VHL gene, Southern blotting to detect gene rearrangements, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm deletions, and complete sequencing of the gene.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: Here we report that we have detected germline mutations in the VHL gene in 100% (93/93) of VHL families tested.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: In addition, we describe 13 novel intragenic VHL germline mutations.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: With the methodology described in this article, it is now possible to identify germline mutations in virtually all families with VHL.
title: Improved detection of germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumor suppressor gene.

text: Hereditary mutations associated with hematologic malignancies are rare.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: Heterozygous mutations affecting the hematopoietic transcription factor CBFA2 (also AML1/RUNX1) were recently reported to be associated with familial platelet disorder with predisposition to acute myeloid leukemia (FPD/AML, MIM 601399).
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: A new 3-generation family with FPD/AML with a novel CBFA2 mutation is described.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: In this family, AML was diagnosed in a second-generation male.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: After allogeneic stem cell transplantation from his human leukocyte antigen-identical sister, a donor-derived, genetically identical leukemia developed in the recipient and the donor.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: Sequencing analysis identified a G-to-T transition within the CBFA2 gene, which involves codon 198, encoding a conserved aspartic acid within the DNA- binding Runt domain.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: Three of 5 siblings affected with the FPD/AML trait harbored the mutation in a heterozygous form.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: This experience underscores the necessity of performing mutation analysis of the CBFA2 gene before sibling allogeneic transplantation in families with FPD/AML.
title: A novel CBFA2 single-nucleotide mutation in familial platelet disorder with propensity to develop myeloid malignancies.

text: INTRODUCTION: Exon 19 deletions and the exon 21 L858R mutation of the epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) predict activity of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors, including erlotinib; however, the ability of less common EGFR mutations to predict efficacy of erlotinib is unclear.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: METHODS: The efficacy of erlotinib in individual patients with rare EGFR mutations from the MERIT, SATURN, TITAN, TRUST, ATLAS, BeTa, and FASTACT-2 trials was analyzed and compared with data from the literature.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: RESULTS: In the patients tested for biomarkers, the frequency of rare mutations identified here ranged from 1.7% (eight of 467) in the SATURN study to 7.4% (27 of 364) in ATLAS.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: Some rare mutations were associated with greater clinical benefit from EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy or improved prognosis independent of treatment, whereas others appeared to have a poorer prognosis.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: In particular, exon 18 G719 mutations, exon 19 K757R and E746G mutations, the exon 20 S768I mutation, and the exon 21 G836S mutation appeared to confer a good outcome with erlotinib treatment, whereas exon 18 S720I showed a particularly poor outcome.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: Owing to the small number of patients with each mutation, however, it is difficult to confirm whether these rare mutations do indeed confer sensitivity or resistance to erlotinib.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Erlotinib can have different efficacy depending on the specific EGFR mutation.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: More research is needed to create a central database such as the My Cancer Genome database of rare mutations to definitively confirm whether these mutations are activating, resistant, or neutral.
title: Examining Treatment Outcomes with Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Harbor Uncommon EGFR Mutations.

text: "Pericytoma with t(7;12)" is a newly defined soft tissue tumor characterized by fusion of the ACTB and GLI genes through the translocation t(7;12)(p22;q13).
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: Recently, we reported the structure of the ACTB-GLI and GLI-ACTB fusion transcripts in five cases, and herein the corresponding genomic breakpoints were investigated.
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: Overall, the findings at the DNA level corresponded well with the structure of the expressed transcripts.
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: In three cases, the fusions were due to junction of intronic sequences, in two cases breakpoints were found in exonic sequences.
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: In four cases the fusions corresponded to the juxtapositioning of unaltered DNA sequences, and in one case, a micro-inversion was found at the junction.
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: All five fusions were molecularly unbalanced, including the two cases with reciprocal GLI-ACTB chimeras.
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: Whereas large repeats or recombinase recognition sequences were not detected, sequences of shared oligonucleotides, possibly important for recombination, were found in the proximity of the respective breakpoints.
title: Molecular genetic characterization of the genomic ACTB-GLI fusion in pericytoma with t(7;12).

text: Somatic mutations of U2AF1 gene have recently been identified in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: In this study, we analyzed the frequency and clinical impact of U2AF1 mutations in a cohort of 452 Chinese patients with myeloid neoplasms.
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: Mutations in U2AF1 were found in 2.5% (7/275) of AML and 6.3% (6/96) of MDS patients, but in none of 81 CML.
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: All mutations were heterozygous missense mutations affecting codon S34 or Q157.
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: There was no significant association of U2AF1 mutation with blood parameters, FAB subtypes, karyotypes and other gene mutations in AML.
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: The overall survival (OS) of AML patients with U2AF1 mutation (median 3 months) was shorter than those without mutation (median 7 months) (P = 0.035).
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: No difference in the OS was observed between MDS patients with and without U2AF1 mutations.
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: Our data show that U2AF1 mutation is a recurrent event at a low frequency in AML and MDS.
title: U2AF1 mutations in Chinese patients with acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.

text: BACKGROUND AND METHODS: TP53 gene-mutation and expression of p53 have been described to influence the radiosensitivity of tumour cells from head and neck carcinomas.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: The present study was performed to evaluate whether TP53 mutation may influence the clinical outcome of head and neck cancer patients treated with radiotherapy or surgery.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: DNA was extracted from formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue sections from primary biopsies taken before radiotherapy.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: Gene mutations (in exons 5-9) were identified using denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) as the initial scanning procedure and characterized by sequencing.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: Patients were treated with primary radiotherapy or surgery alone.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: Treatment was given according to the DAHANCA schedules with 5 or 6 weekly fractions (2 Gy) of radiotherapy (66-68 Gy).
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: Most patients were also treated with the hypoxic radiosensitizer Nimorazole.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: The results are reported as 5-year actuarial values, and differences estimated by log-rank analysis.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: RESULTS: The present analysis is based on 114 patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, pharynx and oral cavity diagnosed between March 1992 and October 1996.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: Ninety patients received primary radiotherapy alone and 21 were treated with surgery.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: TP53 mutations were found in 45 patients (39%) and in patients receiving radiotherapy, TP53 mutation was highly associated with poor prognosis.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: Loco-regional control rates (5-year actuarial values) for TP53 mutation was 29 vs. 54% for TP53 wildtype (P < 0.01).
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: For disease-free survival the corresponding values were 13 and 38% (P < 0.01), respectively.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: The correlations were not found to be related to specific subtypes of mutations (e g  missense mutations affecting DNA-contact or Zn-binding regions) but rather to the presence of any mutation at all.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: In contrast, TP53 mutation did not influence the response to surgery.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: CONCLUSIONS: A strong relationship was observed between TP53 mutation and poor prognosis (increased risk of loco-regional failure and death) in head and neck cancer patients given primary radiotherapy but not surgery.
title: TP53 mutation is related to poor prognosis after radiotherapy, but not surgery, in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

text: The acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)-specific t(15;17) chromosome abnormality is characterized at the molecular level by rearrangement of the PML and RAR alpha genes, resulting in fusion PML/RAR alpha mRNA and a chimeric protein.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Besides its relevance in the pathogenesis of the disease, this hybrid gene represents a specific tumor marker that is rapidly detectable by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) in the RNA extracted from leukemic blasts.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Several studies have highlighted the clinical relevance of PML/RAR alpha detection, which provides a specific diagnosis, prognostic information, and prediction of relapse when monitoring residual disease during the follow-up.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: In fact, this hybrid gene is detected in 100% of APLs.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Rare cases of patients with a morphological diagnosis of FAB M3 AML who lack the specific PML/RAR alpha abnormality have been reported as being unresponsive to differentiation treatment.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Finally, all the studies reported so far on PCR monitoring in APL have documented that the identification of small amounts of residual disease at remission strongly predicts impending relapse.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: Thus, RT-PCR of the hybrid PML/RAR alpha gene is currently performed prospectively as part of cooperative clinical trials aimed at better addressing post-remission treatment in APL.
title: The PML/RAR alpha fusion gene in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: The response to cytotoxic chemotherapy varies greatly in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), and molecular markers may be useful in determining a preferable therapeutic approach for individual patients.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: This retrospective study was performed to evaluate the predictive value of ribonucleotide reductase regulatory subunit M1 (RRM1) on the therapeutic efficacy of platinum-based chemotherapy in patients with NSCLC.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: METHODS: Patients with advanced NSCLC who received platinum doublet chemotherapy (n = 229) were included in this retrospective study, and their clinical outcomes were analyzed according to RRM1 expression.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: RESULTS: In patients receiving gemcitabine-based therapy, the disease control rate (DCR) and progression-free survival (PFS) of patients with RRM1-negative tumors were significantly higher than in patients with RRMI-positive tumors (P = 0.041 and P = 0.01, respectively), and multivariate analysis showed that RRM1 expression was an independent prognostic factor (P = 0.013).
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: No similar differences were found in patients receiving docetaxel- or vinorelbine-based therapy.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: In RRM1-positive patients, the DCRs for docetaxel and vinorelbine were higher than for gemcitabine (P = 0.047 and P = 0.047, respectively), and docetaxel and vinorelbine showed a longer PFS than gemcitabine-based chemotherapy (P = 0.012 and P = 0.007).
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: No similar differences were found among patients with RRM1-negative tumors.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Negative RRM1 expression in advanced NSCLC is associated with a higher response rate to gemcitabine-based chemotherapy.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: In patients with RRM1-positive tumors, docetaxel and vinorelbine showed a higher therapeutic efficacy than gemcitabine-based therapy.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: Additional prospective studies are needed to investigate the predictive meaning of RRM1 in the response to chemotherapy.
title: Response to first-line chemotherapy in patients with non-small cell lung cancer according to RRM1 expression.

text: Stromal antigen 2 (STAG2) is an important member of cohesin, a conserved complex holding the sister chromatid together.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: Recent whole-genome sequencing studies have identified that genetic alterations of stag2 are common in bladder cancer (BC).
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: The prognostic implications of STAG2 expression in BC remain unclear; we therefore analyzed its associations with the histopathological characteristics and clinical outcome in a Chinese population.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: We used immunohistochemistry assay to determine STAG2 protein expression in tumor tissues from 125 BC patients.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: STAG2 expression was analyzed according to clinicopathological features and patients' survival.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: Univariable and multivariable analyses were performed to identify predictors for recurrence-free survival (RFS) and cancer-specific survival (CSS).
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: STAG2 expression was detected in 79.2 % of BC tissues, and 20.8 % of the tumor tissues had a complete loss of STAG2 protein expression.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: This STAG2-negative result was associated with a lower tumor histological grade with P = 0.009.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: The log-rank analysis revealed that the complete loss of STAG2 expression was associated with a lower risk of recurrence (P = 0.023) and a diminished risk of death (P = 0.034), especially in the subgroup of muscle-invasive BC (P = 0.043 for RFS and P = 0.087 for CSS).
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: In multivariable Cox regression models, the loss of STAG2 expression remained a beneficial factor for RFS and CSS of BC patients.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: Univariate and multivariate analyses' results indicated that the complete loss of STAG2 expression was predictive for better RFS and CSS, suggesting its potential value as a prognostic biomarker.
title: Complete loss of STAG2 expression is an indicator of good prognosis in patients with bladder cancer.

text: The ErbB2-targeting antibody, trastuzumab (Herceptin), has remarkable therapeutic efficacy in certain patients with ErbB2-overexpressing tumors.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: The overall trastuzumab response rate, however, is limited and what determines trastuzumab response is poorly understood.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: Here we report that PTEN activation contributes to trastuzumab's antitumor activity.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: Trastuzumab treatment quickly increased PTEN membrane localization and phosphatase activity by reducing PTEN tyrosine phosphorylation via Src inhibition.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: Reducing PTEN in breast cancer cells by antisense oligonucleotides conferred trastuzumab resistance in vitro and in vivo.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: Patients with PTEN-deficient breast cancers had significantly poorer responses to trastuzumab-based therapy than those with normal PTEN.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: Thus, PTEN deficiency is a powerful predictor for trastuzumab resistance.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: Additionally, PI3K inhibitors rescued PTEN loss-induced trastuzumab resistance, suggesting that PI3K-targeting therapies could overcome this resistance.
title: PTEN activation contributes to tumor inhibition by trastuzumab, and loss of PTEN predicts trastuzumab resistance in patients.

text: OCT4B1, a splice variant of OCT4, is a key regulator in maintaining the properties of pluripotency and self-renewal in embryonic stem (ES) cells.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: Recent results have shown that OCT4B1 is involved in tumorigenesis.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: However, the contribution of OCT4B1 in the tumorigenesis and drug resistance of colon cancer remains to be determined.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: The aim of the present study was to determine whether OCT4B1, which maintains the stemness of ES cells, promoted cell growth by facilitating transition of the cell cycle and reduced apoptosis in colon cancer and drugresistant cells using flow cytometry and western blotting.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: The results showed that, OCT4B1 promoted the growth of colon cancer and drugresistant cancer cells by maintaining the activity of ES cells and by facilitating the transition of the cell cycle and reducing apoptosis.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: Additionally, OCT4B1 was able to reduce sensitivity to oxaliplatin by altering the expression of two important mediators in drug resistance, P-gp and ABCG2 [ATP-binding cassette, subfamily G (WHITE), member 2].
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: Furthermore, OCT4B1 enhanced the ability of migration and invasion through alteration of the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in colon cancer.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: In conclusion, to the best of our knowledge, the results demonstrated for the first time that OCT4B1 functions as an oncogene in colon cancer and provides the development of novel therapeutic strategies to treat colon cancer, particularly drug resistance.
title: OCT4B1 promotes cell growth, migration and invasion suppressing sensitivity to omicronxaliplatin in colon cancer.

text: Mutations of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene have been identified in specimens from patients with non-small-cell lung cancer who have a response to anilinoquinazoline EGFR inhibitors.
title: EGFR mutation and resistance of non-small-cell lung cancer to gefitinib.

text: Despite the dramatic responses to such inhibitors, most patients ultimately have a relapse.
title: EGFR mutation and resistance of non-small-cell lung cancer to gefitinib.

text: The mechanism of the drug resistance is unknown.
title: EGFR mutation and resistance of non-small-cell lung cancer to gefitinib.

text: Here we report the case of a patient with EGFR-mutant, gefitinib-responsive, advanced non-small-cell lung cancer who had a relapse after two years of complete remission during treatment with gefitinib.
title: EGFR mutation and resistance of non-small-cell lung cancer to gefitinib.

text: The DNA sequence of the EGFR gene in his tumor biopsy specimen at relapse revealed the presence of a second point mutation, resulting in threonine-to-methionine amino acid change at position 790 of EGFR.
title: EGFR mutation and resistance of non-small-cell lung cancer to gefitinib.

text: Structural modeling and biochemical studies showed that this second mutation led to gefitinib resistance.
title: EGFR mutation and resistance of non-small-cell lung cancer to gefitinib.

text: This study aimed to determine whether the expression of various tumor biomarkers of the mTOR pathway predicts tumor response to everolimus in metastatic recurrent endometrial cancer.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Tumor blocks from 44 patients of a phase II clinical trial receiving everolimus until progression or toxicity were collected and evaluated at 3 and 6 months for response.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Thirty-six blocks were available for analysis of ER, PR, HER2, LKB1, PI3K, PTEN, pAKT, 4E-BP1, p4E-BP1, and S6RP expression by immunohistochemistry, PTEN deletion by FISH, and mutational status of K-RAS, PIK3CA, PTEN, and AKT1 genes.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Twelve of 34 evaluable patients had partial response or stable disease (PR, SD) and 22 had progressive disease (PD).
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Immunohistochemistry showed that no protein expression could predict response to everolimus.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Neither could loss of PTEN expression or PTEN deletion or PTEN mutation predict patient outcome.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Thirty-one samples were assessable for K-RAS mutations (ten for PR+SD and 21 for PD).
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: There are only four patients with K-RAS mutations and none of them responded to treatment.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: Median progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) were longer in patients without K-RAS mutations (PFS 3.12 +/- 1.7 months versus 1.05 +/- 0.4 months, p < 0.001; OS 9.28 +/- 2.0 months versus 2.30 +/- 1.4 months, p = 0.034).
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: In conclusion, the level of expression of proteins of the PI3K/mTOR pathway tested in this study cannot predict response to everolimus.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: However, endometrial cancer patients with K-RAS mutations do not seem to derive benefit from everolimus treatment.
title: Predicting everolimus treatment efficacy in patients with advanced endometrial carcinoma: a GINECO group study.

text: BACKGROUND: In the BRIM-3 trial, vemurafenib was associated with risk reduction versus dacarbazine of both death and progression in patients with advanced BRAF(V600) mutation-positive melanoma.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: We present an extended follow-up analysis of the total population and in the BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation subgroups.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: METHODS: Patients older than 18 years, with treatment-naive metastatic melanoma and whose tumour tissue was positive for BRAF(V600) mutations were eligible.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: Patients also had to have a life expectancy of at least 3 months, an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1, and adequate haematological, hepatic, and renal function.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: Patients were randomly assigned by interactive voice recognition system to receive either vemurafenib (960 mg orally twice daily) or dacarbazine (1000 mg/m(2) of body surface area intravenously every 3 weeks).
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: Coprimary endpoints were overall survival and progression-free survival, analysed in the intention-to-treat population (n=675), with data censored at crossover.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: A sensitivity analysis was done.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01006980.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: FINDINGS: 675 eligible patients were enrolled from 104 centres in 12 countries between Jan 4, 2010, and Dec 16, 2010.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: 337 patients were randomly assigned to receive vemurafenib and 338 to receive dacarbazine.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: Median follow-up was 12.5 months (IQR 7.7-16.0) on vemurafenib and 9.5 months (3.1-14.7) on dacarbazine.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: 83 (25%) of the 338 patients initially randomly assigned to dacarbazine crossed over from dacarbazine to vemurafenib.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: Median overall survival was significantly longer in the vemurafenib group than in the dacarbazine group (13.6 months [95% CI 12.0-15.2] vs 9.7 months [7.9-12.8]; hazard ratio [HR] 0.70 [95% CI 0.57-0.87]; p=0.0008), as was median progression-free survival (6.9 months [95% CI 6.1-7.0] vs 1.6 months [1.6-2.1]; HR 0.38 [95% CI 0.32-0.46]; p<0.0001).
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: For the 598 (91%) patients with BRAF(V600E) disease, median overall survival in the vemurafenib group was 13.3 months (95% CI 11.9-14.9) compared with 10.0 months (8.0-14.0) in the dacarbazine group (HR 0.75 [95% CI 0.60-0.93]; p=0.0085); median progression-free survival was 6.9 months (95% CI 6.2-7.0) and 1.6 months (1.6-2.1), respectively (HR 0.39 [95% CI 0.33-0.47]; p<0.0001).
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: For the 57 (9%) patients with BRAF(V600K) disease, median overall survival in the vemurafenib group was 14.5 months (95% CI 11.2-not estimable) compared with 7.6 months (6.1-16.6) in the dacarbazine group (HR 0.43 [95% CI 0.21-0.90]; p=0.024); median progression-free survival was 5.9 months (95% CI 4.4-9.0) and 1.7 months (1.4-2.9), respectively (HR 0.30 [95% CI 0.16-0.56]; p<0.0001).
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: The most frequent grade 3-4 events were cutaneous squamous-cell carcinoma (65 [19%] of 337 patients) and keratoacanthomas (34 [10%]), rash (30 [9%]), and abnormal liver function tests (38 [11%]) in the vemurafenib group and neutropenia (26 [9%] of 287 patients) in the dacarbazine group.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: Eight (2%) patients in the vemurafenib group and seven (2%) in the dacarbazine group had grade 5 events.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: INTERPRETATION: Inhibition of BRAF with vemurafenib improves survival in patients with the most common BRAF(V600E) mutation and in patients with the less common BRAF(V600K) mutation.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: FUNDING: F Hoffmann-La Roche-Genentech.
title: Safety and efficacy of vemurafenib in BRAF(V600E) and BRAF(V600K) mutation-positive melanoma (BRIM-3): extended follow-up of a phase 3, randomised, open-label study.

text: PURPOSE: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mRNA expression and EGFR gene dosage by quantitative PCR in tumor samples obtained from patients with gefitinib-treated non-small cell lung cancer were analyzed in order to determine the association with treatment outcome, clinical, and biological features [EGFR copy number by fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), EGFR tyrosine kinase mutations, and EGFR protein expression].
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: EGFR mRNA expression was measured by real-time quantitative reverse transcription-PCR in 64 patients, and EGFR gene dosage was analyzed by real-time quantitative PCR in 82 patients from paraffin-embedded specimens.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: EGFR mRNA expression was higher in responders to gefitinib as compared with nonresponders (P = 0.012).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Patients with high EGFR mRNA expression (>5.01) had 43% response probability, whereas patients with low EGFR mRNA expression had 8% response probability (P = 0.006).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Patients with high EGFR mRNA expression had longer median progression-free (5.3 versus 2.8 months, P = 0.028) but not overall survival (13.8 versus 10.9 months, P = 0.87).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EGFR mRNA expression was higher in FISH-positive patients (P = 0.001) and in patients with positive EGFR immunostaining (P < 0.001) but not in patients with EGFR mutations (P = 0.19).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EGFR gene dosage did not predict response (P = 0.54), progression-free (P = 0.73), or overall survival (P = 0.89).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EGFR gene dosage was not associated with FISH positivity (P = 0.15), relative mRNA expression (P = 0.27), EGFR mutation status (P = 0.39), and EGFR protein expression (P = 0.35).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: EGFR mRNA expression is a predictive biomarker for response to gefitinib and to progression-free survival after gefitinib treatment.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: EGFR gene dosage is neither predictive for response nor progression-free nor overall survival.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor messenger RNA expression, gene dosage, and gefitinib sensitivity in non-small cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (mFL-HCC) is a rare liver tumor defined by the presence of both pure FL-HCC and conventional HCC components, represents up to 25% of cases of FL-HCC, and has been associated with worse prognosis.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Recent genomic characterization of pure FL-HCC identified a highly recurrent transcript fusion (DNAJB1:PRKACA) not found in conventional HCC.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We performed exome and transcriptome sequencing of a case of mFL-HCC.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: A novel BAC-capture approach was developed to identify a 400 kb deletion as the underlying genomic mechanism for a DNAJB1:PRKACA fusion in this case.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: A sensitive Nanostring Elements assay was used to screen for this transcript fusion in a second case of mFL-HCC, 112 additional HCC samples and 44 adjacent non-tumor liver samples.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: We report the first comprehensive genomic analysis of a case of mFL-HCC.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: No common HCC-associated mutations were identified.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: The very low mutation rate of this case, large number of mostly single-copy, long-range copy number variants, and high expression of ERBB2 were more consistent with previous reports of pure FL-HCC than conventional HCC.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: In particular, the DNAJB1:PRKACA fusion transcript specifically associated with pure FL-HCC was detected at very high expression levels.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Subsequent analysis revealed the presence of this fusion in all primary and metastatic samples, including those with mixed or conventional HCC pathology.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: A second case of mFL-HCC confirmed our finding that the fusion was detectable in conventional components.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: An expanded screen identified a third case of fusion-positive HCC, which upon review, also had both conventional and fibrolamellar features.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: This screen confirmed the absence of the fusion in all conventional HCC and adjacent non-tumor liver samples.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: These results indicate that mFL-HCC is similar to pure FL-HCC at the genomic level and the DNAJB1:PRKACA fusion can be used as a diagnostic tool for both pure and mFL-HCC.
title: A genomic case study of mixed fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Resistance to endocrine therapy in estrogen receptor-positive (ER(+)) breast cancer remains a major clinical problem.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Recently, the CDK4/6 inhibitor palbociclib combined with letrozole or fulvestrant was approved for treatment of ER(+) advanced breast cancer.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: However, the role of CDK4/6 in endocrine resistance and their potential as predictive biomarkers of endocrine treatment response remains undefined.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We investigated the specific role of increased CDK6 expression in fulvestrant-resistant cells by gene knockdown and treatment with palbociclib, and evaluated the effect in cell proliferation, apoptosis, and kinase activity.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Furthermore, we evaluated CDK6 expression in metastatic samples from breast cancer patients treated or not with fulvestrant.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: RESULTS: We found increased expression of CDK6 in two fulvestrant-resistant cell models versus sensitive cells.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Reduction of CDK6 expression impaired fulvestrant-resistant cell growth and induced apoptosis.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Treatment with palbociclib resensitized fulvestrant-resistant cells to fulvestrant through alteration of retinoblastoma protein phosphorylation.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: High CDK6 levels in metastatic samples from two independent cohorts of breast cancer patients treated with fulvestrant (N = 45 and 46) correlated significantly with shorter progression-free survival (PFS) on fulvestrant treatment (P = 0.0006 and 0.018), whereas no association was observed in patients receiving other first- or second-/third-line endocrine treatments (N = 68, P = 0.135 and 0.511, respectively).
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our results indicate that upregulation of CDK6 may be an important mechanism in overcoming fulvestrant-mediated growth inhibition in breast cancer cells.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Patients with advanced ER(+) breast cancer exhibiting high CDK6 expression in the metastatic lesions show shorter PFS upon fulvestrant treatment and thus may benefit from the addition of CDK4/6 inhibitors in their therapeutic regimens.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 22(22); 5514-26.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: High CDK6 Protects Cells from Fulvestrant-Mediated Apoptosis and is a Predictor of Resistance to Fulvestrant in Estrogen Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.

text: von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is a dominantly inherited disorder predisposing those afflicted to hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system and the retina, renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic tumors.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: The disease has been associated with mutations of the VHL gene.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: The screening of 92 unrelated patients with VHL disease for point mutations in this gene revealed 61 DNA variants.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: In addition, a search for EcoR1 rearrangements revealed germline anomalies in 5 patients.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: The 61 variants could be subdivided in 20 mutations predicted to alter the open reading frame (8 nonsense mutations, 8 frame shift mutations, and 4 mutations in consensus splicing sites) and 43 DNA sequence variants of a priori unknown biological consequence (4 in-frame insertions or deletions, 36 missense mutations, and 3 apparently silent variations).
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: The 3' end of the coding sequence of the VHL gene, which encodes the Elongin binding domain was the site of 5 of 20 truncating mutations (25%) and of 18 of 41 DNA variants (44%) causing uncertain functional impairment.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: A similar screening in 18 patients with sporadic hemangioblastoma revealed 2 missense DNA variants.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: In order to corroborate this latter observation, a systematic screening for germline alteration of the VHL gene might be performed in a larger series of sporadic hemangioblastoma.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: If this preliminary result is confirmed, more than 10% of sporadic hemangioblastoma might be related to a mild VHL disease, thus a follow-up program similar to that recommended in cases of VHL disease should probably be discussed in the corresponding families.
title: Germline mutation profile of the VHL gene in von Hippel-Lindau disease and in sporadic hemangioblastoma.

text: KRAS mutation is a predictive biomarker for resistance to cetuximab (Erbitux) in metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: This study sought to determine if KRAS mutant CRC lines could be sensitized to cetuximab using dasatinib (BMS-354825, Sprycel), a potent, orally bioavailable inhibitor of several tyrosine kinases, including the Src family kinases (SFKs).
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: We analyzed 16 CRC lines for: (1) KRAS mutation status, (2) dependence on mutant KRAS signaling and (3) expression level of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and SFKs.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: From these analyses, we selected three KRAS mutant (LS180, LoVo and HCT116) cell lines and two KRAS wild-type cell lines (SW48 and CaCo2).
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: In vitro, using poly-D-lysine/laminin plates, KRAS mutant cell lines were resistant to cetuximab, whereas KRAS wild-type lines showed sensitivity to cetuximab.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: Treatment with cetuximab and dasatinib showed a greater antiproliferative effect on KRAS mutant lines when compared with either agent alone in vitro and in vivo.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: To investigate potential mechanisms for this antiproliferative response in the combinatorial therapy, we performed Human Phospho-Kinase Antibody Array analysis, measuring the relative phosphorylation levels of 39 intracellular proteins in untreated, cetuximab, dasatinib or the combinatorial treatment in the KRAS mutant lines LS180, LoVo and HCT116 cells.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: The results of this experiment showed a decrease in a broad spectrum of kinases centered on the beta-catenin pathway, the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, AKT/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway and the family of signal transducers and activators of transcription (STATs) when compared with the untreated control or monotherapy treatments.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: Next, we analyzed tumor growth with cetuximab, dasatinib or their combination in vivo.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: KRAS mutant xenografts showed resistance to cetuximab therapy, whereas KRAS wild type demonstrated an antitumor response when treated with cetuximab.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: KRAS mutant tumors exhibited minimal response to dasatinib monotherapy.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: However, as in vitro, KRAS mutant lines exhibited a response to the combination of cetuximab and dasatinib.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: Combinatorial treatment of KRAS mutant xenografts resulted in decreased cell proliferation, as measured by Ki67, and higher rates of apoptosis, as measured by TUNEL (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated dUTP nick end labeling).
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: The data presented in this study indicate that dasatinib can sensitize KRAS mutant CRC tumors to cetuximab and may do so by altering the activity of several key signaling pathways.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: Furthermore, these results suggest that signaling via EGFR and SFKs may be necessary for cell proliferation and survival of KRAS mutant CRC tumors.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: These data strengthen the rationale for clinical trials combining cetuximab and dasatinib in the KRAS mutant CRC genetic setting.
title: Dasatinib sensitizes KRAS mutant colorectal tumors to cetuximab.

text: Oncogenic RAS expression occurs in up to 40% of multiple myeloma (MM) cases and correlates with aggressive disease.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: Since activated RAS induces cyclooxygenase-2 (cox-2) expression in other tumor models, we tested a role for cox-2 in mutant RAS-containing MM cells.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: We used the ANBL-6 isogenic MM cell lines in which the IL-6-dependent parental line becomes cytokine independent following transfection with mutated N-RAS or K-RAS.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: Both mutated N-RAS- and K-RAS-expressing ANBL-6 cells demonstrated a selective up-regulation of cox-2 expression and enhanced secretion of PGE2, a product of cox-2.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: Furthermore, in 3 primary marrow specimens, which contained MM cells expressing mutated RAS, 15% to 40% of tumor cells were positive for cox-2 expression by immunohistochemistry.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: We used cox-2 inhibitors, NS398 and celecoxib, and neutralizing anti-PGE2 antibody to test whether cox-2/PGE2 was involved in the aggressive phenotype of MM ANBL-6 cells containing mutated RAS.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: Although these interventions had no effect on IL-6-independent growth or adhesion to marrow stromal cells, they significantly inhibited the enhanced binding of mutant RAS-containing MM cells to fibronectin and the enhanced resistance to melphalan.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: These results indicate a selective induction of cox-2 in MM cells containing RAS mutations, which results in heightened binding to extracellular matrix protein and chemotherapeutic drug resistance.
title: Oncogenic RAS mutations in myeloma cells selectively induce cox-2 expression, which participates in enhanced adhesion to fibronectin and chemoresistance.

text: Point mutations in the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase gene have recently been identified in mucosal, acral lentiginous, and chronically sun-damaged melanomas.
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: We have identified the first human melanoma cell line with an endogenous L576P mutation, the most common KIT mutation in melanoma ( approximately 30-40%).
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: In vitro testing showed that the cell viability of the L576P mutant cell line was not reduced by imatinib, nilotinib, or sorafenib small molecule KIT inhibitors effective in nonmelanoma cells with other KIT mutations.
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: However, the viability of the mutant cells was reduced by dasatinib at concentrations as low as 10 nM (P = 0.004).
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: Molecular modeling studies found that the L576P mutation induces structural changes in KIT that reduce the affinity for imatinib (DeltaDeltaGbind = -2.52 kcal/mol) but not for dasatinib (DeltaDeltaGbind = +0.32 kcal/mol).
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: Two metastatic melanoma patients with the L576P KIT mutation were treated with dasatinib, including one patient previously treated with imatinib.
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: Both patients had marked reduction (>50%) and elimination of tumor F18-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-avidity by positron emission tomography (PET) imaging after dasatinib treatment.
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: These data support the selective inhibitory effect of dasatinib against cells harboring the most common KIT mutation in melanoma, and thus has therapeutic implications for acrallentiginous, chronic sun-damaged, and mucosal melanomas.
title: Activity of dasatinib against L576P KIT mutant melanoma: molecular, cellular, and clinical correlates.

text: BACKGROUND: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a well-differentiated thyroid tumor that maintains the typical features of C cells.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: An advanced stage and the presence of lymph node metastases at diagnosis have been demonstrated to be the most important bad prognostic factors.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: Somatic RET mutations have been found in 40-50% of MTCs.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: Although a relationship between somatic mutations and bad prognosis has been described, data are controversial and have been performed in small series with short-term follow ups.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: The aim of this study was to verify the prognostic value of somatic RET mutations in a large series of MTCs with a long follow up.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: METHODS: We studied 100 sporadic MTC patients with a 10.2 yr mean follow-up.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: RET gene exons 10-11 and 13-16 were analyzed.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: The correlation between the presence/absence of a somatic RET mutation, clinical/pathological features, and outcome of MTC patients was evaluated.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: RESULTS: A somatic RET mutation was found in 43 of 100 (43%) sporadic MTCs.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: The most frequent mutation (34 of 43, 79%) was M918T.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: RET mutation occurrence was more frequent in larger tumors (P=0.03), and in MTC with node and distant metastases (P<0.0001 and P=0.02, respectively), thus, a significant correlation was found with a more advanced stage at diagnosis (P=0.004).
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: A worse outcome was also significantly correlated with the presence of a somatic RET mutation (P=0.002).
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: Among all prognostic factors found to be correlated with a worse outcome, at multivariate analysis only the advanced stage at diagnosis and the presence of a RET mutation showed an independent correlation (P<0.0001 and P=0.01, respectively).
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: Finally, the survival curves of MTC patients showed a significantly lower percentage of surviving patients in the group with RET mutations (P=0.006).
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We demonstrated that the presence of a somatic RET mutation correlates with a worse outcome of MTC patients, not only for the highest probability to have persistence of the disease, but also for a lower survival rate in a long-term follow up.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: More interestingly, the presence of a somatic RET mutation correlates with the presence of lymph node metastases at diagnosis, which is a known bad prognostic factor for the definitive cure of MTC patients.
title: Prognostic significance of somatic RET oncogene mutations in sporadic medullary thyroid cancer: a 10-year follow-up study.

text: Amplified and/or mutated MET can act as both a primary oncogenic driver and as a promoter of tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) resistance in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: However, the landscape of MET-specific targeting agents remains underdeveloped, and understanding of mechanisms of resistance to MET TKIs is limited.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: Here, we present a case of a patient with lung adenocarcinoma harboring both a mutation in EGFR and an amplification of MET, who after progression on erlotinib responded dramatically to combined MET and EGFR inhibition with savolitinib and osimertinib.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: When resistance developed to this combination, a new MET kinase domain mutation, D1228V, was detected.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: Our in vitro findings demonstrate that MET(D1228V) induces resistance to type I MET TKIs through impaired drug binding, while sensitivity to type II MET TKIs is maintained.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: Based on these findings, the patient was treated with erlotinib combined with cabozantinib, a type II MET inhibitor, and exhibited a response.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: With several structurally distinct MET inhibitors undergoing development for treatment of NSCLC, it is critical to identify mechanism-based therapies for drug resistance.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: We demonstrate that an acquired MET(D1228V) mutation mediates resistance to type I, but not type II, MET inhibitors, having therapeutic implications for the clinical use of sequential MET inhibitors.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: Cancer Discov; 6(12); 1334-41.
title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.See related commentary by Trusolino, p. 1306This article is highlighted in the In This Issue feature, p. 1293.
