title: Acquired METD1228V Mutation and Resistance to MET Inhibition in Lung Cancer.

text: PURPOSE: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) commonly harbor oncogenic mutations of the KIT tyrosine kinase, which is a target for the kinase inhibitor imatinib.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: A subset of GISTs, however, contains mutations in the homologous kinase platelet derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRA), and the most common of these mutations is resistant to imatinib in vitro.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: Little is known of the other types of PDGFRA mutations that occur in GISTs.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: We determined the KIT and PDGFRA mutation status of 1,105 unique GISTs using a combination of denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography and direct sequencing.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: RESULTS: 66 in exon 18, 11 in exon 12, and three in exon 14.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: Transient expression of representative PDGFRA isoforms in CHO cells revealed imatinib sensitivity of exon 12 mutations (SPDHE566-571R and insertion ER561-562) and an exon 14 substitution (N659K).
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: However, most isoforms with a substitution involving codon D842 in exon 18 (D842V, RD841-842KI, DI842-843IM) were resistant to the drug, with the exception of D842Y.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: Interestingly, other mutations in exon 18 (D846Y, N848K, Y849K and HDSN845-848P) were all imatinib sensitive.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: Proliferation studies with BA/F3 cell lines stably expressing selected PDGFRA mutant isoforms supported these findings.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: CONCLUSION: Including our cases, there are 289 reported PDGFRA-mutant GISTs, of which 181 (62.6%) had the imatinib-resistant substitution D842V.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: However, our findings suggest that more than one third of GISTs with PDGFRA mutations may respond to imatinib and that mutation screening may be helpful in the management of these tumors.
title: PDGFRA mutations in gastrointestinal stromal tumors: frequency, spectrum and in vitro sensitivity to imatinib.

text: BACKGROUND: The clinical use of BRAF inhibitors for treatment of metastatic melanoma is limited by the development of drug resistance.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: In this study we investigated whether co-targeting the MAPK and the PI3K-AKT pathway can prevent emergence of resistance or provide additional growth inhibitory effects in vitro.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: METHODS: Anti-tumor effects of the combination of the BRAF inhibitor (BRAFi) dabrafenib and GSK2141795B (AKTi) in a panel of 23 BRAF mutated melanoma cell lines were evaluated on growth inhibition by an ATP-based luminescent assay, on cell cycle and apoptosis by flow cytometry and on cell signaling by western blot.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Moreover, we investigated the possibilities of delaying or reversing resistance or achieving further growth inhibition by combining AKTi with dabrafenib and/or the MEK inhibitor (MEKi) trametinib by using long term cultures.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: RESULTS: More than 40% of the cell lines, including PTEN-/- and AKT mutants showed sensitivity to AKTi (IC50 < 1.5 muM).
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: The combination of dabrafenib and AKTi synergistically potentiated growth inhibition in the majority of cell lines with IC50 > 5 nM dabrafenib.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Combinatorial treatment induced apoptosis only in cell lines sensitive to AKTi.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: In long term cultures of a PTEN-/- cell line, combinatorial treatment with the MAPK inhibitors, dabrafenib and trametinib, and AKTi markedly delayed the emergence of drug resistance.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Moreover, combining AKTi with the MAPK inhibitors from the beginning provided superior growth inhibitory effects compared to addition of AKTi upon development of resistance to MAPK inhibitors in this particular cell line.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: AKTi combined with BRAFi-based therapy may benefit patients with tumors harboring BRAF mutations and particularly PTEN deletions or AKT mutations.
title: Effects of AKT inhibitor therapy in response and resistance to BRAF inhibition in melanoma.

text: Nucleophosmin (NPM1) exon-12 gene mutations are the hallmark of a large acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) subgroup with normal karyotype, but their prognostic value in this AML subset has not yet been determined.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: We screened 401 AML patients with normal karyotype treated within the German AML Cooperative Group Protocol 99 (AMLCG99) study for NPM1 mutations.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: Results were related with partial tandem duplications within the MLL gene (MLL-PTD), Fms-like tyrosine kinase 3-length mutations (FLT3-LM), the tyrosine kinase domain of FLT3 (FLT3-TKD), NRAS, KIT, and CEBPA mutations and with clinical characteristics and outcome.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: NPM1 mutations were detected in 212 (52.9%) of 401 patients.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: Fourteen mutations, including 8 new variants, were identified.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: NPM1-mutated cases associated frequently with FLT3 mutations but rarely with other mutations.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: The NPM1-mutated group had a higher complete remission (CR) rate (70.5% vs 54.7%, P = .003), a trend to a longer overall survival (OS; median 1012 vs 549 days, P = .076), and significantly longer event-free survival (EFS; median 428 vs 336 days; P = .012).
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: The favorable impact of NPM1 mutations on OS and EFS clearly emerged in the large group (264 [66.8%] of 395 cases) of normal-karyotype AML without FLT3-LM.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: This positive effect was lost in the presence of a concomitant FLT3-LM, since survival of the NPM1+/FLT3-LM+ double positive was similar to NPM1-/FLT3-LM+ cases.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: In conclusion, this study demonstrates that NPM1+/FLT3-LM- mutations are an independent predictor for a favorable outcome in AML with normal karyotype.
title: Nucleophosmin gene mutations are predictors of favorable prognosis in acute myelogenous leukemia with a normal karyotype.

text: PURPOSE: To investigate the frequency and the prognostic role of fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) amplification in patients with surgically resected squamous cell carcinoma of the lung (SCCL) and the association between smoking and FGFR1 amplification.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Gene copy number of FGFR1 was investigated in microarrayed tumors from 262 patients with SCCL who had tumor tissue as well as smoking and survival data available.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Gene copy number was evaluated by fluorescent in situ hybridization, and an FGFR1-amplified tumor (FGFR1 amp(+)) was prespecified as a tumor with nine or more copies of FGFR1.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: Among 262 patients, the frequency of FGFR1 amp(+) was 13.0%.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Patients with FGFR1 amp(+) had significantly shorter disease-free survival (DFS; 26.9 v 94.6 months; P < .001) as well as shorter overall survival (OS; 51.2 v 115.0 months; P = .002) than those without FGFR1 amp(+).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Multivariate modeling confirmed that patients with FGFR1 amp(+) had a significantly greater risk of recurrence and death than those without FGFR1 amp(+) after adjusting for sex, smoking status, pathologic stage, and adjuvant chemotherapy (DFS: adjusted hazard ratio [AHR], 2.24; 95% CI, 1.45 to 3.45; P < .001; OS: AHR, 1.83; 95% CI, 1.15 to 2.89; P = .01).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: The frequency of FGFR1 amp(+) was significantly higher in current smokers than in former smokers and never-smokers (28.9% v 2.5% v 0%; P(trend) < .001).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: As the smoking dosage increased, so did the incidence of FGFR1 amp(+) (P(trend) = .002).
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: FGFR1 amplification is an independent negative prognostic factor in surgically resected SCCL and is associated with cigarette smoking in a dose-dependent manner.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: FGFR1 amplification is a relevant therapeutic target in Asian patients with SCCL.
title: Fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 gene amplification is associated with poor survival and cigarette smoking dosage in patients with resected squamous cell lung cancer.

text: Most prostate cancers (PCs) become resistant to combined androgen blockade therapy with surgical or medical castration and antiandrogens after several years.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Some of these refractory PCs regress after discontinuation of antiandrogen administration [antiandrogen withdrawal syndrome (AWS)].
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Although the molecular mechanisms of the AWS are not fully understood because of the lack of suitable experimental models, one hypothesis of the mechanism is mutation of androgen receptor (AR).
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: However, bicalutamide, which has become the most prevalent pure antiandrogen, does not work as an agonist for any mutant AR detected thus far in PC.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: To elucidate the mechanisms of the AWS, we established and characterized novel LNCaP cell sublines, LNCaP-cxDs, which were generated in vitro by culturing androgen-dependent LNCaP-FGC human PC cells in androgen-depleted medium with bicalutamide to mimic the combined androgen blockade therapy.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: LNCaP-FGC cells did not grow at first, but they started to grow after 6-13 weeks of culture.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Bicalutamide stimulated LNCaP-cxD cell growth and increased prostate-specific antigen secretion from LNCaP-cxD cells both in vitro and in vivo.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Sequencing of AR transcripts revealed that the AR in LNCaP-cxD cells harbors a novel mutation in codon 741, TGG (tryptophan) to TGT (cysteine; W741C), or in codon 741, TGG to TTG (leucine; W741L), in the ligand-binding domain.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Transactivation assays showed that bicalutamide worked as an agonist for both W741C and W741L mutant ARs.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Importantly, another antiandrogen, hydroxyflutamide, worked as an antagonist for these mutant ARs.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: In summary, we demonstrate for the first time that within only 6-13 weeks of in vitro exposure to bicalutamide, LNCaP-FGC cells, whose growth had initially been suppressed, came to use bicalutamide as an AR agonist via W741 AR mutation to survive.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: Our data strongly support the hypothesis that AR mutation is one possible mechanism of the AWS and suggest that flutamide might be effective as a second-line therapy for refractory PC previously treated with bicalutamide.
title: Novel mutations of androgen receptor: a possible mechanism of bicalutamide withdrawal syndrome.

text: PURPOSE: TP53 is a key gene in cellular homeostasis and is frequently mutated in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: There is a variety of TP53 mutations, each with its own biological and clinical implication.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Aim of the study was to assess the prognostic significance of TP53 mutations in HNSCCs and to identify the most relevant mutation.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: TP53 mutation status was investigated in 141 consecutive HNSCCs treated by surgery with radiotherapy when indicated and with a known human papilloma virus status.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The type of mutation was correlated with overall and progression-free survival in a multivariate two-sided Cox regression analysis with wild type as reference.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: A TP53 mutation was found in 88 (62.4%) of the carcinomas and was not significantly associated with overall survival (HR = 1.65, P = 0.11).
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Patients with a mutation resulting in a truncated protein (n = 36, 25.5%) had a significantly worse overall survival (HR = 2.54, P = 0.008) and progression-free survival (HR = 2.65, P = 0.002).
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Four of these mutations were at a splice site, 13 were nonsense mutations (produces stop codon), and 19 were insertions or deletions resulting in a frameshift.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: After multivariate analysis, a truncating mutation remained a significant prognosticator.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: A missense (i.e., nontruncating) mutation did not influence prognosis.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Other ways of classification (disruptive vs. nondisruptive, hotspot vs. nonhotspot, and DNA binding vs. non-DNA binding) were less discriminative.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSION: In HNSCCs, a truncating TP53 mutation is associated with a poor prognosis.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: This patient group seems as a target population for adjuvant therapy with chemoradiation or viral vector-mediated TP53 gene transfer.
title: Prognostic significance of truncating TP53 mutations in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: This first-in-human phase I trial assessed the safety, tolerability, and preliminary antitumor activity of apitolisib (GDC-0980), a dual inhibitor of class I PI3K, and mTOR kinases.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Once-daily oral apitolisib was administered to patients with solid tumors for days 1 to 21 or 1 to 28 of 28-day cycles.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameters were assessed.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: RESULTS: Overall, 120 patients were treated at doses between 2 and 70 mg.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: The commonest >/=G3 toxicities related to apitolisib at the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) at 40 mg once daily included hyperglycemia (18%), rash (14%), liver dysfunction (12%), diarrhea (10%), pneumonitis (8%), mucosal inflammation (6%), and fatigue (4%).
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Dose-limiting toxicities (1 patient each) were G4 fasting hyperglycemia at 40 mg (21/28 schedule) and G3 maculopapular rash and G3 fasting hyperglycemia at 70 mg (21/28 schedule).
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: The pharmacokinetic profile was dose-proportional.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Phosphorylated serine-473 AKT levels were suppressed by >/=90% in platelet-rich plasma within 4 hours at the MTD (50 mg).
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Pharmacodynamic decreases in fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography uptake of >25% occurred in 66% (21/32) of patients dosed at 40 mg once daily.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Evidence of single-agent activity included 10 RECIST partial responses (PR; confirmed for peritoneal mesothelioma, PIK3CA mutant head-and-neck cancer, and three pleural mesotheliomas).
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Apitolisib exhibited dose-proportional pharmacokinetics with target modulation at doses >/=16 mg.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: The RP2D was 40 mg once-daily 28/28 schedule; severe on-target toxicities were apparent at >/=40 mg, particularly pneumonitis.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Apitolisib was reasonably tolerated at 30 mg, the selected dose for pleural mesothelioma patients given limited respiratory reserve.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Modest but durable antitumor activity was demonstrated.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: Clin Cancer Res; 22(12); 2874-84.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: (c)2016 AACR.
title: Phase I Study of Apitolisib (GDC-0980), Dual Phosphatidylinositol-3-Kinase and Mammalian Target of Rapamycin Kinase Inhibitor, in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

text: BACKGROUND: Idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome involves a prolonged state of eosinophilia associated with organ dysfunction.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: It is of unknown cause.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: Recent reports of responses to imatinib in patients with the syndrome suggested that an activated kinase such as ABL, platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR), or KIT, all of which are inhibited by imatinib, might be the cause.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: METHODS: We treated 11 patients with the hypereosinophilic syndrome with imatinib and identified the molecular basis for the response.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: RESULTS: Nine of the 11 patients treated with imatinib had responses lasting more than three months in which the eosinophil count returned to normal.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: One such patient had a complex chromosomal abnormality, leading to the identification of a fusion of the Fip1-like 1 (FIP1L1) gene to the PDGFRalpha (PDGFRA) gene generated by an interstitial deletion on chromosome 4q12.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: FIP1L1-PDGFRalpha is a constitutively activated tyrosine kinase that transforms hematopoietic cells and is inhibited by imatinib (50 percent inhibitory concentration, 3.2 nM).
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: The FIP1L1-PDGFRA fusion gene was subsequently detected in 9 of 16 patients with the syndrome and in 5 of the 9 patients with responses to imatinib that lasted more than three months.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: Relapse in one patient correlated with the appearance of a T674I mutation in PDGFRA that confers resistance to imatinib.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The hypereosinophilic syndrome may result from a novel fusion tyrosine kinase - FIP1L1-PDGFRalpha - that is a consequence of an interstitial chromosomal deletion.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: The acquisition of a T674I resistance mutation at the time of relapse demonstrates that FIP1L1-PDGFRalpha is the target of imatinib.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: Our data indicate that the deletion of genetic material may result in gain-of-function fusion proteins.
title: A tyrosine kinase created by fusion of the PDGFRA and FIP1L1 genes as a therapeutic target of imatinib in idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome.

text: UNLABELLED: First-generation EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (EGFR TKI) provide significant clinical benefit in patients with advanced EGFR-mutant (EGFRm(+)) non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: Patients ultimately develop disease progression, often driven by acquisition of a second T790M EGFR TKI resistance mutation.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: AZD9291 is a novel oral, potent, and selective third-generation irreversible inhibitor of both EGFRm(+) sensitizing and T790M resistance mutants that spares wild-type EGFR.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: This mono-anilino-pyrimidine compound is structurally distinct from other third-generation EGFR TKIs and offers a pharmacologically differentiated profile from earlier generation EGFR TKIs.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: Preclinically, the drug potently inhibits signaling pathways and cellular growth in both EGFRm(+) and EGFRm(+)/T790M(+) mutant cell lines in vitro, with lower activity against wild-type EGFR lines, translating into profound and sustained tumor regression in EGFR-mutant tumor xenograft and transgenic models.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: The treatment of 2 patients with advanced EGFRm(+) T790M(+) NSCLC is described as proof of principle.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: We report the development of a novel structurally distinct third-generation EGFR TKI, AZD9291, that irreversibly and selectively targets both sensitizing and resistant T790M(+) mutant EGFR while harboring less activity toward wild-type EGFR.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: AZD9291 is showing promising responses in a phase I trial even at the first-dose level, with first published clinical proof-of-principle validation being presented.
title: AZD9291, an irreversible EGFR TKI, overcomes T790M-mediated resistance to EGFR inhibitors in lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: A germline mutation in the 3'-untranslated region of KRAS (rs61764370, KRAS-variant: TG/GG) has previously been associated with altered patient outcome and drug resistance/sensitivity in various cancers.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: We examined the prognostic and predictive significance of this variant in recurrent/metastatic (R/M) head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We conducted a retrospective study of 103 HNSCCs collected from three completed clinical trials.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: KRAS-variant genotyping was conducted for these samples and 8 HNSCC cell lines.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: p16 expression was determined in a subset of 26 oropharynx tumors by immunohistochemistry.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Microarray analysis was also utilized to elucidate differentially expressed genes between KRAS-variant and non-variant tumors.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Drug sensitivity in cell lines was evaluated to confirm clinical findings.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: KRAS-variant status was determined in 95/103 (92%) of the HNSCC tumor samples and the allelic frequency of TG/GG was 32% (30/95).
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Three of the HNSCC cell lines (3/8) studied had the KRAS-variant.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: No association between KRAS-variant status and p16 expression was observed in the oropharynx subset (Fisher's exact test, P = 1.0).
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: With respect to patient outcome, patients with the KRAS-variant had poor progression-free survival when treated with cisplatin (log-rank P = 0.002).
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Conversely, KRAS-variant patients appeared to experience some improvement in disease control when cetuximab was added to their platinum-based regimen (log-rank P = 0.04).
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The TG/GG rs61764370 KRAS-variant is a potential predictive biomarker for poor platinum response in R/M HNSCC patients.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBERS: NCT00503997, NCT00425750, NCT00003809.
title: A 3'-UTR KRAS-variant is associated with cisplatin resistance in patients with recurrent and/or metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Alterations in the RAS and RAF pathway relate to epigenetic and epigenomic aberrations, and are important in colorectal carcinogenesis.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: KRAS mutation in metastatic colorectal cancer predicts resistance to anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-targeted therapy (cetuximab or panitumumab).
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: It remains uncertain, however, whether KRAS mutation predicts prognosis or clinical outcome of colon cancer patients independent of anti-EGFR therapy.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: METHODS: We conducted a study of 508 cases identified among 1,264 patients with stage III colon cancer who enrolled in a randomized adjuvant chemotherapy trial (5-fluorouracil, leucovorin with or without irinotecan) in 1999-2001 (CALGB 89803).
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: KRAS mutations were detected in 178 tumors (35%) by pyrosequencing.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: Kaplan-Meier and Cox proportional hazard models assessed the prognostic significance of KRAS mutation and adjusted for potential confounders including age, sex, tumor location, tumor/node stage, performance status, adjuvant chemotherapy arm, and microsatellite instability status.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: RESULTS: Compared with patients with KRAS-wild-type tumors, patients with KRAS-mutated tumors did not experience any difference in disease-free, recurrence-free, or overall survival.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: The 5-year disease-free, recurrence-free, and overall survival rates (KRAS-mutated versus KRAS-wild-type patients) were 62% versus 63% (log-rank P = 0.89), 64% versus 66% (P = 0.84), and 75% versus 73% (P = 0.56), respectively.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: The effect of KRAS mutation on patient survival did not significantly differ according to clinical features, chemotherapy arm, or microsatellite instability status, and the effect of adjuvant chemotherapy assignment on outcome did not differ according to KRAS status.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In this large trial of chemotherapy in stage III colon cancer patients, KRAS mutational status was not associated with any significant influence on disease-free or overall survival.
title: KRAS mutation in stage III colon cancer and clinical outcome following intergroup trial CALGB 89803.

text: The proto-oncogene RAS, coding for a 21 kDa protein (p21), is mutated in 20% of lung cancer.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: However, the literature remains controversial on its prognostic significance for survival in lung cancer.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: We performed a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis to assess its possible prognostic value on survival.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: Published studies on lung cancer assessing prognostic value of RAS mutation or p21 overexpression on survival were identified by an electronic search.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: After a methodological assessment, we estimated individual hazard ratios (HR) estimating RAS protein alteration or RAS mutation effect on survival and combined them using meta-analytic methods.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: In total, 53 studies were found eligible, with 10 concerning the same cohorts of patients.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: Among the 43 remaining studies, the revelation method was immunohistochemistry (IHC) in nine and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in 34.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: Results in terms of survival were significantly pejorative, significantly favourable, not significant and not conclusive in 9, 1, 31, 2, respectively.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: In total, 29 studies were evaluable for meta-analysis but we aggregated only the 28 dealing with non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and not the only one dealing with small-cell-lung cancer (SCLC).
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: The quality scores were not statistically significantly different between studies with or without significant results in terms of survival, allowing us to perform a quantitative aggregation.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: The combined HR was 1.35 (95% CI: 1.16-1.56), showing a worse survival for NSCLC with KRAS2 mutations or p21 overexpression and, particularly, in adenocarcinomas (ADC) (HR 1.59; 95% CI 1.26-2.02) and in studies using PCR (HR 1.40; 95% CI 1.18-1.65) but not in studies using IHC (HR 1.08; 95% CI 0.86-1.34).
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: RAS appears to be a pejorative prognostic factor in terms of survival in NSCLC globally, in ADC and when it is studied by PCR.
title: The role of RAS oncogene in survival of patients with lung cancer: a systematic review of the literature with meta-analysis.

text: BACKGROUND: Wild type RAS (RAS-wt) status is predictive of the activities of the anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) monoclonal antibodies cetuximab (C) and panitumumab (P).
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: We examined the impact of C and P on progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS) and overall response rate (ORR) in advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) patients who have RAS-wt/BRAF-mutant (BRAF-mut) status.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: Randomised trials that compared C or P plus chemotherapy (or C or P monotherapy) with standard therapy or best supportive care (BSC) were included.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: We used published hazard ratios (HRs) if they were available, or we derived treatment estimates from other survival data.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: Pooled estimates of the treatment efficacy of anti-EGFR-based therapy with C or P for the RAS-wt/BRAF-mut subgroup were calculated with the random-effect inverse variance weighted method.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: All statistical tests were two-sided.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: Nine phase III trials and one phase II trial (six first-line and two second-line trials, plus two trials involving chemorefractory patients), that included 463 RAS-wt/BRAF-mut CRC patients, were analysed.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: Overall, the addition of C or P treatment in the BRAF-mut subgroup did not significantly improve PFS (HR, 0.88; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.67-1.14; p=0.33), OS (HR, 0.91; 95% CI, 0.62-1.34; p=0.63) and ORR (relative risk, 1.31; 95% CI 0.83-2.08, p=0.25) compared with control regimens.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: C- or P-based therapy did not increase the benefit of standard therapy or the BSC in RAS-wt/BRAF-mut CRC patients.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: These findings support BRAF mutation assessment before initiation of treatment with anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies.
title: Predictive role of BRAF mutations in patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving cetuximab and panitumumab: a meta-analysis.

text: Fibroblast growth factor homologous factors (FHFs) belong to the fibroblast growth factor (FGF) superfamily, which plays an important role in prostate cancer (PCa).
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: Mining of public database suggests that FGF13 (FHF2) mRNA expression is altered in over 30% of PCa cases.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: This study examined the FGF13 expression pattern in human PCa specimens and evaluated its potential as a biomarker for patient outcome after radical prostatectomy (RP).
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) showed that FGF13 was detectable in the majority of human PCa samples, and FGF13 IHC scores were higher in high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, in primary PCa and in metastatic PCa than in benign prostatic tissue.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: There was a significant association between high cytoplasmic FGF13 staining and a risk of biochemical recurrence (BCR) after RP.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: This was also evident in the intermediate to high-risk patient groups.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: In contrast, positive nuclear FGF13 staining along with low cytoplasmic FGF13 group showed a decreased BCR risk.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: Multivariate regression analysis indicated that high cytoplasmic FGF13 staining was associated with BCR and that this could serve as an independent prognostic marker in PCa.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: Several PCa cell lines showed increased FGF13 expression at the mRNA and protein levels compared to the immortalized prostate epithelial cell line PNT1a.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: Analysis of co-labeled cells suggested a possible interaction of FGF13 with alpha-tubulin and the voltage-gated sodium channel proteins (Na(V)s/VGSCs).
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: Our data indicate that, for PCa patients after RP, FGF13 serves as a potential novel prognostic marker that improves prediction of BCR-free survival, in particular if combined with other clinical parameters.
title: Increased expression of fibroblast growth factor 13 in prostate cancer is associated with shortened time to biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy.

text: INTRODUCTION: Activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway is a common phenomenon in cancer due to multiple mechanisms, including mutation of PI3KCA, loss or mutation of PTEN, or over-expression of receptor tyrosine kinases.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: We recently developed a novel AKT kinase inhibitor, AZD5363, and demonstrated that HGC27, a cell line harboring both PI3KCA mutation and PTEN loss, displayed the greatest sensitivity to this AKT inhibitor in vitro and in vivo.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: CASE PREPARATION: To further elucidate the correlation between AZD5363 response and genetic alterations in gastric cancer (GC) and identify GC patients with both PI3KCA mutations and PTEN loss, we investigated the effects of pharmacological inhibition of AKT on a panel of 20 GC cell lines and genetic aberrations in tumor samples from a cohort of Chinese GC patients.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: We demonstrated that GC cells with PI3KCA mutations were selectively sensitive to AZD5363.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: Disease linkage studies showed that PI3KCA activating mutations or PTEN loss were found in 2.7% (4/150) and 23% (14/61) of Chinese GC patients respectively.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: To further dissect the role of PI3KCA mutation and PTEN loss in response to AKT inhibition, we tested the antitumor activity of AZD5363 in two patient-derived GC xenograft (PDGCX) models harboring either PI3KCA mutation or PTEN loss.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: Our data indicated that AZD5363 monotherapy treatment led to a moderate response in the PI3KCA mutant PDGCX model.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: Whilst monotherapy AZD5363 or Taxotere were ineffective in the PTEN negative PDGCX model, significant anti-tumor activity was observed when AZD5363 was combined with Taxotere.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: CONCLUSION: Our results indicated that PI3KCA mutation is an important determinant of response to AKT inhibition in GC and combination with AZD5363 can overcome innate resistance to Taxotere in a PTEN loss PDGCX model.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: It is suggested that AKT inhibitor is an attractive option for treatment of a new segment of GC patients with aberrant PI3K/AKT signaling.
title: The AKT inhibitor AZD5363 is selectively active in PI3KCA mutant gastric cancer, and sensitizes a patient-derived gastric cancer xenograft model with PTEN loss to Taxotere.

text: BACKGROUND: Lung adenocarcinomas from patients who respond to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors gefitinib (Iressa) or erlotinib (Tarceva) usually harbor somatic gain-of-function mutations in exons encoding the kinase domain of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: Despite initial responses, patients eventually progress by unknown mechanisms of "acquired" resistance.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: METHODS AND FINDINGS: We show that in two of five patients with acquired resistance to gefitinib or erlotinib, progressing tumors contain, in addition to a primary drug-sensitive mutation in EGFR, a secondary mutation in exon 20, which leads to substitution of methionine for threonine at position 790 (T790M) in the kinase domain.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: Tumor cells from a sixth patient with a drug-sensitive EGFR mutation whose tumor progressed on adjuvant gefitinib after complete resection also contained the T790M mutation.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: This mutation was not detected in untreated tumor samples.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: Moreover, no tumors with acquired resistance had KRAS mutations, which have been associated with primary resistance to these drugs.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: Biochemical analyses of transfected cells and growth inhibition studies with lung cancer cell lines demonstrate that the T790M mutation confers resistance to EGFR mutants usually sensitive to either gefitinib or erlotinib.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: Interestingly, a mutation analogous to T790M has been observed in other kinases with acquired resistance to another kinase inhibitor, imatinib (Gleevec).
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: CONCLUSION: In patients with tumors bearing gefitinib- or erlotinib-sensitive EGFR mutations, resistant subclones containing an additional EGFR mutation emerge in the presence of drug.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: This observation should help guide the search for more effective therapy against a specific subset of lung cancers.
title: Acquired resistance of lung adenocarcinomas to gefitinib or erlotinib is associated with a second mutation in the EGFR kinase domain.

text: Glutathione S-transferase P1 (GSTP1) participates in detoxification of potentially genotoxic compounds that may alter the efficacy and toxicity of platinum-based chemotherapy.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: We analyzed the influence of I105V polymorphism of GSTP1 on clinico-pathological features and outcomes in 166 Chinese patients with metastatic colorectal carcinoma who had been treated with first-line FOLFOX-4.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: Combined analysis of GSTP1 I105V, ERCC1-118, and XPD-751 polymorphisms was also conducted.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: The results showed that, in comparison with Caucasian populations, a remarkably lower prevalence of Val105 allele variants was noted (24.7%).
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: Patients with Val105 allele variants had a higher response to FOLFOX-4 (56.1%vs 37.6%, P = 0.04), and a longer progression-free (P < 0.01) as well as overall (P < 0.01) survival.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: By adjusted analysis, this polymorphism was identified as an independent prognostic factor (P = 0.01).
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: In combined analysis, patients without any risk genotype, including GSTP1-105 Ile/Ile, ERCC1-118 C/T or T/T, and XPD-751 Lys/Gln, had significantly longer progression-free and overall survivals (P < 0.01).
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: In addition, patients with Val105 allele variants had a higher incidence of grade 3/4 cumulative neuropathy after different cycles of treatment.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: These data suggest that Asian populations have a lower prevalence of I105V polymorphism in GSTP1.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: I105V polymorphism in GSTP1, by reducing its enzymatic activity and consequential detoxification to oxaliplatin, could be a key determinant for a better outcome, but more neurotoxicity, to FOLFOX-4 treatment.
title: Influence of GSTP1 I105V polymorphism on cumulative neuropathy and outcome of FOLFOX-4 treatment in Asian patients with colorectal carcinoma.

text: INTRODUCTION: The esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is the predominant pathological type and accounts for more than 80 % of esophageal cancer in China.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The successful use of anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) treatment in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma provides the rationale for introducing anti-EGFR targeting treatment in ESCC.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: One of our prospective phase II clinical trials analyzed the efficacy of nimotuzumab, an anti-EGFR agent, combined with chemotherapy (paclitaxel and cisplatin) to treat unresectable ESCC.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: MATERIALS AND METHODS: We analyzed the correlation of the clinical response with EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining (IHC).
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Totally 55 tumor samples were analyzed.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: 18/55 (32.7 %) cases were with high EGFR expression while the other 37/55 (67.3 %) cases were with low to moderate EGFR expression.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The expression of EGFR was not related to gender, age, tumor location, tumor differentiation and clinical stage of disease.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The objective response rate (ORR) in high EGFR expression group was 55.6 % (10/18) while that in low to moderate EGFR expression group was 54.1 % (20/37) (P = 0.57).
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Both the progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) in high EGFR expression group were much shorter than those in low to moderate EGFR expression group (PFS: 5.8 +/- 0.5 vs. 11.0 +/- 2.8 months, P = 0.007; OS: 9.7 +/- 0.5 vs. 21.5 +/- 1.5 months, P = 0.03).
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The results showed that over-expression of EGFR was related to poor survival of ESCC.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: The over-expression of EGFR by IHC might not be an ideal predictive biomarker of nimotuzumab treatment.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Other EGFR pathway-associated molecules should be analyzed in further studies.
title: The relation of EGFR expression by immunohistochemical staining and clinical response of combination treatment of nimotuzumab and chemotherapy in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT) is a relatively rare soft tissue tumor.
title: Recurrent involvement of 2p23 in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors.

text: The reactive versus neoplastic pathogenesis of this tumor is unresolved.
title: Recurrent involvement of 2p23 in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors.

text: We found clonal chromosome aberrations involving 2p23 upon metaphase analysis of two IMTs.
title: Recurrent involvement of 2p23 in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors.

text: Fluorescence in situ hybridization with a probe flanking the ALK gene at 2p23 demonstrated rearrangement of the probe in both of these cases and in a third case, and immunohistochemistry revealed ALK expression in all three cases.
title: Recurrent involvement of 2p23 in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors.

text: 2p22-24 involvement has been reported previously in four additional cases of IMT.
title: Recurrent involvement of 2p23 in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors.

text: We suggest that chromosomal rearrangements involving 2p23 near or within ALK are recurrent alterations in IMT and that ALK may have a novel role outside its previously recognized realm of lymphoid neoplasms.
title: Recurrent involvement of 2p23 in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors.

text: Telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) is up-regulated in a variety of human neoplasms.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: Mutations in the core promoter region of the TERT gene, which increases promoter activity, have been reported in melanomas and a variety of human neoplasms, including gliomas.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: In the present study, we screened for TERT promoter mutations by direct DNA sequencing in a population-based collection of 358 glioblastomas.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: TERT promoter mutations (C228T, C250T) were detected in 55 % glioblastomas analysed.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: Of these, 73 % had a C228T mutation, and 27 % had a C250T mutation; only one glioblastoma had both C228T and C250T mutations.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: TERT promoter mutations were significantly more frequent in primary (IDH1 wild-type) glioblastomas (187/322; 58 %) than in secondary (IDH1 mutated) glioblastomas (10/36, 28 %; P = 0.0056).
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: They showed significant inverse correlations with IDH1 mutations (P = 0.0056) and TP53 mutations (P = 0.043), and a significant positive correlation with EGFR amplification (P = 0.048).
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: Glioblastoma patients with TERT mutations showed a shorter survival than those without TERT mutations in univariate analysis (median, 9.3 vs. 10.5 months; P = 0.015) and multivariate analysis after adjusting for age and gender (HR 1.38, 95 % CI 1.01-1.88, P = 0.041).
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: However, TERT mutations had no significant impact on patients' survival in multivariate analysis after further adjusting for other genetic alterations, or when primary and secondary glioblastomas were separately analysed.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: These results suggest that the prognostic value of TERT mutations for poor survival is largely due to their inverse correlation with IDH1 mutations, which are a significant prognostic marker of better survival in patients with secondary glioblastomas.
title: TERT promoter mutations in primary and secondary glioblastomas.

text: BACKGROUND: Expression of class IotaIotaIota beta-tubulin (betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin) correlates with tumor progression and resistance to taxane-based therapies for several human malignancies including breast cancer.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: However its predictive value in a neoadjuvant setting in breast cancer remains unexplored.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: The objective of this explorative study was to determine whether betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin expression in breast cancer correlated with pathologic characteristics and whether its expression was predictive of response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We determined betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin expression in 85 breast cancers, including 41 localized breast cancers treated with primary surgery and 44 treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy before surgery.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin expression was evaluated by immunohistochemical methods and was correlated with pathologic characteristics and response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy using residual cancer burden (RCB) score.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: High betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin expression was significantly associated with poorly differentiated high-grade breast cancers (P = .003) but not with tumor size, estrogen receptor (ER) status, or human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)/neu overexpression.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: In ER(-) tumors treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, high betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin expression was associated with a significantly greater likelihood of achieving a good pathologic response to chemotherapy as reflected by lower RCB scores (P = .021).
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: This study reveals differential betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin expression in breast cancers of different histologic grades, hormone receptors, and HER2/neu status.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: It also suggests a potential role for betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin as a predictive biomarker for response in neoadjuvant chemotherapy for ER(-) breast cancer, which has not been previously reported.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: These data provide a strong rationale for considering betaIotaIotaIota-tubulin status and further validation of this marker in a large study.
title: High expression of class III beta-tubulin predicts good response to neoadjuvant taxane and doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy in estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Neoadjuvant concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) followed by surgery is the mainstay of treatment for locally advanced rectal cancer.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: Several heparin-binding associated proteins have been reported to play a critical role in cancer progression.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: However, the clinical relevancies of such proteins and their associations with CCRT response in rectal cancer have not yet to be fully elucidated.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: METHODS: The analysis of a public transcriptome of rectal cancer indicated that thrombospondin 2 (THBS2) is a predictive factor for CCRT response.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: Immunohistochemical analyses were conducted to evaluate the expression of THBS2 in pretreatment biopsy specimens from rectal cancer patients without distant metastasis.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: Furthermore, the relationships between THBS2 expression and various clinicopathological factors or survival were analyzed.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Low expression of THBS2 was significantly associated with advanced pretreatment tumor (P<0.001) and nodal status (P=0.004), post-treatment tumor (P<0.001) and nodal status (P<0.001), increased vascular invasion (P=0.003), increased perineural invasion (P=0.023) and inferior tumor regression grade (P=0.015).
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: In univariate analysis, low THBS2 expression predicted worse outcomes for disease-free survival, local recurrence-free survival and metastasis-free survival (all P<0.001).
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: In multivariate analysis, low expression of THBS2 still served as a negative prognostic factor for disease-free survival (Hazard ratio=3.057, P=0.002) and metastasis-free survival (Hazard ratio=3.362, P=0.012).
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Low THBS2 expression was correlated with advanced disease status and low tumor regression after preoperative CCRT and that it acted as an independent negative prognostic factor in rectal cancer.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: THBS2 may represent a predictive biomarker for CCRT response in rectal cancer.
title: Low thrombospondin 2 expression is predictive of low tumor regression after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in rectal cancer.

text: Genetic changes underlying clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) include alterations in genes controlling cellular oxygen sensing (for example, VHL) and the maintenance of chromatin states (for example, PBRM1).
title: Comprehensive molecular characterization of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: We surveyed more than 400 tumours using different genomic platforms and identified 19 significantly mutated genes.
title: Comprehensive molecular characterization of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: The PI(3)K/AKT pathway was recurrently mutated, suggesting this pathway as a potential therapeutic target.
title: Comprehensive molecular characterization of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Widespread DNA hypomethylation was associated with mutation of the H3K36 methyltransferase SETD2, and integrative analysis suggested that mutations involving the SWI/SNF chromatin remodelling complex (PBRM1, ARID1A, SMARCA4) could have far-reaching effects on other pathways.
title: Comprehensive molecular characterization of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Aggressive cancers demonstrated evidence of a metabolic shift, involving downregulation of genes involved in the TCA cycle, decreased AMPK and PTEN protein levels, upregulation of the pentose phosphate pathway and the glutamine transporter genes, increased acetyl-CoA carboxylase protein, and altered promoter methylation of miR-21 (also known as MIR21) and GRB10.
title: Comprehensive molecular characterization of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Remodelling cellular metabolism thus constitutes a recurrent pattern in ccRCC that correlates with tumour stage and severity and offers new views on the opportunities for disease treatment.
title: Comprehensive molecular characterization of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

text: Effective targeted therapy strategies are still lacking for the 15-20% of melanoma patients whose melanomas are driven by oncogenic NRAS.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: Here, we report on the NRAS-specific behavior of amuvatinib, a kinase inhibitor with activity against c-KIT, Axl, PDGFRalpha, and Rad51.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: An analysis of BRAF-mutant and NRAS-mutant melanoma cell lines showed the NRAS-mutant cohort to be enriched for targets of amuvatinib, including Axl, c-KIT, and the Axl ligand Gas6.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: Increasing concentrations of amuvatinib selectively inhibited the growth of NRAS-mutant, but not BRAF-mutant melanoma cell lines, an effect associated with induction of S-phase and G2/M-phase cell cycle arrest and induction of apoptosis.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: Mechanistically, amuvatinib was noted to either inhibit Axl, AKT, and MAPK signaling or Axl and AKT signaling and to induce a DNA damage response.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: In three-dimensional cell culture experiments, amuvatinib was cytotoxic against NRAS-mutant melanoma cell lines.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: Thus, we show for the first time that amuvatinib has proapoptotic activity against melanoma cell lines, with selectivity observed for those harboring oncogenic NRAS.
title: Amuvatinib has cytotoxic effects against NRAS-mutant melanoma but not BRAF-mutant melanoma.

text: BACKGROUND: Non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with a mutation in the gene encoding epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is sensitive to approved EGFR inhibitors, but resistance develops, mediated by the T790M EGFR mutation in most cases.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Rociletinib (CO-1686) is an EGFR inhibitor active in preclinical models of EGFR-mutated NSCLC with or without T790M.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: METHODS: In this phase 1-2 study, we administered rociletinib to patients with EGFR-mutated NSCLC who had disease progression during previous treatment with an existing EGFR inhibitor.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In the expansion (phase 2) part of the study, patients with T790M-positive disease received rociletinib at a dose of 500 mg twice daily, 625 mg twice daily, or 750 mg twice daily.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Key objectives were assessment of safety, side-effect profile, pharmacokinetics, and preliminary antitumor activity of rociletinib.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Tumor biopsies to identify T790M were performed during screening.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: Treatment was administered in continuous 21-day cycles.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: A total of 130 patients were enrolled.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The first 57 patients to be enrolled received the free-base form of rociletinib (150 mg once daily to 900 mg twice daily).
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The remaining patients received the hydrogen bromide salt (HBr) form (500 mg twice daily to 1000 mg twice daily).
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: A maximum tolerated dose (the highest dose associated with a rate of dose-limiting toxic effects of less than 33%) was not identified.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: The only common dose-limiting adverse event was hyperglycemia.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: In an efficacy analysis that included patients who received free-base rociletinib at a dose of 900 mg twice daily or the HBr form at any dose, the objective response rate among the 46 patients with T790M-positive disease who could be evaluated was 59% (95% confidence interval [CI], 45 to 73), and the rate among the 17 patients with T790M-negative disease who could be evaluated was 29% (95% CI, 8 to 51).
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Rociletinib was active in patients with EGFR-mutated NSCLC associated with the T790M resistance mutation.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: (Funded by Clovis Oncology; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01526928.
title: Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.
Rociletinib in EGFR-mutated non-small-cell lung cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: A predictive marker of bevacizumab activity is an unmet medical need.
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: We evaluated the predictive value of selected circulating prebiomarkers involved in neoangiogenesis and invasion on patient outcome in recurrent high-grade glioma treated with bevacizumab.
