title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: METHODS: Analyzed in plasma were a set of 11 prebiomakers of interest (vascular endothelial growth factor receptor [VEGF]; VEGF receptor 2; basic fibroblast growth factor; stromal cell derived factor 1; placenta growth factor; urokinase-type plasminogen activator; plasminogen activator inhibitor 1; matrix metalloproteinases 2, 7, and 9; and adrenomedulline), using ELISA, at baseline and 2 weeks after bevacizumab initiation in a prospective cohort of 26 patients (Cohort 1).
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: Correlations were validated in a separate retrospective cohort (Cohort 2; n = 50) and tested in cohort patients treated with cytotoxic agents without bevacizumab (Cohort 3; n = 34).
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: Dosages were correlated to objective response, progression-free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS).
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: RESULTS: In Cohort 1, high MMP2 baseline level was associated with a probability of objective response of 83.3% versus 15.4% for low MMP2 level (P = .001).
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: In multivariate analysis, baseline level of MMP2 correlated with PFS (hazard ratio, 3.92; 95% confidence interval [CI]:1.46-10.52; P = .007) and OS (hazard ratio, 4.62; 95% CI: 1.58-13.53; P = .005), as decrease of VEGF (P = .038 for PFS and P = .013 for OS) and MMP9 (P = .016 for PFS and P = .025 for OS).
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: In Cohort 2, MMP2, but not MMP9, confirmed its predictive significance.
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: In Cohort 3, no association was found between MMP2, MMP9, and outcome.
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: CONCLUSION: In patients with recurrent high-grade glioma treated with bevacizumab, but not with cytotoxic agent, high MMP2 plasma levels are associated with prolonged tumor control and survival.
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: MMP2 should be tested in randomized clinical trials that evaluate bevacizumab efficacy, and its biological role reassessed.
title: Association of matrix metalloproteinase 2 plasma level with response and survival in patients treated with bevacizumab for recurrent high-grade glioma.

text: PURPOSE: The precise prognostic impact of TP53 mutation and its incorporation into treatment algorithms in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is unclear.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: We set out to define the impact of TP53 mutations in CLL.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We assessed TP53 mutations by denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography (exons 2 to 11) in a randomized prospective trial (n = 375) with a follow-up of 52.8 months (German CLL Study Group CLL4 trial; fludarabine [F] v F + cyclophosphamide [FC]).
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: RESULTS: We found TP53 mutations in 8.5% of patients (28 of 328 patients).
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: None of the patients with TP53 mutation showed a complete response.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In patients with TP53 mutation, compared with patients without TP53 mutation, median progression-free survival (PFS; 23.3 v 62.2 months, respectively) and overall survival (OS; 29.2 v 84.6 months, respectively) were significantly decreased (both P < .001).
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: TP53 mutations in the absence of 17p deletions were found in 4.5% of patients.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: PFS and OS for patients with 17p deletion and patients with TP53 mutation in the absence of 17p deletion were similar.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Multivariate analysis identified TP53 mutation as the strongest prognostic marker regarding PFS (hazard ratio [HR] = 3.8; P < .001) and OS (HR = 7.2; P < .001).
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Other independent predictors of OS were IGHV mutation status (HR = 1.9), 11q deletion (HR = 1.9), 17p deletion (HR = 2.3), and FC treatment arm (HR = 0.6).
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: CONCLUSION: CLL with TP53 mutation carries a poor prognosis regardless of the presence of 17p deletion when treated with F-based chemotherapy.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Thus, TP53 mutation analysis should be incorporated into the evaluation of patients with CLL before treatment initiation.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Patients with TP53 mutation should be considered for alternative treatment approaches.
title: TP53 mutation and survival in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: UNLABELLED: Here, we report that novel epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene fusions comprising the N-terminal of EGFR linked to various fusion partners, most commonly RAD51, are recurrent in lung cancer.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: We describe five patients with metastatic lung cancer whose tumors harbored EGFR fusions, four of whom were treated with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) with documented antitumor responses.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: In vitro, EGFR-RAD51 fusions are oncogenic and can be therapeutically targeted with available EGFR TKIs and therapeutic antibodies.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: These results support the dependence of EGFR-rearranged tumors on EGFR-mediated signaling and suggest several therapeutic strategies for patients whose tumors harbor this novel alteration.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: We report for the first time the identification and therapeutic targeting of EGFR C-terminal fusions in patients with lung cancer and document responses to the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib in 4 patients whose tumors harbored EGFR fusions.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: Findings from these studies will be immediately translatable to the clinic, as there are already several approved EGFR inhibitors.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: Cancer Discov; 6(6); 601-11.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: (c)2016 AACR.See related commentary by Paik, p. 574This article is highlighted in the In This Issue feature, p. 561.
title: EGFR Fusions as Novel Therapeutic Targets in Lung Cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Recent studies have provided a detailed census of genes that are mutated in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Our next challenge is to understand how this genetic diversity defines the pathophysiology of AML and informs clinical practice.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: METHODS: We enrolled a total of 1540 patients in three prospective trials of intensive therapy.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Combining driver mutations in 111 cancer genes with cytogenetic and clinical data, we defined AML genomic subgroups and their relevance to clinical outcomes.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: RESULTS: We identified 5234 driver mutations across 76 genes or genomic regions, with 2 or more drivers identified in 86% of the patients.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Patterns of co-mutation compartmentalized the cohort into 11 classes, each with distinct diagnostic features and clinical outcomes.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: In addition to currently defined AML subgroups, three heterogeneous genomic categories emerged: AML with mutations in genes encoding chromatin, RNA-splicing regulators, or both (in 18% of patients); AML with TP53 mutations, chromosomal aneuploidies, or both (in 13%); and, provisionally, AML with IDH2(R172) mutations (in 1%).
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Patients with chromatin-spliceosome and TP53-aneuploidy AML had poor outcomes, with the various class-defining mutations contributing independently and additively to the outcome.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: In addition to class-defining lesions, other co-occurring driver mutations also had a substantial effect on overall survival.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: The prognostic effects of individual mutations were often significantly altered by the presence or absence of other driver mutations.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: Such gene-gene interactions were especially pronounced for NPM1-mutated AML, in which patterns of co-mutation identified groups with a favorable or adverse prognosis.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: These predictions require validation in prospective clinical trials.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The driver landscape in AML reveals distinct molecular subgroups that reflect discrete paths in the evolution of AML, informing disease classification and prognostic stratification.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: (Funded by the Wellcome Trust and others; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00146120.
title: Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.
Genomic Classification and Prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: Protein tyrosine kinases are important regulators of cellular homeostasis with tightly controlled catalytic activity.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: Mutations in kinase-encoding genes can relieve the autoinhibitory constraints on kinase activity, can promote malignant transformation, and appear to be a major determinant of response to kinase inhibitor therapy.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: Missense mutations in the EGFR kinase domain, for example, have recently been identified in patients who showed clinical responses to EGFR kinase inhibitor therapy.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: METHODS AND FINDINGS: Encouraged by the promising clinical activity of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) kinase inhibitors in treating glioblastoma in humans, we have sequenced the complete EGFR coding sequence in glioma tumor samples and cell lines.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: We identified novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain of EGFR in 13.6% (18/132) of glioblastomas and 12.5% (1/8) of glioblastoma cell lines.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: These EGFR mutations were associated with increased EGFR gene dosage and conferred anchorage-independent growth and tumorigenicity to NIH-3T3 cells.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: Cells transformed by expression of these EGFR mutants were sensitive to small-molecule EGFR kinase inhibitors.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our results suggest extracellular missense mutations as a novel mechanism for oncogenic EGFR activation and may help identify patients who can benefit from EGFR kinase inhibitors for treatment of glioblastoma.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor activation in glioblastoma through novel missense mutations in the extracellular domain.

text: OBJECTIVES: Recently, aberrations in the gene encoding for ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated (ATM) protein kinase have been reported for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas (PDAC).
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: These findings argue that ATM deficiency may play a role during carcinogenesis.
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: Therefore, in this study, we investigated the clinical relevance of ATM expression and ATM activation in PDAC.
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: METHODS: Both ATM expression and nuclear phosphoSer1981-ATM levels were assessed by immunohistochemistry in a cohort of 133 PDAC and correlated with clinicopathological parameters.
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: RESULTS: We found stratification in prognostic subgroups.
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: Complete loss of Ser1981-ATM was indicative of the worst prognosis (median survival, 10.8 vs 14.3 months [low expression] vs 31.1 months [high expression], P < 0.001).
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: Similarly, analysis of ATM expression demonstrated absent expression levels of ATM to be associated with dismal prognosis (median survival, 9.6 months), whereas expression of ATM in general was associated with increased survival (17.7 months, P = 0.001).
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Our analysis shows that both ATM expression and activated ATM are prognostic markers in PDAC with respect to standard clinicopathological parameters.
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: These results suggest that ATM should be further explored as prognostic as well as predictive factor with respect to conventional chemotherapies and for putative synthetic lethal approaches.
title: Ataxia-telangiectasia-mutated protein kinase levels stratify patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma into prognostic subgroups with loss being a strong indicator of poor survival.

text: Dysregulation of the Notch1 receptor has been shown to facilitate the development and progression of colorectal cancer (CRC) and has been identified as an independent predictor of disease progression and worse survival.
title: A NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is a prognostic indicator of worse survival and a predictive biomarker to a Notch1 targeting antibody in colorectal cancer.

text: Although mutations in the NOTCH1 receptor have not been described in CRC, we have previously discovered a NOTCH1 gene copy number gain in a portion of CRC tumor samples.
title: A NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is a prognostic indicator of worse survival and a predictive biomarker to a Notch1 targeting antibody in colorectal cancer.

text: Here, we demonstrated that a NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is significantly associated with worse survival and a high percentage of gene duplication in a cohort of patients with advanced CRC.
title: A NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is a prognostic indicator of worse survival and a predictive biomarker to a Notch1 targeting antibody in colorectal cancer.

text: In our CRC patient-derived tumor xenograft (PDTX) model, tumors harboring a NOTCH1 gain exhibited significant elevation of the Notch1 receptor, JAG1 ligand and cleaved Notch1 activity.
title: A NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is a prognostic indicator of worse survival and a predictive biomarker to a Notch1 targeting antibody in colorectal cancer.

text: In addition, a significant association was identified between a gain in NOTCH1 gene copy number and sensitivity to a Notch1-targeting antibody.
title: A NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is a prognostic indicator of worse survival and a predictive biomarker to a Notch1 targeting antibody in colorectal cancer.

text: These findings suggest that patients with metastatic CRC that harbor a gain in NOTCH1 gene copy number have worse survival and that targeting this patient population with a Notch1 antibody may yield improved outcomes.
title: A NOTCH1 gene copy number gain is a prognostic indicator of worse survival and a predictive biomarker to a Notch1 targeting antibody in colorectal cancer.

text: PURPOSE: To determine the frequency of DNMT3A mutations, their associations with clinical and molecular characteristics and outcome, and the associated gene- and microRNA-expression signatures in primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML).
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Four hundred fifteen previously untreated adults were analyzed for DNMT3A mutations and established prognostic gene mutations and expression markers.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Gene- and microRNA-expression profiles were derived using microarrays.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: RESULTS: Younger (< 60 years; n = 181) and older (>/= 60 years; n = 234) patients had similar frequencies of DNMT3A mutations (35.3% v 33.3%).
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Missense mutations affecting arginine codon 882 (R882-DNMT3A) were more common (n = 92; 62%) than those affecting other codons (non-R882-DNMT3A).
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: DNMT3A-mutated patients did not differ regarding complete remission rate, but had shorter disease-free survival (DFS; P = .03) and, by trend, overall survival (OS; P = .07) than DNMT3A-wild-type patients.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In multivariable analyses, DNMT3A mutations remained associated with shorter DFS (P = .01), but not with shorter OS.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: When analyzed separately, the two DNMT3A mutation types had different significance by age group.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Younger patients with non-R882-DNMT3A mutations had shorter DFS (P = .002) and OS (P = .02), whereas older patients with R882-DNMT3A mutations had shorter DFS (P = .005) and OS (P = .002) after adjustment for other clinical and molecular prognosticators.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Gene- and microRNA-expression signatures did not accurately predict DNMT3A mutational status.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: CONCLUSION: DNMT3A mutations are frequent in CN-AML, and their clinical significance seems to be age dependent.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: DNMT3A-R882 mutations are associated with adverse prognosis in older patients, and non-R882-DNMT3A mutations are associated with adverse prognosis in younger patients.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Low accuracy of gene- and microRNA-expression signatures in predicting DNMT3A mutation status suggested that the role of these mutations in AML remains to be elucidated.
title: Age-related prognostic impact of different types of DNMT3A mutations in adults with primary cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia.

text: PURPOSE: The Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational (TEAM) trial included a prospectively planned pathology substudy testing the predictive value of progesterone receptor (PgR) expression for outcome of estrogen receptor-positive (ER-positive) early breast cancer treated with exemestane versus tamoxifen.
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Pathology blocks from 4,781 TEAM patients randomly assigned to exemestane versus tamoxifen followed by exemestane for 5 years of total therapy were collected centrally, and tissue microarrays were constructed from samples from 4,598 patients.
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: Quantitative analysis of hormone receptors (ER and PgR) was performed by using image analysis and immunohistochemistry, and the results were linked to outcome data from the main TEAM trial and analyzed relative to disease-free survival and treatment.
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: RESULTS: Of 4,325 eligible ER-positive patients, 23% were PgR-poor (Allred < 4) and 77% were PgR- rich (Allred >/= 5).
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: No treatment-by-marker effect for PgR was observed for exemestane versus tamoxifen (PgR-rich hazard ratio [HR], 0.83; 95% CI, 0.65 to 1.05; PgR-poor HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.61 to 1.19; P = .88 for interaction).
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: Both PgR and ER expression were associated with patient prognosis in univariate (PgR HR, 0.53; 95% CI, 0.43 to 0.65; P < .001; ER HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.51 to 0.86; P = .002), and multivariate analyses (P < .001 and P = .001, respectively).
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: A trend toward a treatment-by-marker effect for ER-rich patients was observed.
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: CONCLUSION: Preferential exemestane versus tamoxifen treatment benefit was not predicted by PgR expression; conversely, patients with ER-rich tumors may derive additional benefit from exemestane.
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: Quantitative analysis of ER and PgR expression provides highly significant information on risk of early relapse (within 1 to 3 years) during treatment.
title: Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor as predictive biomarkers of response to endocrine therapy: a prospectively powered pathology study in the Tamoxifen and Exemestane Adjuvant Multinational trial.

text: PURPOSE: In Asian countries, paclitaxel once per week is used as second-line treatment in advanced gastric cancer, including human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) -positive tumors.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: The role of anti-HER2 agents, including lapatinib, in this setting and population is unclear.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: TyTAN was a two-part, parallel-group, phase III study in Asian patients.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: An open-label, dose-optimization phase (n = 12) was followed by a randomized phase (n = 261), in which patients who were HER2 positive by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) received lapatinib 1,500 mg once per day plus once-per-week paclitaxel 80 mg/m(2) or paclitaxel alone.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: The primary end point was overall survival (OS).
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: Secondary end points included progression-free survival (PFS), time to progression (TTP), overall response rate (ORR), time to response, response duration, and safety.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: Analyses were based on immunohistochemistry (IHC) and gastrectomy status, prior trastuzumab therapy, and regional subpopulations.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: RESULTS: Median OS was 11.0 months with lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus 8.9 months with paclitaxel alone (P = .1044), with no significant difference in median PFS (5.4 v 4.4 months) or TTP (5.5 v 4.4 months).
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: ORR was higher with lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone (odds ratio, 3.85; P < .001).
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: Better efficacy with lapatinib plus paclitaxel was demonstrated in IHC3+ compared with IHC0/1+ and 2+ patients and in Chinese compared with Japanese patients.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: A similar proportion of patients experienced adverse events with each treatment (lapatinib plus paclitaxel, 100% v paclitaxel alone, 98%).
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: CONCLUSION: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel demonstrated activity in the second-line treatment of patients with HER2 FISH-positive IHC3+ advanced gastric cancer but did not significantly improve OS in the intent-to-treat population.
title: Lapatinib plus paclitaxel versus paclitaxel alone in the second-line treatment of HER2-amplified advanced gastric cancer in Asian populations: TyTAN--a randomized, phase III study.

text: Increasing evidence indicates that aberrant expression of PIM1, p-STAT3 and c-MYC is involved in the pathogenesis of various solid tumors, but its prognostic value is still unclear in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: Here, we sought to evaluate the expression and prognostic role of these markers in patients with lung adenocarcinoma (AD) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: Real time RT-PCR and Western blotting was used to analyze the mRNA and protein expression of PIM1 in NSCLC cell lines, respectively.
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: The expression of PIM1, p-STAT3, and c-MYC was immunohistochemically tested in archival tumor samples from 194 lung AD and SCC patients.
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: High nuclear PIM1 expression was detected in 43.3% of ADs and SCCs, and was significantly correlated with lymph node (LN) metastasis (P = 0.028) and histology (P = 0.003).
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: High nuclear PIM1 expression (P = 0.034), locally advanced stage (P < 0.001), AD (P = 0.007) and poor pathologic differentiation (P = 0.002) were correlated with worse disease-free survival (DFS).
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: High nuclear PIM1 expression (P = 0.009), advanced clinical stage (P < 0.001) and poor pathologic differentiation (P = 0.004) were independent unfavorable prognostic factors for overall survival (OS).
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: High p-STAT3 expression was not associated with OS but significantly correlated with LN metastasis, while c-MYC was not significantly correlated with any clinicopathological parameter or survival.
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: Therefore, in AD and SCC patients, nuclear PIM1 expression level is an independent factor for DFS and OS and it might serve as a predictive biomarker for outcome.
title: Association of Nuclear PIM1 Expression with Lymph Node Metastasis and Poor Prognosis in Patients with Lung Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: CDK4 is amplified in > 90% of well-differentiated (WDLS) and dedifferentiated liposarcomas (DDLS).
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: The selective cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4)/CDK6 inhibitor PD0332991 inhibits growth and induces senescence in cell lines and xenografts.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: In a phase I trial of PD0332991, several patients with WDLS or DDLS experienced prolonged stable disease.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: We performed an open-label phase II study to determine the safety and efficacy of PD0332991 in patients with advanced WDLS/DDLS.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients age >/= 18 years experiencing disease progression while receiving systemic therapy before enrollment received PD0332991 200 mg orally once per day for 14 consecutive days in 21-day cycles.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: All were required to have CDK4 amplification by fluorescence in situ hybridization and retinoblastoma protein (RB) expression by immunohistochemistry (>/= 1+).
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: The primary end point was progression-free survival (PFS) at 12 weeks, with 12-week PFS of >/= 40% considered promising and </= 20% not promising.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: If >/= nine of 28 patients were progression free at 12 weeks, PD0332991 would be considered active.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: RESULTS: We screened 48 patients (44 of 48 had CDK4 amplification; 41 of 44 were RB positive).
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: Of those, 30 were enrolled, and 29 were evaluable for the primary end point.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: Grade 3 to 4 events included anemia (17%), thrombocytopenia (30%), neutropenia (50%), and febrile neutropenia (3%).
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: At 12 weeks, PFS was 66% (90% CI, 51% to 100%), significantly exceeding the primary end point.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: The median PFS was 18 weeks.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: There was one partial response.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: CONCLUSION: Treatment with the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 was associated with a favorable progression-free rate in patients with CDK4-amplified and RB-expressing WDLS/DDLS who had progressive disease despite systemic therapy.
title: Phase II trial of the CDK4 inhibitor PD0332991 in patients with advanced CDK4-amplified well-differentiated or dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

text: PURPOSE: BRAF(V600E) mutations are associated with poor clinical prognosis in colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: Although selective BRAF inhibitors are effective for treatment of melanoma, comparable efforts in CRC have been disappointing.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: Here, we investigated potential mechanisms underlying this resistance to BRAF inhibitors in BRAF(V600E) CRC.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We examined phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/mTOR signaling in BRAF(V600E) CRC cell lines after BRAF inhibition and cell viability and apoptosis after combined BRAF and PI3K/mTOR inhibition.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: We assessed the efficacy of in vivo combination treatment using a novel genetically engineered mouse model (GEMM) for BRAF(V600E) CRC.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: RESULTS: Western blot analysis revealed sustained PI3K/mTOR signaling upon BRAF inhibition.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: Our BRAF(V600E) GEMM presented with sessile serrated adenomas/polyps, as seen in humans.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: Combination treatment in vivo resulted in induction of apoptosis and tumor regression.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: We have established a novel GEMM to interrogate BRAF(V600E) CRC biology and identify more efficacious treatment strategies.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: Combination BRAF and PI3K/mTOR inhibitor treatment should be explored in clinical trials.
title: Concomitant BRAF and PI3K/mTOR blockade is required for effective treatment of BRAF(V600E) colorectal cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) is a hereditary syndrome characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: MEN 2 is caused predominantly by germ-line mutations of the RET proto-oncogene.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: This study aimed to clarify the genotype-phenotype correlation in MEN 2 patients in Japan in order to modify the clinical management according to the genotype.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: METHODS: Constitutive DNA of 64 MEN 2 patients (48 kindreds) were searched for mutations at exons 10, 11, 13, 14 and 16 of the RET proto-oncogene using polymerase chain reaction-single strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP), direct sequencing and restriction enzyme digestion.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: The clinical characteristics of the patients were obtained from a previous nationwide questionnaire survey.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: RESULTS: Overall, 62 (96.9%) out of 64 patients had a germ-line point mutation at the hot spots.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: MTC and pheochromocytoma occurred equally in every genotype except C630S.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: Specific genotype had a correlation between tumor size and age at the operation for MTC or extent of MTC, i.e.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: C618S developed late onset type of MTC as compared with that of C634R, C634Y and M918T.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: Small MTC in C634R may be less aggressive than those in C634Y and M918T.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: CONCLUSIONS: DNA testing has good clinical implications for the management of patients with MEN 2 and the timing and operative procedures of thyroidectomy can be modified according to the genotype.
title: Genotype-phenotype correlation of patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 in Japan.

text: PURPOSE: Overexpression of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is common in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: Recent studies showed that EGFR inhibitors are effective for patients with HNSCC.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: This study analyzed the genetic nature of EGFR gene in HNSCC and its clinical correlations.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: The EGFR gene copy numbers in 134 HNSCC tumors were determined using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: The status of EGFR gene copy numbers was analyzed with clinical parameters including clinical outcome.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: Mutation status of EGFR exons 18, 19, and 21 was determined in the HNSCC tumors.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: RESULTS: Aberrant EGFR copy numbers were found in 32 (24%) of 134 tumors, including 22 (17%) with increased copy number and 10 (7%) with decreased copy number.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: Patients whose tumors had EGFR copy number alterations (particularly patients with increased copy numbers) had significantly poorer overall, cancer-specific, and disease-free survivals compared with patients with normal copy numbers (P < .0001).
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: At 5 years after initial diagnosis, 20 (91%) of the 22 patients with increased copy numbers died of disease compared with 30 (29%) of the 102 patients with normal copy number.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: No mutations on EGFR exons 18, 19, and 21 were detected in any of the tumors.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: A subset of HNSCC manifests EGFR copy number alterations, and this is associated with a poor clinical outcome, suggesting a biologic role of the alterations.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: The rare mutation or small deletion at EGFR exons 18 to 21 indicates a minimal role of these events in HNSCC.
title: Epidermal growth factor receptor copy number alterations correlate with poor clinical outcome in patients with head and neck squamous cancer.

text: A number of previous studies have reported that 30-50% of patients with colorectal cancer (CRC) harbor Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog (KRAS) mutations, which is a major predictive biomarker of resistance to epidermal growth factor (EGFR)-targeted therapy.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: Treatment with an anti-EGFR inhibitor is recommended for patients with KRAS wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: A recent retrospective study of cetuximab reported that patients with KRAS p.G13D mutations had better outcomes compared with those with other mutations.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: The aim of this retrospective study was to assess the prevalence of KRAS p.G13D mutations and evaluate the effectiveness of cetuximab in mCRC patients with KRAS p.G13D or other KRAS mutations.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: We reviewed the clinical records of 98 mCRC patients with KRAS mutations who were treated between August, 2004 and January, 2011 in four hospitals located in Tokyo and Kyushu Island.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: We also investigated KRAS mutation subtypes and patient characteristics.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: In the patients who received cetuximab, univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to assess the effect of KRAS p.G13D mutations on progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS).
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: Of the 98 patients, 23 (23.5%) had KRAS p.G13D-mutated tumors, whereas 75 (76.5%) had tumors harboring other mutations.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: Of the 31 patients who received cetuximab, 9 (29.0%) had KRAS p.G13D mutations and 22 (71.0%) had other mutations.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: There were no significant differences in age, gender, primary site, pathological type, history of chemotherapy, or the combined use of irinotecan between either of the patient subgroups.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: The univariate analysis revealed no significant difference in PFS or OS between the patients with KRAS p.G13D mutations and those with other mutations (median PFS, 4.5 vs. 2.8 months, respectively; P=0.65; and median OS, 15.3 vs. 8.9 months, respectively; P=0.51).
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: However, the multivariate analysis revealed a trend toward better PFS among patients harboring p.G13D mutations (PFS: HR=0.29; 95% CI: 0.08-1.10; P=0.07; OS: HR=0.23; 95% CI: 0.04-1.54; P=0.13).
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: In conclusion, treatment with cetuximab may be more clinically beneficial in mCRC patients with a KRAS p.G13D mutation, compared with those harboring other mutations.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: However, further investigation is required to clearly determine the benefits of cetuximab treatment in patients with KRAS p.G13D mutation-positive mCRC.
title: Cetuximab treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer with KRAS p.G13D mutations improves progression-free survival.

text: Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a genetic disorder with bilateral vestibular schwannomas (VS) as the most frequent manifestation.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Merlin, the NF2 tumor suppressor, was identified as a negative regulator of mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Pre-clinical data in mice showed that mTORC1 inhibition delayed growth of NF2-schwannomas.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: We conducted a prospective single-institution open-label phase II study to evaluate the effects of everolimus in ten NF2 patients with progressive VS. Drug activity was monitored every 3 months.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Everolimus was administered orally for 12 months and, if the decrease in tumor volume was >20 % from baseline, treatment was continued for 12 additional months.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Other patients stopped when completed 12 months of everolimus but were allowed to resume treatment when VS volume was >20 % during 1 year follow-up.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Nine patients were evaluable.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Safety was evaluated using CTCAE 3.0 criteria.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: After 12 months of everolimus, no reduction in volume >/=20 % was observed.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Four patients had progressive disease, and five patients had stable disease with a median annual growth rate decreasing from 67 %/year before treatment to 0.5 %/year during treatment.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: In these patients, tumor growth resumed within 3-6 months after treatment discontinuation.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Everolimus was then reintroduced and VS decreased by a median 6.8 % at 24 months.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Time to tumor progression increased threefold from 4.2 months before treatment to > 12 months.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Hearing was stable under treatment.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: The safety of everolimus was manageable.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Although the primary endpoint was not reached, further studies are required to confirm the potential for stabilization of everolimus.
title: Phase II study of mTORC1 inhibition by everolimus in neurofibromatosis type 2 patients with growing vestibular schwannomas.

text: Toward development of a precision medicine framework for metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC), we established a multi-institutional clinical sequencing infrastructure to conduct prospective whole-exome and transcriptome sequencing of bone or soft tissue tumor biopsies from a cohort of 150 mCRPC affected individuals.
title: Integrative clinical genomics of advanced prostate cancer.

text: Aberrations of AR, ETS genes, TP53, and PTEN were frequent (40%-60% of cases), with TP53 and AR alterations enriched in mCRPC compared to primary prostate cancer.
title: Integrative clinical genomics of advanced prostate cancer.

text: We identified new genomic alterations in PIK3CA/B, R-spondin, BRAF/RAF1, APC, beta-catenin, and ZBTB16/PLZF.
title: Integrative clinical genomics of advanced prostate cancer.

text: Moreover, aberrations of BRCA2, BRCA1, and ATM were observed at substantially higher frequencies (19.3% overall) compared to those in primary prostate cancers.
title: Integrative clinical genomics of advanced prostate cancer.

text: 89% of affected individuals harbored a clinically actionable aberration, including 62.7% with aberrations in AR, 65% in other cancer-related genes, and 8% with actionable pathogenic germline alterations.
title: Integrative clinical genomics of advanced prostate cancer.

text: This cohort study provides clinically actionable information that could impact treatment decisions for these affected individuals.
title: Integrative clinical genomics of advanced prostate cancer.

text: UNLABELLED: Data from 8 breast cancer genome-sequencing projects identified 25 patients with HER2 somatic mutations in cancers lacking HER2 gene amplification.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: To determine the phenotype of these mutations, we functionally characterized 13 HER2 mutations using in vitro kinase assays, protein structure analysis, cell culture, and xenograft experiments.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: Seven of these mutations are activating mutations, including G309A, D769H, D769Y, V777L, P780ins, V842I, and R896C.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: HER2 in-frame deletion 755-759, which is homologous to EGF receptor (EGFR) exon 19 in-frame deletions, had a neomorphic phenotype with increased phosphorylation of EGFR or HER3.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: L755S produced lapatinib resistance, but was not an activating mutation in our experimental systems.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: All of these mutations were sensitive to the irreversible kinase inhibitor, neratinib.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: These findings show that HER2 somatic mutation is an alternative mechanism to activate HER2 in breast cancer and they validate HER2 somatic mutations as drug targets for breast cancer treatment.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: We show that the majority of HER2 somatic mutations in breast cancer patients are activating mutations that likely drive tumorigenesis.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: Several patients had mutations that are resistant to the reversible HER2 inhibitor lapatinib, but are sensitive to the irreversible HER2 inhibitor, neratinib.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: Our results suggest that patients with HER2 mutation-positive breast cancers could benefit from existing HER2-targeted drugs.
title: Activating HER2 mutations in HER2 gene amplification negative breast cancer.

text: Esophageal adenocarcinomas are poorly responsive to chemotherapeutics.
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: This study aimed to determine the levels of Aurora kinase A (AURKA) and the therapeutic potential of MLN8237, an investigational AURKA inhibitor, alone and in combination with cisplatin.
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: Using quantitative real-time PCR, we detected frequent AURKA gene amplification (15 of 34, 44%) and mRNA overexpression (37 of 44, 84%) in esophageal adenocarcinomas (P < 0.01).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: Immunohistochemical analysis showed overexpression of AURKA in more than two-thirds of esophageal adenocarcinoma tissue samples (92 of 132, 70%; P < 0.001).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: Using FLO-1, OE19, and OE33 esophageal adenocarinoma cell lines, with constitutive AURKA overexpression and mutant p53, we observed inhibition of colony formation with a single treatment of 0.5 mumol/L MLN8237 (P < 0.05).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: This effect was further enhanced in combination with 2.5 mumol/L cisplatin (P < 0.001).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: Twenty-four hours after treatment with the MLN8237 or MLN8237 and cisplatin, cell-cycle analyses showed a sharp increase in the percentage of polyploid cells (P < 0.001).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: This was followed by an increase in the percentage of cells in the sub-G(1) phase at 72 hours, concordant with the occurrence of cell death (P < 0.001).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: Western blot analysis showed higher induction of TAp73beta, PUMA, NOXA, cleaved caspase-3, and cleaved PARP with the combined treatment, as compared with a single-agent treatment.
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: Using xenograft models, we showed an enhanced antitumor role for the MLN8237 and cisplatin combination, as compared with single-agent treatments (P < 0.001).
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: In conclusion, this study shows frequent overexpression of AURKA and suggests that MLN8237 could be an effective antitumor agent, which can be combined with cisplatin for a better therapeutic outcome in esophageal adenocarcinomas.
title: The aurora kinase A inhibitor MLN8237 enhances cisplatin-induced cell death in esophageal adenocarcinoma cells.

text: AIM: Despite promising preclinical findings regarding clinical utility of farnesyltransferase inhibitors (FTI), such as lonafarnib, success of clinical trials is limited.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: A multicentre AGO-OVAR-15 phase II trial reported an unfavourable effect of lonafarnib on the outcome of patients with advanced ovarian cancer.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: This study was performed as a genetic subgroup analysis of the AGO-OVAR-15 trial, and investigated the utility of the promoter polymorphism rs11623866 of the farnesyltransferase ss-subunit gene (FNTB) in predicting the clinical effectiveness of lonafarnib.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: METHODS: The influence of rs11623866 (c.-609G > C) on FNTB promoter activity was investigated by electrophoretic-mobility-shift assay, luciferase-reporter assay and RT-qPCR.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: A total of 57 out of 105 patients from the AGO-OVAR-15 trial, treated with carboplatin and paclitaxel +/- lonafarnib, was genotyped for rs11623866 by restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: Genotype-dependent survival analysis was performed by Kaplan-Meier analysis.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: The presence of the G allele was associated with increased FNTB promoter activity compared with the C allele.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: An unfavourable effect of lonafarnib was limited to patients carrying a GG genotype (HRPFS 6.2, 95%CI = 2.01, 19.41, P = 0.002; HROS 9.6, 95%CI = 1.89, 48.54, P = 0.006).
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: Median progression free survival (PFS) for patients with the GG genotype in the lonafarnib treated arm was 10 months, whereas median PFS without FTI-treatment was 40 months.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: Median overall survival (OS) in the lonafarnib-treated group was 19 months, whereas median OS was not reached in the untreated group.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Discrepancies between preclinical success and clinical failure may be due to the patients' genetic variability of FNTB.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: Therefore, our results may encourage retrospective evaluation of FNTB polymorphisms in previous FTI studies, especially those reporting positive FTI response.
title: The FNTB promoter polymorphism rs11623866 as a potential predictive biomarker for lonafarnib treatment of ovarian cancer patients.

text: Genes crucial for cancer development can be mutated via various mechanisms, which may reflect the nature of the mutagen.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: In thyroid papillary carcinomas, mutations of genes coding for effectors along the MAPK pathway are central for transformation.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: BRAF point mutation is most common in sporadic tumors.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: By contrast, radiation-induced tumors are associated with paracentric inversions activating the receptor tyrosine kinases RET and NTRK1.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: We report here a rearrangement of BRAF via paracentric inversion of chromosome 7q resulting in an in-frame fusion between exons 1-8 of the AKAP9 gene and exons 9-18 of BRAF.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: The fusion protein contains the protein kinase domain and lacks the autoinhibitory N-terminal portion of BRAF.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: It has elevated kinase activity and transforms NIH3T3 cells, which provides evidence, for the first time to our knowledge, of in vivo activation of an intracellular effector along the MAPK pathway by recombination.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: The AKAP9-BRAF fusion was preferentially found in radiation-induced papillary carcinomas developing after a short latency, whereas BRAF point mutations were absent in this group.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: These data indicate that in thyroid cancer, radiation activates components of the MAPK pathway primarily through chromosomal paracentric inversions, whereas in sporadic forms of the disease, effectors along the same pathway are activated predominantly by point mutations.
title: Oncogenic AKAP9-BRAF fusion is a novel mechanism of MAPK pathway activation in thyroid cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: Uterine serous carcinomas (USCs) are an aggressive form of uterine cancer that may rely on HER2/neu amplification as a driver of proliferation.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: The objective of this paper is to assess the sensitivity of USC cell lines with and without HER2/neu gene amplification to afatinib, an irreversible ErbB tyrosine kinase inhibitor, and to test the efficacy of afatinib in the treatment of HER2-amplified USC xenografts.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: METHODS: Eight of fifteen primary USC cell lines (four with HER2 amplification and four without) demonstrating similar in vitro growth rates were treated with scalar concentrations of afatinib.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: Effects on cell growth, signalling and cell cycle distribution were determined by flow cytometry assays.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: Mice harbouring xenografts of HER2/neu-amplified USC were treated with afatinib by gavage to determine the effect on tumour growth and overall survival.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: RESULTS: Primary chemotherapy-resistant USC cell lines harbouring HER2/neu gene amplification were exquisitely sensitive to afatinib exposure (mean +/- s.e.m.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: IC50=0.0056 +/- 0.0006 muM) and significantly more sensitive than HER2/neu-non-amplified USC cell lines (mean +/- s.e.m.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.
Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: Afatinib exposure resulted in abrogation of cell survival, inhibition of HER2/neu autophosphorylation and S6 transcription factor phosphorylation in HER2/neu overexpressing USC and inhibited the growth of HER2-amplified tumour xenografts improving overall survival (P=0.0017).
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Afatinib may be highly effective against HER2/neu-amplified chemotherapy-resistant USC.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: The investigation of afatinib in patients harbouring HER2/neu-amplified USC is warranted.
title: Afatinib demonstrates remarkable activity against HER2-amplified uterine serous endometrial cancer in vitro and in vivo.

text: The effects of missense changes and small in-frame deletions and insertions on protein function are not easy to predict, and the identification of such variants in individuals at risk of a genetic disease can complicate genetic counselling.
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: One option is to perform functional tests to assess whether the variants affect protein function.
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: We have used this strategy to characterize variants identified in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes in individuals with, or suspected of having, Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: Here we present an overview of our functional studies on 45 TSC1 and 107 TSC2 variants.
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: Using a standardized protocol we classified 16 TSC1 variants and 70 TSC2 variants as pathogenic.
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: In addition we identified eight putative splice site mutations (five TSC1 and three TSC2).
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: The remaining 24 TSC1 and 34 TSC2 variants were classified as probably neutral.
title: Functional assessment of variants in the TSC1 and TSC2 genes identified in individuals with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

text: BACKGROUND: T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by the expansion of clonal CD3+CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and often associated with autoimmune disorders and immune-mediated cytopenias.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: METHODS: We used next-generation exome sequencing to identify somatic mutations in CTLs from an index patient with large granular lymphocytic leukemia.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Targeted resequencing was performed in a well-characterized cohort of 76 patients with this disorder, characterized by clonal T-cell-receptor rearrangements and increased numbers of large granular lymphocytes.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: RESULTS: Mutations in the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 gene (STAT3) were found in 31 of 77 patients (40%) with large granular lymphocytic leukemia.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Among these 31 patients, recurrent mutational hot spots included Y640F in 13 (17%), D661V in 7 (9%), D661Y in 7 (9%), and N647I in 3 (4%).
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: All mutations were located in exon 21, encoding the Src homology 2 (SH2) domain, which mediates the dimerization and activation of STAT protein.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: The amino acid changes resulted in a more hydrophobic protein surface and were associated with phosphorylation of STAT3 and its localization in the nucleus.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In vitro functional studies showed that the Y640F and D661V mutations increased the transcriptional activity of STAT3.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In the affected patients, downstream target genes of the STAT3 pathway (IFNGR2, BCL2L1, and JAK2) were up-regulated.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Patients with STAT3 mutations presented more often with neutropenia and rheumatoid arthritis than did patients without these mutations.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS: The SH2 dimerization and activation domain of STAT3 is frequently mutated in patients with large granular lymphocytic leukemia; these findings suggest that aberrant STAT3 signaling underlies the pathogenesis of this disease.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: (Funded by the Academy of Finland and others.
title: Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.
Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Sphingosine kinase 1 (SPHK1), an oncogenic kinase, has previously been found to be upregulated in various types of human malignancy and to play a crucial role in tumor development and progression.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Although SPHK1 has gained increasing prominence as an important enzyme in cancer biology, its potential as a predictive biomarker and a therapeutic target in cervical cancer remains unknown.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: SPHK1 expression was examined in 287 formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded cervical cancer tissues using immunohistochemistry, and its clinical implications and prognostic significance were analyzed.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Cervical cancer cell lines including HeLa and SiHa were treated with the SPHK inhibitors SKI-II or FTY720, and effects on cell survival, apoptosis, angiogenesis, and invasion were examined.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Moreover, the effects of FTY720 on tumor growth were evaluated using a patient-derived xenograft (PDX) model of cervical cancer.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that expression of SPHK1 was significantly increased in cervical cancer compared with normal tissues.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: SPHK1 expression was significantly associated with tumor size, invasion depth, FIGO stage, lymph node metastasis, and lymphovascular invasion.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Patients with high SPHK1 expression had lower overall survival and recurrence-free survival rates than those with low expression.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Treatment with SPHK inhibitors significantly reduced viability and increased apoptosis in cervical cancer cells.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Furthermore, FTY720 significantly decreased in vivo tumor weight in the PDX model of cervical cancer.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: We provide the first convincing evidence that SPHK1 is involved in tumor development and progression of cervical cancer.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Our data suggest that SPHK1 might be a potential prognostic marker and therapeutic target for the treatment of cervical cancer.
title: Sphingosine kinase 1 is a reliable prognostic factor and a novel therapeutic target for uterine cervical cancer.

text: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients carrying specific EGFR kinase activating mutations (L858R, delE746-A750) respond well to tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: However, drug resistance develops within a year.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: In about 50% of such patients, acquired drug resistance is attributed to the enrichment of a constitutively active point mutation within the EGFR kinase domain (T790M).
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: To date, differential drug-binding and altered ATP affinities by EGFR mutants have been shown to be responsible for differential TKI response.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
