text: As it has been reported that EGFR stability plays a role in the survival of EGFR driven cancers, we hypothesized that differential TKI-induced receptor degradation between the sensitive L858R and delE746-A750 and the resistant T790M may also play a role in drug responsiveness.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: To explore this, we have utilized an EGFR-null CHO overexpression system as well as NSCLC cell lines expressing various EGFR mutants and determined the effects of erlotinib treatment.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: We found that erlotinib inhibits EGFR phosphorylation in both TKI sensitive and resistant cells, but the protein half-lives of L858R and delE746-A750 were significantly shorter than L858R/T790M.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Third generation EGFR kinase inhibitor (AZD9291) inhibits the growth of L858R/T790M-EGFR driven cells and also induces EGFR degradation.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: Erlotinib treatment induced polyubiquitination and proteasomal degradation, primarily in a c-CBL-independent manner, in TKI sensitive L858R and delE746-A750 mutants when compared to the L858R/T790M mutant, which correlated with drug sensitivity.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: These data suggest an additional mechanism of TKI resistance, and we postulate that agents that degrade L858R/T790M-EGFR protein may overcome TKI resistance.
title: Differential protein stability of EGFR mutants determines responsiveness to tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

text: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a heterogeneous disease with multiple underlying causative genetic mutations.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The B-type Raf proto-oncogene (BRAF) plays an important role in the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling cascade during CRC.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The presence of BRAFV600E mutation can determine the response of a tumor to chemotherapy.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: However, the association between the BRAFV600E mutation and the clinicopathological features of CRC remains controversial.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to estimate the effect of BRAFV600E mutation on the clinicopathological characteristics of CRC.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: METHODS: We identified studies that examined the effect of BRAFV600E mutation on CRC within the PubMed, ISI Science Citation Index, and Embase databases.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The effect of BRAFV600E on outcome parameters was estimated by odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for each study using a fixed effects or random effects model.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: RESULTS: 25 studies with a total of 11,955 CRC patients met inclusion criteria.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The rate of BRAFV600 was 10.8% (1288/11955).
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The BRAFV600E mutation in CRC was associated with advanced TNM stage, poor differentiation, mucinous histology, microsatellite instability (MSI), CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP).
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: This mutation was also associated with female gender, older age, proximal colon, and mutL homolog 1 (MLH1) methylation.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: CONCLUSIONS: This meta-analysis demonstrated that BRAFV600E mutation was significantly correlated with adverse pathological features of CRC and distinct clinical characteristics.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: These data suggest that BRAFV600E mutation could be used to supplement standard clinical and pathological staging for the better management of individual CRC patients, and could be considered as a poor prognostic marker for CRC.
title: BRAFV600E mutation and its association with clinicopathological features of colorectal cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: PURPOSE: The predictive value of topoisomerase-II alpha (topo-II) has been evaluated in advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated with single-agent doxorubicin or docetaxel.
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Primary tumor samples from patients enrolled in a randomized, phase III clinical trial comparing single-agent doxorubicin (75 mg/m(2) q3wks) with docetaxel (100 mg/m(2) q3wks) were collected and topo-II status was evaluated by immunohistochemistry (clone KiS1).
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: RESULTS: Topo-II status was evaluated in 108 samples, 55 (51%) in the doxorubicin arm and 53 (49%) in the docetaxel arm.
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: An increment of 10% in cells expressing topo-II is associated with a statistically significant odds ratio (OR; 95% confidence interval) of 1.09 (1.03-1.15; P = 0.002) for overall response to doxorubicin versus 1.002 (0.94-1.07; P = 0.95) in the docetaxel arm.
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: With increasing topo-II, the favorable OR for overall response to docetaxel compared with doxorubicin decreases to become not significant in patients with topo-II tumor content >10%.
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: In a multivariate analysis, (a) HER-2 status seems positively correlated with overall response to chemotherapy (OR, 2.34; 95% confidence interval, 0.87-6.27; P = 0.09).
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: (b) Overall response to doxorubicin is significantly lower than overall response to docetaxel (OR, 0.17; 95% confidence interval, 0.04-0.64; P = 0.009) but with a significant interaction term for doxorubicin-treated patients with topo-II tumor content >10% (OR, 8.31; 95% confidence interval, 1.86-37.03; P = 0.05).
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: CONCLUSIONS: (a) Topo-II overexpression confers a higher probability of response in the doxorubicin arm only.
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: (b) Despite being a small retrospective study, this study is in line with previously reported studies and the hypotheses raised are now being tested in a prospective neoadjuvant trial.
title: Topoisomerase-II alpha expression as a predictive marker in a population of advanced breast cancer patients randomly treated either with single-agent doxorubicin or single-agent docetaxel.

text: BACKGROUND: In patients with metastatic breast cancer that is positive for human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), progression-free survival was significantly improved after first-line therapy with pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel, as compared with placebo, trastuzumab, and docetaxel.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Overall survival was significantly improved with pertuzumab in an interim analysis without the median being reached.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: We report final prespecified overall survival results with a median follow-up of 50 months.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: METHODS: We randomly assigned patients with metastatic breast cancer who had not received previous chemotherapy or anti-HER2 therapy for their metastatic disease to receive the pertuzumab combination or the placebo combination.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: The secondary end points of overall survival, investigator-assessed progression-free survival, independently assessed duration of response, and safety are reported.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Sensitivity analyses were adjusted for patients who crossed over from placebo to pertuzumab after the interim analysis.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: RESULTS: The median overall survival was 56.5 months (95% confidence interval [CI], 49.3 to not reached) in the group receiving the pertuzumab combination, as compared with 40.8 months (95% CI, 35.8 to 48.3) in the group receiving the placebo combination (hazard ratio favoring the pertuzumab group, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.56 to 0.84; P<0.001), a difference of 15.7 months.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: This analysis was not adjusted for crossover to the pertuzumab group and is therefore conservative.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Results of sensitivity analyses after adjustment for crossover were consistent.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Median progression-free survival as assessed by investigators improved by 6.3 months in the pertuzumab group (hazard ratio, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.58 to 0.80).
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Pertuzumab extended the median duration of response by 7.7 months, as independently assessed.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Most adverse events occurred during the administration of docetaxel in the two groups, with long-term cardiac safety maintained.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: In patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer, the addition of pertuzumab to trastuzumab and docetaxel, as compared with the addition of placebo, significantly improved the median overall survival to 56.5 months and extended the results of previous analyses showing the efficacy of this drug combination.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: (Funded by F. Hoffmann-La Roche and Genentech; CLEOPATRA ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00567190.
title: Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.
Pertuzumab, trastuzumab, and docetaxel in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer.

text: Distinct forms of tyrosine kinase domain (TKD), juxtamembrane domain, exon 8, and internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutations of c-KIT, were observed in about 46% of core binding factor leukemia (CBFL) patients.
title: Prognostic impact of c-KIT mutations in core binding factor leukemias: an Italian retrospective study.

text: To evaluate their prognostic significance, 67 adult patients with CBFL were analyzed to ascertain the c-KIT mutation status.
title: Prognostic impact of c-KIT mutations in core binding factor leukemias: an Italian retrospective study.

text: In acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with t(8;21), the presence of c-KIT TKD mutation at codon 816 (TKD(816)) was associated with a high white blood cell count at diagnosis (median, 29.60 x 10(9)/L) and a higher incidence (33%) of extramedullary leukemia (EML) during the course of the disease.
title: Prognostic impact of c-KIT mutations in core binding factor leukemias: an Italian retrospective study.

text: Data also showed that the TKD(816) mutated patients (n = 12) had a significantly higher incidence of relapse and a lower overall survival (OS) at 24 months, compared with the 17 c-KIT unmutated (c-KIT(-)) patients (90% vs 35.3%, P = .002; 25% vs 76.5%, P = .006, respectively).
title: Prognostic impact of c-KIT mutations in core binding factor leukemias: an Italian retrospective study.

text: No difference in relapse incidence (P = .126) and OS (P = .474) was observed between the c-KIT mutated other than TKD(816) (n = 7) and the c-KIT(-) patients.
title: Prognostic impact of c-KIT mutations in core binding factor leukemias: an Italian retrospective study.

text: These findings indicate that c-KIT TKD(816) mutation has a negative impact on the outcome of AML with t(8;21).
title: Prognostic impact of c-KIT mutations in core binding factor leukemias: an Italian retrospective study.

text: PURPOSE: Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples from CALGB 80203 were analyzed for expression of EGFR axis-related genes to identify prognostic or predictive biomarkers for cetuximab treatment.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Patients (238 total) with first-line metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) were randomized to FOLFOX or FOLFIRI chemotherapy +/- cetuximab.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: qRT-PCR analyses were conducted on tissues from 103 patients at baseline to measure gene expression levels of HER-related genes, including amphiregulin (AREG), betacellulin (BTC), NT5E (CD73), DUSP4, EGF, EGFR, epigen (EPGN), epiregulin (EREG), HBEGF, ERBB2 (HER2), ERBB3 (HER3), ERBB4 (HER4), PHLDA1, and TGFA.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: The interactions between expression levels and treatment with respect to progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) were modeled using multiplicative Cox proportional hazards models.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: RESULTS: High tumor mRNA levels of HER2 [hazard ratio (HR), 0.64; P = 0.002] and EREG (HR, 0.89; P = 0.016) were prognostic markers associated with longer PFS across all patients.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: HER3 and CD73 expression levels were identified as potential predictive markers of benefit from cetuximab.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: In KRAS wild-type (WT) tumors, low HER3 expression was associated with longer OS from cetuximab treatment, whereas high HER3 expression was associated with shorter OS from cetuximab treatment (chemo + cetuximab: HR, 1.15; chemo-only: HR, 0.48; Pinteraction = 0.029).
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: High CD73 expression was associated with longer PFS from cetuximab treatment in patients with KRAS-WT (chemo + cetuximab: HR, 0.91; chemo-only: HR, 1.57; Pinteraction = 0.026) and KRAS-mutant (Mut) tumors (chemo + cetuximab: HR, 0.80; chemo-only: HR, 1.29; P = 0.025).
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: CONCLUSIONS: Gene expression of HER3 and CD73 was identified as a potential predictive marker for cetuximab.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: These data implicate HER axis signaling and immune modulation as potential mechanisms of cetuximab action and sensitivity.
title: Gene expression markers of efficacy and resistance to cetuximab treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer: results from CALGB 80203 (Alliance).

text: Amplification of fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) occurs in approximately 10% of breast cancers and is associated with poor prognosis.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: However, it is uncertain whether overexpression of FGFR1 is causally linked to the poor prognosis of amplified cancers.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: Here, we show that FGFR1 overexpression is robustly associated with FGFR1 amplification in two independent series of breast cancers.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: Breast cancer cell lines with FGFR1 overexpression and amplification show enhanced ligand-dependent signaling, with increased activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase and phosphoinositide 3-kinase-AKT signaling pathways in response to FGF2, but also show basal ligand-independent signaling, and are dependent on FGFR signaling for anchorage-independent growth.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: FGFR1-amplified cell lines show resistance to 4-hydroxytamoxifen, which is reversed by small interfering RNA silencing of FGFR1, suggesting that FGFR1 overexpression also promotes endocrine therapy resistance.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: FGFR1 signaling suppresses progesterone receptor (PR) expression in vitro, and likewise, amplified cancers are frequently PR negative, identifying a potential biomarker for FGFR1 activity.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: Furthermore, we show that amplified cancers have a high proliferative rate assessed by Ki67 staining and that FGFR1 amplification is found in 16% to 27% of luminal B-type breast cancers.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: Our data suggest that amplification and overexpression of FGFR1 may be a major contributor to poor prognosis in luminal-type breast cancers, driving anchorage-independent proliferation and endocrine therapy resistance.
title: FGFR1 amplification drives endocrine therapy resistance and is a therapeutic target in breast cancer.

text: Targeted cancer therapies often induce "outlier" responses in molecularly defined patient subsets.
title: Oncogenic and sorafenib-sensitive ARAF mutations in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: One patient with advanced-stage lung adenocarcinoma, who was treated with oral sorafenib, demonstrated a near-complete clinical and radiographic remission for 5 years.
title: Oncogenic and sorafenib-sensitive ARAF mutations in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Whole-genome sequencing and RNA sequencing of primary tumor and normal samples from this patient identified a somatic mutation, ARAF S214C, present in the cancer genome and expressed at high levels.
title: Oncogenic and sorafenib-sensitive ARAF mutations in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: Additional mutations affecting this residue of ARAF and a nearby residue in the related kinase RAF1 were demonstrated across 1% of an independent cohort of lung adenocarcinoma cases.
title: Oncogenic and sorafenib-sensitive ARAF mutations in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: The ARAF mutations were shown to transform immortalized human airway epithelial cells in a sorafenib-sensitive manner.
title: Oncogenic and sorafenib-sensitive ARAF mutations in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: These results suggest that mutant ARAF is an oncogenic driver in lung adenocarcinoma and an indicator of sorafenib response.
title: Oncogenic and sorafenib-sensitive ARAF mutations in lung adenocarcinoma.

text: OBJECTIVES: This two-part study evaluated trametinib, a MEK1/2 inhibitor, in combination with anticancer agents.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Inhibition of MEK, a downstream effector of KRAS, demonstrated preclinical synergy with chemotherapy in KRAS-mutant NSCLC cell lines.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Part 1 of this study identified recommended phase 2 doses of trametinib combinations.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Part 2, reported herein, evaluated the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy of trametinib combinations in patients with NSCLC with and without KRAS mutations.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: METHODS: Phase 1b evaluated trametinib plus docetaxel with growth factor support (trametinib, 2.0 mg once daily, and docetaxel, 75 mg/m(2) every 3 weeks) or pemetrexed (trametinib, 1.5 mg once daily, and pemetrexed, 500 mg/m(2) every 3 weeks).
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Eligibility criteria for the expansion cohorts included metastatic NSCLC with measurable disease, known KRAS mutation status, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 1 or lower, and no more than two prior regimens.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: RESULTS: The primary end point of overall response rate (ORR) was met for both combinations.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: A confirmed partial response (PR) was observed in 10 of the 47 patients with NSCLC who received trametinib plus docetaxel (21%).
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: The ORR was 18% (four PRs in 22 patients) in those with KRAS wild-type NSCLC versus 24% (six PRs in 25 patients) in those with KRAS-mutant NSCLC.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Of the 42 patients with NSCLC treated with trametinib plus pemetrexed, six (14%) had a PR; the ORR was 17% (four of 23) in patients with KRAS-mutated NSCLC versus 11% (two of 19) in KRAS wild-type NSCLC.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Adverse events-most commonly diarrhea, nausea, and fatigue-were manageable.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Trametinib-plus-chemotherapy combinations were tolerable.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Clinical activity exceeding the ORRs previously reported with docetaxel or pemetrexed alone in KRAS-mutated NSCLC and meeting prespecified criteria was observed.
title: A Phase 1/1b Study Evaluating Trametinib Plus Docetaxel or Pemetrexed in Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.

text: Sarcomas are malignant tumors accounting for a high percentage of cancer morbidity and mortality in children and young adults.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Surgery and radiation therapy are the accepted treatments for most sarcomas; however, patients with metastatic disease are treated with systemic chemotherapy.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Many tumors display marginal levels of chemoresponsiveness and new treatment approaches are needed.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Deregulation of the G1 checkpoint is crucial for various oncogenic transformation processes, suggesting that many cancer cell types depend on CDK4/6 activity.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Thus, CDK4/6 activity appears to represent a promising therapeutic target for cancer treatment.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: In the present work, we explore the efficacy of CDK4 inhibition using palbociclib (PD0332991), a highly selective inhibitor of CDK4/6, in a panel of sarcoma cell lines and sarcoma tumor xenografts (PDXs).
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Palbociclib induces senescence in these cell lines and the responsiveness of these cell lines correlated with their levels of CDK4 mRNA.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Palbociclib is also active in vivo against sarcomas displaying high levels of CDK4 but not against sarcomas displaying low levels of CDK4 and high levels of p16ink4a.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: The analysis of tumors growing after palbociclib showed a clear decrease in the CDK4 levels, indicating that clonal selection occurred in these treated tumors.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: In summary, our data support the efficacy of CDK4 inhibitors against sarcomas displaying increased CDK4 levels, particularly fibrosarcomas and MPNST.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Our results also suggest that high levels of p16ink4a may indicate poor efficacy of CDK4 inhibitors.
title: Efficacy of CDK4 inhibition against sarcomas depends on their levels of CDK4 and p16ink4 mRNA.

text: Trastuzumab is the only HER2/neu-directed therapy to have received Food and Drug Administration approval for the treatment of patients with metastatic breast cancer.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: The efficacy of trastuzumab depends on the HER2/neu status of the tumour and the patient's prior treatment, but even when patients are selected on the basis of HER2/neu gene amplification, the single-agent response rate ranges from 12 to 30% and few patients respond to trastuzumab monotherapy.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: Here, we propose PTEN as a predictive biomarker for trastuzumab efficacy.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: Human breast cancer SKBR3 and drug-resistant SKBR3/R cells were investigated.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: We also examined clinical samples from patients who had been treated with trastuzumab and analysed the relationship between trastuzumab efficacy and PTEN level.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: The PI3K/Akt signalling pathway was observed to be highly active in the drug-resistant cells, and their level of PTEN was low.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: Delivery of antisense PTEN duplex siRNA significantly decreased the trastuzumab chemosensitivity of parental SKBR3 cells, and marked activation of Akt signalling pathway was also recognised.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: Moreover, immunohistochemical investigation revealed that trastuzumab treatment was remarkably successful in cells with elevated PTEN expression.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: Along with the immune-system-associated cytotoxic mechanism, several mechanisms have been proposed for the effect of trastuzumab.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: PTEN activity might play an important and major role in its HER2/PI3K/Akt-mediated antitumour effect, and could be a useful biomarker for predicting the efficacy of trastuzumab in the treatment of breast cancer.
title: PTEN activity could be a predictive marker of trastuzumab efficacy in the treatment of ErbB2-overexpressing breast cancer.

text: Taking a perspective on available evidence that emphasizes relevance to human disease, cyclin D1 is solidly established as an oncogene with an important pathogenetic role in breast cancer and other human tumors.
title: Cyclin D1 in breast cancer pathogenesis.

text: However, the precise cellular mechanisms through which aberrant cyclin D1 expression drives human neoplasia are less well established.
title: Cyclin D1 in breast cancer pathogenesis.

text: Indeed, emerging evidence suggests that cyclin D1 might act, predominantly or at least in part, through pathways that do not involve its widely accepted function as a cell cycle regulator.
title: Cyclin D1 in breast cancer pathogenesis.

text: Although therapeutic exploitation of the role of cyclin D1 as a molecular driver of breast cancer carries great promise, it is also suggested that direct targeting of the cyclin D1 gene or gene products may prove more successful than approaches that rely on arguably incomplete knowledge of the oncogenic mechanisms of cyclin D1.
title: Cyclin D1 in breast cancer pathogenesis.

text: The receptor tyrosine kinase RET is implicated in the progression of luminal breast cancers (BC) but its role in estrogen receptor (ER) negative tumors is unknown.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: Here we investigated the expression of RET in breast cancer patients tumors and patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and evaluated the therapeutic potential of Vandetanib, a tyrosin kinase inhibitor with strong activity against RET, EGFR and VEGFR2, in ER negative breast cancer PDX.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: The RT-PCR analysis of RET expression in breast tumors of 446 patients and 57 PDX, showed elevated levels of RET in ER+ and HER2+ subtypes and in a small subgroup of triple-negative breast cancers (TNBC).
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: The activity of Vandetanib was tested in vivo in three PDX models of TNBC and one model of HER2+ BC with different expression levels of RET and EGFR.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: Vandetanib induced tumor regression in PDX models with high expression of RET or EGFR.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: The effect was associated with inhibition of RET/EGFR phosphorylation and MAP kinase pathway and increased necrosis.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: In a PDX model with no expression of RET nor EGFR, Vandetanib slowed tumor growth without inducing tumor regression.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: In addition, treatment by Vandetanib decreased expression of murine Vegf receptors and the endothelial marker Cd31 in the four PDX models tested, suggesting inhibition of tumor vascularization.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: In summary, these preclinical results suggest that Vandetanib treatment could be useful for patients with ER negative breast cancers overexpressing Vandetanib's main targets.
title: Vandetanib as a potential new treatment for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancers.

text: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal neoplasms of the gut wall that express the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: Somatic mutations that result in constitutive activation of KIT kinase have been identified in a number of studies of GISTs, although the reported frequency of these mutations has varied over a wide range (20 to 92%).
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: Several reports have suggested that KIT gene mutations are more common in malignant GISTs than in benign lesions, and it has been proposed that mutations in exon 11 of KIT are a negative prognostic factor.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: To maximize sensitivity for KIT mutations we have adapted denaturing high-pressure liquid chromatography as a method for screening polymerase chain reaction amplimers of exons 9, 11, 13, and 17 from GIST genomic DNA.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: This approach was used to assess the frequency of KIT mutations in 13 morphologically benign, incidentally discovered, GISTs identified at autopsy, endoscopy, or laparotomy for unrelated disease.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: Representing the smallest pathologically recognizable GISTs, these lesions ranged in size from 4 to 10 mm in diameter and were all immunohistochemically positive for KIT.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: Eleven of the 13 tumors had sequence-confirmed mutations in KIT, including 10 mutations in exon 11 (77%) and one mutation in exon 9 (7.7%).
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: The remaining two tumors were wild type for exons 9, 11, and 17; one of these was also analyzed for exon 13 and was wild type in this exon as well.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: The mutations found in the incidental GISTs were identical to those that have been documented in larger GISTs.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: In addition, the overall frequency of mutations in the incidental tumors (85%) did not differ significantly from that we previously reported in a series of 72 advanced/metastatic GISTs (86%), strongly supporting the view that activating mutations in KIT are acquired very early in the development of most GISTs.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: The findings suggest that KIT mutations per se are of little prognostic importance in GISTs.
title: KIT mutations are common in incidental gastrointestinal stromal tumors one centimeter or less in size.

text: The stratification of breast cancer patients for endocrine therapies by oestrogen or progesterone receptor expression is effective but imperfect.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: The present study aims were to validate microarray studies that demonstrate TFF3 regulation by oestrogen and its association with oestrogen receptors in breast cancer, to evaluate TFF3 as a biomarker of endocrine response, and to investigate TFF3 function.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: Microarray data were validated by quantitative RT-PCR and northern and western transfer analyses.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: TFF3 was induced by oestrogen, and its induction was inhibited by antioestrogens, tamoxifen, 4-hydroxytamoxifen and fulvestrant in oestrogen-responsive breast cancer cells.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: The expression of TFF3 mRNA was associated with oestrogen receptor mRNA in breast tumours (Pearson's coefficient=0.762, P=0.000).
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: Monoclonal antibodies raised against the TFF3 protein detected TFF3 by immunohistochemistry in oesophageal submucosal glands, intestinal goblet and neuroendocrine cells, Barrett's metaplasia and intestinal metaplasia.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: TFF3 protein expression was associated with oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor and TFF1 expression in malignant breast cells.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: TFF3 is a specific and sensitive predictive biomarker of response to endocrine therapy, degree of response and duration of response in unstratified metastatic breast cancer patients (P=0.000, P=0.002 and P=0.002 respectively).
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: Multivariate binary logistic regression analysis demonstrated that TFF3 is an independent biomarker of endocrine response and degree of response, and this was confirmed in a validation cohort.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: TFF3 stimulated migration and invasion of breast cancer cells.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: In conclusion, TFF3 expression is associated with response to endocrine therapy, and outperforms oestrogen receptor, progesterone receptor and TFF1 as an independent biomarker, possibly because it mediates the malign effects of oestrogen on invasion and metastasis.
title: TFF3 is a valuable predictive biomarker of endocrine response in metastatic breast cancer.

text: BACKGROUND: The BRAF inhibitors vemurafenib and dabrafenib have shown efficacy as monotherapies in patients with previously untreated metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600E or V600K mutations.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: Combining dabrafenib and the MEK inhibitor trametinib, as compared with dabrafenib alone, enhanced antitumor activity in this population of patients.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: METHODS: In this open-label, phase 3 trial, we randomly assigned 704 patients with metastatic melanoma with a BRAF V600 mutation to receive either a combination of dabrafenib (150 mg twice daily) and trametinib (2 mg once daily) or vemurafenib (960 mg twice daily) orally as first-line therapy.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: The primary end point was overall survival.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: RESULTS: At the preplanned interim overall survival analysis, which was performed after 77% of the total number of expected events occurred, the overall survival rate at 12 months was 72% (95% confidence interval [CI], 67 to 77) in the combination-therapy group and 65% (95% CI, 59 to 70) in the vemurafenib group (hazard ratio for death in the combination-therapy group, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.53 to 0.89; P=0.005).
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: The prespecified interim stopping boundary was crossed, and the study was stopped for efficacy in July 2014.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: Median progression-free survival was 11.4 months in the combination-therapy group and 7.3 months in the vemurafenib group (hazard ratio, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.46 to 0.69; P<0.001).
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: The objective response rate was 64% in the combination-therapy group and 51% in the vemurafenib group (P<0.001).
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: Rates of severe adverse events and study-drug discontinuations were similar in the two groups.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: Cutaneous squamous-cell carcinoma and keratoacanthoma occurred in 1% of patients in the combination-therapy group and 18% of those in the vemurafenib group.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Dabrafenib plus trametinib, as compared with vemurafenib monotherapy, significantly improved overall survival in previously untreated patients with metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600E or V600K mutations, without increased overall toxicity.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: (Funded by GlaxoSmithKline; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01597908.
title: Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.
Improved overall survival in melanoma with combined dabrafenib and trametinib.

text: A t(2;5) chromosomal translocation resulting in expression of an oncogenic kinase fusion protein known as nucleophosmin-anaplastic lymphoma kinase (NPM-ALK) has been implicated in the pathogenesis of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (ALCL).
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: PF-2341066 was recently identified as a p o  bioavailable, small-molecule inhibitor of the catalytic activity of c-Met kinase and the NPM-ALK fusion protein.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: PF-2341066 also potently inhibited NPM-ALK phosphorylation in Karpas299 or SU-DHL-1 ALCL cells (mean IC(50) value, 24 nmol/L).
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: In biochemical and cellular screens, PF-2341066 was shown to be selective for c-Met and ALK at pharmacologically relevant concentrations across a panel of >120 diverse kinases.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: PF-2341066 potently inhibited cell proliferation, which was associated with G(1)-S-phase cell cycle arrest and induction of apoptosis in ALK-positive ALCL cells (IC(50) values, approximately 30 nmol/L) but not ALK-negative lymphoma cells.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: The induction of apoptosis was confirmed using terminal deoxyribonucleotide transferase-mediated nick-end labeling and Annexin V staining (IC(50) values, 25-50 nmol/L).
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: p o  administration of PF-2341066 to severe combined immunodeficient-Beige mice bearing Karpas299 ALCL tumor xenografts resulted in dose-dependent antitumor efficacy with complete regression of all tumors at the 100 mg/kg/d dose within 15 days of initial compound administration.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: A strong correlation was observed between antitumor response and inhibition of NPM-ALK phosphorylation and induction of apoptosis in tumor tissue.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: In addition, inhibition of key NPM-ALK signaling mediators, including phospholipase C-gamma, signal transducers and activators of transcription 3, extracellular signal-regulated kinases, and Akt by PF-2341066 were observed at concentrations or dose levels, which correlated with inhibition of NPM-ALK phosphorylation and function.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: Collectively, these data illustrate the potential clinical utility of inhibitors of NPM-ALK in treatment of patients with ALK-positive ALCL.
title: Cytoreductive antitumor activity of PF-2341066, a novel inhibitor of anaplastic lymphoma kinase and c-Met, in experimental models of anaplastic large-cell lymphoma.

text: Bromodomain and extraterminal protein (BET) inhibitors suppress the expression of c-MYC.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: U266, a human myeloma cell line, expresses the MYCL gene, but not the c-MYC gene.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: Our aim was to analyse the antimyeloma activity of BET inhibitors on U266 cells.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: Two BET inhibitors, I-BET151 and JQ1, were tested.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: U266 cell proliferation decreased to 61.5 and 54.0% of the control after incubation with 500 nmol/l I-BET151 for 72 and 96 h and to 53.5 and 56.4% of control after incubation with 500 nmol/l JQ1 for 72 and 96 h by MTS tetrazolium, respectively.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: BET inhibitors induced cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase in U266 cells, but did not induce apoptosis by flow cytometry.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: According to Gene Set Enrichment Analysis, MYC-related genes were significantly downregulated in U266 cells treated with I-BET151 similar to KMS11 cells that expressed c-MYC.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: The MYCL1 was expressed in U266 cells, whereas c-MYC and MYCN were not by quantitative real-time reverse-transcription-PCR.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: Incubation with I-BET151 induced downregulation of MYCL1 in U266 cells.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: BET inhibitors decreased the cell proliferation in U266 cells with overexpression of MYCL less than those without overexpression of MYCL.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: BET inhibitors induce G1 arrest without apoptosis and interfere with the proliferation of U266 myeloma cells, which express MYCL, but not c-MYC.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: BET inhibitors might be active in cancers that express MYCL, but not c-MYC.
title: Antimyeloma activity of bromodomain inhibitors on the human myeloma cell line U266 by downregulation of MYCL.

text: BACKGROUND: The HER2 gene, which encodes the growth factor receptor HER2, is amplified and HER2 is overexpressed in 25 to 30 percent of breast cancers, increasing the aggressiveness of the tumor.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: METHODS: We evaluated the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, in women with metastatic breast cancer that overexpressed HER2.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: We randomly assigned 234 patients to receive standard chemotherapy alone and 235 patients to receive standard chemotherapy plus trastuzumab.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: Patients who had not previously received adjuvant (postoperative) therapy with an anthracycline were treated with doxorubicin (or epirubicin in the case of 36 women) and cyclophosphamide alone (138 women) or with trastuzumab (143 women).
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: Patients who had previously received adjuvant anthracycline were treated with paclitaxel alone (96 women) or paclitaxel with trastuzumab (92 women).
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: RESULTS: The addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy was associated with a longer time to disease progression (median, 7.4 vs. 4.6 months; P<0.001), a higher rate of objective response (50 percent vs. 32 percent, P<0.001), a longer duration of response (median, 9.1 vs. 6.1 months; P<0.001), a lower rate of death at 1 year (22 percent vs. 33 percent, P=0.008), longer survival (median survival, 25.1 vs. 20.3 months; P=0.01), and a 20 percent reduction in the risk of death.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: The most important adverse event was cardiac dysfunction of New York Heart Association class III or IV, which occurred in 27 percent of the group given an anthracycline, cyclophosphamide, and trastuzumab; 8 percent of the group given an anthracycline and cyclophosphamide alone; 13 percent of the group given paclitaxel and trastuzumab; and 1 percent of the group given paclitaxel alone.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: Although the cardiotoxicity was potentially severe and, in some cases, life-threatening, the symptoms generally improved with standard medical management.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Trastuzumab increases the clinical benefit of first-line chemotherapy in metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.
title: Use of chemotherapy plus a monoclonal antibody against HER2 for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

text: PURPOSE: Recurrent glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is incurable with current therapies.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: Biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (bMMRD) is a highly penetrant childhood cancer syndrome often resulting in GBM characterized by a high mutational burden.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: Evidence suggests that high mutation and neoantigen loads are associated with response to immune checkpoint inhibition.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We performed exome sequencing and neoantigen prediction on 37 bMMRD cancers and compared them with childhood and adult brain neoplasms.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: Neoantigen prediction bMMRD GBM was compared with responsive adult cancers from multiple tissues.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: Two siblings with recurrent multifocal bMMRD GBM were treated with the immune checkpoint inhibitor nivolumab.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: RESULTS: All malignant tumors (n = 32) were hypermutant.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: Although bMMRD brain tumors had the highest mutational load because of secondary polymerase mutations (mean, 17,740 +/- standard deviation, 7,703), all other high-grade tumors were hypermutant (mean, 1,589 +/- standard deviation, 1,043), similar to other cancers that responded favorably to immune checkpoint inhibitors.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: bMMRD GBM had a significantly higher mutational load than sporadic pediatric and adult gliomas and all other brain tumors (P < .001).
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: bMMRD GBM harbored mean neoantigen loads seven to 16 times higher than those in immunoresponsive melanomas, lung cancers, or microsatellite-unstable GI cancers (P < .001).
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: On the basis of these preclinical data, we treated two bMMRD siblings with recurrent multifocal GBM with the anti-programmed death-1 inhibitor nivolumab, which resulted in clinically significant responses and a profound radiologic response.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: CONCLUSION: This report of initial and durable responses of recurrent GBM to immune checkpoint inhibition may have implications for GBM in general and other hypermutant cancers arising from primary (genetic predisposition) or secondary MMRD.
title: Immune Checkpoint Inhibition for Hypermutant Glioblastoma Multiforme Resulting From Germline Biallelic Mismatch Repair Deficiency.

text: To examine the risk of lung cancer associated with the codon 72, intron 6 and intron 3 TP53 polymorphisms a meta-analysis of published case-control studies was undertaken.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The principle outcome measure was the odds ratio (OR) for the risk of lung cancer using homozygosity of the 'wild-type allele' as the reference group.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Data from 13 studies detailing the relationship between lung cancer and the codon 72 polymorphism of TP53 and three studies examining the intron 3 and 6 polymorphisms of TP53 were analysed.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The ORs of lung cancer associated with the Pro-Pro and Pro-carrier genotypes of codon 72 were 1.18 [95% confidence interval (CI) 0.99-1.41] and 1.02 (95% CI 0.86-1.20), respectively.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: The ORs of lung cancer associated with homozygous and variant allele carrier genotypes of the intron 6 (MspI RFLP) polymorphism were 1.13 (95% CI 0.55-2.27) and 1.30 (95% CI 0.75-2.26) and of the intron 3 (16 bp duplication) polymorphism were 1.50 (95% CI 0.76-2.97) and 1.11 (95% CI 0.53-2.35), respectively.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Although polymorphic variations in TP53 represent attractive candidate susceptibility alleles for lung cancer the results from this analysis provide little support for this hypothesis.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: Additional well-designed studies based on sample sizes commensurate with the detection of small genotypic risks may allow a more definitive conclusion.
title: TP53 polymorphisms and lung cancer risk: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

text: PURPOSE: There is an unmet need for treatment options in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Sorafenib is currently the only approved systemic treatment for HCC.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Refametinib, an oral, allosteric MEK inhibitor, has demonstrated antitumor activity in combination with sorafenib in vitro and in vivo.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: A phase II study evaluated efficacy and safety of refametinib plus sorafenib in Asian patients with HCC (NCT01204177).
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Eligible patients received twice-daily refametinib 50 mg plus twice-daily sorafenib 200 mg (morning)/400 mg (evening), with dose escalation to sorafenib 400 mg twice daily from cycle 2 if no grade >/= 2 hand-foot skin reaction, fatigue, or gastrointestinal toxicity occurred.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Primary efficacy endpoint: disease control rate.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Secondary endpoints: time to progression, overall survival, pharmacokinetic assessment, biomarker analysis, safety, and tolerability.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: RESULTS: Of 95 enrolled patients, 70 received study treatment.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Most patients had liver cirrhosis (82.9%) and hepatitis B viral infection (75.7%).
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Disease control rate was 44.8% (primary efficacy analysis; n = 58).
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Median time to progression was 122 days, median overall survival was 290 days (n = 70).
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Best clinical responders had RAS mutations; majority of poor responders had wild-type RAS.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Most frequent drug-related adverse events were diarrhea, rash, aspartate aminotransferase elevation, vomiting, and nausea.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Dose modifications due to adverse events were necessary in almost all patients.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Refametinib plus sorafenib showed antitumor activity in patients with HCC and was tolerated at reduced doses by most patients.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Frequent dose modifications due to grade 3 adverse events may have contributed to limited treatment effect.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: Patients with RAS mutations appear to benefit from refametinib/sorafenib combination.
title: A phase II study of the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of the MEK inhibitor refametinib (BAY 86-9766) plus sorafenib for Asian patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Most gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) harbor mutant KIT or platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRA) kinases, which are imatinib targets.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Sunitinib, which targets KIT, PDGFRs, and several other kinases, has demonstrated efficacy in patients with GIST after they experience imatinib failure.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: We evaluated the impact of primary and secondary kinase genotype on sunitinib activity.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Tumor responses were assessed radiologically in a phase I/II trial of sunitinib in 97 patients with metastatic, imatinib-resistant/intolerant GIST.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: KIT/PDGFRA mutational status was determined for 78 patients by using tumor specimens obtained before and after prior imatinib therapy.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Kinase mutants were biochemically profiled for sunitinib and imatinib sensitivity.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: RESULTS: Clinical benefit (partial response or stable disease for > or = 6 months) with sunitinib was observed for the three most common primary GIST genotypes: KIT exon 9 (58%), KIT exon 11 (34%), and wild-type KIT/PDGFRA (56%).
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Progression-free survival (PFS) was significantly longer for patients with primary KIT exon 9 mutations (P = .0005) or with a wild-type genotype (P = .0356) than for those with KIT exon 11 mutations.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: The same pattern was observed for overall survival (OS).
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: PFS and OS were longer for patients with secondary KIT exon 13 or 14 mutations (which involve the KIT-adenosine triphosphate binding pocket) than for those with exon 17 or 18 mutations (which involve the KIT activation loop).
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Biochemical profiling studies confirmed the clinical results.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: CONCLUSION: The clinical activity of sunitinib after imatinib failure is significantly influenced by both primary and secondary mutations in the predominant pathogenic kinases, which has implications for optimization of the treatment of patients with GIST.
title: Primary and secondary kinase genotypes correlate with the biological and clinical activity of sunitinib in imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: BACKGROUND: There are no established therapies specific for NRAS-mutant melanoma despite the emergence of immunotherapy.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: We aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of the MEK inhibitor binimetinib versus that of dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: METHODS: NEMO is an ongoing, randomised, open-label phase 3 study done at 118 hospitals in 26 countries.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Patients with advanced, unresectable, American Joint Committee on Cancer stage IIIC or stage IV NRAS-mutant melanoma who were previously untreated or had progressed on or after previous immunotherapy were randomised (2:1) to receive either binimetinib 45 mg orally twice daily or dacarbazine 1000 mg/m(2) intravenously every 3 weeks.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Randomisation was stratified by stage, performance status, and previous immunotherapy.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was progression-free survival assessed by blinded central review in the intention-to-treat population.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Safety analyses were done in the safety population, consisting of all patients who received at least one study drug dose and one post-baseline safety assessment.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01763164 and with EudraCT, number 2012-003593-51.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Aug 19, 2013, and April 28, 2015, 402 patients were enrolled and randomly assigned, 269 to binimetinib and 133 to dacarbazine.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Median follow-up was 1.7 months (IQR 1.4-4.1).
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Median progression-free survival was 2.8 months (95% CI 2.8-3.6) in the binimetinib group and 1.5 months (1.5-1.7) in the dacarbazine group (hazard ratio 0.62 [95% CI 0.47-0.80]; one-sided p<0.001).
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Grade 3-4 adverse events seen in at least 5% of patients the safety population in either group were increased creatine phosphokinase (52 [19%] of 269 patients in the binimetinib group vs none of 114 in the dacarbazine group), hypertension (20 [7%] vs two [2%]), anaemia (five [2%] vs six [5%]), and neutropenia (two [1%] vs ten [9%]).
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Serious adverse events (all grades) occurred in 91 (34%) patients in the binimetinib group and 25 (22%) patients in the dacarbazine group.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Binimetinib improved progression-free survival compared with dacarbazine and was tolerable.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: Binimetinib might represent a new treatment option for patients with NRAS-mutant melanoma after failure of immunotherapy.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: FUNDING: Array BioPharma and Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation.
title: Binimetinib versus dacarbazine in patients with advanced NRAS-mutant melanoma (NEMO): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, phase 3 trial.

text: An internal tandem duplication in the fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 gene (FLT3/ITD) is associated with poor prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), but the impact of mutant level, size, and interaction with nucleophosmin 1 (NPM1) mutations remains controversial.
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: We evaluated these characteristics in a large cohort of young adult AML patients.
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: There was a highly significant trend for worsening in relapse risk (RR) and overall survival (OS) with increasing FLT3/ITD mutant level (P < .001 for both), and even in the low level mutant group (1%-24% of total FLT3 alleles), RR was significantly worse than in the FLT3 wild-type (WT) group (P < .001).
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In multivariate analysis, mutant level was the most powerful prognostic factor for RR.
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Mutant size and number had no significant impact on outcome.
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: The beneficial impact of an NPM1 mutation on RR and OS was seen in FLT3/ITD(+) as well as FLT3/WT patients; both markers were highly significant independent predictors of outcome (P < .001).
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Stratification using both markers identified 3 prognostic groups: good (FLT3/ITD(-)NPM1(+)), intermediate (FLT3/ITD(-)NPM1(-) or FLT3/ITD(+)NPM1(+)), and poor (FLT3/ITD(+)NPM1(-)).
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: Patients with high FLT3/ITD mutant level (greater than 50%) or FLT3/ITD(+) in the absence of an NPM1 mutation may be good candidates for more experimental therapeutic approaches.
title: The impact of FLT3 internal tandem duplication mutant level, number, size, and interaction with NPM1 mutations in a large cohort of young adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

text: In this study, we focused on p53 mutations in specific regions, including DNA-binding surface regions, to clarify the correlation between mutations within the specific regions of p53 and clinical outcomes of patients with oral cancers.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: We analyzed p53 mutations in 121 fresh primary oral squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs) by polymerase chain reaction-single-strand conformation polymorphism or a yeast functional assay.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: p53 mutations were detected in 51/121 (42%) cases.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Mutation of p53 was not associated with any clinicopathological parameters; however, tumors containing specific p53 mutations, e.g.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: DNA-binding surface regions (L2, L3 and the LSH motif) and conserved regions (II-V), had significantly poorer prognoses than tumors with mutations outside of those regions.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: Moreover, locoregional failure, lymph node metastasis and the occurrence of subsequent distant metastasis were also significantly associated with mutations within DNA-binding surface regions.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: These data indicate that specific mutations of p53 could be important prognostic factors in oral SCCs.
title: Specific p53 mutations predict poor prognosis in oral squamous cell carcinoma.

text: PURPOSE Cetuximab or panitumumab are effective in 10% to 20% unselected metastatic colorectal cancer (CRC) patients.
title: Wild-type BRAF is required for response to panitumumab or cetuximab in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: KRAS mutations account for approximately 30% to 40% patients who are not responsive.
title: Wild-type BRAF is required for response to panitumumab or cetuximab in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: The serine-threonine kinase BRAF is the principal effector of KRAS.
title: Wild-type BRAF is required for response to panitumumab or cetuximab in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: We hypothesized that, in KRAS wild-type patients, BRAF mutations could have a predictive/prognostic value.
title: Wild-type BRAF is required for response to panitumumab or cetuximab in metastatic colorectal cancer.
