title: Novel targeted therapies for Bcr-Abl positive acute leukemias: beyond STI571.

text: Support for this has only been strengthened by the observations that resistance to imatinib mesylate (imatinib) commonly involves a breakthrough and the persistent activity of Bcr-Abl TK.
title: Novel targeted therapies for Bcr-Abl positive acute leukemias: beyond STI571.

text: This is due to either mutations that inhibit imatinib action on Bcr-Abl TK or amplification of the bcr-abl gene.
title: Novel targeted therapies for Bcr-Abl positive acute leukemias: beyond STI571.

text: Recent studies have demonstrated that other small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitors that also inhibit Bcr-Abl TK may be highly active in inducing differentiation and apoptosis of CML progenitors, regardless of their sensitivity to imatinib.
title: Novel targeted therapies for Bcr-Abl positive acute leukemias: beyond STI571.

text: Small molecule inhibitors that downregulate the levels of Bcr-Abl by inhibiting its translation, e.g., arsenic trioxide, or promoting its proteasomal degradation, e.g., geldanamycin analogues, have also been identified.
title: Novel targeted therapies for Bcr-Abl positive acute leukemias: beyond STI571.

text: Finally the identification of other potent survival and antiapoptotic signaling pathways in imatinib-resistant CML progenitors indicates that inhibitors of these pathways will eventually be treatment strategies for advanced phases of CML.
title: Novel targeted therapies for Bcr-Abl positive acute leukemias: beyond STI571.

text: PURPOSE: Identifying rectal cancer patients at risk for local recurrence would allow for refinement in the selection of patients who would benefit from preoperative radiotherapy.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: PIK3CA, KRAS, and BRAF mutations are commonly found in colon cancers, but their prevalence has not been clearly assessed in rectal cancer.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: In this study, we aim to determine the mutation frequencies of PIK3CA, KRAS, and BRAF and to investigate whether a mutation may be used as a prognostic parameter in rectal cancer patients.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: We evaluated DNA mutations in PIK3CA, KRAS, and BRAF in 240 stage I to III rectal tumors obtained from nonirradiated patients from the Dutch Total Mesorectal Excision trial.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: RESULTS: PIK3CA, KRAS, and BRAF mutations were identified in 19 (7.9%), 81 (33.9%), and 5 (2.1%) rectal cancers.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: Patients with PIK3CA mutations developed more local recurrences (5-year risks, 27.8% versus 9.4%; P = 0.006) and tended to develop these recurrences more rapidly after surgery (median local recurrence-free interval since surgery: 7.9 versus 19.6 months; P = 0.07) than patients without PIK3CA mutations.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: In multivariate analysis, PIK3CA mutations remained as an independent predictor for the development of local recurrences (hazard ratio, 3.4; 95% confidence interval, 1.2-9.2; P = 0.017), next to tumor-node-metastasis stage.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: CONCLUSION: PIK3CA mutations can be used as a biomarker in identifying rectal cancer patients with an increased risk for local recurrences.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: Currently, our findings suggest that prospective evaluation of PIK3CA mutation status could reduce overtreatment by preoperative radiotherapy for the low-risk patients who might otherwise only experience the side effects.
title: PIK3CA mutations predict local recurrences in rectal cancer patients.

text: The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) kinase inhibitors gefitinib and erlotinib are effective treatments for lung cancers with EGFR activating mutations, but these tumors invariably develop drug resistance.
title: MET amplification leads to gefitinib resistance in lung cancer by activating ERBB3 signaling.

text: Here, we describe a gefitinib-sensitive lung cancer cell line that developed resistance to gefitinib as a result of focal amplification of the MET proto-oncogene.
title: MET amplification leads to gefitinib resistance in lung cancer by activating ERBB3 signaling.

text: inhibition of MET signaling in these cells restored their sensitivity to gefitinib.
title: MET amplification leads to gefitinib resistance in lung cancer by activating ERBB3 signaling.

text: MET amplification was detected in 4 of 18 (22%) lung cancer specimens that had developed resistance to gefitinib or erlotinib.
title: MET amplification leads to gefitinib resistance in lung cancer by activating ERBB3 signaling.

text: We find that amplification of MET causes gefitinib resistance by driving ERBB3 (HER3)-dependent activation of PI3K, a pathway thought to be specific to EGFR/ERBB family receptors.
title: MET amplification leads to gefitinib resistance in lung cancer by activating ERBB3 signaling.

text: Thus, we propose that MET amplification may promote drug resistance in other ERBB-driven cancers as well.
title: MET amplification leads to gefitinib resistance in lung cancer by activating ERBB3 signaling.

text: Mutations in DNMT3A encoding DNA methyltransferase 3A were recently described in patients with acute myeloid leukemia.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: To assess their prognostic significance, we determined the mutational status of DNMT3A exon 23 in 288 patients with AML excluding acute promyelocytic leukemia, aged from 18 to 65 years and treated in Toulouse University Hospital.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: A mutation was detected in 39 patients (13.5%).
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: All DNMT3A exon 23+ patients had intermediate-risk cytogenetics.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: Mutations significantly correlated with a higher WBC count (p less than 0.001), NPM1 and FLT3-ITD mutations (p=0.027).
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: DNMT3A mutations were conserved through xenotransplantation in immunodeficient mice.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: No difference in outcome between DNMT3A exon 23+ and DNMT3A exon 23- patients was found even if the results were stratified by NPM1 or FLT3-ITD status.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: However, DNMT3A exon 23+ patients had better median DFS (not reached vs 11.6 months, p=0.009) and OS (not reached vs 14.3 months, p=0.005) as compared to DNMT3A exon 23- patients when treated with idarubicin, whereas patients treated with daunorubicin had similar outcome regardless the DNMT3A status.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: This study shows that DNMT3A mutations have no impact on outcome but could be a predictive factor for response to idarubicin and thus, could have a direct influence in the way AML patients should be managed.
title: Do AML patients with DNMT3A exon 23 mutations benefit from idarubicin as compared to daunorubicin? A single center experience.

text: BRAF V600R-M-D are uncommon mutations, not included in the experimental protocols of BRAF selective inhibitors.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: We report the evaluation of correlations among different types of BRAF somatic mutations in melanoma and their management with BRAF inhibitors.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: 21 patients with BRAF mutated metastatic melanoma were enrolled in the protocol with BRAF inhibitors for compassionate use at the University of Modena.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: Hot spot V600E mutations were found in 19 patients.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: V600R mutation and double (V600E -V600M) mutation were identified in two melanomas.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: In one case, V600K mutation was found.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: Two screening failures were noted.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: Mean progression free survival at follow-up of to 8 weeks, was 7.6 months.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: Five patients had a very short follow-up and the experimental protocol is still ongoing, so we cannot provide complete follow-up data.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: However, all of them are still under treatment and disease progression free.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: An objective response with few side effects was observed in all patients.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: in vitro studies with the aim of testing drug sensitivity.
title: The somatic affairs of BRAF: tailored therapies for advanced malignant melanoma and orphan non-V600E (V600R-M) mutations.

text: Genomic studies have revealed the complex clonal heterogeneity of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: The acquisition and selection of genomic aberrations may be critical to understanding the progression of this disease.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In this study, we have extensively characterized the mutational status of TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM in 406 untreated CLL cases by ultra-deep next-generation sequencing, which detected subclonal mutations down to 0.3% allele frequency.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Clonal dynamics were examined in longitudinal samples of 48 CLL patients.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: We identified a high proportion of subclonal mutations, isolated or associated with clonal aberrations.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: TP53 mutations were present in 10.6% of patients (6.4% clonal, 4.2% subclonal), ATM mutations in 11.1% (7.8% clonal, 1.3% subclonal, 2% germ line mutations considered pathogenic), SF3B1 mutations in 12.6% (7.4% clonal, 5.2% subclonal), NOTCH1 mutations in 21.8% (14.2% clonal, 7.6% subclonal), and BIRC3 mutations in 4.2% (2% clonal, 2.2% subclonal).
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: ATM mutations, clonal SF3B1, and both clonal and subclonal NOTCH1 mutations predicted for shorter time to first treatment irrespective of the immunoglobulin heavy-chain variable-region gene (IGHV) mutational status.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Clonal and subclonal TP53 and clonal NOTCH1 mutations predicted for shorter overall survival together with the IGHV mutational status.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Clonal evolution in longitudinal samples mainly occurred in cases with mutations in the initial samples and was observed not only after chemotherapy but also in untreated patients.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: These findings suggest that the characterization of the subclonal architecture and its dynamics in the evolution of the disease may be relevant for the management of CLL patients.
title: Clinical impact of clonal and subclonal TP53, SF3B1, BIRC3, NOTCH1, and ATM mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: BACKGROUND: Protein tyrosine phosphatase receptor type D (PTPRD) is a putative tumor suppressor in several cancers including head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: STAT3 is a frequently hyperactivated oncogene in HNSCC.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: As STAT3 is a direct substrate of PTPRD, we sought to determine the genetic or epigenetic alterations of PTPRD that contribute to overactive STAT3 in HNSCC.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: METHODS: We analyzed data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) and our previous whole-exome sequencing study and summarized the mutation, methylation, and copy number status of PTPRD in HNSCC and other cancers.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: In vitro studies involved standard transfection and MTT protocols, as well as methylation-specific PCR.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: RESULTS: Our findings indicate that PTPRD mutation, rather than methylation or copy number alteration, is the primary mechanism by which PTPRD function is lost in HNSCC.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: We demonstrate that overexpression of wild-type PTPRD in HNSCC cells significantly inhibits growth and STAT3 activation while PTPRD mutants do not, suggesting that mutation may lead to loss of function and subsequent hyper-phosphorylation of PTPRD substrates, especially STAT3.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: Importantly, we determined that HNSCC cells harboring an endogenous PTPRD mutation are more sensitive to STAT3 blockade than PTPRD wild-type cells.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: We additionally found that PTPRD mRNA expression does not correlate with pSTAT3 expression, suggesting that alterations that manifest through altered mRNA expression, including hypermethylation and gene copy number alterations, do not significantly contribute to STAT3 overactivation in HNSCC.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: PTPRD mutation, but not methylation or copy number loss, may serve as a predictive biomarker of sensitivity to STAT3 inhibitors in HNSCC.
title: Loss-of-Function PTPRD Mutations Lead to Increased STAT3 Activation and Sensitivity to STAT3 Inhibition in Head and Neck Cancer.

text: Recent studies have shown an association between the GNAS1 T393C polymorphism and clinical outcome for various solid tumors.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with histopathological response to neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.

text: In this study, we genotyped 51 patients from an observational trial on cisplatin/5-FU-based neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy of locally advanced esophageal cancer (cT2-4, Nx, M0) and genotyping was correlated with histomorphological tumor regression.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with histopathological response to neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.

text: The C-allele frequency in esophageal cancer patients was 0.49.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with histopathological response to neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.

text: Pearson's chi(2)-test showed a significant (P<0.05) association between tumor regression grades and T393C genotypes.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with histopathological response to neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.

text: Overall, 63% of the patients in the T-allele group (TT+CT) were minor responders with more than 10% residual vital tumor cells in resection specimens, whereas T(-) genotypes (CC) showed a major histopathological response with less than 10% residual vital tumor cells in 80%.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with histopathological response to neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.

text: The results support the role of the T393C polymorphism as a predictive molecular marker for tumor response to cisplatin/5-FU-based radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.
title: GNAS1 T393C polymorphism is associated with histopathological response to neoadjuvant radiochemotherapy in esophageal cancer.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of two doses of gefitinib (Iressa [ZD1839]; AstraZeneca, Wilmington, DE), a novel epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in patients with pretreated advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: This was a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, multicenter phase II trial.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Two hundred ten patients with advanced NSCLC who were previously treated with one or two chemotherapy regimens (at least one containing platinum) were randomly assigned to receive either 250-mg or 500-mg oral doses of gefitinib once daily.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: RESULTS: Efficacy was similar for the 250- and 500-mg/d groups.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Objective tumor response rates were 18.4% (95% confidence interval [CI], 11.5 to 27.3) and 19.0% (95% CI, 12.1 to 27.9); among evaluable patients, symptom improvement rates were 40.3% (95% CI, 28.5 to 53.0) and 37.0% (95% CI, 26.0 to 49.1); median progression-free survival times were 2.7 and 2.8 months; and median overall survival times were 7.6 and 8.0 months, respectively.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Symptom improvements were recorded for 69.2% (250 mg/d) and 85.7% (500 mg/d) of patients with a tumor response.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Adverse events (AEs) at both dose levels were generally mild (grade 1 or 2) and consisted mainly of skin reactions and diarrhea.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Drug-related toxicities were more frequent in the higher-dose group.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Withdrawal due to drug-related AEs was 1.9% and 9.4% for patients receiving gefitinib 250 and 500 mg/d, respectively.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: CONCLUSION: Gefitinib showed clinically meaningful antitumor activity and provided symptom relief as second- and third-line treatment in these patients.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: At 250 mg/d, gefitinib had a favorable AE profile.
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: Gefitinib 250 mg/d is an important, novel treatment option for patients with pretreated advanced NSCLC [corrected]
title: Multi-institutional randomized phase II trial of gefitinib for previously treated patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (The IDEAL 1 Trial) [corrected].

text: BACKGROUND: Gastric carcinoma (GC) has one of the highest mortality rates of cancer diseases and has a high incidence rate in China.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: Palliative chemotherapy is the main treatment for advanced gastric cancer.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: It is necessary to compare the effectiveness and toxicities of different regimens.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: This study explores the possibility of methylation of DNA damage repair genes serving as a prognostic and chemo-sensitive marker in human gastric cancer.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: METHODS: The methylation status of five DNA damage repair genes (CHFR, FANCF, MGMT, MLH1, and RASSF1A) was detected by nested methylation-specific PCR in 102 paraffin-embedded gastric cancer samples.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: Chi-square or Fisher's exact tests were used to evaluate the association of methylation status and clinic-pathological factors.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: The Kaplan-Meier method and Cox proportional hazards models were employed to analyze the association of methylation status and chemo-sensitivity.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: RESULTS: The results indicate that CHFR, MLH1, RASSF1A, MGMT, and FANCF were methylated in 34.3% (35/102), 21.6% (22/102), 12.7% (13/102), 9.8% (10/102), and 0% (0/102) of samples, respectively.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: No association was found between methylation of CHFR, MLH1, RASSF1A, MGMT, or FANCF with gender, age, tumor size, tumor differentiation, lymph node metastasis, and TNM stage.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: In docetaxel-treated gastric cancer patients, resistance to docetaxel was found in CHFR unmethylated patients by Cox proportional hazards model (HR 0.243, 95% CI, 0.069-0.859, p = 0.028), and overall survival is longer in the CHFR methylated group compared with the CHFR unmethylated group (log-rank, p = 0.036).
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: In oxaliplatin-treated gastric cancer patients, resistance to oxaliplatin was found in MLH1 methylated patients (HR 2.988, 95% CI, 1.064-8.394, p = 0.038), and overall survival was longer in the MLH1 unmethylated group compared with the MLH1 methylated group (log-rank, p = 0.046).
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: CONCLUSIONS: CHFR is frequently methylated in human gastric cancer, and CHFR methylation may serve as a docetaxel-sensitive marker.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: MLH1 methylation was related to oxaliplatin resistance in gastric cancer patients.
title: Predictive value of CHFR and MLH1 methylation in human gastric cancer.

text: TP53 mutations are found in 5-10% of MDS and AML, where they are generally associated with complex karyotype and an overall poor prognosis.
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: However, the impact of TP53 mutations in MDS treated with azacitidine (AZA) remains unclear.
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: We analyzed TP53 mutations in 62 patients with high risk MDS or AML treated with AZA.
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: A TP53 mutation was found in 23 patients (37.1%), associated with complex karyotype in 18 (78.3%) of them.
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: TP53 mutations had no significant impact on response or complete response to AZA (p=0.60 and p=0.26, respectively).
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: By univariate analysis, OS was negatively influenced by the presence of TP53 mutation (median OS 12.4 months versus 23.7 months, p<10(-4)), abnormal cytogenetics (median OS 14.4 months vs 33 months, p=0.02) complex cytogenetics (median OS 12.7 months versus 23.7 months, p=0.0005), and a diagnosis of AML (median 14.5 months vs 21.2 months for MDS or CMML, p=0.02).
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: By multivariate analysis, only TP53 mutational status (HR 2.89 (95% confidence interval 1.38-6.04; p=0.005) retained statistical significance for OS.
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: Results were similar when the analysis was restricted to MDS and CMML patients, excluding AML (HR=2.46 (95% confidence interval: 1.1-6.4); p=0.04)).
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: Thus, TP53 mutations strongly correlated with poorer survival in higher risk MDS and AML treated with AZA.
title: Prognostic value of TP53 gene mutations in myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia treated with azacitidine.

text: PURPOSE: We conducted a retrospective evaluation of the IMCL-9815 study to examine the association of human papillomavirus (HPV) and p16 protein expression status with outcomes in patients with oropharyngeal carcinoma (OPC) receiving radiotherapy (RT) plus cetuximab or RT alone.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: In the IMCL-9815 study, patients were randomly allocated to receive RT plus weekly cetuximab or RT alone.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: A subpopulation of patients with p16-evaluable OPC was retrospectively evaluated on the basis of locoregional control (LRC), overall survival (OS), and progression-free survival (PFS).
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: Evaluable samples from patients with p16-positive OPC were also tested for HPV DNA.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: RESULTS: Tumor p16 status was evaluable in 182 patients with OPC enrolled in the IMCL-9815 study; 41% were p16 positive.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: When treated with RT alone or RT plus cetuximab, p16-positive patients had a longer OS than p16-negative patients (hazard ratio, 0.40; 95% CI, 0.21 to 0.74 and hazard ratio, 0.16; 95% CI, 0.07 to 0.36, respectively).
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: The addition of cetuximab to RT increased LRC, OS, and PFS in both patients with p16-positive OPC and those with p16-negative disease.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: Interaction tests for LRC, OS, and PFS did not demonstrate any significant interaction between p16 status and treatment effect (P = .087, .085, and .253, respectively).
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: Similar trends were observed when patients with p16-positive/HPV-positive OPC (n = 49) and those with p16-positive/HPV-negative OPC (n = 14) were compared.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: CONCLUSION: p16 status was strongly prognostic for patients with OPC.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: The data suggest that the addition of cetuximab to RT improved clinical outcomes regardless of p16 or HPV status versus RT alone.
title: Association of Human Papillomavirus and p16 Status With Outcomes in the IMCL-9815 Phase III Registration Trial for Patients With Locoregionally Advanced Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck Treated With Radiotherapy With or Without Cetuximab.

text: SF3B1 is a critical component of the splicing machinery, which catalyzes the removal of introns from precursor messenger RNA (mRNA).
title: SF3B1 mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Next-generation sequencing studies have identified mutations in SF3B1 in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) at high frequency.
title: SF3B1 mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: In CLL, SF3B1 mutation is associated with more aggressive disease and shorter survival, and recent studies suggest that it can be incorporated into prognostic schema to improve the prediction of disease progression.
title: SF3B1 mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Mutations in SF3B1 are predominantly subclonal genetic events in CLL, and hence are likely later events in the progression of CLL.
title: SF3B1 mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Evidence of altered pre-mRNA splicing has been detected in CLL cases with SF3B1 mutations.
title: SF3B1 mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: Although the causative link between SF3B1 mutation and CLL pathogenesis remains unclear, several lines of evidence suggest SF3B1 mutation might be linked to genomic stability and epigenetic modification.
title: SF3B1 mutations in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

text: PURPOSE: BRCA2, FANCC, and FANCG gene mutations are present in a subset of pancreatic cancer.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: Defects in these genes could lead to hypersensitivity to interstrand cross-linkers in vivo and a more optimal treatment of pancreatic cancer patients based on the genetic profile of the tumor.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: Two retrovirally complemented pancreatic cancer cell lines having defects in the Fanconi anemia pathway, PL11 (FANCC-mutated) and Hs766T (FANCG-mutated), as well as several parental pancreatic cancer cell lines with or without mutations in the Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 pathway, were assayed for in vitro and in vivo sensitivities to various chemotherapeutic agents.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: RESULTS: A distinct dichotomy of drug responses was observed.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: Fanconi anemia-defective cancer cells were hypersensitive to the cross-linking agents mitomycin C (MMC), cisplatin, chlorambucil, and melphalan but not to 5-fluorouracil, gemcitabine, doxorubicin, etoposide, vinblastine, or paclitaxel.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: Hypersensitivity to cross-linking agents was confirmed in vivo; FANCC-deficient xenografts of PL11 and BRCA2-deficient xenografts of CAPAN1 regressed on treatment with two different regimens of MMC whereas Fanconi anemia-proficient xenografts did not.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: The MMC response comprised cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, and necrosis.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: Xenografts of PL11 also regressed after a single dose of cyclophosphamide whereas xenografts of genetically complemented PL11(FANCC) did not.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: CONCLUSIONS: MMC or other cross-linking agents as a clinical therapy for pancreatic cancer patients with tumors harboring defects in the Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 pathway should be specifically investigated.
title: In vivo therapeutic responses contingent on Fanconi anemia/BRCA2 status of the tumor.

text: We report that TG101348, a selective small-molecule inhibitor of JAK2 with an in vitro IC50 of approximately 3 nM, shows therapeutic efficacy in a murine model of myeloproliferative disease induced by the JAK2V617F mutation.
title: Efficacy of TG101348, a selective JAK2 inhibitor, in treatment of a murine model of JAK2V617F-induced polycythemia vera.

text: In treated animals, there was a statistically significant reduction in hematocrit and leukocyte count, a dose-dependent reduction/elimination of extramedullary hematopoiesis, and, at least in some instances, evidence for attenuation of myelofibrosis.
title: Efficacy of TG101348, a selective JAK2 inhibitor, in treatment of a murine model of JAK2V617F-induced polycythemia vera.

text: There were no apparent toxicities and no effect on T cell number.
title: Efficacy of TG101348, a selective JAK2 inhibitor, in treatment of a murine model of JAK2V617F-induced polycythemia vera.

text: In vivo responses were correlated with surrogate endpoints, including reduction/elimination of JAK2V617F disease burden assessed by quantitative genomic PCR, suppression of endogenous erythroid colony formation, and in vivo inhibition of JAK-STAT signal transduction as assessed by flow cytometric measurement of phosphorylated Stat5.
title: Efficacy of TG101348, a selective JAK2 inhibitor, in treatment of a murine model of JAK2V617F-induced polycythemia vera.

text: BACKGROUND: Hairy-cell leukemia (HCL) is a well-defined clinicopathological entity whose underlying genetic lesion is still obscure.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: METHODS: We searched for HCL-associated mutations by performing massively parallel sequencing of the whole exome of leukemic and matched normal cells purified from the peripheral blood of an index patient with HCL.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: Findings were validated by Sanger sequencing in 47 additional patients with HCL.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: RESULTS: Whole-exome sequencing identified five missense somatic clonal mutations that were confirmed on Sanger sequencing, including a heterozygous mutation in BRAF that results in the BRAF V600E variant protein.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: Since BRAF V600E is oncogenic in other tumors, further analyses were focused on this genetic lesion.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: The same BRAF mutation was noted in all the other 47 patients with HCL who were evaluated by means of Sanger sequencing.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: None of the 195 patients with other peripheral B-cell lymphomas or leukemias who were evaluated carried the BRAF V600E variant, including 38 patients with splenic marginal-zone lymphomas or unclassifiable splenic lymphomas or leukemias.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: In immunohistologic and Western blot studies, HCL cells expressed phosphorylated MEK and ERK (the downstream targets of the BRAF kinase), indicating a constitutive activation of the RAF-MEK-ERK mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway in HCL.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: In vitro incubation of BRAF-mutated primary leukemic hairy cells from 5 patients with PLX-4720, a specific inhibitor of active BRAF, led to a marked decrease in phosphorylated ERK and MEK.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: CONCLUSIONS; The BRAF V600E mutation was present in all patients with HCL who were evaluated.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: This finding may have implications for the pathogenesis, diagnosis, and targeted therapy of HCL.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: (Funded by Associazione Italiana per la Ricerca sul Cancro and others.
title: BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.
BRAF mutations in hairy-cell leukemia.

text: More aggressive and therapy-resistant oestrogen receptor (ER)-positive breast cancers remain a great clinical challenge.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: Here our integrative genomic analysis identifies tousled-like kinase 2 (TLK2) as a candidate kinase target frequently amplified in approximately 10.5% of ER-positive breast tumours.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: The resulting overexpression of TLK2 is more significant in aggressive and advanced tumours, and correlates with worse clinical outcome regardless of endocrine therapy.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: Ectopic expression of TLK2 leads to enhanced aggressiveness in breast cancer cells, which may involve the EGFR/SRC/FAK signalling.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: Conversely, TLK2 inhibition selectively inhibits the growth of TLK2-high breast cancer cells, downregulates ERalpha, BCL2 and SKP2, impairs G1/S cell cycle progression, induces apoptosis and significantly improves progression-free survival in vivo.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: We identify two potential TLK2 inhibitors that could serve as backbones for future drug development.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: Together, amplification of the cell cycle kinase TLK2 presents an attractive genomic target for aggressive ER-positive breast cancers.
title: Comprehensive functional analysis of the tousled-like kinase 2 frequently amplified in aggressive luminal breast cancers.

text: BACKGROUND: The potential predictive role of programmed death-ligand-1 (PD-L1) expression on tumor cells in the context of solid tumor treated with checkpoint inhibitors targeting the PD-1 pathway represents an issue for clinical research.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: METHODS: Overall response rate (ORR) was extracted from phase I-III trials investigating nivolumab, pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A for advanced melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and genitourinary cancer, and cumulated by adopting a fixed and random-effect model with 95% confidence interval (CI).
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: Interaction test according to tumor PD-L1 was accomplished.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: A sensitivity analysis according to adopted drug, tumor type, PD-L1 cut-off and treatment line was performed.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: RESULTS: Twenty trials (1,475 patients) were identified.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: A significant interaction (p<0.0001) according to tumor PD-L1 expression was found in the overall sample with an ORR of 34.1% (95% CI 27.6-41.3%) in the PD-L1 positive and 19.9% (95% CI 15.4-25.3%) in the PD-L1 negative population.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: ORR was significantly higher in PD-L1 positive in comparison to PD-L1 negative patients for nivolumab and pembrolizumab, with an absolute difference of 16.4% and 19.5%, respectively.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: A significant difference in activity of 22.8% and 8.7% according to PD-L1 was found for melanoma and NSCLC, respectively, with no significant difference for genitourinary cancer.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: CONCLUSION: Overall, the three antibodies provide a significant differential effect in terms of activity according to PD-L1 expression on tumor cells.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: The predictive value of PD-L1 on tumor cells seems to be more robust for anti-PD-1 antibody (nivolumab and pembrolizumab), and in the context of advanced melanoma and NSCLC.
title: Differential Activity of Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and MPDL3280A according to the Tumor Expression of Programmed Death-Ligand-1 (PD-L1): Sensitivity Analysis of Trials in Melanoma, Lung and Genitourinary Cancers.

text: Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma (AITL) is a common subtype of peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PTCL) with a poor prognosis.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: We performed targeted resequencing on 92 cases of PTCL and identified frequent mutations affecting RHOA, TET2, DNMT3A, and isocitrate dehydrogenase 2 (IDH2).
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: Although IDH2 mutations are largely confined to AITL, mutations of the other 3 can be found in other types of PTCL, although at lower frequencies.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: These findings indicate a key role of epigenetic regulation in the pathogenesis of AITL.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: However, the epigenetic alterations induced by these mutations and their role in AITL pathogenesis are still largely unknown.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: We correlated mutational status with gene expression and global DNA methylation changes in AITL.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: Strikingly, AITL cases with IDH2(R172) mutations demonstrated a distinct gene expression signature characterized by downregulation of genes associated with TH1 differentiation (eg, STAT1 and IFNG) and a striking enrichment of an interleukin 12-induced gene signature.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: Ectopic expression of IDH2(R172K) in the Jurkat cell line and CD4(+) T cells led to markedly increased levels of 2-hydroxyglutarate, histone-3 lysine methylation, and 5-methylcytosine and a decrease of 5-hydroxymethylcytosine.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: Correspondingly, clinical samples with IDH2 mutations displayed a prominent increase in H3K27me3 and DNA hypermethylation of gene promoters.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: Integrative analysis of gene expression and promoter methylation revealed recurrently hypermethylated genes involved in T-cell receptor signaling and T-cell differentiation that likely contribute to lymphomagenesis in AITL.
title: IDH2R172 mutations define a unique subgroup of patients with angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is an aggressive hematological tumor resulting from the malignant transformation of lymphoid progenitors.
title: Activating mutations in the NT5C2 nucleotidase gene drive chemotherapy resistance in relapsed ALL.

text: Despite intensive chemotherapy, 20% of pediatric patients and over 50% of adult patients with ALL do not achieve a complete remission or relapse after intensified chemotherapy, making disease relapse and resistance to therapy the most substantial challenge in the treatment of this disease.
title: Activating mutations in the NT5C2 nucleotidase gene drive chemotherapy resistance in relapsed ALL.

text: Using whole-exome sequencing, we identify mutations in the cytosolic 5'-nucleotidase II gene (NT5C2), which encodes a 5'-nucleotidase enzyme that is responsible for the inactivation of nucleoside-analog chemotherapy drugs, in 20/103 (19%) relapse T cell ALLs and 1/35 (3%) relapse B-precursor ALLs.
title: Activating mutations in the NT5C2 nucleotidase gene drive chemotherapy resistance in relapsed ALL.

text: NT5C2 mutant proteins show increased nucleotidase activity in vitro and conferred resistance to chemotherapy with 6-mercaptopurine and 6-thioguanine when expressed in ALL lymphoblasts.
title: Activating mutations in the NT5C2 nucleotidase gene drive chemotherapy resistance in relapsed ALL.

text: These results support a prominent role for activating mutations in NT5C2 and increased nucleoside-analog metabolism in disease progression and chemotherapy resistance in ALL.
title: Activating mutations in the NT5C2 nucleotidase gene drive chemotherapy resistance in relapsed ALL.

text: BACKGROUND: Enzastaurin, an oral serine-threonine kinase inhibitor, was initially developed as an ATP-competitive selective inhibitor against protein kinase Cbeta.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: However, the mechanism by which enzastaurin contributes to tumourigenesis remains unclear.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: METHODS: We analysed the anti-tumour effects of enzastaurin in 22 lung cancer cell lines to ascertain the potential for enzastaurin-based treatment of lung cancer.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: To identify molecules or signalling pathways associated with this sensitivity, we conducted a gene, receptor tyrosine kinases phosphorylation and microRNA expression profiling study on the same set of cell lines.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: RESULTS: We identified eight genes by pathway analysis of molecules having gene-drug sensitivity correlation, and used them to build a support vector machine algorithm model by which sensitive cell lines were distinguished from resistant cell lines.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: Pathway analysis revealed that the JAK/STAT signalling pathway was one of the main ones involved in sensitivity to enzastaurin.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: Overexpression of JAK1 was observed in the sensitive cells by western blotting.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: Simultaneous administration of enzastaurin and JAK inhibitor inhibited enzastaurin-induced cell growth-inhibitory effect.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: Furthermore, lentiviral-mediated JAK1-overexpressing cells were more sensitive to enzastaurin than control cells.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: CONCLUSION: Our results suggested that the JAK1 pathway may be used as a single predictive biomarker for enzastaurin treatment.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: The anti-tumour effect of enzastaurin should be evaluated in lung cancer with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.
title: Enzastaurin has anti-tumour effects in lung cancers with overexpressed JAK pathway molecules.

text: PURPOSE: To evaluate the antitumor activity and toxicity of single-agent cetuximab in patients with chemotherapy-refractory colorectal cancer whose tumors express the epidermal growth factor receptor.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Phase II, open-label clinical trial.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Patients were required to have EGFr expression demonstrated on formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor tissue by immunohistochemical staining before study participation.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Patients were required to have received irinotecan, either alone or in a combination regimen, and to have demonstrated clinical failure on this regimen before study entry.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Cetuximab was administered weekly by intravenous infusion.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: The first dose of 400 mg/m(2) was given during the course of 2 hours.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Subsequent weekly treatments were given at a dose of 250 mg/m(2) during the course of 1 hour.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: RESULTS: Fifty-seven eligible patients were treated.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: All were assessable for toxicity and response.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: The most commonly encountered grade 3 to 4 adverse events, regardless of relationship to study drug, were an acne-like skin rash, predominantly on the face and upper torso (86% with any grade; 18% with grade 3), and a composite of asthenia, fatigue, malaise, or lethargy (56% with any grade, 9% with grade 3).
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Two patients (3.5%) experienced grade 3 allergic reactions requiring discontinuation of study treatment.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: A third patient experienced a grade 3 allergic reaction that resolved, and the patient continued on the study.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Neither diarrhea nor neutropenia were dose limiting in any of the 57 patients treated.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Five patients (9%; 95% CI, 3% to 19%) achieved a partial response.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Twenty-one additional patients had stable disease or minor responses.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: The median survival in these previously treated patients with chemotherapy-refractory colorectal cancer is 6.4 months.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: CONCLUSION: Cetuximab on this once-weekly schedule has modest activity and is well-tolerated as a single agent in patients with chemotherapy-refractory colorectal cancer whose tumors express the epidermal growth factor receptor.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: Further studies of cetuximab will evaluate the use of cetuximab in conjunction with first-line and adjuvant treatments for this disease.
title: Phase II trial of cetuximab in patients with refractory colorectal cancer that expresses the epidermal growth factor receptor.

text: A role of heat shock protein 27 (HSP27) as a potential biomarker has been reported in various tumour entities, but comprehensive studies in pancreatic cancer are lacking.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Applying tissue microarray (TMA) analysis, we correlated HSP27 protein expression status with clinicopathologic parameters in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma specimens from 86 patients.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Complementary, we established HSP27 overexpression and RNA-interference models to assess the impact of HSP27 on chemo- and radiosensitivity directly in pancreatic cancer cells.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: In the TMA study, HSP27 expression was found in 49% of tumour samples.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Applying univariate analyses, a significant correlation was found between HSP27 expression and survival.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: In the multivariate Cox-regression model, HSP27 expression emerged as an independent prognostic factor.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: HSP27 expression also correlated inversely with nuclear p53 accumulation, indicating either protein interactions between HSP27 and p53 or TP53 mutation-dependent HSP27-regulation in pancreatic cancer.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: In the sensitivity studies, HSP27 overexpression rendered HSP27 low-expressing PL5 pancreatic cancer cells more susceptible towards treatment with gemcitabine.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Vice versa, HSP27 protein depletion in HSP27 high-expressing AsPC-1 cells caused increased gemcitabine resistance.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Importantly, HSP27 expression was inducible in pancreatic cancer cell lines as well as primary cells.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Taken together, our study suggests a role for HSP27 as a prognostic and predictive marker in pancreatic cancer.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Assessment of HSP27 expression could thus facilitate the identification of specific patient subpopulations that might benefit from individualized treatment options.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: Additional studies need to clarify whether modulation of HSP27 expression could represent an attractive concept to support the incorporation of hyperthermia in clinical treatment protocols for pancreatic cancer.
title: Heat shock protein 27 as a prognostic and predictive biomarker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

text: PURPOSE: Most gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) express constitutively activated mutant isoforms of KIT or kinase platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFRA) that are potential therapeutic targets for imatinib mesylate.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: The relationship between mutations in these kinases and clinical response to imatinib was examined in a group of patients with advanced GIST.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: GISTs from 127 patients enrolled onto a phase II clinical study of imatinib were examined for mutations of KIT or PDGFRA.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Mutation types were correlated with clinical outcome.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: RESULTS: Activating mutations of KIT or PDGFRA were found in 112 (88.2%) and six (4.7%) GISTs, respectively.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Most KIT mutations involved exon 9 (n = 23) or exon 11 (n = 85).
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: All KIT mutant isoforms, but only a subset of PDGFRA mutant isoforms, were sensitive to imatinib, in vitro.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: In patients with GISTs harboring exon 11 KIT mutations, the partial response rate (PR) was 83.5%, whereas patients with tumors containing an exon 9 KIT mutation or no detectable mutation of KIT or PDGFRA had PR rates of 47.8% (P =.0006) and 0.0% (P <.0001), respectively.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: Patients whose tumors contained exon 11 KIT mutations had a longer event-free and overall survival than those whose tumors expressed either exon 9 KIT mutations or had no detectable kinase mutation.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: CONCLUSION: Activating mutations of KIT or PDGFRA are found in the vast majority of GISTs, and the mutational status of these oncoproteins is predictive of clinical response to imatinib.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: PDGFRA mutations can explain response and sensitivity to imatinib in some GISTs lacking KIT mutations.
title: Kinase mutations and imatinib response in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

text: PURPOSE: To analyze the baseline clinicopathologic characteristics of prostate tumors with germline BRCA1 and BRCA2 (BRCA1/2) mutations and the prognostic value of those mutations on prostate cancer (PCa) outcomes.
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: This study analyzed the tumor features and outcomes of 2,019 patients with PCa (18 BRCA1 carriers, 61 BRCA2 carriers, and 1,940 noncarriers).
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: The Kaplan-Meier method and Cox regression analysis were used to evaluate the associations between BRCA1/2 status and other PCa prognostic factors with overall survival (OS), cause-specific OS (CSS), CSS in localized PCa (CSS_M0), metastasis-free survival (MFS), and CSS from metastasis (CSS_M1).
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: RESULTS: PCa with germline BRCA1/2 mutations were more frequently associated with Gleason >/= 8 (P = .00003), T3/T4 stage (P = .003), nodal involvement (P = .00005), and metastases at diagnosis (P = .005) than PCa in noncarriers.
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: CSS was significantly longer in noncarriers than in carriers (15.7 v 8.6 years, multivariable analyses [MVA] P = .015; hazard ratio [HR] = 1.8).
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: For localized PCa, 5-year CSS and MFS were significantly higher in noncarriers (96% v 82%; MVA P = .01; HR = 2.6%; and 93% v 77%; MVA P = .009; HR = 2.7, respectively).
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: Subgroup analyses confirmed the poor outcomes in BRCA2 patients, whereas the role of BRCA1 was not well defined due to the limited size and follow-up in this subgroup.
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Our results confirm that BRCA1/2 mutations confer a more aggressive PCa phenotype with a higher probability of nodal involvement and distant metastasis.
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: BRCA mutations are associated with poor survival outcomes and this should be considered for tailoring clinical management of these patients.
title: Germline BRCA mutations are associated with higher risk of nodal involvement, distant metastasis, and poor survival outcomes in prostate cancer.

text: In multiple myeloma, there has been little progress in the specific therapeutic targeting of oncogenic mutations.
title: Targeting the BRAF V600E mutation in multiple myeloma.

text: Whole-genome sequencing data have recently revealed that a subset of patients carry an activating mutation (V600E) in the BRAF kinase.
title: Targeting the BRAF V600E mutation in multiple myeloma.

text: To uncover the clinical relevance of this mutation in multiple myeloma, we correlated the mutation status in primary tumor samples from 379 patients with myeloma with disease outcome.
title: Targeting the BRAF V600E mutation in multiple myeloma.

text: We found a significantly higher incidence of extramedullary disease and a shorter overall survival in mutation carriers when compared with controls.
title: Targeting the BRAF V600E mutation in multiple myeloma.

text: Most importantly, we report on a patient with confirmed BRAF V600E mutation and relapsed myeloma with extensive extramedullary disease, refractory to all approved therapeutic options, who has rapidly and durably responded to low doses of the mutation-specific BRAF inhibitor vermurafenib.
title: Targeting the BRAF V600E mutation in multiple myeloma.

text: Collectively, we provide evidence for the development of the BRAF V600E mutation in the context of clonal evolution and describe the prognostic and therapeutic relevance of this targetable mutation.
title: Targeting the BRAF V600E mutation in multiple myeloma.

text: Mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1) and isocitrate dehydrogenase 2 (IDH2) occur in most grade 2 and 3 gliomas, secondary glioblastomas, and a subset of acute myelogenous leukemias but have not been detected in other tumor types.
title: IDH2 mutations are frequent in angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: The mutations occur at specific arginine residues and result in the acquisition of a novel enzymatic activity that converts 2-oxoglutarate to D-2-hydroxyglutarate.
title: IDH2 mutations are frequent in angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: This study reports IDH1 and IDH2 genotyping results from a set of lymphomas, which included a large set of peripheral T-cell lymphomas.
title: IDH2 mutations are frequent in angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: IDH2 mutations were identified in approximately 20% of angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphomas (AITLs), but not in other peripheral T-cell lymphoma entities.
title: IDH2 mutations are frequent in angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: These results were confirmed in an independent set of AITL patients, where the IDH2 mutation rate was approximately 45%.
title: IDH2 mutations are frequent in angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: This is the second common genetic lesion identified in AITL after TET2 and extends the number of neoplastic diseases where IDH1 and IDH2 mutations may play a role.
title: IDH2 mutations are frequent in angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma.

text: BACKGROUND: The presence of EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor) mutations is a robust predictor of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) responsiveness.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Predictors of EGFR-TKI responsiveness in EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients, however, have not been well investigated.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The purpose of this study is to examine predictors of EGFR-TKI responsiveness in EGFR-mutant NSCLC patients.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: Seventy EGFR-mutant NSCLC patients who received EGFR-TKIs in our institution between April 2007 and March 2013 were analyzed retrospectively.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: RESULTS: The objective response rate was 50.0% (95% confidence interval, CI, 38.6-61.4%) and the disease control rate was 91.4% (95% CI, 82.5-96.0%).
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: The median progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival were 9.0 (95% CI, 3.92-14.08) and 20.8 months (95% CI, 14.56-27.04), respectively.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: In multivariate analysis, adenocarcinoma (hazard ratio, HR, 12.25; 95% CI, 37.7-41.10; p < 0.001) and major mutations (deletions in exon 19 and L858R point mutation in exon 21; HR, 2.46; 95% CI, 1.14-5.28; p = 0.022) were significant predictors of longer PFS.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: CONCLUSION: Major mutations and adenocarcinoma histology were independent predictors of better treatment outcome in EGFR-mutant NSCLC patients who received EGFR-TKIs.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: Further well-controlled prospective studies are warranted to confirm our findings.
title: Clinical predictors of response to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer.

text: KRAS mutations are major factors involved in initiation and maintenance of pancreatic tumors.
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: The impact of different mutations on patient survival has not been clearly defined.
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: We screened tumors from 171 pancreatic cancer patients for mutations in KRAS and CDKN2A genes.
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: Mutations in KRAS were detected in 134 tumors, with 131 in codon 12 and only 3 in codon 61.
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: The GGT>GAT (G12D) was the most frequent mutation and was present in 60% (80/134).
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: Deletions and mutations in CDKN2A were detected in 43 tumors.
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: Analysis showed that KRAS mutations were associated with reduced patient survival in both malignant exocrine and ductal adenocarcinomas (PDAC).
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: Patients with PDACs that had KRAS mutations showed a median survival of 17 months compared to 30 months for those without mutations (log-rank P = 0.07) with a multivariate hazard ratio (HR) of 2.19 (95%CI 1.09-4.42).
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: The patients with G12D mutation showed a median survival of 16 months (log-rank-test P = 0.03) and an associated multivariate HR 2.42 (95%CI 1.14-2.67).
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: Although, the association of survival in PDAC patients with CDKN2A aberrations in tumors was not statistically significant, the sub-group of patients with concomitant KRAS mutations and CDKN2A alterations in tumors were associated with a median survival of 13.5 months compared to 22 months without mutation (log-rank-test P = 0.02) and a corresponding HR of 3.07 (95%CI 1.33-7.10).
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: Our results are indicative of an association between mutational status and survival in PDAC patients, which if confirmed in subsequent studies can have potential clinical application.
title: Somatic mutations in exocrine pancreatic tumors: association with patient survival.

text: The recent findings brought the necessity of testing the mutational status of a series of genes which had been already identified as responsible for melanomas development and progression, such as BRAF, CKIT and PTEN: the consequent results are, in fact, essential to guide the assessment of the novel treatment protocols based on tailored targeted therapies.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: We present here the case of a 66 year-old male patient, diagnosed with an advanced melanoma in June 2011, and treated with Dabrafenib for double mutant metastatic disease.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: The patient was referred to our attention for a large exophytic malignant melanoma on the left shoulder.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: After complete surgical excision and elective lymph node dissection for presence of metastatic sentinel lymph node, the patient has started high-dose interferon alfa-2b injections as adjuvant therapy for a complete negative staging.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: The treatment was interrupted in August 2011 due to the appearance of metastatic lymph nodes.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: Tumor burden was rapidly growing reaching in few months the size of a tennis ball for the tumor mass located in the shoulder.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: Mutational study of the tumor revealed a double BRAF mutation on V-600E and V600M.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: This finding incited us to enroll the patient in compassionate Dabrafenib clinical trial.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: The therapy was started on may 2012 at 150 mg bid dosage.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: Almost surprisingly for the rapidity of the effect, one week later the lesion on the shoulder has reduced its size by 60% and one month later it has completely disappeared from sight.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: CT scan of June 2012 documented the astonishing clinical response.
title: Overwhelming response to Dabrafenib in a patient with double BRAF mutation (V600E; V600M) metastatic malignant melanoma.

text: Antioestrogen treatment by tamoxifen is a well-established adjuvant therapy for oestrogen receptor-alpha (ERalpha) positive breast cancer.
title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: Despite ERalpha expression some tumours do not respond to tamoxifen and we therefore delineated the potential link between the cell cycle regulator and ERalpha co-factor, cyclin D1, and tamoxifen response in a material of 167 postmenopausal breast cancers arranged in a tissue array.
