title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: The patients had been randomised to 2 years of tamoxifen treatment or no treatment and the median follow-up time was 18 years.
title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: Interestingly in the 55 strongly ERalpha positive samples with moderate or low cyclin D1 levels, patients responded to tamoxifen treatment whereas the 46 patients with highly ERalpha positive and cyclin D1 overexpressing tumours did not show any difference in survival between tamoxifen and no treatment.
title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: Survival in untreated patients with cyclin D1 high tumours was slightly better than for patients with cyclin D1 low/moderate tumours.
title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: However, there was a clearly increased risk of death in the cyclin D1 high group compared to an age-matched control population.
title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: Our results suggest that cyclin D1 overexpression predicts for tamoxifen treatment resistance in breast cancer, which is line with recent experimental data using breast cancer cell lines and overexpression systems.
title: Cyclin D1 overexpression is a negative predictive factor for tamoxifen response in postmenopausal breast cancer patients.

text: CEBPA mutations have been associated with improved outcome in adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: We evaluated the prevalence and prognostic significance of CEBPA mutations in 847 children with AML treated on 3 consecutive pediatric trials.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: Two types of CEBPA mutations-N-terminal truncating mutations and in-frame bZip-domain mutations-were detected in 38 (4.5%) of 847 patients tested; 31 (82%) of 38 patients with mutations harbored both mutation types.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: Mutation status was correlated with laboratory and clinical characteristics and clinical outcome.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: CEBPA mutations were significantly more common in older patients, patients with FAB M1 or M2, and patients with normal karyotype.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: Mutations did not occur in patients with either favorable or unfavorable cytogenetics.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: Actuarial event-free survival at 5 years was 70% versus 38% (P = .015) with a cumulative incidence of relapse from complete remission of 13% versus 44% (P = .007) for those with and without CEBPA mutations.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: The presence of CEBPA mutations was an independent prognostic factor for improved outcome (HR = 0.24, P = .047).
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: As CEBPA mutations are associated with lower relapse rate and improved survival, CEBPA mutation analysis needs to be incorporated into initial screening for risk identification and therapy allocation at diagnosis.
title: Prevalence and prognostic implications of CEBPA mutations in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML): a report from the Children's Oncology Group.

text: Mutations of the nucleophosmin (NPM1) gene have recently been described in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: To clarify the prevalence as well as the clinical impact of this mutation, we investigated 1485 patients with AML for NPM1 exon 12 mutations using fragment analysis.
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: A 4 bp insert was detected in 408 of 1485 patients (27.5%).
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: Sequence analysis revealed known mutations (type A, B, and D) as well as 13 novel alterations in 229 analyzed cases.
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: NPM1 mutations were most prevalent in patients with normal karyotype (NK) (324 of 709; 45.7%) compared with 58 of 686 with karyotype abnormalities (8.5%; P < .001) and were significantly associated with several clinical parameters (high bone marrow [BM] blasts, high white blood cell [WBC] and platelet counts, female sex).
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: NPM1 alterations were associated with FLT3-ITD mutations, even if restricted to patients with NK (NPM1-mut/FLT3-ITD: 43.8%; versus NPM1-wt/FLT3-ITD: 19.9%; P < .001).
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: The analysis of the clinical impact in 4 groups (NPM1 and FLT3-ITD single mutants, double mutants, and wild-type [wt] for both) revealed that patients having only an NPM1 mutation had a significantly better overall and disease-free survival and a lower cumulative incidence of relapse.
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: In conclusion, NPM1 mutations represent a common genetic abnormality in adult AML.
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: If not associated with FLT3-ITD mutations, mutant NPM1 appears to identify patients with improved response toward treatment.
title: Prevalence and prognostic impact of NPM1 mutations in 1485 adult patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

text: PURPOSE: More than 90% of Ewing's sarcomas (ES) contain a fusion of the EWS and FLI1 genes, due to the t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: At the molecular level, the EWS-FLI1 rearrangements show great diversity.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Specifically, many different combinations of exons from EWS and FLI1 encode in-frame fusion transcripts and result in differences in the length and composition of the chimeric protein, which functions as an oncogenic aberrant transcription factor.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: In the most common fusion type (type 1), EWS exon 7 is linked in frame with exon 6 of FLI1.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: As the fundamental pathogenetic lesion in ES, the molecular heterogeneity of these fusion transcripts may have functional and clinical significance.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: PATIENTS AND METHODS: We performed a clinical and pathologic analysis of 112 patients with ES in which EWS-FLI1 fusion transcripts were identified by reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Adequate treatment and follow-up data were available in 99 patients treated with curative intent.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Median follow-up in these 99 patients was 26 months (range, 1 to 140 months).
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Univariate and multivariate survival analyses were performed that included other prognostic factors, such as age, tumor location, size, and stage.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: RESULTS: Among the 99 patients suitable for survival analysis, the tumors in 64 patients contained the type 1 fusion and in 35 patients contained less common fusion types.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Stage at presentation was localized in 74 patients and metastatic in 25.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Metastases (relative risk [RR] = 2.6; P = .008), and type 1 EWS-FLI1 fusion (RR = 0.37; P = .014) were, respectively, independent negative and positive prognostic factors for overall survival by multivariate analysis.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Among 74 patients with localized tumors, the type 1 EWS-FLI1 fusion was also a significant positive predictor of overall survival (RR = 0.32; P = .034) by multivariate analysis.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: CONCLUSION: EWS-FLI1 fusion type appears to be prognostically relevant in ES, independent of tumor site, stage, and size.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: Further studies are needed to clarify the biologic basis of this phenomenon.
title: EWS-FLI1 fusion transcript structure is an independent determinant of prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

text: PURPOSE: Two recent phase III trials, BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3 (Breast Cancer Trials of Oral Everolimus), evaluated the addition of everolimus to trastuzumab and chemotherapy in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-overexpressing advanced breast cancer.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: The current analysis aimed to identify biomarkers to predict the clinical efficacy of everolimus treatment.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: METHODS: Archival tumor samples from patients in BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3 were analyzed using next-generation sequencing, immunohistochemistry, and Sanger sequencing.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: RESULTS: Biomarker data were available for 549 patients.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: PIK3CA activating mutations and PTEN loss were reported in 30% and 16% of BOLERO-1 samples and in 32% and 12% of BOLERO-3 samples, respectively.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: PI3K pathway was hyperactive (PIK3CA mutations and/or PTEN loss and/or AKT1 mutation) in 47% of BOLERO-1 and 41% of BOLERO-3 samples.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: In both studies, differential progression-free survival (PFS) benefits of everolimus were consistently observed in patient subgroups defined by their PI3K pathway status.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: When analyzing combined data sets of both studies, everolimus was associated with a decreased hazard of progression in patients with PIK3CA mutations (hazard ratio [HR], 0.67; 95% CI, 0.45 to 1.00), PTEN loss (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.31 to 0.96), or hyperactive PI3K pathway (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.48 to 0.93).
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: Patients with wild-type PIK3CA (HR, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.83 to 1.46), normal PTEN (HR, 1.00; 95% CI, 0.80 to 1.26), or normal PI3K pathway activity (HR, 1.19; 95% CI, 0.87 to 1.62) did not derive PFS benefit from everolimus.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: CONCLUSION: This analysis, although exploratory, suggests that patients with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive advanced breast cancer having tumors with PIK3CA mutations, PTEN loss, or hyperactive PI3K pathway could derive PFS benefit from everolimus.
title: Molecular Alterations and Everolimus Efficacy in Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2-Overexpressing Metastatic Breast Cancers: Combined Exploratory Biomarker Analysis From BOLERO-1 and BOLERO-3.

text: BACKGROUND: In patients with melanoma, ipilimumab (an antibody against cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated antigen 4 [CTLA-4]) prolongs overall survival, and nivolumab (an antibody against the programmed death 1 [PD-1] receptor) produced durable tumor regression in a phase 1 trial.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: On the basis of their distinct immunologic mechanisms of action and supportive preclinical data, we conducted a phase 1 trial of nivolumab combined with ipilimumab in patients with advanced melanoma.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: METHODS: We administered intravenous doses of nivolumab and ipilimumab in patients every 3 weeks for 4 doses, followed by nivolumab alone every 3 weeks for 4 doses (concurrent regimen).
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: The combined treatment was subsequently administered every 12 weeks for up to 8 doses.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: In a sequenced regimen, patients previously treated with ipilimumab received nivolumab every 2 weeks for up to 48 doses.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: RESULTS: A total of 53 patients received concurrent therapy with nivolumab and ipilimumab, and 33 received sequenced treatment.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: The objective-response rate (according to modified World Health Organization criteria) for all patients in the concurrent-regimen group was 40%.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: Evidence of clinical activity (conventional, unconfirmed, or immune-related response or stable disease for >/=24 weeks) was observed in 65% of patients.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: At the maximum doses that were associated with an acceptable level of adverse events (nivolumab at a dose of 1 mg per kilogram of body weight and ipilimumab at a dose of 3 mg per kilogram), 53% of patients had an objective response, all with tumor reduction of 80% or more.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: Grade 3 or 4 adverse events related to therapy occurred in 53% of patients in the concurrent-regimen group but were qualitatively similar to previous experience with monotherapy and were generally reversible.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: Among patients in the sequenced-regimen group, 18% had grade 3 or 4 adverse events related to therapy and the objective-response rate was 20%.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: CONCLUSIONS: Concurrent therapy with nivolumab and ipilimumab had a manageable safety profile and provided clinical activity that appears to be distinct from that in published data on monotherapy, with rapid and deep tumor regression in a substantial proportion of patients.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: (Funded by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Ono Pharmaceutical; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01024231.
title: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.
Nivolumab plus ipilimumab in advanced melanoma.

text: BACKGROUND: We previously found that dual HER2 blockade with trastuzumab and lapatinib led to inhibition of tumour growth in patient-derived xenografts of HER2-amplified metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: In this study, we aimed to assess the antitumour activity of trastuzumab and lapatinib in patients with HER2-positive colorectal cancer.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: METHODS: HERACLES was a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial done at four Italian academic cancer centres.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: We enrolled adult patients with KRAS exon 2 (codons 12 and 13) wild-type and HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer refractory to standard of care (including cetuximab or panitumumab), an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0 or 1, and at least one measurable lesion.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: We defined HER2 positivity in tumour samples by use of immunohistochemistry and fluorescence in-situ hybridisation in accordance with our previously validated colorectal cancer-specific diagnostic criteria.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Eligible patients received intravenous trastuzumab at 4 mg/kg loading dose followed by 2 mg/kg once per week, and oral lapatinib at 1000 mg per day until evidence of disease progression.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients achieving an objective response (defined as complete response or partial response), which was assessed by independent central review in the intention-to-treat population.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: This trial is registered with EudraCT, number 2012-002128-33.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: FINDINGS: Between Aug 27, 2012, and May 15, 2015, we screened 914 patients with KRAS exon 2 (codons 12 and 13) wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer and identified 48 (5%) patients with HER2-positive tumours, although two died before enrolment.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Of these patients, 27 were eligible for the trial.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: All were evaluable for response.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: At the time of data cutoff on Oct 15, 2015, with a median follow-up of 94 weeks (IQR 51-127), eight (30%, 95% CI 14-50) of 27 patients had achieved an objective response, with one patient (4%, 95% CI -3 to 11) achieving a complete response, and seven (26%, 95% CI 9-43) achieving partial responses; 12 (44%, 95% CI 25-63) patients had stable disease.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: Six (22%) of 27 patients had grade 3 adverse events, which consisted of fatigue in four patients, skin rash in one patient, and increased bilirubin concentration in one patient.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: No grade 4 or 5 adverse events were reported.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: We detected no drug-related serious adverse events.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: The combination of trastuzumab and lapatinib is active and well tolerated in treatment-refractory patients with HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: Dual-targeted therapy with trastuzumab and lapatinib in treatment-refractory, KRAS codon 12/13 wild-type, HER2-positive metastatic colorectal cancer (HERACLES): a proof-of-concept, multicentre, open-label, phase 2 trial.

text: BACKGROUND: Outcomes are poor for patients with previously treated, advanced or metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: The anti-programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) antibody atezolizumab is clinically active against cancer, including NSCLC, especially cancers expressing PD-L1 on tumour cells, tumour-infiltrating immune cells, or both.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: We assessed efficacy and safety of atezolizumab versus docetaxel in previously treated NSCLC, analysed by PD-L1 expression levels on tumour cells and tumour-infiltrating immune cells and in the intention-to-treat population.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: METHODS: In this open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial, patients with NSCLC who progressed on post-platinum chemotherapy were recruited in 61 academic medical centres and community oncology practices across 13 countries in Europe and North America.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Key inclusion criteria were Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status 0 or 1, measurable disease by Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST v1.1), and adequate haematological and end-organ function.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Patients were stratified by PD-L1 tumour-infiltrating immune cell status, histology, and previous lines of therapy, and randomly assigned (1:1) by permuted block randomisation (with a block size of four) using an interactive voice or web system to receive intravenous atezolizumab 1200 mg or docetaxel 75 mg/m(2) once every 3 weeks.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Baseline PD-L1 expression was scored by immunohistochemistry in tumour cells (as percentage of PD-L1-expressing tumour cells TC3>/=50%, TC2>/=5% and <50%, TC1>/=1% and <5%, and TC0<1%) and tumour-infiltrating immune cells (as percentage of tumour area: IC3>/=10%, IC2>/=5% and <10%, IC1>/=1% and <5%, and IC0<1%).
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: The primary endpoint was overall survival in the intention-to-treat population and PD-L1 subgroups at 173 deaths.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Biomarkers were assessed in an exploratory analysis.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: We assessed safety in all patients who received at least one dose of study drug.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01903993.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: FINDINGS: Patients were enrolled between Aug 5, 2013, and March 31, 2014.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: 144 patients were randomly allocated to the atezolizumab group, and 143 to the docetaxel group.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: 142 patients received at least one dose of atezolizumab and 135 received docetaxel.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Overall survival in the intention-to-treat population was 12.6 months (95% CI 9.7-16.4) for atezolizumab versus 9.7 months (8.6-12.0) for docetaxel (hazard ratio [HR] 0.73 [95% CI 0.53-0.99]; p=0.04).
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Increasing improvement in overall survival was associated with increasing PD-L1 expression (TC3 or IC3 HR 0.49 [0.22-1.07; p=0.068], TC2/3 or IC2/3 HR 0.54 [0.33-0.89; p=0.014], TC1/2/3 or IC1/2/3 HR 0.59 [0.40-0.85; p=0.005], TC0 and IC0 HR 1.04 [0.62-1.75; p=0.871]).
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: In our exploratory analysis, patients with pre-existing immunity, defined by high T-effector-interferon-gamma-associated gene expression, had improved overall survival with atezolizumab.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: 11 (8%) patients in the atezolizumab group discontinued because of adverse events versus 30 (22%) patients in the docetaxel group.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: 16 (11%) patients in the atezolizumab group versus 52 (39%) patients in the docetaxel group had treatment-related grade 3-4 adverse events, and one (<1%) patient in the atezolizumab group versus three (2%) patients in the docetaxel group died from a treatment-related adverse event.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: INTERPRETATION: Atezolizumab significantly improved survival compared with docetaxel in patients with previously treated NSCLC.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Improvement correlated with PD-L1 immunohistochemistry expression on tumour cells and tumour-infiltrating immune cells, suggesting that PD-L1 expression is predictive for atezolizumab benefit.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: Atezolizumab was well tolerated, with a safety profile distinct from chemotherapy.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: FUNDING: F Hoffmann-La Roche/Genentech Inc.
title: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial.

text: UNLABELLED: FGFR1 and FGFR2 are amplified in many tumor types, yet what determines response to FGFR inhibition in amplified cancers is unknown.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: In a translational clinical trial, we show that gastric cancers with high-level clonal FGFR2 amplification have a high response rate to the selective FGFR inhibitor AZD4547, whereas cancers with subclonal or low-level amplification did not respond.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: Using cell lines and patient-derived xenograft models, we show that high-level FGFR2 amplification initiates a distinct oncogene addiction phenotype, characterized by FGFR2-mediated transactivation of alternative receptor kinases, bringing PI3K/mTOR signaling under FGFR control.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: Signaling in low-level FGFR1-amplified cancers is more restricted to MAPK signaling, limiting sensitivity to FGFR inhibition.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: Finally, we show that circulating tumor DNA screening can identify high-level clonally amplified cancers.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: Our data provide a mechanistic understanding of the distinct pattern of oncogene addiction seen in highly amplified cancers and demonstrate the importance of clonality in predicting response to targeted therapy.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: SIGNIFICANCE: Robust single-agent response to FGFR inhibition is seen only in high-level FGFR-amplified cancers, with copy-number level dictating response to FGFR inhibition in vitro, in vivo, and in the clinic.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: High-level amplification of FGFR2 is relatively rare in gastric and breast cancers, and we show that screening for amplification in circulating tumor DNA may present a viable strategy to screen patients.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: Cancer Discov; 6(8); 838-51.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: (c)2016 AACR.This article is highlighted in the In This Issue feature, p. 803.
title: High-Level Clonal FGFR Amplification and Response to FGFR Inhibition in a Translational Clinical Trial.

text: The discovery of mutant KRAS as a predictor of resistance to epidermal growth-factor receptor (EGFR) monoclonal antibodies brought a major change in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.
title: KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and PTEN mutations: implications for targeted therapies in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: This seminal finding also highlighted our sparse knowledge about key signalling pathways in colorectal tumours.
title: KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and PTEN mutations: implications for targeted therapies in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: Drugs that inhibit oncogenic alterations such as phospho-MAP2K (also called MEK), phospho-AKT, and mutant B-RAF seem promising as single treatment or when given with EGFR inhibitors.
title: KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and PTEN mutations: implications for targeted therapies in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: However, our understanding of the precise role these potential drug targets have in colorectal tumours, and the oncogenic dependence that tumours might have on these components, has not progressed at the same rate.
title: KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and PTEN mutations: implications for targeted therapies in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: As a result, patient selection and prediction of treatment effects remain problematic.
title: KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and PTEN mutations: implications for targeted therapies in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: We review the role of mutations in genes other than KRAS on the efficacy of anti-EGFR therapy, and discuss strategies to target these oncogenic alterations alone or in combination with receptor tyrosine-kinase inhibition.
title: KRAS, BRAF, PIK3CA, and PTEN mutations: implications for targeted therapies in metastatic colorectal cancer.

text: AIM: The treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer has changed after the development of the immune checkpoint inhibitors.
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: Although the most studied biomarker is PD-L1 expression, its clinical significance is still debatable.
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: In this article, we show the updated survival analysis of all published data.
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: METHODS: We searched in network and conference data sources for relevant clinical studies of immunotherapy for non-small-cell lung cancer that assessed the PD-L1 expression even as an exploratory analysis.
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: The updated survival hazard ratios (HR) were included in the analysis.
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: RESULTS: 14 studies with 2857 patients were included (2019 treated with immunotherapy).
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: The response rate was as higher among PD-L1-positive patients (RR: 2.19, 95% CI: 1.63-2.94).
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: PD-L1 expression was also related to better progression-free survival (HR: 0.69, 95% CI: 0.57-0.85) and better overall survival (HR: 0.77, 95% CI: 0.67-0.89).
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: CONCLUSION: PD-L1 overexpression predicts activity as well as better survival for patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors.
title: PD-L1 expression as a predictive biomarker in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: updated survival data.

text: PURPOSE: To review the evidence implicating the deregulation of cyclin D1 in the pathogenesis of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), and to discuss the opportunities for targeted clinical intervention.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: METHODS: Data published until June 2006 are summarized, and previously unpublished results from our own research are included.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: RESULTS: In normal cells, cyclin D1 complexes with and activates cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) and acts as a transcriptional regulator.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: The protein is frequently overexpressed in a wide range of cancers, sometimes coincident with CCND1 (cyclin D1) gene amplification (5-20% of tumours).
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: A low level of somatic mutations have been seen in certain tumours.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: CCND1 is amplified in NSCLC and cyclin D1 is frequently overexpressed in tumours and pre-invasive bronchial lesions, generally from one parental allele.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: Mutation analyses revealed a frequent CCND1 gene polymorphism (A870G) that modulates alternative splicing and allows expression of an alternative cyclin D1 transcript (transcript cyclin D1b).
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: The encoded cyclin D1b protein lacks a specific phosphorylation site required for nuclear export.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: Genotype has been correlated with the risk and/or severity of disease or drug response across a range of malignancies, including lung cancer.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: Together, these findings suggest a strong pathological role for cyclin D1 deregulation in bronchial neoplasia.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: CONCLUSION: Current data indicate that cyclin D1 overexpression is not a consequence of, but rather a pivotal element in the process of malignant transformation in the lung and other tissues.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.

text: This understanding may open new avenues for lung cancer diagnosis, treatment and prevention.
title: Cyclin D1 in non-small cell lung cancer: a key driver of malignant transformation.
